site_title: Japan debates fresh cash payouts to help the poor cope with pandemic: sources
summary: Japan is considering fresh cash payouts to low-income households to help them cope with the pandemic's economic impact. The potential payouts, which have not been finalized, aim to support households struggling with job losses and suicides. The previous 100,000 yen cash payout package cost 12.9 trillion yen, and discussions come after ruling party lawmakers called for similar support. Finance Minister Taro Aso has resisted new spending, citing the need to enact the budget and tap emergency reserves, amid concerns about Japan's heavy public debt burden.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 1.53% at 29,408.81, following a mixed close on Wall Street. The retreat in US bond yields contributed to the mixed US market, which saw the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edge to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.60 points, or 0.04%, to 1,577.15. Volume was 423.17 million lots worth RM210.87 million. Gainers beat losers 337 to 189.

site_title: Asia: Markets stage rebound after last week's rout
summary: Asia's stock markets rebounded on Monday, with Tokyo rising over 2% and Hong Kong and Sydney gaining over 1%. The rebound came after last week's heavy selling, partly due to a drop in US Treasury yields and the passage of Joe Biden's stimulus package. However, concerns about inflation and interest rate hikes remain, with analysts warning that the expected global economic recovery could fuel inflation and force earlier rate hikes.

site_title: Airline stocks are soaring, but there's still a long way back
summary: Airline stocks have surged 15% in the past month, but still lag 17% behind their 2020 peak due to ongoing pandemic-related losses. Leisure travel is expected to rebound sharply, but business trips and intercontinental flights may take longer to recover. Analysts predict only two European airlines, Ryanair and Wizz Air, will see positive share-price performance over the next year, with declines expected for major carriers like Deutsche Lufthansa and Air France-KLM. Vaccine passports and travel restrictions remain key factors in the sector's recovery.

site_title: South Korea's Feb exports extend growth on strong chip, auto demand
summary: South Korea's exports expanded for the fourth consecutive month in February, growing 9.5% year-over-year to $44.81 billion, driven by strong demand for memory chips and cars. Shipments of semiconductors and cars surged 13.2% and 47% respectively, while petrochemicals and bio-health products increased 22.4% and 62.5%. The trade surplus narrowed to $2.71 billion, beating forecasts. This growth underpins the trade-led recovery in Asia's fourth-largest economy, with exports also rising 26.4% year-over-year when excluding the impact of Lunar New Year holidays.

site_title: CapitaLand and CDL's earnings may rebound in 2021, but will that lift their share prices?
summary: Singaporean property development groups CapitaLand and City Developments (CDL) reported dismal FY2020 results, with CapitaLand suffering a net loss of S$1.574m and CDL reporting a pre-tax loss of S$1.7908m. Both companies emphasized their focus on future growth potential and plans to pivot towards "new economy" assets, such as business parks and logistics centers. Despite this, CDL's exposure to its China-based unit Sincere Property Group (SPG) remains a concern, and the company's NAV fell to S$9.38 per share. CDL's RNAV would be S$16.88 per share if fair-value gains were factored in, making its shares a 56% discount to its RNAV.

site_title: Dozens of Hong Kong dissidents charged with security crime
summary: Dozens of Hong Kong dissidents, including prominent pro-democracy campaigners, were charged with subversion on Sunday under Beijing's national security law. 47 of the 55 arrested individuals were formally charged, facing up to life in prison if convicted. Critics describe the move as a body blow to Hong Kong's democracy movement, with the European Union and Britain expressing "great concern" and "deeply disturbing" charges. The charges are seen as a crackdown on opposition politics, with critics accusing Beijing of eroding freedoms promised under the "One Country, Two Systems" setup.

site_title: US retailers see millions in sales delays with shipping logjam
summary: US retailers are experiencing significant delays in shipping due to overwhelmed ports, elevated freight costs, and accidents that have resulted in lost goods. The issues are affecting companies across various industries, including appliance makers, shoe brands, and fitness equipment manufacturers. Despite efforts to mitigate the problems, economists predict that supply chain disruptions will continue for the foreseeable future, posing a threat to inventories if the issues persist.

site_title: DBS appoints Raof Latiff as new Malaysia country head
summary: DBS Bank has appointed Raof Latiff as the new Malaysia country head, replacing Jeffrey Ling who will retire from the role on June 1, 2021. Latiff, who joined DBS in 2017, will oversee the bank's institutional banking ecosystems and strategic platform partnerships. Lim Soon Chong will succeed Latiff and will be responsible for digital, cash, and trade product agendas of DBS's institutional banking group. The move aims to groom talent from within and provide development opportunities to senior team members.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.20% on Monday, following a sharp sell-off last week, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 29,326.61. Asia-wide markets rebounded, with the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increasing. This rebound is attributed to an Asia-wide trend.

site_title: Debt engineers tackle climate change with bonds to rewild land
summary: Activists are pushing for "nature bonds" - securities that explicitly protect the natural world - as governments and companies focus on green finance to combat climate change. The idea involves countries issuing debt to rewild land, with investors earning interest and supplementing it with carbon credits or species restoration credits. This concept is gaining traction, with Pakistan and Uruguay exploring such bonds, and could be a step towards meeting biodiversity and climate change targets.

site_title: Logitech warns on FY2022 outlook after pandemic-boosted FY2021
summary: Logitech International has warned that operating income for fiscal 2022 will drop to between $750 million and $800 million, down from a 2021 boom driven by pandemic-driven demand for work-from-home products. The company expects sales for fiscal 2022 to be flat, plus or minus 5%, and has raised its long-term sales growth forecast to 8-10% in constant currency. This marks a decrease from the company's previous estimate of a 63% sales growth forecast for fiscal 2021.

site_title: Myanmar crackdown leaves at least 9 dead in violent weekend
summary: At least nine people have died in Myanmar's military crackdown on protests over the weekend, with four killed in Dawei and three in Yangon. The country's permanent representative to the UN, Kyaw Moe Tun, was fired after criticizing the coup and defending deposed leader Aung San Suu Kyi. Riot police arrested hundreds of demonstrators and five journalists for reporting on anti-coup protests, and the US has announced sanctions targeting the country's military leaders. The international community has condemned the violence, with Human Rights Watch calling for the use of lethal force to be halted.

site_title: AMMB to pay Malaysian government RM2.83b in 1MDB-linked settlement
summary: AMMB Holdings, the Malaysian lender linked to former Prime Minister Najib Razak's bank accounts, has agreed to pay RM2.83 billion (S$930 million) in a settlement related to 1MDB transactions. The payment resolves the lender's involvement in the scandal, which drew international attention. The settlement is seen as a significant development in the ongoing 1MDB saga, although the full details of the agreement remain unclear.

site_title: Spurring sustainable mobility
summary: Singapore should aim to achieve a balance between electric vehicles and a car-lite culture as part of its strategy to tackle climate change and air pollution. Experts agree that a holistic approach, including investments in public transport, digital mobility-as-a-service, and car-sharing schemes, is necessary. While electric vehicles can help reduce emissions, the government must also address the issue of power generation and battery manufacturing. Encouraging a shift to green energy, improving public transport, and promoting a sharing economy can also contribute to a sustainable future for Singapore.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB downgrades First Resources to 'neutral'; target prices cut
summary: RHB downgraded its call on Indonesian palm oil producer First Resources to "neutral" and lowered its target price to S$1.60 from S$1.90, citing the company's aggressive forward sales as a potential detriment to earnings. The downgrade follows First Resources' FY2020 results, which were in line with expectations but showed "disappointing" average selling prices. Other brokerages, UOB Kay Hian and Maybank Kim Eng, maintained their "buy" calls but reduced target prices.

site_title: Biden backs Amazon workers' right to unionise
summary: US President Joe Biden has backed Amazon workers' right to unionize, stating that every worker should have a free and fair choice to join a union. The move comes as Amazon warehouse workers in Alabama vote on forming the first American union at the e-commerce giant. Biden's support for unionization follows a series of protests over safety and working conditions at Amazon. If a majority vote in favor, Amazon workers will be automatically represented by the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, but will only become full members after approval of a new company contract.

site_title: Q&M Dental posts 10% rise in FY2020 profit, declares 2.5 S cents special dividend
summary: Q&M Dental Group reported a 10% increase in FY2020 net profit to S$19.7 million, driven by higher revenue and lower operating expenses. Total revenue grew 8% to S$137.6 million, with full-year revenue from dental outlets increasing 6%. The company declared a 2.5 Singapore cent special dividend and plans to double its PCR laboratory-testing capacity. CEO Ng Chin Siau aims to maintain the company's position as the leading private dental healthcare group in Asia through expansion and growth initiatives.

images.alt_text: Q&M Dental has declared a second special interim dividend of 2.5 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: China Feb home price growth cools as large cities tighten rules: private poll
summary: China's new home price growth slowed in February to 0.2% from 0.37% in January, as demand eased during the Chinese New Year and cities tightened rules to curb speculative buying. Major cities like Shanghai, Shenzhen, and Beijing introduced regulations to close loopholes and contain illegal funds. Despite this, home prices are still expected to rise 4.01% annually. 66 cities reported monthly gains, while 27 posted lower prices, with home transactions and land sales declining 38.4% and 37% respectively.

site_title: Gold rebounds after worst month in four years; yields in focus
summary: Gold prices rebounded after its worst monthly slump in four years, rising 1% to $1,750.49 an ounce, amid a retreat in the US dollar and concerns about accelerating inflation. The sell-off in global bonds stabilized after central banks provided reassurance about policy support, and Treasury yields pulled back from their highest level in a year. Investors remain cautious, with bets on inflation raising concerns about a potential pullback in monetary policy support.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's de facto ruler cements control over oil firm Adnoc
summary: Abu Dhabi's de facto ruler, Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Zayed, has solidified his control over state energy company Adnoc by becoming chairman of a newly-established board of directors. He also appointed his son, Khaled bin Mohamed bin Zayed, as chairman of the executive board. The move formalizes the crown prince's role as head of Adnoc, which pumps nearly all the oil and gas in the UAE. The decision comes after Abu Dhabi merged the Supreme Petroleum Council with a new Supreme Council for Financial and Economic Affairs.

images.alt_text: Abu Dhabi's de facto ruler, Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Zayed, has cemented his control over the emirate's state energy company by becoming chairman of a newly-established board of directors.

site_title: At least 18 protesters killed in Myanmar in worst violence since coup
summary: At least 18 protesters were killed in Myanmar in the worst violence since the military coup on February 1, according to the United Nations. The violence, which included police and military firing on protesters, occurred across the country, with several deaths reported in Yangon, Dawei, and Mandalay. The UN called on the international community to act to stop the repression, while US Secretary of State Antony Blinken condemned the "abhorrent violence" by Myanmar security forces. The country has been in chaos since the army seized power, detaining the elected government leader Aung San Suu Kyi and her party leadership.

images.alt_text: Myanmar police fired on protesters around the country on Sunday and at least 18 people were killed in the worst violence since a Feb 1 military coup, the United Nations said, calling on the international community to act to stop the repression.

site_title: Commerzbank to exit Hong Kong, Luxembourg in restructuring
summary: Commerzbank plans to exit locations including Hong Kong, Luxembourg, and Hungary as part of its restructuring, according to an internal memo. The bank will reduce correspondent banks to about 1,300 globally and close branches in cities such as Barcelona and Brussels. Representative offices in countries like Azerbaijan and Venezuela will also be shut by 2024. The restructuring includes 10,000 job cuts and a 2020 loss of about US$3.5 billion. The bank's foreign presence is expected to drop to fewer than 40 countries from about 50.

site_title: Oil prices climb after progress on huge US stimulus bill
summary: Oil prices rose over $1 on Monday due to optimism in the global economy from progress on the US stimulus package and improving oil demand as vaccines are rolled out. Brent crude futures for May rose 1.7% to $65.49 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures jumped 1.8% to $62.60 a barrel. The US House of Representatives passed a $1.9 trillion coronavirus relief package, and a US CDC advisory panel recommended Johnson & Johnson's Covid-19 shot for widespread use.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose more than US$1 on Monday on optimism in the global economy thanks to progress in a huge US stimulus package and on hopes for improving oil demand as vaccines are rolled out.

site_title: Index that profiles climate conscious Reits
summary: A growing number of climate-conscious Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) have emerged globally, with Asia-Pacific being a key focus. The Solactive CarbonCare Asia Pacific Green Reit Index, launched in November 2020, tracks climate-conscious REITs with strong sustainability performance and carbon reduction targets. Eight Singapore REITs, including CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust and Frasers Centrepoint Trust, are among the index's 49 constituents, with many having achieved green building certifications and set net-zero carbon targets.

site_title: Trump eyes return to spotlight at conservative conference
summary: Former US President Donald Trump is set to address the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) in Orlando, Florida, where he is expected to reassert his dominance over the Republican Party and tease attendees about his 2024 presidential ambitions. Trump has maintained a low profile since leaving the White House and has been endorsed by some party officials, who see him as a key figure in the party's future. Despite divisions within the party, Trump's speech is expected to be met with reverence by a loyalist crowd, with some attendees praising his leadership and warning against attempts to "erase" him from the party.

site_title: Citigroup restates Q4 earnings after writing down Revlon loan
summary: Citigroup restated its Q4 earnings after writing down a portion of a loan to Revlon, a cosmetics giant it now owns after losing a court battle over a mistaken payment. The bank transferred $900 million to a group of lenders in August, but only $509.2 million was returned. Citi has written down the loan and continues to believe it is entitled to the remaining funds, which it will appeal. This incident led to a $390 million boost in operating expenses and a $230 million decrease in net income compared to the previous quarter.

site_title: Trump repeats election lie, declares himself future of the Republican Party
summary: Former US President Donald Trump hinted at a possible 2024 presidential run, repeating his claims of a fraudulent 2020 election win and criticizing President Joe Biden. In a speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference, Trump said the Republican Party is united and he has no plans to start a new party. A straw poll of CPAC participants showed Trump leading with 55% support for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination. Despite a mixed result on whether he should run again, Trump is making plans to set up a super PAC to support candidates mirroring his policies.

site_title: Australia's home prices, job ads surge as recovery blitzes expectations
summary: Australia's economy is rapidly recovering from its recession, with home prices surging at the fastest clip in almost two decades in February, and job ads skyrocketing 7.2% in February. New mortgage loans rose 10.5% to a record high, and loans to owner-occupiers increased by 52.3%. The Reserve Bank of Australia has responded by boosting its daily quantitative easing program and slashing its cash rate to 0.1%. While this may suggest a more flexible approach to policy, economists warn that top policymakers may still unwind some monetary stimulus.

site_title: New Zealand lockdown costs millions each day to Auckland businesses
summary: Auckland, New Zealand's largest city, is under its fourth lockdown, costing millions of dollars a day, due to a person's infectious case. The 7-day lockdown affects nearly 2 million residents, with 200 jobs lost and NZ$30 million (S$28.1 million) lost daily under Level 3 restrictions. Mayor Phil Goff prioritizes vaccine roll-out for Auckland residents to avoid future lockdowns and protect jobs. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern criticized the person for making "multiple mistakes" but left enforcement to the police.

site_title: US to distribute 4 million J&J Covid-19 vaccines by Tuesday
summary: The US is set to distribute 4 million doses of Johnson & Johnson's Covid-19 vaccine by Tuesday, following its approval for emergency use on Saturday. This move boosts President Joe Biden's plan to combat the outbreak, which has claimed over 500,000 American lives. The single-shot vaccine is highly effective in preventing severe Covid-19, including against newer variants.

site_title: Spokeswoman for Japan PM Suga resigns over expensive dinners with his son
summary: Makiko Yamada, a key spokeswoman for Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga, has resigned after being reprimanded for attending expensive dinners with her son, a company executive. The dinners, which cost 74,203 yen (S$926) per person, were in 2019 and broke Japan's National Civil Service Ethics Law. Yamada, 60, admitted to hospital for ill health and missed a parliamentary committee meeting where she was expected to be questioned about the dinners. Her resignation was deemed "unavoidable" by the prime minister, and she will continue to receive medical treatment.

images.alt_text: Makiko Yamada, a key spokeswoman for Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga, has resigned after she and other senior bureaucrats were reprimanded for attending expensive dinners hosted by Mr Suga's son, the government said.

site_title: Golden Energy and Resources posts 18.7% drop in FY2020 earnings after acquisitions
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) posted a 18.7% drop in FY2020 earnings to US$8.1 million, primarily due to the consolidation of its Stanmore Coal subsidiary and investment in the Ravenswood Gold project. Revenue grew 4.2% to a record US$1.16 billion, driven by the metallurgical coal segment. The company also reported higher selling and distribution expenses, administrative costs, and a US$4.9 million loss from a joint venture. Gear remains cautiously optimistic on the near-term outlook for energy and metallurgical coal demand and prices.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump most in nearly two months as upbeat data boosts recovery hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 1.7% to close at 6,789.6, the largest intraday gain since January 7, driven by upbeat economic data and a Reserve Bank of Australia announcement of a larger-than-usual A$4 billion bond purchase. Home prices surged at the fastest pace in almost two decades, while job advertisements skyrocketed, boosting recovery hopes. Real estate stocks were leading gainers, and markets await the post-meeting statement for any commentary on soaring home prices and rising bond yields.

site_title: Singapore stocks edge up at Monday's open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 2,956.47 at Monday's open, driven by gains from banking stocks DBS, UOB, and OCBC. Gainers outnumbered losers 110 to 61, with Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Venture Corp also making notable gains. The move comes despite a 8.1% drop in Venture Corp's H2 net profit.

site_title: Indonesia's Feb inflation rate cools to six-month low of 1.38%
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate dropped to a six-month low of 1.38% in February, the slowest since August 2020, according to data from the statistics bureau. This marks the second consecutive month of cooling inflation, staying below the central bank's 2-4% target range. The core inflation rate, excluding volatile food and government-controlled prices, was 1.53%. The decrease is attributed to weak demand during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Asia-Pacific retailers bounce back from pandemic with new growth plans
summary: Retailers in the Asia-Pacific region are bouncing back from the pandemic with new growth plans, shifting to mobile commerce and expanding their service offerings. A study by Stripe found that 41% of respondents believed the crisis had a positive impact on their business, and 46% planned to improve customer experience and adopt new business models. However, retailers face challenges such as increased fraud attempts and difficulties in leveraging data from online sales. Payment specialists are seen as key to unlocking growth, with 43% of respondents citing having too many payment vendors to manage as their top challenge.

site_title: Biden's hopes for rare earth independence likely to be at least a decade away
summary: US President Joe Biden's goal of reducing the country's reliance on foreign rare earths and minerals for clean energy transition is unlikely to be achieved in less than a decade. A review of the US supply chain ordered by the president is expected to show that significant changes are needed, but self-sufficiency is at least a decade away. This comes as other countries, such as India, are also taking steps to increase their rare earth production to reduce their reliance on China.

site_title: Singapore's wealth-related taxes
summary: Singapore's government plans to review wealth taxes amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The country's personal income tax rates range from 7% to 22%, while stamp duties on property transactions contribute 5.7% to the government's revenue. Property taxes, considered assets taxes, account for 4.8% of revenue. The review aims to address the effects of the pandemic on the economy.

site_title: Japanese companies go high-tech in the battle against food waste
summary: Japanese companies are leveraging artificial intelligence to reduce food waste and cut costs, with the aim of halving waste costs by 2030. Convenience store chain Lawson Inc. uses AI to estimate unsold products and minimize overstock, while drinks maker Suntory Beverage & Food uses AI to detect damaged goods during shipping. Other companies, such as Kuradashi and NEC Corp, are also developing technological platforms to reduce food waste, with the goal of meeting global sustainability goals.

site_title: Under pressure, New York governor bows to outside probe of abuse claims
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo agreed to an independent investigation into sexual harassment allegations against him by two former aides, Charlotte Bennett and Lindsey Boylan. The investigation was prompted by mounting US political pressure, including calls from fellow Democrats and President Joe Biden's spokeswoman, Jen Psaki. Cuomo denies any wrongdoing, but his special counsel, Beth Garvey, selected state Attorney General Letitia James to lead the inquiry, which will have subpoena power. The investigation comes after Bennett alleged Cuomo made unwanted advances towards her in 2020, and Boylan claimed he harassed her from 2015 to 2018.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Venture, IHH Healthcare, Top Glove, UOL, SPH, Riverstone, Yanlord
summary:
Here is a summary of the article in 100 words or less:

Singapore stocks saw mixed results on Monday, with Venture Corporation posting a 8.1% decline in net profit, while IHH Healthcare's net profit surged 1,045%. Top Glove plans to raise RM7.77 billion to fund expansion, while UOL Group's net profit plummeted 97%. Singapore Press Holdings rose 9.4% on news of a potential Coupang IPO, and Riverstone Holdings reported a 85% revenue growth. Other companies, including Q&M Dental Group, Golden Energy and Resources, and Nanofilm Technologies, also reported varying results.

images.alt_text: Top Glove has announced plans to raise RM7.77 billion (S$2.55 billion) from a listing in Hong Kong to fund expansion and bolster its profile with overseas investors.

site_title: South Korea, Switzerland agree to extend currency swap agreement for five years
summary: South Korea's central bank has extended its currency swap agreement with Switzerland for five years, effective March 1. The deal, worth 10 billion Swiss francs (S$14.71 billion), aims to enhance bilateral cooperation and facilitate financial markets between the two countries. This is the third extension of the agreement, following the initial 2018 deal. The move is seen as a boost to South Korea's financial stability and its relations with Switzerland.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rebound after US yields drop
summary: Tokyo shares rebounded by 2.41% on Monday following a previous day's sharp losses, driven by a decline in US bond yields. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 29,663.50 and the Topix index surged to 1,902.48. This rebound comes amid a global stock rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Nanofilm to benefit from increased interest in electric vehicles
summary: Nanofilm Technologies has seen a 61.1% rise in net profit to S$57.6 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2020, driven by its surface solutions for fuel cells in electric vehicles. The firm's proprietary solutions offer high corrosion resistance and electrical conductivity at a lower cost than traditional gold-plating methods. With increasing interest in electric vehicles, particularly in Shanghai's commitment to greener initiatives, Nanofilm is poised to benefit from the demand for fuel cells. The company's revenue surged 66.4% to S$182.5 million, and shares ended Monday at S$4.86, up 4.7%.

site_title: Strong global chip demand boosts Excelpoint
summary: Excelpoint Technology, a Singapore-based electronics component distributor, has posted a strong rebound despite the uncertainties of the Covid-19 pandemic. The company's net profit for FY20 reached US$10.3 million, more than six times the US$1.6 million achieved in FY19. Excelpoint aims to hit US$2 billion in revenue in the next two to three years, driven by growing demand for semiconductors and technology adoption. The company is investing in AI and IoT space through its investment arm PlanetSpark, which aims to nurture startups and move up the value chain.

images.alt_text: Mr Phuay says the innovation centre launched by PlanetSpark, whose managing director is his daughter Phuay Li Ying (right), is "a dream of Excelpoint for many years".

site_title: Singapore visitor numbers slip in January despite rise in Indian travellers
summary: Singapore recorded its first month-on-month decline in international arrivals since the Covid-19 pandemic, with 23,150 visitors in January, a 98.6% drop from the previous year. The decline was mainly attributed to a decrease in arrivals from China and Indonesia, but an increase in visitors from India. Overnight visitors were down 99.6% year on year, with an average stay of 23.9 days. This marks a 3.6% dip from December 2020, and the first decline since the pandemic's impact on global travel.

site_title: Israel clears Greek tanker over Mediterranean oil spill
summary: Israel has cleared a Greek tanker, the Minerva Helen, of suspicion in relation to an oil spill that caused massive tar pollution on the Mediterranean coastline, devastating marine life. The incident, Israel's worst maritime pollution incident in decades, occurred on February 17 due to powerful winds and high waves. An investigation found the ship was not involved, and its owner denied any connection to the spill. The environmental protection ministry will continue to investigate other vessels under suspicion, with a stain in the sea offshore that could be oil still being monitored.

site_title: India's biggest oil retailers are focusing on rural revival
summary: India's largest oil retailers, Bharat Petroleum, Hindustan Petroleum, and Indian Oil Corp, are expanding their presence in rural areas, aiming to capitalize on the sector's growth. The rural economy has been less affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, with a bumper agricultural crop and government spending boosting rural farmers' and laborers' incomes. The retailers plan to increase their rural outlets, with Bharat Petroleum opening 2,212 outlets in the past year, two-thirds of which were in rural areas. This expansion is expected to help India's economy recover from its worst recession since the 1950s.

site_title: Wilmar resumes buybacks; RMG chair ups stake
summary: Wilmar International resumed its share buyback program, purchasing 463,000 shares at an average price of S$5.38 per share. The company has purchased S$190 million of its shares since FY20. Other companies with notable director transactions include Raffles Medical Group, where executive chairman Loo Choon Yong acquired 1.5 million shares, and Credit Bureau Asia, where founder Koo Chiang acquired 1,070,200 shares.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds quotation, NTT DC Reit's public offer oversubscribed 9.8 times, and Creative Technology warns of potential revenue and operating loss shortfall. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detains an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long is set to become OCBC's new CEO. MAS and PBOC are deepening cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experience a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: 'The Crown' sweeps Golden Globes for television
summary: "The Crown" dominated the Golden Globes, sweeping top television honors with Emma Corrin winning best TV drama actress and Josh O'Connor winning best TV drama actor. The Netflix series also won the award for best TV drama. Meanwhile, "Schitt's Creek" won the award for best comedy series, with Dan Levy praising the show's message of inclusion. The ceremony also recognized diverse winners, including "Minari" for best foreign language movie and Jason Sudeikis for his role in "Ted Lasso." The Hollywood Foreign Press Association pledged to increase diversity in its membership.

site_title: Macau's gambling revenue surges 135.6% in February
summary: Macau's gambling revenue surged 135.6% in February, reaching 7.312 billion patacas (S$1.22 billion), despite a decline in visitors from mainland China due to travel restrictions. The significant increase was attributed to a strong performance from the gaming industry.

site_title: Hollywood, history combine in Churchill art auction
summary: Angelina Jolie is auctioning off a World War II-era oil painting by Sir Winston Churchill, titled "The Tower of the Koutoubia Mosque," at Christie's in London on March 1. Estimated to fetch between £1.5 million and £2.5 million, the painting is considered Churchill's most important work, made during his visits to Morocco in the 1930s and 1940s. The artwork was gifted to US President Franklin D. Roosevelt by Churchill and is a rare example of Churchill's landscape paintings, with only one other piece, "Scene in Marrakesh," also going under the hammer.

site_title: For manga's striving artists, success lurks online
summary: Manga artist Kamentotsu's four-panel strip about an anthropomorphic bear running a cake shop on Twitter three years ago unexpectedly gained tens of thousands of likes, attracting 40 companies offering publishing deals. The artist notes that publishing company editors now "hunt" for manga artists, unlike in the past when they were seen as "farming" talent. This shift has led to increased opportunities for aspiring manga artists to find success online.

site_title: UK vaccinates over 20 million with at least one dose
summary: The UK has administered over 20 million people with at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson calling it a "huge national achievement". The vaccination programme, which began in December, has rolled out rapidly, with 20,089,551 people receiving a first dose. The government aims to offer a first jab to the whole adult population by the end of July, after meeting a target of 15 million of the most vulnerable people receiving first doses in mid-February.

site_title: Prince Harry tells Oprah he worried history would repeat itself
summary: Prince Harry expressed concern that history would repeat itself, referencing his mother Princess Diana's struggles with the British press. In an upcoming interview with Oprah Winfrey, Harry, 36, and his wife Meghan, 39, discussed their decision to step back from royal duties and the challenges they faced, including racism and bullying from the British tabloids. The couple announced they are expecting their second child and will not be returning to their royal roles. The interview is scheduled to air on March 7.

site_title: New World's Adrian Cheng is said to plan up to US$400m SPAC
summary: New World Development Co's CEO Adrian Cheng plans to raise up to $400 million through a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) in the US. This follows a growing trend of Asian tycoons tapping into the red-hot US blank-check firm market, which has seen over $60 billion raised so far this year. Cheng joins fellow Hong Kong tycoons Li Ka-shing and Richard Li in planning a blank-check company, with New World Development also seeking a senior executive to oversee mergers and acquisitions. Details of the SPAC's initial public offering are still in the early stages.

site_title: Facebook to pay US$650m settlement over US privacy dispute
summary: A US federal judge has given final approval for Facebook to pay $650 million to settle a privacy dispute with 1.6 million Illinois users. The settlement resolves a 2015 lawsuit alleging Facebook collected biometric data without users' consent in violation of a 2008 Illinois law. The judge deemed the settlement the largest for a privacy violation, with plaintiffs receiving at least $345 each in compensation.

site_title: Modi takes home-grown vaccine as India widens immunisation drive
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi received the first dose of the home-grown COVAXIN vaccine, marking an expansion of the country's immunization campaign. Eligible individuals, including those above 60 and those with certain medical conditions, are now eligible for vaccinations. Over 12 million health and front-line workers have been vaccinated so far. The government has also allowed people to choose between COVAXIN and the AstraZeneca vaccine, a change from earlier restrictions. The campaign has faced challenges, including low vaccination rates among healthcare workers, but Modi appeals to the public to take the vaccine to make India "Covid-19 free".

site_title: Green, blue and now brown: Why transition bonds offer an exciting opportunity for Asean
summary: The Asean region is making strides in sustainable finance, with green and blue bonds reaching $25.4 billion in 2020, supporting projects in renewable energy, transport, and water management. However, industries like energy and transportation, which contribute to greenhouse gas emissions, are often excluded from these bonds. Transition bonds, which help companies reduce their carbon footprint, are gaining momentum, with several issuers and investors embracing the format. Despite the potential for "green washing," the financial industry is taking steps to ensure transition finance remains credible and creates positive change.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb 1.5% as country inches towards pre-pandemic normal
summary: Australia's shares rose 1.5% on Monday, nearing pre-pandemic levels, as states eased COVID-19 restrictions. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed to 6,775.60, driven by a tech sub-index that rose 2.8%. Healthcare stocks also gained, while gold stocks fell 1.6% due to a stronger dollar and rising US Treasury yields. New Zealand's benchmark index slid 0.3% after Auckland's second lockdown.

site_title: In Russian Arctic, miner Nornickel exhibits green goal
summary: Russia's Norilsk Nickel, a leading mining giant, is closing its 74-year-old Nikel metallurgical plant in the Arctic, a major source of pollution, by 2029. The plant, which produced over 2.4 million tonnes of nickel, was notorious for emitting four times as much sulphur dioxide as Norway's industries. The closure is part of Norilsk Nickel's global strategy to transform into an environmentally friendly company, with plans to invest $5.5 billion over 10 years to modernize equipment and clean up pollution. Despite the move, environmental groups say it's not enough to address the company's significant impact on the Arctic ecosystem.

site_title: China's coal consumption share falls to 56.8% at end-2020
summary: China's coal consumption share dropped to 56.8% of energy consumption at the end of 2020, meeting its target of below 58%. Despite this, coal consumption rose 0.6% year-over-year, driven by record industrial output and new power plants. Renewable energy share increased to 24.3%, while energy consumption grew 2.2% to 4.98 billion tonnes. China's carbon intensity fell 1.0% last year, but missed its target for cutting energy intensity, falling 13.7% instead of 15%.

site_title: Medtecs full-year profit surges to US$131.7m on economies of scale, higher sales
summary: Medtecs International Corp reported a net profit of US$131.7 million for the full year ended Dec 31, 2020, nearly 110 times the US$1.2 million net profit a year ago. Improved economies of scale and higher sales of Medtecs-branded products and personal protective equipment (PPEs) drove the surge. Revenue jumped to US$400.3 million, up nearly six times from the previous year. A final cash dividend of 4.18 US cents has been recommended for the financial year.

site_title: Chip shortages hit Japan car sales as Nissan, Honda cut output
summary: Japan's motor vehicle sales dropped 2.2% in February, the first decline in four months, due to the global semiconductor shortage. The decline is attributed to reduced consumption amid government calls for reduced hours at restaurants and bars, further pushing the economy into contraction this quarter. Nissan and Honda have cut output, exacerbating the issue.

site_title: China's economic recovery slows amid holiday disruptions
summary: China's economic recovery slowed in February due to factory shutdowns during the Chinese New Year holidays and virus restrictions. The manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) fell to a nine-month low of 50.6, while the non-manufacturing gauge declined to 51.4. Despite the seasonal slump, the PMIs remain above 50, indicating output is still expanding at a slower pace. Retailing, catering, and entertainment remained relatively active, but employment indexes for manufacturing and non-manufacturing sectors remained below 50, indicating jobs are still being lost.

site_title: How global market plays out depends on bond yields
summary: The global market's direction is heavily influenced by bond yields, with a recent surge in yields causing a mini panic in equity and commodity markets. Despite the rise in yields, investors remain optimistic about economies, driven by central banks' money pumping and trillions of aid to stressed businesses and individuals. The US Federal Reserve's potential intervention to buy bonds may help stabilize the market, but growth and inflation will be key to a recovery in bond prices and lower yields.

site_title: New World closes Hong Kong mall after virus cluster emerges
summary: New World Development Co. closed its Hong Kong mall, K11 MUSEA, through Friday due to a cluster of 44 Covid-19 cases linked to a Chinese restaurant. The mall was previously set to close from Sunday to Monday. This marks the first time a Hong Kong landlord has closed a mall due to virus concerns. The developer extended the closure to allow staff to complete another round of tests. The closure affects retail sales, with New World's shares falling 4.1% due to the move.

site_title: UAE's Amanat buys Cambridge Medical in US$232m deal
summary: UAE-based Amanat Holdings PJSC acquired Cambridge Medical and Rehabilitation Center in a US$232 million deal, highlighting demand for specialist medical services in the Gulf region. The post-acute care and rehabilitation provider has over 250 beds across three facilities in the UAE and Saudi Arabia, with revenue of US$75.3 million and net income of US$15.2 million for 2020. Amanat's CEO said post-acute care and rehabilitation has proven resilient during the pandemic, and the acquisition will build the region's biggest provider of post-acute care and rehabilitation services.

site_title: Singapore calls on Myanmar to stop use of lethal force, release Aung San Suu Kyi
summary: Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan urged Myanmar's military regime to stop using lethal force and release detained leader Aung San Suu Kyi, amid escalating violence against protesters. At least 18 people were killed on Feb 28, and many more injured, drawing global condemnation. Balakrishnan called for restraint, de-escalation, and negotiations, emphasizing that the use of lethal force against unarmed civilians is inexcusable. He also highlighted the importance of Asean's role in facilitating a peaceful solution, warning of severe divisions if the crisis is not addressed.

site_title: Dollar gains on higher yields while risky currencies weaken
summary: The US dollar strengthened on Friday, rising 0.59% to 90.847, its highest level in a week, as US government bond yields held near one-year highs. The surge in yields was driven by optimism over improving global growth and inflation, leading investors to price in earlier monetary tightening. The Australian dollar weakened 1.99% to US$0.7713, while emerging market currencies are expected to be among the biggest losers.

site_title: Singapore needs 1.2m more digital workers by 2025 to remain competitive: report
summary: Singapore needs 1.2 million additional digital workers by 2025 to remain competitive, a 55% increase from today's levels, according to a report commissioned by Amazon Web Services. The report identified top in-demand skills as cloud architecture design, cybersecurity, and large-scale data modeling. Currently, 63% of Singapore's workforce has digitally skilled workers, and 51% of digital workers believe they need cloud computing skills to perform their jobs.

site_title: China's factory activity growth slips to nine-month low: Caixin PMI
summary: China's factory activity growth has slowed to a nine-month low in February, according to Caixin PMI, due to weak overseas demand and coronavirus flare-ups. This slowdown underscores the fragility of China's ongoing economic recovery, despite the recent stamping out of domestic Covid-19 cases. The result contrasts with an official survey showing the weakest pace since last May, and analysts expect a strong rebound in full-year growth.

site_title: ANZ writes down AmBank stake after 1MDB scandal settlement
summary: ANZ is writing down the value of its 24% stake in Malaysian bank AmBank by A$212 million due to AmBank's settlement with the Malaysian government over its role in the 1MDB scandal. The settlement involves a US$700 million payment. This will lower ANZ's half-year earnings for fiscal 2021 but will not affect its overall capital position. The carrying value of ANZ's stake in AmBank will be lowered to A$850 million from A$1.05 billion.

site_title: China chips away at coal usage to chase climate goals
summary: China's coal usage declined to 56.8% of total energy consumption in 2020, meeting a government target to reduce coal's share to 57.5%. Despite this, total coal use increased by 0.6% due to rising energy consumption. China aims to target carbon neutrality by 2060 and is considering measures to cut coal's share to 52% by 2025. The country's clean energy share rose to 24.3% in 2020, but a gap remains between its ambitious goals and the desire of companies to maintain economic growth.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Riverstone Holdings reported a record-high net profit of RM647.3 million for FY 2020, up from RM130.4 million in FY 2019. The company recommended a special dividend of four sen per share and a final dividend of 16 sen per share. Yanlord Land Group's net profit edged down 3% to 2.1 billion yuan in the half-year ended December 2020. SPH's indirect stake in Coupang is estimated at 0.1%, with a reported investment of US$3.9 million in 2014.

site_title: India's factory activity extends growth in Feb, input costs soar: PMI
summary: India's factory activity expanded for the seventh consecutive month in February, driven by strong demand and increased output, according to a private sector survey. The Nikkei Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index eased slightly to 57.5, above the 50-level separating growth from contraction. Output and new orders rose sharply, but firms shed jobs at a modest pace due to government-imposed restrictions. Input costs inflation hit a 32-month high, with purchases of raw materials increasing at the fastest pace in nearly a decade.

site_title: Aggressive marketing of buy-now-pay-later schemes needs review
summary: Aggressive marketing of buy-now-pay-later (BNPL) schemes in Singapore needs review, experts say. Millions have turned to these interest-free installment payments for retail goods, a trend that was once considered unusual. The growth of BNPL has raised concerns about consumer protection and debt management. Regulatory bodies must assess the impact of these schemes on consumers and ensure they are operating in a fair and transparent manner.

site_title: Syria intercepts Israeli missiles over Damascus: state media
summary: Syria's state news agency Sana reported that Syrian air defenses intercepted Israeli missiles over Damascus on Sunday. The strike, which occurred at 10:16pm GMT, targeted areas in the Damascus region where Iranian Revolutionary Guards and Lebanese Hezbollah forces are present. There were no immediate reports of casualties. The incident comes amid ongoing tensions between Israel and Iran in Syria, with Israel having carried out raids in the country since the Syrian civil war began in 2011.

site_title: Chinese scientists find new strains of African swine fever virus
summary: Chinese scientists have discovered new strains of African swine fever virus, which are milder but highly transmissible. The strains were found in seven Chinese provinces during a six-month surveillance last year and pose new challenges for controlling the disease. The new variants can be difficult to detect, as they are shed through oral and rectal routes, complicating early diagnosis and culling of infected animals. This development adds to the ongoing difficulties in recovering China's hog herds, which were severely impacted by swine fever outbreaks in 2018.

site_title: Thousands gather outside Hong Kong court for subversion hearing
summary: Hundreds of people gathered outside a Hong Kong court on March 1, 2021, as 47 democracy activists, including former law professor Benny Tai and veteran activists Lester Shum and Joshua Wong, faced charges under the national security law for conspiracy to commit subversion. The activists were accused of organizing an unofficial primary poll last July, which authorities claimed was part of a plan to "overthrow" the government. The charges are the latest blow to Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement, which has seen elected legislators disqualified, activists arrested, and others flee overseas since the security legislation was imposed last June.

site_title: Property taxes are likely first stop for wealth tax review
summary: Singapore's government may review wealth taxes to fund growing expenses, with property taxes as a potential first point of focus. However, tax analysts advise a calibrated approach to protect the country's competitiveness as a wealth hub. Singapore's handling of the pandemic has allowed it to wait and potentially raise taxes later, if other countries increase taxes to fund Covid-19 measures. The review aims to balance economic growth with tax increases.

site_title: UIC secures green, sustainability-linked loans worth S$300m
summary: United Industrial Corporation Limited (UIC) secured S$300 million in green and sustainability-linked loans from UOB and DBS. The loans include a S$200 million sustainability-linked loan and a S$100 million green loan. The green loan will fund major upgrading works at the Singapore Land Tower, introducing more green features by 2023. The S$200 million loan will be used for refinancing and general corporate purposes. Both loans are three-year credit-revolving facilities. The move aims to balance business outcomes with environmental and social needs, as UIC strives to become a more responsible business.

site_title: US urban office market, stung by pandemic, hopes tech firms drive comeback
summary: The US urban office market is recovering from the pandemic, driven by major tech companies like Amazon, Facebook, and Google. However, the shift to remote work and declining demand for office space pose significant challenges. Leasing volumes and building sales have plummeted, with valuations at lower-end properties falling. To remain valuable, office buildings must provide a great environment, meet changing workspace demands, and cater to employees' expectations for health and wellness centers. If not, they risk becoming obsolete and losing significant value.

site_title: Opec+ faces calls to cool oil market frenzy with extra barrels
summary: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec+) is expected to agree to increase oil production when it meets this week, reversing some of the output cuts made last year. However, if the alliance agrees to an output hike that falls short of requirements, it could trigger a further price surge, potentially leading to a market supercycle. Global oil inventories are plummeting at the steepest rate in two decades, and prices have rallied to pre-virus levels, prompting traders to expect a significant increase in supply.

site_title: HK charges dozens of opposition activists under security law
summary: Hong Kong police charged 47 opposition activists, including Joshua Wong, under the national security law, the largest mass charge since the law's implementation. The charges stem from their roles in organizing a democratic primary contest and plans to vote down the budget. Wong, who is already serving a sentence, faces a new charge under the national security law. The charges come ahead of China's National People's Congress, where reforms to Hong Kong's electoral system may be discussed.

site_title: UK seeks G-7 consensus on digital competition after Facebook blackout
summary: The UK is seeking a G-7 consensus on regulating digital competition, following a media blackout by Facebook in Australia. Digital minister Oliver Dowden warned that tech companies must be held accountable for their actions, preventing exploitation of dominance. A meeting of G-7 leaders is set for June, with Britain aiming to build consensus on promoting competitive digital markets and protecting free speech. The UK is also working on a new competition regime to give consumers more control over their data and regulating social media platforms.

site_title: Singapore bank lending up 0.7% in January: MAS data
summary: Singapore's bank lending rose 0.7% in January, driven by higher loans to businesses, according to MAS data. Business loans grew 0.9% to S$422.73 billion, while consumer loans increased 0.5% to S$260.87 billion. Housing loans rose 0.4% to S$202.14 billion. Year-over-year, total bank lending fell 1.1%.

site_title: Cinema operators need to rethink business model
summary: Cinema operators face uncertain future due to pandemic-related delays, reduced seating capacities, and streaming services' popularity. Industry experts predict companies must restructure and adapt to technology to survive. Mainboard-listed mm2 Asia, however, appears to be optimistic about the market's appetite for cinema assets, suggesting a potential future for theatre chains.

images.alt_text: Singapore's box office takings last year are estimated to have fallen to S$106 million from S$259 million a year earlier, according to data from PwC's Global Entertainment and Media Outlook 2020-2024.

site_title: Singapore IPO pipeline looking robust, fuelled by Asia growth and US-China tensions
summary: Singapore's IPO pipeline appears robust, driven by Asian growth and US-China tensions. Lawyers expect a healthier pipeline this year, with larger companies like Nanofilm Technologies International listing, and some smaller US-listed Chinese companies seeking a secondary listing in Singapore. This follows a series of executive orders targeting Chinese technology companies as national security risks, leading to increased interest in Hong Kong and Shanghai. Singapore remains an attractive destination for companies, with potential IPO candidates including Reits, non-Reits, and companies in the IT and renewable space.

site_title: Australia moves closer to pre-pandemic life, Covid-19 reined in for now
summary: Australia has largely returned to pre-pandemic life, with New South Wales and South Australia lifting restrictions and Victoria allowing 50% capacity at sporting events. The country has reported fewer than 29,000 Covid-19 cases and 909 deaths. Australia's vaccination program has begun, with over 60,000 doses administered, aiming to offer immunizations to all Australians by October. Foreign Minister Marise Payne received her first vaccine dose, citing it will help facilitate international travel and vital national interests.

site_title: Myanmar police fire rubber bullets to disperse protesters in Yangon
summary: Myanmar police fired rubber bullets to disperse protesters in Yangon, following a UN ambassador's call for action against the military junta. The country has been experiencing pro-democracy protests since a military coup on February 1, with hundreds of ethnic Mon protesters gathering to commemorate Mon National Day. Three journalists were detained during the clashes, which saw protesters scattering into residential streets and building barricades to stop the police. The police chased protesters and journalists, with shots fired at the scene.

site_title: Thailand's vaccine roll-out kicks off amid controversy
summary: Thailand has begun its COVID-19 vaccine roll-out, with the first batches of Sinovac and AstraZeneca vaccines arriving on February 24. However, the program has been criticized for its tardiness and lack of diversified vaccine imports. The government has signed a deal with Siam Bioscience to produce locally-made AstraZeneca vaccines, with plans to inoculate half of Thailand's 69 million population by the end of 2021. Critics argue that the government should diversify its vaccine sources to speed up the recovery of the tourism sector, which is heavily reliant on international visitors.

site_title: Yanlord H2 profit shrinks 3% to 2.1b yuan
summary: Yanlord Land Group reported a 3% decline in net profit to 2.1 billion yuan for the half-year ended December 2020, driven by lower other operating income and gains. Revenue rose 35% to 14.8 billion yuan, mainly due to increased gross floor area and average selling prices. For the full year, net profit fell 23% to 2.6 billion yuan, attributed to various factors including lower fair value gains. The company recommended a final cash dividend of 34.19 fen, slightly lower than the previous year.

site_title: London's West End turns dead end as shoppers leave Oxford Street
summary: Oxford Street, London's premier shopping destination, is facing its biggest threat in decades due to store closures and a decline in foot traffic. At least a fifth of stores on the street have shut down, with Topshop and Debenhams among the casualties. The local authority plans to "reinvent" the street with £150 million in funding, aiming to create more pedestrian space, pop-up parks, and a wider range of businesses. The council hopes the revival will help Oxford Street regain its appeal, but it faces stiff competition from other major cities like Berlin and Paris.

site_title: SPX returns to middle of ascending channel
summary: The S&P 500 (SPX) has returned to the middle of its ascending channel, with prices likely to test the 23.6% Fibonacci level of 4,013.6 in the coming days. A bullish trend is expected, with the MACD indicator narrowing and poised to cross above the zero line, indicating a decrease in bearish momentum. Reasons for further gains include a potential shakeout of overvalued technology stocks and a rotation into cyclical stocks as the vaccine rollout progresses, with the Federal Reserve committing to easy-money policy and a focus on full employment.

site_title: The London chef with three stars and 20,000 dinner cancellations
summary: London chef Clare Smyth, who became the first British woman to win three Michelin stars, has seen her restaurant bookings plummet to zero during the lockdown, forcing the closure of her eatery, Core by Clare Smyth. However, her home-delivery service, Core at Home, has revealed pent-up demand, selling out almost immediately. Smyth is cautious about reopening, citing 20,000 cancelled reservations due to changing rules, and is calling for the government to extend reduced VAT and business-rate holidays to support the industry's recovery.

site_title: South Korea launches review of Johnson & Johnson's Covid-19 vaccine
summary: South Korea has launched a review of Johnson & Johnson's Covid-19 vaccine after the US pharmaceutical firm submitted an application for approval. The government will study the one-shot vaccine with private advisory panels before authorizing it. This move comes as the US has submitted the application for approval of the vaccine.

site_title: CNMC posts first annual loss since 2011 on Covid-19 fallout
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings reported its first annual loss since 2011, with a net loss of US$3.5 million for FY 2020, compared to a net profit of US$4.4 million in the previous year. Revenue for the second half of FY 2020 fell 28.4% to US$13.4 million, largely due to a significant drop in gold production and sales volumes. The loss was attributed to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on the gold mining industry.

site_title: Australia considers aid to Qantas, others once wage subsidy ends
summary: Australia's Treasurer is considering measures to support industries, including Qantas Airways, after the government's JobKeeper wage subsidy expires late this month. The airline has received A$459 million under the wage support program and faces a 75% revenue reduction due to COVID-19 travel restrictions. The Treasurer believes the domestic market will improve with the rollout of a COVID-19 vaccine and less frequent border closures.

site_title: Roman chariot unearthed almost intact near Pompeii
summary: A nearly intact Roman chariot has been discovered near Pompeii, Italy, in the portico to stables where three horses were unearthed in 2018. The four-wheeled processional carriage, likely a ceremonial Pilentum, features ornate decorations and is considered an exceptional discovery with no parallel in Italy. Found in the Civita Giuliana excavation site, the chariot's preservation is attributed to careful excavation techniques, allowing for the recovery of organic materials and imprints of ropes. The discovery is a significant addition to Pompeii's remarkably well-preserved remains, with 20 hectares still to be excavated.

site_title: Lady Gaga's dogs safely returned: LA police
summary: Lady Gaga's two French bulldogs, Koji and Gustav, were safely returned to her after being stolen at gunpoint in Hollywood. The incident occurred on Wednesday night when a dog walker, Ryan Fischer, was shot and hospitalized. The attackers escaped in a vehicle with two of the dogs. A woman later found the dogs and contacted Gaga's staff, leading to their safe return. The Los Angeles Police Department is investigating the incident, and Gaga offered a $500,000 reward for their safe return.

site_title: Trading app Robinhood says facing US regulator inquiries
summary: Robinhood, a US stock trading app, is cooperating with inquiries from US regulators and federal financial regulators into its decision to temporarily limit purchases of GameStop shares in January. The company faces dozens of class action lawsuits, alleging breach of contract and breach of fiduciary duty. Robinhood co-founder Vlad Tenev testified before a House of Representatives committee, stating the company played by the books and did not manipulate the market. The company's actions sparked an unprecedented trading frenzy, with GameStop shares surging over 400%.

site_title: Japfa FY20 net profit rises to US$322m
summary: Japfa, an industrial agri-food company, reported a net profit of US$322 million for fiscal year 2020, up from US$120 million last year. Revenue fell 1% to US$3.87 billion, with its Indonesian unit experiencing a decline due to COVID-19 disruptions. However, the company's swine operations and dairy operations in Vietnam and China, respectively, delivered robust results, offsetting the weaker performance of its Indonesian unit. Japfa's earnings per share increased to 15.86 US cents, and the company proposes an interim special dividend of 10 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: SPH holds about 0.1% of South Korean e-commerce company Coupang
summary: SPH, the publisher of The Business Times, holds an estimated 0.1% stake in South Korean e-commerce company Coupang, valued at US$50 million if the company's proposed IPO takes place. SPH initially invested US$3.9 million in Coupang in 2014. The IPO, expected to value Coupang at US$50 billion, is not expected to affect SPH's financial performance. SPH's shares rose 9.4% following the news, citing the need for shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in the company's shares.

site_title: Biden's US$1.9t Covid-19 relief plan passes hurdle in US House
summary: The US House of Representatives moved towards a late-night vote on President Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion coronavirus aid bill, despite opposition from Republicans. Democrats control the chamber and have few votes to spare, with the bill aimed at fighting the pandemic, paying for vaccines, and providing emergency financial aid. The measure includes a $15 minimum wage increase, which is unlikely to pass in the Senate, but Democrats are exploring alternative provisions. The bill's passage is seen as crucial to revive the US economy, with the White House and economists arguing that a big package is needed.

images.alt_text: There is an increasing interest in Lean Six Sigma by healthcare practitioners. While it offers both process and data lenses to examine problems towards a resolution roadmap, practitioners endorse it to be easy to learn and effective when applied.

site_title: US expert panel recommends authorising J&J Covid vaccine
summary: US experts have unanimously voted to authorise emergency approval for Johnson & Johnson's one-shot Covid-19 vaccine, clearing the way for its use in the US. The decision comes as the country faces a shortage of authorized vaccines and is still in the midst of the pandemic. The vaccine's authorisation is expected to help meet current vaccine needs.

site_title: Why an animated flying cat with a Pop-Tart body sold for almost US$600,000
summary: A unique digital art piece, Nyan Cat, created by Chris Torres, sold for approximately $580,000 on the Foundation website, setting a new high point in the fast-growing market for non-fungible tokens (NFTs). The buyer, identified only by a cryptocurrency wallet number, acquired bragging rights and the knowledge of owning the authentic copy. This sale follows recent NFT sales, including a LeBron James clip for $100,000 and a Mark Cuban tweet for $952. The NFT market reflects a move by creators to connect financially with their audience and eliminates middlemen, with some buyers collecting and others trying to make a quick buck.

site_title: Trump endorses rival to Republican who voted to impeach
summary: Former US President Donald Trump has endorsed Max Miller, an ex-aide, in his bid to challenge Ohio Congressman Anthony Gonzalez, one of 10 Republicans who voted to impeach Trump. Trump expressed his support for Miller, calling him a "wonderful person" who will be a "fantastic congressman." This endorsement comes as Trump seeks revenge against fellow Republicans who voted against him during the January 6 US Capitol riot.

site_title: Malaysian pension fund EPF assets grow to value of RM1.02 trillion in 2020
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) reported a 7.9% growth in its investment assets to RM1.02 trillion (S$335.7 billion) at the end of 2020, driven by equities and fixed income assets. Despite market volatility, the fund achieved a record gross investment income of RM60.98 billion. Equities, particularly foreign stocks, generated RM28.71 billion, while fixed income instruments provided RM25.42 billion. The fund took prudent measures to maintain long-term investments, achieving a net 5.26% return on investment.

site_title: Asian green bond market catching up with rest of the world
summary: The Asian green bond market is rapidly catching up with the rest of the world, accounting for almost a quarter of the global US dollar green bond universe. Despite lagging European counterparts, the market is expected to grow significantly, with China being the largest issuer in the region. HSBC forecasts $17-20 billion in gross issuance in the region this year, driven by strong investor demand and favorable government policies. The market is expected to expand into green building-related projects and financing, with issuers including banks, renewables, and property companies.

site_title: Sunak promises 'fair' plan to plug hole in UK public finances
summary: UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak has promised a "fair" plan to address the UK's public finances, which were severely impacted by the pandemic. He warned that if action is not taken, borrowing will remain high and debt will continue to rise indefinitely. Sunak emphasized the need for honesty with the public and vowed to present a comprehensive plan to fill the financial gap. The UK economy has also shrunk for the second consecutive month, adding to the challenges faced by Prime Minister Starmer.

images.alt_text: Mr Sunak has also pledged to keep supporting workers and jobs as the economy reopens.

site_title: Biden on track to apply Trump-era rule targeting Chinese tech supply chain concerns
summary: The Biden administration plans to allow a Trump-era rule targeting Chinese technology firms to go into effect, despite objections from US businesses. The rule aims to address information and communications technology supply chain concerns and will become effective after a 60-day public comment period. The US Chamber of Commerce and Business Roundtable have raised concerns about the rule's impact on US businesses, but the Commerce Department will continue to accept public comments until March 22. The rule aims to ensure national and economic security.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration plans to allow a Trump-era rule targeting Chinese technology firms deemed to pose a threat to the United States to go into effect despite objections from US businesses, the US Commerce Department said on Friday.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for February 26, 2021, reveals a mild downward slide in the market, with the 5TC closing at $11,934. The Pacific basin remained stable, while the transatlantic C8 dropped $2,550 to $15,025. Owner optimism sees demand for Capesize ramping up, but timing remains uncertain. The Panamax market showed weaker rates, with Mineral activity in the north Atlantic waning. Ultramaxes and Supramaxes saw positive week, with charterers seeking period cover. Handysize rates broke 1,000 points, with the timecharter average increasing to almost $19,000. VLCC rates under pressure, while Suezmax and Aframax markets remained positive.

site_title: TikTok agrees US$92m deal to settle US privacy lawsuits
summary: TikTok has agreed to pay US$92 million to settle US class-action lawsuits alleging the platform invades the privacy of young users. The settlement includes increased transparency about data gathering and better employee training on user privacy. It applies to 89 million TikTok users in the US, with eligible users receiving 96 cents each if they file claims. The deal comes amid pressure from US officials to sell TikTok, following a plan by former President Trump to require its sale to US tech giant Oracle.

site_title: Riverstone Q4 net profit rises to RM331.1m, full-year profit reaches record high
summary: Malaysian glove maker Riverstone Holdings reported a record-high net profit of RM647.3 million for FY 2020, up from RM130.4 million in FY 2019. The company's revenue rose 85% to RM1.83 billion, driven by higher quantities of healthcare and cleanroom gloves being shipped. Riverstone has recommended a special dividend of four sen per share and a final dividend of 16 sen per share, and plans to expand its production capacity to 12 billion pieces of gloves per annum by the end of 2021. Despite macroeconomic challenges, the company expects demand for its healthcare and cleanroom gloves to remain high.

site_title: SoftBank reaches settlement with former WeWork CEO Neumann
summary: SoftBank Group Corp has reached a settlement with WeWork's special committee and co-founder Adam Neumann, ending a 2-year legal battle. The deal reportedly includes a nearly $500 million cut in Neumann's payout from SoftBank, and SoftBank will purchase around half of the shares it had originally agreed to buy. The settlement clears the way for WeWork's potential public listing by merging with a special purpose acquisition company. The agreement was reached after all parties came to the table to prioritize WeWork's future.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 fall to conclude rocky week for stocks
summary: US stocks ended a volatile week mostly lower, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.5% and the S&P 500 shedding 0.5%. Despite a 0.6% gain by the Nasdaq Composite Index, the tech-heavy index was the biggest loser for the week, down 5%. Investors worry about potential interest rate hikes due to inflation concerns, but some experts argue that the Federal Reserve will not suddenly lift rates. A US$1.9 trillion spending package and regulatory progress on a coronavirus vaccine also boosted markets.

site_title: White House restores key climate measure calculating carbon's harm
summary: The White House has restored the "social cost of greenhouse gases" calculation, previously slashed under the Trump administration, to estimate the economic damages of climate change. The Biden administration will use a price estimate of about $50 per ton of greenhouse gases emitted, compared to the Trump administration's $10 per ton. The move aims to enable federal agencies to account for climate impacts in decision-making while a new estimate is developed. Economists recommend setting the social cost of carbon at $100 per ton by 2030 to achieve the Paris agreement's goal of limiting global temperatures to 1.5 degrees Celsius.

site_title: The smart money on money
summary: Jacob Goldstein's book "Money: The True Story Of A Made-Up Thing" simplifies the history of currency, highlighting how systems of money are fundamentally systems of social trust. From the invention of paper money in Greece and China to the Great Depression and Great Financial Crisis, Goldstein's engaging narrative demonstrates the power of money in shaping human progress. He also explores the role of fiat currency, citing examples like Kublai Khan's creation of paper money in 13th century China, which revolutionized the global economy centuries before President Nixon's 1971 decision. The book offers a concise and entertaining history of money, but its contemporary chapters may be less informative for longtime readers of The Business Times.

site_title: 'My heart is sick': Lady Gaga offers US$500,000 for stolen dogs
summary: Lady Gaga has offered a $500,000 reward for the safe return of her two stolen French bulldogs, Koji and Gustav, after they were taken at gunpoint in Los Angeles. Lady Gaga's dog walker, Ryan Fischer, was shot and hospitalized in the incident. A third dog, Miss Asia, was found and recovered by law enforcement. The Los Angeles Police Department is investigating the incident. Lady Gaga, who is currently in Italy filming her next movie, expressed her gratitude to Fischer, calling him a hero.

site_title: Tiger Woods recovering, in 'good spirits' after follow-up procedures
summary: Tiger Woods, a 15-time major winner, is recovering from injuries sustained in a car accident, with a fractured right leg and shattered ankle. He received successful follow-up procedures and is in "good spirits." Woods, 45, was being treated at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. His family expressed gratitude for the support and messages received, stating they will not have further updates at this time, and Woods had hoped to compete at the Augusta Masters in April.

site_title: Central banks fight back against bond rout, calming investors
summary: Central banks from Asia to Europe are intervening to calm market panic after US Treasury yields surged to a one-year high, prompting concerns about the pace of economic recovery. The Reserve Bank of Australia and European Central Bank announced debt purchases and intervention threats, while the Bank of Japan warned against sudden yield jumps. Despite the response, a deepening divide between traders and central banks remains, with policy makers fearing the "reflation trade" could harm economies still recovering from the coronavirus shock.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says 'completely rejects' US assessment on Khashoggi murder
summary: Saudi Arabia has rejected a US report that found Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman approved the 2018 murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The report, released by President Joe Biden's administration, concluded that the prince "approved an operation in Istanbul to capture or kill" Khashoggi. Saudi Arabia has previously denied the crown prince's involvement and described the murder as a rogue operation. The country rejects the report's conclusions, stating it contains inaccurate information and infringes upon its sovereignty. Saudi Arabia aims to maintain its relationship with the US, calling it a "robust and enduring partnership".

site_title: Europe: Shares drop as high yields spark profit taking in tech, resources
summary: European stocks declined 1.6% on Friday, marking the first weekly loss this month, as investors took profits in technology and resource stocks due to rising inflation and interest rates. Bond yields rose, making fixed income markets more attractive. Despite this, the Stoxx 600 gained 1.3% for the month, driven by a rotation into energy, banking, and mining stocks. Travel and leisure sectors also performed well, driven by economic reopening expectations.

images.alt_text: European stocks closed lower on Friday, ending three weeks of gains as investors booked profits in technology and commodity-linked shares due to concerns over rising inflation and interest rates on the back of a jump in bond yields.

site_title: Boeing CEO asked to testify in crash litigation, lawmakers demand FAA release records
summary: Families of 346 victims of the Boeing 737 MAX crashes in Ethiopia and Indonesia are pressing Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun and the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to release internal records and testify in crash litigation. Relatives are seeking testimony from Calhoun, his predecessor, and other current and former employees, as part of their legal case in Chicago. The FAA has faced criticism for lapses in aviation safety oversight and is under pressure to release internal emails and documents related to the crashes.

images.alt_text: Relatives of victims of a Boeing 737 MAX crash in Ethiopia that occurred five months after an Indonesian Lion Air disaster are stepping up pressure on the American planemaker and the federal government, according to a court filing and a letter to US lawmakers.

site_title: Who's afraid of flying? (Or why aircraft engines explode)
summary: Aircraft engines do fail, but most recent failures do not result in fatalities. A 1989 US Airways crash led to improvements in jet engine design and placement to protect vital control systems. Despite this, some engine blowouts still occur, as seen in a recent United Airlines incident. The industry has learned from past tragedies, and most engine failures do not lead to catastrophic consequences. Manufacturers continue to refine engine design to minimize the risk of catastrophic failures.

images.alt_text: The damaged engine of UA flight 328 - a Boeing 777-200 - after its Feb 20 engine failure incident, seen here in a hangar at Denver International Airport, Colorado.

site_title: Development charge rates up 0.3% for non-landed residential use, 1.5% cut for commercial use
