summary: Singapore's government has increased development charge (DC) rates for non-landed residential use by 0.3% and decreased rates for commercial use by 1.5% for the half-year period starting March 1. This marks the first increase for non-landed residential rates since 2019. The changes aim to reflect the improving private housing market and the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on the office and retail sectors. The revisions do not affect DC rates for other use groups, which remain unchanged.

site_title: Myanmar envoy makes emotional appeal for UN action against coup
summary: Myanmar's ambassador to the UN, Kyaw Moe Tun, made an emotional appeal for the international community to take action against the military regime that ousted the country's elected government. Tun urged countries to issue public statements condemning the coup, not recognize the regime, and demand respect for last year's democratic elections. The UN envoy to Myanmar, Christine Schraner Burgener, also condemned the military's actions and called for a return to democracy. Diplomats from countries including the US, Britain, and China responded with statements and applause, with some pledging to take action against the regime.

site_title: NYSE begins move to delist Chinese state oil producer CNOOC
summary: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) has begun the formal delisting process of Chinese state oil giant CNOOC, 60 days after adding it to a list of companies prohibited from US investments. The decision was made in response to an executive order signed by former US President Donald Trump in November 2020. CNOOC has the right to appeal the decision, which will be submitted to the US Securities and Exchange Commission upon completion of procedures. The NYSE will include any appeal in its application.

site_title: Further scope to review wealth taxes: Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that Singapore will review its wealth taxes, but it won't replace the need for a goods and services tax (GST) hike. Heng said the government will consider property-related taxes, but must balance progressivity with staying competitive. He also emphasized the need for economic investments to emerge stronger from the Covid-19 crisis, with the possibility of using past reserves if the situation worsens. The government expects to fund expenditures without drawing on past reserves, but will review various options, including borrowing for education and special purpose borrowing for economic investments.

site_title: SGX queries Emerging Towns & Cities over Myanmar project
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has queried Emerging Towns & Cities (ETC) over its Myanmar project, Golden City, amid criticism from rights group Justice for Myanmar for doing business with the military. ETC has a 49% stake in the project, which has a 70-year lease to the Myanmar army. The SGX is seeking clarification on fundraising efforts and project details by March 1, putting on hold a proposed placement exercise and other fundraising activities. This move comes as Singapore is the biggest source of foreign investment into Myanmar.

site_title: Olam shortlists six bourses for big IPO of food ingredients unit
summary: Olam International, a Singapore-based agri-food giant, has shortlisted six bourses for its mega IPO of its food ingredients unit, Olam Food Ingredients (OFI), which is expected to be listed in the second quarter of next year. CEO Sunny Verghese stated that Singapore is among the contenders, but the company is evaluating other options. The IPO is expected to have a meaningful free float of 25-30%. The company aims to demerge OFI from its parent company, Olam Global Agri (OGA), through a full-fledged spin-off to avoid the "holdco discount" and value leakage.

images.alt_text: Mr Verghese says "full-fledged spin-off" of OFI will be the same route that OGA will undertake.

site_title: IHH Healthcare Q4 gain up 28%, excluding exceptional items
summary: IHH Healthcare's fourth-quarter underlying net profit rose 28% to RM371.8 million, driven by cost-cutting measures and better operational efficiency. Revenue declined 2% to RM3.8 billion due to pandemic-related delays. The company aims to double its return on equity over five years, with most growth driven by organic expansion. A cash dividend of four sen per share has been declared. Despite encouraging results, the firm remains cautious about the impact of vaccine roll-out on travel restrictions.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sasseur Real Estate Investment Trust posted an 18.8% rise in distribution per unit to 1.935 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2020, driven by a 4.7% appreciation of yuan against the Singapore dollar. In contrast, China Aviation Oil (CAO) saw a 27.6% drop in net profit to US$32.6 million for its second half ended Dec 31, 2020, due to the Covid-19 pandemic and increased expenses. First Resources reported a 5.8% drop in net profit to US$56.4 million for the half year ended December 2020, despite an 18.8% increase in revenue.

site_title: Landlords eager for Covid-era revamps find growing appetite from investors
summary: Investors in commercial real estate are regaining their appetite as interest rates near zero, with demand for short-term financing increasing. This is driven by the need for landlords to refurbish and upgrade properties while the pandemic continues to disrupt the economy. Investors are seeking higher yields for taking on risk, and are focusing on loans for multifamily housing units and industrial parks. Deals such as a $45 million loan for a vacant mall and a $22 million bank loan for a office building renovation are being closed, with investors like Aflac and Sound Point Capital Management investing in partnerships to lend money to landlords.

site_title: Oil drops on US dollar strength and Opec+ supply expectations
summary: Oil prices dropped on Friday as the US dollar rose, with Brent crude futures falling 74 cents to $66.14 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures falling $1.42 to $62.11. The US dollar's rise, driven by near-one-year high bond yields, made dollar-priced oil more expensive for holders of other currencies. Investors are betting on increased supply from Opec+ next week, which may put downward pressure on prices. Despite supply disruptions and optimism over demand recovery, the demand side of the market is not warranting current oil prices.

site_title: Trial for Moderna's Covid variant vaccine begins in March: Fauci
summary: US to begin clinical trial in mid-March of a Covid-19 vaccine specific to the South Africa variant, with 210 people participating to study immune response and safety. The trial will compare different vaccine strategies against the B.1.351 strain, which partially reduces vaccine effectiveness. The trial's outcome will determine future production of the vaccine, which may or may not be authorized by the FDA. The trial's results will also inform the US response to potential future variants.

images.alt_text: The US will begin in mid-March a clinical trial of a version of Moderna's Covid vaccine specific to the South Africa variant, Anthony Fauci, the top advisor to the White House on the pandemic, said on Friday.

site_title: NanoFilm Technologies FY2020 net profit rises 61%
summary: NanoFilm Technologies, a Singapore-based nanotechnology solutions provider, reported a 61.1% rise in net profit to S$57.6 million for FY2020, outpacing 52.8% revenue growth to S$218.3 million. The improvement was driven by increased revenue from its advanced materials and nanofabrication business units, while its industrial equipment business unit saw a 10% decrease in revenue. This was NanoFilm's first financial report since listing on the Singapore Exchange mainboard in October 2020.

site_title: Can Clubhouse move fast without breaking things?
summary: Clubhouse, an 11-month-old audio social network, has gained over 10 million users, sparking a mad dash among investors and celebrities. The app's popularity has raised concerns about moderation, data privacy, and the potential for abuse, echoing the life cycle of earlier social networks. Despite its unique features, such as moderated rooms and a lack of ads, Clubhouse faces challenges from competing platforms and the need to scale moderation efforts. The app's potential to create a more thoughtful alternative to existing social networks remains, but it must address its issues to survive.

site_title: European officials urge World Bank to exclude fossil-fuel investments: sources
summary: European officials have urged the World Bank to expand its climate change strategy to exclude investments in oil- and coal-related projects, and phase out investment in natural gas projects, according to a six-page letter. The letter, from major European shareholder countries and Canada, welcomes moves to reduce carbon emissions but calls for further action. The World Bank is already finalizing a second-phase climate action plan, which includes recommendations to exclude coal- and oil-related investments and phase out gas power generation. The Bank's President, David Malpass, has vowed to make record investments in climate change mitigation and adaptation.

site_title: UOL full-year profit dives 97% to S$13m; better second-half more than offsets H1 loss
summary: UOL Group's full-year profit plummeted 97% to S$13.1 million due to significant losses from investment properties and lower revenue from most segments. The decline in office demand and uncertain retail outlook are expected to continue, with a 13% fall in revenue to S$1.98 billion. Despite this, the group's property development and technology operations segments saw higher revenue recognition. A dividend of 15 cents per share was proposed, and shares fell 1.73% to S$7.39.

site_title: In China, an electric-car maker loses money but thinks big
summary: China's electric car maker Nio, despite losing money on each car, is gaining investors' confidence due to its access to the country's well-funded supply chain. With 14 years of sustained government investment and regulations forcing multinational companies to transfer electric technologies to Chinese manufacturers, Nio can order parts inexpensively and assemble cars with the help of state-controlled automaker JAC. Nio plans to expand production and offer high-quality family electric cars at $25,000 or less, with a new model expected to double the range of its current entry-level sedan.

images.alt_text: Rows of bright orange, 15-foot-tall robots - mainly from Sweden - help assemble electric cars at the Nio factory in Hefei, China.

site_title: Bond rout shows risk of uneven recovery in world's top economies
summary: The US economy is expected to recover from the Covid-19 slump faster than other developed-world economies, causing bond market volatility and potentially exacerbating global imbalances. The US is forecast to expand 6.2% this year, while the euro area, Japan, and UK won't reach pre-Covid-19 GDP until 2022. This uneven recovery may lead to tensions over trade and currencies, and deepen inequality between countries. G-20 leaders are under pressure to prevent the gap with the world's poorest nations from widening further and to address the uneven recovery in their own economies.

site_title: US air strikes on Iran-backed militias in Syria kill at least one fighter
summary: US air strikes in eastern Syria targeted Iran-backed militias, killing at least one fighter and wounding several others. The strikes, authorized by President Joe Biden, aimed to deter further attacks on US personnel in Iraq, following a series of rocket attacks. The limited response was designed to avoid major regional escalation, and the US is seeking maximum leverage in negotiations with Iran over the 2015 nuclear deal.

site_title: Jaguar F-Type: Sultry new looks for a car worthy of applause
summary: The Jaguar F-Type has undergone a facelift, resulting in a more sultry and appealing design. The car's new features include a 12.3-inch digital instrument display, a larger touchscreen system, and bigger brakes and 20-inch wheels. However, the ride is bumpy, and the car lacks excitement, particularly in its 2.0-liter engine. The V8 version, with 450 horsepower, is recommended over the 2.0 model, offering a wild ride and a more dramatic experience. The F-Type's price tag of S$377,999 is steep, but the car's beauty and performance make it worth considering for those who can afford it.

site_title: Companies say they care about the climate, but their actions fall short
summary: Companies claiming to care about climate change often lack concrete targets to reduce emissions, with many setting weak or no targets at all. Despite this, some companies, like Google and Microsoft, have made significant progress in reducing their carbon footprint. However, a lack of regulatory standards and comprehensive disclosures makes it difficult to assess the true commitment of companies. According to Institutional Shareholder Services, only 33% of S&P 500 companies have set ambitious targets, while 215 have no target at all. Experts warn that without more ambitious targets, companies will struggle to meet the necessary emission reductions by 2050.

site_title: Bank of England's Haldane warns inflation 'tiger' is prowling
summary: Bank of England chief economist Andy Haldane warned that an inflationary "tiger" has emerged, posing a risk to the economy's recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. He cautioned that central banks may not be adequately prepared for potential inflation, which could lead to a more assertive monetary policy response. Haldane cited a smaller-than-expected economic slack and a glut of savings built during the pandemic as factors contributing to the inflation risk. His comments put him at odds with other MPC members, who are more relaxed about the inflation outlook.

site_title: GIC to buy 9% of Indonesia's Bank Jago to tap digital banking business
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC is set to purchase a 9% stake in Indonesian lender Bank Jago through a rights issue, spending up to $295 million. The move is aimed at tapping Bank Jago's digital banking business, which is set to become the first fully digital bank in Southeast Asia. The bank plans to use the funds to boost its capital to $8 trillion. The partnership with ride-hailing firm Gojek will allow users to manage their bank accounts on the app.

images.alt_text: Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC will purchase a stake in Bank Jago, a publicly-listed Indonesian lender that is set to become the first fully digital bank in South-east Asia's largest economy, a rights issue prospectus shows.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo from the US on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target and an operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC are to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, ahead of Singapore's GDP data release.

site_title: GIC to buy 9% of Indonesia's Bank Jago to tap digital banking business
summary: Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC will purchase a 9% stake in Bank Jago, Indonesia's first fully digital bank, through a rights issue valued at up to $295 million. The acquisition aims to tap into Bank Jago's digital banking business, which is expected to cater to Indonesia's unbanked population of up to one-third of its 270 million people. The bank's existing major shareholders will transfer their rights to GIC and other foreign institutional investors, boosting Bank Jago's capital to about $8 trillion.

site_title: Mortgage rates hit 6-month high, threatening US housing boom
summary: US mortgage rates have reached a 6-month high, with the average 30-year fixed loan rate at 2.97%, up from 2.81% last week. This marks the highest level since August, posing a threat to the pandemic housing boom. Rising rates, coupled with low inventory and soaring home prices, may limit homebuyers' competitiveness and purchasing power. Experts warn that the rapid jump in borrowing costs could slow the housing market, despite optimism about an economic recovery.

images.alt_text: With rates climbing, mortgage applications dipped to a nine-month low last week, while pending home sales in January fell to a six-month low.

site_title: Britain sets out blueprint to keep fintech 'crown' after Brexit
summary: Britain's government-backed review, led by Ron Kalifa, has proposed a plan to keep the UK's fintech industry competitive after Brexit. The plan includes a new £1 billion startup fund, fast-tracking work visas, and flexible listing rules. The review acknowledges that Brexit, Covid-19, and overseas competition have made the UK less attractive for fintechs. The government aims to make the UK a strong destination for fintech scale-ups and startups, and to simplify regulatory processes to attract talent and global markets.

site_title: Soaring US incomes help drive biggest spending gain since June
summary: US personal incomes surged 10% in January, the largest gain in nine months, driven by pandemic-relief checks and boosting consumer spending by 2.4%. Disposable incomes rose 13.3% from last year, and government transfer payments increased 52% due to stimulus checks and jobless benefits. The increase in spending and income growth is seen as fuel for the economy, particularly with a potential $1.9 trillion aid plan on the horizon, which could drive even more income growth and inflation.

site_title: Tom Holland goes through transformation in opioid crisis movie 'Cherry'
summary: Tom Holland underwent a physical transformation to play a drug-addicted war veteran in the new Russo brothers' movie Cherry. The 24-year-old actor, known for playing Spider-Man, lost and gained 30 pounds to portray the character. The film, inspired by Nico Walker's novel, tells the story of a young Ohio-native who becomes a bank robber after struggling with PTSD. The movie aims to highlight the opioid crisis and its impact on individuals, drawing from the Russos' own experiences with friends and family members affected by the issue.

site_title: Petrol duty increase meant to set price signals and change behaviour: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the petrol duty increase as part of a deliberate decision to protect the environment and change behavior. The move aims to set price signals and encourage people to make conscious choices about driving, with alternatives such as electric and hybrid vehicles also available. The government will offset the impact on drivers who rely on petrol for work, including taxi and private-hire car drivers, with additional rebates.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's factory output jumped 8.6% in January, driven by the semiconductor boom. The government expects to fund its spending without drawing on past reserves for the rest of its term, but keeps the option open if needed. Petrol duty was raised to set price signals and protect the environment. The decline in services revenue eased to -7.9% in Q4. The global chip shortage is expected to boost factory output in H1 2021.

site_title: Europe: Shares drop more than 1% as bond sell-off intensifies
summary: European stocks fell 1.5% on Friday, led by miners and technology stocks, amid concerns over lofty equity valuations and rising bond yields. This marked the benchmark European stock index's worst single-day fall this month. The sell-off intensified a bond sell-off, with investors seeking safer assets.

site_title: Becoming a tourist in my own country
summary: Singaporeans are turning to staycations as the pandemic restricts international travel, with many opting for luxury experiences and local attractions. The Singapore Tourism Board reports over 400,000 locals using their SingapoRediscovers vouchers, generating $51.8 million in revenue. To entice Singaporeans to explore their own country as a travel destination, experts suggest catering to different segments, such as families, seniors, and those seeking nature and wellness experiences. The Singapore Tourism Board plans to invest in new infrastructure and redevelopment projects, including reimagining the Singapore Racecourse and Wildlife Reserves attractions, to provide locals with new and exciting experiences.

site_title: Venture Corp H2 profit drops 8.1%
summary: Venture Corp reported a net profit of S$166.8 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2020, down 8.1% from S$181.5 million in H2 2019. Revenue decreased 8.6% to S$1.65 billion. Despite pandemic-related disruptions, H2 revenue showed a 20.6% improvement compared to H1. The company plans to scale up its photonics and semiconductor-related equipment segments to capture opportunities in the electric vehicle industry. A final cash dividend of 50 Singapore cents per share was proposed.

site_title: US: Nasdaq rises as bond yields retreat
summary: The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.6% to 13,193.01, rebounding from a 3.5% decline the previous day, as US Treasury yields retreated and markets anticipated progress on President Biden's economic relief package. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dipped 0.4%, while the S&P 500 added 0.2%. Tech shares were boosted by regulatory progress on Johnson & Johnson's single-dose coronavirus vaccine and partnerships with fast-food giants, while AT&T fell after announcing a spin-off of its assets. The House of Representatives was expected to vote on Biden's US$1.9 trillion rescue package.

site_title: Barclays found guilty of 'serious deceit' in 2008 fundraising, Staveley denied damages
summary: A London High Court judge has found Barclays guilty of "serious deceit" over its 2008 fundraising, but denied damages to Amanda Staveley's PCP Capital Partners. The court ruled that PCP succeeded in proving liability, but failed to demonstrate causation and loss, leading to the overall claim's failure. Staveley claimed £836 million in compensation, alleging Barclays lied to her when seeking private investment. The judge's decision was welcomed by Barclays, but Staveley plans to appeal.

site_title: Nissan says makes breakthrough with engine in reducing CO2 emissions
summary: Nissan Motor has achieved a breakthrough in its e-POWER hybrid technology, reaching a 50% thermal efficiency, which could lead to a 25% improvement in fuel consumption and further reduction in CO2 emissions. The company's goal is to maximize thermal efficiency to reduce emissions while driving. Nissan aims to electrify all its new models by the early 2030s to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050, with plans for over one million electrified vehicles per year by 2023. The company's e-POWER technology uses a petrol engine to charge a battery, and its latest advancements could accelerate the industry's transition to more sustainable vehicles.

site_title: Rising global government bond yields takes the shine off gold
summary: Gold prices ended the week at US$1,760 an ounce, failing to break above major support levels as rising global government bond yields took a toll. Despite a weakening dollar index, gold's price decline was attributed to the Fed chair's testimony, which did not mention new initiatives. Silver prices maintained their poise, consolidating around US$27.50, driven by growing economic growth optimism. The gold market is facing headwinds, but a rebound could occur if prices break above US$1,815, potentially leading to a resumption of the uptrend and investment flows into gold markets.

site_title: Top Glove plans to raise RM7.77b in Hong Kong listing
summary: Top Glove, the world's largest rubber glove maker, plans to raise up to RM7.77 billion through a Hong Kong listing to fund expansion and attract overseas investors. The company will issue up to 1.49 billion shares at a later-set price. This is the largest ever listing by a Malaysian company in Hong Kong, surpassing US$1 billion. The move comes as medical glove makers face heavy selling due to global vaccine rollouts. The listing will allow new investors to participate in the company's equity, and issuance of new shares will provide fresh capital without a cash call from existing shareholders.

site_title: Venture Corp H2 profit falls 8.1%
summary: Venture Corp reported a 6-month net profit of S$166.8 million, down 8.1% from S$181.5 million in 2019. Revenue decreased 8.6% to S$1.6 billion due to pandemic-related disruptions. Despite this, H2 revenue showed a 20.6% improvement compared to H1. The company plans to scale up its photonics and semiconductor segments to capture opportunities in the electric vehicle industry. It proposed a final cash dividend of 50 cents per share and shares closed at S$19.20, down 2.54%.

site_title: UOL Group posts 97% drop in FY2020 net profit
summary: UOL Group reported a 97% drop in FY2020 net profit to S$13.1 million due to attributable fair value and other losses of S$246.7 million. Revenue declined 13% to S$2 billion, mainly due to the COVID-19 impact on hotels in Singapore and Australia. The company proposed a 15 cents per share cash dividend, down from 17.5 cents in the previous year.

site_title: Covid-19 HealthCerts to ease travel; Smart Nation push continues with new cloud migration target
summary: Singapore's 2021 budget focuses on easing travel with the introduction of HealthCerts, a global standard for cross-border verification of Covid-19 test records. The government also aims to extend this technology to vaccine certificates. Additionally, the public sector will prioritize skills upgrading, with a new academy to hone digital skills. Minister Vivian Balakrishnan announced these initiatives during the Committee of Supply debate.

site_title: IHH Healthcare Q4 net profit surges to RM419.4m
summary: IHH Healthcare's fourth quarter net profit surged to RM419.4 million (S$137.5 million) in 2020, up from RM40.6 million in the previous year, due to lower base items and proactive debt management. Revenue shrank 2% to RM3.8 billion, while earnings per share rose 4.52 sen. The full-year net profit was RM288.9 million, down 48% from 2019, and revenue declined 10%. The company declared a first and final cash dividend of four sen per share to be paid out on April 30.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares plunge at end of tough week
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted over 3% on Friday, mirroring global market declines due to concerns about inflation and potential interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index fell 3.64% to 28,980.21, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 2.12%. Market worries stem from expected economic recovery this year, which could fuel inflation and prompt central banks to raise interest rates.

site_title: Global chip shortage should buoy Singapore factory output in H1 2021, watchers say
summary: Singapore's factory output surged 8.6% year-on-year in January, exceeding expectations, driven by the global chip shortage. The electronics cluster, particularly semiconductors, saw significant growth, with the sector expanding 19.8%. Precision engineering also rose 15.3%. However, the biomedical cluster declined 8.6% due to a drop in pharmaceutical production. Economists predict the strong start could push full-year growth forecasts upwards, but output may moderate in the second half as global chip supply catches up with demand.

site_title: Asian markets dip on Friday; STI ends 0.82% lower
summary: Asian markets ended the week in the red on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.82% due to rising US Treasury bond yields and inflation fears. The Nikkei 225 Index in Tokyo dropped 3.99%, while the Kospi in South Korea fell 2.80%. The Hang Seng Index in China declined 3.64%, and the Shanghai Composite Index fell 2.12%. Despite this, some local stocks, such as Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and UOB, saw gains.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday, down 3.79 points to 1,577.75, with a volume of 9.817 billion lots worth RM7.005 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 931 to 317.

site_title: Malaysia's Ambank to pay government RM2.83b in 1MDB-linked settlement
summary: Malaysia's banking group AmBank will pay RM2.83 billion to settle claims related to the 1MDB scandal, resolving a multi-billion-dollar financial scandal. The settlement follows former Prime Minister Najib Razak's conviction on corruption and money laundering charges linked to the scandal. The payment will expedite the resolution, allowing the 1MDB fund to fulfill its outstanding obligations, which total US$7.8 billion. The government had previously fined AmBank RM53.7 million for breaching financial regulations.

site_title: Huawei's CFO takes HSBC to Hong Kong court to gain documents
summary: Huawei's CFO, Meng Wanzhou, has summoned HSBC Holdings' local unit to a Hong Kong court hearing to gain access to documents related to transactions that allegedly violated US sanctions targeting Iran. The documents requested include those from late 2012 to 2015, regarding compliance and sanctions risk posed by Huawei and Skycom. Meng's lawyers claim lenders were aware of the company's connections to Iran-linked Skycom, while US authorities allege she misled banks into handling transactions that violated sanctions. The hearing is scheduled for March 12.

site_title: Ant to boost consumer finance unit capital as it restructures micro-lending: sources
summary: China's Ant Group is in talks with other shareholders to bolster its consumer finance unit's capital, requiring an additional 30 billion yuan (S$6.16 billion) to meet regulatory requirements. The unit, which will handle Ant's lucrative micro-lending businesses, aims to expand nationwide and maintain operations. Ant plans to shift its micro-lending businesses into the unit, allowing it to leverage up to 10 times its registered capital, unlike online micro-loan firms. The move aims to comply with new regulatory rules and capitalize on the growing demand for micro-lending in China.

site_title: Parliamentary budget office 'no substitute' for political courage: Indranee
summary: Indranee Rajah, Second Minister for Finance, has rejected the need for an independent budget office to scrutinize government spending, citing Singapore's strict fiscal prudence and AAA credit rating. She pointed out that the country has run balanced budgets and that the government has been upfront about making difficult budgetary choices. Indranee also questioned the relevance of a proposed S$20 million fiscal council, saying it would only serve the Opposition, and that the government does not need it.

images.alt_text: Indranee Rajah, Second Minister for Finance, in Parliament in November 2020.

site_title: Covid-19 HealthCerts to ease travel; Smart Nation push continues with new cloud migration target
summary: Singapore has developed a new global standard, HealthCerts, to ease cross-border verification of Covid-19 test records and vaccine certificates, aiming to ease travel restrictions. The initiative, developed by GovTech and the Ministry of Health, will allow travellers to upload and notarise digital Covid-19 pre-departure test certificates, which can be verified at airports and immigration checkpoints. The government also plans to extend this technology to vaccine certificates and aims to have 70% of eligible IT systems migrated to the cloud by 2023.

site_title: Eurozone bonds find some respite after dramatic selloff
summary: Eurozone government bond yields fell on Friday after a dramatic selloff, but Germany's benchmark yield remains on track for its largest monthly jump in three years. Rising inflation expectations and US fiscal stimulus hopes led to a surge in yields, with the European Central Bank's Isabel Schnabel stating that rate changes must be closely monitored. Despite a limited fall in yields, analysts warn that the bond market has entered crisis mode, and central banks may need to intervene to stabilize financial conditions. The eurozone's weaker economic and inflation outlook makes the rise in yields less justified.

site_title: Singapore government expects to fund this term's spending without further draw on past reserves
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that the government expects to fund the rest of its term's spending without drawing from past reserves, but may consider it if the fiscal situation worsens. Heng emphasized the need for economic investments to emerge stronger and urged caution, as a prolonged slump would increase the need for fiscal resources. The government will review its fiscal strategy, focusing on prudence and stewardship, and may study borrowing for special purpose investments to support economic growth.

site_title: Trouble in Yangon: Tracking the business impact of the military coup
summary: Myanmar's military coup on February 1 has led to widespread condemnation from countries and organizations worldwide, with five deaths reported so far. The crisis has impacted businesses, with Singapore firms continuing to operate despite escalating unrest and protests. The military's extensive business interests have raised concerns about the country's risk for foreign investors, with some multinationals pulling out or suspending operations. Analysts warn that investors may exit the country, and the currency may weaken, while others, like Sembcorp, remain committed to Myanmar's infrastructure assets.

site_title: NanoFilm posts 61.1% rise in profit in first report since mainboard listing
summary: NanoFilm Technologies reported a 61.1% rise in net profit to S$57.6 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2020, its first financial report since listing on the Singapore Exchange mainboard in October 2020. Revenue grew 52.8% to S$218.3 million, driven by increased revenue from advanced materials and nanofabrication business units. The company attributed the profit increase to economies of scale and operational excellence, and stated it is well-positioned for growth in existing and new markets.

site_title: Indonesia permits private Covid-19 vaccination scheme
summary: Indonesia has authorized a private COVID-19 vaccination scheme, allowing companies to buy state-procured vaccines to inoculate staff. The initiative, approved by a government regulation, aims to speed up vaccinations and reopen the economy. However, health experts warn it could worsen inequity, citing concerns over corruption and commercialization. The scheme requires vaccines to differ from the current rollout and must be distributed by state-owned pharmaceutical company Bio Farma. Over 6,600 companies have signed up for the private scheme, with some seeking up to 70,000 doses.

site_title: Australia: Shares tumble as firmer bond yields, fall in tech stocks weigh
summary: Australian shares fell 2.4% to their lowest level in nearly a month, with tech stocks leading the declines, as global bond yields firmed on expectations of economic expansion and rising inflation. Yields on Australian and global bonds rose, prompting the Reserve Bank of Australia to launch an unscheduled bond buyback. Tech stocks dived 5.3% and energy stocks skidded 2.5%, with miners and financials also falling.

site_title: Bitcoin heads for worst weekly slide in a year amid selloff
summary: Bitcoin experienced its worst weekly slide in almost a year, dropping as much as 21% amid wider losses in risk assets. The cryptocurrency's price hit a low of $45,525 before recovering to $46,375. Market experts attribute the decline to growing expectations of higher growth and inflation, which is forcing traders to reevaluate their positions. Detractors argue that Bitcoin's surge is a speculative bubble, while proponents are concerned about its efficacy as a store of value and hedge against inflation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, increasing 1.64 points or 0.1% to 1583.18. Volume reached 723.6 million lots worth RM403.4 million, with losers beating gainers 607 to 133.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends down almost 4% after US rout
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index plummeted nearly 4% at close on Friday, following a US stock rout fueled by rising bond yields and inflation fears. The Nikkei ended at 28,966.01, while the Topix index dropped 3.21%. The decline comes amid concerns over global economic growth and the impact of rising interest rates.

site_title: China Aviation Oil posts 27.6% drop in H2 profit to US$32.6m
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 27.6% drop in second-half profit to US$32.6 million, mainly due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on gross profit and share of results from associates. Revenue declined 51.8% to US$5.14 billion, and net profit for the full year fell 43.7% to US$56.2 million. The company's board proposed a final dividend of 2.58 Singapore cents per share, subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: Decline in services revenue in Singapore eases to -7.9% in Q4
summary: Singapore's services sector revenue declined by 7.9% in Q4 2020, easing from a -10.2% decline in the previous quarter. This brings the full-year revenue decline to -8.3% compared to 2019's 3.2% growth. Larger declines were recorded in recreation and personal services (-37.6%), transportation and storage (-22.4%), and administrative and support services (-22.5%). However, the information and communications services industry saw a 12.1% growth, driven by software publishers and gaming firms.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Shares plunge at open
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 2.2% at the open, following steep losses on Wall Street, amid concerns that a global economic recovery will force central banks to raise interest rates. The Hang Seng Index fell to 29,412.13, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also dropped 2% and 2.1%, respectively. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US.

site_title: Planemaker Airbus unveils emissions data amid climate pressure
summary: Airbus has released emissions data, becoming the first planemaker to do so. The data shows estimated lifetime emissions of 740 million tonnes of CO2 equivalent (CO2e) for 863 jets delivered in 2019, and 440 million tonnes for 566 aircraft in 2020. Airbus aims to drive aerospace towards zero-emission flying with plans for a commercial aircraft powered by hydrogen by 2035. Environmentalist groups argue that flying itself needs to be curbed to have a meaningful impact on climate change.

site_title: Biden's minimum-wage increase ruled out of order for Senate
summary: US President Joe Biden's plan to raise the minimum wage to $15 per hour via his $1.9 trillion Covid-relief bill has been ruled out of order by Senate parliamentarian Elizabeth MacDonough. The ruling means Democrats will likely remove the wage provision from the bill, which would face broad Republican opposition. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer vowed to continue fighting for the wage hike, with Chairman Bernie Sanders proposing an amendment to tax corporations that don't pay workers at least $15 an hour.

site_title: Sias requests offer price revision, two-week extension for GL offer
summary: INVESTOR watchdog Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is calling for GL Limited's offeror to reconsider the offer price, citing concerns that it undervalues shareholders' holdings. Shareholders and an independent financial adviser believe the current S$0.70 per share is not fair, and a two-week extension of the offer deadline is needed for minority shareholders to understand the issues. The offeror had justified the price by citing Covid-19 operating conditions and premiums, but analysts argue that GL's hotel assets may be undervalued and that a privatisation exercise may not be opportune given recovering oil prices and the UK hospitality sector.

site_title: 13 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 13 new Covid-19 cases, all imported, bringing the total to 59,913. The cases were confirmed on Friday, with no community cases and no cases from migrant workers' dormitories. A 27-year-old teacher and a 33-year-old Malaysian man were previously confirmed with community cases. The Ministry of Health attributed the cases to individuals arriving from India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Indonesia, and the Philippines. The Singapore permanent resident, who tested positive, was asymptomatic despite receiving both doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post worst weekly fall in one month on foreign selloff
summary: South Korean shares fell 2.80% to 3,012.95 on Friday, marking the worst weekly decline in four weeks, due to a record foreign selloff following a sharp overnight drop in US tech shares and rising Treasury bond yields. The won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield rose. Technology giants Samsung and SK Hynix plummeted 3.28% and 4.71% respectively. Despite this, Kia rose 8.1% on potential partnership with Apple. The Bank of Korea plans to buy treasury bonds worth 5-7 trillion won during the first half of the year.

site_title: Airbnb and DoorDash log losses as they ride out pandemic
summary: Airbnb and DoorDash reported their first financial results as publicly traded companies, with Airbnb logging a loss of $3.9 billion and DoorDash reporting a loss of $312 million. Despite the losses, Airbnb is optimistic about the travel industry's recovery, while DoorDash faces challenges from price controls imposed by jurisdictions limiting its commissions. DoorDash shares fell 12% after the earnings release, but the company gained market share in the US and set new records for orders.

site_title: Development charge rates raised 0.3% for non-landed residential use, cut 1.5% for commercial use
summary: The Singapore government has revised development charge (DC) rates for various use groups. For non-landed residential use, DC rates were increased by 0.3% and cut by 1.5% for commercial use. The 1.5% cut applies to 60 sectors, including areas like the CBD and Little India. In contrast, 44 sectors for landed residential use saw rate increases ranging from 1% to 6%. The revisions take effect from March 1, 2021, and September 1, 2021.

site_title: Singapore factory output jumps by better-than-expected 8.6% in January
summary: Singapore's factory output surged 8.6% in January, exceeding forecasted 3.6% growth, driven by the semiconductor boom. The electronics cluster saw a 19.8% increase, while precision engineering and chemicals also rose. Biomedical output declined 8.6%, primarily due to a drop in pharmaceuticals output. The transport engineering cluster remained underperforming, but showed a gentler decline than the previous month. The growth is seen as a positive sign for the country's economy.

site_title: Huawei, reeling from US sanctions, plans foray into EVs: sources
summary: Huawei, reeling from US sanctions, plans to make electric vehicles under its own brand, with potential launches as early as this year. The company is in talks with state-owned Changan Automobile and BAIC Group's BluePark New Energy Technology to use their car plants to manufacture its electric vehicles. Huawei has started internally designing EVs and approaching suppliers, with Richard Yu, head of Huawei's consumer business group, shifting his focus to EVs. The move aims to capitalize on China's growing EV market, which is expected to reach 20% of overall auto sales by 2025.

site_title: Boeing 777 with engine trouble makes emergency landing in Moscow
summary: A Boeing 777 airliner made an emergency landing in Moscow due to engine problems, with the crew reporting "incorrect operation of the engine control sensor" on a flight from Hong Kong to Madrid. The incident occurred just days after another 777 model experienced engine failure and debris scattered over the US. The Moscow landing was without incident, and the aircraft will continue its journey to Madrid after a delay. No injuries were reported.

site_title: Japan to end state of emergency for six prefectures this month
summary: Japan will end a state of emergency in six prefectures, including Osaka, Kyoto, and Fukuoka, by the end of the month, a week earlier than scheduled, due to declining new coronavirus cases. The move comes with conditions, including close monitoring of the spread of new virus strains and sufficient hospital beds. The government is also warning against complacency, particularly among young people, and emphasizes the need for strict anti-infection measures. The remaining four prefectures, including Tokyo, will still be under the state of emergency until March 7.

site_title: Facebook restores news for Australian users after media bargaining deal
summary: Facebook has restored news access for Australian users after reaching a deal with the government, requiring tech firms to pay for journalistic content. The ban was lifted after Facebook and Google negotiated paid arrangements with Australian media outlets, including News Corp and Nine Entertainment. The agreements mark a new foray into content payment for Facebook and Google, who will invest around $1 billion in news over the next three years. Facebook will pay providers who appear on its "News" feature, while Google will pay for content on its "Showcase" product.

site_title: Sasseur Reit posts 18.8% rise in Q4 DPU to 1.935 S cents
summary: Sasseur Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, reported a 18.8% rise in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.935 Singapore cents in the fourth quarter of 2020, from 1.629 cents a year ago. The trust's rental income under entrusted management agreements increased 23% to S$34.7 million, while distributable income rose 19.7% to S$23.3 million. The portfolio occupancy level remained stable at 93.5% in the quarter.

site_title: Britain's Queen says Covid jab 'didn't hurt' as she urges take-up
summary: Queen Elizabeth II, 94, says her COVID-19 jab "didn't hurt at all" and urged those wary of vaccination to consider others. The monarch, who received the jab in January along with Prince Philip, now feels "protected." Over 18 million people in Britain have been vaccinated as part of the rollout, which the Queen praised for its speed. She compared the pandemic's community spirit to World War II, saying it has inspired a similar sense of unity.

site_title: Centurion sinks into the red with S$3.8m net loss for H2 FY2020
summary: Centurion Corp, a Singapore-based accommodation provider, reported a net loss of S$3.8 million for the second half of its fiscal year 2020, compared to a net profit of S$81.9 million in the same period last year. The company attributed the decline to lower occupancy due to the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly in its student accommodation portfolio in Australia and the UK. Despite the challenges, Centurion remains optimistic about its student accommodation assets and expects a slow recovery in occupancy for most of its markets in 2021.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks drop 3% on Wall St tech rout, higher US yields
summary: South Korean shares dropped 3% on Friday, reversing gains from the previous session, due to a tech rout on Wall Street and rising US Treasury yields. The benchmark Kospi fell 85.74 points to 3,013.95, with technology giants Samsung and SK Hynix slumping 3.6% and 4.4% respectively. Despite this, South Korea's exports likely grew for a fourth straight month in February, driven by improving global trade and demand for semiconductors and cars. The Bank of Korea plans to make treasury bond purchases worth around 5-7 trillion won this year.

site_title: Australia lifts ban on Boeing 737 MAX, among first in Asia-Pacific region
summary: Australia's aviation regulator has lifted a near two-year ban on flights to and from the country that use the Boeing 737 MAX planes, becoming the first in the Asia-Pacific region to do so. The regulator accepted the comprehensive return-to-service requirements set by the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) as the state of design for the 737 MAX, citing confidence in the aircraft's safety.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts raise target price on UOB as net interest margin bottoms out
summary: Analysts at DBS have raised their target price on United Overseas Bank (UOB) to S$27.60 from S$22.20, citing a bottomed-out net interest margin. Analyst Lim Rui Wen expects a better business environment for local banks, with UOB's net interest margin forecasted to reach 1.57% in FY2021. The bank is poised for return-on-equity recovery as asset quality stabilizes and fee income growth is expected. Meanwhile, Maybank Kim Eng maintained a "hold" call on UOB, expecting loans to expand 7% in FY2021.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble on inflation worries, S&P 500 down 2.5%
summary: US stocks plummeted on Thursday, with the Dow Jones falling 1.8% to 31,402.01, and the S&P 500 sinking 2.5% to 3,829.24. Investors fear inflation will prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, despite assurances to the contrary. The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 3.5% to 13,119.43. Analysts point to a potential overheating of the US economy in the second half of 2021, driven by coronavirus vaccinations and a new government aid package.

site_title: Higher palm oil prices offset lower production output for Golden Agri
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported improved revenue and profits for its H2 FY2020, driven by higher crude palm oil (CPO) prices averaging US$691 per tonne in 2020, a 32% increase from the previous year. The company's downstream and upstream segments benefited from the price increase. With sustained prices expected, Golden Agri anticipates higher revenue in 2021.

site_title: First Resources posts 5.8% lower H2 net profit after booking expected credit losses
summary: First Resources reported a 5.8% lower net profit for the half year ended December 2020, despite a 18.8% revenue growth to US$382.2 million. The decline in profitability was attributed to expected credit losses from changes in fair value of biological assets and unquoted investment. Excluding the writeback of expected credit losses, the underlying net profit would have declined 10.1%. The company's full-year net profit was US$99.7 million, up 11.8% from the previous year.

site_title: Olam to list food ingredients business by 2022; reports S$87m H2 loss
summary: Olam International plans to list its food ingredients business, Olam Food Ingredients (OFI), by the first half of 2022 as part of its business reorganisation. OFI, which includes cocoa, coffee, and edible nuts, will be demerged from the company's grains and animal feed business, Olam Global Agri. The listing will be followed by a carve-out and separation of the two businesses by the end of 2021. Olam reported a net loss of S$87 million for the second half-year ended December 2020, reversing from its net profit a year ago.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 1.9% and the Topix index down 1.5%, amid fears about inflation and US Treasury yields reaching a 52-week high. Investors were disheartened by the rout on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened sharply lower Friday with investors disheartened by a rout on Wall Street, as US Treasury yields hit a new 52-week high amid ongoing fears about inflation.

site_title: Two self-made South Korea tycoons pledge to give away half their wealth
summary: Two South Korean billionaires, Kim Beom-su and Kim Bong-jin, have pledged to donate half of their fortunes, a rare move in a country dominated by family-controlled conglomerates. The philanthropic initiative, known as the Giving Pledge, was founded by Bill and Melinda Gates and Warren Buffett. Unlike most ultra-wealthy South Koreans, who are descendants of chaebol families, the Kims were born to working-class families and have built their fortunes through their own entrepreneurial efforts. Their pledge aims to address social issues and provide a better inheritance for their children.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, CDL, Yangzijiang, Golden Agri, First Resources
summary: Several Singaporean companies reported financial results on Friday, with notable losses and profits. Olam International announced plans to list its food ingredients arm by 2022, while City Developments Limited reported a net loss of S$1.92 billion. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's net profit rose 17% year-over-year, while Golden Agri-Resources posted a net profit of US$188.6 million. Other companies, including Hong Leong Finance, The Straits Trading Company, and First Resources, also reported significant changes in their financials.

site_title: The pandemic MBA: better business than usual
summary: Business schools in Singapore see a surge in MBA applications amid the pandemic, as people invest in the degree to secure their jobs when the economy recovers. The trend is driven by recession and Covid disruptions, with universities adapting to the new normal. The shift is expected to impact the job market, with experts predicting changes in the industry.

site_title: US dollar firms on sudden spike in Treasury yields
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.27% against a basket of currencies after 10-year US Treasury yields jumped to 1.6%, the highest in seven weeks, due to weaker-than-expected bids in a US government debt auction. The move is attributed to a growing belief that central banks may begin to pare back ultra-loose policies, driven by a strong economic rebound after the pandemic. Other commodity-linked currencies, such as the Australian, New Zealand, and Canadian dollars, also surged, while the euro rose to a three-week high.

site_title: Australia passes law requiring tech firms to pay for news
summary: Australia has passed a law requiring tech firms like Google and Facebook to pay for news content, aiming to sustain public interest journalism. The legislation allows for paid deals between tech giants and local media, potentially worth tens of millions of dollars. Facebook and Google have already brokered deals with major Australian media companies, and the tech firms plan to invest around $1 billion in news globally over the next three years. The move is seen as a precedent in the battle between Big Tech and regulators.

site_title: Gold slides more than 2% as US Treasury yields rise
summary: Gold prices fell 2.2% to a near one-week low on Thursday, dipping to US$1,772.86 per ounce, due to a surge in US Treasury yields and better-than-expected economic data. Higher bond yields eroded gold's status as a hedge against inflation, and data showed fewer Americans filing new unemployment claims. Silver, platinum, and palladium also declined, with silver falling 1.9% and platinum dropping 3.5%.

site_title: Mr Potato Head goes gender neutral
summary: Hasbro has announced that its iconic Mr. Potato Head toy will be rebranded as simply "Potato Head" to promote gender equality and inclusion. The change, set to be implemented in the fall, will be accompanied by a new "Potato Family Pack" and more inclusive messaging. GLAAD has applauded the move, citing its potential to encourage kids to see toys as neutral and promote self-acceptance. This decision is part of a larger trend by toy makers to update classic brands to make them more diverse and inclusive.

site_title: GameStop jumps nearly 19%; 'meme stocks' fade after another wild ride
summary: GameStop shares surged 18.5% on Thursday, closing at $108.73, after a sharp retreat from session highs, despite a 2.4% drop in the benchmark S&P. The rally, led by passionate retail investors on Reddit's WallStreetBets, followed a surprise resurgence of "meme stocks" championed by GameStop. Analysts attributed the rally to a fear of betting against the company and a short squeeze, with the number of GameStop shares shorted standing at 15.47 million.

site_title: Crypto firm Kraken seeks roughly US$10b valuation
summary: Kraken, a cryptocurrency exchange, is in talks to raise new funding, which could more than double its valuation to over $10 billion. The company, founded in 2011, is discussing with firms like Fidelity, Tribe Capital, and General Atlantic. This move comes as the crypto market experiences a surge in trading volume and attention as an asset class. Kraken's valuation could reach $20 billion depending on demand, following Coinbase Global's direct listing earlier this week, which valued the company at nearly $100 billion.

site_title: Singapore shares decline amid US inflation fears; STI down 1.4% at Friday's open
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.4% to 2,932.08 on Friday, tracking the overnight US stock market decline amid inflation fears. US Treasury yields hit a 52-week high, causing losses in banking stocks and major companies like City Developments, Olam International, and Singtel. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.8%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes fell 2.5% and 3.5%, respectively.

site_title: Thailand eager to cement its status as 'Detroit of S-E Asia' with EV push
summary: Thailand is pushing to solidify its position as the "Detroit of South-east Asia" by investing heavily in the electric vehicle (EV) market. China's Great Wall Motors Company (GWM) announced plans to build nine automobile models in Thailand, seven of which would be EVs. This move aims to capitalize on Thailand's existing automotive manufacturing expertise and become a regional leader in EVs. The country's efforts are part of its broader strategy to drive economic growth and diversify its economy.

site_title: Predicting the unpredictable future of ESG
summary: Singapore's recent budget prioritizes sustainability and green efforts, with a focus on increasing green bonds and deepening market liquidity. The country aims to anchor itself as a green finance hub and catalyze the flow of capital towards sustainable development. ESG investments have gained momentum globally, with record-high green bond issuance, but concerns arise about the authenticity of ESG investing and the challenges of adopting this approach in Asia-Pacific, where data availability, regulations, and benchmarks are limited. A virtual conference in March will discuss these challenges and potential solutions.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip as high yields, inflation concerns return to fore
summary: European shares ended 0.4% lower on Thursday, despite a rise in euro zone economic sentiment, as higher bond yields and inflation concerns weighed on major sectors. Commodity-linked sectors, such as healthcare and utilities, fell amid pressure from higher yields, while sectors like steel pipe maker Tenaris rose 13.7% on strong quarterly sales. Weak earnings from Standard Chartered and Anheuser-Busch also contributed to the decline.

site_title: CDL charts next steps for Sincere, hotels after S$1.92b loss
summary: CDL, a Singapore-based real estate giant, has posted a net loss of S$1.92 billion for 2020, its first full-year loss since the 1970s. The loss was largely due to a non-cash S$1.78 billion write-down on its investment in China-based Sincere Property Group. CDL is now focusing on unlocking "deep value" in its London subsidiary's hotel portfolio and nursing Sincere back to health. The company is also exploring the establishment of a Reit with UK commercial assets, which could be listed in Singapore. CDL's shares fell 2% to close at S$7.36 after the announcement.

site_title: Oil mixed, US crude hits highest since 2019 as refineries restart
summary: US crude oil prices reached their highest close since 2019, closing at $63.53 a barrel, as Texas refineries restarted production after a freeze. Brent futures fell 0.2% to $66.88 a barrel. The US crude production drop due to the freeze was over 10%, while refining runs tumbled to levels not seen since 2008. Analysts expect price gains to slow ahead of the Opec+ meeting on March 4, citing the risk of new setbacks in the pandemic and potential easing of oil supply curbs.

site_title: Li Ka-shing planning to raise funds by listing SPAC in US
summary: Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing's family is planning to raise funds by listing a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) in the US, with a potential IPO of around $400 million. The company, backed by Li's family, is working with advisers and could file registration documents with the US Securities and Exchange Commission as soon as this week. This move comes after Li's younger son, Richard, has raised $900 million via two US-listed SPACs.

site_title: Netflix plans US$500m S Korea budget this year to crack Asia
summary: Netflix plans to invest $500 million in original content in South Korea this year, boosting its presence in the country's rapidly growing market. With 3.8 million paid subscribers, South Korea is Netflix's third-largest market in Asia, following Australia and Japan. The investment will fund a growing slate of dramas, reality TV, and documentaries, including the first Korean sitcom, So Not Worth It. This move aims to sustain Netflix's recent growth in Asia, where it has created over 200 original films and series and added 9.2 million customers last year.

site_title: Yellen backs new allocation of IMF's own currency to help poor nations
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen backs a new allocation of the IMF's Special Drawing Rights (SDR) to help poor nations, reversing the Trump administration's opposition. The allocation could boost liquidity for low-income countries, particularly those hard hit by the global pandemic. Yellen calls for broad parameters to enhance transparency and accountability in SDR usage. The Biden administration has backed a US$500 billion allocation, with the IMF approving a last allocation of US$250 billion in 2009.

site_title: Leadership is not about the leader
summary: Leadership is not solely about the leader, but a collective process where everyone in a social unit or organization plays a role in shaping the climate and culture towards a better future. The traditional view of leadership, which focuses on the leader's traits and power, has been challenged by social scientists who argue that collective views of leadership are more effective. This understanding is essential in today's world, where organizations and societies face numerous challenges that require a collective effort. By embracing a culture of collective leadership, individuals can create psychological safety, foster boundary spanning, and distribute power to achieve a better future.

site_title: Indonesia banks on lithium batteries, EVs
summary: Indonesia aims to become a major player in the global electric vehicle (EV) market, leveraging its rich natural resources, particularly nickel and lithium. By 2027, the country is expected to become the world's second or third-largest producer of lithium batteries, supported by its growing downstream industry. Car giants Hyundai and Tesla are studying the possibility of establishing EV manufacturing plants in Indonesia, with Fitch Solutions predicting Tesla's investment will propel the country into a global player. Indonesia also sets an ambitious target of having 2.1 million electric motorcycles and 2,200 electric cars on its roads by 2025.

site_title: Trump supporters want to 'blow up' Capitol, police chief warns
summary: US Capitol Police Acting Chief Yogananda Pittman warned lawmakers that Trump supporters who stormed the Capitol on January 6th have expressed a desire to "blow up" the building and kill members of Congress. The threats come ahead of President Joe Biden's State of the Union address, prompting the police to maintain enhanced security measures. Over 200 people have been charged for their roles in the riot, including those with ties to far-right groups. The police are concerned that the threat of violence could target the building during the State of the Union address.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump supporters who launched a deadly assault on the US Capitol last month have indicated they want to "blow up" the building and kill members of Congress, the acting chief of the Capitol Police said on Thursday.

site_title: Commodity prices: a bull run in the Year of the Ox?
summary: Commodity prices may be nearing their trough after a bull run, but a new era of rising prices is unlikely, according to experts. A current commodity price cycle initiated in 1998 reached its peak in 2011 and is now expected to decline. Historical data suggests that real commodity prices have increased by 0.18% per year from 1950, with two complete cycles, but not all commodities are created equal, with some experiencing downward price trends. Policymakers and investors should approach commodity markets on a commodity-by-commodity basis, rather than assuming a new "supercycle."

site_title: Petrochemical giant Dow braces for 'high impact' from climate change: Executive
summary: Dow Inc, the third-largest petrochemical producer, is adapting to climate change by reducing its carbon footprint and developing products to help customers cut emissions. The company aims to become carbon neutral by 2050 through increased renewable energy use and energy efficiency improvements. Dow is developing lightweighting materials for electric vehicles, sealants for heating efficiencies, and products for a circular economy. The company is also collaborating with traditional manufacturers and startups in China to tap into the growing electric vehicle market.

site_title: London high rises are investors' fix for ghostly shopping malls
summary: Investors are transforming London's aging shopping malls into mass housing blocks, with over 80 projects underway. Landlords, including BlackRock and DWS, are converting dated properties into apartment towers to capitalize on the city's housing shortage and high residential property values. However, the move has raised concerns about affordability, safety, and the impact on local infrastructure, particularly in poorer boroughs. While some investors are betting on rental housing, others are relying on rents recovering to make the project financially viable.

site_title: Maybank posts 37% drop in Q4 net as impairments rise
summary: Maybank, Malaysia's largest lender, reported a 37% drop in Q4 net profit to RM1.54 billion due to a 227.5% increase in impairment losses and declines in net interest income and Islamic banking income. The company's 2020 full-year net profit fell to RM6.48 billion, down from RM8.2 billion in 2019. Despite a challenging operating environment amid the coronavirus pandemic, Maybank aims to mitigate further net interest margin compression by focusing on lower-cost deposits and fee-based income opportunities.

site_title: Increased interest in electric vehicles suggests tipping point in Singapore
summary: Singapore is moving towards a tipping point in electric vehicle adoption, driven by increased interest and government incentives. The country aims to have 60,000 charging points by 2030, with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat introducing incentives to encourage early adoption. However, limited vehicle choices and charging infrastructure remain barriers, with only 14 passenger vehicle models available in Singapore. The government is positioning itself to ride the EV wave, with the potential to manufacture EVs and enter the downstream value chain, including recycling rare-earth elements.

site_title: The smart car buying guide
summary: There is no relevant article to summarize as the provided links are not related to the article "The smart car buying guide".

site_title: Businesses should seek opportunities across all industries: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore has emerged from the Covid-19 crisis, shifting its focus from "survival mode" to "emerging stronger". Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for businesses to seek opportunities across all industries, citing sectors such as infocomm, communication technology, and professional services. Despite downside risks, Singapore can capitalize on its strong supply chain links and position itself as a hub for financial services and trade. The government will facilitate change by enabling progressive rules and regulations, while companies and workers must adapt to seize opportunities and transform.

site_title: Zoom era sees boom in US plastic surgeries
summary: US plastic surgery procedures have seen a 64% surge in virtual consultations since the COVID-19 pandemic, with surgeons citing a rise in people seeking procedures to address Zoom-related insecurities, such as double chins and neck sagging. Virtual consultations have also led to a 50-60% increase in surgical procedures, with the top sought-after procedures being upper eyelid and neck surgeries. Patients have taken advantage of the pandemic to address insecurities and boost their confidence, with many undergoing procedures that had been delayed.

site_title: Singapore not expected to move out of Phase 3 'any time soon': Janil Puthucheary
summary: Singapore is not expected to move out of Phase 3 of its Covid-19 reopening "any time soon," said Senior Minister of State for Health Janil Puthucheary. To exit Phase 3, Singapore must see evidence of vaccine effectiveness, substantial vaccination of the population, and global control of the virus. The country has seen an increase in unlinked cases and community clusters, prompting tightened community safe management measures. The government is also considering providing more options for dedicated stay-home notice facilities for travellers.

site_title: Xi declares 'complete victory' in drive to end China rural poverty
summary: China President Xi Jinping declared "complete victory" in eradicating rural poverty, lifting nearly 100 million people from poverty. Xi attributed the success to the Communist Party's leadership and China's socialist system. The country has invested 1.6 trillion yuan in poverty alleviation over the past eight years. A new National Rural Revitalisation Bureau was established, replacing an office for poverty alleviation and development. Xi's leadership is seen as a milestone in his eight-year tenure, with some experts noting China's definition of poverty as a low bar that requires sustained investment for continued development.

site_title: City of London approves third new skyscraper within a month
summary: The City of London Corporation approved a third new office tower in less than a month, with British Land Co and GIC Pte Ltd's 38-story development at 2 Finsbury Avenue receiving the green light. The project will provide 83,000 square meters of new workspace, despite banks cutting their office footprints. Developers believe demand will endure for high-quality buildings to attract and retain staff post-pandemic. The approval comes as finance firms such as Lloyds Banking Group and HSBC Holdings slash office space and costs.

site_title: Risks and rewards of the return of Chinese firms to India
summary: China's mobile company Vivo has returned as the title sponsor of India's Indian Premier League (IPL) cricket tournament after a year-long suspension following a border clash between the two countries. The move signals a thaw in Sino-Indian relations, with Chinese investors set to receive faster approval for foreign direct investment (FDI) proposals. Vivo's return is seen as a positive development for both sides, with the IPL expected to gain from the increased investment and Vivo looking to boost its corporate image in the country. However, the move also carries a risk of backfiring if border tensions escalate again.

site_title: Oil hovers near 13-month highs
summary: Oil prices reached 13-month highs for the fourth consecutive session, driven by low US interest rates and a drop in US crude output due to a Texas storm. Brent crude futures rose 33 US cents to $67.37 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 23 cents to $63.45 a barrel, both hitting their highest levels since January 8, 2020.

site_title: A classic in its own right
summary: Zenith's new Chronomaster Sport watch has been met with excitement, but its CEO, Julien Tornare, assures it's not a copycat of the Rolex Cosmography Daytona. The watch features a high-frequency chronograph movement, a ceramic bezel, and a stainless steel case inspired by 1969's El Primero A 386. Tornare emphasizes the watch's legitimacy, citing Zenith's long history with the El Primero movement and its connection with Rolex. The watch's readability and modern design have also been praised, making it a flagship model for Zenith's Chronomaster collections.

site_title: Recovery in Thailand to be patchy; govt reliefs planned
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to recover unevenly from the COVID-19 pandemic, with a patchy recovery predicted. The central bank estimates the economy may return to pre-pandemic levels in the third quarter of 2022. Exports are expected to recover, with a 5.5% expansion excluding weaker gold shipments. The tourism sector is expected to take longer to recover due to 10 months of travel curbs, but the government plans to introduce relief measures to support tourism and struggling smaller firms. Economic growth is forecast to reach the upper 2% levels this year.

site_title: A taste of things to come
summary: Waku Ghin, a 10-year-old Singapore flagship restaurant of Tetsuya Wakuda, has reopened its bar for pre-dining experiences, drawing in regulars despite not officially reopening for dining until March 1. This follows a busy February for the restaurant, which has seen a growing appetite for dining experiences as travel plans remain in limbo. Other notable restaurant openings and reopenings include Joel Robuchon, Mauro Colagreco's Carne, and Odette's Julien Royer, who will take over The White Rabbit in Dempsey Hill. Basque Kitchen by Aitor will also move to the Fullerton Waterboat House in April.

site_title: Timeless Japanese classics
summary: Chef Tetsuya Wakuda's new Waku Ghin restaurant at Marina Bay Sands is set to open on March 1, offering an upscale dining experience with a focus on seasonal, premium ingredients sourced from exclusive farms in Japan. The restaurant features a contemporary space designed by Yohei Akao, with a separate bar area offering an ala carte menu. The menu, described as "even more Japanese," features classic Wakuda dishes with a signature twist, including premium wagyu and microgreens. The bar serves cocktails and snacks, with no difference in quality between bar and dining room offerings.

site_title: Hongkongers snapping up more homes in UK to lease out
summary: Hong Kong residents are buying homes in the UK to lease out, driven by a wave of emigration expected after China's national security law. The trend includes middle-class residents pooling money to invest, with over 300,000 predicted to emigrate over the next five years. UK residents are offering a new visa to Hong Kong BNO passport holders, which may encourage more to invest in properties. This new wave of buying is increasing interest in older apartments and houses as rental assets, with some residents using rental income to finance living expenses and future property purchases.

site_title: Biden's trade nominee says China is both a rival and a partner
summary: US President Joe Biden's nominee for trade chief, Katherine Tai, has pledged to work with allies to take on China, but also to engage in a pragmatic approach with the Asian nation, recognizing both its rival and partner status. Tai, a progressive Democrat, has a reputation for finding common ground and will play a key role in setting and implementing Biden's trade policy, focusing on workers and the middle class. She will likely face questions on the US-China trade deal and tariffs on Chinese goods, and her approach will be seen as a departure from the Trump administration's chaotic trade agenda.

site_title: Tech expansion in Singapore fans tussle for talent
summary: Tech firms in Singapore are facing a talent shortage, with companies such as Grab, Razer, and Dell Technologies announcing over 1,500 new job openings. Despite the growing demand, industry experts warn that supply may outstrip demand for years, prompting a focus on training and reskilling mature workers. The government is also launching initiatives to upskill workers, while companies are advised to consider non-technical skills and cultural fit in their hiring processes. This talent shortage could lead to a boom in the tech industry, with experts predicting more companies will add positions in the next five to ten years.

site_title: Nature bonds may be next big thing for EMs
summary: Emerging-market nations are exploring the use of nature-linked bonds to make their debt more sustainable. The World Bank and major sovereign creditors are discussing the proposal, which would tie debt repayments to targets for biodiversity and carbon emissions. Pakistan is set to issue a $1 billion nature-performance bond this year, with the goal of reducing its reliance on coal and increasing green energy. The move aims to integrate nature and climate into sovereign debt more systemically, potentially creating a new instrument for financing sustainable development.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Indian duet Tiffin Room and Samy's Curry unite for a joint dining event at Raffles Hotel's Tiffin Room, blending North and South Indian specialties for two weeks. The event features elegant surroundings, starters like tandoori prawns, and signature dishes like Mysore mutton and fish curry. This collaboration showcases a spicy medley of Tiffin's grilled tandoor specialties and Samy's flavorful curries inspired by India's coastal regions.

site_title: Racing for time
summary: TAG Heuer and Porsche have collaborated on a striking watch, the Carrera Porsche Chronograph, solidifying their 50-year partnership rooted in motor sports. The chronograph timepiece is inspired by the Carrera Panamericana road race and features Porsche's design aesthetic, including a tachymeter scale and red inscription. The watch is powered by an in-house movement with 80-hour power reserve and is available in two versions: a stainless steel bracelet and a soft calf leather strap. This collaboration marks the first joint project between the two brands, with more collaborations planned in golf, tennis, and other fields.

site_title: Lufthansa adds more summer holiday destinations in bet on recovery
summary: Lufthansa is adding 20 new summer holiday destinations from Frankfurt and 13 from Munich, aiming for a strong rebound in bookings as Covid-19 vaccines and testing are expected to make vacation travel possible. The airline plans to expand to the Caribbean, Canary Islands, and Greece, with strict hygiene rules and prerequisites for travel. Lufthansa expects a sharp increase in demand once restrictions are lifted, driven by a "great yearning for travel" and a gradual relaxation of coronavirus restrictions in Europe.

site_title: Currency markets turn 'risk on'; US dollar down
summary: The US dollar index dropped 0.3% against a basket of currencies, while risk currencies rose to three-year highs due to dovish signals from the US Federal Reserve. The euro surged against the Swiss franc, reaching a one-month high, as investors shifted away from safe-haven currencies.
