The Australian and Canadian dollars also hit new three-year highs against the US dollar, driven by the reflation trade and accelerating Covid-19 vaccine rollouts. Oil prices have rallied 30% since the start of the year, supporting commodity-linked currencies.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall more than expected
summary: US initial jobless claims fell to 730,000 for the week ended Feb 20, beating economists' forecasts of 838,000, but the near-term labor market outlook remains unclear due to winter storms in the South. Daily coronavirus cases and hospitalizations have dropped, allowing businesses to reopen, but persistently high claims are partly attributed to fraud in Ohio and a global semiconductor chip shortage. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell confirmed the central bank will keep interest rates low until substantial progress is made towards maximum employment and inflation.

site_title: Twitter aims to double revenue in three years; shares surge
summary: Twitter aims to double its annual revenue to $7.5 billion by 2023 and increase its user base by 20% annually for the next three years, reaching 315 million daily active users. The company also aims to "double development velocity" of product shipments, doubling the number of features shipped per employee. Twitter's shares surged 12% to a record high of $80.75 following the announcement, which was made in conjunction with its first Analyst Day since 2014.

site_title: Travel quarantines: Enduring the mundane, one day at a time
summary: Travelers worldwide are facing mandatory government quarantines in hotels, often with limited freedom and financial costs. These quarantines can last up to two weeks, during which time travelers are confined to their rooms and may not have a choice in their accommodations. Some travelers, like Pete Lee, chose their quarantine hotels, while others were assigned by the government. To pass the time, travelers turned to activities like working remotely, exercising, and ordering food and grocery delivery. Social media and online communities helped alleviate the monotony and provided a sense of connection with others.

site_title: New school French cuisine
summary: Chef Louis Pacquelin, an Alain Ducasse protégé, is opening Clos Pasoh, a new French cuisine restaurant, on March 1. Pacquelin credits Ducasse for his culinary success, having worked under him since age 16. The restaurant is a tribute to the French cuisine Pacquelin grew up with, reflecting Ducasse's values and influence.

site_title: Far East Orchard's full-year profit down 94%
summary: Far East Orchard's net profit for FY20 dropped 94% to S$1.54 million due to the pandemic's impact on its hospitality business, with revenue 28.1% lower at S$112.21 million. The company expects FY21 performance to remain under pressure, with its hospitality segment being the largest contributor to recurring income. The board recommends a dividend of 3 Singapore cents per share, down from 6 cents last year, amid ongoing border closures and limited international travel.

site_title: GameStop shares rise in early trade before being halted
summary: GameStop shares surged in early trading on Thursday, reaching a high of US$160 before being halted due to trading activity, following a 100% surge on Wednesday. The rally, fueled by retail traders on social media, has puzzled analysts, who note that short interest is lower than last time, and some may not participate in this episode. The stock's price is still below its peak of US$483 in January, and analysts caution that the rally is likely to be short-lived.

site_title: Growing focus on sustainability gives Singapore an edge in green economy
summary: Singapore's growing focus on sustainability gives the country an edge in the green economy, with businesses recognizing the need to differentiate themselves in the face of the climate crisis. The government has invested in initiatives such as the SME Sustainable Financing Framework to simplify access to green finance for small and medium-sized enterprises. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing notes that the sustainability agenda and economic efficiency can intersect, creating opportunities for Singapore to export sustainable solutions and develop a carbon trading market. The government aims to capitalize on these opportunities, with a focus on areas such as water and energy management.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reports higher profit for Q4 FY20; maintains dividend
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 17% year-on-year increase in Q4 FY20 net profit to 753.46 million yuan, driven by improved margins despite a 38% decline in revenue. The company maintained its FY20 dividend of 4.5 Singapore cents per share. CEO Ren Letian attributed the improvement to the group's R&D efforts and its position to capture emerging market opportunities as major economies recover. The company's full-year net profit shrank 19% to 2.52 billion yuan.

site_title: Auditor EY replaces Germany boss after Wirecard scandal
summary: Auditing firm EY has replaced its German office head, Hubert Barth, amid efforts to restore trust following the Wirecard scandal. Barth will remain at EY and lead a new European-level role. Henrik Ahlers and Jean-Yves Jegourel have taken over as leaders of the German office, focusing on strengthening quality and growth. The move comes after EY faced criticism for its role in Wirecard's collapse, with the firm denying wrongdoing and accusing the company of an "elaborate and sophisticated fraud."

site_title: China approves two more domestic Covid-19 vaccines, increasing number to four
summary: China has approved two more domestic Covid-19 vaccines, increasing the total number of approved vaccines to four. The newly approved vaccines are made by CanSino Biologics and Wuhan Institute of Biological Products, an affiliate of Sinopharm. The vaccines, which have an efficacy rate of 72.51%, can be stored at normal freezer temperatures, making them a potentially attractive option for developing countries. China has been exporting the Sinovac and earlier Sinopharm vaccines to countries worldwide, and the four approved vaccines join a growing list of domestic options available in China.

site_title: US bank regulators say pandemic drove up risk in leveraged lending
summary: US bank regulators warn that the COVID-19 pandemic increased risk in leveraged lending, with nearly 12.4% of large, syndicated loans being non-pass loans in 2020. Most of these riskier loans were held by nonbanks, with US banks accounting for 45% of the $5.1 trillion in large loans. Loan performance struggled in retail and transportation sectors, but regulators note that banks have improved risk management systems and increased loan-loss reserves since the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: Beaujolais: The wines of Fleurie offer more
summary: The article discusses the evolution of Beaujolais wines, particularly those from Fleurie, a region in eastern France. For years, Beaujolais has been associated with simple, easy-drinking wines, but recent developments suggest a shift towards more complex and thoughtful wines. Cru Beaujolais, made from specific grape varieties and vineyards, offer a range of flavors and styles, from fruity and floral to earthy and mineral. The article highlights three Fleurie wines, Clos de la Roilette, Domaine Chapel, and Jean-Louis Dutraive, showcasing their unique characteristics and aging potential. These wines demonstrate that Beaujolais is not just one type of wine, but rather a diverse and nuanced region with something to offer for every taste.

images.alt_text: The great thing about Beaujolais is that you can have it many different ways because it's not just one type of wine.

site_title: MPs debate Singapore's borrowing and expenditures
summary: Singapore's government is facing debate over its borrowing and expenditures, with MPs questioning the long-term fiscal approach. The government plans to issue up to S$90 billion in new bonds, while MP Jamus Lim suggested using these bonds to fund areas such as research and development and unemployment insurance. In contrast, MP Foo Mee Har urged caution and restraint in government borrowing, citing unsustainable reliance on debt. The government's expenditures have ballooned, and MPs are calling for a longer-term perspective on spending, with some advocating for stretching existing resources instead of dipping into reserves.

site_title: Wackadoodle Race is irresistibly funny
summary: The Amazing Celestial Race, a Singapore pantomime inspired by Chinese zodiac mythology, has been hailed as one of the best live theatre productions since the pandemic. Directed by Glen Goei, the show features a 25-character cast played by only five actors, showcasing ambition and ingenuity in the face of budget challenges and social distancing constraints. The show tells the story of how the Chinese zodiac came to be, with a unique blend of music, choreography, and puppetry. Despite limited seating and technical constraints, the production exudes an "irrepressible energy and wackadoodle spirit" that has captivated audiences.

images.alt_text: The animals use their wits to cross a river to win The Amazing Celestial Race, based on the Chinese zodiac mythology.

site_title: Singapore banks see improved asset quality in 2021 with recovery ahead
summary: Singapore banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB report improved asset quality in 2021, with lower credit costs expected as the bulk of provisions have been taken. DBS projects total allowances of S$3-5 billion, while OCBC and UOB expect credit costs to come in at the lower end of their two-year projections. The banks await guidance on lifting dividend caps, with OCBC and UOB seeking to resume dividend payouts once the cap is lifted. Capital levels have increased, with all three banks above the optimal CET-1 ratio range, potentially leading to increased dividends and potential merger and acquisition exercises.

site_title: Turning the Covid crisis into an opportunity of a generation
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 focuses on emerging from the Covid-19 crisis as a stronger nation, leveraging opportunities in the digital economy, and positioning the country as a trusted partner for investment. Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasizes the need to address downside risks, including the pandemic's impact and global geopolitics. He highlights areas of green shoots, such as the ICT industry, professional services, biomed, and the semiconductor sector. The government aims to create a favorable business environment, enabling companies to grow their top line while controlling costs. This includes initiatives like digital economy agreements, regulatory sandboxes, and green financing.

site_title: Britain imposes more sanctions as Myanmar sees fresh clashes
summary: Britain imposed sanctions on Myanmar's generals for overseeing human rights violations since the coup, as clashes broke out between pro-junta supporters and anti-coup residents. Hundreds of thousands took to the streets nationwide, calling for Aung San Suu Kyi's release and a return to democracy. At least five people have been killed in protests since the February 1 coup, and a police officer died in a protest. The country remains gripped by anger and unrest, with the military showing increasing force against demonstrators.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as tech shares fall
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.02% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declining 0.25% and 0.63%, respectively. The drop was attributed to a rise in US Treasury yields and pressure on technology-related stocks. Despite this, weekly jobless claims fell more than expected, a positive economic indicator.

site_title: Coinbase reveals healthy revenue growth, profit in listing application with SEC
summary: Coinbase, a US cryptocurrency exchange, has revealed healthy revenue growth and profit in its listing application with the SEC, taking a step closer to a landmark stock market listing on the Nasdaq. The exchange reported $1.3 billion in revenue for the year ended December 31, up 145% from the previous year, and net income of $322.3 million. Coinbase is opting for a direct listing, where existing shareholders can sell stock, and has not yet received regulatory approval to trade certain securities deemed "securities" under US federal securities laws.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB upgrades OCBC to 'buy'; Maybank KE, Jefferies raise target prices
summary: RHB upgraded OCBC to "buy" from "neutral" with a target price of S$12.50, citing lower credit costs and sustained net interest margins. Maybank KE and Jefferies also raised their targets, with Maybank KE at S$12.74 and Jefferies at S$12.50. The upgrades follow OCBC's earnings beat in FY2020 and its Greater China advances. Analysts expect a recovery in return on equity and higher dividends, supporting a share price rerating.

site_title: Gold falls 1% as elevated US yields hit safe haven appeal
summary: Gold prices fell 1% to $1,788.56 per ounce as US treasury yields remained elevated, reducing its safe haven appeal. Higher bond yields eroded gold's status as a hedge against inflation. Goldman Sachs downgraded its 2021 gold price target to $2,000/oz, citing conflicting market forces. Despite a weaker dollar, holdings of the world's largest gold-backed ETF fell to their lowest since May 2020, with some analysts predicting gold could rebound to $2,000/oz if riskier assets consolidate.

site_title: Seafood fare in a retro setting at Marcy's
summary: Marcy's, a new retro-themed eatery in Singapore, boasts a charming atmosphere with attention to detail, but its menu falls short. The restaurant's seafood fare is inconsistent, with some dishes, like the crab toast and red prawn aguachile, showing promise, while others, such as the pan-seared hake and rigatoni with wine-braised octopus, are disappointing. The restaurant's strongest aspect is its decor, which is reminiscent of a B&B in the Cotswolds. Despite its potential, Marcy's needs to refine its menu to match its aesthetic. Rating: 6/10.

site_title: New issuance of Astrea PE-backed bonds launched; interest rates to be decided
summary: AZALEA Asset Management, an indirect subsidiary of Temasek Holdings, is launching a new series of bonds backed by private equity (PE) called Astrea VI, with a total size of US$643 million. The issuance includes a retail tranche of S$250 million, with interest rates to be decided. The bonds carry a mandatory call after five years and a legal maturity of 10 years. The issue is expected to open for applications on March 10 and close on March 16, with trading starting on March 19.

site_title: AirAsia Group delays releasing earnings to end-March
summary: AirAsia Group has delayed its fourth-quarter earnings release by about a month to the end of March, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The airline's Japan unit has begun bankruptcy proceedings and will recognize a US$74.1 million loss in its 2020 second half financial results. AirAsia has also incurred expenses related to aircraft de-registration and is locked in negotiations with Airbus over fleet reorganization. The company's shares rose 16.6% following news of a private placement, increasing the stake of Hong Kong businessman Stanley Choi to 8.96%.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: UOB reported a 32% fall in Q4 profit, estimating credit costs at 30-40 basis points. Grab announced plans to create 350 new jobs in Singapore, partnering with the government to develop the local tech ecosystem. Singapore is unlikely to exit Phase 3 of its COVID-19 recovery plan soon, according to Senior Minister Janil Puthucheary. Aztech Global lodged a preliminary prospectus for a mainboard listing, while Angliss Singapore sued a former employee for misappropriating confidential information. Asian air travel is expected to grow by 5.7% a year until 2039, according to Boeing.

site_title: Ministers spar with NCMP Leong Mun Wai over suggestion of Employment Pass levy
summary: Singaporean Ministers disagree over a proposed Employment Pass levy, with Member of Parliament Leong Mun Wai suggesting a S$1,200 monthly levy to differentiate between high-salaried foreign talent and "cheap labour." Minister of State for Manpower Gan Siow Huang argues that such a levy would deter foreign investors and harm the economy. The debate highlights concerns about the balance between globalization and local talent in Singapore, with Leong calling for rebalancing and Gan defending the city-state's openness to foreign investment.

site_title: Pfizer-BioNTech testing booster of their Covid-19 vaccine in new trial
summary: Pfizer and BioNTech are testing a third dose of their Covid-19 vaccine to better understand the immune response against new variants, including the highly transmissible B.1.351 variant found in South Africa. The companies also plan to modify the vaccine to protect specifically against this variant and test it as a second arm of the study. The trials aim to assess the antibody response and safety of a third dose, with the goal of staying ahead of circulating variants and potentially reducing the need for frequent booster shots.

site_title: The Straits Trading Co chalks up higher H2 profit lifted by fair value gains
summary: Straits Trading Co reported a net profit of S$46 million for 6 months ended Dec 31, 2020, up 10% year-on-year, driven by fair value gains from its real estate segment. Revenue rose 18.1% to S$173.88 million. The company's hospitality segment reported a loss for 2020 due to the pandemic. For the full year, net profit shrank 39% to S$51.48 million. The group plans to grow its existing business engines and convert assets into investible securities.

site_title: Asian markets claw back losses after Fed eases fears of rate rise; STI up 1.7%
summary: Asian markets recovered from Wednesday's losses, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 1.7% to 2,973.54 points. The US Federal Reserve eased concerns about a potential interest rate hike, which had weighed on markets earlier. Index stocks including Singapore Airlines, Sembcorp Industries, and United Overseas Bank rose, while Thomson Medical hit a two-year high. The rally comes as investors await GDP data and amid a global airline stock rally.

site_title: UMS Holdings reports 86% drop in Q4 net profit
summary: UMS Holdings reported a 86% year-on-year drop in Q4 net profit to S$1.26 million, primarily due to a one-off impairment of goodwill and increased investment in associate company JEP. Revenue rose 9% to S$44.09 million, driven by increased semiconductor demand. Earnings per share fell to 0.24 Singapore cents from 1.72 cents a year ago.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance reports 38% decline in net profit for FY20
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 38% decline in net profit for FY20 to S$63.91 million, down from S$102.29 million the previous year. The decline was attributed to a 34.3% drop in profit from operations and higher general loan loss allowances due to the pandemic. Net interest income fell 27.2% and fee and commission income declined 25.4%. The board proposed a final dividend of 5.5 Singapore cents per share, down from 10 cents the previous year. The company expressed cautious optimism for 2021, driven by vaccine developments and improved operating environment.

site_title: India unveils tougher rules for social media such as Facebook, Twitter
summary: India has unveiled new rules to regulate big social media firms, including Facebook and Twitter, in response to the government's efforts to clamp down on disinformation and unlawful content. The rules require social media companies to set up grievance redressal mechanisms and appoint executives to coordinate with law enforcement, following Twitter's refusal to drop content related to farmers' protests in 2018. The move is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government's tightening control over Big Tech firms.

images.alt_text: India announced new rules on Thursday to regulate big social media firms, such as Facebook and Twitter, the latest effort by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government to tighten control over Big Tech firms.

site_title: Mobile shopping drives Chinese New Year e-commerce in South-east Asia: Report
summary: Mobile shopping surged during the Chinese New Year holidays in South-east Asia, with Thailand and Singapore leading sales volume increases. App traffic volume also rose significantly in Indonesia. According to an analysis by Criteo, 260 billion visits and 3 million transactions were recorded at 71 regional retailers. This growth trend is attributed to more customers making in-app buys, particularly in Thailand and Singapore.

site_title: Thai Jan factory output falls 2.8%, smaller drop than forecast
summary: Thailand's manufacturing production index (MPI) in January fell 2.8% from a year earlier, beating forecast expectations of a 4.4% decline. The drop was attributed to the impact of a coronavirus outbreak on domestic activity. This is a smaller decline than the 2.8% drop in December. The data suggests that the Thai manufacturing sector is recovering from the pandemic-related disruptions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares begin Thursday's session on front foot
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.53% on Thursday, driven by a record close on Wall Street and reassurances from the Federal Reserve on interest rates. The Hang Seng Index jumped to 30,174.22, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also saw gains. The record close on Wall Street and interest rate reassurances from the Federal Reserve lifted investor sentiment.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing plans US SPAC
summary: Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing plans to raise funds through a US special purpose acquisition company (SPAC), potentially seeking $400 million. The move comes as his family's conglomerate, CK Hutchison Holdings, is led by his elder son, Victor, and his younger son, Richard, has previously raised $900 million through US-listed SPACs. No final decisions have been made, and details of the transaction could change. Li, 92, is known for his investing prowess and has built a corporate empire spanning 50 countries.

site_title: China vows five-year plan dedicated to climate but growth, security concerns weigh
summary: China has promised its new five-year plan will focus on addressing climate change, aiming to peak emissions by 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2060. However, concerns over economic growth and energy security are expected to temper green ambitions, with regions likely to be given leeway to prioritize growth and build new coal-fired power stations. The plan is expected to include targets for renewable energy and carbon trading, but may not set an absolute cap on carbon emissions.

site_title: Tesla temporarily halts production at Model 3 line in California
summary: Tesla temporarily halted production at its Model 3 line in Fremont, California, from February 22 to March 7, citing a global semiconductor shortage. The halt affects the Fremont plant's annual production capacity of 500,000 Model 3s and Model Ys. The reason for the halt is unclear, and the impact on volume and revenue is also unknown. Tesla had previously mentioned the potential for a temporary impact due to the shortage, which has affected several automakers, including General Motors, Volkswagen, and Ford.

images.alt_text: Tesla has told workers it will temporarily halt some production at its car assembly plant in California, Bloomberg News reported on Thursday, citing a person familiar with the matter.

site_title: Berries World tuition teacher among two new Covid-19 community cases in Singapore
summary: A 27-year-old Singapore permanent resident, a teacher at Berries World of Learning School, has tested positive for Covid-19, bringing the total community cases to two. The teacher was asymptomatic and received both doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. Eight imported cases were also confirmed, bringing the total case count to 59,900. The number of new cases in the community has increased, with 24 patients discharged and 16 remaining in hospital.

site_title: Tencent-backed WeDoctor's Hong Kong IPO looms with valuation near US$7b
summary: WeDoctor, a Tencent-backed healthcare platform, is planning to file for an initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong as soon as next month with a valuation of US$6.8 billion. The company raised US$400 million in a pre-IPO round from investors including Sequoia Capital China and Millennium Management. WeDoctor is splitting its business into two parts, with its healthcare services operations set to be listed publicly and its sensitive data business kept private. The company's CEO, Jeff Chen, rejoined as chief strategy officer, overseeing capital markets and the listing process.

site_title: Europe: Stocks make gains at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trade on Thursday, driven by a positive performance in Asia. London's FTSE 100 index climbed 0.4% to 6,686.52 points, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices rose 0.2% and 0.5% respectively. A reassuring statement from the US Federal Reserve and positive developments on the vaccine front also boosted Asian markets.

site_title: Golden Agri H2 net profit down 21.5% to US$188.6m
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a net profit of US$188.6 million for the second half of FY 2020, down 21.5% from the same period last year. Revenue rose 12.9% to US$3.69 billion, driven by higher crude palm oil prices. The company's upstream business benefited from the higher market prices, while its downstream business improved with the recovery from Covid-19 lockdowns. Despite the increase in revenue, the group's Ebitda and net profit figures were affected by foreign-exchange losses and lower fair-value gain on financial assets.

site_title: WeWork's Neumann to leave board for a year under proposed deal
summary: Adam Neumann, former WeWork CEO, is set to leave the company's board for at least a year under a proposed settlement. As part of the deal, Neumann will receive $50 million to cover legal fees and have his $430 million SoftBank loan extended by five years. The agreement would also remove Neumann's seat as a board observer for a year, after which he could request to attend meetings or designate someone to take his place. The settlement resolves a high-profile legal battle between Neumann and SoftBank, and WeWork is expected to move forward with a potential public listing.

site_title: Seek 'green shoots' across sectors, global supply chain niches, says Chan Chun Sing at BT Budget Dialogue
summary: Singapore Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need to seek "green shoots" in emerging sectors, global supply chains, and the green economy as the country recovers from the Covid-19 crisis. Despite downside risks, the government is shifting its focus towards helping businesses seize opportunities, having moved out of "survival mode" since last year.

images.alt_text: BT Budget Dialogue 2021: (L- R) Linus Goh, Head, Global Commercial Banking, OCBC Bank; Chan Chun Sing, Minister for Trade and Industry and Wong Wei Kong, Editor, The Business Times.

site_title: GameStop's Frankfurt shares surge, overshoot Wall Street rally
summary: GameStop's Frankfurt-listed shares surged, tripling in premarket trading and reaching 240% gain, surpassing the Wall Street rally of 100% overnight. European retail traders joined the buying push, with analysts citing options trading and the resignation of GameStop's CFO as possible reasons. Shares jumped another 210% as of 7:41am GMT, following a 104% surge in US-listed shares on Wednesday. Similar gains were seen in AMC Entertainment's German shares, driven by the Reddit rally.

images.alt_text: GameStop's Frankfurt-listed shares trebled at one point on Thursday, overshooting the videogame retailer's 100 per cent surge on Wall Street overnight, as European retail traders joined in the fresh buying push.

site_title: Traveloka plans regional fintech expansion before 2021
summary: Traveloka, South-east Asia's largest online travel startup, plans to expand its fintech services in Thailand and Vietnam, with a focus on "buy now, pay later" services. The company has seen a strong rebound in its business after the Covid-19 pandemic and has already facilitated over six million loans in Indonesia. Traveloka is developing a US listing through a blank-cheque company and is exploring partnerships with banks in Thailand and Vietnam. The company's president, Caesar Indra, said domestic travel is driving recovery and the business potential is huge in Indonesia, where only 6% of the population has credit cards.

site_title: LVMH-backed L Catterton nears deal to acquire Birkenstock
summary: L Catterton, a private equity firm backed by LVMH, is nearing a deal to acquire Birkenstock, valued at approximately 4 billion euros (S$6.43 billion). The investment firm outbid CVC Capital Partners, which was close to a deal earlier this year, due to L Catterton's track record with family-backed consumer brands and its ability to expand in Asia. This deal would mark a significant acquisition for L Catterton, which manages over $23 billion of assets and has invested in brands such as Pepe Jeans and Everlane.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end firmer as Fed's Powell soothes inflation fears
summary: South Korean shares surged 3.50% on Thursday, their best day in almost two months, driven by chip heavyweights and foreign buying. US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's reaffirmation of keeping interest rates low boosted global risk appetite. The benchmark Kospi closed at 3,099.69, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix rising 4.02% and 9.19%, respectively. The won strengthened, with foreigners net buyers of 968.4 billion won worth of shares, and the 10-year bond yield rose 4 basis points to 1.891%.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rise on vaccine hopes, US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.67% on Thursday, tracking US gains, as hopes for increased COVID-19 vaccine supplies boosted investor confidence. The Nikkei 225 index ended at 30,168.27, while the Topix index gained 1.22%. The US FDA's approval of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine and US stocks reaching new all-time highs supported Japanese shares. Key stocks rose, including Nintendo, SoftBank, and Toyota, while chipmaker Murata Manufacturing and Suzuki made gains.

site_title: Biden says he has seen intelligence report on Saudi journalist's murder
summary: US President Joe Biden has confirmed that he has seen the unclassified intelligence report on the 2018 murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul. The report has linked Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to the crime, and Biden has vowed to "recalibrate" the US relationship with Saudi Arabia, steering away from former President Donald Trump's reliance on Prince Mohammed. Biden will also speak with Saudi King Salman for the first time since taking office, amid pressure on the Saudi leadership over human rights abuses.

site_title: Singapore unlikely to move out of Phase 3 soon: Janil
summary: Singapore is unlikely to move out of Phase 3 of its Covid-19 reopening "any time soon" due to ongoing outbreaks and the emergence of more easily transmitted variants of the virus. Senior Minister of State for Health Janil Puthucheary cited three key milestones, including evidence on vaccine effectiveness, substantial vaccination of the population, and global control of the virus. The country will reassess its vaccination timeline based on factors such as increased vaccination center capacity and public willingness to get vaccinated.

site_title: StanChart profit falls 57% as Covid-19 inflates bad loans
summary: Standard Chartered reported a 57% drop in annual profit to $1.61 billion due to higher credit impairments from the Covid-19 pandemic. The bank's pretax profit was lower than analyst estimates. Credit impairments more than doubled to $2.3 billion, primarily occurring in the first half of the year. Despite the decline, StanChart remains the largest bank in Asia, with most of its revenue coming from the region.

site_title: Coup chaos in Myanmar leaves employers fretting over paying staff
summary: A military coup in Myanmar three weeks ago has disrupted the country's economy, leaving employers uncertain about paying staff. The kyat currency is depreciating, businesses are paralyzed, and banks are in disarray, causing payroll problems and reduced wages. Hundreds of thousands of protesters have rallied against the junta, leading to calls for people not to go to work, which has disrupted import and export processes, including salary payments and bank transfers. Economists predict the crisis will lead to reduced wages, overtime, and increased borrowing, with the textiles sector being a major concern.

images.alt_text: The day the military seized power in Myanmar three weeks ago, Phyu delved into her company's emergency funds and gave her staff a one-month advance on their salaries.

site_title: Grab to add 350 jobs, partners IMDA for talent development
summary: Grab is partnering with the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) and Digital Industry Singapore (DISG) to develop the local tech ecosystem, with plans to create around 350 new jobs in Singapore this year. The tech firm will work with talent development programmes, such as the TechSkills Accelerator, to enhance the deep technical skills of experienced professionals and provide hands-on training opportunities. The new hires will support Grab's regional growth plans, including expanding products and services for micro-small and medium enterprises, digital financial services, and a digital bank.

images.alt_text: Some of Grab's new hires will come from fields including artificial intelligence, cybersecurity, data science, software engineering, and product management and design.

site_title: Angliss Singapore sues ex-staff for misappropriating confidential information after joining competitor
summary: Angliss Singapore is suing its former business development manager, Roger Yee, for allegedly misappropriating confidential information after joining competitor Indoguna. Yee took over 100 files containing confidential information when he left Angliss, allowing Indoguna to secure a distributorship deal with Arla, resulting in a loss of S$749,000 for Angliss. The company claims Yee breached his confidentiality obligation, non-compete, and solicitation clause. The case is set to be heard in the High Court six months later.

site_title: New Zealand central bank told to focus on rising house prices
summary: New Zealand's central bank is ordered to consider the housing market when setting interest rates, a world-first move aimed at easing a crisis driven by a 20% surge in residential property prices in 2020. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern's government directive comes despite the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's protests that it could hinder monetary policy goals. Finance Minister Grant Robertson said the bank will remain independent but must examine the impact of interest rate decisions on the housing market.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit raises 100m euros in private placement
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) successfully raised 100 million euros (S$160.5 million) from a private placement of 232.6 million new units, exceeding its initial target of 90 million euros. The placement was upsized following strong demand, with an issue price of 43 euro cents per new unit.

site_title: Some Federal Reserve services down due to 'operational error'
summary: The US Federal Reserve experienced a disruption in services due to an "operational error," affecting several business lines, including a system linking the Fed to commercial banks and a service for transferring funds called FedACH. The outage began late morning on Wednesday and was caused by a technical issue, not a suspected hack. The Fed has restored most services, but two services related to wiring funds and accounts are still experiencing issues. The disruption raised concerns in the financial world due to its potential impact on various transactions, including payrolls and utility bills.

site_title: Singapore needs 1.2m more digital workers by 2025 to remain competitive: report
summary: Singapore needs 1.2 million additional digital workers by 2025 to remain competitive, a 55% increase from current levels. The report, commissioned by Amazon Web Services, found that 23.8 million digital skill trainings will be required between 2020 and 2025. The top five in-demand skills include cloud architecture design, cybersecurity, and large-scale data modelling. Digitally skilled workers currently make up 63% of Singapore's workforce, highlighting the need for significant workforce development to meet industry demands.

site_title: European stocks set for record highs in 2021: poll
summary: European stocks are expected to reach record highs by the end of 2021, according to a Reuters poll of 24 fund managers and strategists. The Stoxx 600 index is forecast to climb to 440 points, a 7% gain from its current level of 411.32 points, driven by corporate profits rebounding from the pandemic and fiscal/monetary stimulus. This would mark a significant recovery for the benchmark, which has struggled to keep pace with global equity markets.

site_title: Texas governor vows to overhaul electric grid operator after storm failure
summary: Texas Governor Greg Abbott vowed to overhaul the state's electric grid operator, ERCOT, after a massive blackout left residents without heat, power, or water for days, causing billions of dollars in damages and dozens of deaths. Abbott blamed ERCOT for failing to prepare for severe cold and said power generators also needed to winterize their facilities. Six ERCOT directors have resigned and a board nominee declined a seat in the wake of criticism. Abbott pledged to investigate the causes of the failure and promised to add more power to the grid.

site_title: Facebook bans Myanmar military from its platforms with immediate effect
summary: Facebook has banned the Myanmar military from its platforms with immediate effect due to "exceptionally severe human rights abuses" and the risk of future violence. The ban follows weeks of mass demonstrations after the military seized power in the South-east Asian country. At least three protesters and one policeman have been killed in violence. The US tech giant also banned all "Tatmadaw-linked commercial entities" from advertising on its platforms. This decision comes after Facebook previously banned army chief Min Aung Hlaing and removed hundreds of pages and accounts run by military members.

images.alt_text: Facebook on Thursday said it had banned the Myanmar military from using its Facebook and Instagram platforms with immediate effect, as weeks of mass demonstrations continue in the South-east Asian country after the military seized power.

site_title: New game plan needed for Orchard's retailers
summary: The pandemic has had an uneven impact on businesses, with suburban malls faring better than tourist-focused malls like Orchard Road. Retailers at Orchard Road will need to adapt to domestic demand, as border closures keep tourists away. A new game plan is necessary to keep cash registers ringing, according to the NUS' Institute of Real Estate and Urban Studies.

site_title: South Korea's central bank holds fire on rates; investors eye bond purchase plan
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, held interest rates steady at 0.5% as expected, maintaining support for the fragile economic recovery. The bank raised its inflation outlook to 1.3% and kept its growth outlook at 3.0%. Investors are focusing on government debt purchase plans, which may be announced in the coming weeks, to aid small businesses and vulnerable groups. The bank's decision aims to stabilize bond yields, which have been rising, and address financial imbalances. The economy remains fragile, with a jobs decline in over two decades.

site_title: Australia's Q4 business investment surprisingly jumps
summary: Australian business investment rose 3% in the December quarter to A$29.4 billion, the first increase since 2018 and largest since 2013. The growth was driven by non-mining activity, particularly construction, accommodation, and online shopping. This positive sign for the economy suggests that firms are becoming more confident about the future, with revised spending plans for 2020/21 estimated at A$121.4 billion.

site_title: Cambodia tipped to lead the pack in regional casino recovery: report
summary: Casinos in Cambodia are expected to regain three-fifths of their pre-pandemic revenue this year, driven by the VIP segment. Colliers International predicts Macau, Cambodia, Singapore, the Philippines, and Vietnam will lead the regional recovery, with premium mass gaming lifting Macau's GGR to 50-60% of 2019 levels. Cambodia's GGR is forecasted to hit 60% of pre-Covid-19 levels, while Singapore's could achieve 45%. The recovery is expected to begin in Q3 2021, with the global economic outlook improving and travel rebounding over the next three years.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 14.47 points, or 0.93%, to 1,572.02. The market saw 1.82 billion lots traded, worth RM742.33 million. Gainers beat losers 566 to 212, indicating a positive trend.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street record after Powell's soothing words
summary: Asian markets surged on Thursday, following Wall Street's record close, after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell reassured investors that interest rates won't rise until inflation reaches its 2% target. Powell stated that inflation would rise as the economy recovers, but not run away, and that the Fed has tools to deal with it. The positivity was further boosted by vaccine developments, with Pfizer's 94% effective Covid-19 vaccine and Johnson & Johnson's single-shot vaccine showing promise. Markets in Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and others rose more than 1%, while Singapore surged 2%.

site_title: Singapore shares track Wall Street gains; STI up 1.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.1% on Thursday, following overnight gains on Wall Street, driven by news of a potential influx of COVID-19 vaccine doses. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached 2,957.16, with 149 gainers outnumbering losers 36. The market saw 99.1 million securities worth S$102.5 million change hands.

site_title: Qantas posts huge loss, says no international flights until October
summary: Qantas reported a US$5.5 billion revenue decline in the second half of 2020, resulting in an underlying loss of A$1.1 billion. The airline suspended international flights until October due to the pandemic, with domestic flights expected to return to 60% capacity by March and 80% by June. The company is cutting costs by grounding 100 planes and laying off 8,500 staff, aiming to save A$1 billion annually from 2023.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH maintains 'buy' on Venture, flags potential risks for 2021
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) maintains its "buy" call on Venture Corp, citing potential sequential growth in Q4 results driven by reopening economies and strong demand for essential products. The research house sets a price target of S$23.76 based on a forward mean P/E of 19.4 times. Analyst John Cheong highlights three key risks: delayed product launches, potential disruption to production capacity due to Covid-19 cases in Malaysia, and reduced demand for essential products linked to a global recovery. Venture is due to report its FY2020 results on Friday.

site_title: South-east Asian air travel boom expected on low-cost carrier growth: Boeing
summary: South-east Asian air travel is expected to experience a 5.7% annual growth rate until 2039, the second-fastest pace globally, driven by the growth of low-cost carriers. Domestic air travel within Asean is projected to become the world's fifth-largest market, surpassing the current seventh-largest position in 2019. Intra-China aviation is also poised to take the top spot worldwide, surpassing North American and European markets. This growth is attributed to the expansion of low-cost carriers in the region, driven by increasing demand for air travel.

site_title: Large real world study confirms Pfizer vaccine 94% effective
summary: A large study published in the New England Journal of Medicine confirms the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine is 94% effective in a real-world setting involving 1.2 million people in Israel. This is the first peer-reviewed study to confirm the vaccine's power in mass immunization campaigns. The findings provide evidence that the vaccine can bring the pandemic to a close, marking a significant milestone in the global fight against Covid-19.

site_title: YouTube to roll out parent-approved accounts for tweens
summary: YouTube is rolling out parent-approved accounts for tweens, allowing them to explore the platform within set boundaries. The new accounts, set to be released in coming months, will let parents use Google accounts to control content and features. The move aims to address concerns about violence and inappropriate content viewed by minors on the platform. This feature will help parents manage their children's YouTube experience, providing a safer and more controlled environment for young users.

site_title: Australia passes landmark law requiring tech firms to pay for news
summary: Australia's parliament passed a landmark law requiring global tech firms, Google and Facebook, to pay for local news content. The law, which was watered down from original binding rules, paves the way for the tech giants to invest tens of millions of dollars in local content deals. Google will pay for news content on its "Showcase" product, while Facebook will pay for content on its "News" product. The move aims to ensure that news businesses are fairly remunerated for their content, helping to sustain public interest journalism in Australia.

site_title: Australia: Energy stocks drive shares higher; a2 Milk drags down New Zealand
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% to 6,840.1, driven by energy stocks jumping on stronger crude oil prices, while technology stocks followed US peers higher. Energy stocks, including Santos and Woodside Petroleum, reached one-month highs. In contrast, New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.9% due to a2 Milk's 19.9% drop after forecasting lower full-year revenue.

site_title: FAA must improve inspections after Boeing 737 MAX crashes: review
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) must improve inspections of new aircraft, according to a government review of the Boeing 737 MAX certification process. The 60-page report found weaknesses in the FAA's guidance and processes that impacted the certification of the MAX, contributing to two fatal accidents in 2018 and 2019. The FAA agreed with the report's conclusions and has already taken steps to ensure a more holistic assessment of aircraft design changes. The report recommends stricter inspections, including analyses of "failure probability" and notification of certification engineers of any changes made to System Safety Assessments.

site_title: SPH, family office could see returns from US$50b Coupang IPO
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) and the family office of Trafigura's Asia-Pacific chief Tan Chin Hwee may see significant returns if South Korean e-commerce firm Coupang goes through with its planned $50 billion initial public offering (IPO). Coupang, founded in 2010, has grown rapidly into a dominant e-commerce player in South Korea, with expected valuation of $50 billion, making it the largest listing by a foreign company in New York since Alibaba's 2014 IPO.

site_title: Regulators order deeper testing after Boeing engine scare
summary: US regulators ordered deeper testing of Pratt & Whitney engines similar to the one that broke up on a Boeing 777 passenger plane in Denver, after an engine burst into flames and scattered debris. The incident led to scores of Boeing 777s being grounded worldwide, with no injuries reported. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) directed inspections of 125 planes with similar blades before they can return to service, citing metal fatigue as the suspected cause of the engine failure.

site_title: US: Dow ends at record on dovish Federal Reserve, vaccine progress
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a fresh record, closing at 31,961.86, following dovish comments from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and progress on a coronavirus vaccine. Powell reassured investors that inflation will remain mild and interest rates will stay low. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also advanced, with Johnson & Johnson rising 1.3% after the FDA released data showing its single-shot vaccine is highly effective in preventing severe Covid-19.

images.alt_text: The Dow finished at a fresh record on Wednesday, shaking off early weakness following dovish comments from the Federal Reserve chief and progress on another coronavirus vaccine.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, OUE, Sheng Siong, OUELH, Cromwell E-Reit, SIA Engg
summary: Singapore stocks saw varied developments on Thursday, with UOB's net profit falling 32% to S$688 million, while OUE Limited posted a net loss of S$343.4 million. Sheng Siong reported a net profit of S$32.1 million, up 84.9% from the same period last year. Cromwell E-Reit raised S$160.5 million from a private placement, and SIA Engineering Company is setting up an Engine Services Division to grow its engine services business. The STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore Exchange to collaborate with OneConnect to build an environmental, social and governance (ESG) platform, simplifying ESG disclosure processes for listed companies. SIA Engineering Company is setting up an Engine Services Division to grow its engine services business, requiring over 100 staff. OUE Lippo Healthcare has been allotted rights units of First Real Estate Investment Trust, indirectly owning approximately 15.4% of the total units issued.

site_title: Data-focused Powell paves way for era of extended loose Federal Reserve policy
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell reassured investors that the central bank won't raise interest rates until inflation exceeds 2% and the economy reaches full employment, citing the need for "tangible progress" before shifting policy. Powell stated that inflation concerns are being closely watched, but an expected price jump in spring may be due to post-pandemic supply bottlenecks rather than a policy response. The Fed has committed to maintaining its current monetary policy until substantial progress is made towards its maximum employment and inflation goals.

site_title: TV series 'Frasier' latest 1990s hit to get a revival
summary: The TV series "Frasier," a 1990s hit starring Kelsey Grammer as Dr. Frasier Crane, is getting a revival. Grammer will reprise his role, with no further details given. The revival will focus on "the next chapter in the continuing journey of Dr. Frasier Crane" and will be produced by CBS Studios for the Paramount+ streaming service. This marks the latest in a series of revivals and reboots of hit TV shows from the 1990s, following shows like "Sex and the City" and "Will & Grace."

site_title: Foodtech startup Next Gen raises US$10m in seed round
summary: Next Gen, a Singapore-based foodtech startup, has raised US$10 million in a seed round. Investors include Temasek, K3 Ventures, and Metro's NX-Food. The funds will be used for the global launch of its plant-based chicken consumer brand, TiNDLE, in Singapore and international expansion. Next Gen plans to diversify products and expand into Europe and the US, with plans to recruit a growth director for US expansion. The company's co-founder and CEO, Timo Recker, described the seed round as a "strong validation" of the team and business model.

site_title: Argentine economy contracted 10% in 2020: official estimate
summary: Argentina's economy contracted by 10% in 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic, according to initial estimates. The country's GDP fell by 2.2% in December 2020 compared to the same month in 2019. The economy experienced a decline in April and May due to strict lockdowns, but recovered in eight of the 12 months. This contraction is attributed to the pandemic's impact on economic activity, with the economy badly hit during lockdowns.

site_title: UOB sounds optimistic note; Q4 profit falls 32%
summary: UOB's chief executive Wee Ee Cheong expressed optimism about the bank's growth prospects, citing a "clearer skies" for the small and medium-sized enterprises space. The bank's Q4 profit fell 32% due to lower interest rates and increased credit costs, but it still maintains a stable cost-income ratio. UOB's loan book under relief decreased to S$18 billion, with most loans being from government relief programs that have resumed repayment. The bank expects to stay profitable and resilient, with a potential new non-performing asset (NPA) estimate of S$2 billion.

site_title: OUE posts S$343.4m loss for FY2020
summary: OUE Limited posted a net loss of S$343.4 million for FY2020, reversing the S$255.2 million net profit in FY2019. The loss was attributed to S$435.4 million in net fair-value losses and impairment losses on investment properties and assets. Revenue shrank 43% to S$530.5 million, with declines across all segments, mainly due to the pandemic's impact on the hospitality division. OUE is proposing a final cash dividend of one cent per share.

site_title: Facebook pledges US$1b in news investments over three years
summary: Facebook has pledged to invest at least US$1 billion over three years to support journalism, amid a dispute with Australia over payments to media organizations. The move comes after the company restored news links in Australia as part of a compromise. Facebook's head of global affairs, Nick Clegg, defended the company's handling of the dispute, stating that it supports quality journalism and has driven significant revenue for Australian news publishers. The investment aims to promote a better understanding of the relationship between Facebook and news publishers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, following a rally on Wall Street, as investors gained confidence from news of a potential vaccine delivery. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.28% and the Topix index gained 1.13%. This follows a global trend, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Tesla's stock reversal delivers US$10b hit to China EV tycoons
summary: US-listed shares of Chinese electric-vehicle companies Xpeng, Li Auto, and Nio have plummeted, wiping out around $10 billion in investor wealth, following Tesla's stock reversal. The companies' shares have dropped 33%, 27%, and 22% respectively, after speculative money poured into the sector last year. Analysts attribute the decline to shifts in sentiment and increased competition, as traditional carmakers prepare to electrify their fleets. The decline also affects the combined fortune of the companies' founders, which has declined by around $10 billion.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher on upbeat German data
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Wednesday, with Germany's DAX adding 0.8% after strong data showed bullish exports and solid construction activity helped the country grow 0.3% in the fourth quarter. Travel stocks jumped 1.9% to near one-year highs, while the technology sector lost nearly 4% this week. US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell reiterated that interest rates will remain low despite rising inflation concerns.

site_title: Losses mount for virus-hit Air New Zealand
summary: Air New Zealand posted a NZ$72 million half-year loss due to the coronavirus pandemic, a significant decline from a NZ$101 million profit in the same period last year. The airline attributes the loss to decreased international travel demand, despite strong domestic and cargo performance. With a 60% fall in overall operating revenue and a 42% drop in labour costs, Air New Zealand warns of a significant loss in 2021. The airline's domestic capacity is at 76% of pre-pandemic levels, fueled by New Zealand's contained virus situation.

site_title: Oil rises after data shows slump in US output amid Texas freeze
summary: Oil prices rose to fresh 13-month highs after US government data showed a 10% drop in crude output due to a Texas freeze, the largest weekly fall ever. US crude oil production fell by 1 million barrels per day, and refinery crude inputs dropped to the lowest since 2008. Brent crude futures rose 2.6% to $67.04 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 2.5% to $63.22 a barrel. The rally is driven by concerns that the production drop will be long-term and by ongoing supply cuts by OPEC+ producers.

site_title: US, rights groups criticise Malaysia for deportations to Myanmar
summary: The US and rights groups have criticized Malaysia for deporting over 1,000 Myanmar nationals back to their military-ruled nation despite a court order. The deportations, which included vulnerable asylum seekers, were condemned by the US State Department as "concerning" and urged other countries to halt repatriations until the UNHCR can assess protection concerns. Malaysian authorities claim there were no Rohingya asylum seekers among the deportees, but rights groups dispute this, citing a lack of assessment by the UNHCR.

images.alt_text: The United States on Wednesday led criticism of Malaysia for deporing more than 1,000 Myanmar nationals back to their military-ruled nation in defiance of a court order.

site_title: E-commerce explosion fuels Canada warehouse boom
summary: Canada is on the verge of a warehouse boom due to soaring e-commerce demand. A report from CBRE predicts 40 million square feet of additional warehouse space will be needed in the next five years, following a 32% increase in e-commerce sales last year.

site_title: Aztech Global lodges preliminary prospectus for mainboard listing
summary: Aztech Global, a technology unit of conglomerate Aztech Group, has lodged a preliminary prospectus for a mainboard listing on the Singapore Exchange. The company, which provides IoT, data-communication, and LED lighting products, aims to raise funds to expand manufacturing facilities and enhance research and development capabilities. Aztech Global reported a net profit of S$30.5 million in the first nine months of FY2020, down from S$35.3 million in the previous year. The company intends to pay dividends of at least 30% of net profit after tax, excluding exceptional items.

site_title: Investment in grads, green economy, SMEs in procurement feature in debate
summary: Singapore lawmakers debated key issues in the 2021 budget, including investments in graduates and talents, the green economy, and supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). MPs called for greater investment in research, developing capabilities in areas like pandemic analysis and vaccine manufacturing, and building deep skills for long-term resilience. They also urged the government to give local SMEs preferential treatment in procurements and tap into the opportunities in the green economy, with some arguing for the development of green local firms to support sustainability efforts.

site_title: Ant investor Boyu Capital said to target US$6b for new fund
summary: Chinese private equity firm Boyu Capital is raising a new fund of up to $6 billion, targeting China-focused investments. The fifth and largest US dollar-denominated fund is expected to close soon. Boyu, which has invested in companies like Ant Group and Alibaba Group, aims to capitalize on the region's largest and most lucrative China-focused funds. The fundraising comes amid heightened oversight of China's tech giants and delayed returns for investors.

site_title: Aussie, pound soar on reflation bets; dollar struggles
summary: The US dollar fell to multi-year lows against the Australian and British currencies, with the Australian dollar reaching a three-year high and the British pound surpassing $1.42 for the first time since 2018, as reflation trades and growing confidence in a global economic recovery drove investors to currencies expected to benefit from increased global trade. The dollar's decline came as benchmark 10-year US yields held near their highest in nearly a year, and safe-haven currencies like the Swiss franc weakened.

site_title: Labour MPs call for support for vulnerable groups and protection of 'Singaporean Core'
summary: Singapore Labour MPs are calling for measures to protect vulnerable workers, including lower-wage employees, seniors, and migrant workers, and to lessen income inequality. They are also seeking to protect the "Singaporean core" workforce by expanding the Progressive Work Model and Workforce Income Supplement schemes. Key demands include reforms to the schemes, increased support for senior workers, and tougher sanctions to protect jobs for older professionals and managers. The MPs aim to narrow the gap between the 20th percentile of wage earners and the median income, with the current gap being 54%.

images.alt_text: Members of Parliament (MPs) from the Labour Movement have called for more measures to protect vulnerable workers - including lower-wage employees, seniors and migrant workers - and lessen income equality, with several also asking to protect the workforce's "Singaporean core".

site_title: SPAC listings: An opportunity for Singapore, but risks lurk for investors
summary: Singapore has an opportunity to capitalize on the surge in special purpose acquisition vehicles (SPACs) listings, with 168 SPAC IPOs already this year, raising nearly US$52 billion. However, investors should be cautious of the risks, including the quality of sponsors, a glut of capital chasing targets, and weak recent returns. To strike a balance, the Singapore Exchange must ensure quality listings while providing sufficient investor protection and regulating with a relatively light touch.

site_title: IonQ in talks to go public through merger with DMY SPAC
summary: IonQ is in talks to merge with DMY Technology Group Inc III, a SPAC, in a deal valued at approximately US$2 billion. The combined company will be one of the first public quantum-computing companies. Strategic investors, including Silver Lake and MSD Partners, are set to participate in a strategic private investment in public equity (PIPE), which will raise an additional US$300 million. Existing IonQ investors are expected to roll over their equity into the transaction. The deal is expected to be announced in coming weeks, pending finalization.

site_title: Nasa releases panorama taken by Mars rover
summary: NASA released a panoramic view of the Perseverance rover's landing site on Mars, capturing the rim of the Jezero Crater and an ancient river delta. The image, composed of 142 individual photos, showcases the rover's location and features similar to previous Mars missions. The panoramic view was taken by rotating the rover's mast 360 degrees, utilizing its dual cameras. This image will aid scientists in assessing the geologic history and atmospheric conditions of Jezero Crater and identifying rocks for closer examination.

images.alt_text: The US space agency Nasa released a spectacular panoramic view on Wednesday of the landing site of the Perseverance rover on Mars.

site_title: Pritam Singh questions timing of petrol tax hike, calls for an independent panel to scrutinise Budget
summary: Opposition Leader Pritam Singh criticized the Singapore Budget 2021, calling the petrol tax hike "ill-timed" and urging a phased approach. He also suggested an independent panel to scrutinize the budget and greater transparency in government spending. Singh noted that the hike overlaps with an anticipated GST increase and may lead to added cost of living pressures for middle-class Singaporeans. He also called for closer scrutiny of expenditure to ensure effectiveness and prevent a perception of large sums of money being deployed without clear results.

site_title: With clean slate, is OUE Lippo Healthcare on road to recovery?
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare (OUELH) has completed a recapitalisation exercise, converting shareholder loans to convertible perpetual bonds. This move is expected to improve OUELH's gearing and net tangible assets per share, while also reversing its FY2020 loss. The company's shares have gained 5.41% following the announcement, while OUE's shares have dipped 1.79%. Analysts believe OUELH's performance should improve in FY2021, with the company poised to report better results after the removal of its borrowings.

site_title: Marriott International taps Tony Capuano as new CEO
summary: Marriott International has appointed Tony Capuano as its new CEO, succeeding Arne Sorenson who died at 62 after a battle with pancreatic cancer. Capuano, a veteran development executive, will be the company's fourth leader in history and faces the challenge of navigating the hotel giant's recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite sluggish demand trends, investors remain bullish on a recovery, and experts expect increased consumer spending on hotels in 2021. Capuano, who has been with the company for nearly 40 years, will oversee Marriott's brands, including Ritz-Carlton and Courtyard, and will focus on deploying creative and brand strategies to drive revenue growth.

site_title: The rise of intangibles and innovation
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat highlighted Singapore's response to the post-pandemic economic landscape, focusing on intangible assets as a pathway to economic growth. The Singapore economy is well-equipped to navigate this new landscape, with a strong focus on science and technology innovation and digital transformation. Intangible assets now account for over 90% of company value, driving earnings and profit growth, whereas tangible assets account for less than 10%. To unlock their value, businesses must identify and protect valuable intangible assets, assess and value them, and unlock their value, ultimately driving growth and competitiveness.

site_title: He writes unreliable narrators because he is one, too
summary: Viet Thanh Nguyen, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of "The Sympathizer," releases his sequel "The Committed," exploring questions of identity, memory, and war. The novel follows Vo Danh, a narrator who has escaped Communist interrogators and joins a gang of drug dealers in Paris, grappling with displacement and disillusionment. Nguyen draws on his own experiences as a refugee and his family's escape from Vietnam, weaving together historical and philosophical references. The book delves into the complexities of identity, memory, and the impact of war on individuals and communities.

site_title: Analysts see volume as key to success of airasia food's flat-rate fee model
summary: AirAsia's food delivery service, airasia food, is set to launch in Singapore on March 2 with a flat-rate fee model, charging S$3 to S$5 per order, potentially lower than market players' 25-35% commissions. Analysts see volume as key to its success, but question whether it can generate sufficient customers without passing on costs to consumers or sacrificing delivery riders' interests. Incumbents GrabFood, foodpanda, and Deliveroo acknowledge the competition but remain focused on their own models.

site_title: Trials in Singapore on Smartphone app offering mini check-ups
summary: Singapore is testing a smartphone app that offers mini check-ups, including heart rate, oxygen levels, and stress levels, to prevent another outbreak of the novel coronavirus. Developed by Nervotec, the app uses a smartphone camera to measure heart rate and provides a diagnosis of the user's health condition. The city-state aims to avoid a repeat of last year's outbreak in migrant worker dormitories. If approved, the app could be a game-changer in healthcare, according to the National University of Singapore's Institute of Health Innovation and Technology.

site_title: Unsettling future for golf after Tiger Woods' crash
summary: Tiger Woods, a 15-time Major winner, was involved in a single-car crash in California, leaving him with multiple leg injuries. The incident raises concerns about his future in golf, with some speculating that his career may be nearing its end. Woods' longtime sponsors may still support him, despite his declining health and recent injuries, as his historical success and brand value remain significant. The golf world will miss his presence, as he was a key factor in driving television ratings and purses.

site_title: China's crackdown on defaulters starts to embolden creditors
summary: China's crackdown on corporate debt defaults is emboldening creditors, who are successfully pushing for borrower concessions. Disgruntled creditors have forced concessions from a major carmaker and an energy producer, securing unprecedented court rulings that require underwriters and rating firms to compensate individual bondholders. The shift is part of a broader reform push aimed at improving the efficiency of China's US$5.2 trillion credit market, with regulators gradually dialing back financial support to distressed borrowers.

site_title: Hong Kong's January home prices edge up as optimism returns
summary: Hong Kong's home prices rose 0.13% in January, snapping a three-month decline, as optimism returned amid a jump in launches and anticipation of vaccine-led economic recovery. The modest gain follows a 0.08% increase in 2020. Developers have launched over 2,000 new flats this year, with many participating in land auctions and offering higher bids. Realtors expect home prices to remain sluggish until vaccines are widely available in the second half, with potential gains of up to 5% for the full year.

site_title: German prosecutor looking into regulator's handling of Wirecard
summary: German prosecutors are investigating the handling of Wirecard by the German financial regulator BaFin, following the company's collapse. Prosecutors visited BaFin's headquarters and another unidentified authority, seeking information on alleged lack of oversight and insider trading. The probe comes amid widespread criticism of BaFin's failure to detect wrongdoing before Wirecard's collapse. BaFin's chief is stepping down, and prosecutors have received letters from citizens requesting charges against unnamed individuals. The investigation has raised questions about Germany's supervision of Wirecard, a company that processed payments for gambling and pornography before becoming a fintech firm.

site_title: S-Reits may gain if China citizens allowed to invest in securities abroad
summary: Singapore's real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) may benefit from China's potential rule change allowing its citizens to invest in overseas equities. China is considering easing capital controls to allow domestic investors to use their annual forex quota for purchases of securities and insurance offshore. This move could increase liquidity flows to Singapore equities, particularly S-Reits, which offer exposure to Singapore and global property markets, and could appeal to Chinese investors seeking yield and stability.

site_title: Tencent-backed edtech startup seeks funding at US$20 billion value
summary: Tencent-backed edtech startup Yuanfudao is seeking fresh funding at a valuation of over US$20 billion, with plans to raise at least US$1 billion. This comes after a US$2.2 billion round in November 2020 that valued the startup at US$15.5 billion. Yuanfudao competes with top teaching providers and internet giants in China's private education industry, with a possible stock market debut in 2022. The company's fundraising aims to boost its valuation ahead of the debut.

site_title: Sterling gets a boost from vaccinations and moves to ease lockdown measures
summary: The UK's sterling currency has seen a significant boost due to vaccinations and easing of lockdown measures. Sterling has surged 13.2% against the US dollar, 10% against the yen, and 6.1% and 5.5% against the Singapore dollar and euro, respectively. With almost 18 million people vaccinated, infection rates, hospital admissions, and death rates are falling. The government projects a complete vaccine rollout by summer's end. Analysts predict the pound will reach 1.49 in six months and 1.57 against the US dollar in a year, driven by pent-up financial energy and potential savings of over £250 billion.

site_title: Does the Covid-19 vaccine stop transmission?
summary: Scientists say that Covid-19 vaccines will eventually stop the spread of the virus, but more data is needed to confirm this. The vaccines are highly effective at preventing Covid-19 symptoms, but it's unknown how well they prevent infection with SARS-CoV-2. Vaccinated people may still spread the virus to others who are not vaccinated, but the data suggests that vaccination reduces asymptomatic infection and virus production. Historical evidence shows that vaccines that don't prevent virus infection can still stop epidemics, and the Covid-19 vaccines are expected to have a similar impact.

site_title: Garment workers in Thailand receive full compensation after wages expose
summary: Thailand garment workers who were underpaid for products made for major brands, including Universal Studios, have received full compensation after the company agreed to pay outstanding wages. Three other global brands also made payments to settle 3.5 million Thai baht (S$153,737) owed in unpaid wages. NBCUniversal stated that the matter is taken seriously and does not align with their core values. This move comes after similar settlements with other brands, urging greater accountability in labor practices.

site_title: After 2020 boom, Home Depot says sales to be flat this year
summary: Home Depot reported strong same-store sales growth of 25% in the first quarter, but warned that 2021 sales will be flat to slightly positive due to difficult comparisons and increasing costs. The company's profit margin will be pressured by rising transportation costs and increased spending on infrastructure and shoplifting. Despite this, Home Depot's customers are spending more per transaction, and the retailer has managed to sustain growth above 20% for three quarters.

site_title: Enabling Singapore's youths to adapt in an era of climate change
summary: Singapore is experiencing rapid climate change, with temperatures rising twice as fast as the global average, and is expected to see a 1.4-4.6°C increase in daily mean temperature by the end of the century. To address this, the government has committed close to S$1 billion to climate change mitigation and adaptation efforts, including increasing solar energy production and phasing out internal combustion engine vehicles. The focus is on nudging youths towards more eco-friendly behaviors through education and experiential learning approaches, such as guided trips to waste-to-energy plants and smart city management courses. Researchers argue that moral persuasion and traditional education methods are ineffective, and that a nudge-based approach can be more effective in changing behavior.

site_title: No Code revolution is coming to the world of apps
summary: A No Code revolution is expected to transform the world of apps, similar to its impact on website design. No Code platforms, such as Wix and SquareSpace, allow users to create complex apps with ease, eliminating the need for extensive coding and design experience. By 2024, Gartner predicts that 65% of all app development will be done using low-code or no-code solutions, reducing costs and time-to-market for startups. This shift is expected to increase entrepreneurship, with lower barriers to entry and faster prototype development, allowing for quicker product failure and success.

site_title: IMF chief urges G-20 action to reverse global economy's 'dangerous divergence'
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva urges G-20 countries to take strong policy actions to reverse a "dangerous divergence" in the global economy, where most developing economies are expected to lag behind. The divergence threatens to leave these countries languishing for years, with cumulative per capita income projected to be 22% below pre-crisis levels by 2022. Georgieva calls for accelerated vaccination efforts, increased vaccine production capacity, and targeted fiscal support to support economies. She also recommends maintaining accommodative monetary policies and leveraging private finance to support vulnerable countries.

site_title: AirAsia's food delivery flight here unlikely to unseat incumbents
summary: AirAsia's planned food delivery flight in Singapore is unlikely to significantly disrupt the market, dominated by Grab and Foodpanda, which hold 76% of the market share. The revenue generated by AirAsia's service is expected to be minimal, given its loss-making status in the aviation sector. The move may be an attempt to distract from its current problems or maintain customer connectivity.

site_title: Thailand working on plan to welcome vaccinated tourists by Q3
summary: Thailand is working on a plan to welcome vaccinated tourists by the third quarter of 2021, with measures including shortening or waiving mandatory quarantine for arrivals. The Tourism Authority of Thailand and the tourism ministry are preparing for the easing of restrictions, with plans to sell tour packages after April. The country aims to revive its tourism industry, which has been severely impacted by travel curbs, with forecasts predicting around 15 million visitors in 2022 and pre-pandemic levels in 2023.

site_title: Lucid Motors CEO aims to launch Tesla Model 3 rival in 2024/2025
summary: Lucid Motors CEO Peter Rawlinson plans to launch a luxury electric car rival to Tesla's Model 3 in 2024 or 2025. The company will start by producing a luxury car, then expand into the mass market. Rawlinson believes scaling up production of a mass car is a major financial challenge, citing the need for a bigger factory and more automation. Experts question whether Lucid can still launch an affordable model, given competition from legacy makers like Volkswagen and Hyundai, which are introducing affordable electric vehicles.

site_title: Iata plans digital travel pass to steer airlines towards recovery
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) plans to launch a digital travel pass in March to facilitate travel recovery. Despite tightening coronavirus restrictions, IATA forecasts a travel recovery later this year, but warns of continued cash burn, with losses projected to reach $75-95 billion. The industry is focusing on restarting travel at scale when borders reopen and pent-up demand is released, with airlines such as Delta Air Lines offering upbeat outlooks on travel demand.

site_title: Thailand says nears vaccine passport, hopes to welcome tourists in Q3
summary: Thailand is preparing to introduce a vaccine passport, allowing vaccinated travelers to ease restrictions, with the goal of welcoming tourists in the third quarter. The plan includes shortening mandatory quarantine to three days or waiving it entirely for vaccinated visitors.
