The site's editor-in-chief Steven Gan was cleared of contempt charges, but criticized the decision as "uncalled for". International condemnation poured in, with Human Rights Watch calling the ruling a "blatant violation of freedom of expression".

site_title: 14 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 14 new COVID-19 cases on February 19, all of which were imported and required stay-home notices or isolation upon arrival. The total number of cases in Singapore rose to 59,846. There were no community cases or cases from migrant workers' dormitories. The number of unlinked cases in the community decreased from six to one over the past week, and 59,664 people have recovered from the virus.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on upbeat Hermes earnings; Renault slides
summary: European shares rose 0.1% on Friday, driven by an upbeat earnings report from Hermes, which boosted confidence in economic recovery. Hermes shares jumped 5.7% after the Birkin bag maker reported sharply recovered sales in the fourth quarter. However, the Stoxx 600 was set to snap a two-week gaining streak due to concerns over rising inflation, which could lead to central banks tapering stimulus packages. Meanwhile, Renault fell 3.5% after posting a record annual loss of €8 billion.

site_title: STI tracks Wall Street to dip 1% on rising rate worries
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 28.21 points, or 0.97%, to 2,880.64, marking a 1.5% decline for the week. The decline followed US stocks, which fell after Treasury yields rose, prompting investors to assess the impact on the equity market. Losers outnumbered gainers 261 to 202, with Jardine Matheson being the biggest loser, while Wilmar International was the top gainer. The region's markets finished mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Malaysia's KLCI also experiencing declines.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower ahead of weekend
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday, following Wall Street's decline, with investors awaiting the weekend. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.72% to 30,017.92, while the Topix index dropped 0.67% to 1,928.95. This move tracks global market trends, with investors in a wait-and-see mode ahead of the weekend.

site_title: Tencent raises US$8.3b in offshore syndicated loan
summary: Tencent Holdings has secured a record-breaking US$8.3 billion offshore syndicated loan, with 12 banks participating in the deal. The loan, initially valued at US$6 billion, will be used for general corporate purposes. This marks the largest offshore syndicated loan for a Chinese firm since 2016. Representatives for Tencent did not immediately comment on the deal.

site_title: Singapura Finance FY2020 earnings fall 36.3% on allowances for loan impairment
summary: Singapura Finance reported a 36.3% drop in FY2020 earnings to S$4.78 million, primarily due to a S$2.3 million net charge for loan impairment losses. Interest income rose 3.8% to S$31.4 million, while interest expenses increased 35.2% to S$13.2 million, resulting in a 11.1% drop in net interest and hiring charges. The firm attributed the impairment losses to a weak economic outlook and made provisions to its Regulatory Loss Allowance Reserve. Despite this, shareholders' funds of S$255 million are deemed "more than adequate" to buffer further economic volatility.

site_title: What worked, and what didn't, for remote workers
summary: Remote work changed dramatically in 2020, offering flexibility and productivity benefits but also challenges to employee morale and data security. A survey found that 47% of remote workers feel more productive at home, citing flexibility to run errands and take breaks. However, distractions from family and pets, blurred work-life boundaries, and poor security practices hindered remote work's long-term viability. Employers must address these challenges to ensure remote work arrangements remain viable, with cybersecurity best practices being a crucial step in protecting businesses.

images.alt_text: Teck Wee Lim, Regional Director, ASEAN, CyberArk

site_title: Deutsche Bank cut bonus pool plans after criticism from ECB
summary: Deutsche Bank scaled back its bonus pool plans after European Central Bank (ECB) objections, cutting payouts from over 2 billion euros to an undisclosed amount. The ECB had raised concerns about rewarding top performers during the pandemic, prompting the lender to reconsider its 2020 payout levels. Representatives for Deutsche Bank and the ECB declined to comment on the matter. The decision highlights the challenges of balancing performance incentives with regulatory demands for restraint during times of economic uncertainty.

site_title: One Uniqlo share for 100,000 yen sparks concern over Nikkei dominance
summary: Uniqlo's record share price has sparked concern over its influence on Japan's Nikkei 225 Stock Average. The casual fashion giant's share price increased by 100,000 yen, boosting its tick size and weighting in the index, making its rise increasingly intertwined with the Nikkei's. This technical change comes as the Nikkei broke the 30,000 barrier for the first time since 1990, raising questions about the dominance of the apparel retailer in the market.

site_title: Mapletree wins HK$813m land tender, to develop first data centre in Hong Kong
summary: Mapletree Investments has won a land tender in Hong Kong, acquiring a 4,000 square metre site for HK$813 million to develop the city's first data centre. The 20,140 sq m facility is expected to be completed by 2023 and will provide up to 50 megavolt amperes of building power. Located in Fanling, the data centre will be connected to CLP Group's supply network and can be leased to an end user or data centre operator upon completion, marking Mapletree's entry into Hong Kong's data centre market.

site_title: Strong Asia pushes Birkin bag maker Hermes' sales up 16% for Q4
summary: Hermes' sales rose 16% in Q4, driven by strong Asia performance, with 47% growth in the region. China, South Korea, and Australia led the rebound. For 2020, revenues declined 6% to 6.39 billion euros, a better performance than the luxury goods sector. The strong Asia sales helped offset the decline, indicating resilience in the brand despite the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Australia: Shares track Asian peers lower, commodity stocks weigh
summary: Australian shares fell 1.34% to 6,793.8 points, their worst session in three weeks, due to weaker oil and gold prices and worse-than-expected US jobless claims data. Commodity stocks, including energy and mining, were hit hard, while technology stocks rose after Morgan Stanley increased Afterpay's price target. The S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand also fell 0.67% for its fourth consecutive week of losses.

site_title: Thai Airways cuts about 240 executive positions
summary: Thai Airways International has cut approximately 240 executive positions as part of its bankruptcy restructuring process. The airline, which has around 21,000 employees, aims to increase efficiency by reducing supervisory levels from eight to five. The move is part of its efforts to submit a restructuring plan to a bankruptcy court for creditor approval by March 2. The airline's acting president stated that a successful restructuring will require cooperation from all parties, including creditors and employees. This comes as the airline continues to struggle since 2012 due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: 17 healthcare providers appointed to run Covid-19 jab centres, mobile teams
summary: Seventeen healthcare providers, including Raffles Medical and Parkway Shenton, have been appointed by the Singapore Ministry of Health to set up and run 36 vaccination centres and 10 mobile vaccination teams to administer COVID-19 vaccines. The centres and teams aim to cater to at least 2,000 people a day and will operate progressively. The mobile teams will provide mass vaccinations at nursing homes and other sites. The move follows Singapore's plan to start mass vaccinations for the elderly from February 22, with a total of 250,000 people receiving at least one jab so far.

site_title: Temasek-backed China grocery app raises US$2b in new funding round: sources
summary: Chinese community grocery shopping app Xingsheng Youxuan has raised approximately US$2 billion in a new funding round, valuing the company at US$6 billion. The round was led by Sequoia Capital China and included investors such as private equity firms FountainVest Partners and KKR & Co, as well as Tencent Holdings and Singapore's Temasek. The fundraising comes as demand for grocery delivery in China has surged due to COVID-19 social distancing restrictions, and regulators have urged Internet giants to tighten oversight of the community group buying sector.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.49 points to 1,583.44. The market saw 654.27 million lots traded worth RM227.17 million, with 412 gainers and 155 losers.

site_title: Facebook inflated its advertising audiences: lawsuit
summary: Facebook has been accused of inflating its advertising audiences to generate more revenue. A class action lawsuit claims the company knew its "Potential Reach" measure was unreliable and artificially high, but ignored the issue to avoid losing advertising revenue. Facebook's revenue is largely derived from targeted advertising, and the company allegedly made a deliberate decision not to remove duplicate or fake accounts from the Potential Reach tool metrics. The company has since modified the tool, but the lawsuit seeks to reject Facebook's request to dismiss the two-year-old litigation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.37% on Friday, extending losses from the previous day, amid worries of inflation and potential interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 30,483.46, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The losses were attributed to concerns about the economic recovery and its impact on inflation.

site_title: Gold goes from commodity leader to laggard in shocking reversal
summary: Gold, once a commodity leader, has experienced its worst start to a year since 1991, with a 6.7% decline in 2021. The metal has fallen to a seven-month low due to the resilience of the US dollar and a rally in US Treasury yields, as economic indicators show a recovery from the pandemic. Analysts attribute the decline to profit-taking and a shift in investor sentiment, with some predicting further losses if gold fails to move above $1,765. Despite this, some analysts remain bullish on gold's long-term prospects.

site_title: Honda CEO Hachigo to step down, be replaced by R&D chief Mibe
summary: Honda Motor announced that CEO Takahiro Hachigo will step down on April 1, handing over the reins to R&D chief Toshihiro Mibe. Hachigo will remain on the company board, while Mibe, 59, has been with Honda since 1987 and led the R&D unit since 2019. Mibe's appointment comes as Honda seeks to catch up in the electric car market and faces competition from tech giants. Hachigo will focus on zero-emission technology, and the company aims for new-energy vehicles to make up two-thirds of sales by 2030.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB raises Sea target to US$315 ahead of likely MSCI inclusion
summary: CGS-CIMB has raised its target price for Sea Ltd to US$315, citing the company's likely inclusion in the MSCI Singapore Index as a catalyst for growth. The tech startup is expected to benefit from a higher gaming multiple and stronger Shopee monetization. Sea's gaming subsidiary Garena is projected to grow 6% in Q4 FY2020, while Shopee is expected to report 16.9% quarter-on-quarter GMV growth. The company's adjusted revenue is forecasted to reach US$1.9 billion, with adjusted Ebitda expected to be lower quarter-over-quarter.

site_title: Malaysia's rail chief moots enabling speedy clearance for travellers on JB-Singapore RTS
summary: Malaysia's rail chief, Mohd Zarif, proposes enabling speedy clearance for travelers on the Johor-Singapore RTS Link, aiming for a 15-minute travel time between the two countries. To achieve this, the two governments would need to innovate border checks at terminal stations. The RTS Link project, suspended in 2019, has resumed and is on track to start operations in July 2026. Zarif is concerned about the efficiency of rail operations, not just infrastructure, and has suggested a common green lane program for frequent travelers to clear immigration and customs quickly.

images.alt_text: If Mohd Zarif Hashim has his way, 15 minutes would be all it takes for a train passenger to cross from Johor Baru to Singapore and vice versa.
The RTS Link project was suspended in April 2019 at Malaysia's request to allow it more time to undertake a review but has since resumed following a ceremony at the Causeway in July 2020.

site_title: Nasa confirms Perseverance rover has landed on Mars
summary: NASA confirms the Perseverance rover has landed on Mars after a successful "seven minutes of terror" landing phase. The autonomously-guided procedure was completed over 11 minutes ago, with mission control erupting in cheers. This marks a significant milestone in the Mars exploration program.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.37 points, or 0.21%, to 1,579.21. The market saw 2.10 billion lots traded worth RM781.32 million, with losers beating gainers 431 to 289.

site_title: US Fed's Brainard highlights risks banks face from climate change
summary: US Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard warned that climate change poses risks to financial institutions, including physical risks from severe weather events and transition risks from an economy-wide shift to green energy. Brainard suggested that scenario analysis and stress tests could help assess these risks. The Fed has launched a Supervision Climate Committee to study climate-related financial risks and has joined the Network for Greening the Financial System, an international network of central banks focused on climate change.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall further as recovery pace fuels rate-hike fear
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Friday as investors fretted over the prospect of interest rate hikes amid a global economic recovery. Despite record-breaking highs in recent weeks, the rally was undermined by concerns that central banks would eventually tighten monetary policies. The US stimulus package and falling infection rates are expected to fuel inflation, prompting the Federal Reserve to hike interest rates. Asian stocks fell more than 1% in Hong Kong, Sydney, Seoul, and Taipei, while Wall Street indexes also declined, with experts warning of a steep correction in vulnerable assets.

site_title: Asean e-payments market could be worth US$1.5 trillion: report
summary: A recent report estimates the Asean e-payments market could be worth US$1.5 trillion, with fintech players poised to capture a large share of cash and card payments, retail transfers, and online insurance sales. Third-party payment firms are expected to break into the Asean insurance market through online channels, offering high-margin business opportunities. The report suggests fintech players will benefit from the growing demand for online payment services in the region's six economies: Indonesia, Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Vietnam.

site_title: Facebook will expand climate hub in battle against misinformation
summary: Facebook is expanding its climate information hub to combat misinformation, adding a section that debunks common climate myths and partnering with climate experts from top universities. The move comes as the social media giant faces criticism for its handling of climate-related misinformation, including claims spread by former President Donald Trump. Facebook will direct users to experts to debunk myths and hoaxes, and will also improve its climate hub with new features. The expansion is part of a broader effort by authorities and social networks to strike a balance between free speech and anti-misinformation efforts.

site_title: Former UOB V-P accused of multiple offences including misappropriating more than S$5m
summary: A former vice-president of United Overseas Bank (UOB) has been accused of misappropriating over S$5.3 million, including nearly £2.9 million, between 2004 and 2014. He faces 74 charges, including cheating, forgery, and criminal breach of trust. The alleged offences involved false documents and duping a man into handing over funds. If convicted, he could face up to 15 years in jail and fines. The bank has dismissed him and lodged a police report against him, with a pre-trial conference set for March 11.

site_title: Australia: Shares track Wall Street lower, miners and banks weigh
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% to 6,841.10 on Friday, weighed down by miners and financials, but were on track to end the week 0.5% higher due to strong earnings reports from blue-chip companies. Mining stocks fell 1.5% but were set to add nearly 4% for the week, boosted by record dividend payouts. Financials slipped 0.9% but were set to add 1% for the week.

site_title: Geely departs from convention with plan for new EV unit: sources
summary: Geely, the owner of Volvo Cars, plans to establish a new firm, Lingling Technologies, to explore unconventional approaches to electric vehicle (EV) marketing and sales. The unit will manage models based on Geely's open-source EV chassis base, dubbed Sustainable Experience Architecture (SEA), and take over marketing and sales of SEA-based EVs under Geely's Lynk & Co and Geometry brands. This move aims to differentiate Geely's EV sales from traditional cars and compete with EV leader Tesla. The new entity will conduct research, implement technology updates, and source market data independently.

site_title: Philippines set to take rare, top spot for IPOs in South-east Asia
summary: The Philippines is poised to become the top IPO market in Southeast Asia, driven by attractive valuations and a recovering economy. Several Philippine firms, including real estate investment trusts, are lining up record fundraisings, potentially surpassing the combined total of the last seven years. The country's economy is expected to grow by 6.5-7.5% this year, and investors are taking advantage of abundant market liquidity and favorable market conditions.

site_title: Australia to continue talks with Facebook's Zuckerberg over media code
summary: Australian Treasurer Josh Frydenberg will continue talks with Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg over a new media payment code after the social media platform blocked news feeds in the country. Facebook took down pages of news outlets and state governments due to unclear definitions, with Prime Minister Scott Morrison rebuking the action as "arrogant." Australia plans to vote on legislation requiring Big Tech firms to pay news outlets or agree on a price through arbitration, with Frydenberg saying it's about Australia's sovereignty. Talks between Frydenberg and Zuckerberg will determine the outcome of the negotiations.

site_title: Keppel Reit prices private placement at S$1.13 per unit
summary: Keppel Reit has priced its private placement at S$1.13 per unit, a 4.1% discount to its volume-weighted average price. The placement, which raised S$270 million, will partially fund the Reit's acquisition of Keppel Bay Tower from Keppel Land and pay fees and expenses. Trading of the new units is expected to begin on March 1, subject to certain conditions. The placement was 4.6 times covered and saw strong participation from investors.

site_title: Australia retail sales up 0.6% in Jan, Covid-19 restrictions a drag
summary: Australia's retail sales rose 0.6% in January, missing market forecasts of a 2.0% gain, due to a coronavirus lockdown in Brisbane that kept shoppers at home. Despite this, sales were still up 10.7% compared to January last year. The state of Queensland saw a 1.5% decline, primarily due to restrictions on household goods and department stores. Retail activity has been volatile, with a 7.1% surge in November followed by a 4.1% drop in December. The final estimate will be released on March 4.

site_title: Paris wins court challenge to restrictions on Airbnb rentals
summary: Paris' court challenge to restrictions on Airbnb rentals has been successful, with France's highest court ruling that regulations against short-term rentals are "proportionate" and in line with European law. The regulations, introduced to counter Airbnb's impact on the local property market, require apartment owners to register their properties and restrict rentals to primary residences to 120 days a year. The ruling paves the way for the city to resume claims against 420 renters who have been fined for breaking the rules, and is seen as a victory for other European cities seeking to limit Airbnb's impact.

site_title: Myanmar generals under sanctions pressure
summary: Myanmar's generals face growing global pressure as Britain and Canada impose targeted sanctions. The sanctions, freezing assets and imposing travel bans, come after the US cut off $1 billion in funds. Rights groups say the moves are insufficient to hold the military accountable. Protests continue, with over 520 people arrested and detentions of civilians and foreign officials reported. The junta justifies its power seizure by alleging electoral fraud, with Aung San Suu Kyi's hearing on an obscure charge set for March 1.

site_title: Banks' rates transition may pinch margins in near term
summary: Singapore banks may experience margin compression as they transition to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) as the main interest rate benchmark, but analysts believe there won't be a "race to the bottom" for loan pricing. Sora is considered a risk-free rate due to its stability, whereas SOR and Sibor rates are exposed to market factors and credit risk. Banks will apply a spread to Sora-referenced loans, but effective interest rates are expected to remain similar to pre-Sora rates, with loan pricing dependent on multiple factors including customer credit profiles and funding costs.

site_title: Japan's Feb factory activity expands for first time in 22 months: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity expanded for the first time in 22 months in February, with the private-sector survey showing a 50.6 PMI, up from 49.8 in January. Strong export demand helped manufacturers recover from the pandemic's drag. However, the service sector remained pessimistic, with the au Jibun Bank Flash Japan Services PMI index falling to a six-month low of 45.8. Despite this, the economy is expected to continue benefiting from overseas demand, particularly for chip-making equipment.

site_title: Walmart's investment year will hold back profit growth; shares slide
summary: Walmart expects slow profit growth in its upcoming fiscal year due to investments in its business, including a wage hike to over $15 per hour on average. The company's shares slid 6.5% following the announcement, which also forecast low single-digit sales growth and flat-to-slightly up earnings per share. Walmart plans to invest $14 billion in capital expenditure, focusing on supply chain and automation, as it aims to position itself for future growth.

site_title: ST Engineering posts 14% fall in H2 profit
summary: ST Engineering posted a 14% fall in net profit for the half year ended Dec 31 to S$264.4 million, down from S$308.6 million a year ago. Revenue slipped 18% to S$3.6 billion. The company attributed the decline to Covid-19, customer demand reduction, supply chain challenges, and workforce disruption. Net profit for the full year fell 9.7% to S$521.8 million, while revenue dipped 9% to S$7.16 billion. Group president Vincent Chong expects a continued downtrend in 2021, but aims to offset effects through order book delivery and cost reduction initiatives.

site_title: Bitcoin gold rush sparks fears of speculative bubble
summary: Bitcoin surged past US$50,000 after Tesla's investment and Wall Street giants' plans to support the cryptocurrency, sparking fears of a speculative bubble. The unit has increased five times in value over the past year, with the combined value of all units reaching almost US$1 trillion. Industry professionals describe bitcoin as the "new digital gold," but experts warn of its volatility and lack of regulation, with some comparing it to the 2017 bubble that burst after reaching nearly US$20,000.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has enjoyed a record-breaking week after electric carmaker Tesla and Wall Street finance giants sparked a goldrush for the world's most popular virtual currency, but bubble fears persist.

site_title: US life expectancy fell by a year as Covid hit: data
summary: US life expectancy fell by a year in the first half of 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, according to CDC data. The life expectancy at birth for the total US population dropped from 78.8 years in 2019 to 77.8 years. Minorities, particularly non-Hispanic Blacks and Hispanics, were disproportionately affected, with life expectancy decreasing by three and nearly two years, respectively. The US has registered 490,000 coronavirus deaths, the highest national death toll in the world.

site_title: Transcelestial gets US$2m from Kickstart Ventures, enters Philippines
summary: Singapore-based startup Transcelestial has secured US$2 million from Kickstart Ventures, a corporate venture capital arm of Globe Telecom in the Philippines. The investment will enable Transcelestial to enter the Philippine market and increase access to high-speed, reliable Internet. Transcelestial's proprietary wireless laser communication technology allows for faster and more affordable deployment of Internet infrastructure, with the potential to deliver speeds of up to 100 gigabits per second. The investment aims to address the country's low average download speed and increase Internet penetration.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engg, Keppel Reit, SGX, OCBC, Roxy-Pacific, Aspen
summary: ST Engineering reported a 14% decline in net profit to S$264.4 million for its half-year ended Dec 31, due to Covid-19-related lower demand and supply chain challenges. Keppel Reit priced a private placement at S$1.13 per unit, covering 4.6 times, while Singapore Exchange launched a new Orchid bond structure. OCBC acquired a stake in Malaysia-incorporated Horizon Asset Management for RM2.55 million (S$837,650). Roxy-Pacific Holdings entered an agreement to acquire a residential site for S$33.6 million. Aspen Holdings incorporated a new subsidiary for research and development of medical engineering technology.

site_title: Australian news sites' traffic falls after Facebook blocks content: Chartbeat
summary: Australian news sites experienced a 13% drop in web traffic after Facebook blocked their content in protest of a looming law requiring the platform to pay publishers. The decline was largely outweighed by a 30% drop in traffic from Facebook, with Google seeing a 8% increase in traffic from Australian news sites. The move highlights Facebook's significant impact on the local market, with 15% of Australian news site visits coming from the platform, according to historical data.

site_title: GlobalConnect@SBF reports 15 successful overseas ventures
summary: The Singapore Business Federation's (SBF) GlobalConnect@SBF programme has achieved 15 successful overseas ventures for Singapore businesses in Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, the US, and Turkey since its launch in November 2019. The programme, in partnership with Enterprise Singapore, has reached out to 2,500 companies and provided over 900 market advisories. SBF aims to scale up its efforts, expecting the number of successful ventures to double in the second year.

site_title: Singapore stocks retreat, tracking Wall Street losses; STI down 0.5% at open
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.5% at open, following a weak lead from US indices overnight. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 13.87 points to 2,894.98, amid 'risk off' sentiment. This marks a reversal of the 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, following a decline on Wall Street due to disappointing US labor data. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.61% to 30,053.09, and the Topix index dropped 0.66% to 1,929.16. This move tracked the US market's losses, which saw the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edge to fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty and conflicting Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Credit Suisse targets lending volume after better-than-expected Q4 loss
summary: Credit Suisse reported a net loss of 353 million Swiss francs in Q4 2020, despite better-than-expected results, due to low interest rates and legal charges. The bank aims to increase lending volume and capitalize on a boom in share listings to shore up revenue. CEO Thomas Gottstein targets 10% annual earnings growth in wealth management and a digital overhaul to cut costs. The bank's investment bank saw a surge in revenue, and it proposed a dividend and started a share buyback program.

site_title: The realities of vaccination
summary: Employers can make COVID-19 vaccination mandatory for staff, but workers may face potential discrimination or job loss if they refuse. Airlines are requiring proof of vaccination, and employers are encouraging inoculation for workplace safety and customer protection. As the pandemic subsides, those who choose not to get vaccinated may face treatment differences from employers and institutions.

site_title: Oil falls after surging past US$65 on Texas freeze
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday, despite a drop in US crude inventories, after market participants took profits following days of buying due to a Texas freeze. Brent crude fell 41 cents to US$63.93 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 62 cents to US$60.52 a barrel, after reaching their highest levels since January 2020. The drop was attributed to a bearish outlook following US President Trump's tariff announcements, which led to a decrease in investor confidence.

site_title: US and 'Quad' allies push democracy in Myanmar
summary: The US, along with its 'Quad' allies Australia, India, and Japan, has called for strengthening democracy in Asia and reversing Myanmar's military coup. The US, under President Joe Biden, has renewed the Quad alliance despite concerns from China. The four countries agreed to meet at least once a year to discuss democracy and the rule of law, with Japan urging Myanmar's military to stop violent protests and release Aung San Suu Kyi. The Biden administration plans to put pressure on Myanmar through cooperation with Japan and India, while China has warned of economic retaliation if the Quad crosses its "red lines".

site_title: Global debt surges to an all-time record of US$281 trillion in 2020
summary: Global debt reached an all-time record of $281 trillion in 2020, a surge of $24 trillion from the previous year, driven by massive government aid and declining state and corporate revenues. The debt represents 355% of global GDP, exceeding earlier estimates. Economists warn that high debt levels will crimp long-term growth, while governments may allow inflation to reduce real debt levels in the coming years.

site_title: Love me, love Star Wars
summary: A recent Valentine's Day weekend saw couples and solo visitors alike bonding over the Star Wars: Identities exhibition at the ArtScience Museum in Singapore. Men enthusiastically explained Star Wars lore to their female partners, while some solo males engaged in debates about the franchise. The exhibition, designed as a journey of self-discovery, allowed visitors to choose their Star Wars character and admire themselves on a large screen. The event ran from February 18, 2021, to June 13, 2021, and tickets were available for S$25.

site_title: Time to get tough with 'bully' Facebook, UK lawmaker and publishers say
summary: UK lawmakers and publishers say Facebook's move to block all news content in Australia is a bully tactic that will strengthen their resolve to regulate tech giants. The move, launched 17 years ago, has already disrupted the global news industry. Chair of the British Parliament's Digital Committee, Julian Knight, believes this action will ignite a desire for further regulation among legislators worldwide.

site_title: San Francisco exodus leads pandemic housing reshuffle
summary: San Francisco's exodus from the housing market has led to a significant shift in the US housing landscape. Data suggests that 1.5% to 3% of the city's population has left for surrounding counties or states, with around 46,000 people exiting the Bay Area's 10 counties, including 13,000 leaving San Francisco. This trend is expected to continue, with higher home sales in neighboring states like Texas and North Carolina, and a 15-year high in available condominiums in San Francisco.

site_title: Should Spotify payments go to artists you actually listen to?
summary: Spotify payments to artists are a contentious issue, with many struggling to survive despite having millions of listeners. The current model favors top artists, with the top 10 artists taking nearly 10% of the pay-out, while others face an "absurd" chance of survival. A proposed "user-centric model" could redistribute funds to artists based on user listening habits, but critics argue it's not a silver bullet and won't solve the industry's deeper issues, such as the stranglehold of major labels. Campaigners are calling for a more equitable distribution of funds and greater transparency in the streaming industry.

site_title: GameStop key players tell US lawmakers no manipulation
summary: US lawmakers heard testimony from key players in the GameStop trading frenzy, with founders of Robinhood and Reddit stating their actions were above board. Robinhood CEO Vlad Tenev and amateur investor Keith Gill denied manipulation, with Gill saying he researched GameStop shares independently and not to influence the market. Melvin Capital Management's founder Gabriel Plotkin also testified that his fund did not manipulate trading, citing significant losses after the shares jumped. US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has promised to review the market volatility caused by the social media-fueled buying frenzy.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower on weak earnings, rising inflation concerns
summary: European shares fell for a third consecutive day, with the Stoxx 600 dropping 0.8% due to disappointing earnings reports and rising inflation concerns. Oil and gas stocks led losses despite higher crude prices, while a wider fourth-quarter loss from Norway's Nel ASA and Royal Dutch Shell's plan to sell assets in Alberta contributed to the decline. Analysts expect European corporate earnings to decline 20% in the fourth quarter, with the European Central Bank concerned about the impact of high inflation on the economic recovery.

images.alt_text: European shares marked a third straight day of losses on Thursday as a clutch of disappointing earnings reports added to concerns over a quicker-than-expected spike in inflation due to higher commodity prices and a strong euro.

site_title: Electric vehicles may not be best answer to climate change
summary: Electric vehicles may not be the best solution to address climate change, according to a former industry executive. The author cites the UK's diesel saga as an example of how over-regulation can hinder progress. Instead of dictating the solution, governments should identify the problem, provide funding, and let scientists and engineers develop multiple technologies to achieve a cleaner future. The author suggests that alternative options, such as hydrogen, synthetic fuels, and unknown technologies, may be more efficient and effective in reducing emissions.

site_title: Health, jobs, income gaps are the top challenges in SEA
summary: A survey by the Asean Studies Centre found that the top concerns in South-east Asia are health, jobs, and income disparities, surpassing previous issues such as domestic instability and terrorism. The pandemic remains a significant threat, with 76% of respondents citing health concerns. Unemployment and economic recession ranked second, and widening socio-economic gaps came in third. The survey also showed a shift in perceptions of China's influence, with the US regaining its position as the most influential economic and political power in the region, particularly among countries such as Vietnam and Singapore.

site_title: Copper's hot run tipped to last given tight market
summary: Copper prices have surged to their highest level since 2012 due to a global supply crunch, output disruptions, and renewed green impetus. The US stimulus, vaccine roll-out, and weaker US dollar have also fueled the rally. Copper concentrate treatment charges have fallen by half, indicating a tightening supply. Green infrastructure stimulus and the need for copper in electric vehicle charging stations are also driving demand. Analysts predict the price environment will attract investment to meet future demand, but some experts warn the rally may not be sustainable in the long run.

site_title: Indonesian bank regulator says Shopee has bought Bank BKE
summary: Shopee, the e-commerce arm of Sea Group, has acquired Indonesian lender Bank Kesejahteraan Ekonomi (Bank BKE) with the goal of transforming it into a digital bank. The Indonesian Financial Services Authority (OJK) has not yet received an official application, but Shopee is preparing the necessary infrastructure. The new digital bank is expected to prepare 3 trillion rupiah in capital, and regulations are being prepared by OJK, with a likely release in mid-2021. This move is part of Shopee's fintech push in the region, competing with other digital banks like Jago.

site_title: Singapore, Indonesia say Asean can play important role in Myanmar
summary: Singapore and Indonesia's foreign ministers believe Asean can play a crucial role in promoting dialogue and normalcy in Myanmar following the military coup on February 1. They expressed support for an informal ministerial meeting to facilitate constructive exchange and foster inclusive dialogue with all stakeholders. The move comes amid differing responses to the coup among Asean members, with some countries, including the US and Britain, imposing sanctions.

site_title: US: Stocks decline after disappointing labour data
summary: US stocks declined after disappointing labour data and Walmart's quarterly loss. New jobless claims rose 13,000 to 861,000, while Walmart dropped 6.4% due to higher capital spending. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 fell 0.4% each, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.7%. Robinhood's Vlad Tenev defended the trading site's handling of the GameStop frenzy, and analysts cited unease over high equity valuations and rising yields on US Treasury bonds. Investors await potential stimulus spending and its impact on inflation.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks declined on Thursday following disappointing US labour data and Walmart results as key players in the GameStop trading upheaval defended their actions at a Capitol Hill hearing.

site_title: Anger mounts as Facebook's Australia news ban sweeps up charities, government pages
summary: Facebook blocked news content in Australia, shutting down dozens of companies, charities, and information providers, including government pages and local newspapers. The move followed an escalation of a proposed media bargaining code requiring the company to pay news outlets for content. Charities, small businesses, and community groups were also affected, with many expressing outrage and calling for users to delete the platform. Facebook restored some government services pages, but many remain blocked, sparking calls for the social media giant to restore access.

site_title: Biden pledges US$4b for global Covid-19 vaccine programme
summary: US President Joe Biden will pledge $4 billion in US aid to the Covax global Covid-19 vaccination programme during a virtual meeting with G-7 leaders. An initial $2 billion will be released by the end of the month, with the remaining $2 billion to be disbursed over the next two years. This aid aims to support poorer nations in catching up with vaccination efforts, focusing on the most vulnerable 20% of the population in each country.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden will pledge US$4 billion in US aid to the Covax global Covid-19 vaccination programme during his virtual meeting with other G-7 leaders on Friday, White House officials said.

site_title: A tasty way to spur EV adoption
summary: Singapore aims to have 60,000 charging points by 2030 to encourage electric vehicle adoption. However, the country has only around 1,300 electric cars, with more charging points than cars. To boost EV adoption, the government could consider allowing EV drivers to use bus lanes, leading by example, and requiring new condominium developments to install charging points. Existing condominium management committees may be hesitant to install charging points due to concerns about cost and reserved parking spots. The government could consider providing funding to help pay for charging points in condos, potentially turning EV drivers into "benefactors" rather than "freeloaders."

site_title: Warburg Pincus to raise US$750m in IPOs for 2 blank-cheque firms
summary: Private equity firm Warburg Pincus is raising up to $750 million for two blank-cheque firms, Warburg Pincus Capital Corporation I-A and Warburg Pincus Capital Corporation I-B, through initial public offerings (IPOs). The firms plan to merge with businesses with near-term potential to bring in strong free cash flow. This is part of the growing trend of special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs), which raised $24.26 billion in January 2021, a 20-fold increase from the same period in 2020. The IPOs will list on the New York Stock Exchange.

site_title: The decarbonisation paradox
summary: Achieving a net-zero global economy by 2050 is technically feasible with existing and emerging technologies, but requires drastic shifts in behavior and massive policy interventions. The UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change estimates a 45% reduction in CO2 emissions by 2030 and net zero by 2050, requiring rapid and far-reaching transitions in various sectors. Despite technological optimism, widespread alarmism persists due to inadequate international cooperation, distributional challenges, and insufficient funding. Policymakers must channel massive savings into long-term investment and demonstrate unprecedented commitment to domestic and international equity to resolve the paradox and prevent catastrophic climate events.

site_title: British online gaming company to use AI to identify problem gamblers
summary: British online gaming company Entain plc will use AI-powered data science and psychology experts to identify problem gamblers. The Advanced Protection & Care system (ARC) will flag erratic behavior and enable the company to switch off riskier features or connect players to customer service before harm occurs. The system aims to balance player enjoyment with harm prevention, with the goal of making games more engaging for players who play for fun. The UK company's online net gaming revenue rose 27% in 2020, amid growing regulatory scrutiny and pressure from campaigners.

site_title: Bank Indonesia cuts rate as economic recovery stalls
summary: Bank Indonesia cut its benchmark interest rate to a record low of 3.5% amid fears of a Covid-19 resurgence slowing economic recovery. The 25 basis point reduction was expected by 22 out of 29 economists surveyed. The move aims to stimulate economic growth, but the central bank downgraded its growth outlook, citing concerns over the impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Airbus cautious on 2021 despite cementing cash flow turnaround
summary: Airbus reported a 4.9 billion euros in cash generated during the fourth quarter, beating its target to break even for a second straight quarter based on adjusted free cash flow. However, the company remains cautious on the pace of its recovery from the aviation crisis, citing uncertain airline demand and tight borders. Airbus forecasts jet handovers this year to match 566 delivered in 2020 and expects breakeven adjusted free cash flow, with EBIT forecast at 2 billion euros. The company expects the commercial aircaft market to return to pre-Covid levels until 2023-2025.

site_title: US dollar steadies; Bitcoin nears record US$52,640
summary: The US dollar steadied on Thursday after its first back-to-back gains in two weeks, driven by upbeat data showing the US economy rebounding from the coronavirus pandemic. Bitcoin traded near a record high of $52,640, with investors expecting a further boost from President Joe Biden's proposed $1.9 trillion Covid-19 relief package. The dollar index gained 1% this year, rebounding from a 7% slide in 2020, and analysts expect the dollar to remain the most expensive currency in the G10.

site_title: Family behind Spring Court Restaurant buys Bukit Pasoh shophouse
summary: A shophouse at the corner of Neil and Bukit Pasoh roads in Singapore is being bought by members of the family that owns Spring Court Restaurant for S$12.93 million. The 3,700 sq ft property has a built-up area of about 4,000 sq ft and is approved for restaurant use on both levels. The purchase is part of a strong start to the year for the Singapore shophouse market, with 16 deals totaling nearly S$116 million so far in 2021, according to CBRE.

site_title: Court dismisses fraud claims against CAG, says structure of lawsuit is illegal
summary: The Singapore High Court dismissed allegations of fraud against Capital Asia Group (CAG) and its sole director over an oil investment scheme. The court ruled that the structure of the lawsuit was illegal, throwing out claims of fraudulent misrepresentations and a "ponzi" scheme. The case involved over 1,000 multinational investors and Canadian companies Proven Oil Asia and Conserve Oil Group Inc. The ruling was handed down by High Court judge Choo Han Teck.

site_title: Implosion reduces the Trump era in Atlantic City to dust and debris
summary: The Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City imploded in a symbolic finale, erasing the last remnants of former President Donald Trump's casino empire. The implosion occurred after an auction for the right to detonate the dynamite failed. The property's billionaire owner, Carl Icahn, has yet to reveal plans for the site, leaving its future unclear. The implosion marks the end of the Trump era in Atlantic City, a seaside resort city that once hosted the former president's casino empire.

site_title: Institutional demand seen for SINGA bonds that follow SGS structure
summary: Singapore's new Significant Infrastructure Government Loan Act (SINGA) bonds will qualify as liquid assets for financial institutions, mirroring existing Singapore Government Securities (SGS) in yield, tenor, and structure. This is expected to attract institutional demand from banks and insurers, rather than retail investors. The bonds will be priced along the same yield curve, backed by the government's assets, and carry the same credit risk as SGS. Proceeds will finance major infrastructure projects crucial to Singapore's long-term sustainability.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Takayama restaurant in OUE Downtown Gallery is offering a unique omakase dinner experience, featuring Tottori's signature produce, including snow crab and premium fish. Chef Taro Takayama incorporates these ingredients into dishes like donabe cooked crab rice, charred Tottori Spanish mackerel, and buttery kampachi. The meal also includes other local specialties, such as abalone and strawberries, and is priced at S$280. Reservations can be made through takayama.com.sg.

site_title: Clean up toxic work environments
summary: A toxic work environment has become a major issue, partly due to incompetent leadership and self-satisfaction. As COVID-19 has exposed the vulnerability of authority, people are seeking decent behavior and trust in their workplaces. Tech start-ups are an exception, with a refreshing reminder that business can thrive despite the challenges. To identify a toxic environment, ask employees about their terms and conditions, resources, communication, and treatment by management. Leaders must practice decency, interpret rules, and prioritize the well-being of their team members. Implementing positive changes can lead to a resounding success.

site_title: How to think about wine vintages
summary: A 2011 Northern California wine vintage was widely regarded as poor, but a tasting of six cabernet-based wines from top producers showed them to be complex and elegant, contradicting expectations. The disparity may be due to the exceptional quality of the wines from Ridge Monte Bello, Cathy Corison, and Inglenook, which were produced by renowned vintners. This experience highlights the importance of considering the specific characteristics of individual wines when evaluating vintage quality.

images.alt_text: Conventional wisdom can often lead consumers away from delicious wines - it's better to think of individual years in terms of character than of quality:

site_title: Mercedes-AMG GLA 45 S review: Good to the last drop
summary: The Mercedes-AMG GLA 45 S is a high-performance SUV that satisfies its owners' thirst for power but consumes a lot of fuel. With a 421 horsepower, hand-built 2.0-liter engine, it outperforms the base GLA 180, despite being visually similar. The car offers a sporty driving experience, solid handling, and an adaptive four-wheel drive system. However, its fuel efficiency is relatively low, making it a potentially last-of-its-kind model in the wake of the shift to electric cars. The GLA 45 S is priced at S$311,888, making it a significant investment.

site_title: Living large in a small space
summary: A Singaporean lawyer hired architect Lim Shing Hui to renovate her 1,100 sq ft ground-floor apartment into a single-storey house-like home. The transformation features a pitched roof, timber rafters, and a bed of river stones to separate spaces, creating a sense of "three different houses." The apartment now has an open-plan kitchen, exposed brick walls, and a neutral color palette. The homeowner, who initially doubted the design, now loves her new sanctuary, appreciating the unique blend of apartment living and single-storey home feel.

site_title: AirAsia to enter food delivery business in Singapore
summary: AirAsia is set to enter the food delivery business in Singapore, according to CEO Tony Fernandes. He announced the venture in a LinkedIn post, but did not specify when operations will begin. This move marks AirAsia's expansion into a new industry, as the budget carrier primarily focuses on air travel services.

site_title: Credit Suisse CEO sees SPAC boom lasting whereas Goldman has its doubts
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Thomas Gottstein believes the SPAC (special purpose acquisition vehicle) boom will continue, citing increasing demand in Asia and a growing alternative to private equity and traditional IPOs. In contrast, Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon has expressed doubts, warning that the market may be too enamored and that a pullback could occur this year. Despite Goldman's concerns, SPACs raised a record $39 billion in the fourth quarter, more than 10 times the same period in 2019, with Credit Suisse leading as the top adviser on IPOs of such companies.

site_title: Port of Los Angeles at capacity, cargo ships diverted
summary: The Port of Los Angeles is experiencing a six-month import surge, straining its capacity, and cargo ships are being diverted to other West Coast ports. The port has a record backlog of 62 ships, with an average wait of eight days to enter the complex. To ease the congestion, shipping lines such as Hapag Lloyd and CMA CGM are temporarily diverting sailings to Oakland and other ports. The surge in imports is due to US businesses rebuilding depleted inventories, with total volume at the Port of Los Angeles reaching 835,516 20-foot equivalent units in January.

site_title: The art of giving
summary: Philanthropist Pierre Lorinet is leading an initiative to encourage companies to donate to the arts. The Sustain The Arts (stART) Fund, launched by the National Arts Council, aims to raise S$10 million by 2023 to support small arts organizations. Lorinet believes the arts provide essential value to society, promoting creativity and innovation, and are often misunderstood as a luxury. Despite government support during the pandemic, many arts groups continue to struggle financially. Lorinet advocates for a network between arts groups and the private sector to provide long-term support and equip small organizations with the skills to sustain themselves.

images.alt_text: Some recipients of the Sustain The Arts (stART) Fund include Paper Monkeys (above), Bhumi Collective and Decadance Co Limited.
Some recipients of the Sustain The Arts (stART) Fund include Paper Monkeys, Bhumi Collective (above) and Decadance Co Limited.
Some recipients of the Sustain The Arts (stART) Fund include Paper Monkeys, Bhumi Collective and Decadance Co Limited (above).

Mr Lorinet: "I realise it's a challenge for some organisations to give to the arts. Most organisations see value in donating to causes that are directly or better aligned with their company's missions . . . But the arts can benefit organisations in unexpected ways.

site_title: Last year's worst Nikkei stocks are now best performers
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 Stock Average has seen a reversal, with old-world technology stocks like Konica Minolta, Nikon, and Citizen Watch surging. Konica Minolta has risen 46% this year, after dropping 45% last year due to the pandemic. Analysts attribute the surge to the normalization of work and profits rebounding after the pandemic fades. Other cyclical stocks, such as oil explorer Inpex, are also performing well, despite global focus on modern-world names like cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Selfless leadership is all about giving, not taking
summary: Leaders who exhibit selfless leadership qualities tend to be servant leaders, prioritizing the growth and success of their team members. Research by Adam Grant suggests that about 35% of leaders are self-aware, recognizing their own strengths and weaknesses, and are focused on collaboration and service. These selfless leaders, often referred to as "Givers," are more likely to build a culture of success, with higher profits, customer satisfaction, and employee retention. To build a culture of Givers, leaders must recognize the value of Givers, encourage help-seeking, and create a culture where asking for help is the norm.

images.alt_text: Leaders need to walk the talk. They just cannot afford to be Takers and expect the rest of the organisation to give to each other. The first thing that's really critical is for them to recognise that Givers are their most valuable asset and protect them or they will burn out.

site_title: Ex-minister Lim Hwee Hua launches book about government in business
summary: Former Singapore Cabinet minister Lim Hwee Hua has launched a book titled "Government In Business: Leading Or Lagging?" discussing the government's involvement in business, including the Singapore Sports Hub, MRT disruptions, and home-sharing via Airbnb. The book features 64 case studies from around the world, including Singapore, highlighting the challenges of regulating businesses amid rapid technological change. The book's findings were echoed by Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing, who emphasized the importance of regulatory agility, transparency, and accountability in enabling innovation and growth.

site_title: HK$459.4 million Hong Kong flat sale sets new Asia record
summary: A luxury penthouse in Hong Kong's Mid-Levels neighbourhood has set a new record for price per square foot, selling for HK$459.4 million (US$59 million) at US$17,500 per square foot. This sale comes despite the city's economic contraction and high unemployment rate, highlighting the stark inequality in Hong Kong. The record price beats the previous record set in 2017 and underscores the resilience of the super-rich in the luxury property market.

site_title: Malaysia's Sime Darby Plantation eyes palm oil output recovery, high prices
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby Plantation expects crude palm oil output in Malaysia and Indonesia to recover from last year's decline due to extreme weather and pandemic-induced labour shortages. The company forecasts high prices for palm oil this year. Last year's production fell due to these factors, which also affected the edible oil market. Despite this, Sime Darby Plantation remains optimistic about the market outlook.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover cutting 2,000 workers in reorganisation
summary: Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) plans to cut 2,000 salaried workers globally in the next financial year as part of a reorganisation under new CEO Thierry Bollore. The company, owned by Tata Motors, aims to reduce costs and invest £2.5 billion in electrification technologies. JLR reported a 38% profit rise last quarter, driven by pent-up demand in China. The reorganisation will not affect hourly manufacturing workers, and the company has set aside £35 million for expected fines related to non-compliance with Europe's carbon-dioxide emissions rules.

site_title: Business 'bubble' travellers to arrive from early March
summary: Singapore's quarantine-free "business travel bubble" facility, Connect@Changi, will welcome its first guests from early March, despite a delayed launch. The facility, operated by Temasek Holdings, offers short-term business travelers a quarantine-free experience, with an initial capacity of 150 guest rooms. The scheme aims to boost Singapore's reputation as a business hub and support economic recovery, particularly in the hospitality sector. While some experts predict limited demand, others see potential for growth, particularly from regions without no-quarantine travel arrangements.

images.alt_text: The boardroom at Connect@Changi, the world's first pilot purpose-built facility designed for travellers to conduct meetings and engagements in a safe environment.

site_title: US home construction slows in January
summary: US new home construction projects slowed in January for the first time since August, with a 6.0% drop in single-family homes and a 1.58 million units seasonally-adjusted annual rate. This decline came despite strong demand for homes, due to rising lumber prices and a shortage of workers. However, building permits issued in January jumped 10.4%, indicating more supply in the pipeline. Experts expect recovering demand and low mortgage rates to support a healthy rate of new home construction, with the risk of further upside surprises.

site_title: Oil trader GP Global Apac seeking debt moratorium
summary: GP Global Apac, a Singapore-based oil trader, has applied to the Singapore High Court for a six-month debt moratorium as its parent company seeks to restructure over US$1 billion in debt. The company, owned by India's Goel family, has missed loan payments and faced several lawsuits and ship seizures by creditors. A restructuring strategy includes "standstill agreements" with creditors, allowing the company to sell assets without threats of creditor action. The moratorium application aims to give the company breathing space to carry out the restructuring.

site_title: Chinese cancer screening firm trebles in Hong Kong IPO debut
summary: A Chinese cancer screening firm, New Horizon Health, made its Hong Kong IPO debut, tripling in value to close at HK$84, up 215% from its offer price of HK$26.66. The company raised at least HK$2 billion (US$263 million) in the IPO, which was oversubscribed 4,133 times. This marks the largest first-day rise in Hong Kong's IPO history and follows Kuaishou Technology's 161% debut two weeks prior, fueling concerns of an overheated market.

site_title: The Bollywood movie isn't over yet, my friend
summary: India's media and entertainment sector is expected to decline by 20% in the 2021 fiscal year due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with print media, films, and television showing the biggest decline. However, digital media and online gaming segments are expected to show positive growth. Advertising revenues for digital media are projected to overtake TV advertising revenues for the first time in 2021, with a 33% growth projected for 2022. Bollywood producers are shifting towards over-the-top (OTT) streaming services, with Netflix, Amazon, and Hotstar investing heavily in content for Indian audiences. The government is considering initiatives to improve growth, including creating a culture that respects intellectual property and opting for "light touch" regulations.

site_title: Former US presidential candidate Bob Dole has lung cancer
summary: Former US presidential candidate Bob Dole, 97, announced he has stage four lung cancer and will begin treatment next week. Dole, a five-term US senator and 1996 Republican presidential nominee, has battled health challenges throughout his life, including being severely wounded in World War II. He joins millions of Americans facing significant health challenges. Dole's announcement comes after a long career in politics, including time as House and Senate representative, majority and minority leader, and presidential nominee.

site_title: US jobless claims hit four-week high in fresh labour setback
summary: US jobless claims rose to a four-week high, reaching 861,000 in the week ended Feb 13, up 13,000 from the prior week. Continuing claims fell to 4.49 million, while the federal pandemic unemployment benefit program saw a decline to 4.06 million. The data indicates the labour market has a tougher recovery road ahead, with initial claims failing to show sustained decline for five months. This may influence the Labor Department's March 5 jobs report, highlighting millions of Americans struggling to pay bills despite other parts of the economy nearing pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Katrina warns of FY2020 loss on Covid-19 impact
summary: Katrina Group, a Singapore-based dining company, expects a loss for FY2020 due to lower revenue and impairment losses from the Covid-19 pandemic. The company will announce its full-year results by March 1. Shares closed flat at S$0.134 on the day of the announcement.

site_title: 2021 BMW 318i review: Huat price, perfection?
summary: The 2021 BMW 318i Sport is a compact sedan that delivers a perfect driving experience, despite being the least powerful in its class. It features a modern engine, plush interior, and advanced safety features. However, its high price tag and limited electric options make it less appealing compared to rivals from Audi and Mercedes. Despite this, the 318i remains a reliable choice for those seeking a premium driving experience, with a starting price of $207,888 in Singapore. Its balance of performance and comfort makes it a compelling option, but its cost may be a barrier for some buyers.

site_title: Aspen sets up new unit for glove R&D
summary: Aspen has set up a new unit, AG Medical Tech, for the research and development of medical-grade latex and nitrile gloves. The subsidiary will manage intellectual property rights and develop a blockchain-based supply-chain management system. Aspen Glove will also explore collaborations with universities and research institutes. The move aims to improve the manufacturing and distribution of medical gloves. Shares of Aspen closed flat at S$0.22 on the announcement.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on mixed data, valuation concerns
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday due to mixed economic data, with new jobless claims rising to 861,000 and new home construction declining for the first time in five months. Despite optimism over potential stimulus spending, investors expressed concerns over high equity valuations and rising interest rates. The Dow Jones fell 0.7%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.7%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.9%. Walmart's stock fell 5.9% after announcing a significant increase in capital spending and employee wages.

site_title: Sygnum raises eight-figure investment from Japan's SBI Group
summary: Sygnum, a digital asset company, has secured an eight-figure US-dollar investment from SBI Digital Asset Holdings, the digital asset arm of Japan's SBI Group. This investment is part of a recent series of partnerships between entities in Singapore and Japan, considered friendly jurisdictions for digital assets. The partnership aims to unlock deep tech innovation, following a trend of startup funding in the region.

site_title: Thai PM's aide files complaint accusing lawmaker of insulting king
summary: A Thai PM's aide filed a complaint accusing an opposition lawmaker of insulting the king under Thailand's lese majeste law, punishable by up to 15 years in prison. The complaint was filed after the lawmaker posted allegedly offensive content on Facebook. The opposition lawmaker denies the accusation, stating she will address the issue in parliament. This is part of a broader crackdown on lese majeste cases, with at least 59 people charged since November, according to human rights records.

site_title: Technology and food distribution key to F&B growth, says founder of Ebb & Flow
summary: Lim Kian Chun, 29-year-old CEO of Ebb & Flow Group, attributes the success of his F&B business to technology and food distribution. The three-year-old company has 12 brands, including eight launched last year and four this year, such as Sommer, Chin Mee Chin, and Tigerlily. Despite the high stakes and slow returns of the industry, Lim persevered, becoming besotted with the F&B sector. His group is now one of the fastest-growing in Singapore, with a focus on innovative and modern concepts.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings' associate Mequity Hills has agreed to acquire a 999-year leasehold site in Singapore for S$33.6 million. The site, located at 10A and 10B Institution Hill, will be amalgamated with another site at 11 Institution Hill to create a combined site with an estimated total land area of 14,300 sq ft. The project is expected to have a total gross floor area of 40,040 sq ft for residential development. The acquisition is part of Mequity Hills' plans to develop the site into a residential project.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post biggest fall in nearly three weeks on virus woes
summary: South Korean shares plummeted 1.50% on Thursday, marking the largest decline in nearly three weeks, as concerns over the lingering domestic Covid-19 situation weighed on sentiment. The benchmark Kospi closed at 3,086.75, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix falling 1.3% and 3.1%, respectively. Foreigners were net sellers of 858.9 billion won worth of shares, while the won remained flat against the US dollar. The country reported 621 new infections, unchanged from the previous day, and the won's benchmark bond yield fell.

site_title: Chinese cancer screening firm triples in Hong Kong IPO debut
summary: Chinese cancer screening firm New Horizon Health's Hong Kong IPO debut tripled its stock price, closing at HK$84, up 215% from its offer price of HK$26.66. The biotech company raised US$263 million in the IPO, which saw over one million Hong Kong investors put in orders worth HK$844 billion. This marks the biggest first-day rise in Hong Kong's IPO history, following Kuaishou Technology's 161% debut two weeks prior.

site_title: Top Bhutan general and judges detained for overthrow plot
summary: Bhutanese authorities have detained a top general, Brigadier Thinley Tobgay, and two judges, Kuenley Tshering and Yeshey Dorji, over an alleged plot to overthrow the country's top military officer and chief justice. The alleged plot involved implicating Lieutenant General Batoo Tshering in a corruption scandal, with Tobgay accused of obtaining military documents. The three were denied bail and remanded in custody until a formal hearing on February 27. The plot was reportedly revealed by a woman detained a few months ago, and the three men were said to have wanted to take on key positions in the military and judiciary.

site_title: Keto goes chic at Persea
summary: Persea, a keto-leaning restaurant in Singapore, offers a unique dining experience that combines healthy eating with a playful approach. The menu features Mediterranean-inspired dishes, such as Eggs Muhammara, Chicharonnes, and calamari, all made with high-fat ingredients to satisfy keto diets. While some dishes may be overly rich, the restaurant's cheerful and earnest staff make the experience enjoyable. With a focus on fresh ingredients and creative flavor combinations, Persea is a promising addition to the Singapore dining scene, offering a guilt-free and indulgent experience.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down after rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Thursday, shedding 1.58% after a seven-day rally, as traders worried valuations may have gone too far. The Hang Seng Index fell to 30,595.27, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.55%. The decline follows a surge in recent days, with investors taking profits and awaiting further guidance from the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Singapore, Indonesia say Asean can play important role in Myanmar
summary: Singapore and Indonesia's foreign ministers believe Asean can play a crucial role in encouraging dialogue and normalcy in Myanmar after a coup on February 1. They discussed possible next steps for the 10-member Asean to address the situation. The two countries aim to utilize Asean's influence to promote a peaceful resolution in the region.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific associate acquires 999-year leasehold residential site for S$33.6m
summary: Roxy-Pacific associate Mequity Hills has acquired a 999-year leasehold residential site at 10A and 10B Institution Hill for S$33.6 million. The site will be amalgamated with another 999-year leasehold site to create a total of 14,300 sq ft for residential development. Roxy-Pacific will finance the purchase with internal funds and bank borrowings. The location, near Orchard Road and other entertainment and retail outlets, is considered desirable, with recent transacted prices averaging between S$2,700 and S$3,000 psf.

site_title: New Tokyo 2020 head deeply regrets behaviour from seven years ago
summary: Seiko Hashimoto, newly appointed head of the Tokyo 2020 organising committee, has expressed deep regret for her past behavior, including a 2014 incident where she was accused of making unwanted advances towards a sportsman. Hashimoto, a seven-time Olympian, also faces controversy over her involvement in a 2014 sexual harassment scandal. She has vowed to "regain trust" in the committee, increase the number of women on the executive board, and prioritize anti-infection measures for the Games, set to take place in July.

site_title: SGX, Euroclear Bank to launch Orchid bond structure bridging Singapore issuers, global investors
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Euroclear Bank are launching the Orchid bond structure, a new platform combining domestic bond issuance with global distribution channels. International investors can purchase Singapore-based issuer bonds directly on The Central Depository, with real-time multi-currency delivery versus payment settlement. HSBC is the arranger, custodian bank, and paying agent. The partnership aims to tap into the Asian bond market, with plans to extend the offering to other regional issuers and explore ESG bond issuance in foreign currencies. This move aims to provide issuers with diversified funding sources and deeper liquidity pools.

site_title: Facebook 'unfriends' Australia: news pages go dark in test for global publishing
summary: Facebook blocked news feeds in Australia, including official health pages and emergency warnings, in a dispute with the government over a planned law requiring the tech giant to pay news outlets for content. The move, which also affected international outlets such as the New York Times and BBC, was widely condemned by media groups, politicians, and human rights organizations. Facebook cited the lack of clear definition of news content in the law as the reason for the ban, but critics argue it is an attempt by the company to protect its dominant position and hoard revenue.

site_title: Ex-minister Lim Hwee Hua launches book about government in business
summary: Former Singapore Cabinet minister Lim Hwee Hua has launched a book titled "Government In Business: Leading Or Lagging?" discussing government involvement in business, including the Singapore Sports Hub, MRT disruptions, and home-sharing via Airbnb. The book features 64 case studies, including Singapore, and explores regulatory challenges, public-private partnerships, and the importance of collaboration between sectors. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the government's goal of being a "proactive enabler" of innovation and growth, while acknowledging the need for balance between social and economic objectives.

site_title: White House revokes Trump order limiting climate change in federal reviews
summary: The Biden administration has revoked a Trump-era policy limiting climate change impacts in federal reviews of major projects, including pipelines and highways. The 2019 draft National Environmental Policy Act (Nepa) guidance had rolled back an Obama-era policy requiring agencies to evaluate climate change impacts. The move aims to put decisions on "firmer legal and scientific footing" and prioritize climate change impacts on disadvantaged communities. The White House Council for Environmental Quality will now focus on undoing Trump-era changes and strengthening the use of the law to protect the environment.

site_title: OCBC unit acquires remaining 51% of Horizon Asset Management
summary: OCBC's wholly-owned unit KIM acquired the remaining 51% stake in Malaysia-incorporated Horizon Asset Management for RM2.55 million (S$837,650) in cash. This makes Horizon a fully-owned unit of OCBC. The acquisition's net tangible asset value is approximately RM420,000, and it is not expected to impact OCBC's performance for the year ended December 2021.

site_title: Indonesia's recovery depends on effective vaccine roll-outs, fiscal stimulus: economists
summary: Indonesia's economic recovery is at risk due to high infection rates and potential lockdowns, according to a senior economist. The country aims to achieve herd immunity early next year and has started its vaccination program, which is expected to facilitate a strong recovery. Indonesia has taken proactive measures to secure vaccines and has implemented large stimulus packages to support households and businesses affected by the pandemic. The country has preserved its credibility through transparent policy coordination, and domestic consumption has gradually rebounded in the second half of last year.

images.alt_text: High infection rates and tightened social restrictions in Indonesia could weigh down the pace of rebound for Indonesia's economy, said AMRO's Dr Nguyen.

site_title: US import prices post biggest gain since 2012
summary: US import prices surged 1.4% in January, the largest gain since March 2012, driven by higher energy costs and a weak dollar. This marked the biggest year-over-year gain since October 2018. Economists had forecast a 1.0% increase. The rebound in import prices follows 11 consecutive monthly declines and is expected to support inflation expectations in the coming months.

site_title: Robinhood, Citadel fight conspiracies ahead of GameStop grilling
summary: Robinhood CEO Vlad Tenev and Citadel founder Ken Griffin plan to tell US lawmakers that conspiracies surrounding their firms' handling of GameStop trades are false. They will claim that hedge funds like Citadel did not order Robinhood to limit GameStop bets. Robinhood halted trades due to clearinghouse demands, and Citadel says it had no role in the decision. Lawmakers are expected to grill executives on the frenzied trading, with some calling for stronger guardrails for retail investors and others arguing rule changes are unnecessary.

site_title: STI falls 0.4% as regional rally runs out of steam
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.4% to 2,908.85, following a regional rally that ran out of steam, despite upbeat US retail sales data. Major Asian markets also declined, with some caution amid rising US bond yields and inflation concerns. Analysts say the rally may be short-lived, but risk assets are still expected to gain. Local bourse turnover was 3.11 billion units worth S$1.26 billion, with 18 counters down and eight up.

site_title: Hong Kong unemployment hits highest level since April 2004
summary: Hong Kong's unemployment rate surged to 7% in the November-to-January period, the highest level in over 16 years, amid the pandemic and social unrest. The underemployment rate also rose to 3.8%. Retail and tourism-related industries were severely impacted, with joblessness rates of 11.3% and 14.7% respectively. However, the government announced plans to reopen some venues and relax restaurant restrictions, potentially providing some relief to the labor market. Vaccinations are expected to start later this month, offering a glimmer of hope for economic recovery.

site_title: Hong Kong fast tracks China's Sinovac vaccine approval
summary: Hong Kong has approved the Chinese-made Sinovac coronavirus vaccine for emergency use, allowing the first batch of one million doses to arrive soon. The decision was made despite the vaccine's relatively low efficacy rate of 62.3% compared to other approved vaccines. The approval was fast-tracked by a panel of experts, who deemed the benefits of using the vaccine outweighed the risks. However, the city's public may be hesitant to take the vaccine due to deep-seated distrust of Chinese authorities. The first vaccinations are expected to begin as early as this Friday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 19.45 points to 1,575.84. The index saw a volume of 14.495 billion lots worth RM6.740 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 823 to 448.

site_title: Singapore Exchange hopes to list SPACs as early as this year
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is considering listing special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) as early as this year, provided it receives sufficient industry support. The concept of SPACs, which avoid the risk of an initial public offering, has gained popularity, and the SGX had initially consulted on SPAC listings in 2010 but was met with limited interest. With changing capital markets and lower interest rates, the SGX believes SPACs could facilitate investment and minimize market risk exposure, potentially reviving investor interest in Singapore's stock market.

site_title: Progressive Wage Model may be expanded to middle-wage workers: NTUC
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) is considering expanding the Progressive Wage Model (PWM) to middle-wage workers, including those in pest management, strata management, and solar technology.
