The current model focuses on lower-wage workers, with three new sectors expected to be implemented in the next 12 months. NTUC labour chief Ng Chee Meng believes the PWM can be applied to higher-wage workers, promoting fair pay and improving working conditions.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: European stock markets remained steady at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index opening flat at 6,709.72 points. The eurozone saw gains, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 index rising 0.2% to 13,938.14 points and the Paris CAC 40 edging up 0.1% to 5,770.25 points. Traders were monitoring pandemic-affected earnings updates and US-EU trade talks, which were expected to influence market sentiment.

site_title: Malaysia's Sime Darby Plantation eyes palm oil output recovery, high prices
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby Plantation, the world's largest palm oil planter, forecasts a recovery in crude palm oil output in Malaysia and Indonesia this year, driven by high prices. Production declined last year due to extreme weather and a labor shortage. The company expects prices to average RM3,100 a tonne for the first half and RM3,000 for the second half, despite potential production gains. Sime Darby reported a net profit of RM149 million for the October-December period, driven by higher prices and a stronger downstream segment.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's state-owned Temasek Holdings has opened bookings for the CONNECT@CHANGI travel bubble, set to start in March after a month's delay. The labour movement is considering expanding the Progressive Wage Model to middle-wage workers, while Cromwell E-Reit reported portfolio valuation growth. Keppel Reit launched a private placement to raise at least S$270m, and SGX is focusing on bolstering its multi-asset strategy through M&A deals. Meanwhile, Heeton warned of a FY2020 loss due to the Covid-19 pandemic, and the STI fell 0.4% due to a regional rally slowdown.

site_title: Privatisation bid for GL 'not fair but reasonable': IFA
summary: GL Limited's appointed independent financial adviser, W Capital Markets, deemed Guoco Group's offer to take the company private at S$0.70 as "not fair but reasonable". The offer, which represents a 1.4% discount, is based on a net loss of US$19.8 million for the six months ended Dec 31 last year. Shareholders can choose to sell their shares in the open market if they can obtain a higher price, and the offer price is above the mean and median weighted average of P/NAV of comparable companies.

site_title: Business 'bubble' travellers to arrive in Singapore from March, after month's delay
summary: Singapore's first "business travel bubble" facility, Connect@Changi, will welcome its first guests from early March, more than a month after its planned launch. The facility, developed by Temasek Holdings, will offer quarantine-free stays for short-term business travelers from regions without reciprocal travel arrangements. The move aims to catalyze economic recovery in Singapore and the region by hosting conferences and meetings in person, with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat noting the importance of resuming business travel and international meetings.

site_title: Uber ruling at top court may change its UK business forever
summary: The UK Supreme Court is set to rule on whether Uber drivers should be classified as workers, entitling them to minimum wage and holiday pay. This decision could have a significant impact on the gig economy and businesses that engage independent contractors. If Uber loses, it may lead to similar claims being pursued by other companies, potentially altering their contractual terms. Uber's shares have gained 50% in the last year, with the company leaning on its food-delivery service to compensate for declining ride-hailing app usage.

site_title: Indonesian banking regulator says Shopee acquires Bank BKE
summary: Indonesia's Financial Services Authority (OJK) announced that Shopee, the e-commerce arm of Sea Group, has acquired Bank Kesejahteraan Ekonomi (Bank BKE) with plans to transform it into a digital bank. Shopee is "currently preparing the infrastructure" to become a digital institution, but has yet to submit an official application. OJK expects the new digital bank to prepare 3 trillion rupiah in capital and is preparing regulations for new digital banks, which are expected to be released in mid-2021.

site_title: Hot stock: Thomson Medical surges 12.5%, surpassing 52-week high
summary: Thomson Medical Group's shares surged 12.5% to an intraday high of 9.9 Singapore cents, surpassing its 52-week high, amid active trading. The healthcare player gained 64.6% last week and 25.3% so far this week, driven by its return to profitability for the first half of FY2021. The company posted a net profit of S$8.1 million, reversing a net loss of S$1.9 million in the same period last year.

site_title: Barclays resumes dividend payouts as annual profit halves
summary: Barclays has resumed dividend payouts after a year-long hiatus, paying a full-year dividend of one pence per share and buying back £700 million worth of shares. The move comes as the bank's annual profit halves, but is driven by a strong performance from its investment bank. Regulators gave the green light for payouts in December, and the resumption is seen as a vote of confidence in the bank's balance sheet. Other British lenders are expected to follow suit when they report full-year earnings in the coming days.

site_title: Oil trader GP Global APAC seeks debt moratorium in Singapore
summary: GP Global APAC, a Singapore-based oil trader, has applied to the Singapore High Court for a six-month debt moratorium as its parent company seeks to restructure over $1 billion in debt. The company, which has missed loan payments, joins a string of Asian oil trading companies that have defaulted due to the pandemic-driven crash in oil prices. The restructuring strategy includes "standstill agreements" with creditors, allowing GP APAC to sell assets without creditor action. The company's unsecured liabilities are expected to be reduced to around $800 million, with creditors potentially recovering 20-30 cents on the dollar.

site_title: Cloudy outlook for stalled jet fuel demand recovery
summary: Global jet fuel demand is expected to remain sluggish due to lingering COVID-19 uncertainties and travel restrictions, with most traders and analysts predicting a recovery only in the second half of 2021. Jet fuel demand declined by 10% in OECD countries between 2019 and 2020, and is expected to remain below average global consumption levels. Analysts expect jet fuel consumption to pick up as vaccination roll-outs continue, but international flights are expected to take longer to recover, mainly due to the emergence of more contagious COVID-19 variants.

site_title: 11 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 11 new COVID-19 cases on Feb 18, all imported, with 10 asymptomatic and one symptomatic woman who arrived from Italy. The total cases rose to 59,832, with 59,664 patients recovered and 20 remaining in hospital. The number of unlinked community cases fell from six to one over the same period. A cluster linked to a police K-9 unit was closed after 28 days without new cases, and new measures were implemented for work permit and S Pass holders arriving from higher-risk countries.

site_title: Indonesia delivers rate cut as economic recovery stalls
summary: Indonesia's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate to a record low of 3.5% amid fears of a slowing economic recovery due to a resurgence in Covid-19 cases. The 25 basis point reduction was expected by 22 economists, downgrading the country's growth outlook to 4.3-5.3% for 2021. The move aims to stimulate the economy, as inflation remains weak at 1.55% in January, below the target of 2-4%. The decision was made to counter the impact of movement curbs and the country's first recession in over two decades.

site_title: Hot stock: Sri Trang up 27.2% after posting higher profit, dividend
summary: Sri Trang Agro-Industry (STA) shares rose 27.2% after the Thailand-based rubber producer posted higher profits and a significant dividend of 1.75 baht per share for its fourth fiscal quarter ended December 2020. The company reported a net profit of 5.5 billion baht, driven by healthy performances from its glove and natural rubber businesses. With a total dividend of 2.25 baht per share for 2020, investors can expect to receive their payouts on April 29.

site_title: Airbus sees stable aircraft deliveries after 2020 loss
summary: Airbus posted a pandemic-driven loss for 2020, but restored key business targets after generating cash in the fourth quarter. The company predicted flat 2021 deliveries and adjusted operating profit of €2 billion. Airbus reported a full-year operating loss of €510 million, weighed down by charges for coronavirus restructuring and program closures. Despite this, the company generated €4.9 billion in cash flow before M&A and customer financing in the fourth quarter, beating a quarterly break-even target. Airbus aims for stability in 2021 and expects free-cash-flow breakeven.

images.alt_text: European planemaker Airbus restored key business targets after generating cash in the fourth quarter, but withheld a dividend as it posted a pandemic-driven loss for 2020 amid the industry's "most challenging crisis".

site_title: Credit Suisse targets lending volume after better-than-expected Q4 loss
summary: Credit Suisse reported a 353 million Swiss franc (S$521.8 million) net loss for the fourth quarter, surpassing expectations of a 566 million franc loss. The bank attributed the loss to low interest rates and legal charges, including a 757 million franc charge. However, the bank plans to increase lending volume and capitalize on a boom in share listings to shore up revenue. This move comes after the bank settled a legacy mortgage-backed security case for US$80 million less than initially flagged, resulting in a 22% annual profit decline.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat as energy stocks weigh; Treasury Wine shines
summary: Australia's shares ended flat at 6,885.9 points, weighed down by energy stocks, particularly Woodside Petroleum, which fell 2.4% after its annual profit more than halved. Treasury Wine Estates, however, surged 17.5% after unveiling plans to reorganize into three divisions and sell underperforming brands. The benchmark closed 0.5% lower on Wednesday, with six of the nine major sectors on the bourse closing in the red.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as inflation fears play against recovery hopes
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday, driven by profit-taking and growing inflation concerns. Despite optimism about the global recovery, oil prices surged to 13-month highs due to a severe cold snap in the US, while vaccine rollout and easing lockdowns boosted confidence. However, inflation fears and higher borrowing costs sparked worries, with the US retail sales jump and wholesale inflation climb providing some relief. The Dow edged to a record high, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq dipped.

site_title: Air France-KLM expects bailout within weeks as cash burn mounts
summary: Air France-KLM expects a government bailout within weeks due to a significant cash burn from the resurgent Covid-19 pandemic. The carrier reported burning 2.1 billion euros in the final quarter of last year, leaving it with 9.8 billion euros in liquidity and credit lines. Chief Financial Officer Frederic Gagey stated that a rescue package is imminent, with talks ongoing between the airline's shareholders, governments, and the European Commission. A recapitalization plan is expected to be finalized in days or weeks, rather than months.

site_title: White House ramps up effort to tackle automotive chip shortage
summary: The White House has ramped up efforts to address the global semiconductor chip shortage affecting the US auto industry, with top officials meeting with companies and suppliers to identify chokepoints and urging cooperation. The administration has also reached out to Taiwan, a key chip producer, and is launching a review of critical supply chains to identify vulnerabilities and spur US domestic production. This comes as major automakers like General Motors and Ford warn of production cuts and potential losses due to the shortage.

images.alt_text: The effort includes outreach to Taiwan, home of key chip maker Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC), to find ways to resolve the shortage.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower in cautious trading
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.19% to 30,236.09 and the Topix index down 1% to 1,941.91. Investors remained cautious about over-valuation after recent rallies, despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell despite a 0.4% gain in Singapore's STI index, which was driven by positive investor sentiment despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Gold prices off 2-1/2-month low as US Treasury yields pull back
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to US$1,782.64 per ounce, rebounding from a 2-1/2-month low, as US Treasury yields retreated and inflation concerns increased. The US retail sales rebounded sharply, while producer prices rose by the most since 2009, suggesting inflation is creeping up. Federal Reserve officials remain committed to easy monetary policy to heal the economy. Despite this, gold is seen as a hedge against inflation and a break below US$1,760 remains a critical level.

site_title: Malaysia police question 'luxury dating' app founder in prostitution probe
summary: Malaysian police have questioned the founder of the dating app Sugarbook, suspected of exploiting university students who signed up as "sugarbabies" on the platform. The 34-year-old man was detained for questioning after receiving 74 complaints about the app's claims. Sugarbook, described as an "industry leader in luxury dating", has been accused of potentially forcing students into prostitution. The police are investigating the matter further, but no arrests have been made yet.

site_title: Venture firm that made US$30b on Chinese video app plans new fund
summary: 5Y Capital, the venture firm behind a $30 billion return on its investment in Chinese short-video app Kuaishou, is planning to raise at least $1 billion for a new fund. The firm, founded by Richard Liu and Ken Shi, has also invested in companies like Xiaomi and Agora. 5Y Capital will focus on new areas of growth, including cloud computing, AI, semiconductors, and bio-pharma companies, following a shift in its investment strategy.

site_title: More 'Brexit' companies shift to the Netherlands as uncertainty persists
summary: The Netherlands has seen a continued influx of businesses shifting their European operations due to Brexit uncertainty, with 78 companies relocating to the country in 2020. This brings the total to 218 since the 2016 Brexit referendum. Amsterdam is attracting companies in various sectors, including trading, finance, and logistics, and is poised to become Europe's number one corporate listing venue. The 2020 arrivals are expected to generate 6,000 jobs and 544 million euros in investments over the first three years, with a record 550 businesses currently in discussions with the Netherlands Foreign Investment Agency.

site_title: Australia's beleaguered Crown posts first half-year loss in decade
summary: Australia's Crown Resorts reported its first half-year loss in over a decade due to intermittent Covid-19 lockdowns. The company's new executive chair, Helen Coonan, has committed to "root and branch" change, following a report deemed the casino operator unsuitable for a licence and criticism of former CEO Ken Barton's governance. Several directors have resigned, including general counsel and company secretary Mary Manos. Crown posted a net loss of A$120.9 million for the six months ended Dec 31, and shares were 1% higher.

site_title: KKR Asia-Pacific managing director quits: sources
summary: KKR Asia-Pacific managing director Terence Lee has resigned after 10 years, according to sources. Lee led technology, media, and telecommunications investments in South-east Asia and stepped down from boards of companies including Voyager Innovations, PropertyGuru, and Gojek. A KKR representative declined to comment, while Lee could not be immediately reached. The departure marks the end of Lee's tenure at the firm, which he joined in 2010 after stints at CVC Capital Partners, Morgan Stanley, and Lehman Brothers.

site_title: Virus crisis upends hopes for aviation careers
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has severely impacted aviation careers, with many flight attendants and apprentices facing job uncertainty. In France, the number of apprentices in the aerospace and aviation industries has decreased by half, and some schools, like the CFA centre near Paris, have halted courses for flight attendants. Airlines are shedding jobs, with companies like Airbus and Air France planning to cut thousands of staff. The industry is expected to take years to recover, leaving students like Perrine Chaumet, who trained to become a flight attendant, uncertain about their future.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda tell Suga March review aimed at sustaining easy policy
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda told Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga the central bank will conduct a review of its policy tools in March to maintain ultra-loose monetary settings for a long period. The review aims to make policy more effective and sustainable. Kuroda also stated that the global economy appears to be picking up, based on IMF estimates. Japan's consumption is "picking up somewhat," with service spending remaining sluggish, and exports and output are recovering to pre-pandemic levels. The review follows the BOJ's December announcement to assess its policy tools in March.

site_title: Brokers' take: Lendlease Global Reit a top Orchard Road recovery play for DBS
summary: DBS Group Research maintains Lendlease Global Commercial Reit (Lendlease Global Reit) as its top pick for an Orchard Road recovery play due to its attractive risk-to-reward perspective. The research team favors Lendlease Global Reit over Starhill Global Reit and SPH Reit, citing a discounted valuation and higher-income visibility from master and anchor leases. DBS predicts a recovery in Orchard Road malls' shopper traffic and tenant sales, driven by various festivities in Q1 2021, and has a "buy" call for Lendlease Global Reit with a target price of S$0.90.

site_title: US manufacturer stuck with 30 million N95 masks
summary: A Florida manufacturer, DemeTech, is struggling to sell its 30 million N95 masks due to low wholesale prices from Chinese suppliers and a ban on online advertising by major platforms like Google and Facebook. The company blames this disconnect for its inability to find customers, despite receiving approval from the federal government nine months ago. The N95 mask shortage has eased, but demand remains high, and US manufacturers like DemeTech face challenges competing with cheaper foreign alternatives.

site_title: US mail delivery still facing 'unacceptable delays', group of senators says
summary: US mail deliveries continue to face "unacceptable delays" with nationwide on-time delivery rates at 64% for first-class mail and 45% for periodicals, according to 33 US senators. This issue has persisted months after first appearing and Postmaster General Louis DeJoy is being called upon to explain the lack of resolution. Delays in mail delivery, including paychecks, have been a concern since the summer when a record number of voters mailed in ballots to elect a new president.

site_title: Tesla cuts prices of base variants of Model 3, Model Y
summary: Tesla has reduced the prices of its base variants of the Model 3 sedan and Model Y SUV, lowering the Model 3 Standard Range Plus to $36,990 and the Model Y Standard Range to $39,990. The company has also raised prices for its performance variants, with the Model 3 Performance now priced at $55,990 and the Model Y Performance at $60,990. The price cuts come as Tesla aims to ramp up deliveries, exceeding Wall Street estimates of 481,261 vehicles in 2020 with 499,550 deliveries. The moves aim to make Tesla's models more affordable in the competitive electric vehicle market.

site_title: SGX seeks M&A deals to drive multi-asset strategy
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is seeking mergers and acquisitions (M&A) to drive its multi-asset strategy, aiming to bolster foreign exchange, fixed income, data, and capital markets connectivity businesses. CEO Loh Boon Chye stated that the bourse will focus on scaling up further, with potential acquisitions guided by the credit strength of its clearinghouse and funds it can raise. SGX has previously set a goal to double revenues from fixed income, currencies, and commodities by 2025, and may reach this goal before the initial target date.

site_title: Malaysian court orders wife of ex-PM Najib to enter defence in graft trial
summary: A Malaysian court ordered Rosmah Mansor, the wife of former Prime Minister Najib Razak, to enter a defense in a corruption trial linked to a multi-million dollar solar power project. The prosecution proved sufficient grounds for the case to proceed, with credible evidence against Rosmah on three charges of soliciting and receiving bribes totaling RM194 million. Rosmah has denied any wrongdoing, but faces charges of arranging for RM187 million as a political donation to Najib and receiving two bribes of RM6.5 million.

site_title: Return of Britain's fallen star fund manager sparks concern
summary: Former UK fund manager Neil Woodford, known as "Britain's Warren Buffett," is returning to the finance industry with a new firm, Woodford Capital Management Partners, 20 months after his previous company's collapse led to losses for pension funds and investors. The True and Fair Campaign is calling for an independent probe into the scandal, citing concerns about Woodford's ability to re-enter the financial world so soon. The Financial Conduct Authority has confirmed that his new business needs to apply for permissions before commencing any regulated activity.

images.alt_text: The return of Britain's former star investor Neil Woodford has caused concern in London's City finance district, where his spectacular fall from grace is still fresh in the memory.

site_title: Smartphones, consoles could get pricier as chip crisis bites
summary: A global microchip shortage, caused by a "perfect storm" of the coronavirus pandemic, supply chain disruptions, and trade war stockpiling, is expected to lead to price increases for popular gadgets such as smartphones, consoles, and cars. The shortage, affecting major chipmakers like Qualcomm and AMD, has resulted in limited sales of certain iPhone models and PlayStation 5 consoles. Experts warn that the crisis is a wake-up call for governments to strengthen domestic industries and reduce reliance on a few players, as semiconductors are at the heart of the global economy.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Thursday's open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% to 2,918.31, following a mixed US session. The index declined after Sembcorp Marine's share price dropped 2.5% due to material provisions in its Q4 results. DBS and UOB rose, while OCBC slipped. The decline comes as investors weighed better economic data against inflation concerns in the US.

site_title: Australia's employment rises again in January, jobless rate eases
summary: Australian employment rose by 29,100 in January, marking a fourth consecutive month of growth. The jobless rate dropped to 6.4%, beating market forecasts of 6.5% and down from a peak of 7.5% in July. This encouraging economic sign comes after authorities largely controlled the coronavirus pandemic. The data suggests a positive outlook for the economy.

site_title: AirAsia to enter food delivery business in Singapore
summary: AirAsia is expanding its food delivery service, AirAsia Food, to Singapore, marking its first overseas foray. The service, launched almost a year ago, will operate in the country. AirAsia CEO Tony Fernandes announced the venture on LinkedIn, stating it will "come to Singapore with a roar." No specific launch date was mentioned. This move comes as the food delivery service gears up for operations in major Malaysian cities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.18 points, or 0.14%, to 1,597.47, with volume reaching 1.56 billion lots worth RM604.98 million. Gainers outpaced losers 367 to 358.

site_title: Seven shophouses at Lavender Street up for sale with S$60m guide price
summary: Seven adjoining shophouses at 296-308 Lavender Street in Singapore are up for sale with a guide price of S$60 million, translating to S$1,526 per square foot. The freehold shophouses have triple road frontage and are zoned residential with commercial use on the first floor. The sale comes after the removal of tunnel reserves, allowing for increased development potential. The property is situated near prominent landmarks and upcoming developments, including Aperia Mall and the Kallang River lifestyle hub.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit reports portfolio valuation growth over 2020
summary: Cromwell European Reit reported a 2.2% fair-value increase in its portfolio valuation to 2.13 billion euros as of Dec 31, 2020, driven by a 57.8 million euro gain in the logistics sector. The portfolio's initial yield is 6.2% and reversionary yield is 6.5%. The valuation growth is attributed to diversification and asset management capabilities. Overall, the portfolio has grown by 169.5 million euros or 8.4% since its purchase prices.

site_title: Warburg Pincus aims to raise up to US$750m in IPOs for two blank-cheque firms
summary: Warburg Pincus, a private equity firm, is planning to raise up to $750 million for two blank-cheque firms, Warburg Pincus Capital Corporation I-A and I-B, through initial public offerings (IPOs). The firms aim to merge with businesses that have near-term potential for strong free cash flow. SPACs, or special purpose acquisition companies, typically go public at $10 a share and use the proceeds to buy a private firm, which then becomes publicly traded within two years. The IPOs are expected to raise $250 million and $500 million respectively.

site_title: ANZ flags record capital levels as profit rises on housing boom
summary: ANZ Banking Group reported a higher first-quarter profit, driven by reversing 10% of a $1.7 billion bad debt provision charge and strong home loan volumes in New Zealand. The bank's core tier-one capital ratio reached a record 11.7%, allowing it to consider returning capital to investors. ANZ's cash profit from continuing operations increased 54% from the previous quarter, with shares rising 3.37% on the news. The bank's recovery is attributed to the fast-recovering Antipodean economies and low interest rates.

site_title: Celebrities turn to podcasts to hang on to fans during pandemic
summary: Celebrities are turning to podcasts to maintain fan engagement during the pandemic. Notable examples include Demi Moore's erotic podcast "Dirty Diana," Jamie Lee Curtis and Matthew McConaughey's children's podcast, and Michelle Obama's personal issues-focused show. Other notable podcasts include "SmartLess" with Jason Bateman, Sean Hayes, and Will Arnett, and "The Michelle Obama Podcast." These podcasts offer a range of content, catering to diverse interests and demographics, as celebrities seek to stay connected with fans during the pandemic.

site_title: Baidu's stronger-than-expected outlook validates AI push
summary: Baidu reported a stronger-than-expected sales forecast, with revenue projected at 26-28.5 billion yuan for the period ending in March. The company's efforts to diversify into cloud and AI businesses are paying off, driven by a 52% increase in non-advertising businesses like AI cloud. This repositioning strategy comes as Baidu faces competition from up-and-coming rivals, including TikTok owner ByteDance, in China's online advertising market. The forecast validates Baidu's push into AI, as the company seeks to establish itself as a mature AI tech provider.

site_title: UN urges global Covid-19 vaccine plan, warns of dangerous inequity
summary: The UN is urging a global Covid-19 vaccine plan, citing a "deepening gap" in vaccine distribution, where 10 nations have administered 75% of doses, while 130 countries have had none. The UN Secretary-General and foreign ministers from major economies, including the US, UK, and China, are calling for a coordinated effort to vaccinate all countries, with the US pledging to make a "significant" contribution to Covax. The UN warns that vaccine inequity could lead to prolonged pandemics and new variants, threatening global health.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS keeps 'buy' on CSE Global, sees continued sequential improvement
summary: DBS Group Research maintains its "buy" call on CSE Global with a target price of S$0.55 after securing S$98.4 million in new orders for Q4 2020. This is down from S$230.1 million in Q4 2019 and S$431.5 million for FY2020. The new order figures align with DBS's forward assumptions for FY2020.

site_title: One-third of US military refusing Covid vaccine: Pentagon
summary: The US military has reported that about one-third of its personnel are declining to receive the Covid-19 vaccine, despite high infection rates. Pentagon officials stated that the vaccine is classified as optional due to lack of full FDA approval. However, vaccination rates are similar to those of the general population. Over 916,500 military personnel have received the vaccine so far, with over 1 million expected to receive shots by the end of the week. The Department of Defense emphasizes that personnel are making informed decisions about their health.

images.alt_text: Pentagon officials said on Wednesday that about one-third of the US military are declining to receive the Covid-19 vaccine, despite significant coronavirus infection levels in the forces.

site_title: Hackers target Myanmar government websites in coup protest
summary: Hackers in Myanmar targeted government websites, including the Central Bank and state-run broadcaster MRTV, in a cyber protest against the military coup that ousted Aung San Suu Kyi's government. The group, calling itself Myanmar Hackers, said they were fighting for justice, and cybersecurity experts believe the hacking was aimed at generating publicity. Internet connectivity dropped to 21% of normal levels, with the military shutting down the internet for a fourth consecutive night. The move is seen as a form of hacktivism, raising awareness about the coup and its impact on the country.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat on mixed corporate earnings, miners weigh
summary: Australian shares remained flat at 6,886.20, after shedding 0.5% on Wednesday. The gains in healthcare and banking sectors countered losses in miners and energy firms. Top iron ore miner Fortescue Metals Group fell 2.6% after hiking its cost estimate and delaying a key project. Healthcare firm CSL rose 5% on a rise in half-year profit. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index gained 0.9% to 12,785.68, driven by financials and utilities.

site_title: Biden renews 'Quad' with allies despite Beijing pressure
summary: The US has renewed the "Quad" alliance with Australia, India, and Japan, despite warnings from China. Secretary of State Antony Blinken will speak virtually with the foreign ministers of the three nations on Thursday, focusing on the Covid-19 pandemic and climate change. The alliance was launched in 2007 as a counterbalance to China's growing influence, and tensions have escalated since India and Australia joined in recent years. China has warned that renewing the Quad would trigger a "severe strategic confrontation" with Beijing.

site_title: Air pollution kills thousands in megacities despite Covid-19 lockdowns
summary: Air pollution in the world's five most populous cities, including Delhi, Mexico City, Sao Paulo, Shanghai, and Tokyo, caused approximately 160,000 deaths and $85 billion in economic losses in 2021, despite coronavirus lockdowns. The study, which measured pollution levels across 28 cities, found that air pollution is the single largest environmental risk to human health globally, killing an estimated 7 million people annually. Experts urge governments to invest in cleaner technologies and renewable energy to address the issue, which is linked to strokes, lung cancer, and heart disease.

site_title: Six killed in fire at gold mine in eastern China
summary: A fire at a gold mine in eastern China's Shandong province killed six people, with ten miners trapped. The incident occurred during maintenance at the Caojiawa gold mine, prompting the local government to launch a safety inspection campaign. This is the second major incident at a Shandong gold mine in less than a month, following an explosion at the Hushan mine that killed 11 workers. China's mines are among the world's deadliest, with 573 mine-related deaths recorded in 2020.

site_title: Heeton warns of FY2020 loss due to Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Heeton Holdings expects to report a net operating loss for FY2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, which led to decreases in rentals, room occupancies, and rates at its malls and hotels worldwide. The company intends to disclose further details on its performance when it announces its FY2020 unaudited financial results on or before Feb 24.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower as high yields, inflation concerns weigh
summary: Europe's shares fell 0.7% on Wednesday, weighed down by concerns over inflation and rising bond yields. The Stoxx 600 index retreated from near one-year highs, with Kering's lower sales contributing to losses. Investors are pricing in potential tapering of monetary policy, which could impact risk-driven assets. Bond yields in Germany reached a nearly year-high, and US yields recently scaled a similar milestone, as markets await cues from the Federal Reserve's recent meeting.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks surge at open on return after break
summary: Mainland Chinese shares surged on the first trading day after a week-long holiday, driven by hopes for economic recovery. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.81% to 3,721.09, while the Shenzhen Composite Index climbed 1.89%. The Hang Seng Index also gained 0.32% to 31,183.36. The gains were fueled by a global surge and traders' optimism despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Grab suspends commissions in Myanmar as junta cuts off Internet
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based tech firm, suspended collecting commissions from its drivers and restaurant partners in Myanmar due to the junta's internet cut-off. This move ensures 100% of user payments go directly to drivers and partners until the end of this month. The decision comes amid the ongoing internet blackout in Myanmar.

images.alt_text: Singapore-based tech firm Grab suspended collecting commissions from its drivers and restaurant partners in Myanmar on Tuesday, and will hold off on doing so until the end of this month, it said in a post on its Myanmar Facebook page.

site_title: Sygnum raises eight-figure investment from Japan's SBI Group
summary: Sygnum, a digital asset company with operations in Singapore and Switzerland, has secured an eight-figure US-dollar investment from SBI Digital Asset Holdings, the digital asset arm of Japan's SBI Group. The fundraising round brings Sygnum's total raised capital to around US$30 million in the past six months. The proceeds will be used to grow Sygnum's assets under administration, currently over US$500 million.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover to cut 2,000 jobs globally: company
summary: Jaguar Land Rover plans to cut 2,000 jobs globally as part of its "Reimagine" plan, aiming for a carbon-neutral supply chain and operations by 2039. The move, under new CEO Thierry Bollore, follows announcements of electric vehicle production targets, including Jaguar's transition to only electric vehicles by 2025 and Land Rover's first fully-electric vehicle in 2024. The company will invest £2.5 billion annually, with a full review of the organization already underway.

site_title: Keppel Reit launches private placement to raise at least S$270m
summary: Keppel Reit has launched a private placement to raise at least S$270 million, with a proposed issue price of between S$1.112 and S$1.146 per unit. The funds will be used to partially fund the S$651.5 million acquisition of Keppel Bay Tower from Keppel Land. The placement is expected to increase the Reit's trading liquidity and potentially enhance its weightage in indices, leading to stronger investor demand for the units. The deal is subject to the approval of Keppel Reit unitholders at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Jansen Mansion makes second en bloc attempt at lower reserve price
summary: The owners of 999-year leasehold condominium Jansen Mansion in Singapore are making a second attempt at a collective sale, this time at a lowered reserve price of S$19.8 million, down from S$22 million in 2018. The site, located in the Kovan area, offers a land rate of S$879 per square foot per plot ratio and is zoned for residential use. PropNex believes the land rate is "very attractive" and expects healthy interest from developers, with the successful tenderer able to build 21 new residential units on the plot.

site_title: Agri-food sector wants support for training and new technologies
summary: Singapore is allocating S$60 million for a new Agri-Food Cluster Transformation Fund to support local farmers in adopting technology and reducing operating costs. Industry players, including Barramundi Asia and Petalicious Farm, are calling for more financial support and an environment that brings down costs, enabling business sustainability. The fund aims to help farmers overcome climate change and compete with imports from countries like Malaysia. Experts emphasize the need for customized solutions, training, and a focus on efficiency rather than output volume to make local products more competitive in the export market.

site_title: Facebook to restrict Australia news sharing, defying regulators
summary: Facebook will restrict news content sharing in Australia, refusing to comply with a proposed law that would force digital companies to pay for news content. The move comes after Google brokered deals with major Australian media to pay for news, while Facebook argues that the law would "penalize" the company for content it didn't take or ask for. Facebook's decision contrasts with Google's response and has sparked a standoff with Australian officials, with the US tech giant threatening to partially withdraw services from the country if the rules become law.

site_title: Nearly 5,000 Hong Kong citizens sign up for new UK visa: The Times
summary: Nearly 5,000 Hong Kong citizens have signed up for UK visas since changes allowing BNO passport holders to live and work in the UK for five years and eventually apply for citizenship. The visa changes were made in response to Beijing's imposition of a national security law in Hong Kong last year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, SembMarine, OUE, Prime US Reit, CSE Global
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore stocks saw new developments Thursday, including a cybersecurity breach at Singtel, which leaked 129,000 customers' data. SembCorp Marine made material provisions due to an adverse impact on its performance. OUE expects to post a loss for FY2020, reversing its S$321.8 million profit in FY2019. Prime US Reit posted a higher distribution per unit, and CSE Global secured new orders. Trading was halted for Keppel Reit pending a private placement announcement. The STI rose 0.4% on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.15% and the Topix index gaining 0.02%. The gains followed the US Dow's third straight record high. This improvement in market sentiment comes despite tariff uncertainty and split views on the Fed's future actions.

site_title: Supermarket firm Ahold reports better-than-expected Q4 sales with online boost
summary: Ahold Delhaize, a major supermarket operator, reported better-than-expected Q4 sales with a 18% increase in sales to 19.6 billion euros, driven by a surge in online orders during the pandemic. Online sales jumped 84% to 2.6 billion euros, with growth expected to outpace traditional sales growth this year, projected at 30% in 2021. The company attributes the growth to investments in distribution networks and pick-up points for online orders.

site_title: Aussie media firms squeeze more from Google as new law looms
summary: Australia's two largest free-to-air TV broadcasters, Seven and Nine, have struck deals with Google worth A$60 million (S$62 million) annually, surpassing global rivals. This comes ahead of a government plan to pass laws allowing an arbitrator to set Google's content fees if a private deal cannot be reached. The deals were reportedly more lucrative than the US$76 million Google will pay French publishers over three years. The Australian deals were facilitated by the government's protracted licensing battle with Google, which threatened to shut down its search engine in Australia.

site_title: Airbus looks to A321 XLR to recover from pandemic
summary: Airbus is looking to its new A321 XLR aircraft to help drive its recovery from the pandemic, with deliveries set to begin in 2023. The XLR, which can fly the North Atlantic route, has garnered over 450 orders, including from major carriers like American Airlines and Qantas. The aircraft fills a gap in the market for single-aisle aircraft with a range of 4,700 nautical miles, and its lower operating costs make it an attractive option for airlines rebuilding their route networks. Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury sees the XLR as a key factor in the company's recovery, with Boeing facing a significant challenge in the same market.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp ends talks with Liberty Steel over steel unit sale
summary: Thyssenkrupp has ended talks with Liberty Steel Group over the sale of its steel unit, citing irreconcilable differences in corporate value and transaction structure. The German conglomerate will maintain its steel unit, focusing on addressing the consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic and making steel production sustainable. Thyssenkrupp had previously received an offer from Liberty Steel in October, but the talks have been halted. The decision comes as demand for steel has risen in recent months due to pent-up demand following last year's lockdowns, boosting Thyssenkrupp's earnings outlook for 2021.

site_title: GameStop fan 'Roaring Kitty' to tell US Congress: 'I like the stock'
summary: A GameStop fan known as 'Roaring Kitty' is set to testify before the US Congress, expressing his enthusiasm for the stock. The hearing aims to explore the events surrounding GameStop's short squeeze. The stock's surge has raised questions about market volatility and the role of retail investors. No specific details on Roaring Kitty's testimony or the hearing's conclusions are provided, but the event marks a significant development in the ongoing discussion about the GameStop phenomenon.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as markets weigh better data, inflation
summary: US stocks ended in a mixed session, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching a record high, while the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.6% due to inflation concerns. Retail sales surged 5.3% in January, but the producer price index spiked 1.3%, fueling worries about inflation. Despite this, Federal Reserve officials showed no concern about inflation pressures. The Dow finished 0.3% higher at 31,613.02, while the S&P 500 slipped less than 0.1% to 3,931.31.

site_title: Dollar hits 5-month high versus yen as US yields rise
summary: The US dollar reached a five-month high against the yen due to rising US bond yields, which boosted the dollar's value. The 10-year US yield rose to 1.333%, causing a sell-off in US Treasuries and a subsequent rise in the dollar's index against six major currencies. Bitcoin set a record high of $51,721, and traders continue to bet on its acceptance among major companies. Experts warn that the rise in US yields may lead to a correction in risk assets.

site_title: Rio Tinto ups dividend to record as profit beats forecasts
summary: Rio Tinto reported its best annual earnings since 2011, beating forecasts with underlying earnings of US$12.45 billion. The company declared a record final dividend of US$3.09 per share and a special dividend payout of 93 cents a share, following BHP's surprise return to investors. Strong commodity prices, driven by China's infrastructure spending, and an expected global economic rebound from Covid-19 vaccines are expected to benefit miners.

site_title: Christo's personal collection sells for 8m euros
summary: Christo's personal collection sold for 8 million euros at Sotheby's auction in Paris, exceeding initial estimates. The 28 lots, including preparatory drawings for the couple's "The Umbrellas" installations, were snapped up by buyers in the US, Asia, and Europe. The works, which included the yellow Californian umbrellas, set new records for Christo, with the drawings selling for 1.7 million euros and the Japanese version for 1.2 million euros. This sale comes just a year after Christo's death at 84, cementing his enduring demand.

site_title: Waymo brings robo-taxis to San Francisco in new test
summary: Waymo, the autonomous driving unit of Alphabet, is testing its driverless ride-hailing service in San Francisco, expanding on its existing tests in Phoenix, Arizona. The company will start with employee feedback before expanding to riders, with improved technology including a lidar vision system and highly sensitive cameras. Waymo aims to tackle San Francisco's diverse topography and detect potential hazards like jaywalkers. This move is part of the growing testing of autonomous driving by several firms, with no large-scale deployments yet.

site_title: Draghi sets out plan to rebuild virus-hit Italy
summary: Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi has pledged to use "all means" to combat the coronavirus pandemic, which has devastated the country, and to rebuild its economy. With over 94,000 Italians dead and the economy contracting almost nine percent last year, Draghi has promised to fight the pandemic and implement reforms to improve the country's growth potential. His new government, comprising a mix of politicians and technocrats, aims to tackle issues such as bureaucracy, tax code, and climate change, with a focus on education and female employment.

site_title: BlackRock to polluters: declare emissions data before shareholder meetings
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, has warned polluting companies to disclose their full scope of greenhouse gas emissions or risk confrontation with investors at shareholder meetings. This is part of its efforts to hold companies accountable for climate change, particularly Scope 3 emissions generated by products or services. BlackRock may vote against directors responsible for climate risk oversight and support shareholder proposals addressing climate risk gaps. The move comes after CEO Larry Fink made climate central to his annual letter to CEOs.

site_title: Transforming Singapore beyond the pandemic
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat's FY2021 Budget statement focuses on building a stronger Singapore beyond the pandemic. The government has allocated S$24 billion over the next three years to drive economic transformation, including investments in digital adoption, clean energy, and infrastructure. The aim is to create a more vibrant economy, with a focus on SMEs, innovation, and productivity. However, despite positive news on vaccine development, the path to recovery for Singapore's economy is still uncertain, and the writer expects the ROE of the Singapore market to remain lacklustre in 2022, impacting job creation and livelihoods.

site_title: Bitcoin scales US$51,000 for the first time amid cryptocurrency fever
summary: Bitcoin has reached a record high of $51,431, surpassing $51,000 for the first time, after a 6% surge. The largest cryptocurrency has seen a fivefold increase in value over the past year. MicroStrategy's plan to buy more Bitcoin with $600 million from convertible bonds has sparked concerns of speculative froth in financial markets. However, others believe institutional investors and companies will continue to drive demand, driving further gains. The crypto market's volatility remains high, with 60-day realised volatility near its peak.

site_title: Gucci stumbles as brand gears up for 100th year
summary: Gucci's sales fell 10.3% in the fourth quarter, missing analysts' expectations of a 4% drop, due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on travel and shopping. Despite this, Gucci's financial chief Jean-Marc Duplaix expressed confidence in the brand's ability to return to growth in 2021, marking its 100th anniversary. The company attributed the decline to a short-term view, citing a strong recovery trend in luxury markets, particularly in Asia and the US. Analysts expect Gucci management to implement changes to bolster the brand and capture an older demographic.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sen Yue Holdings' unit SMC Industrial received a letter of demand for over $196,700 from Indonesian copper supplier Garuda Surya Anugerah (GSA). SMC is discussing repayment proposals with GSA, which may take legal action if not resolved. Meanwhile, OUE expects to post a loss after tax for FY2020 due to a fair value loss from the sale of the US Bank Tower, reversing a $321.8 million profit in FY2019. FSL Trust sold two LR2 product tanker vessels for an undisclosed price.

site_title: Essential bank staff in Singapore to get Covid-19 jabs
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced that essential bank staff in the financial sector will be offered Covid-19 vaccines in several phases. Workers involved in "critical operations" have been invited to indicate their interest to be vaccinated. This move aims to protect critical workers in the financial sector from the virus.

site_title: Daimler's Torc Robotics picks Amazon as cloud provider for self-driving trucks
summary: Daimler's Torc Robotics has partnered with Amazon's cloud computing division, Amazon Web Services (AWS), to handle data for its self-driving trucks. The partnership aims to process massive amounts of data in real-time for Torc's level 4 autonomous technology. Tests on Torc's second-generation trucks will begin this quarter, with AWS providing tools to design tests and run simulations. The collaboration is part of Amazon's efforts to advance its role in self-driving technology, connected cars, and electric vehicles.

site_title: ESG investing requires true transparency and recognition that it's not a one-size-fits-all approach
summary: The investment industry is shifting towards ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) focused investments, recognizing its importance beyond traditional financial returns. This trend is driven by global concerns, including climate change, with the UK announcing plans to launch green gilts and require climate risk disclosures. As investors increasingly prioritize sustainability, companies must adapt and demonstrate transparency in their ESG practices. The article highlights the need for a tailored approach to ESG investing, rather than a one-size-fits-all solution.

site_title: Oil jumps US$1/barrel as Texas freeze prompts US output drop
summary: US oil prices surged over $1 a barrel on Wednesday due to a Texas freeze that shut production across the largest US crude-producing state. The freeze, which has halted an estimated 1 million barrels a day of production, is expected to disrupt output for several days or weeks. Oil prices reached their highest levels since January last year, with Brent crude settling at $64.34 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude settling at $61.14 a barrel. Industry experts expect prices to continue to rise, with some predicting a peak of around $65.65 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Oil prices gained more than US$1 a barrel on Wednesday, as frigid Texas temperatures shut production across the largest US crude producing state, with the unusually cold weather expected to hamper output for days or even weeks.

site_title: The pandemic emptied Europe's cities - what will bring people back?
summary: Europe's cities, emptied by the pandemic, are grappling with the challenge of attracting people back. Despite efforts to address housing affordability, transportation, and access to green spaces, many cities are seeing a permanent shift in population dynamics. Affluent individuals, particularly in the US, have been leaving cities for second homes or scattered across the country. European cities are introducing bike-friendly commuting options and expanded green spaces, but quantifying the exact number of people who left is difficult due to pandemic-related data complications. Experts see an opportunity to introduce new behaviors and policies to improve urban life.

site_title: The benefits of doing good
summary: Amgen Singapore Manufacturing and Grace at Work were recognized for their corporate social responsibility (CSR) efforts. A community outreach session was held, where staff volunteers partnered with the Science Centre Singapore to engage beneficiaries from the Children's Cancer Foundation. The initiative, Amgen Biotech Experience Befriender, aims to promote genetic engineering and drug production via bacteria cultivation, while fostering a sense of community and social responsibility among staff volunteers.

site_title: Traders chase sky-high returns from leveraged exchange traded products
summary: Traders are seeking high returns from leveraged exchange-traded products (ETPs), which amplify the moves of an underlying index or stock several times over. Despite accounting for only 1% of the US$5.9 trillion universe of US-listed ETPs, these funds have drawn significant interest, with inflows reported for five straight weeks. Funds such as Direxion Daily Semiconductor Bull 3X Shares and ProShares Ultra VIX Short Term Futures ETF have seen record inflows, with assets reaching $3.27 billion and $2.5 billion, respectively. However, analysts caution that these ETPs are designed for short-term trading and can result in significant losses if held long-term.

site_title: Twitter's clash with India government gives boost to local rival
summary: Twitter's clash with the Indian government has boosted a local rival, Koo app, an Indian alternative to Twitter. The Koo app, which allows users to send tweet-like posts in English and seven Indian languages, gained popularity after Twitter's weeks-long standoff with the Indian government over blocking certain content. This highlights the growing political challenges for social media services operating in India, where governments have been increasingly scrutinizing online content. Koo's surge in popularity is seen as a sign of the Indian market's growing demand for local alternatives to international social media platforms.

site_title: Good Class Bungalows still seen as a sure bet by the ultra-rich. Are there risks ahead?
summary: Singapore's Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market experienced a 35% increase in transaction value in 2020, reaching S$1.05 billion. Despite economic damage from Covid-19, market watchers expect positive momentum this year. GCBs remain a sought-after investment option for the ultra-rich, with only 2,500 available plots in Singapore. However, potential risks include government actions, such as rezoning, and a proposed wealth tax, which could impact prices. The tax, proposed by economists, could lead to the wealthy reducing investment in luxury property, potentially affecting GCB prices.

images.alt_text: Members of Singapore's old money live in GCBs and they have been joined by the new rich such as Haidilao's Zhang Yong.

site_title: Europe braces for pandemic reality to hit banks
summary: European banks are bracing for a potential pandemic-induced financial crisis as unpaid debt from pandemic-stricken borrowers continues to ravage profits. Despite bank executives' optimism about a rebound, officials fear that borrowers will default when government support, such as loan guarantees, is unwound. A report to eurozone finance ministers warned of "wide-scale corporate distress" and highlighted the reliance of banks on government assistance. The European Central Bank also expressed concerns about banks' provisions for bad loans, with some suspecting that some lenders are not taking sufficient measures to address the risk.

site_title: Inflation isn't lurking around the corner. This isn't the 1970s
summary: The US economy faces no imminent threat of inflation, contrary to warnings from some experts, including Olivier Blanchard and Lawrence Summers. The Biden administration's $1.9 trillion stimulus plan, aimed at combating the coronavirus, is unlikely to revive inflation due to anaemic inflation rates and the Fed's watchfulness. The plan's focus on specific needs, such as pandemic response and financial aid, rather than filling the output gap, is more effective. Experts, including Paul Krugman, argue that the plan is "disaster relief" and that the right amount of spending is necessary to get the pandemic under control, rather than raising inflation concerns.

site_title: HSBC to name new Singapore CEO as Tony Cripps moves to Saudi British Bank
summary: HSBC Singapore is set to announce a new CEO, replacing Tony Cripps who will join Saudi British Bank (SABB) as managing director-designate and board member from April 4. HSBC Deputy Chairman and CEO Peter Wong stated in an internal memo that Cripps' successor will be announced "shortly." Cripps, who led HSBC's Singapore business for four years, oversaw the bank's three-year country strategic plan.

site_title: Millennium spin-off fund bets on Indonesia, Singapore currencies
summary: A MACRO hedge fund has taken a bullish stance on the Indonesian rupiah and Singapore dollar, expecting the Indonesian currency to appreciate by 4% this year due to its drive to become a regional electric vehicle hub, and the Singapore dollar to strengthen by 8% as the country accelerates its vaccine rollout. This is based on investments in the country by major companies such as Tesla and Contemporary Amperex Technology. The fund also expects the Thai baht and Philippine peso to weaken.

site_title: He's asking you to support the arts in these times ...
summary: Philanthropist Pierre Lorinet is leading an initiative to encourage corporations and individuals to support the arts during the Covid-19 pandemic, a time when the industry is often overlooked in favor of more pressing issues. Lorinet believes the arts provide a creative respite from hardships and aims to change the perception that arts are a luxury. His mission seeks to raise awareness and solicit donations for arts-related causes, highlighting their importance in bringing people together and promoting well-being.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund makes US$3.3 billion bet on video-game makers
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has made a $3.3 billion investment in US video-game makers Activision Blizzard, Electronic Arts, and Take-Two Interactive Software. The fund, controlled by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, aims to diversify the Saudi economy from its reliance on oil. This move follows recent high-profile investments in Uber Technologies and Softbank Group's Vision Fund. The fund's total value has increased to $12.77 billion, with the video game investments contributing to the growth.

site_title: Aviation sector to get additional wage support - but vaccination is key
summary: The Singapore government has announced an additional wage support for the aviation sector until September, offering 20% of the first S$4,600 of gross monthly wages for Singaporean or permanent resident employees from April to June. This brings the total support to 50% inclusive of the Jobs Support Scheme payout. The move aims to help the hard-hit sector recover from the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: A targeted Budget needed to drive transformation and recovery
summary: Singapore's 2021 Budget focuses on targeted relief measures to drive transformation and recovery in the economy, which was hardest hit by the pandemic. The government has set aside S$11 billion for Covid-19 relief, and has extended the Jobs Support Scheme to help worst-hit sectors. Industry observers note that the budget's pragmatic approach could also help the city-state reach a more balanced fiscal position in the future. Key initiatives include the expansion of the Productivity Solutions Grant, the introduction of a green technology fund, and measures to support companies in the manufacturing sector.

site_title: McLaren's hybrid boasts blazing speed without guilt
summary: McLaren's hybrid model, the Artura, boasts supercar performance with hatchback-level emissions. Priced at £185,500, it can drive 30km on battery power alone and features a twin-turbo six-cylinder engine. The company expects the car to account for a third of its total sales and has invested £400 million in hybrid development. McLaren plans to introduce a fully electric car before the end of the decade, with the Artura accelerating from 0-97km/h in three seconds and reaching a top speed of 330km/h. Deliveries are scheduled to begin in June.

site_title: Time for Singapore to grab the tax rules by the horns?
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat has emphasized the potential impact of the OECD's Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) project on the country's tax fundamentals, citing the risk of losing corporate income tax revenue. The BEPS project aims to end tax avoidance strategies and impose a global minimum tax rate, which could affect multinational companies operating in Singapore. Heng has "doubled down" on the need for tax reforms, but the government has not yet reached a consensus on major local tax reforms.

images.alt_text: Recent reports of Google co-founder Sergey Brin setting up a family office in Singapore to help manage his wealth also pointed to the rush by super-rich families opening family offices here, including hedge fund boss Ray Dalio (above).

site_title: Ready to use the reserves if crisis worsens, to emerge stronger
summary: The Singapore government has proposed drawing up to S$11 billion from past reserves to fund the Covid-19 Resilience Package in the 2021 budget. This marks the first time the government intends to use reserves in consecutive financial years. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat cited the extraordinary nature of the crisis, but also hinted at a broader strategy to ensure the country emerges stronger. The government expects to balance its budget as the economy recovers, but may draw on reserves if the situation deteriorates. This move aims to signal confidence in Singapore's ability to deal with the crisis and boost recovery efforts.

site_title: Agricultural labour crunch in Asia to worsen unless public, private investments step up
summary: Agricultural labor shortages in Asia are expected to worsen unless public and private investments increase in the sector. Experts warn that the industry's "economically unattractive" characteristics and lack of qualifications for jobs will drive people out, particularly smallholders. Companies in the sector face difficulties in recruiting and retaining workers, with some attributing it to the industry's "dirty, dangerous and difficult" nature. To address the issue, forward-thinking companies are investing in technological-driven initiatives, while governments are advised to provide access to lands, credits, and skills development opportunities for young people.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat amid inflation worries
summary: US stocks retreated early Wednesday amid worries about potentially higher inflation and rising interest rates. The Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.1%, 0.3%, and 0.6% respectively. Analysts attribute the decline to higher Treasury bond yields and anticipation of new stimulus measures by President Joe Biden, which could lead to higher interest rates and slow down growth stocks.

site_title: Christie's jumps into burgeoning digital art market
summary: Christie's, a major auction house, is selling the first purely digital artwork by American digital artist Beeple, titled "Everydays - The First 5,000 Days." The artwork, comprising 13 years of Beeple's daily creations, will be sold online with a starting bid of $100. The piece features a Non-Fungible Token (NFT), a unique digital token verifying ownership and authenticity. This auction marks a significant expansion of the digital art market, which is gaining traction with the use of computer-generated imagery and NFTs.

site_title: S Pass tightening: job take-up by locals to differ between industries
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 aims to reduce the reliance on foreign workers in manufacturing by lowering the maximum share of S Pass holders from 20% to 15% by 2023. This move is expected to benefit mid-skilled locals, particularly in manufacturing, where they can be re-trained and redeployed to higher-value roles. However, the impact on other sectors, such as construction and services, may be limited, and wages may not necessarily increase for locals in these industries. The government hopes to incentivize companies to hire more locals through digitization and automation, reducing operating costs.

images.alt_text: The latest Budget reduces the maximum share of S Pass holders that manufacturers can employ from 20 per cent now, to 15 per cent by 2023.

site_title: Ancient Rome has an urgent warning for us
summary: The Antonine Plague, a pandemic that ravaged ancient Rome in the 2nd century AD, serves as a reminder of the power of nature and its impact on human societies. The plague, which killed an estimated 2-10 million people, was likely caused by an ancestor of the smallpox virus and spread along trade routes connecting Rome to East Africa, the Near East, and China. The plague was a symptom of Rome's success, highlighting the empire's ecological fragility. The experience offers a cautionary tale about the interconnectedness of human and animal health, and the importance of recognizing the limits of human power in the face of nature.

site_title: China's retail, catering sales jump in Lunar New Year staycation
summary: China's retail and catering sectors experienced a significant surge in sales during the Lunar New Year holiday, with revenues rising 28.7% from 2020 levels and 4.9% from 2019 levels. Sales reached $127 billion, driven by staycationing consumers and a shift towards contactless and safe consumption. The jewellery sector saw the largest increase, with sales up 160.8%, while digital home appliance sales and fitness equipment also saw significant growth. This trend is attributed to the government's efforts to curb travel and prevent potential infections during the pandemic.

site_title: Amazon deployed secret strategy to dodge India's regulators, documents show
summary: Amazon secretly favored a small group of sellers in India, giving them preferential treatment and discounted fees to bypass regulatory restrictions. Documents show the company helped around 33 sellers account for a third of its sales value and 35 sellers for two-thirds of its revenue in 2019. Amazon claimed it complied with the law and treats all sellers fairly, but the strategy could deepen risks for the company in a key growth market.

site_title: OUE expects FY2020 loss partly due to sale of US Bank Tower
summary: OUE Limited expects to post a loss after tax for FY2020 due to a fair-value loss from the sale of the US Bank Tower, resulting in a net loss of S$435.4 million. The loss is partly attributed to impairment losses on property, plant and equipment, and intangible assets, as well as the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak. OUE's FY2019 profit was S$321.8 million. The company will release its FY2020 results on February 24.

site_title: Green vehicle perks: restrict them to public transport players
summary: Singapore is planning to deploy 60,000 electric vehicle charging points by 2030, with the goal of having 8 in 10 households within a 10-minute walk from an MRT station. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a budget of S$30 million for EV-related initiatives, including measures to improve charging provision at private premises. The government aims to revise road tax treatment for electric cars to make them comparable to internal combustion engine equivalents. Subsidies will be directed to public transport operators, such as ComfortDelGro Corp, which already has a significant number of electric and hybrid vehicles in its fleet.

site_title: Countries should maximise cooperation on climate action
summary: Countries must maximize cooperation on climate action to minimize friction and points of collision. Despite the pandemic and economic downturn, many governments and companies are moving ahead with green recovery efforts, including the European Union's 750 billion euro budget boost and Asia's commitment to net-zero targets. However, tensions are emerging over issues like palm oil and carbon pricing, which could impact EU-Asean trade. Opportunities for dialogue and practical collaboration on green growth exist, particularly in bilateral trade agreements between the EU and Asean members, and through Singapore's role as a sustainable finance hub and climate action coordinator.

site_title: US manufacturing output rose by more than forecast in January
summary: US manufacturing output rose 1% in January, exceeding forecasts, for a fourth consecutive monthly gain. The increase was driven by broad-based gains in consumer goods, business equipment, and construction materials, despite a decline in auto production due to semiconductor shortages. The Federal Reserve's index of factory output is 1.9% below its pre-pandemic level, indicating a steady recovery. Despite ongoing supply chain challenges and labor shortages, the pandemic-related disruptions are expected to dissipate as vaccinations pick up.

site_title: Prince Philip taken to hospital as a 'precaution'
summary: Prince Philip, 99, was admitted to a London hospital as a precautionary measure due to feeling unwell. He was taken to the private King Edward VII Hospital and is expected to remain there for a few days of observation and rest. The hospitalization comes ahead of his 100th birthday in June, renewing concerns about his health. Prince Philip does not have Covid, and the Queen, 94, has been maintaining social distancing rules at Windsor Castle due to their age.

site_title: US business inventories rise solidly in December
summary: US business inventories rose 0.6% in December, exceeding initial estimates, and contributed to a 4.0% annualized GDP growth rate in the fourth quarter. Retail inventories, excluding autos, gained 1.2%, while motor vehicle inventories rose 1.1%. This follows a 0.7% increase in November. The increase in inventories has helped underpin manufacturing, offsetting slowing consumer spending. This marks the second consecutive quarter that inventories contributed to GDP growth.

site_title: Business group touts 'single market' plan for South-east Asian e-commerce industry
summary: A US-Asean Business Council report proposes an "Asean single e-commerce market" to boost revenue and financial inclusion for small businesses. The plan includes simplified customs procedures, a regional locker network, and a pilot for land-based cross-border trucking. The report also suggests an Asean-wide e-commerce association and public-private dialogue to enhance recognition and capacity-building for the e-commerce workforce. The initiative aims to promote regional integration and facilitate cross-border e-commerce, with the goal of giving small businesses access to new markets and lowering entry barriers.

site_title: Shopify beats estimates, sees revenue growth slowing in 2021
summary: Shopify reported a strong fourth quarter, beating analyst forecasts with US$41.1 billion in gross merchandise value, a 99% increase from the same quarter last year. Full-year gross merchandise value reached US$119.6 billion. The company expects revenue growth to slow in 2021 as economies improve and consumer spending shifts back to offline retail. Adjusted earnings per share beat analyst estimates, and revenue reached US$977.7 billion, surpassing expectations. A "more normalised pace of growth" is expected in 2021.

site_title: Nadal is out of the Australian Open
summary: Rafael Nadal's Australian Open bid ended with a loss to Stefanos Tsitsipas in the quarterfinals. Nadal, the second-ranked player, dominated the first three sets but missed crucial opportunities in the third-set tiebreaker, ultimately losing 3-6, 2-6, 7-6 (4), 6-4, 7-5. This marks Nadal's first Grand Slam quarterfinal exit since 2019. Tsitsipas secured his biggest Grand Slam win, advancing to the semifinals.

site_title: Boeing 737 MAX back in European skies
summary: The Boeing 737 MAX made its first commercial flight in Europe on February 17, 2021, after being grounded for 22 months following two deadly crashes. The flight, operated by TUI fly, took off from Brussels to Alicante and then Malaga in Spain. The aircraft was cleared to resume operations by European air safety regulator EASA in January, following US regulator clearance two months earlier. The 737 MAX was grounded in March 2019 after 346 deaths in two crashes, with a faulty flight handling system being identified as a main cause.

site_title: Bharti Airtel to buy 20% stake in its DTH arm from Warburg Pincus
summary: Bharti Airtel agreed to buy 20% stake in its DTH arm from US private equity firm Warburg Pincus for 31.26 billion rupees (S$570.9 million). The transaction involves issuing 36.5 million shares at 600 rupees per share and up to 10.38 billion rupees in cash. The move aims to simplify Bharti Airtel's shareholding in its customer-facing businesses, with the DTH service being an integral part of its Homes strategy.

site_title: 5 things to know about BEPS 2.0
summary: The OECD has introduced BEPS 2.0, a global reform aimed at preventing multinational corporations from avoiding taxes. Key points include enhanced cross-border tax cooperation, country-by-country reporting, and a minimum effective tax rate. Singapore has committed to implementing this reform. The digital economy has also highlighted the need for international cooperation, with the OECD focusing on tax avoidance and the Asian garment industry preparing for potential US tariff increases. The reform is expected to increase transparency and fairness in taxation. Implementation is expected to begin in the coming years.

site_title: WTO chief calls on nations to end Covid export restrictions
summary: World Trade Organization Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala has urged European Union and other WTO members to end export restrictions on COVID-19 vaccines and medical goods, citing the need for a freer flow of goods to countries in need. The EU's recent prior authorization requirements for vaccine exports sparked international condemnation and warnings of protectionism. Okonjo-Iweala believes that ending restrictions would be in the self-interest of each member, allowing for more efficient access to vaccines and reducing the risk of variants requiring new vaccinations.

site_title: Axington given more time to release FY2020 results and hold AGM
summary: Axington Inc, a Catalist-listed firm, has been granted a one-month extension to issue its FY2020 results by March 31, and a 2.5-month extension to July 22 to hold its FY2020 annual general meeting. The extensions follow a series of events, including a change of management and the resignation of board members, amid controversy surrounding Bellagraph Nova Group. Axington also has until June 30 to file its sustainability report. The extensions are based on the series of events following the Bellagraph Nova saga.

site_title: Thailand losing US$8.3b as vaccine delayed, lawmaker says
summary: Thailand's slow vaccine rollout is estimated to cost the country around $8.3 billion per month, according to opposition lawmaker Wiroj Lakkhanaadisorn. The delay is attributed to the government's decision to wait for AstraZeneca shots, which won't be ready until late May. This has resulted in a slower economic recovery and may impact the nation's readiness to reopen its borders and tourism industry, which accounts for one-fifth of the pre-pandemic economy.

site_title: UK's vaccine roll-out set to reach half the population by March
summary: The UK's COVID-19 vaccination program is on track to reach half the population by March, with 32 million people receiving their first dose, surpassing the government's May target. The vaccination effort, led by the Vaccine Task Force, has been successful, with the UK achieving one of the best vaccination rates globally. The government is now considering vaccination passports to boost the economy, which has been devastated by the pandemic. The UK's vaccination program has been praised by the World Health Organization and other countries, with scientists attributing its success to collaboration with the WHO and the US, as well as swift order placement and logistics.

site_title: US producer prices post biggest gain since 2009
summary: US producer prices surged 1.3% in January, the largest gain since 2009, indicating inflation at the factory gate is rising. This follows a 0.3% rise in December and a 1.7% acceleration in the 12 months through January. The increase suggests inflation is starting to creep up, potentially impacting consumer prices.

site_title: NODX growth triggers optimism for 2021
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 12.8% year-on-year in January, exceeding economists' expectations of 5.2%. This growth, partly due to low base from a year ago, suggests an optimistic external environment for the country's economy. Electronics exports rose 13.5%, driven by shipments of integrated circuits, while non-electronic exports, including non-monetary gold and petrochemicals, also showed strong growth. Economists predict a resilient manufacturing sector in 2021, with growth forecasts ranging from 1% to 4%.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine to make provision in light of 'adverse' impact on Q4 results
summary: SembCorp Marine announced it will make material provisions in its Q4 results due to an "adverse impact" on its performance. The company previously expected losses to continue into Q4 and has reviewed its assets and assumptions. The full-year results will be released on Feb 23. Shares closed at S$0.159, down 1.24% before the announcement, following the news.

site_title: Data of 129,000 Singtel customers, 23 enterprises leaked in cybersecurity breach
