summary: A cybersecurity breach has exposed the personally identifiable information of 129,000 Singtel customers, including their NRIC numbers, and data of 23 enterprises through a third-party file-sharing system. Singtel is providing free identity monitoring services to affected customers through a global data firm. The breach was previously disclosed on Feb 11, and Singtel is now reaching out to affected individuals and corporate customers to support them in managing the risks involved.

site_title: Prime US Reit posts H2 DPU of 3.42 US cents
summary: Prime US Reit posted a second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.42 US cents, an 8.4% increase from the same period in 2019. The office-focused REIT recorded $72.4 million in gross revenue and $47.5 million in net property income for the quarter, driven by contributions from its Park Tower acquisition and leasing momentum. The company's FY2020 DPU was 6.94 US cents, 3.6% higher than its initial IPO forecast.

site_title: Myanmar protesters stage biggest rallies since troop deployments
summary: Myanmar protesters staged the largest rallies since troop deployments against the military junta, which seized power at the start of February, charging Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi under an import law. Tens of thousands gathered in Yangon, blocking roads and preventing security forces from moving around the city. This marks the biggest demonstrations since the military's actions, with much of the country in open revolt.

site_title: FSL Trust to sell two vessels
summary: First Ship Lease Trust (FSL Trust) has agreed to sell two LR2 product tanker new-building vessels, the FSL Suez and FSL Fos, to an unaffiliated third party following their deliveries from COSCO Shipping Heavy Industry. The sale price will be announced later, with FSL Trust initially receiving a 15% deposit in escrow. The trust has waived acquisition and divestment fees to finance the vessel deliveries.

site_title: US retail sales surged 5.3% in January
summary: US retail sales surged 5.3% in January, the largest increase in seven months, driven by fresh stimulus checks and easing of COVID-19 restrictions. This beats economists' expectations and suggests a rebound in household demand. Nonstore retailers, food services, and furniture stores saw double-digit gains, with gas station receipts rising 4%. The data could embolden Republican opposition to President Biden's stimulus plan, but Democrats are on track to pass the package without Republican votes. The jump in sales could highlight the critical role of relief payments in the economy and jobs.

site_title: Firms need calibrated support to change structurally: panel
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 aims to alleviate the impact of the pandemic on the country's worst-hit sectors through targeted schemes. However, panellists at The Business Times' Budget Roundtable emphasized the need for more calibrated support to help companies change structurally and engage in R&D opportunities. The Re-Align Framework, set to end on Feb 26, may need to be extended to assist companies in renegotiating contracts. A more effective R&D credit scheme and increased engagement in infrastructure projects were also suggested to support local businesses.

images.alt_text: The Re-Align Framework, which gives small enterprises a chance to renegotiate business contracts that they have difficulties fulfilling, will end on Feb 26.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoon Jimmy Lai arrested again while in jail
summary: Hong Kong tycoon Jimmy Lai was arrested again while in jail on suspicion of assisting one of 12 fugitives captured by China at sea last year. Lai is awaiting a Thursday bail hearing, charged with colluding with foreign forces under Hong Kong's national security law imposed by Beijing.

site_title: Honda to appoint R&D chief Mibe as new CEO: sources
summary: Honda Motor will appoint Toshihiro Mibe, head of its research and development arm, as the new CEO, replacing Takahiro Hachigo. Mibe, 59, will be confirmed as president and representative director at an annual shareholders' meeting in June. Mibe joined Honda in 1987 and previously led structural reform at the research unit, with electrification in mind. He will support Seiji Kuraishi, who will remain executive vice-president and chief operating officer. Honda announced the decision after a board meeting as early as Friday, contradicting the company's earlier statement that no change was planned.

site_title: Grab suspends commissions in Myanmar, rolls out perk for bikers
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based tech firm, has suspended collecting commissions from drivers and restaurant partners in Myanmar until the end of the month. This change means 100% of user payments will go to drivers and partners, and an additional 50% will be added to earnings for GrabFood bikers. The move aims to support Myanmar's communities amid disruptions and uncertainty. Grab remains committed to providing safe and reliable services, creating income opportunities for its partners.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore government has announced additional wage support for the aviation sector until September, increasing the total support to 50%. Singapore's January export growth has boosted optimism for 2021, while the first shipment of Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine arrived in Singapore earlier than expected. A serviced apartment building in Novena is up for sale at S$93m, and Grab has suspended commissions in Myanmar and introduced a perk for its bikers. The Straits Times Index fell 0.5% due to profit taking, closing at 2,920.43.

images.alt_text: The aviation sector that has been hard-hit by the pandemic will get additional wage support from the government, making it a total of 50 per cent till September.

site_title: Bitcoin scales US$51,000 for the first time amid crypto fever
summary: Bitcoin surpassed US$51,000 for the first time, rising 6% in a fivefold surge over the past year. The Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index reached a record, with MicroStrategy's plan to buy more Bitcoin sparking debate over the market's speculative nature. Institutional investors and companies are seen driving demand, but analysts warn of a potential bust akin to the 2017 implosion. Bitcoin's volatility remains high, with a 60-day realised volatility around its peak levels.

site_title: Singapore's January export growth triggers optimism for 2021
summary: Singapore's January export growth exceeded expectations, with non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rising 12.8% year-on-year. This growth, driven by electronics exports, has left economists optimistic about the year ahead. Electronics exports grew 13.5% in January, with non-monetary gold, specialized machinery, and petrochemicals also showing strong growth. Economists predict a resilient manufacturing sector in 2021, with some expecting 1-3% growth, driven by global economic recovery and 5G infrastructure developments.

site_title: Europe car sales plunge 26% in worst January total on record
summary: Europe car sales plummeted 26% in January, the worst total on record, due to coronavirus lockdowns. New-vehicle registrations fell to 842,835, with Spain experiencing a 52% decline and Germany a 33% drop. Automakers face production outages and semiconductor shortages, but are boosted by resurgent demand from China. Analysts expect further declines in the first half of the year due to stringent credit standards and economic uncertainty.

site_title: CSE Global's Q4 new orders more than halved to S$98.4m
summary: CSE Global reported a significant decline in Q4 new orders, dropping to S$98.4 million, down from S$230.1 million in the same period last year. The company's total FY2020 new orders fell to S$431.5 million, a decrease from S$578.8 million in FY2019. The oil-and-gas segment saw a decline, while the infrastructure segment experienced a 4.6% year-on-year growth. CSE's group managing director attributed the decline to market uncertainties, including the Covid-19 pandemic, low oil prices, and a weak global economy.

site_title: Epic Games takes Apple fight to EU antitrust regulators
summary: Epic Games, the creator of Fortnite, has taken its dispute with Apple to European Union antitrust regulators, alleging the iPhone maker's control over the App Store payment system and app downloads creates an unfair level playing field. Epic launched its own in-app payment system, prompting Apple to remove Fortnite from the App Store and threaten to block distribution of Unreal Engine, a software tool used by hundreds of app makers. The EU Commission has confirmed receipt of the complaint and will assess it based on standard procedures.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 0.58% to 30,292.19, and the Topix index slipping 0.18% to 1,961.49. The decline followed recent rallies, with investors taking profit.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Wednesday, down 10.85 points to 1,595.29. The index saw 10.144 billion lots traded worth RM5.228 billion, with 622 losers outweighing 548 gainers.

site_title: STI falls 0.5% alongside key regional bourses on profit taking
summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Wednesday, retreating 14.91 points or 0.51% to 2,920.43, after two consecutive gains. Key analysts deemed Budget 2021 as relatively non-event, unlike last year's bonanza. US Treasury yields spiked, leading to profit-taking, while markets in Japan, South Korea, and Australia corrected. Only HRnetGroup Ltd outperformed the STI, gaining 1.75%. Singapore Airlines slipped 0.23% due to wage support scheme expiration in September.

site_title: Malaysia's regulator, stock exchange announce temporary reliefs for listed firms
summary: Malaysia's Securities Commission and Bursa Malaysia announced temporary relief measures for listed companies, allowing a one-month extension for issuing quarterly financial statements and annual reports. Firms with unsatisfactory financial conditions will be granted more time to reassess their financial situation before making announcements. This move aims to provide relief to listed companies during challenging market conditions.

site_title: Aviation sector gets additional wage support
summary: The Singapore government has announced additional wage support for the aviation sector, providing 50% wage subsidies from April to September. The Aviation Workforce Retention Grant offers 20% of the first S$4,600 of gross monthly wages paid to each Singaporean or permanent resident employee from April to June, and 40% from July to September. This is in addition to the 30% support under the Jobs Support Scheme. Existing rebates on fees and charges at Changi and Seletar Airport will also be extended for another year.

site_title: 11 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore; 10 imported, one in the community
summary: Singapore reported 11 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 59,821. The cases include one community case and 10 imported cases, with all being placed on stay-home notices. One imported case had a past infection serology test result, but her arrival timing makes it unclear if she was no longer infectious. The country has also closed one active Covid-19 cluster and implemented mandatory on-arrival tests for certain workers.

site_title: Indonesians show negative attitudes towards online lending: study
summary: Indonesians have negative attitudes towards online lending, with 60% exhibiting a negative view and only 7% having a positive attitude. A study of 520 respondents found that 81% have low intentions to use online lending, while 5% have high intentions. The majority of online lenders' practices cited by respondents include humiliating and threatening borrowers, collection before maturity, and harassing contacts. Experts warn of risks associated with unlicensed online lending sites, which can misuse customers' data and infringe on their privacy.

site_title: India and China aviation appear on track to turn around, says report
summary: India's domestic flights have reached 80% of pre-pandemic levels, with low-cost carrier IndiGo accounting for over half of the daily services. In contrast, Indian carriers' international arrivals are below half the normal level. China's aviation sector appears on track to recover as well, with storage rates of planes in the market indicating a rebound. However, the Indian aviation sector still faces significant challenges due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: First shipment of Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine arrives in Singapore earlier than expected
summary: The first shipment of Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine arrived in Singapore ahead of schedule on February 17, following a flight from Brussels to Changi Airport. The vaccine, which has a 94% efficacy rate, is the second approved for use in Singapore after Pfizer-BioNTech's vaccine. The Ministry of Health had initially expected the shipment in March, but the early arrival is a step forward in Singapore's efforts to control the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Cathay Pacific traffic numbers plunged to new lows in January
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways reported a 99% slump in passenger traffic in January, with an average of 981 passengers per day and a record-low load factor of 13.3%. Revenue passenger kilometres fell 98.7% from the previous year. The airline attributes the decline to ongoing COVID-19 challenges and new lockdowns in key markets. Despite a brief surge in cargo demand ahead of the Chinese New Year holiday, Cathay expects the coming months to be "extremely challenging" due to new quarantine measures for flight crew.

site_title: Seoul: Shares snap three-session winning streak as virus cases jump
summary: South Korean shares ended down 0.93% at 3,133.73, snapping a three-session winning streak, amid concerns over rising coronavirus cases and inflation. The won weakened to a one-week low, while US Treasury yields hit one-year highs, pressuring stock valuations. Foreigners were net sellers of 509.3 billion won worth of shares, and South Korea's prime minister warned against loosening social-distancing rules amid a surge in new infections.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets fall at open
summary: European stock markets fell at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.4% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index down 0.7%. The decline followed losses in Asia and was attributed to traders looking past UK inflation data, which showed a slight increase in January. The eurozone markets also declined, with Paris' CAC 40 index down 0.5%.

site_title: BHG department stores in 'reinvention' mode, exploring new revenue streams
summary: BHG Singapore, a department store operator, is undergoing a "reinvention" to adapt to changing consumer habits and preferences. The company plans to introduce new concepts, workshops, and personalized events at its flagship Bugis store, as well as expand its presence in Singapore when the opportunity arises. BHG aims to create new revenue streams through experiential retail, digital payments, and high-tech counters. The company's CFO, Jheeva Subramanian, emphasized the need for agility and evolution in its business model to stay relevant in the competitive retail market.

site_title: Signature Aviation to sell engine repairs business for US$230m
summary: Signature Aviation agrees to sell its engine repairs business to US-based StandardAero for $230 million, aiming to streamline operations and focus on cash-generating areas. The sale is part of the company's efforts to cut debt, with net proceeds of $140 million to be used for debt reduction. The deal is expected to be completed this year.

site_title: Taiwan says BioNTech vaccine deal on hold, cites potential Chinese pressure
summary: Taiwan's health minister has put a deal to buy five million doses of the BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine on hold due to potential Chinese pressure. The deal was supposed to be announced in December but was pulled by BioNTech. Chen Shih-chung implied that China's influence may have led to the delay, citing concerns about "outside forces intervening". The decision comes amid tensions between Taiwan and China over the pandemic, with China claiming Taiwan as its own territory.

site_title: Europe pulls ahead in race for hydrogen, as global project pipeline grows: report
summary: The European Union is leading the global push for hydrogen production, with most planned projects and investments expected to be in Europe this decade. The EU aims to eliminate greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 and plans to install 40GW of electrolysers to produce emissions-free hydrogen. Europe accounts for 55% of the 228 global hydrogen projects, with investments expected to exceed $300 billion this decade. The Hydrogen Council attributes Europe's lead to early investments in supply chains, climate change policies, and a stable policy commitment environment, with hydrogen investments expected to increase six-fold by 2025.

site_title: Pair of freehold shophouses along East Coast Road up for sale at S$7.8m
summary: A pair of freehold shophouses along East Coast Road in Singapore have been put up for sale via an expression of interest exercise with an indicative price of S$7.8 million, or about S$1,092 per square foot. The two-storey shophouses sit on a 2,380 sq ft land plot and have a total existing built-up area of around 3,960 sq ft. Interested parties have until March 31 to submit their offers, with the property potentially being redeveloped into a mixed-use development with a building height of up to five storeys, subject to approval from authorities.

images.alt_text: The price tag works out to about S$1,092 psf on the maximum allowable gross floor area of 7,140 sq ft, said sole marketing agent CBRE on Wednesday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.36% or 110.29 points to 30,636.67 in the first few minutes of trade on Wednesday, following a six-day rally. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a holiday.

site_title: COE prices end lower at latest tender
summary: COE prices ended lower at the latest tender, continuing a downward trend. Commercial vehicle premiums fell by 10% to S$40,890, while smaller car premiums dropped to S$41,001 and larger car premiums to S$46,002. The Open COE premium slid 4.5% to S$47,506, and motorcycle COE prices also decreased to S$7,500. The lower prices follow a three-year peak for commercial vehicles two weeks ago.

images.alt_text: Certificate of entitlement (COE) prices fell across the board at the end of the latest bidding exercise on Wednesday (Feb 17), continuing a mostly downward trend from the previous tender.

site_title: Christie's jumps into burgeoning digital art market
summary: Christie's is auctioning off the first purely digital artwork, "Everydays - The First 5000 Days" by American digital artist Beeple, on February 27-March 11. The piece, which comprises 13 years of Beeple's artwork, will start bidding at $100. The artwork is verified with a Non-Fungible Token (NFT) and is part of the rapidly expanding digital art market, where NFTs enable the sale of digital art like traditional paintings and sculptures. This marks a significant milestone in the market's growth, with Christie's specialist Noah Davis describing NFT-based art as "the next ingeniously disruptive force in the art market."

site_title: Biden says vaccines available for all Americans by end July
summary: President Joe Biden announced that all Americans will have access to COVID-19 vaccines by the end of July, with 600 million doses available to vaccinate every American. He also expressed hope for a faster return to schools and backed vaccinations for teachers. Biden predicted that life would return to normal by next Christmas, with significantly fewer people needing to socially distance and wear masks.

site_title: Deficit narrowed in FY2021
summary: The Singapore Budget 2021 revealed a narrowed deficit in FY2021, with the government aiming to reduce its fiscal deficit to 2.5% of GDP by 2025. The budget allocated S$43.9 billion for COVID-19-related measures, while also focusing on sustainable and inclusive growth. The government plans to implement a range of initiatives, including tax incentives and subsidies, to support businesses and individuals affected by the pandemic. Overall, the budget aims to promote economic recovery and long-term sustainability.

site_title: JD.com plans to list shipping unit to ride e-commerce boom
summary: JD.com plans to list its shipping unit in Hong Kong, potentially raising $5 billion and valuing the unit at $40 billion. The move is part of the company's efforts to capitalize on China's post-Covid e-commerce boom. JD.com's shares gained over 6% on the news, following an IPO rush fueled by global liquidity. The proposed spin-off is expected to be finalized in the coming months, with details yet to be finalized.

site_title: Serviced apartment building in Novena up for sale at S$93m
summary: A 15-storey serviced apartment building, "12 on Shan," in Singapore's Novena area is up for sale with an indicative price tag of S$93 million. The 78-unit development, featuring studio, one, and two-bedroom apartments, is zoned residential and offers fully furnished units with prices ranging from S$350 to S$930 sq ft. The property is strategically located near medical facilities and is expected to benefit from Singapore's strong medical tourism industry, according to the marketing agent. The sale price is considered low, with the guide price at S$1,367 psf, and the property is available via an expression of interest exercise.

site_title: Biden says China to face repercussions on human rights
summary: US President Joe Biden warned China that human rights abuses in its Xinjiang region will have repercussions. Biden criticized China's treatment of Muslim minorities, calling it "contrary to basic human rights." He emphasized the US priority of preserving a free and open Indo-Pacific region and expressed concern over Beijing's trade practices and rights issues. The US will reassert its global role in speaking up for human rights, working with the international community to pressure China to protect them.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip as gold miners weigh, BHP hits record high
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% to 6,885.2 points, dragged down by gold miners due to weak bullion prices. BHP, however, reached a record high after brokerages upgraded its shares following the miner's annual results. Gold miners declined 6.2%, their worst day in nearly three months, as inflation bets and rising US Treasury yields impacted the market.

site_title: Brokers' take: Upside for aviation, consumer and manufacturing stocks from Budget 2021
summary: DBS Group Research views Singapore Budget 2021 as "more shots in the arm" for sectors like retail Reits, aviation, and consumer stocks. Key measures include taxing low-value goods via GST from 2023, creating a more level playing field for brick-and-mortar retailers. This is expected to benefit retail Singapore Reits in the medium term. The budget aims to support growth in key sectors, providing targeted support to help them recover and thrive in the post-pandemic economy.

site_title: Kovan's Jansen Mansion in second en bloc attempt, reserve price lowered to S$19.8m
summary: The owners of 12-unit condominium Jansen Mansion in Kovan, Singapore are making a second attempt at a collective sale with a lowered reserve price of S$19.8 million, down from S$22 million in 2018. The new reserve price translates to a land rate of S$879 per square foot per plot ratio, inclusive of development charge and 7% bonus balcony space. The 999-year leasehold condominium has been on the market since September 1, 1876.

site_title: Nestle to sell North American water brands to buyout firm for US$4.3b
summary: Nestle will sell its North American water brands, including Pure Life and Poland Spring, to private equity firms One Rock Capital Partners and Metropoulos & Co for US$4.3 billion. The sale includes brands such as Deer Park, Ozarka, and Ice Mountain. Nestle had previously announced its intention to explore a potential sale of part of its North American water business in June 2020. The deal marks a significant exit for Nestle from its North American water market.

site_title: China trade key to regional recovery, but Asean economies still struggling: Moody's
summary: China's growing trade demand has boosted the Asia-Pacific region's recovery, with key beneficiaries including Vietnam, Malaysia, Taiwan, and Indonesia. Exports to China are a critical lifeline, with Vietnam and Taiwan outperforming the region and rebounding to pre-pandemic levels. However, the report warns that regional trade is still vulnerable to external factors, and most of Southeast Asia is not expected to resume pre-pandemic output until early 2022. Longer-term economic challenges include fiscal positions, debt, and structural changes.

site_title: Australian media firms squeeze more from Google as new law looms
summary: Australian media firms have reached lucrative deals with Google, worth A$60 million (S$61.8 million) annually, after the US tech giant threatened to shut down its search engine in the country. The deals surpass those of Google's French publishers, averaging US$209,000 a year. The agreements come ahead of a law that would allow the government to appoint an arbitrator to set Google's content fees if negotiations stall. Despite the deals, the law is set to pass, with Australian Treasurer Josh Frydenberg saying it would have been impossible to reach agreements without the legislation.

site_title: Malaysian durian trade battered as lockdown bites
summary: Malaysia's durian trade has been severely impacted by a prolonged lockdown, leading to a significant decline in domestic demand. The industry, which relies heavily on China's appetite for the fruit, has seen sales plummet. Traders are now more reliant on exports to China, but the prolonged lockdown has disrupted supply chains, causing concern that the industry could collapse if exports are not sustained. The lockdown has also led to a decrease in local sales, with roadside stalls largely empty of customers.

site_title: Singapore minister flags risks of low rates on property market
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat warned that ultra-low interest rates can lead to mispricing of asset prices and a risk of investing in the wrong places. The government may take fresh steps to cool the housing market, which has made a rapid recovery after the pandemic. Heng emphasized the need for sustainable property investments, saying it's premature to ease current property curbs, and the government will monitor the market. The government has previously imposed measures such as higher stamp duties and tighter home loan limits to curb price spikes.

site_title: ByteDance denies being in preliminary talks to list TikTok on NYSE: Global Times
summary: ByteDance, the parent company of TikTok, has denied being in preliminary talks to list the video app on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE). According to a report by China's Global Times, ByteDance responded that previous media reports were not true. This comes after the newspaper earlier cited sources as saying ByteDance was in discussions to list TikTok on the NYSE. The denial marks a potential setback for TikTok's plans to go public in the US.

site_title: Asia: Most markets down on profit-taking but optimism remains
summary: Asian markets fell on Wednesday due to profit-taking after a strong rally, with investors worried about valuation levels. Despite this, analysts remain optimistic, citing vaccine rollouts, slowing infection rates, and the easing of lockdowns as drivers of a strong upward market trend. The US stimulus package and rising inflation expectations have also fueled concerns about rising borrowing costs. However, traders remain confident in the market's resilience, citing the Federal Reserve's support and the potential for further stimulus.

site_title: Can Asean recover this year?
summary: Southeast Asia, or Asean, is facing a significant economic challenge due to the Covid-19 pandemic, which has devastated the region's growth prospects. However, there are positive signs of recovery, with Asean nations implementing strategies such as improving healthcare infrastructure, trade integration, and vaccination efforts. The Asian Development Bank predicts a 5.2% GDP increase in 2021, driven by China, Asean's largest trading partner. Asean governments are also taking steps to mitigate the economic impact, including stimulus packages and digital payments initiatives. The Asean chair for 2021, Brunei, aims to promote regional cooperation and economic growth.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister, Coordinating Minister for Economic Policies and Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat's Royal Audience with His Majesty Sultan Haji Hassanal Bolkiah Mu'izzaddin Waddaulah, Sultan and Yang Di-Pertuan of Brunei Darussalam, 10 November 2020

site_title: 'Terrified' UN envoy issues stark warning on Myanmar
summary: The UN special rapporteur for Myanmar, Tom Andrews, has issued a stern warning about the potential for violence in the country as protests continued following a military coup. The generals who deposed and detained civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi have shut down the internet, and Andrews fears that Wednesday's planned mass protests could lead to greater violence. He has called on the international community to put pressure on the generals and urged foreign businesses to cut ties with Myanmar if the violence continues. The military justified its power seizure by alleging widespread voter fraud in the November elections.

site_title: Olympics torch relay plan stirs concern from Japanese official
summary: Japanese prefecture governor expresses concern over the Olympic torch relay due to the coronavirus, adding to the Tokyo 2020 Games' challenges. The Games have already faced a delay, public opposition, and the resignation of the head of the Tokyo organising committee. A new head for the organisation is being selected, following the second meeting of the candidate selection committee.

images.alt_text: The governor of Japan's Shimane prefecture said on Wednesday the Olympic torch relay should be reconsidered because of the coronavirus, the latest setback to the Tokyo 2020 Games amid the pandemic.

site_title: New York attorney general sues Amazon over Covid-19 shortfalls
summary: New York Attorney General Letitia James sued Amazon on Tuesday over its handling of worker safety during the Covid-19 pandemic at two warehouses. James accused Amazon of prioritizing profits over worker safety, leading to "flagrant disregard" for necessary measures to protect workers. The lawsuit seeks to require Amazon to upgrade protection for workers, reinstate a fired worker, and pay damages. Amazon responded by filing its own lawsuit to block James' case, citing federal labour and safety laws.

site_title: Japan starts vaccine roll-out with healthcare workers
summary: Japan began vaccinating healthcare workers against the coronavirus on February 17, 2021, with the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine. The initial rollout targeted 800 healthcare workers, with plans to vaccinate 40,000 staff nationwide. The country aims to eventually vaccinate 3.7 million healthcare workers and 36 million people aged 65 or older. Japan has approved only the Pfizer jab, with AstraZeneca awaiting approval, and has seen a relatively limited outbreak of cases, with nearly 418,000 infections and 7,000 deaths so far.

site_title: Thai economic outlook highly uncertain, fiscal policy should continue: BOT
summary: Thailand's economic outlook remains uncertain due to large downside risks, with limited monetary policy room. The Bank of Thailand (BOT) voted unanimously to keep the one-day repurchase rate unchanged at 0.50% for a sixth straight meeting. The economy is expected to expand at a slower pace than previously projected, with a recovery among sectors being uneven and increasing labor market vulnerability. Fiscal support is crucial for an economic recovery, and the BOT will review monetary policy on March 24 with updated economic projections. The economy is expected to return to pre-pandemic levels in the third quarter of 2022.

site_title: Japan's ruling party wants more women at meetings but only if they don't talk
summary: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party has proposed allowing five female lawmakers to join key meetings as observers, despite criticism that the move is a PR exercise. The female observers can't speak during the meetings but can submit opinions separately. The decision comes after a sexism row sparked by Tokyo Olympics chief Yoshiro Mori's derogatory comments about women speaking too much. The party's secretary general, Toshihiro Nikai, said the move is intended to allow female members to "look" at the party's decision-making process, but critics argue it doesn't address the underlying sexism.

site_title: Gold drops a fifth day as bond yield rally delivers 'fatal blow'
summary: Gold prices fell for a fifth consecutive day, with a 5% decline this year, as Treasury yields surged due to optimism over global economic recovery from the pandemic. The rising yields are triggering an unwind of safe-haven trades, with analysts calling it a "fatal blow" to gold. A death cross pattern, where the 50-day moving average fell below the 200-day counterpart, has also been reached, indicating further losses may be on the horizon.

site_title: New Zealand releasing Auckland from brief Covid-19 lockdown
summary: New Zealand lifted a Covid-19 lockdown of Auckland and eased restrictions nationwide from midnight on Wednesday, February 17, 2021. The lockdown was implemented after a new, more contagious Covid-19 variant was detected in Auckland. Three locally transmitted cases were reported, prompting a brief three-day lockdown. The country is set to start inoculating its five million people against the new coronavirus on February 20, with the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine being administered earlier. The move follows a nationwide shutdown that largely eliminated local transmission and comes after Australia suspended travel arrangements with New Zealand.

site_title: Westpac sees profit rebound as economy recovers, shares surge
summary: Westpac Banking Corp reported a 16% increase in first-quarter profit to A$1.97 billion, driven by a reversal in bad debt charges as the Australian economy recovers from the pandemic. The bank's shares surged over 6% to their highest level in a year, outperforming analyst expectations. Core earnings rose 28% due to higher revenues and improving margins, driven by the resurgent housing market. The result was attributed to the country's successful pandemic containment and unprecedented monetary and fiscal support. However, the bank warned that margins remain under pressure and investment spending is likely to increase in 2021.

site_title: Australia: Gold miners drag down shares; BHP, Westpac soar
summary: Australian shares declined 0.3% to 6,897.60, after two sessions of gains, due to losses in healthcare and gold miners. Iron ore mining giants and banks, such as BHP and Westpac, rose. Gold miners, including BHP, lost 5% as bullion prices fell. The decline was attributed to stronger US Treasury yields.

site_title: Biden goes to US heartland for support on massive economic package
summary: US President Joe Biden is hosting a televised town hall in Wisconsin to seek support for his $1.9 trillion economic rescue package, which would more than double the previous measure passed by Congress. The administration believes the package's massive injections of money, including $1,400 checks, are vital to preventing a sluggish economic recovery from stalling. Despite skepticism from most Republicans, Biden's efforts seem to be paying off, with nearly 70% of Americans supporting the stimulus package, according to recent polls.

site_title: Myanmar's Internet goes down for third night running
summary: Myanmar experienced a near-total Internet shutdown for the third consecutive night amid protests against the military junta, according to NetBlocks. The blackout, which lasted from 1am to 9am, resulted in only 19% of normal internet connectivity. Over 420 people have been arrested since the coup, with neighborhood watch groups forming to protect protesters. The shutdown has left the public on edge, highlighting the military's efforts to restrict information and suppress dissent.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.52% or 158.70 points at 30,309.05. Investors took profits following a mixed close on Wall Street, citing concerns over the over-valuation of stocks after recent rallies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.02 points, or 0.37%, to 1,600.12. Losers beat gainers 403 to 275. This is the first update from the article, as the other provided articles discuss separate market events in Singapore, Asia, Europe, and the US.

site_title: Salesforce, Slack asked to provide additional information by DOJ's antitrust unit
summary: Salesforce and Slack have received requests for additional information from the US Department of Justice's antitrust unit regarding their $27.7 billion merger. The companies were asked to provide documentary material and additional information. The deal, which was agreed to on December 1, is still expected to be completed by July 31. The DOJ's investigation into the merger is ongoing.

site_title: Berkshire trims Apple bet, reveals Chevron, Verizon holdings
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway trimmed its Apple stake, reducing its valuation to about $120 billion at the end of 2020. The conglomerate also revealed three new buys: Verizon Communications, insurance broker Marsh & McLennan Cos, and Chevron. The new investments were granted confidential status and not disclosed in a third-quarter filing. The news sent shares of the three companies up in after-market trading. Berkshire's Apple stake remains its largest single stock holding.

site_title: Comet from edge of solar system killed the dinosaurs: study
summary: A comet from the edge of the solar system struck off the coast of Mexico 66 million years ago, causing a massive impact that led to the extinction of 75% of life on Earth, including the dinosaurs. Researchers at Harvard have solved long-standing mysteries about the Chicxulub impactor, concluding it originated in icy debris, was influenced by Jupiter, and will recur every 250-750 million years. This comet theory resolves the debate over a massive asteroid and supports the asteroid impact theory.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Soilbuild Reit, Sembcorp, Sunningdale, CDL, Intraco
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Several companies are experiencing significant developments that may impact trading of their shares. Soilbuild Reit has released a scheme document with a reduced consideration of 53.806 Singapore cents per unit. Sembcorp Industries' power plant in Myanmar remains operational, and shares closed flat. Sunningdale Tech's minority shareholders must vote on a private equity buyout by Wednesday. City Developments Limited reported multiple hotel cancellations in New Zealand, causing its shares to drop. Intraco Limited expects a "material net loss" due to impairment losses and a loss on disposal. These developments may affect trading of these companies' shares.

site_title: Billions of pounds in the red, UK budget to have greenish hue
summary: UK finance minister Rishi Sunak's budget on March 3 is expected to have a green hue, with plans to launch Britain's first "green" government bonds to finance environmentally friendly investments. The government aims to reduce net carbon emissions to zero by 2050, but progress on carbon taxes may be slow due to a £400 billion budget deficit. The UK will also review its Bank of England's remits to focus more on climate change, and consider new taxes on carbon emissions.

site_title: Citi can't get back US$500m it wrongly paid out: US judge
summary: A US judge has ruled that Citigroup is liable for US$900 million in mistaken payments it made to 10 financial companies in August 2020. The payments were intended for interest, but Citigroup mistakenly sent the full principal amount instead. The judge found that the lenders believed in good faith that the payments were for the full loan repayment, and therefore, they are entitled to keep the money. Citigroup plans to appeal the decision, stating that it believes it is entitled to the funds and will continue to pursue a complete recovery.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit's independent adviser says S$0.55 per unit offer is 'fair and reasonable'
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit's independent adviser, KPMG, has stated that the offer to take the Reit private at S$0.55 per unit is "fair and reasonable". The adjusted scheme consideration, taking into account the Q4 distribution, is 53.806 cents per unit, implying a price to net asset value multiple of 0.96 to 0.99 times. An extraordinary general meeting will be held on March 11, and if approved, the transaction is expected to become effective by March 31.

site_title: Japan's exports, machine orders pick up as demand recovers
summary: Japan's exports rose 6.4% in January, driven by a 37.5% increase in exports to China, its largest trading partner. This follows a 6.6% increase forecast by economists. Core machinery orders also rose for the third straight month, indicating a gradual recovery from last year's coronavirus slump. However, policymakers face a fragile recovery, with renewed pandemic curbs weighing on business activity and service consumption expected to contract in the current quarter.

images.alt_text: Japan's exports accelerated in January, led by a jump in Chinese demand, and manufacturers'sentiment turned positive for the first time since 2019 signalling a gradual recovery from last year's deep coronavirus slump.

site_title: China's Sinovac vaccine CoronaVac endorsed by advisory panel for use in HK
summary: Hong Kong's advisory panel endorsed the Sinovac vaccine CoronaVac, paving the way for its approval and a second shot. The vaccine has an overall efficacy rate of slightly more than 50%. This decision follows the completion of the approval process for vaccines developed by BioNTech and Pfizer. The endorsement comes as Hong Kong prepares to inoculate its residents, marking a significant step forward in the city's COVID-19 vaccination efforts.

site_title: Millions struggle without power as cold snap grips US
summary: A deadly winter storm has gripped the southern and central US, leaving millions without power as record low temperatures hit several states. In Texas, utility companies implemented rotating blackouts due to high demand. At least three people were killed by a tornado in another area. The extreme cold has brought unprecedented challenges, highlighting the region's lack of preparedness for such conditions.

site_title: Millennium spin-off fund bets on Indonesia, Singapore currencies
summary: A macro hedge fund, Modular Asset Management, is building bullish positions in the Indonesian rupiah and Singapore dollar, anticipating a 4% appreciation in the Indonesian currency due to its drive to become a regional electric-vehicle hub. The firm also expects the Singapore dollar to strengthen on a faster vaccine roll-out. Meanwhile, the Thai baht and Philippine peso are forecast to weaken. Indonesia's battery-grade nickel production is expected to more than triple by 2025, driven by its large reserves and potential for a production boom.

images.alt_text: A macro hedge fund spun out of Millennium Management is building bullish positions in the Indonesian rupiah and Singapore dollar, betting that measures adopted by the two countries could boost their currencies.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports rise for second straight month in January with 12.8% growth
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports rose 12.8% year-over-year in January, driven by growth in non-electronics and electronics shipments. Non-electronic exports increased 12.5% and electronic products grew 13.5% from a low base. Key growth areas included telecommunications equipment, integrated circuits, and diodes and transistors. Total trade fell 1.9% due to a decline in oil trade, but shipments to emerging markets expanded 43.4%. The growth beats private-sector analyst forecasts, with non-oil domestic exports expected to grow 0-2% in 2021.

site_title: Sias reminds Sunningdale shareholders to cast their votes
summary: Sunningdale Precision, a plastic-components supplier, is urging minority shareholders to cast their votes by 3pm on Wednesday in a deal to take the company private. The offeror has raised its offer price to S$1.65 a share, a 42.6% premium over the volume-weighted average price of Sunningdale shares for the last year. The deal aims to provide flexibility to make significant long-term investments, but shareholders may choose to receive a combination of cash and shares in the offeror, allowing them to remain invested in Sunningdale.

site_title: Big oil companies are investing in startup that drills for clean energy
summary: Big oil companies BP and Chevron have invested $40 million in Eavor Technologies, a startup that aims to expand geothermal power by harnessing heat from beneath the earth's surface. The technology uses drilling techniques from the oil and gas industry to create a loop that can be used to heat buildings or generate electricity. Eavor plans to scale up and bring down costs to supply 10 million homes by 2030, with a pipeline of potential projects in Germany, the Netherlands, Japan, and the US.

site_title: Amazon quietly acquires e-commerce rival Selz
summary: Amazon has quietly acquired e-commerce platform Selz, which enables businesses to build their own online stores. The deal's terms were not disclosed, and it was confirmed by Selz in a blog post. This acquisition could help Amazon fend off challenges from Shopify, a Canadian-based firm offering similar services to retailers. The move aims to expand Amazon's presence in the e-commerce market and strengthen its competitive edge.

site_title: Oil settles near 13-month highs; Texas deep freeze supports
summary: Oil prices settled near 13-month highs on Tuesday, driven by a deep freeze in the US South that shut wells and oil refineries in Texas, supporting prices. US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures rose 1% to $60.05, while Brent settled 0.1% higher at $63.35. Cold temperatures led to well freeze-offs and refinery disruptions, with 500,000-1.2 million barrels of US crude oil production expected to be shut down. OPEC+ producers are likely to ease output curbs after April, but remain cautious about the pandemic.

site_title: Parler back online after getting boot from Amazon over riot
summary: Parler, a conservative social media website, has returned to the internet after being suspended by Amazon Web Services due to its failure to remove content promoting violence after the January 6 US Capitol riot. Cloud hosting company SkySilk, which is based in Los Angeles, has taken over Parler's internet service. The site was intermittently available on Monday, with some users unable to access it. SkySilk's CEO, Kevin Matossian, stated that the company advocates for private judgment and rejects the role of being the judge, jury, and executioner.

site_title: Singapore reviewing carbon tax after 2023
summary: Singapore's government will review the carbon tax after 2023, aiming to increase it from S$5 to S$10-15 per tonne by 2030. The review will consider international climate developments, emissions mitigation efforts, and economic competitiveness. The current rate, introduced in 2019, provides businesses with certainty in the current challenging economic climate. The review's outcome will be announced at Budget 2022, allowing businesses to adjust to any revisions.

site_title: Europe: Shares end flat as mining gains offset broader losses
summary: European shares ended flat, reaching a one-year peak, despite losses in most sectors, due to gains in mining and bank stocks. A 2% rise in Glencore shares lifted the European mining index to a near 10-year high, while energy stocks rose 0.5% on stronger oil prices. Bank stocks rose to an 11-month high, but remain below pre-pandemic levels. Analysts expect economic growth to bounce back in the second half of the year, driven by pent-up demand and easing restrictions.

site_title: New Covid-19 cases down 16% last week: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization reported a 16% decline in new Covid-19 cases worldwide last week, with 2.7 million cases and 81,000 deaths. This marks the fifth consecutive week of decline, with only the Eastern Mediterranean region showing an increase. The decline is attributed to the effectiveness of simple public health measures. The WHO also approved the AstraZeneca vaccine for shipment via the Covax facility, with deliveries expected to take place in March. Local transmission of Covid-19 variants has been reported in over 100 countries, but the WHO notes that the fire is not out and continued vigilance is necessary.

site_title: Mental health can be an organisation's wealth
summary: A new survey found that 48% of Gen Z and 44% of Millennials experience anxiety or stress all or most of the time, making mental health a significant concern for organizations. With three-quarters of the workforce falling into this category, companies must prioritize mental wellbeing to attract and retain top talent. Experts recommend creating a mental health advocate at the highest level, providing awareness and training, and promoting group care to foster a supportive work culture. Investing in mental health can have long-term benefits, including improved productivity and employee engagement, and is an essential aspect of an organization's ESG value.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as markets watch for stimulus progress
summary: US stocks ended a mixed session, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching a fresh record, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index declined. Investors await stimulus progress from Washington and assess the risks of a market pullback. Tech stocks fell, with Palantir Technologies and Apple losing 12.8% and 1.6%, respectively. General Motors unveiled an all-electric SUV model, while CVS Health dropped 5.0% due to disappointing profit forecasts. The market remains cautious despite a strong start to the week, with analysts warning of potential corrections.

site_title: Record deficit of S$64.9b for FY2020, amounting to 13.9% of GDP
summary: Singapore recorded a record budget deficit of S$64.9 billion for FY2020, 13.9% of GDP, due to lower revenues and increased spending to combat the Covid-19 pandemic. The revised estimated total expenditure for FY2020 is S$94.06 billion, higher than initially anticipated. The government's top-ups to endowment and trust funds and net investment returns contribution also contributed to the deficit. This marks the largest budget deficit since Singapore's independence in 1965, with the government relying on past reserves and special measures to support the economy.

site_title: S$900m Household Support Package to provide short-term relief
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 introduces a S$900 million Household Support Package to provide short-term relief to lower-income households. The package includes vouchers for GST savings, utilities rebates, and community development council vouchers. Additionally, S$200 will be given to each of the 780,000 children in Singapore to support their education. The government also allocates funds for the Community Link programme to support families with children in rental housing, and a new "Change for Charity" grant to support charities.

site_title: HSBC, Standard Chartered among top bank share gainers in Asia on reflation bets
summary: HSBC and Standard Chartered's Hong Kong shares rose 6.9% and 6.3% respectively, leading gains in the region's bank stocks. The MSCI AC Asia Pacific Financials Index rose 1% to its highest level since June 2018, driven by optimism over faster economic growth and higher interest rates. A slowdown in virus cases and progress on vaccine roll-outs have boosted global growth prospects, while rising yields have boosted bank earnings. The two banks are due to report earnings next week, with investors optimistic about the resumption of dividends.

site_title: Vaccines: UK and US can draw optimism from Israel and the UAE
summary: Israel and the UAE have successfully vaccinated 40-60% of their populations, with the UK and US nearing 20% vaccination rates. In contrast, continental European nations have lagged, with only 2-4% vaccinated. Widespread vaccination is expected to lead to reduced case growth, hospitalizations, and economic benefits. Investors can draw optimism from these developments, which may provide a roadmap for the global economy as vaccine roll-outs continue.

site_title: Trump urges Republicans to dump Senate leader McConnell
summary: Donald Trump urged Republican senators to dump Senate leader Mitch McConnell, criticizing him as a "dour, sullen, and unsmiling political hack" after his impeachment trial. Trump blamed McConnell for the Republicans' loss of Senate control and took credit for his party's gains in the House of Representatives. He also claimed McConnell would have lost his re-election bid in Kentucky without his endorsement. Trump threatened to support primary rivals who share his agenda, using his popularity among the Republican base to influence the next national election.

site_title: Investing in new areas, in good times or bad
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021, dubbed "Emerging Stronger Together," allocates S$107 billion to support the economy's recovery and long-term sustainability. The plan includes S$24 billion for firms and workers to innovate, transform, and scale up globally, as well as S$30 million to encourage the adoption of electric vehicles. The budget also focuses on building a vibrant business sector and innovation ecosystem, addressing manpower issues, and strengthening Singapore's status as a "global-Asia node." However, the budget is projected to remain in the red, with a S$11 billion deficit, and the need to "return to running balanced budgets" is emphasized.

site_title: Indonesia banker to helm country's new sovereign wealth fund
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo appointed Ridha DM Wirakusumah, a senior banker with over 30 years of experience, as the chief executive of the country's new sovereign wealth fund, the Indonesia Investment Authority (INA). The fund aims to manage $20 billion and finance infrastructure projects, with an initial seed of $5 billion from the government. Wirakusumah vowed to carry out duties with the highest integrity, with a pipeline of $9.5 billion in potential investments, including toll roads. The fund's creation aims to attract foreign co-investors and avoid the fate of Malaysia's 1MDB scandal.

site_title: Built environment sector anticipating greater digitalisation and collaboration
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the Growth and Transformation Scheme (GTS) to transform the built environment sector, focusing on digitalisation and collaboration. The scheme will require developers to work closely with consultants, contractors, and suppliers to level up as an ecosystem or value chain. The goal is to integrate and digitalise processes, upskill workers, and encourage partnerships and alliancing to share risks. The government aims to provide incentives for early completion and offer subsidies to local players to deploy technologies, addressing manpower shortages.

site_title: 3D-printed homes build hope for US affordable housing
summary: US developers are turning to 3D-printed homes as a quicker, cheaper, and more efficient way to build affordable housing. Icon, an Austin-based developer, has completed the largest 3D-printed structure in North America - a military barracks. The technology has the potential to boost the affordable housing sector, reducing construction times by over a third and waste by about 65%. The global market for 3D-printed construction is projected to grow to $1.5 billion by 2024, with several companies working on 3D-printed houses globally.

site_title: Budget 2021: S$11b for Covid relief, and even more to fortify future
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 allocates S$11 billion for Covid-19 relief and S$24 billion for economic transformation over the next three years. The budget aims to boost business, catalyze capital, and redesign jobs. Key initiatives include a S$900 million Household Support Package, S$5.4 billion for the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package, and a S$60 million Agri-Food Cluster Transformation Fund. The government also plans to issue green bonds and raise petrol duty rates to encourage the use of electric vehicles. To balance the budget, the government will increase the goods and services tax (GST) and borrow to fund major infrastructure projects.

site_title: Cruise industry eyes return a year after Diamond Princess
summary: The cruise industry is cautiously optimistic about a return to normalcy after the COVID-19 pandemic, with bookings already picking up. A year after the Diamond Princess was quarantined off Japan, passengers like David Abel, who contracted the virus on the ship, are eager to return to sea. Despite restrictions and limited liability for operators, some cruise lines, such as MSC Cruises, are seeing increased bookings, with summer and winter 2021-22 bookings at 60% and 80% of pre-pandemic levels, respectively. Resumption of cruises is expected in the second half of 2021, with Carnival and Royal Caribbean targeting late April and early May, respectively.

site_title: Businesses have to take a leap of faith for the future
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 continues to be expansionary despite the Covid-19 pandemic, with a focus on targeted support schemes for businesses and workers. The government has committed to tapping past reserves for the second consecutive year to fund these measures. Key initiatives include the extension of the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) for six months, a wage subsidy scheme for the Jobs Growth Incentive (JGI), and measures to promote innovation and sustainability. The government also signaled plans to increase Goods and Services Tax (GST) in 2022-2025 for fiscal sustainability. Despite potential casualties from scaling back broad-based measures, the government is committed to supporting businesses in a post-Covid-19 environment.

site_title: World fashion capitals get a US$600m haircut thanks to Covid-19
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in a significant economic impact on the world's fashion capitals, with a total loss of US$600 million. The fashion industry's annual four-week events in New York, London, Paris, and Milan will be held virtually for the second consecutive season, erasing investment and tourist spending. The loss is attributed to the pandemic's disruption of the fashion industry's economy, which relies heavily on events and travel.

site_title: Milk and music: Indian villages support protesting farmers
summary: Indian villages near the capital New Delhi are supporting protesting farmers with donations, including milk, food, and water, in their fight against new agriculture laws. Over 70% of India's population relies on agriculture, and the protests, which turned deadly in January, are a major challenge to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government. Villages like Makrauli have formed a support network, with tractors and volunteers delivering supplies to the protest camps, fostering a sense of community and solidarity among the protesters.

site_title: No major tax changes but fiscal prudence reiterated
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 did not introduce significant tax reforms, despite some observers' hopes. However, the government reiterated fiscal prudence and targeted plans to preserve public revenue and recover from the Covid-19 pandemic. The Budget includes measures to issue more bonds to finance infrastructure and long-term assets, potentially freeing up fiscal room without raising taxes. The Goods and Services Tax (GST) will rise from 7% to 9% between 2022 and 2025, and will be imposed on imported low-value goods from 2023.

site_title: Retail, F&B, nightlife operators find Budget measures wanting
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 has been met with mixed reactions from small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), particularly in the retail, food and beverage, and nightlife sectors. While some sectors, such as retail and F&B, will benefit from a S$700 million extension of the Jobs Support Scheme, nightlife establishments will not receive targeted help. Many SMEs expressed disappointment, citing the need for more specific support to help them "emerge stronger together" from the pandemic. However, the government's initiatives, such as grants and digital transformation programs, are seen as beneficial in easing cash flow pressures.

site_title: Technology a key enabler in Singapore's fight against climate change
summary: Singapore's 2021 budget focuses on sustainability, with technology playing a key role in reducing the country's carbon footprint. A new $60 million Agri-Food Cluster Transformation Fund will support technology adoption in the sector. The government also plans to launch an Enterprise Sustainability Programme for small and medium-sized enterprises and increase sustainability goals for the public sector. Additionally, the government will support grassroots projects through the SG Eco Fund. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for a whole-of-society effort to build a green Singapore.

site_title: Riding on Asian high yield credit
summary: Investors are flocking to high-yield credit markets, particularly Asia high yield, driven by low-rate policies and risk-on sentiment. Asia's robust export growth and positive cycle dynamics support the region's recovery, with China's real estate sector showing healthy fundamentals. Asia HY bonds offer attractive income returns, with yields around 6.9% and manageable default risks, despite a relatively high credit spread. The asset class' low duration and high yield-to-duration ratio make it an attractive option for investors seeking yield without excessive credit risk.

images.alt_text: The fundamentals of China's real estate sector look healthy at the moment. China HY bonds, of which the majority are property developers, make up almost 50 per cent of Asia HY.

site_title: Building a digital Silk Road in Asia
summary: Asia is poised to build a digital Silk Road, strengthening ties between economies, promoting economic integration, regional security, and political stability. A growing digital economy will help Asia withstand the impact of shrinking global trade and create a new Asian industrial value chain. The region's high level of digitalization, with Asia accounting for a third of global digital innovation, will drive growth and lead global digitalization. A common digital currency could emerge, enabling Asia to control its financial destiny. Singapore and China have valuable experience in developing the digital economy, which they can contribute to building an Asian digital economy.

images.alt_text: Building the digital economy has been a key part of China's strategic development, and digitisation has permeated and impacted the various segments of production, distribution, consumption, and import and export.

site_title: Budget 2021 is a far-sighted but firmly grounded fiscal strategy
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 is a far-sighted but firmly grounded fiscal strategy, aimed at supporting the economy through the ongoing pandemic. The budget features a targeted Covid-19 Resilience package of S$11 billion, drawn from past reserves, and extends support for industries heavily impacted by the virus. The government has also signaled its intention to raise the Goods and Services Tax (GST) "sooner rather than later" to fund the budget deficit. Additionally, the budget includes initiatives to promote sustainable development, such as expanding public electric vehicle charging infrastructure and implementing green bonds.

site_title: Investors' cash levels at their lowest since pre-taper tantrum of 2013: Bank of America
summary: Bank of America's February fund manager survey found cash levels in investment portfolios at their lowest since 2013, at 3.8%, as investors remain bullish on the economic outlook. 91% of respondents expect a stronger economy, the best reading in BofA's survey. Despite concerns about a potential "taper tantrum" and market volatility, only 13% of participants think the US equity market is in a bubble, with 53% seeing it in a late-stage bull market.

site_title: S Pass cut is latest shake-up as planners woo locals for factory jobs
summary: Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat trimmed the foreign worker headcount in manufacturing through quota cuts in the 2021 budget. Analysts say fresh quota cuts alone are insufficient to attract locals to industry roles, suggesting more policy tightening may be needed for mid- and higher-skilled foreign workers. This move aims to increase domestic participation in the manufacturing sector, which has been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Dollar at 3-week lows; quick US recovery bets fade
summary: The US dollar fell to three-week lows on Tuesday, weakening 0.2% against a basket of its rivals, amid weak consumer sentiment and slower jobs growth. This decline was driven by unwinding of bullish bets on the US economy's outlook after disappointing survey data. The dollar's weakness also dragged on safe-haven currencies, while sterling rose to its highest level since 2018 and the euro re-tested recent resistance.

site_title: The search for income in 2021
summary: Investors seeking income in 2021 can still achieve a 4-5% yield by diversifying across bonds, equities, and non-traditional assets. With about $17 trillion of global bond markets offering negative yields, investors are not condemned to accepting lower yields. A multi-asset income strategy can generate income from bonds, equity dividends, and non-traditional assets like Real Estate Investment Trusts. To manage risk, investors should assess their individual risk appetite and carefully select assets, with a focus on higher-quality but lower-yielding bonds and equities.

site_title: SINGA issues will deepen liquidity in local bond market
summary: Singapore's government has issued S$90 billion in Significant Infrastructure Government Loan Act (SINGA) bonds, aiming to deepen the local bond market and attract institutional investors. The move is expected to develop expertise among banks and ratings agencies, cementing Singapore's status as a green and infrastructure financing hub. Analysts predict warm demand from investors seeking long-term returns, including pension funds and insurers, with pricing estimates suggesting a 20-year government guaranteed infrastructure bond could be priced at around 1.65%.

site_title: Quarz pares stake in Sunningdale ahead of EGM; eyes opportunities with 'higher upside potential'
summary: ACTIVIST investor Quarz Capital Management has reduced its stake in Sunningdale Tech ahead of the upcoming extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to vote on a private equity buyout. Quarz now owns 7.987% of the company's total voting shares, down from 8.023% previously. The buyout offer is at S$1.65 per scheme share, with Quarz arguing that the initial takeover price was undervalued. Sunningdale's chairman, Koh Boon Hwee, has teamed up with Novo Tellus PE Fund 2 to take the company private, and the EGM will be held electronically on Feb 19.

site_title: How McLaren aims to rebuild supercars to roar into electric era
summary: McLaren, a British supercar maker, is taking time to rethink its vehicle-building process as it transitions to electric vehicles. Despite having the technology to produce an electric car tomorrow, the company's executive director, Ruth Nic Aoidh, says the weight of batteries would compromise the performance and exclusivity of its vehicles. Instead, McLaren is developing a new carbon composite chassis and planning to monetize its technology by selling it to other automakers. The company aims to have fully electric models on the road by the end of the decade, with a hybrid model, the Artura, launching on February 17.

site_title: Sembcorp: Myanmar power plant still operating
summary: Sembcorp Industries confirmed its 225-megawatt gas-fired power plant in Mandalay, Myanmar, is still operating despite the military coup. The plant, which began full commercial operation in 2018, has a net book value of US$57 million and an outstanding loan of US$230 million. Employees are safe, and the company will continue to monitor the situation. Sembcorp's other investment, an industrial park development, has not yet commenced. The company's shares closed flat on Tuesday before the announcement.

site_title: Second chance for Mario Draghi to prove his mettle and save Europe
summary: Mario Draghi, the former European Central Bank president, has taken over as Italian prime minister, leading a broad consensus government with a technocratic makeup. The government aims to implement the EU's pandemic recovery fund, which includes €200 billion in grants and loans. Draghi faces a challenging timetable, including elections for the next Italian president in February 2022 and a general election in May 2023. His success will depend on his ability to manage funding from Brussels and negotiate in European capitals, while navigating domestic politics and potential opposition from the League and other parties.

site_title: Hollywood struggles for fans in China's growing film market
summary: China's box office revenue is expected to return to near pre-pandemic highs in 2021, with ticket sales potentially reaching 60 billion yuan, close to 2019's record of 64 billion yuan. This growth comes as Chinese viewers increasingly favor local language films and show sensitivity towards portrayals of China and its people in Western culture. Hollywood studios are under pressure, with a bilateral pact with China expiring and the US-China film agreement not being renewed. This has led to a decline in foreign film releases in China, with the share of foreign films slipping to 16% of Chinese ticket receipts in 2020.

images.alt_text: With China studios now making high quality and culturally relevant films, the days of China's market saving a mediocre movie are over.

site_title: Wage support for aviation, aerospace and tourism sectors extended, but on smaller scale
summary: The Singapore government has extended wage support for the aviation, aerospace, and tourism sectors through June 2021, but at a reduced rate of 30% for April to June and 10% for July to September. This move aims to mitigate the impact of the pandemic, but firms must also demonstrate cost efficiency and yield improvements. The government will also provide targeted support and invest in on-arrival testing and biosafety systems to secure Changi Airport's position as a key aviation hub.

site_title: Vaccine bounce not enough to lift Boris over other issues
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's support remains resilient despite a high per-capita death rate from the pandemic and a hard-hit economy. The recent vaccine roll-out has provided a morale boost, with 86% of the public believing the government has done a good job in administering jabs. However, Johnson faces challenges in easing restrictions, with differing views from former Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt and Coronavirus Recovery Group chair Mark Harper. The government's decision on restrictions will be made on Feb 22, and the outcome may impact Johnson's term, which could be shortened due to Brexit and other issues.

site_title: The haunted House of Soviets gets a new life
summary: The House of Soviets, a notorious building in Kaliningrad, Russia, is getting a new life. The 62-year-old resident, Yevgenia Kvasova, who claims the building's eye-like balconies give her the evil eye, is among those who will benefit from the renovation. The project aims to transform the building into a trendy office space and residential complex. The renovation is part of a broader effort to revitalize the city's property market, which has seen a surge in demand for luxury properties. The project's completion is expected to boost the local economy and improve the city's image.

site_title: Pre-retirees can mitigate reduced retirement benefits brought on by Covid-19
summary: A 2020 study by the CFA Institute Mercer found that Covid-19 may reduce retirement benefits globally. To mitigate this, pre-retirees can save more, consider taking on more risk in investments, or work longer to accumulate funds. However, they should also consider their financial position and family dependents. Experts suggest separating needs from wants, such as selling non-essential items, and finding fulfilling second careers to supplement retirement savings. Ultimately, working longer may be a viable alternative to accumulating adequate funds.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine Holdings sold three vessels to Bridgewater Marine (Taiwan) Limited for S$3 million, resulting in a gain of S$1.67 million. Intraco Limited expects a "material net loss" for its fiscal year ended Dec 31, 2020, due to impairment losses and a loss on disposal. Millennium & Copthorne Hotels New Zealand reported multiple cancellations of bookings due to New Zealand's Covid alert level changes.

site_title: Targeted lifeline for listed firms in worst-hit sectors
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 extends the Jobs Support Scheme by up to six months, providing targeted lifelines for businesses in the worst-hit sectors, including aviation, hospitality, and aerospace. The extension, with subsidies ranging from 10% to 30%, aims to help these sectors recover in the second half of 2021. The move is seen as a significant relief for companies such as Singapore Airlines and ST Engineering, which have been severely impacted by the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Engineers and mechanics (above) retrofitting an Airbus A321 passenger plane into a freighter plane at an ST Engineering hangar. ST Engineering, a big aerospace player, has received millions in wage support to cushion the blow that Covid-19 has dealt the sector.

site_title: Petrol tax hike won't see quick switch to electric vehicles: car rental firms
summary: Singapore's petrol duty hike of 23% for premium petrol and 18% for intermediate petrol aims to discourage the use of petrol-powered vehicles. However, car rental firms say they won't switch to electric vehicles immediately due to affordability and infrastructure concerns. To ease the transition, varying rebates will be offered to affected vehicle owners, including a 15% road tax rebate for private cars and a S$360 petrol duty rebate for taxis and private-hire cars. The government expects the revenue increase to cost about S$130 million, which will be paid out through offsets.

site_title: FY2021 Budget deficit to narrow to S$11.01b
summary: Singapore's FY2021 budget deficit is expected to narrow to S$11.01 billion, representing 2.2% of GDP. This marks the country's third consecutive deficit, following extensive spending in FY2020 to support the economy amid the Covid-19 crisis. The deficit is in line with market expectations of S$10 billion to S$12 billion.

site_title: Old-school sectors could benefit from S$1b in funding platform
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a new Local Enterprises Funding Platform, co-investing S$1 billion with Temasek to support Large Local Enterprises (LLEs) in traditional sectors like retail and manufacturing. The platform aims to provide more sustainable funding for LLEs, which may struggle to access private equity funding. However, some observers suggest extending the platform to mid-sized companies, known as the "sandwiched class," and large SMEs. The government also introduced measures to support high-growth enterprises, including increasing the cap on loans under the Venture Debt programme and launching initiatives to help mature companies digitalize.

images.alt_text: The manufacturing sector can benefit from greater funding "to expand beyond the shores of Singapore as well as upgrade towards higher value-add, advanced manufacturing capabilities", says Mr Chai of EY.

site_title: From crisis to strength
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 focuses on recovery from the COVID-19 crisis. The government aims to drive economic growth and create jobs. A new centre for sustainable aviation will be set up in the Asia-Pacific region. The budget also includes measures to support workers, such as a new grant of up to S$100,000 for tariff-hit businesses and training programs. Additionally, the government encourages graduates to future-proof their careers and provides resources to help workers adapt to changing job markets. The budget aims to rebuild Singapore's economy and position the country for long-term growth.

site_title: Tom Stoppard tells of an enormous life spent in constant motion
summary: Czech-born playwright Tom Stoppard, 83, has led an "enormous life" marked by constant motion, according to his new biography. Born in 1937, Stoppard fled Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia with his family at age 8 and eventually settled in England. His play "The Real Thing" features a cricket-bat speech that metaphorically explores writing, a theme echoed in his life of prolific writing and activism. Stoppard's biography, "Tom Stoppard: A Life," by Hermione Lee, chronicles his relationships, politics, and creative process, revealing a man who remains loyal to friends and family despite his demanding career.

images.alt_text: Although Stoppard has spacious offices in which to work, he prefers to write at the kitchen table, late into the night, after everyone else has gone to bed.

site_title: Fake meat moves beyond burgers with money for printing steaks
summary: Israel's Redefine Meat raises US$29 million to build a large-scale pilot factory and begin sales of 3D-printed steaks later this year. The startup aims to change consumer perception that meat can only come from animals, targeting high-end restaurants in Israel, Europe, and Asia. With distribution partners in four countries, Redefine plans to become the world's biggest alternative meat company by 2030. The company's 3D-printed steaks can be printed countless times and deliver a complex layering of muscle and fat, offering a sensory experience similar to prime beef.

site_title: Closed-door trial of Aung San Suu Kyi and Win Myint begins
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi and Win Myint, the ousted leaders of Myanmar, began a closed-door trial on Tuesday. The trial started with a video conference and lasted less than an hour, with the defense attorney not aware of the proceedings. Suu Kyi is accused of violating import restrictions and breaching a natural disaster management law, while Win Myint is charged with breaching the same law.
