summary: Saudi Arabia has announced it will stop signing contracts with foreign companies having regional headquarters in other countries starting January 1, 2024, in an effort to boost domestic businesses and attract more investment. The move aims to create jobs, limit economic leakage, and increase spending efficiency. The decision, which applies to government agencies and institutions, follows a previous initiative to relocate Middle East headquarters to Riyadh, with 24 international companies already committing to do so. The move is seen as a challenge to the UAE, with analysts suggesting it could have a commercial impact on the country.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda says stock boom reflects economic optimism, defends ETF scheme
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda defended the central bank's ultra-loose monetary policy, citing market optimism over the global economic outlook. The recent stock price rally was attributed to steady vaccine rollouts and global economic uncertainty. Kuroda emphasized the need for vigilance in monitoring financial risks associated with prolonged easing, but deemed it premature to discuss an exit from the BOJ's super-loose policy, including its exchange-traded fund (ETF) buying program, given the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. A review of policy tools, including the ETF program, is planned for March.

site_title: Australia: Shares near one-year high on BHP's record dividend, strong profit
summary: Australian shares rose to their highest in nearly a year, driven by BHP Group's record interim dividend and strong profit. The S&P/ASX 200 index increased 0.3% to 6,888.3, with miners jumping 1.7% to their highest since January 27. Strong commodity prices further lifted mining and energy stocks.

site_title: US' SolarWinds hacking is world's largest, most sophisticated attack: Microsoft
summary: Microsoft president Brad Smith says the SolarWinds hacking campaign is the largest and most sophisticated attack the world has ever seen. The operation, likely orchestrated by Russia, compromised thousands of US government agencies and companies using SolarWinds' software, gaining access to email at the Treasury, Justice, and Commerce departments. Cyber security experts warn it could take months to identify and expel the hackers, and estimate over 1,000 engineers may have worked on the attack. US intelligence confirms Russia's involvement, but the country has denied responsibility.

site_title: Regulator denies Crown licence for huge Sydney casino
summary: Australia's Independent Liquor and Gaming Authority has denied Crown Resorts a licence to operate a new Sydney casino due to suspected links to organised crime. The decision follows a public inquiry's report, which found Crown had "facilitated" money-laundering through high roller junkets linked to Chinese triads. The company has faced criticism over its governance and risk management practices, leading to resignations of the CEO and three directors. Crown will continue to consult with the Gaming Authority to address concerns, but it's unclear what steps can reverse the regulator's decision.

site_title: UK housing prices up even as tax break expiry draws near
summary: UK housing prices rose 0.5% in January and early February, despite a soon-to-expire tax incentive, according to Rightmove. Despite a decline in new sellers due to coronavirus lockdowns, buyer demand remained strong, with 45% more website visits and 7% more purchases agreed in February. The tax break, set to expire on March 31, has not deterred buyers, with new demand at a six-month high.

site_title: Tesla's Bitcoin bet is environmental idiocy
summary: Tesla's investment in Bitcoin, worth $1.5 billion, has sparked environmental concerns as the cryptocurrency's mining process requires vast amounts of electricity, contributing to a significant carbon footprint. The mining process, which uses around 78 terawatt hours of electricity annually, is often linked to fossil fuels and has a carbon intensity of 480-500g of CO2 per kilowatt hour. This move is at odds with Tesla's environmental image and may worsen the company's carbon footprint, highlighting the contradiction between investing in Bitcoin and promoting sustainability.

site_title: Oil hits 13-month highs as market rebalances
summary: Oil prices surged to 13-month highs on Monday, reaching $63.76 a barrel for Brent crude and $60.95 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate, driven by production cuts from OPEC and allied producers, and promising vaccine rollouts to revive demand. Prices gained 5% last week and are expected to average $45-$60 a barrel this year, according to Russian Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Novak. However, a potential strike at Norway's largest oil loading terminal and cold weather in Texas and Oklahoma could disrupt supply and impact US production.

site_title: Global Covid vaccination push gets a shot in the arm
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has approved the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine, paving the way for its global distribution through the Covax program, which aims to ensure equitable access to vaccines for the world's poorest countries. Covax has secured agreements for 2 billion doses, with the first wave of distribution set to begin in late February, targeting 145 economies with enough doses to immunize 3.3% of their population by mid-2021. The program, which has secured over $6 billion in pledges, is seen as a crucial step in tackling the pandemic globally.

site_title: US vows to be 'constructive partner' for new WTO chief
summary: The US has welcomed the appointment of Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala as the new director-general of the World Trade Organization, pledging to work closely with her as a "constructive partner" in efforts to reform and revitalize the global trade body. The US had previously blocked her appointment, but the Biden administration reversed this decision. Okonjo-Iweala, with her experience in economics, trade, and diplomacy, is expected to help move forward efforts to promote equitable economic growth and address global challenges.

site_title: Thai economy shrinks most since 1997 on tourism collapse
summary: Thailand's economy contracted 6.1% in 2021, its worst full-year performance since 1997, due to the collapse of its tourism industry and ongoing political upheaval. The economy is expected to expand at a slower pace than initially predicted, with a revised growth forecast of 2.5-3.5%. The pandemic and ongoing protests have hit the economy hard, with the government implementing a record stimulus package and providing additional relief to low-income workers.

site_title: Pandemic threatens New York's iconic yellow taxis
summary: New York's iconic yellow taxis are facing an uncertain future due to the pandemic, with widespread working from home, school closures, and a lack of tourists resulting in plummeting ride demand. The pandemic has caused a 90% decline in ridership, with only about 5,000 of the 13,000 licensed taxis operating regularly. Drivers, many of whom are first-generation immigrants, are struggling to make ends meet, with some earning as little as $100-150 per day. The city government is considering erasing drivers' debts to help the industry recover, but the future of the yellow taxis remains uncertain.

site_title: UK rolls out hotel quarantine for 'high-risk' country returnees
summary: The UK has introduced mandatory hotel quarantine rules for arrivals from 33 high-risk countries, requiring self-isolation in approved hotels for 10 days and multiple Covid-19 tests. The policy aims to stop new strains of the virus from spreading. Arrivals must book and pay for the package before travel, with costs of £1,750 (S$3,200) including transport, food, and security. Failure to comply can result in fines of £1,000 to £2,000 or £5,000 to £10,000.

site_title: Central banks criticised for risky gamble on climate risks
summary: Central banks are being criticized for using climate scenarios that downplay the need for a rapid transition to a carbon-neutral economy, potentially perpetuating the use of fossil fuels. A study by Oil Change International and Reclaim Finance found the scenarios used by the Network for Greening the Financial System (NGFS) are biased towards higher temperatures and slower fossil fuel phase-outs. The activists warn that this could lead to more harm than good and urge central banks to limit warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius through a rapid phase-out of fossil fuels.

site_title: SembMarine could derive value from buying Keppel assets
summary: SembMarine, a Singaporean offshore and marine company, may benefit from acquiring Keppel Corp's offshore rig business to gain economies of scale. The company faces a "margin problem" and operates in an increasingly unattractive industry due to declining oil prices and growing demand for renewable energy. Analysts suggest a well-structured deal could help SembMarine compete with larger foreign shipyards and boost its depressed margins, potentially reaching 30% of its income from sustainable products by 2030.

images.alt_text: View of Sembcorp Marine's Tuas Boulevard Yard. Acquiring some of Keppel's O&M assets would give SembMarine the necessary heft to compete with foreign shipyards, said Phillip Securities Research's Mr Chua.

site_title: UBS investment bank to have one president instead of two
summary: UBS is set to have one president instead of two in its investment bank, as Piero Novelli leaves to become chairman of Euronext at the end of next month. Robert Karofsky, who joined UBS in 2014, will take over as sole president. Karofsky led the global equities business and oversaw the investment bank's digital transformation, contributing to the bank's best fourth-quarter and full-year results since 2012. CEO Ralph Hamers praised Karofsky's leadership, expressing confidence in his ability to achieve strategic ambitions.

site_title: Free-spending private equity firms set record pace in Europe
summary: Deep-pocketed private equity firms in Europe are making record-breaking deals, with $29 billion in takeovers announced this year, a 60% increase from last year. The surge in dealmaking is driven by opportunities created by the pandemic crisis, cheap credit, and willing sellers. Soaring equity markets are also driving up prices. Industry experts predict that larger deals, including jumbo deployments, are likely this year, with some firms teaming up to outbid strategic buyers. This marks a shift from pandemic prudence to aggressive dealmaking in the European private equity market.

site_title: Crown CEO quits as casino operator bows to regulatory heat
summary: Crown Resorts CEO Ken Barton has resigned amid growing pressure following a report on widespread money laundering and governance issues. The exit removes a major block to regaining the company's gambling licence for its Sydney casino. Three other directors have also stood down, and a fourth has broken ties with major shareholder James Packer. Chairperson Helen Coonan will lead the company as executive chairperson, with the board overseeing the search for a new CEO. The company aims to improve governance, compliance, and culture to regain its licence.

site_title: UK's Johnson sets 'cautious' path out of lockdown
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has outlined a cautious path out of the Covid-19 lockdown, citing high infection rates and the need to protect vulnerable groups. With nearly a quarter of the UK's population vaccinated, Johnson plans to set out a path out of lockdown on February 22, but may delay it if infection rates remain high. Schools are expected to reopen on March 8, with no plans for pubs to reopen with vaccination passports. The UK's death toll stands at 117,166, with the global economy still reeling from the pandemic.

site_title: Jollibee eyes 450 new, mostly overseas stores as it expects rebound
summary: Jollibee Foods Corp plans to open 450 new stores worldwide, mostly overseas, with a 22% increase in capital spending to 12.2 billion pesos. The company expects a return to profit in 2021 after posting its first annual loss in nearly three decades. International business will drive sales and profit growth, with stores opening in North America, Vietnam, and China. Jollibee's net loss in 2020 was 11.5 billion pesos, but it reported a net income of 2.05 billion pesos in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Japan economy shrinks for first time since 2009 but tops forecast
summary: Japan's economy contracted by 4.8% in 2020, its first annual decline since 2009, but better than forecast due to a strong October-December performance. The contraction was driven by a resilient trade position and exports, with private consumption moderating due to a third Covid-19 wave. Government stimulus measures totaling $3 trillion helped support the economy. Despite this, analysts warn of a bumpy near-term outlook due to fresh virus restrictions and the postponed Olympics, which may not receive a boost from foreign spectators.

site_title: Market optimism lifts riskier currencies
summary: The US dollar fell to two-week lows as optimism over Covid-19 vaccine rollouts and a planned US$1.9 trillion stimulus package boosted riskier currencies and stock markets. The British pound broke the $1.39 barrier for the first time in nearly three years, while commodity currencies, including the South African rand, reached fresh highs.

site_title: Norway wealth fund wants firms to put more women on their boards
summary: Norway's $1.3 trillion sovereign wealth fund is urging global companies to increase female representation on their boards, setting a target of at least 30% female directors. The fund, which owns stakes in 9,200 companies, will begin applying pressure by voting against appointments to nomination committees with all-male boards. Companies without at least two women on the board will be scrutinized, and those that do not meet the target may face divestment or opposition at annual general meetings. The move aims to improve decision-making and legitimacy, and reflects Norway's earlier implementation of a 40% female board quota in 2003.

site_title: Asian central banks are ahead of the green curve
summary: Asian central banks are leading the global effort to promote green finance and develop green macro-prudential policies. The region is responsible for half of global greenhouse-gas emissions and is vulnerable to climate-related loss events. Countries such as Singapore, China, and Bangladesh have implemented policies to encourage green finance, including mandatory green finance regulations, green loans, and green bonds. The Networking for Greening the Financial System (NGFS) has 83 member countries and 13 observer organizations, with Asia accounting for 10 members. Asian central banks should maintain momentum and engage regionally and globally to address the existential threat of climate change.

site_title: Surge in Britain's renewable power exposes grid risks
summary: Britain achieved a record year for renewable power in 2020, with green energy exceeding coal and gas generation for the first time. However, this shift highlights the need for a broader suite of green technologies, such as nuclear, hydrogen, and carbon capture, to balance the grid when renewable sources are not available. A report by Imperial College London and Drax Group Plc emphasizes the importance of diversifying energy sources to meet strict climate goals.

site_title: Norway wealth fund tells firms to put more women on their boards
summary: Norway's $1.3 trillion sovereign wealth fund has urged global companies to increase the number of women on their boards, setting a target of at least 30% female representation. The fund, which invests in 9,200 companies worldwide, will start applying pressure by voting against nominations to boards with less than two women. Companies with "very good explanations" for low female representation will be spared, but those without a clear plan will face scrutiny. The move aims to improve decision-making and legitimacy, as well as bring a more diverse perspective to boards.

site_title: Take a leaf from World War II: beware the rise of the vaccine industrial complex
summary: A vaccine industrial complex similar to the military-industrial complex of World War II is emerging, where the supply of Covid-19 vaccines has been sparse and pharmaceutical companies' stock prices have soared. This phenomenon raises concerns about the potential for revolving doors between government officials and Big Pharma, leading to perpetual profits for vaccine manufacturers. The pandemic's duration will likely be maintained to justify current vaccine valuations, highlighting the need for scrutiny of the industry's interests and the government's role in regulating it.

site_title: Businesses should take digitisation track for long-term growth: GetApp
summary: Businesses in Singapore have largely shifted to digital operations since the pandemic, with 76% of over 500 surveyed companies operating mostly virtually. GetApp, a search engine for business apps and software, emphasizes the need for long-term digital strategies for growth.

site_title: UK kicks off first G-7 of post-Trump era
summary: The UK kicked off its presidency of the G-7, marking the first meeting of the group since the Trump era. Finance ministers, including US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, met to discuss fiscal stimulus, climate change, and digital economy taxation. The US proposed a $1.9 trillion spending and tax cut package, and Yellen encouraged other G-7 nations to "go big" with their own stimulus plans. The meeting also addressed climate change and biodiversity ahead of the COP 26 conference in Glasgow, and discussed support for vulnerable countries to aid the global recovery.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AEM Holdings received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange to list and quote new shares, a prerequisite for its S$99.7 million buy-out offer for CEI. AEM has reaffirmed its S$1.15 per share offer, allowing shareholders to choose between an all-cash option or a mix of cash and new shares. The offer price is a 26.1% premium to CEI's volume-weighted average price.

site_title: Young people's despair deepens as Covid-19 crisis drags on
summary: Young people in Europe are experiencing deepening despair and mental health crises due to the prolonged COVID-19 pandemic. Many, particularly those in their 20s, are struggling with loneliness, anxiety, depression, and suicidal thoughts. Mental health professionals warn that the crisis is being underestimated, with young people facing significant economic, social, and emotional challenges. In some countries, hospitals and psychiatric wards are filling to record capacity, and authorities are urging reopening of schools to combat loneliness. The situation is particularly dire for those from poorer households, who lack resources and support.

site_title: January's strong new home sales likely to be a one-off
summary: Singapore's private-home sales in January rose 32% to 1,609 units, driven by mega projects and low interest rates. The majority of buyers were locals, but foreign buyers also increased sharply. Analysts expect this surge to be a one-off, with no more mega projects planned for the rest of the year, potentially leading to lower sales in February. Median prices rose to S$1,778 psf, and foreign buyers accounted for 5.5% of total transactions. Consultants predict full-year 2021 sales to fall below 2020's 9,982 units, with estimates ranging from 8,000 to 9,000 units.

site_title: Indonesia takes another shot at Islamic banking with BSI
summary: Indonesia has launched Bank Syariah Indonesia (BSI), the country's first publicly-listed Islamic bank, after merging three state-owned syariah banks. The bank has consolidated assets of 240 trillion rupiah and 1,200 branches, aiming to attract new capital investments from the Middle East and Malaysia. BSI will focus on wholesale banking, digital banking, and innovative products for small and medium-sized enterprises, with President Joko Widodo tasking the bank to compete with traditional banks using digital technology. The move aims to broaden Indonesia's appeal to retail consumers and attract foreign capital.

images.alt_text: Although Indonesia has the largest Muslim population in the world, its syariah banking sector is relatively small compared to Malaysia and the Gulf states.

site_title: Pan-European consortium seeking big pharma partner for Covid-19 shot
summary: A pan-European consortium, including Leukocare, ReiThera, and Univercells, is in talks with a big pharma partner to support the late-stage development and manufacturing of its Covid-19 vaccine. The consortium aims to start a mid-stage trial this month and move to late-stage testing in May. Leukocare is seeking additional manufacturing capacity and help advancing its candidate through Phase III clinical trials. The company has secured 81 million euros in Italian funding and has a production capacity of 100 million doses per year.

site_title: More protests after Myanmar junta cuts Internet
summary: Myanmar's military junta intensified its crackdown on anti-coup protests, deploying extra troops and cutting internet connectivity. The country's leaders, Aung San Suu Kyi and President Win Myint, are expected to be questioned by a court via video-conferencing this week. Despite the military's efforts, protesters continued to take to the streets, with fresh rallies reported in Yangon and the southern city of Dawei. The international community, including the US, EU, and UN, has condemned the junta's actions, calling for the protection of civilians and an end to the crackdown.

site_title: Pandemic hastening the evolution of retail
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the evolution of retail, with people increasingly turning to online shopping for therapy, food, and entertainment. This shift is transforming the industry, with significant implications for property markets and developers. Meanwhile, other sectors, such as mortgages, condos, and real estate, are also experiencing changes. US mortgage rates have risen after five consecutive weeks of decline, while condo launches in Singapore and Manhattan rents have reached new records, signaling increased demand for luxury properties. The pandemic is driving significant changes across various industries and markets.

site_title: Providing smart security for a Smart Nation
summary: A Singaporean man survived a heart attack at a 24-hour gym after pressing a panic button, alerting a security guard via CCTV. This incident highlights the need for businesses to balance customer safety with high costs associated with 24/7 security guards. Ademco, a security technology company, offers a contract-based, pay-as-you-go managed security solution called VerifSuite, which enables businesses to trim costs without compromising security. The company's scalable business model and integration of technology with human security officers ensure cost efficiency and improved surveillance.

images.alt_text: As technology has been core at increasing productivity, the key is to be willing to adopt novel solutions to old problems, says Ademco's group managing director Toby Koh.

site_title: Dubai airport's 2020 traffic slumps 70% amid lockdowns
summary: Dubai International Airport reported a 70% slump in traffic in 2020 due to COVID-19 lockdowns, with 25.9 million travellers passing through, down from 17.8 million in the first quarter. The airport attributed the decline to a lack of confidence in international travel. Despite the slump, the airport acknowledged progress in protecting people's health, and expressed a need for more confidence in travel between countries.

site_title: Tech giants 'close' to payment deals with Australian media
summary: Australia is close to deals with tech giants Google and Facebook to pay for news content, with Treasurer Josh Frydenberg stating talks have made "great progress." The agreements could avoid the most severe parts of the proposed legislation, including arbitration. SevenWest Media, owner of 7NEWS and The West Australian, has signed a deal worth over A$30 million a year with Google's News Showcase product. Major media organizations are expected to follow, with the government considering amendments to the news media bargaining code before its presentation to Parliament.

site_title: Need an app? Japanese startup Yappli has a platform for that
summary: Japanese startup Yappli Inc has developed a platform for creating off-the-shelf apps, addressing the country's shortage of engineers and programmers. The company's shares have doubled since its Tokyo listing, reaching a market cap of $750 million, and has attracted investors with its software-as-a-service model. Yappli creates apps for international clients, including Under Armour and Toyota, and aims to expand globally in the next 3-5 years, capitalizing on Japan's growing need for digital transformation.

site_title: Jaguar car brand to go fully electric from 2025
summary: Jaguar, owned by Tata Motors, will transition to fully electric vehicles by 2025, investing £2.5 billion annually under its 'Reimagine' plan. The company aims to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2039 and will launch its first all-electric Land Rover model in 2024. Jaguar currently has only one all-electric vehicle, the I-Pace. The move follows increasing pressure from governments and consumers to reduce carbon emissions and adopt greener products.

site_title: Bitcoin's epic run winning more attention on Wall St
summary: Bitcoin surged to new heights, closing in on US$50,000 for the first time, as the cryptocurrency continues to gain traction in traditional finance. A week after Tesla's US$1.5 billion investment, Morgan Stanley's investment unit is considering a Bitcoin bet, and Canada approved the first North American Bitcoin exchange-traded fund. BNY Mellon formed a team for digital assets, and Mastercard will allow cardholders to transact in certain cryptocurrencies. Despite controversy and volatility, corporate endorsements are seen as key to Bitcoin's path higher, with JPMorgan Chase and others exploring crypto investments.

site_title: Regulators have no real need to take action in response to GameStop saga
summary: US regulators face no need to take action in response to the GameStop saga, where retail traders successfully executed a "short squeeze" against institutional short-sellers, making significant profits. This episode is a culmination of decades of market liberalization, which has driven lower trading costs and encouraged more retail investors to engage in short-term trading. Regulators cannot effectively curb speculating without restricting the rights of retail investors, who have co-existed with institutional players and play a vital role in efficient price discovery. Short-term disruptions will always occur, and the market will self-correct.

site_title: Croods beats Judas debut at US box office
summary: Judas and the Black Messiah, a film about the FBI's infiltration of the Black Panthers, debuted at US box office in the No 2 spot, earning $2 million in ticket sales. The Croods: A New Age led the box office with $2.04 million, while the film's streaming premiere on HBO Max was also seen as an attempt to maximize viewership during the pandemic, which has disrupted movie-awards season.

site_title: ESG maintains official 2021 non-oil export estimate; economists more optimistic
summary: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) maintained its modest forecast for non-oil domestic export (NODX) growth at 0-2% year-on-year in 2021, citing uncertainty in the global economy. However, the forecast for total merchandise trade was upgraded to 2-4% growth. Economists are more optimistic, with some expecting 2.3-4% NODX growth, driven by a global vaccine-fueled recovery and uneven economic growth. The Singapore economy is expected to contract 5.4% in 2020 and recover in 2021, with manufacturing and exports driving the growth.

site_title: Locked down and lonely, London Zoo fights for survival
summary: London Zoo, the world's oldest scientific zoo, is struggling to survive due to the ongoing lockdown and lack of visitors. The zoo, which has been open since 1828, is losing millions of pounds and has a £1.8 million budget shortfall. Despite efforts to inspire people about wildlife through online content, the zoo's chief operating officer says that nothing beats having visitors and experiencing a "great day out." The zoo's future is uncertain, with its multi-million-pound budget hole putting its survival at risk.

site_title: Vegan chocolate race heats up as Nestle plans rice-based KitKat
summary: Nestle is introducing its first vegan milk chocolate, KitKat V, made with a rice-based formula, as the company expands its plant-based offerings. The product will be available online and in select stores in the UK and other markets as a test run. The company aims to capitalize on growing demand for plant-based food, following similar moves by other major brands such as Lindt, Mars, and Cadbury. KitKat V took two years to develop, addressing the challenge of blending plant-based ingredients with cocoa and sugar for a creamy texture.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.65 points to 1,608.07, closing higher on Monday. The index saw 10.022 billion lots traded worth RM4.688 billion, with 864 gainers and 339 losers.

site_title: Copper hits highest level since 2012 amid concern over supplies
summary: Copper prices have surged to their highest level since 2012 due to concerns over a market deficit driven by tight supply and strong demand. The metal is expected to post an 11th monthly gain, with production guidance from top copper producers indicating a possible deficit of half a million tons. Rising inflation expectations, a falling dollar, and historically low stocks are also contributing to the price increase. Other base metals, such as nickel and tin, have also gained ground, with copper reaching a 0.9% gain to US$8,406 a ton on the London Metal Exchange.

site_title: Deliveroo to kick off London Listing in March
summary: Deliveroo, a UK food-delivery startup, plans to list on the London Stock Exchange in March, with a proposed initial public offering (IPO) on March 8. The company, which has received a boost from Amazon, is valued at over $7 billion following a recent funding round. Deliveroo has 140,000 restaurant partners and 110,000 delivery riders globally, and its app has 9.6 million downloads. The IPO comes amid a surge in IPO activity in London, with other notable listings including Dr. Martens and Moonpig Group.

site_title: Europe: Stocks make positive start to week
summary: Europe's major stock markets began the week on a positive note, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.9% to 6,649.31 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also gained, with the DAX up 0.4% and the CAC 40 adding 0.5%. This follows a rally in Singapore stocks, which reached a five-day high ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Timing Singapore's GST hike a catch-22 situation: tax analysts
summary: The Singapore government is facing a challenge in deciding on the timing of a Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike, which could impact the economy's nascent recovery. Tax analysts predict a possible hike in 2023, with some expecting it to come in late 2022 or 2024. A delay could lead to a Budget deficit, while a hike too close to the next General Election could be politically costly. The government is considering alternative revenue sources, such as property taxes or a "Netflix tax," to fund its increasing expenditures.

site_title: Britain considers legal fix to avoid clogging courts with Libor lawsuits
summary: Britain is considering introducing a "safe harbour" provision to avoid lawsuits related to legacy Libor contracts. The move aims to prevent clogging of courts and disrupting markets. The provision would allow users to continue using the outdated Libor benchmark until December, when it's replaced by the Bank of England's Sonia rate. This could help prevent mass class action claims and market disruption. The finance ministry plans to add the safe harbour provision to the financial services Bill currently being approved by parliament.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust to acquire five South Korean logistics facilities for 280 billion won
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) has acquired five South Korean logistics facilities for 280 billion won (S$334.8 million). The properties, valued at 290.7 billion won, offer high-quality building specifications and a prime location in the Yongin-Icheon area, generating an initial net property income yield of 4.5%. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to MLT's distribution per unit (DPU) and will increase the trust's gross floor area in South Korea by 40%.

site_title: South Korea cuts Q1 Covid-19 vaccination plan, restricts use of AstraZeneca shot
summary: South Korea has revised its COVID-19 vaccination plan, cutting its initial target from 1.3 million to 750,000 people in the first quarter due to delayed shipments from the COVAX vaccine-sharing scheme. The country has also restricted the use of AstraZeneca's vaccine on people aged 65 and older until more efficacy data becomes available. Despite this, South Korea remains committed to reaching herd immunity by November.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2% up on upbeat data, widening vaccine rollout
summary: Singapore shares closed 0.21% higher at 2,931.52, driven by record US stock highs, a hopeful vaccine rollout, and easing pandemic pain. The Straits Times Index advanced 6.04 points. Macroeconomic data showed Singapore maintaining a 4-6% GDP growth forecast for 2021, with improved estimates for last year's GDP. Key stocks like OCBC, Wilmar International, and Singtel led gains, while DBS fell 0.73%. The upbeat mood in financial markets is attributed to a robust risk-on tone and expectations of a large US stimulus package by mid-March.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's 2020 GDP contraction was better than forecast at 0.8%, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. The country maintains its growth forecast of 4-6% for 2021, with global vaccine distribution expected to boost recovery and export growth. Labour costs are expected to rise as wage subsidies wear off, while new private home sales surged 32% in January to 1,609 units, the highest monthly sales since 2018. The Straits Times Index closed 0.2% up, driven by upbeat data and the widening vaccine rollout.

site_title: US Capitol attack and impeachment trial could be deadly for the GOP
summary: US Capitol attack and impeachment trial could be deadly for the GOP, as the refusal of Republican senators to convict Trump sends a clear message that the GOP of old is gone, usurped by Trump. Despite initial predictions of Trump's demise, he has maintained a strong base of support, drawing in working-class Americans and rural voters. However, this has come at the cost of alienating traditional conservative voters, including business executives, suburban voters, and college-educated Americans. The Democratic-led Senate impeachment trial may be a strategic move to deter wavering Republicans from returning to the party, emphasizing the transformation of the GOP under Trump's leadership.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's stock market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with key events including NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer being 9.8 times oversubscribed and OCBC announcing the appointment of Tan Teck Long as its new CEO. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss, while London's Heathrow eyed higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Singapore authorities detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case and MAS and PBOC announced deeper cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: ERP charges to increase by S$1 at gantries along AYE, CTE and KPE
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore will increase Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) charges by S$1 at specific gantries along the Ayer Rajah Expressway (AYE), Central Expressway (CTE), and Kallang-Paya Lebar Expressway (KPE) starting Feb 22. The increases aim to manage congestion during peak periods. Drivers will face S$1 charges on AYE between 8.30am-9.30am, S$2 on CTE before Braddell Road between 8am-9am, and S$1 on CTE after Braddell Road between 8am-9am. Other ERP rates remain unchanged.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Achieving passive income and wealth growth amid Covid-19 (Ep 90)
summary: BT Money Hacks podcast episode 90 discusses strategies for achieving passive income and wealth growth amid the Covid-19 pandemic and post-pandemic recovery. Host Chris Lim is joined by Luke Lim, managing director at Phillip Securities, to explore concrete steps for rebuilding passive income, diversifying investments, and using the "barbell" approach. They also discuss views on single stocks, ETFs, and index funds. The episode aims to provide useful financial tips for listeners in Singapore, emphasizing the importance of consulting a financial adviser before making any investment decisions.

site_title: Heng warns of lingering fiscal tightness, urges 'prudent spending' ahead of Budget
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat warned that Singapore's fiscal situation will remain "tight" for several years due to a record budget deficit of S$74.2 billion in FY2020. He urged "prudent spending" ahead of the upcoming Budget, emphasizing the need for an "economically vibrant" and "fiscally disciplined" society. Heng also highlighted the importance of addressing climate change, sustainability, and supporting those with greater needs, while maintaining a growth forecast of 4-6% in 2021.

site_title: Rolls-Royce names former Deloitte partner Kakoullis as CFO
summary: Rolls-Royce has named Panos Kakoullis as its new chief financial officer, replacing Stephen Daintith who resigned last year. Kakoullis, a former Deloitte partner, will start on May 3. The move aims to help the aero-engines maker navigate the post-Covid-19 recovery, with the company facing significant financial challenges due to its reliance on flying-hours payment from airlines. Kakoullis brings experience in cost-cutting and simplification, having delivered transformational change at Deloitte.

site_title: DoctorxDentist owner disposes of entire stake in company
summary: DoctorxDentist's sole shareholder, Rose Chen Ah Keow, has disposed of all her shares and stepped down as director, transferring 40,182 shares to Gerald Guan Yew Kin and 9,818 shares to Tan Ah Tin. This move comes after the company faced controversy. Chen Ah Keow's decision marks a significant shift in the company's leadership and ownership structure.

site_title: Comfort reports 77 per cent drop in profit for FY20 as pandemic bites
summary: ComfortDelGro's net profit for FY20 plummeted 77% to S$61.8 million due to the pandemic, with revenue and group operating costs also declining 17% and 10.9% respectively. The company's operating performance was boosted by government relief packages. Despite this, ComfortDelGro remains hopeful for a gradual global recovery and plans to double down on digitalisation efforts to prepare for future opportunities. A final dividend of 1.43 Singapore cents has been proposed.

site_title: Ex-director of investment firm pleads guilty to rigging Gaylin shares to salvage reputation
summary: A former director of an investment firm, Tay Peck Gek, pleaded guilty to rigging the share price of Gaylin Holdings (now Amos Group) by 6.5% to 38.6% higher, between November 2015 and October 2016, to protect his reputation and preserve investor confidence. He manipulated the market by buying shares and placing buy orders to artificially prop up the closing price. Wong Leon Keat, a 45-year-old, faces 16 weeks to 20 weeks of imprisonment and a fine of S$40,000.

site_title: Drones seen capturing 30% of express delivery market by 2040
summary: Drones are projected to capture 30% of the express delivery market by 2040, according to a report by L.E.K. Consulting. The technology's cost-effectiveness and ability to navigate congested areas make it an attractive option for companies like Amazon and JD.com. However, challenges remain, including building sufficient scale and community acceptance. Drones offer the advantage of vertical takeoff and landing, requiring less space than traditional aircraft. Industry experts believe the drone delivery market could be worth billions of dollars, but significant hurdles must be overcome before widespread adoption can occur.

site_title: BNP Paribas to limit finance to customers using converted Amazon forest land
summary: BNP Paribas announced a corporate policy to fight deforestation in the Amazon and Cerrado regions, limiting finance to customers producing or buying beef or soybeans from land cleared or converted after 2008. The bank will only provide financial products or services to companies with a zero-deforestation strategy by 2025. This move aims to reduce the bank's contribution to deforestation and promote sustainable practices.

site_title: KPMG to end consulting services for South African listed clients
summary: KPMG South Africa will end its consulting services for listed clients on March 31, aiming to rebuild trust in the profession and avoid conflicts of interest. The move follows measures to clean up the firm's business after scandals in 2017, including a report on the nation's revenue service. CEO Ignatius Sehoole said the change will help restore trust, and the firm has worked with the Independent Regulatory Board of Auditors to improve audit quality. This makes KPMG the first major auditor to stop offering consulting services to listed clients.

site_title: Hot stock: Oxley up 4.4% after H1 profit more than doubles to S$34.1m
summary: Oxley Holdings, a property developer, saw its shares rise 4.4% after announcing a significant increase in half-year profits to S$34.1 million, more than doubling from S$15.7 million in the same period last year. Revenue also rose 25% to S$745.4 million, driven by contributions from an Australian subsidiary. The company's total unbilled contract value is about S$3.1 billion, and it has secured S$9.1 billion in sales for its development portfolio.

site_title: Red Sea coral reefs 'under threat' from Israel-UAE oil deal
summary: Israel's new oil pipeline deal with the UAE threatens unique Red Sea coral reefs, which could lead to a "next ecological disaster." The deal, signed last year, allows Emirati crude oil to be unloaded at the Eilat port, which is close to coral reefs that are home to a rich variety of marine life. Experts warn of possible leaks and spills, and activists are mobilizing to protest the deal, citing the risk of oil pollution and the impact on ecological tourism.

site_title: Need an app? This Japanese startup has a platform for that
summary: Japan's Yappli Inc, a startup that creates off-the-shelf apps for local clients, has seen its shares almost double since its Tokyo listing, reaching a market cap of about $750 million. The company's software-as-a-service model aims for a steady revenue stream and has attracted investors due to Japan's shortage of engineers and programmers. Yappli has created apps for international clients, including Under Armour and Toyota, and plans to expand abroad in the next three to five years, targeting the global app market.

site_title: Pfizer herd immunity study stymied by Iceland's wins over Covid
summary: Iceland's efforts to establish a nationwide study on herd immunity through Pfizer's vaccine have been hindered due to the country's low Covid-19 infection rate. Despite having 14,500 people vaccinated, Pfizer deemed the number of cases too low to support a study. Iceland's strict measures, such as social distancing and mask-wearing, have contributed to the low infection rate. Pfizer has expressed interest in accelerating vaccine deliveries in other countries, including Israel, which has seen high vaccination rates with minimal cases.

site_title: Japan's quake-rattled utility has adequate generation capacity
summary: Japan's Tohoku Electric Power has sufficient electricity generation capacity to meet demand after a 7.3-magnitude earthquake, despite knocking out several power stations. The company has restarted halted units and secured additional supplies to prevent a blackout. Wholesale electricity prices have fallen to normal ranges, and no incidents occurred at nuclear plants. The quake is believed to be related to greater seismic activity following the 2011 Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster. Tohoku Electric will continue to monitor the situation and consider measures to secure stable power supplies if needed.

site_title: Singapore maintains GDP forecast for 2021, but economy not yet out of the woods
summary: Singapore's economy contracted by 5.4% in 2020, beating the government's earlier estimate of a 5.8% decline, but analysts warn the recovery is not yet out of the woods. The economy is expected to grow between 4-6% in 2021, with a slowing and uneven recovery, and significant uncertainties in the external outlook. The tourism and construction sectors, which were severely impacted by the pandemic, are expected to take longer to recover. Analysts attribute the better-than-expected figures to the phased reopening of economic activities in the second half of 2020, but warn of elevated risks, including the emergence of new Covid-19 strains and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: External climate, border reopening key to Thailand's economic recovery: reports
summary: Thailand's economy contracted by 6.1% in 2020, its worst performance since the 1998 Asian financial crisis. External factors, including a record 18.8% decline in exports, weighed on the gross domestic product. However, domestic demand and private consumption supported the economy, driven by stimulus measures such as a domestic tourism package. To mitigate external weakness, Thailand's economy may focus on reopening its borders and leveraging external climate to drive growth.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end at three-week high on upbeat exports data
summary: South Korean shares rose to a three-week high, closing 1.5% higher at 3,147.00, driven by upbeat preliminary trade data showing exports surged 69.1% in the first 10 days of February. Chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix gained 3.2% and 4.8%, respectively, while LG Chem jumped over 3%. Foreigners were net buyers of 728.1 billion won worth of shares, and the won ended 0.51% stronger against the US dollar.

site_title: Surge in Britain's renewable power exposes grid risks
summary: Britain's renewable power reached a record high in 2020, exceeding coal and gas generation for the first time. However, this shift poses challenges for grid balancing, particularly on days with low wind and solar output. The reliance on renewables exposes the system to greater swings in power production, leading to higher grid balancing costs. To mitigate this, technologies like nuclear, hydrogen, and carbon capture are needed to compensate for periods of low renewable energy production. A broader suite of green technologies is required to balance the grid once fossil fuels fade away entirely.

site_title: Singapore made 759 data requests on 1,039 Facebook accounts in H1 2020
summary: Singapore made 759 data requests to Facebook for 1,039 accounts in H1 2020, exceeding the total from other Asean nations. Facebook complied with 72% of the requests, providing some data. The government's data requests more than doubled from the same period in 2019, with the country making more requests than the total from all other Asean nations combined.

images.alt_text: The government made 759 requests to Facebook for information covering 1,039 accounts from January to June last year, more than double the number over the same period in 2019 and exceeding the total from all other Asean nations.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes above 30,000, first time since 1990
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 1.91% to close at 30,084.15, surpassing the 30,000 mark for the first time in over three decades. The milestone is driven by hopes for business recovery, marking a significant turnaround from the financial crisis. This marks the highest close since 1990, as investors cautiously look to the future despite ongoing global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend rally on recovery bets, eyes on stimulus
summary: Asian markets rallied on Monday, extending a global advance as traders cheered the prospect of a huge US stimulus package and further falls in coronavirus infection and death rates. Tokyo broke through 30,000 points for the first time in 31 years, while oil prices surged to highs not seen since January. The US stimulus package is expected to be passed, despite concerns it could exacerbate inflation and force central banks to tighten monetary policies.

site_title: Top economists warn US against underestimating climate damage
summary: Top economists Joseph Stiglitz and Lord Nicholas Stern warn the US government against underestimating the financial impact of climate change, citing the need for a more accurate estimate of the social cost of carbon. They suggest the cost should be at least $100 per metric ton, compared to the Trump administration's revised estimate of $8. Without a new approach, they warn the US risks failing to meet its Paris Agreement goals and hinder President Biden's efforts to steer the country towards a net-zero economy by 2050.

site_title: Jollibee eyes 450 new, mostly overseas stores as it sees rebound
summary: Jollibee Foods Corp plans to boost capital spending by 22% to open 450 new stores, mostly overseas, as it expects a return to profit in 2021. The company will spend 12.2 billion pesos (S$337 million) this year, driven by its international business. Jollibee's sales and profit growth will start this year, following its first annual loss in nearly three decades, with a net loss of 11.5 billion pesos in 2020.

site_title: Arrest of young Indian activist, tied to Thunberg's movement, stirs outrage
summary: Indian opposition politicians and activists have condemned the arrest of 22-year-old climate activist Disha Ravi, accused of helping disseminate a document by Greta Thunberg promoting farmer protests. Ravi was arrested and taken to Delhi for questioning in a sedition case, which carries a penalty of life imprisonment. The arrest sparked outrage on social media and among farm unions, with Shashi Tharoor calling it an escalation of India's crackdown on free expression and political dissent. Ravi is a leader of the Indian arm of Thunberg's Fridays for Future campaign movement.

site_title: China cracks down on spurious, illegal, pricey vaccines
summary: China has arrested 70 suspects in 21 vaccine-related cases, cracking down on production and distribution of fake coronavirus vaccines, price gouging, and illegal inoculations. Authorities have seized over 58,000 doses of spurious vaccines, with one group making a profit of 18 million yuan by selling saline solution as vaccine. China's Supreme People's Procuratorate urges regional agencies to take swift action to curb such activities, as the country has largely controlled the pandemic with strict measures.

site_title: Indonesia says number of poor rises by 2.76 million due to pandemic
summary: Indonesia reported a 2.76 million increase in poor people, reaching 27.55 million (10.19% of the population) as of September 2020, largely due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The poverty line was defined as spending below 458,947 rupiah ($43.70) per month.

site_title: Dubai airport passenger numbers slid 70% to 25.9 million in 2020
summary: Dubai International Airport's passenger numbers plummeted 70% to 25.9 million in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Flight operations decreased by 51.4% and average passengers per flight fell 20.3%. Cargo handling also declined by 23.2%. The airport's recovery is expected to take years, as global travel restrictions continue to impact demand. Dubai's lack of a domestic flight network makes it vulnerable to international travel downturns.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi detained on remand until Feb 17, lawyer says
summary: Myanmar's ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi has been detained on remand until February 17, according to her lawyer Khin Maung Zaw. Initially expected to appear in court on Monday via video conferencing, Suu Kyi will now be held until the 17th, with her lawyer stating that the decision is in line with the law. Suu Kyi's lawyer declined to comment on the fairness of the proceedings.

site_title: Free-spending private equity firms set a record pace in Europe
summary: Private equity firms in Europe have set a record pace in dealmaking, announcing $29 billion in takeovers involving European companies this year, a 60% increase from last year. The surge is driven by the pandemic, cheap credit, and willing sellers looking to clean up their balance sheets. Soaring equity markets are also driving up prices, with big buyout firms such as Blackstone and CVC Capital Partners leading the charge. The industry has a record amount of unspent capital, and investors continue to pour money into buyout funds.

site_title: Japan assesses damage after earthquake struck near Fukushima
summary: A magnitude-7.3 earthquake struck off Fukushima, Japan, on Saturday, injuring about 150 people and cutting power to nearly a million households. No deaths were reported, and Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga confirmed that no incidents occurred at nuclear reactors. Six power units are offline due to the quake, with no restart timeline. The earthquake was an aftershock of the 2011 quake that led to a meltdown at Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear plant, killing 19,000 people.

site_title: UK rolls out hotel quarantine for 'high risk' country returnees
summary: The UK government has introduced mandatory hotel quarantine rules for arrivals from 33 "high-risk" countries, requiring a 10-day stay and multiple Covid-19 tests. The policy aims to stop new coronavirus variants from spreading, with arrivals found to have given false information facing up to 10 years in prison. The 11-night quarantine costs £1,750 and includes essential services and testing, with exemptions for hauliers, defence personnel, and diplomatic missions. The measures are part of the UK's efforts to ease lockdown measures and protect its vaccination programme.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on commodity boost, economic rebound bets
summary: Australian shares rose 0.91% to 6868.9, driven by a surge in commodity prices and hopes of a global economic rebound. Mining stocks, including Rio Tinto and BHP, gained 1.8% and 2.3% respectively, while energy stocks rose as oil prices hit their highest in over a year. Nearmap saw its best session in 7 years, and electronics retailer JB Hi-Fi jumped 86% on first-half profit. However, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.63% due to a three-day lockdown in Auckland.

site_title: Japan PM Suga sees currencies among most vital economic indicators
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga emphasized the importance of monitoring currencies as a vital economic indicator, citing his past efforts to manage currency volatility. This rare statement highlights Suga's continued focus on currency management.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga suggested on Monday that currencies were among the most vital economic indicators to monitor, in a rare reference to the matter by a premier.

site_title: Brexit causing supply problems for small UK manufacturers: survey
summary: A survey of nearly 300 UK small manufacturers found that new post-Brexit trade restrictions have caused price hikes and supply chain disruptions for two-thirds of respondents, with extended lead times on raw materials. The survey adds to existing concerns about the impact of customs checks on goods trade with the European Union. The disruptions have been immediate, with many manufacturers reporting increased costs and difficulties in sourcing parts and materials. The findings highlight the challenges facing small UK manufacturers in the post-Brexit era.

site_title: Asian real estate outlook 'optimistic' on Covid-19 recovery in 2021: report
summary: Asian real estate investments are expected to recover from the Covid-19 downturn in 2021, with "undemanding valuations" and growing demand for logistics and data centers. In Indonesia, major developers posted 14% year-on-year growth in pre-sales, while in Singapore, data centers are expected to benefit from healthy demand and supply dynamics. However, office rentals and retail space demand are expected to remain subdued, with a "modest recovery" in office rentals and "broadly stable" industrial rentals. Real estate players with strong balance sheets are best positioned to ride out the uncertainty.

site_title: Economic recovery bets push platinum to over six-year peak
summary: Platinum prices reached a six-year high of $1,283.75 an ounce, up 2.2% from the previous day, driven by investor expectations of an economic recovery boosting demand for the auto-catalyst metal. The rally is also attributed to concerns over South Africa's supply vulnerability to the Covid-19 pandemic and the push for greener policies by US President Joe Biden. Platinum may see a third consecutive annual deficit in 2021, according to Johnson Matthey, with further price targets extending to $1,330 and $1,577.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts positive on Lendlease Reit on expectations of domestic recovery
summary: Analysts from UOB Kay Hian, CGS-CIMB, and Phillip Capital have expressed positive views on Lendlease Global Commercial Reit (LReit) due to expectations of a domestic recovery in Singapore amid the COVID-19 vaccine rollouts. LReit posted a higher H1 distribution per unit of 2.34 Singapore cents and is trading at a 7% discount below its net asset value. Analysts expect benefits from redevelopment plans, including the Grange Road event space and Sky Complex, to attract more footfall and drive rental income.

site_title: Wage subsidies helped trim Singapore firms' unit business costs in 2020: MTI report
summary: Singapore firms' unit business costs decreased by 14.4% and 0.2% in manufacturing and services, respectively, in 2020 due to wage subsidies. However, these subsidies are expected to wear off in 2021, leading to a rise in unit labour costs. Despite this, overall unit labour costs defied productivity growth and shed 9.1% in 2020, while manufacturing saw the biggest fall in unit labour costs, dropping by 22.8%. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) report notes that costs such as utilities, fuel, and transportation may see upward pressure in 2021 due to higher global oil prices.

site_title: Trive, family foundation launch fund to provide 'tenacious' founders S$100,000 each
summary: Trive, a venture capital firm, has launched a philanthropy fund called the Tenacious Founders Venture Philanthropy Fund, providing Singapore-based entrepreneurs with up to S$100,000 in financial support. The fund aims to support 10 founders who have shown tenacity in running their businesses, helping them overcome financial resource constraints. The funding will come from redeemable SAFE Notes, which do not require equity participation from Trive, and encourages repayment upon financial positivity. The initiative is designed to support local entrepreneurs who have demonstrated resilience in their business operations.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 12.47 points, or 0.78%, to 1,611.89. The market saw 1.03 billion lots traded worth RM500.09 million, with gainers beating losers 510 to 202.

site_title: Google, Facebook nearing deals to pay for news, Australia says
summary: Google and Facebook are nearing deals to pay Australian domestic media companies for news, following talks between Australian Treasurer Josh Frydenberg and the companies' CEOs. The agreements could soften a regulatory standoff over planned legislation forcing the internet giants to pay media companies for news. If agreements are not reached, Australia's pay-for-news law may become a template for other jurisdictions. Google proposes compensating publishers through its News Showcase product, while the Australian government is willing to let the companies avoid paying for news snippets if media companies sign up to Google Showcase and Facebook News.

site_title: SolarWinds hack was 'largest and most sophisticated attack' ever: Microsoft president
summary: A US tech company's software was used as a springboard to breach thousands of companies and government offices, compromising emails at the US Treasury, Justice, and Commerce departments. Microsoft president Brad Smith calls it the "largest and most sophisticated attack the world has ever seen". The US government believes Russia orchestrated the attack, but Russia denies responsibility. Experts estimate it may take months to identify and expel the hackers, who accessed software used by up to 18,000 customers.

site_title: South Korea eases coronavirus curbs, to announce vaccine plans
summary: South Korea has eased some social distancing rules, lifting curfews for cinemas, internet cafes, and hair salons in the greater Seoul area, while keeping limits on private gatherings. The country plans to start its COVID-19 vaccination program on February 26, with healthcare workers and older residents among the first to receive the vaccine. Despite eased restrictions, authorities remain cautious due to ongoing infection clusters in the capital and neighboring areas, with Health Minister Kwon Deok-cheol urging caution to prevent a rise in infections.

site_title: Tesla to start making cars in India, targeting sprawling market
summary: Tesla is set to start making cars in India, targeting the country's sprawling market. The company has chosen Karnataka, a southern state, for its first plant, with the state's chief minister announcing the move. Tesla has been negotiating with local officials for six months and is considering car assembly in Bengaluru's suburbs. The company has already incorporated its Indian unit and registered offices in downtown Bengaluru. Despite the challenge of a relatively small EV market, Tesla's entry could disrupt India's auto industry, with the country aiming to increase EV sales and build out charging infrastructure.

site_title: Thailand's Q4 GDP contracts 4.2% y-o-y, less than expected
summary: Thailand's Q4 GDP contracted 4.2% year-over-year, less than the forecasted 5.4% drop, due to easing coronavirus curbs and recovered domestic activity and exports. Despite a 6.4% decline in July-September, the economy is expected to expand 2.5-3.5% this year, down from a previous forecast of 3.5-4.5%. The easing of curbs and recovery of exports helped mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Valentine's Day nudge gives NYC restaurants cause for optimism
summary: New York City's restaurant industry has experienced a modest increase in indoor dining after the first weekend of reopening at 25% capacity on Valentine's Day. Data from OpenTable shows a 75% decline in seated diners compared to last year, but the smallest decline since November. Some restaurants, like Chez Josephine, reported profitability, while others, like James, opted not to serve guests indoors due to safety concerns. The industry continues to face challenges, with over 110,000 restaurant closures nationwide since the pandemic began, and many owners are lobbying for federal aid.

site_title: UK house prices up again despite tax break deadline's approach: poll
summary: UK house prices rose 0.5% in January and February, defying expectations of a decline due to an expiring tax incentive. Rightmove's survey showed increased buyer demand, with 45% more website visits and 7% more purchases agreed, but new sellers dropped 21% due to home-schooling lockdowns. Despite this, the survey's director believes new buyer demand won't face a cliff-edge after the tax exemption expires on March 31.

site_title: Covid's puzzling decline in India sparks a shopping spree
summary: India has seen a puzzling decline in COVID-19 cases, with infection and death rates dropping nearly 90% since daily cases peaked in September. Despite concerns from scientists about low testing rates and underreporting, the trend suggests a real lull in the country's COVID wards. As a result, the economy is showing strong gains, with consumer confidence reviving and government economists predicting 11% economic growth for the financial year. Retail and consumer companies are also benefiting, with record profits posted by major companies. However, worsening poverty remains a concern, with an estimated 85 million people swelling the ranks of the newly poor.

site_title: January new private home sales surge 32% over December on mega project launches
summary: Singapore's private home sales surged 32% in January to 1,609 units, the highest monthly sales since July 2018, driven by mega project launches. This marks a 160% increase from January 2020, with 2,600 units launched for sale. The record-breaking sales also surpass the 3,489 units launched in March 2013.

site_title: Pandemic threatens New York's iconic yellow taxis
summary: The pandemic has severely impacted New York's iconic yellow taxis, with many cabs being parked in a lot near La Guardia Airport due to reduced demand. The area used to be filled with hundreds of cabs, but now only a few dozen remain. The decrease in yellow taxis is a result of the pandemic's effects on the city's transportation industry, leaving the future of these iconic vehicles uncertain.

site_title: Guoco Midtown to bring 30 thematic gardens into Singapore's CBD
summary: Guoco Midtown, a 3.2-hectare mixed-use development in Singapore's CBD, will feature 30 thematic gardens, including 10 publicly accessible ones, covering 3.8 hectares. The development, set to be completed in phases starting from 2022, will also include a 30-storey office tower, luxury apartments, and retail clusters. The gardens will feature over 350 species of plants, including rare and endangered native species, and incorporate biophilic design to conserve water and energy. The project aims to contribute to Singapore's Green Plan 2030 and create a more liveable and sustainable city.

site_title: Appeals court halts construction at ConocoPhillips Alaska project
summary: An appeals court has blocked construction of ConocoPhillips' $2 billion-plus Willow crude oil project in Alaska, halting plans for one of the biggest oil projects in North Slope history. The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals sided with environmental and Native plaintiffs who challenged the Trump administration's approval of the project. The injunction, issued Saturday night, bars ConocoPhillips from conducting winter gravel mining and road-building for the project while the lawsuit is ongoing, likely precluding construction until at least January. The project, which holds 590 million barrels of recoverable oil, could produce up to 160,000 barrels per day by 2024.

site_title: Bitcoin pulls back from brink of US$50,000
summary: Bitcoin fell 5.6% to $45,914 after reaching a record high of $49,714.66 on Sunday, amidst investors taking profits from a record-breaking rally that pushed the cryptocurrency close to $50,000. Ethereum also slipped 8% following the sell-off. The price surge was attributed to Tesla's $1.5 billion investment in bitcoin and growing legitimacy as an asset class. Bitcoin has gained 60% this year and 1,100% since its one-year low in March, with some analysts predicting a pullback and others considering buying opportunities.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin pulled back from a record high on Monday and other cryptocurrencies slipped, as investors took profits from a record-breaking rally that had pushed bitcoin close to US$50,000.

site_title: Icy weather chills Texas wind energy as deep freeze grips much of US
summary: A rare deep freeze across Texas knocked out nearly half of the state's wind-power generating capacity, with 12,000 megawatts out of service due to frozen turbines. The Electric Reliability Council of Texas issued an alert asking consumers to conserve power amid record-breaking energy demands. A federal emergency declaration was granted for all 254 counties in Texas, authorizing US agencies to coordinate disaster relief. The winter storm, which also affected much of the US, caused widespread disruptions and has been attributed to an Arctic air mass.

site_title: Quest Ventures joins S$200,000 seed round for celebrity video platform Sendjoy
summary: Quest Ventures has joined a S$200,000 seed funding round for Singapore-based celebrity video platform Sendjoy, which has grown from 20 to over 200 "sendjoyers" since its launch in June 2020. The funding aims to expand Sendjoy in Asia and offer a diverse pool of creators for international users. The platform has seen a surge in demand for personalized greeting videos during the COVID-19 pandemic, with most bookings for Christmas and New Year greetings. The funding will help Sendjoy reach more users and meet growing demand for its services.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Monday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 2,931.52 on Monday, driven by a strong finish from Wall Street and a lack of market-moving news over the weekend. The market saw gains from local stocks such as Thai Beverage, CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, and DBS, while Thomson Medical and Oxley Holdings also rallied. The Ministry of Trade and Industry maintained its GDP growth forecast for 2021 at 4-6% and non-oil domestic export growth at 0-2%.

site_title: Insurtech: Insurance reimagined in Asia
summary: The insurance industry is undergoing a significant transformation with the rise of insurtech, driven by digital acceleration and the shift to online sales. Despite initial challenges, insurtech companies are leveraging cutting-edge technology to maximize customer savings, improve the customer experience, and generate cost efficiencies. Traditional insurers face a battle to remain relevant, with two possible routes: investing in technologies to overhaul their business model or seeking strategic collaboration with insurtechs. Implementing digital technologies, such as AI, analytics, and IoT, can improve the accuracy of risk assessments and quotes, expedite underwriting, and enhance customer service.

site_title: Singapore banks latch onto electric-car market
summary: Singaporean banks OCBC and DBS are partnering with local electric vehicle (EV) solutions firm Charge+ to encourage the adoption of EVs in the city-state. OCBC aims to provide financing for EV charging infrastructure and implement digital payment solutions, while DBS is launching Singapore's first green car loan with a 1.68% interest rate. The partnerships aim to accelerate the "greening" of Singapore's land transport sector, with Charge+ targeting 10,000 EV charging points by 2030. The move is seen as a step towards reducing carbon emissions and promoting sustainable finance.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump on positive corporate earnings, Wall Street
summary: Australian shares rose 1% on Monday, rebounding from last week's losses, driven by positive domestic corporate earnings and Wall Street's record finish. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed to 6,877.10, with miners and financials leading the gains. Retailers such as JB Hi-Fi and Bendigo and Adelaide Bank surged. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 1% due to a three-day lockdown in Auckland after local Covid-19 cases emerged.

site_title: Apple approached Nissan over autonomous car project: FT
summary: Apple approached Nissan in recent months about a tie-up for its autonomous car project, but talks ended after disagreement over branding, with Apple requesting Nissan make Apple-branded cars. The discussions did not advance to senior management levels, and the contact was brief. The failure to agree on branding led to the talks faltering, according to the Financial Times.

site_title: Oil rises on fears of heightened tensions in Middle East
summary: Oil prices rose to a one-year high, with Brent crude up 1.1% to $63.09 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures up 1.5% to $60.33 a barrel. The rally was driven by fears of heightened tensions in the Middle East following a Saudi-led coalition's interception of an explosive-laden drone by the Iran-aligned Houthi group. Hopes for US stimulus and easing of lockdowns also contributed to the price increase.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose to their highest in more than a year on Monday, after a Saudi-led coalition fighting in Yemen said it intercepted an explosive-laden drone fired by the Iran-aligned Houthi group, raising fears of fresh Middle East tensions.

site_title: Tadashi Shoji picks sparkly metallics at virtual NY fashion week
summary: Tadashi Shoji presented a virtual autumn/winter 2021 collection at New York Fashion Week, featuring armor-inspired metallics and embellishments. The designs included silhouette-hugging dresses with fringed sleeves, puffed shoulders, and paillettes. Models wore the outfits against a fire-lit sky, with smoke billowing from underneath. Shoji aimed to inspire a sense of protection and strength with his collection, using a predominantly bronze and dark brown color palette. The virtual event, due to Covid-19 restrictions, marked a new way for designers to showcase their collections.

site_title: Japan's economic recovery slows as pandemic pain lingers
summary: Japan's economy grew 12.7% in the fourth quarter, exceeding expectations, but still slower than the previous quarter. The growth, driven by exports, marked the second consecutive increase and a slowdown from the 22.7% surge in the previous quarter. For the full year, Japan's economy contracted 4.8%, its first annual fall since 2009. The recovery remains fragile, with the government's new restrictions from January raising concerns of another recession. Policymakers face challenges in keeping the economy afloat amid the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: AEM gets SGX in-principle approval for new shares, affirms S$1.15 CEI share offer
summary: AEM Holdings, a Singapore-based electronics services provider, received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to list and quote new shares. This approval paves the way for AEM's S$99.7 million buy-out offer for CEI to proceed. AEM has reaffirmed its final offer price of S$1.15 per share, with an option for all-cash or cash with new AEM shares. The offer allows for various share allocation options, including 85% cash and 15% new shares or 70% cash and 30% new shares.

site_title: MTI maintains Singapore's GDP growth forecast at 4% to 6% for 2021
summary: Singapore's gross domestic product (GDP) growth forecast is maintained by the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) at 4-6% for 2021, despite a 5.4% contraction in 2020. The outlook considers progress in COVID-19 vaccine development and deployment, as well as regional economic recoveries. However, growth is weighed down by resurgence in infections in Malaysia and Indonesia, and significant global economic uncertainties. Outward-oriented sectors, such as manufacturing and finance, are expected to benefit from external demand, while tourism, aviation, and consumer-facing sectors are expected to experience slower and weaker recovery.

site_title: Grab's head of wealth management leaving: sources
summary: Grab's head of wealth management, Chandrima Das, is leaving the company for personal reasons, according to Grab Financial Group. Ooi Huey Tyng, head of Grab's payments business, is stepping down to take on an advisory role. The moves come as Grab continues to expand its financial services, including a recent win of a digital full bank licence in Singapore. Grab has a strong leadership bench and experienced leaders will take on the roles vacated by Das and Tyng, who led the launch of GrabInvest, a robo-advisory investment service.

site_title: China, Hong Kong, Taiwan: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Financial markets in China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan are closed on Monday for public holidays. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have recorded a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release. In other news, a popiah king has made a mandatory offer for the rest of PSC at S$0.40 a share, and eSIM platform Airalo has raised US$220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion. US stocks, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, have edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, following Wall Street gains. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.82% or 242.60 points to 29,762.67, while the Topix index advanced 0.66% or 12.73 points to 1,946.61. This comes after US stocks reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Elon Musk says he supports top dogecoin holders selling most of their coins
summary: Elon Musk expressed support for major dogecoin holders selling most of their coins, citing too much concentration as the "real issue". The billionaire's tweet comes as dogecoin prices surged due to retail investment and his own involvement. Tesla recently bought $1.5 billion in bitcoin and plans to accept it as car payment. Musk's comments follow a frenzy in retail investment, with shares of GameStop also increasing.

images.alt_text: Billionaire Elon Musk said on Sunday that he supports major holders of the meme-based digital currency dogecoin selling most of their coins, adding that he felt too much concentration in dogecoin was the "real issue".

site_title: Coca-Cola's European bottler sweetens US$7.70b offer for Coca-Cola Amatil
summary: Coca-Cola's European bottler, Coca-Cola European Partners (CCEP), has increased its takeover offer for Coca-Cola Amatil to A$9.93 billion (S$10.20 billion), a 6% hike from its previous offer. The new offer values Amatil at A$13.5 per share, making it Australia's largest deal this year. The Australian bottler backs the new offer, citing improved economic outlook and strong demand in Australia and New Zealand.

site_title: After Trump acquittal, Republicans see 'battle for soul of party'
summary: The US Senate acquitted Donald Trump in a historic second impeachment trial, voting 57-43 to convict him of inciting the January 6 assault on the US Capitol. Despite the rebuke, Trump hinted at a possible future in politics, and Republicans are grappling with a deep divide over his legacy. Seven Republicans joined all Democrats in the most bipartisan impeachment vote ever, but the party's future remains uncertain, with some calling for a "real battle for the soul of the Republican Party."

site_title: Stocks to watch: Oxley, Far East Orchard, Straco, Raffles Education, Penguin
summary: Several Singaporean companies reported new developments that may impact trading of their shares. Oxley Holdings' net profit for the six months ended Dec 31, 2020, more than doubled to S$34.1 million, while Far East Orchard and Straco Corp expect to report a net loss for FY2020.
