Raffles Education Corp's net profit jumped to S$35.7 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2020. Penguin International's net profit fell 16% year on year to S$9.3 million.

site_title: Preparing for Singapore's future
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 should prioritize environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, supporting the development of new capabilities in renewable energy and innovative technology. The budget should also focus on digital transformation, encouraging investments in new growth areas and new capabilities. Key areas include strengthening the innovation ecosystem, nurturing the new generation, and preparing a robust silver economy. Decarbonization, fintech, and manufacturing are also crucial, with measures to address the looming ageing crisis and enhance the population's skills in a rapidly evolving world. The budget should be expansionary and strategic, supporting critical sectors and restoring the economy's finances for the future.

site_title: Israeli study shows Pfizer vaccine 94% effective
summary: Israel's largest healthcare provider, Clalit Health Services, announced a study of over 600,000 Israelis who received the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine showed 94% protection against Covid-19. The study found a 94% reduction in symptomatic infections and a 92% decrease in serious illnesses compared to unvaccinated subjects. The results suggest the vaccine is highly effective in preventing serious morbidity and emphasize the importance of vaccination to the unvaccinated population.

site_title: Australia suspends travel 'bubble' with New Zealand as Auckland goes into lockdown
summary: Australia has suspended its quarantine-free travel bubble with New Zealand after three new community cases of Covid-19 were detected in Auckland, New Zealand's largest city. The cases are of the more transmissible B1.1.7 variant. As a result, all flights from New Zealand will be classified as "Red Zone" flights for 72 hours, requiring 14 days of supervised hotel quarantine for those arriving during this period. New Zealand has raised restrictions in Auckland to Level 3 and the rest of the country to Level 2, limiting gatherings and public venues.

site_title: Australia's Crown Resorts CEO resigns after damning inquiry report
summary: Australia's Crown Resorts CEO Ken Barton resigned after a damning inquiry report found him unfit for the job due to money laundering allegations. The report also criticized the company's governance and culture. Current chair Helen Coonan took over as interim executive chairman, while the board searches for a new CEO. The resignation comes after other executives, including Andrew Demetriou and two directors representing major shareholder James Packer, stepped down. The report called for sweeping changes to Crown's board and culture to address money laundering and governance issues.

images.alt_text: Crown Resorts chief executive officer Ken Barton resigned on Monday after an inquiry into money laundering allegations found he was not fit for the job, putting its gambling licence in jeopardy.

site_title: New Silkroutes Group focused on transforming into a healthtech play
summary: New Silkroutes Group, a Singapore-based company, is shifting its focus from an energy trading business to a healthtech play. CEO VicPearly Wong aims to drive the company's transformation, leveraging technology to improve healthcare services. The group currently operates 16 medical and dental clinics and has a manufacturing facility in China. Wong sees strong demand for healthcare due to rising incomes and an aging population, and plans to grow into a leading integrated healthcare provider in Asia. NSG recently signed a memorandum of understanding with Huawei International to develop an AI genomic analysis platform.

images.alt_text: "The pandemic has pushed our envelope in accepting technology in the archaic world of medicine; and that healthcare is no longer just a brick-and-mortar story," says Dr Wong.

site_title: Penguin International posts 16% drop in net profit for H2 FY20
summary: Penguin International, a high-speed craft builder, reported a 16% drop in net profit for the six months ended Dec 31, 2020, to S$9.3 million. Revenue increased 1.3% to S$69.28 million, driven by an increase in stock vessel sales. The company attributed the decline to the pandemic and depressed oil prices, which weakened demand for new vessels and depressed crewboat charter rates.

site_title: Biden calls on Congress to reform US gun laws
summary: US President Joe Biden called on Congress to enact "commonsense" gun law reforms, three years after the Parkland school shooting. He wants Congress to pass laws requiring background checks on all gun sales, banning assault weapons and high-capacity magazines, and eliminating "immunity for gun manufacturers." Despite polls showing most Americans support gun law reforms, successive US administrations have been powerless to pass legislation. Biden's administration will take action to end the "epidemic of gun violence" and make schools and communities safer.

site_title: Prince Harry, Meghan Markle expecting second child
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle are expecting their second child, with Archie set to become a big brother. The couple, who reside in California, released a photo showing Markle's pregnancy. This news comes after they quit frontline royal duties and have been involved in high-profile projects, including a Spotify podcast featuring Archie. The couple has also been involved in several legal cases against news outlets alleging invasion of privacy, with one case ending in a victory against Associated Newspapers in the UK.

site_title: Myanmar junta cuts Internet as troops fire to break up protest
summary: Myanmar's junta has cut internet services and deployed troops nationwide in an effort to quell anti-coup protests, following a demonstration in the northern city of Myitkyina where troops fired tear gas and live rounds. The UN and international ambassadors have called for security forces to refrain from violence against civilians, while the US has advised American citizens to shelter in place. The military has so far remained unmoved by international condemnation, with at least 400 people detained since the coup.

site_title: American Airlines to weigh refinancing of Treasury debt: sources
summary: American Airlines is considering refinancing its US$7.5 billion US Treasury loan with a new debt deal as soon as March, with Goldman Sachs sounding out potential credit investors for a US$7-9 billion deal. The airline may use its frequent-flier programme as collateral, similar to United Airlines, and is still deciding which government debt to pay off. With low interest rates, demand for higher-yielding debt has soared, and junk-rated companies are rushing to the bond and loan markets.

site_title: The Californians are coming. So is their housing crisis
summary: Idaho's economic success is attributed to low taxes and minimal regulation, but the state is also experiencing a surge in housing costs due to Californians fleeing high home prices. The influx of wealthier outsiders pushes housing costs further out of reach for locals, exacerbating the nation's housing problem. Studies show that homelessness has a distinct financial tipping point, and cities built around jobs reflect the country's inequality. Local governments are exploring ways to address the issue, including rewriting zoning codes and limiting single-family zoning, but the federal government's track record suggests that significant change may be needed to solve the crisis.

site_title: UK's virus jabs pass 15 million, as New Zealand orders city lockdown
summary: The UK's coronavirus vaccination program has reached 15 million doses, just over two months after its launch, with all top four priority groups fully vaccinated. Meanwhile, New Zealand ordered a city lockdown in Auckland after three family members tested positive for the virus. The European Union has agreed to fast-track approval of updated vaccines targeting new variants, while Germany partially closed its borders with Austria to slow the spread of contagious variants. Lebanon launched its vaccination campaign, and Japan approved its first coronavirus vaccine ahead of the postponed 2020 Olympics.

site_title: Trump's acquittal shows he is still a powerful force in Republican politics
summary: US President Donald Trump has been acquitted by 43 Republican senators in his impeachment trial, solidifying his grip on the Republican Party. Despite the acquittal, Trump remains a polarizing figure, with many swing districts viewing him as political poison. The party is now in a precarious position as it tries to forge a winning coalition in the 2022 elections for control of Congress and a potential 2024 White House race. Trump's influence on the party's direction and candidates remains significant, with some speculating he may run again in the future.

site_title: US dollar inches up as risk appetite returns; bitcoin retreats
summary: The US dollar rose 0.1% on Friday, its strongest level for the day, as risk appetite returned to markets. The dollar's outlook remains lower due to the US Fed's hold on interest rates and the expectation that it will be widely used as a funding currency, pushing its value down. Bitcoin fell 1.3% to US$47,356 after hitting a record high earlier in the week. The decline is attributed to the US banking group BNY Mellon's formation of a unit to help clients hold digital assets.

site_title: Australia's Seven West Media strikes partnership with Google
summary: Australia's Seven West Media has entered into an initial deal with Google to provide content to the tech company's News Showcase product. The partnership aims to counter Australia's proposed legislation requiring Google to pay publishers and broadcasters for content. Seven West Media Chairman Kerry Stokes stated that the deal ensures fair payment and secures its digital future. The agreement is subject to a long-form contract within 30 days, with financial terms not disclosed. This move comes as Google launches its News Showcase platform in Australia, marking a tactic against the proposed legislation.

site_title: Lanxess to buy Emerald Kalama for US$1.075b
summary: LANXESS agreed to purchase Emerald Kalama Chemical for US$1.075 billion, expanding its presence in North America. The German chemicals group aims to acquire a maker of specialty chemicals used in foods and cosmetics. Emerald, which employs about 500 people, reported US$425 million in sales last year. The deal marks American Securities' exit from Emerald Performance Materials and meets Lanxess CEO Matthias Zachert's goal of acquiring higher-margin specialty chemicals. The transaction highlights industrial companies' interest in mergers ahead of the reopening of developed economies.

site_title: Ex-UniCredit CEO Mustier said to be planning finance SPAC
summary: Ex-UniCredit CEO Jean Pierre Mustier plans to raise funds for a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) to invest in financial services, including wealth management and fintechs. He will work with former Bank of America executive Diego de Giorgi and JPMorgan Chase & Co. as an advisor. This follows a trend of former top bankers seeking to revive their careers through the SPAC trend. Mustier's departure from UniCredit came after a boardroom power struggle, and he will be replaced by former UBS investment banker Andrea Orcel.

site_title: Data centres a growing asset class within S-Reits
summary: Data centres are becoming a significant asset class within South-east Asia's S-Reits, driven by growing demand in the digital era. The region is expected to be a key driver in catapulting Asia-Pacific to the world's largest co-location data centre market by 2024, worth US$28 billion. Three Singapore-listed Reits, Keppel DC Reit, Mapletree Industrial Trust, and Ascendas Reit, have substantial data centre assets and have performed defensively in the stock market, averaging 20% total returns in 2020. The data centre market is expected to grow at a CAGR of 4% in Singapore from 2020 to 2025.

site_title: Silver lining for Singapore's struggling pros despite major golf events still on hold
summary: Singapore's professional golfers are facing a prolonged wait for major competitions due to the COVID-19 pandemic. However, businessmen Kelvin Chng and James Koh have stepped forward to help ease their pain by sponsoring a monthly tournament starting in March with prize money and appearance fees for participating players. The tournament aims to provide a silver lining for the 10 pros, who have been struggling to earn a living due to travel restrictions and health laws.

site_title: Strong start for Hang Seng Index in 2021
summary: The Hang Seng Index (HSI) has experienced a strong rally in 2021, up 10.1% year-to-date as of February 10. This follows a challenging 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic and government regulations. Key catalysts for 2021 include the vaccination process and economic recovery, as well as the new US administration. However, the HSI may face a pullback during the Chinese New Year holiday, with near-term support at 29,160 and a longer-term support at 26,360. A bullish scenario sees the HSI potentially reaching 2018 levels, but a correction back to 26,000 would require a significant global market downturn.

site_title: US bond markets expected to keep up frenzy this week
summary: US bond markets are expected to continue their issuance frenzy this week as investors seek higher yields to escape ultra-low interest rates. Last week, $14 billion of US junk bonds were priced, making it the second busiest of the year. With yields below 4%, more borrowers are expected to come forward after the long weekend.

site_title: Google's US$76m deal with French publishers infuriates many outlets
summary: Google has agreed to pay $76 million to 121 French news publishers over three years to end a copyright dispute. The deal, worth $22 million annually, was reached with the Alliance de la presse d'information generale (APIG), a lobby group representing major French publishers. The agreement follows France's implementation of a European Union law requiring tech platforms to compensate publishers for news content. Other French outlets not part of the agreement are pressing forward with lawsuits against Google.

site_title: MRT station retailers struggle as customers continue WFH
summary: Retailers at train stations in Singapore, particularly those in the Central Business District, continue to struggle with declining sales due to the ongoing work-from-home arrangement. Sales have dropped significantly since the partial lockdown last April, with some retailers experiencing a 60% year-on-year decline in sales. Despite the reopening of the economy, crowds have not returned, and rents remain unchanged. Transport operators have refused to lower rents, leaving retailers to bear the financial burden. The situation is expected to remain challenging until vaccines are rolled out, and working from home arrangements change.

site_title: Myanmar security forces fire to disperse protest at power plant in Kachin state
summary: Myanmar's security forces fired to disperse protesters outside a power plant in Kachin state, according to live footage on Facebook. Hundreds of protesters gathered, and security forces used a water cannon and shots to drive them away. The US embassy warned of military troop movements and possible telecommunications interruptions. The military regime has issued arrest warrants for veteran democracy campaigners and stepped up arrests of doctors and others joining a civil disobedience movement. The incident comes as protests continue nationwide against the military regime.

site_title: 146 hurt in Japan earthquake
summary: A magnitude-7.3 earthquake struck northern Japan's Fukushima region on Saturday, injuring 146 people and causing temporary power outages across the area. No deaths were reported, and energy companies reported no damage to nuclear power units. The earthquake occurred less than a month before the 10-year anniversary of the 2011 earthquake and tsunami that led to a meltdown at three nuclear units. Power outages affected over 830,000 households, but supply resumed in most areas by Sunday morning. Recovery efforts are underway in the region.

site_title: Nicki Minaj's father killed in hit-and-run
summary: Nicki Minaj's father, Robert Maraj, 64, was killed in a hit-and-run accident on Long Island, New York, on Friday. Maraj was walking on a road at 6:15pm when he was struck by a vehicle, which left the scene. He was pronounced dead on Saturday at a hospital. The investigation is ongoing, but a police spokesman confirmed Maraj was Nicki Minaj's father. Minaj, 38, was born in Trinidad and Tobago and has been nominated for ten Grammy awards.

images.alt_text: The father of rapper Nicki Minaj has died after being struck by a hit-and-run driver near New York City, police said Sunday.

site_title: Lockdowns are pushing London theatres into the abyss: Andrew Lloyd Webber
summary: Andrew Lloyd Webber warns that London's theatres are on the brink of collapse due to prolonged lockdowns. The composer, who owns seven West End venues, says the UK government's lack of clarity on reopening plans is crippling the industry, which contributes £10.8 billion to the economy each year. With fixed costs and no government support for freelance workers, theatres risk going bankrupt, threatening the livelihoods of actors and stagehands. Lloyd Webber urges the government to open up public spaces to prevent the industry's collapse.

site_title: Carlos Menem, Argentine leader who tamed inflation, dies at 90
summary: Carlos Menem, Argentina's former president known for taming inflation, has died at 90. The article does not provide further details on his death.

site_title: Macif emerges as favourite to buy US$3.6 billion Aviva France unit
summary: French mutual insurer Macif is emerging as the frontrunner to acquire Aviva Plc's insurance operations in France, with a potential deal worth over €3 billion. Macif, a local player, is seen as the most suitable buyer, while French private equity firm Eurazeo SE is also in the running. The sale is part of Aviva's plan to offload non-core assets and improve its struggling share price. Aviva has initiated talks with other potential buyers, including French insurance group CNP Assurances and Allianz, Germany's largest insurer.

site_title: Singapore keeps 0-2% non-oil export forecast for 2021, upgrades total merchandise trade forecast
summary: Singapore has maintained its forecast for non-oil domestic export (NODX) growth to slow in 2021, with a 0-2% year-on-year growth, despite continued uncertainty in the global economy. The country has upgraded its total merchandise trade forecast to 2-4% growth, up from an earlier forecast of 1-3%. This is attributed to improved oil prices, which may provide support for oil trade and total trade in 2021. The country's total merchandise trade fell 5.2% in 2020, but still better than the official forecast of -7.5% to -7.0%.

images.alt_text: Singapore is maintaining its forecast for non-oil domestic export growth to slow in 2021, though it has upgraded its forecast for total merchandise trade.

site_title: Indonesia awaits fiscal response to subdued economic outlook
summary: Indonesia awaits fiscal response as it emerges from its first annual GDP contraction since the Asian financial crisis in 1998. The country's official growth target for 2021 is between 4.5 and 5.5%, but analysts expect a subdued outlook due to public activity restriction measures and tax revenues that are falling short of the economy's potential. The government has raised its Covid-19 recovery budget, but these increases are likely to be funded through budget reallocations to maintain spending discipline. Analysts expect higher deficits to push public debt levels to up to 40% of GDP.

site_title: Homebuilders group in US calls for lumber supply increase
summary: The National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) is urging the Biden administration to increase lumber supply, citing record-high costs that threaten to price potential home buyers out of the market. US lumber prices have more than doubled since the middle of last year, forcing builders to delay construction starts and exacerbating supply shortages. The NAHB recommends removing import tariffs on Canadian lumber and urging domestic producers to boost output to ease growing shortages.

site_title: Sanofi's mRNA Covid-19 vaccine candidate will not be ready this year, says CEO
summary: Sanofi's mRNA Covid-19 vaccine candidate will not be ready this year, according to CEO Paul Hudson. Clinical trials are expected to start this quarter, with the vaccine potentially being approved in the second half of 2021. This news comes after Sanofi faced setbacks with its traditional Covid-19 vaccine, which showed insufficient immune response in older people, and a delay in launching a new vaccine candidate with GlaxoSmithKline. The development is a blow to Sanofi, which is also dealing with the emergence of variant strains forcing countries to accelerate their vaccination efforts.

site_title: Bankers crossing fingers for infrastructure bond push in Budget
summary: Singapore's infrastructure bond market may receive a boost in the upcoming budget as the government prepares to launch several major infrastructure projects, including green infrastructure like electric car charging points. Bankers are hoping for incentives for project owners to bring more bankable infrastructure projects to the market. The government has announced ambitious targets to phase out internal combustion engine vehicles by 2040 and plans to build 60,000 public charging points by 2030. Proceeds from infrastructure bond issuances could go towards upcoming public sector projects, redevelopment of districts, and rejuvenation of public infrastructure in mature HDB estates.

site_title: HSBC to target wealth management in latest strategic shift
summary: HSBC Holdings is shifting its focus to wealth management as a potential growth area, aiming to become one of the world's biggest wealth managers. CEO Noel Quinn announced the strategy, targeting Asia, the UK, and the Middle East for expansion. The bank currently oversees $361 billion of assets for wealthy customers, a fraction of UBS Group AG's $2.6 trillion. This move comes as HSBC navigates challenges, including the COVID-19 pandemic and political conflicts over its China operations.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The tanker and dry bulk market saw mixed performance this week, with the VLCC market plummeting but a floor seemingly found in the Middle East Gulf and West Africa. The Capesize market surged, with rates rising in the Pacific and South Brazil, while the Panamax market gained traction, particularly in the Atlantic. The Ultramax/Supramax market remained challenging, with rates under downward pressure. In contrast, Suezmax owners pushed rates up in the Atlantic, and Aframax rates recovered in the Mediterranean. The LNG market saw muted activity, with freight rates posting losses on longer Pacific routes.

images.alt_text: The LNG market softened further this week, with small declines across both spot and period markets as sentiment turned cautious.

site_title: Myanmar security forces fire to disperse protest at power plant in Kachin state
summary: Myanmar security forces fired on protesters outside a power plant in Kachin state, dispersing crowds with water cannons and shots. Hundreds had gathered near the occupied power plant in Myitkyina, prompting a military response. The US embassy warned of military troop movements and possible telecommunications disruptions in Yangon. The incident occurred amid ongoing protests against the military regime in Myanmar.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index up 0.3% or 74.04 points at 29,636.97. The Topix index also edged up 0.3% or 4.91 points. The market move comes amid concerns about overheating after a mixed close on Wall Street.

site_title: Ark Investment risks having too much money, not enough stocks
summary: Ark Investment Management, led by Cathie Wood, is at risk of having too much money, not enough stocks. The firm's ETFs have added US$7 billion and US$8 billion in assets in February and January, respectively, taking total assets to US$58 billion. This rapid growth may leave the firm unable to invest in enough stocks, a concern for thematic fund specialists. Wood's approach focuses on future-focused trends, with her firm already owning 10% or more of at least 24 firms.

site_title: Challenger's blowout FY2020 earnings a cautionary tale about big fiscal initiatives
summary: Challenger Technologies, a Singapore-based consumer electronics retailer, reported a 32% increase in earnings per share for FY2020, driven by government subsidies and Covid-19-related support. The company's revenue declined 18% due to pandemic restrictions, but its profitability soared due to "sundry income" of nearly S$5.1 million from government grants. Shareholders are benefiting from the Covid-19 subsidy, with the company announcing a higher dividend. The strong earnings report serves as a cautionary tale about the dangers of excessive government support and the need for a fiscal pullback as the economy recovers.

site_title: ExxonMobil stays the course on Singapore expansion but watching market closely
summary: ExxonMobil is moving forward with its multi-billion dollar expansion on Jurong Island in Singapore, despite the pandemic's impact on fuel demand. The company's newly appointed Asia-Pacific chairman, Geraldine Chin, stated that they are "watching the market closely" and will adjust production according to demand. ExxonMobil recently reported a loss of $22.4 billion in 2020 and has announced plans to cut greenhouse gas emissions. Chin emphasized the company's commitment to sustainability, citing its expertise in low-carbon solutions and plans to invest $3 billion in lower-emission solutions by 2025.

images.alt_text: "We are doing it (reviews) on a country-by-country basis, and function by business function basis, because we want to be very deliberate and think through this properly," says Ms Chin on potential layoffs.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Raffles Education Corporation reported a significant jump in net profit for the six months ended Dec 31, 2020, with a gain of S$28.1 million from the disposal of property, plant, and equipment. Revenue declined 7% year-over-year to S$48.43 million due to the pandemic and border controls affecting foreign students. NutryFarm International narrowed its losses to HK$0.96 million for the three months ended Dec 31, 2020, with revenue rising 12% year-over-year. Both companies plan to streamline and restructure operations to enhance efficiency and manage costs.

site_title: Speculative traders add billions to 'meme' stocks at new records
summary: Speculative traders have added billions to "meme" stocks, digital currencies, and cannabis companies, reaching all-time highs. US stocks have surged, with global equity indexes rising, while digital currencies have boomed to a market cap of over $1.4 trillion. Strategists at Goldman Sachs warn that the market's bull run may be vulnerable to disappointments, citing high valuations and increased volatility.

site_title: Hundreds of thousands protest in Myanmar as army faces crippling mass strike
summary: Hundreds of thousands of protesters in Myanmar took to the streets for a ninth day of anti-coup demonstrations, with the army facing a crippling mass strike by government workers. The strike has brought vital functions to a halt, including power plants, with protesters refusing to cut off electricity to carry out nightly arrests. The military has deployed soldiers to power plants, leading to confrontations with protesters. The civil disobedience movement, which started with doctors, now affects a swathe of government departments. The international community has condemned the coup, and over 384 people have been detained since the takeover.

site_title: ByteDance in talks to sell Indian assets of TikTok to rival Glance, sources say
summary: ByteDance is in talks to sell TikTok's Indian assets to rival Glance, amid efforts to resuscitate the short video sharing app banned in the country. The sale, initiated by SoftBank Group, involves four parties: SoftBank, ByteDance, Glance, and Indian authorities. The Indian government will require user data and technology to stay within its borders, and the sale could need approval from Chinese authorities. The move follows TikTok's ban in India last year, which led to the firing of hundreds of Indian employees and a significant decline in user base.

site_title: Clear crypto rules urgently needed as major firms embrace asset: SEC official
summary: A top SEC official, Hester Peirce, urges the need for clear crypto regulations as major companies like Tesla, BNY Mellon, and Mastercard increasingly adopt the alternative asset class. The "Crypto Mom" cited the recent "Reddit Rally" in GameStop Corp and other stocks, but emphasized that policy conclusions should not be drawn from the event. She believes a regulatory framework is crucial to allow crypto assets to thrive without fear of breaking the law, particularly with Tesla's $1.5 billion investment in Bitcoin and other companies' moves to integrate digital assets.

site_title: London office investment to cross £10b in 2021
summary: London's office real estate market is expected to see a surge in foreign investment, potentially reaching £10 billion in 2021, according to Knight Frank. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic and Brexit concerns, investors remain optimistic about London's commercial market, citing its safe haven status and liquidity benefits. However, the pandemic has led to a decline in office rents, with occupier demand being deferred rather than eliminated, and developers face challenges in securing finance and meeting environmental requirements.

images.alt_text: London is viewed as a safe haven with relative liquidity, transparency, familiarity, time-zone and language benefits, says Knight Frank, and investors are keen to buy into the inevitable recovery early.

site_title: Indonesia to give tax incentives for sales of some cars
summary: Indonesia plans to offer temporary tax incentives for the sale of certain cars from March to May, removing a luxury tax on sedans and two-wheel drive cars with engine power below 1,500 cc. The incentives will include a 50% discount for luxury tax payments in the next three months, followed by a 25% discount in the subsequent three months. The move aims to boost the automotive industry, which has been impacted by the pandemic, and is expected to increase production by 81,752 units.

images.alt_text: Indonesia will temporarily remove a luxury tax on sales of some cars to bolster its automotive industry, which has been badly hit by mobility restrictions to contain the coronavirus epidemic, its economic ministry said.

site_title: Will money laundering laws end art world's culture of secrecy?
summary: Regulators in Europe and the US are cracking down on the art world's culture of secrecy, requiring art and antiquities dealers to record the actual beneficiaries of their sales for the first time. This comes after high-profile cases of money laundering, such as those involving Russian oligarchs and a Malaysian fugitive. The new anti-money laundering rules aim to prevent exploitation by criminals, but some dealers fear they will be forced to reveal sensitive information and compromise their business. The art market is expected to adapt to the new regulations, potentially incorporating technology to ensure privacy while keeping a traceable log of purchases.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge lower as US-China worries resurface
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% to 6,828.90, weighed by energy and gold stocks, following US President Joe Biden's comments on China, which sparked concerns about strained relations. Biden's warning that China is "poised to eat our lunch" led to a decline in appetite for risky assets. The S&P/ASX 200 index was set to mark a weekly loss, following a 0.1% drop on Thursday.

site_title: Biden, reflecting on Senate acquittal of Trump, says 'democracy is fragile'
summary: US President Joe Biden stated that the Senate's acquittal of former President Donald Trump for inciting an insurrection is a reminder that democracy is fragile. The Senate fell short of the two-thirds majority needed to convict Trump, despite 57 senators voting to find him guilty. Biden emphasized the importance of defending the truth and noted the bipartisan vote by the House of Representatives to impeach Trump. The acquittal serves as a warning that democracy requires constant vigilance and collective effort to maintain its integrity.

site_title: Asia: Shares stuck in holiday lull, bitcoin powers higher
summary: Asian shares hovered near a record high on Friday, influenced by mixed US economic data. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific index fell 0.03% and Australian stocks lost 0.3%, while Tokyo shares retreated from 30-year highs. US futures were off 0.1%. The Asia-Pacific market's recent rally is attributed to bitcoin's surge, which has driven investor confidence. Despite mixed data, the region's stocks remain near record highs, indicating investor optimism.

site_title: New Zealand plans to start Covid-19 vaccinations next week
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced the country's Covid-19 inoculation program will start on February 20, bringing forward the expected start date due to early receipt of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. The program aims to vaccinate the country's 5 million people, with initial focus on border workers, healthcare workers, and high-risk individuals. Ardern expressed hope that vaccine efficacy would lead to eased border restrictions and improved travel between New Zealand and Australia, but noted that the initial impact would be minimal.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise with tech stocks in the lead
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Thursday, on track for a near 4% gain in February, driven by strong performances from tech stocks. The Stoxx 600 index is 5% away from its peak in February 2020. Investors closely watched US stimulus bill progress and earnings reports for clues on business recovery. Technology stocks surged, with the Nasdaq near all-time highs, while the banks sector declined due to Germany's Commerzbank's loss. Analysts expect moderate growth in corporate earnings this year, but warn of fading stimulus effects next year.

site_title: Man City eye Spurs revenge as Liverpool face Leicester test
summary: Manchester City seeks revenge against Tottenham as they face Jose Mourinho's men on Saturday, following their 4-1 loss to City at Anfield last weekend. City, led by Pep Guardiola, has not tasted defeat in 22 games and aims to secure a third league title in four years. Meanwhile, Liverpool, struggling with a 22-point swing in form, faces a tough test against Leicester, who are determined to avoid last season's mistakes and maintain their third-place position.

site_title: Restaurant, bar in Robertson Quay added to list of places visited by Covid-19 patients
summary: Restaurant Beast & Butterflies at M Social Singapore and Bar Bar Black Sheep in Robertson Quay have been added to the list of places visited by Covid-19 patients while they were still infectious, according to the Ministry of Health (MOH). The MOH is monitoring the health of individuals who visited these establishments for at least 30 minutes. This move aims to prevent potential transmission and protect public health.

site_title: Chinatown Complex shop owner and son among three new Covid-19 community cases
summary: A 66-year-old Chinatown Complex shop owner and his 32-year-old son, who works at Swensen's in Changi Airport Terminal 3, are among three new Covid-19 community cases in Singapore. The father developed symptoms on January 28 and was detected through community surveillance testing, while his son tested positive after showing symptoms on February 3. Both were brought to the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) after testing positive. The Ministry of Health (MOH) urged people to be socially responsible, see a doctor immediately, and stay at home to reduce transmission risks.

site_title: Nutryfarm International posts narrower loss in Q1 FY21
summary: NutryFarm International reported a narrower loss of HK$0.96 million (S$0.16 million) for Q1 FY21, down from a net loss of HK$3.14 million a year ago. Revenue rose 12% year-on-year to HK$14.69 million, driven by its subsidiary NFC. The company has restarted economic activities in China and is exploring ways to turn its business around. It has also incorporated a subsidiary in Singapore, which has signed agreements worth 962 million yuan (S$197.36 million) to sell fresh durians to major Chinese fruit importers.

site_title: Oil eases after record rally as Opec, IEA fret about demand
summary: Oil prices eased after a record rally, with Brent futures falling 0.5% to $61.14 a barrel and US WTI crude falling 0.8% to $58.24. The Opec and IEA expressed concerns about a slow demand recovery due to renewed lockdowns and new coronavirus variants. Oil supply cuts by Opec and allies are expected to be unwound in the second half of the year, and increased output in Argentina and Libya may also pressure prices.

site_title: US slaps sanctions on Myanmar junta leaders, warns of more action
summary: The US has imposed sanctions on the leaders of Myanmar's junta and several gem companies, targeting 10 current or former military officials. The sanctions block US assets and transactions with the individuals, who are responsible for the February 1 coup. The move warns that further action will be taken if the military uses violence against protesters. General Min Aung Hlaing, the junta chief, is already under US sanctions due to his role in the brutal campaign against the Rohingya minority. The sanctions are a response to the military's actions, which have led to widespread protests and unrest.

site_title: Gold dips 1% as US dollar steadies, platinum eases off six-year peak
summary: Gold fell 1% to $1,826.00 per ounce, while platinum eased 0.4% to $1,236.76 per ounce, after a sharp US dollar decline eased profit-taking. Platinum reached a six-year high due to strong investment demand and tight market conditions, with analysts expecting further upside driven by the automobile sector. Palladium fell 0.7% to $2,339.32. Citi Research predicts prices will rise to $1,300 an ounce by the end of the year.

site_title: US dollar falls vs some currencies; bitcoin climbs to record peak
summary: The US dollar fell against some major currencies, including the euro, due to weaker-than-expected jobless claims data and a dovish Federal Reserve message. Bitcoin reached a record peak of $48,481.45, rising 6.3% after BNY Mellon announced its support for cryptocurrencies. The dollar index was down slightly, with the euro up 0.1% against the US dollar. Analysts attribute the dollar's weakness to interest rate expectations and a potential shift in the currency's role as a safe haven.

site_title: Tokyo 2020 chief to resign, but successor choice criticised
summary: Tokyo 2020 Olympics chief Yoshiro Mori is expected to resign over a sexism row, following a firestorm of criticism over comments that women talk too much in meetings. Mori's reported choice for a successor, 84-year-old sports administrator Saburo Kawabuchi, has also raised eyebrows, with some questioning the legitimacy of the appointment. The move comes with the Games just five months away, amid public doubts about the virus-postponed event, with around 80% of Japanese polled backing a further postponement or cancellation.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq end at records as Bumble takes off
summary: US stocks closed at fresh records on Thursday, driven by a surge in online dating platform Bumble's market debut and a boost in jobless claims data. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.4% to 14,025.77, while the S&P 500 climbed 0.2% to a new high. Bumble's IPO raised $2.2 billion, while Uber Technologies fell 4% due to a hefty loss. Other stocks, such as Kraft Heinz and Hormel Foods, also saw significant price movements.

site_title: State-owned Cambodian electricity company shortens contract with Asiatic Group subsidiary
summary: Cambodian state-owned electricity supplier Electricite Du Cambodge (EDC) has shortened a power purchase agreement with Colben Energy, an indirect 85% subsidiary of Asiatic Group, by bringing forward the term to August 31. The agreement, originally set to end April 30, 2022, was extended three times based on goodwill and good faith. The move is part of a broader effort to adjust the terms of the agreement, which listed a minimum electrical amount of 65% of contracted capacity. The exact reasons for the change are not specified.

site_title: Dine in on Valentine's Day
summary: For a romantic Valentine's Day dinner at home, consider a three-course meal featuring Braised Taro in its Braising Sauce, Spaghetti with Anchovy Colatura and Butter, and White Peach Tart. Chefs JP Fiechtner, Mirko Febbrile, and Maxine Ngooi share recipes using dashi, sake, mirin, and other ingredients to create an intimate and delicious meal. Each dish can be prepared ahead of time, allowing for a stress-free and memorable evening with loved ones.

site_title: PTT Oil surges in Bangkok debut after US$1.57b IPO
summary: PTT Oil & Retail Business, Thailand's largest energy company, raised US$1.57 billion in its debut IPO, becoming the country's biggest initial public offering in almost a year. The company's shares surged as much as 50% to 27 baht in their trading debut, with over 500,000 retail investors subscribing to the offering. This marks the third mega Thai IPO in the past year, following Central Retail's US$2.5 billion offering and SCG Packaging's US$1.3 billion share sale.

site_title: Oil drops after strong rally, talk of more supply
summary: Oil prices dropped 0.7% to $61.07 a barrel, after reaching a 2020 high on Wednesday, amid speculation that producers like Saudi Arabia may increase output. Crude stocks fell 6.6 million barrels to 469 million, their lowest since March. Analysts believe prices have risen too far, and producers may respond by reducing output. The decline follows a nine-session gain for Brent crude, its longest sustained period since January 2019.

site_title: More spend on CNY takeaways this year, say restaurants
summary: Singaporean hotels and restaurants are experiencing high demand for Chinese New Year bookings and takeaway orders due to travel restrictions and social distancing rules. Yanting at St Regis Singapore reported a 100% occupancy on Chinese New Year and its Eve, with all takeaway slots fully booked. This trend is expected to continue throughout the 15-day Chinese New Year period.

site_title: Oxley reports higher profit for H1 2021
summary: Oxley Holdings reported a 115% increase in net profit to S$34.12 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2020, driven by higher revenue and lower finance costs. Revenue rose 25% to S$745.35 million, with contributions from a subsidiary in Australia. The group's earnings per share increased to 0.81 Singapore cent, and its total unbilled contract value stood at about S$3.1 billion. However, development projects are expected to fall behind target completion dates due to the pandemic, and the company's hotels generated positive cash flows from operations.

site_title: UK house prices rise in January despite buyers staying away
summary: UK house prices rose in January despite a third national coronavirus lockdown, according to a Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors survey. London was the only region to see prices decline, while other areas experienced a short supply of suitable properties. Real estate agents reported demand from buyers seeking to take advantage of a £15,000 tax cut before its expiry on March 31. However, buyers and sellers were reluctant to conduct in-person viewings due to high infection rates and homeschooling. The easing of lockdown restrictions and end of tax breaks are expected to impact the market.

site_title: SPH pays tribute to newspaper vendors
summary: SPH pays tribute to newspaper vendors who were severely impacted by the COVID-19 "circuit breaker" in April 2020, when many migrant workers and senior citizens were unable to deliver papers, forcing vendors like Selvarani Chidambaram to enlist family members for help. To alleviate the situation, SPH's circulation department introduced letterbox deliveries, and operations have since returned to normal with vendors now having about 15 workers. SPH has produced a video tribute to honor the vendors' hard work and contribution.

site_title: Big Tech shares reach new highs despite upcoming regulations
summary: Big tech shares, including Amazon, Apple, Netflix, and Google, reached new highs despite potential upcoming regulations, taxes, and anti-monopoly measures. Investors believe these measures will not significantly impact the massive profits of these companies. The US House Judiciary Committee has proposed ways to reduce their influence and use US anti-trust laws to make the digital world more competitive. Meanwhile, UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak is considering an online tax on companies like Amazon to reduce borrowing and support businesses during the pandemic.

site_title: How tax can help anchor Singapore as the startup hub of choice
summary: Singapore aims to enhance its startup ecosystem by introducing tax credits for research and development (R&D) activities, a move that could help the country remain competitive as a startup hub. Currently, Singapore has a tax programme focused on investors, but it lacks a specific programme for startups. R&D tax credits could supplement R&D budgets, regardless of the company's tax-paying status, benefiting cash-constrained startups. The government is also exploring other enhancements, such as preferential individual income tax regimes for tech talent and expanded double tax deduction (DTD) for R&D costs.

site_title: CNY snack sellers adapt to Covid curbs, reap online sales
summary: Singaporean retailers are adapting to the Covid-19 pandemic by shifting to online sales, particularly for Chinese New Year (CNY) festivities. Lim Chee Guan, a popular bak kwa retailer, is selling its products exclusively online for the first time. This trend is also attributed to the ongoing digitalization of the food industry. As a result, gift exchanges have increased to compensate for reduced in-store visits, with online sales expected to play a significant role in the industry's growth.

site_title: Owner of London's Westfield shopping centres slashing US exposure to near zero
summary: Unibail-Rodamco-Westfield, the owner of London's Westfield shopping centers, plans to cut its US exposure to near zero and complete the disposal of its remaining European assets worth 3.2 billion euros by the end of 2022. The company's new management team aims to tackle long-term debt issues amid the financial fallout of the coronavirus lockdowns. The US accounted for 28% of the group's net rental income in 2019, but the new CEO, Jean-Marie Tritant, says the exposure will be minimal, if not zero. The company will retain its two London Westfield malls.

site_title: Promising debut by Sommer
summary: Lewis Barker, a sous chef, has made his debut as head chef at Sommer #01-02 in Singapore's Marina Boulevard. The restaurant offers modern European cuisine with Japanese fine dining influences, showcasing Barker's polished creations with a strong balance and precision. While some moments of service and complexity were noted, the overall experience was commendable, with standout dishes like smoked mackerel "toast" and langoustine with roasted eringi mushroom broth. The Experience menu (S$228) and luncheon options (S$68) offer good value. Sommer is a promising debut, with Barker's technical execution and meticulous detail making the menu memorable.

site_title: Social commerce is here to stay. Get on board this train
summary: Social commerce is becoming increasingly popular, with large social media platforms such as Facebook and WeChat expanding their e-commerce capabilities. Digital payments are a key component of social commerce, allowing brands to reach a wider audience and monetize their user bases. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the growth of digital payments, with Asia-Pacific countries seeing significant growth in digital payment methods. To succeed in social commerce, brands must adopt an agnostic approach to digital payments, leveraging partnerships with local payment methods to cater to diverse consumer preferences.

site_title: Foreign banks lead retreat from Hong Kong's pricey office market
summary: International banks in Hong Kong are relinquishing office space to cut costs, threatening the city's expensive office market. Lenders such as BNP Paribas, Standard Chartered, and UBS Group have given up floors in their headquarters, following a wider trend among multinational firms. This trend, driven by the pandemic, is expected to continue, with forecasters predicting a 7% fall in office rents in 2021 and a vacancy rate for premium office buildings reaching its highest since 2004.

site_title: Jumbo taps hawker scene to diversify income and adapt to new dining habits
summary: Jumbo Group, a Singapore-based F&B player, is expanding into the local hawker scene to diversify income and adapt to changing dining habits amid the pandemic. The company acquired a 75% stake in Kok Kee Wanton Noodle for S$2.1 million in November 2020, its first inorganic expansion since 2015. This move aims to tap into the lower operating costs and wider market segment of the hawker scene, potentially accelerating its breakthrough into the local mass segment.

site_title: Decorating for luck
summary: Genevieve Chang and her family are adapting their Chinese New Year celebrations to pandemic restrictions, prioritizing traditional activities like spring cleaning and decorating their home. The family has decorated their three-story home with auspicious symbols, couplets, and lanterns to welcome good fortune. They will also follow traditional practices such as not sweeping the floor and staying up late to honor their elders. Despite the limitations, Chang is committed to keeping the family's traditions alive, including a vegetarian meal and a reunion dinner on Chinese New Year Eve.

site_title: Myanmar now a much riskier destination for foreign firms after military coup
summary: Myanmar has become a much-riskier destination for foreign firms following the February 1 military coup, with some multinationals pulling out or suspending operations. The country is entering a period of heightened political uncertainty, leading to concerns about future investments. The coup has heightened tensions, and more firms are likely to follow suit, citing the increased risk. The situation is expected to remain uncertain, impacting potential investments and economic growth in the region.

site_title: UK taxes developers to fund safer apartment blocks, but critics say it's not enough
summary: The UK government has announced an additional £3.5 billion to remove cladding from apartment blocks in England, following the 2017 Grenfell Tower fire that killed 72 people. A new tax on developers will raise £2 billion over the next decade to cover the costs, with grants and loans available for leaseholders in affected buildings. However, critics argue that the plan does not go far enough, as leaseholders in smaller buildings will still be responsible for the costs, potentially saddling them with debt for 30 years.

site_title: New Covid wave drives Malaysia economy to worst showing since 1998
summary: Malaysia's economy contracted 3.4% in Q4 2020, its third straight contraction and worst annual performance since the Asian financial crisis in 1998. The country's GDP shrunk 5.6% for the full year 2020, with the central bank governor saying monetary policy remains appropriate but room to provide further support if needed. The government's decision to ease lockdown restrictions aims to balance protecting lives with ensuring economic activity continues, with the economy expected to shrink more sharply this quarter due to a second wave of COVID-19 infections.

images.alt_text: The second wave of infections will see the economy shrink much more sharply this quarter, says economist Alex Holmes, adding that even if the current lockdown is not extended beyond Feb 18, high numbers of infections mean social distancing will remain a drag for months to come.

site_title: Elon Musk's effect on crypto world shows how irrational markets are
summary: Elon Musk's tweets have significantly impacted the cryptocurrency market, particularly with his endorsement of Dogecoin and Tesla's investment in bitcoin. In recent weeks, Musk's tweets boosted Dogecoin's value to over $10 billion, a record high, and contributed to a 900% increase in its value since late January. Similarly, Tesla's $1.5 billion bitcoin investment and plans to accept bitcoin for payments led to a 14% increase in bitcoin's price to a new record of over $44,000. The article concludes that Musk's influence on the crypto world highlights the irrational nature of the market, where speculation and wild behavior can lead to significant price fluctuations.

site_title: Biden talks of 'unfair economic practices' in call with Xi
summary: US President Joe Biden discussed "coercive and unfair economic practices" with Chinese leader Xi Jinping in their first phone call. Biden expressed concerns over human rights abuses in Xinjiang, restrictions on freedoms in Hong Kong, and increasingly assertive actions in the region, including toward Taiwan. The two leaders also exchanged views on countering Covid-19, climate change, and preventing weapons proliferation.

site_title: Clubhouse mania drove US$6b to loss-making Chinese startup Agora
summary: Agora Inc., a loss-making Shanghai startup, has seen its stock price surge over 150% after Clubhouse, a popular audio-chat app, began using its software development kit (SDK) in February. The SDK allows developers to build real-time voice and video functions within applications. Agora's involvement with Clubhouse has raised concerns about the potential for Chinese surveillance, as Beijing requires companies to hand over data on request and can compel them to spy on behalf of the government. The company's customisable tools run on users' devices, but it claims not to store end-user data.

site_title: Romantic reads over the festive season
summary: Four romantic comedy novels are perfect for the festive season, coinciding with Chinese New Year and Valentine's Day. "A Fake Girlfriend for Chinese New Year" by Jackie Lau follows a Chinese-American teacher who poses his friend as his girlfriend to avoid family pressure. "Last Tang Standing" by Lauren Ho is about a lawyer who invents a fake boyfriend to impress her family. Kevin Kwan's "China Rich Girlfriend" and "Rich People Problems" continue the Crazy Rich Asians series, poking fun at wealthy Asians. These novels offer relatable scenes and characters, making them enjoyable reads for the holiday season.

site_title: A post-Covid flight path for the aviation industry
summary: The global aviation industry is expected to take a year to recover to 2019 levels due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, according to the International Air Transport Association (IATA). To regain passenger confidence, airports and airlines must make necessary changes, including investments in health and safety measures, technology, and infrastructure. Key changes include the use of new cleaning technology, comprehensive passenger wellness screening solutions, and e-commerce capabilities in retail areas. Airlines must also communicate clearly about travel requirements and offer Covid-19 travel insurance to restore passenger confidence.

images.alt_text: While safety has always been the top priority in the architecture and design of future airports, with Covid-19, the safety of passengers takes on a new dimension, with protection from the virus becoming the overriding concern.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Several companies reported financial losses due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Far East Orchard expects a net loss for FY2020, while Straco Corporation swung into a net loss in FY2020 compared to a net profit in FY2019. Pacific Star Development reported a deeper net loss of S$7.8 million in the second quarter of FY2020, with revenue falling 84% and other expenses increasing due to cancelled sales. The companies' losses are attributed to impairment losses and lower revenue due to the pandemic.

site_title: Labour crunch hampers fulfilment by gifts, florist firms
summary: Singapore's gift hamper companies face a mixed outlook during the Chinese New Year, with some experiencing a surge in revenue and others suffering from slow demand and high costs. Companies like FarEastFlora.com and Simply Hamper have seen a 15% and 20% increase in revenue respectively, while others, such as Bell Brand and Noel Gifts, have seen a 40% and 5% fall in sales revenue. Supply issues, manpower crunches, and freight costs have also contributed to the challenges faced by the industry, with many companies opting to limit their product range and focus on digital sales.

site_title: Jeff Immelt oversaw the downfall of GE. Now he'd like you to read his book
summary: Jeff Immelt, the former CEO of General Electric, is releasing a book that attempts to explain his 16-year tenure, which was marked by the company's downfall. Immelt acknowledges his mistakes and blames some of the failures on others, including Steve Bolze, the head of GE's power division, who championed an ill-fated acquisition and was deemed "naïve" and "indecisive" by Immelt. The book also criticizes the leadership of his successors, John Flannery, who failed to make decisions and created a culture of victimhood. Immelt's account offers a candid look at the complexities of running a massive company, but some question the accuracy of his narrative, with Bolze disputing Immelt's portrayal.

site_title: US sanctions Myanmar military leaders
summary: US President Joe Biden announced sanctions on Myanmar military leaders linked to the recent coup, targeting their business interests and family members. The sanctions will also prevent the military from accessing approximately $1 billion in government funds held in the US. The move aims to pressure the military leadership and ensure they cannot access these funds.

site_title: Cathie Wood copycats trigger US$3b surge in Ping An Health shares
summary: Cathie Wood's investment in Ping An Healthcare & Technology triggered a record $3.3 billion surge in the company's market value after her Ark Investment Management bought 497,800 shares worth $6.8 million. The trade boosted the stock by 2% in Hong Kong, its largest gain since 2018. This move follows Wood's previous market-moving trades, with her funds' assets under management reaching $50 billion, up from $3.6 billion last year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks firm at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets held firm at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.2% to 6,534.13 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indexes rose 0.1% and 0.1% respectively. Despite US tariff uncertainty, investors remained positive, driving the Singapore Stock Index (STI) up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Facebook said to be building product to compete with audio chat app Clubhouse
summary: Facebook is reportedly developing an audio chat product to compete with Clubhouse, a popular app that allows users to gather in audio chat rooms to discuss various topics. The product, in its early stages of development, aims to expand Facebook's communication offerings. This move follows Facebook's history of entering new technologies and cloning its competitors, as seen with its acquisition of Instagram, WhatsApp, and Oculus. The development of the audio chat product comes as Clubhouse has gained popularity among Silicon Valley's elite, with over two million weekly users and a recent valuation of $1 billion.

site_title: GIC, CDH bidding for Philips' US$3.6b home appliance unit
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and Chinese asset manager CDH Investments are teaming up to bid for Philips' US$3.6 billion home appliance unit. They face competition from Asia-focused private equity firm Hillhouse Capital and a consortium of Citic Capital, Sequoia, and TCL Capital. Philips has set a deadline of March for binding offers, and if no deal is reached, it may consider an initial public offering. The sale is part of Philips' transformation into a health technology business, with the home appliance unit valued at US$3.64 billion and mostly manufactured in China.

site_title: Coca-Cola HBC hikes dividend, sees strong recovery after virus hit
summary: Coca-Cola HBC raised its dividend and expects a strong recovery in 2021 revenue, driven by at-home demand and gradual volume recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. The company reported a 17.4% decline in 2020 comparable net profit due to a hit to its out-of-home channel. Its shares rose 5% to the top of the FTSE 100 index after the announcement. The company attributes its strong outlook to vaccine rollouts and expects a FX-neutral revenue recovery in 2021.

site_title: ThaiBev, BeerCo profits higher for Q1; RHB raises target price to S$0.94
summary: ThaiBev, a beer and liquor giant, reported a net profit of 8.47 billion baht (S$376 million) for its first quarter, a 0.5% increase from the previous year. Group sales revenue declined 5.1% due to lower sales in the beer, non-alcoholic beverages, and food businesses. However, the spirits business saw a 1% year-on-year growth, driven by off-trade sales. BeerCo, ThaiBev's brewery unit, reported a 72.4% increase in net profit to S$77.4 million, despite a 15.1% decline in sales. Analyst RHB raised its target price to S$0.94, citing potential value unlocking from BeerCo's spin-off and ThaiBev's established presence in Thailand and Vietnam.

site_title: Dollar near two-week low after soft US inflation
summary: The US dollar fell to a two-week low due to soft US inflation and the Federal Reserve's promise to keep interest rates low. The dollar is expected to remain weak, with Westpac analyst Imre Speizer stating that "easy policy" will stay in place for a long time, negatively impacting the dollar. Other major currencies, such as the euro and sterling, rose, while the safe-haven Japanese yen reached a two-week peak. Investors await upcoming economic data, including European Commission forecasts and US labour market figures, to gauge the recovery.

site_title: Business environment picks up for second straight quarter
summary: Singapore businesses experienced an improving business environment for the second consecutive quarter, according to the BT-SUSS Business Climate Survey. The net balance in six-month business outlook rose to -12% in the fourth quarter of 2020, with 42% of companies expecting worse business prospects and 30% expecting improvement. However, sales, operating conditions, and profits remained slower to recover, with sales net balance at -58% and profit net balance at -54%. The finance and business services sector was the least pessimistic, with large and foreign firms showing optimism.

site_title: Singtel says standalone third-party file-sharing system hacked
summary: Singtel has confirmed that a third-party file-sharing system, FTA, used by the telecommunications company was hacked by unidentified hackers. The attack, which occurred in December 2020 and January 2021, may have compromised customer information. Accellion, the vendor of the system, notified Singtel of the vulnerability on December 23, 2020, and the telco has since suspended the system's use and activated investigations. Accellion has patched the vulnerabilities and is providing additional guidance to Singtel. The company is working closely with cybersecurity experts and authorities to assess the impact of the breach and support affected customers.

site_title: Gearing up for the long weekend
summary:

Chinese New Year celebrations continue with unique dining experiences. Junior the Pocket Bar collaborates with Remy Martin for a pop-up featuring Asian-inspired cocktails and dishes. The [Not-So] Convenience Store promotes sustainable living with reusable items.

site_title: Finnish insurer Sampo books 899m euro impairment on Nordea stake
summary: Finnish insurer Sampo reported a 899 million euro impairment charge due to a revaluation of its shares in lender Nordea, resulting in a pretax loss of 675 million euros for the fourth quarter. Sampo's main insurance unit, If, reported a 25% increase in quarterly profit to 285 million euros. Despite this, CEO Torbjorn Magnusson expressed optimism for the future, citing robust underwriting results and a focus on a more streamlined group structure.

site_title: Gold edges lower on dollar rebound, softer US inflation data
summary: Gold prices edged lower, falling 0.3% to $1,835.99 per ounce, due to a stronger US dollar and softer US inflation data, which reduced the bullion's appeal as an inflation hedge. This follows a one-week high reached on Wednesday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 helped avert a 12.4% shrinkage in GDP and reduced inequality. The finance ministry released a paper assessing the impact of the budget measures. Meanwhile, Singtel reported a potential data breach, and Frasers Property proposed a 37-for-100 rights issue. SIA, Scoot, and SilkAir began flights with vaccinated air crew. Corporate earnings were reported, with Far East Hospitality Trust and ThaiBev seeing significant changes in their profits. The STI fell marginally due to CNY eve half-day trading.

site_title: Myanmar junta's proposed cyber Bill alarms Internet giants
summary: The Myanmar junta's proposed cyber Bill has sparked alarm among internet giants, with the Asia Internet Coalition warning that it would contravene fundamental rights and hurt the economy. The 36-page bill, which outlines censorship powers and privacy violations, has been given to mobile operators and telecoms licence holders for comment. Civil society groups and internet companies, including Apple, Facebook, Google, and Amazon, have expressed concerns that the bill would undermine freedom of expression and represent a regressive step. The bill's aims include protecting the public and preventing crime, but critics argue it would have devastating consequences for the people and economy of Myanmar.

site_title: 'I thought I had the luxury of time'
summary: Former General Electric CEO Jeff Immelt reflects on his time at the company, which was once the most valuable in the world. Immelt believes that he and others in leadership positions can offer valuable advice to entrepreneurs, but notes that it's essential to have a non-executive perspective. He also comments on the current business landscape, stating that there's a growing need for authentic leadership in uncertain times. Immelt emphasizes the importance of having a CEO who can make tough decisions and provide direction, rather than relying solely on an executive chairman.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.57 points to 1,599.42, closing higher on Thursday. Volume reached 3.21 billion lots worth RM2.048 billion, with 574 gainers outnumbering 383 losers.

site_title: Keeping heritage alive
summary: Jacelyn Lai, a 56-year-old art patron, reminisces about her childhood in 1970s Singapore, where she was captivated by Chinese culture through her grandparents' home. She now seeks to preserve her family's heritage by researching their roots and sharing stories about her grandfather's life, who arrived in Singapore as a teenager in 1922. Lai's passion for Chinese culture has led her to support Asian artists, particularly in Myanmar, where she serves as an unofficial patron to several prominent artists. She aims to instill old-fashioned family values and cultural traditions into her four children, keeping her family's history and heritage alive.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend rally in morning
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.45% in half-day trading on Thursday, driven by optimism over economic recovery and potential relaxation of virus restrictions. The Hang Seng Index reached 30,173.57, ahead of an extended holiday weekend. The rally comes despite US tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Singapore to have new electronic waste disposal system this year
summary: Singapore is set to introduce a new electronic waste disposal system this year, with the Abla Group taking over as the producer responsibility scheme (PRS) operator. The system, which will run from July 1, 2021 to June 30, 2026, aims to reduce e-waste and promote responsible management of electronic products. Producers, rather than consumers, will bear more of the costs of dealing with e-waste, and the system will include public receptacles, scheduled collection drives, and ad-hoc doorstep collection services.

site_title: Singapore's Budget 2020 'helped avert 12.4% shrinkage in GDP and reduced inequality'
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 helped mitigate the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, averting a 12.4% GDP shrinkage and reducing resident unemployment to 6.1%. The government's fiscal and monetary policies, totaling S$100 billion, cushioned the recession. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that early findings suggest the measures have helped cushion the impact of the recession.

site_title: Uber's valuation requires both hands on the wheel
summary: Uber's valuation is high due to its diversified business, with investors giving it credit for operating both ridesharing and food delivery. Despite a 16% revenue drop, the company's food delivery unit, Uber Eats, more than tripled revenue in the quarter. However, Uber Eats is still losing money, and growth in food deliveries may slow down in a post-Covid economy. Uber's valuation is trading at an enterprise value to forward sales multiple of over six times, compared to Lyft's less than five times, indicating investors believe the benefits of owning both businesses outweigh the risks.

images.alt_text: Uber's investors have given it full credit for straddling both the human and food delivery businesses.

site_title: 12 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including three in the community
summary: Singapore reported 12 new Covid-19 cases, including three in the community, bringing the total to 59,759. Three community cases and nine imported cases were confirmed, with the latter coming from India, Brazil, and Myanmar. A 22-year-old construction worker from Bangladesh, who was asymptomatic, tested positive after a serology test, prompting quarantine measures. The number of unlinked community cases increased to four, and 20 patients were discharged, leaving 156 recuperating in community facilities.

site_title: Dozens of former Republican officials in talks to form anti-Trump third party
summary: Dozens of former Republican officials are in talks to form a centre-right breakaway party, aiming to distance themselves from former President Donald Trump's attempts to undermine US democracy. The group, which would run on a platform of "principled conservatism," includes former officials from Ronald Reagan, George HW Bush, and George W Bush administrations. The plan involves running candidates in some races and endorsing centre-right candidates, with over 40% of participants backing the idea of a national third party.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Thursday with a 0.14% decline, dipping to 29,995.28, following a 6% rally in under two weeks. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a holiday. US stocks reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged forward. In other news, an eSIM platform raised $220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion, and Singapore's STI rose 0.4% on Thursday despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: WeWork tiptoes back to the water cooler
summary: WeWork is considering raising funds or going public via a Special Purpose Acquisition Company (SPAC) after a two-year hiatus. This comes after the company's failed attempt to go public in 2019 due to inability to generate positive cash flows and side-deals with founder Adam Neumann. WeWork's valuation plummeted from $47 billion to $8 billion during that period. The company has since secured new tenants and filled more space, demonstrating its ability to recover. A successful listing this time could be possible if done at a realistic price.

images.alt_text: WeWork, though not quite the sensation it was in 2019, still looks strong when stacked up against other firms.

site_title: Tencent says executive held by China linked to 'personal' corruption allegations
summary: Tencent has confirmed that one of its executives, Zhang Feng, is being held by Chinese authorities due to allegations of personal corruption, specifically unauthorized sharing of personal data collected by WeChat. The company stated that the case is unrelated to its Weixin or WeChat platforms. This development comes as part of a high-profile corruption probe involving a former top law-enforcement official in China.

site_title: Taiwan expresses 'admiration' for Biden's 'rock solid' support
summary: Taiwan's government expressed gratitude and admiration for US President Joe Biden's "rock solid" support, following his comments on China's pressure against the island. Biden's government has reassured democratic Taiwan of its commitment, amid increased military activity near the island. The White House stated Biden's "fundamental concerns" about China's coercive practices and human rights abuses. Taiwan's Presidential Office thanked Biden for his concern, pledging to work with like-minded countries to promote stability and prosperity in the Indo-Pacific region.

site_title: Australia: Shares end marginally lower on tech losses
summary: Australian shares ended the day marginally lower, closing at 6,850.1 points, due to losses among tech and industrial stocks offsetting gains in gold and mining stocks. Domestic gold stocks rose, with Newcrest Mining's underlying half-year profit nearly doubling, and mining stocks like Rio Tinto and BHP Group also gained. Tech stocks, however, dropped 2.1% mirroring global peers. Earnings reports from major Australian companies, including BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and National Australia Bank, are scheduled for release next week.

site_title: Amazon appeals to India's Supreme Court in Future deal dispute: sources
summary: Amazon has appealed to India's Supreme Court against its partner Future Group's US$3.4 billion retail assets sale to Reliance Industries, citing alleged contract violations. Future denies any wrongdoing. A New Delhi court recently revoked a previous decision blocking the deal, prompting Amazon's appeal. The dispute revolves around Amazon's claims that Future sold its assets without permission. The outcome of the appeal is uncertain, with both parties maintaining their positions.

site_title: Facebook said to be building a product to compete with Clubhouse
summary: Facebook is reportedly building an audio chat product to compete with Clubhouse, a popular social networking app that allows users to gather in audio chat rooms to discuss various topics. The product, in its earliest stages of development, aims to expand Facebook's communication offerings and follows the company's history of entering new technologies and cloning its competitors. Clubhouse, founded last year, has gained traction among Silicon Valley's elite, with over two million weekly users, and has been valued at $1 billion.

site_title: Biden announces sanctions targeting Myanmar military leaders
summary: US President Joe Biden announced sanctions targeting Myanmar military leaders linked to the recent coup, freezing about $1 billion in government funds. The sanctions, the strongest against a foreign nation since Biden took office, also impose export controls and will identify a first round of targets. The move aims to pressure the military and maximize US leverage over the Southeast Asian nation, which has been aligned with China despite opening to the West. Thousands of anti-coup protesters continue to demand the release of detained leaders, including Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi.

site_title: Commerzbank sees lower revenue as Knof drops growth target
summary: Commerzbank, a German bank, posted its largest quarterly loss in over a decade, with a 2.7 billion euro loss in the last three months of 2020. New CEO Manfred Knof has ditched a failed growth strategy in favor of deep cost cuts, aiming to save 1.4 billion euros annually. The bank plans to focus on profitable client relationships, leading to a drop in revenue this year, but expects to make an operating profit. Commerzbank also plans to return up to 3 billion euros to investors through dividends and share buybacks by 2023 and 2024.

site_title: ThaiBev Q1 profit rises 0.5% to 8.47b baht
summary: ThaiBev reported a net profit of 8.47 billion baht (S$376 million) for its first quarter, a 0.5% increase from the previous year. The growth was driven by increased profits from spirits, beer, and non-alcoholic beverages businesses, offsetting lower contributions from food businesses and stakes in Frasers and Neave. Group sales revenue declined 5.1% to 71.79 billion baht, with the spirits business experiencing a 1% year-on-year growth.

site_title: Microsoft approached Pinterest in recent months about potential deal: FT
summary: Microsoft approached Pinterest about a potential $51 billion acquisition deal in recent months, according to a Financial Times report. The negotiations are currently inactive. Pinterest's monthly active users jumped 37% to 459 million in the fourth quarter, driven by a shift to virtual interactions. The company added a record 100 million monthly active users in 2020 and has seen its shares rise seven times since the pandemic. Pinterest had previously stated it wants to remain an independent company, and a deal would test the Biden administration's appetite for allowing large tech companies to strike deals.

site_title: Frasers Property proposes 37-for-100 rights issue at S$1.18 per share
summary: Frasers Property has proposed a 37-for-100 rights issue at S$1.18 per share, allotting and issuing up to 1.09 billion rights shares to raise S$1.28 billion. Two of its controlling shareholders, TCC Assets and Thai Beverage Public Co, have subscribed for 940.17 million rights shares, representing 86.63% of the issue. The company plans to use the net proceeds for industrial, logistics, and business park assets, and for general corporate purposes. The rights issue price represents a discount of 4.8% to the closing price and 3.6% to the theoretical ex-rights price.

site_title: Goldman, other financial firms add China staff, eyeing growth
summary: Global financial firms, including Goldman Sachs, BlackRock, and Fidelity International, plan to add hundreds of staff in China this year as they take advantage of the country's liberalized financial sector.
