The move comes as Beijing steps up the pace of opening up its US$40 trillion financial sector, allowing foreigners to fully own their local ventures. Goldman aims to hire 70 staff in China, doubling its headcount to 600 by 2024, while Fidelity plans to hire around 100 people. The expansion is driven by a revival in China's economy and increased onshore deal activities, sparking a talent war among Western firms.

site_title: US to look at more restrictions on tech exports to China
summary: The Biden administration plans to review and potentially add new restrictions on sensitive technology exports to China, in cooperation with US allies. The decision comes ahead of President Biden's first call with Chinese leader Xi Jinping. The administration will maintain Chinese trade tariffs imposed by the Trump administration until it conducts a review with allies. The goal is to prevent China from acquiring technology that could advance its military capabilities, while also working with Republicans to boost US public investment in key technology sectors.

site_title: Suu Kyi's aide among new wave of arrests in Myanmar: party official
summary: Myanmar authorities have arrested Kyaw Tint Swe, a close aide to ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi, in a new wave of detentions following the military coup. Kyaw Tint Swe, who served as Minister for the Office of the State Counsellor, was taken from his home along with four others. The arrests come after Suu Kyi's detention on February 1. Authorities have not commented on the arrests, which Reuters was unable to confirm independently.

site_title: Manufacturer for hire: China's Geely sets out to become a force in electric cars
summary: China's Geely, owner of Volvo Cars and 9.7% of Daimler, aims to become a leading contract manufacturer for electric vehicles. The company has announced several tie-ups, including a venture with Taiwan's Foxconn to provide electric vehicle manufacturing services, and partnerships with Faraday Future, Baidu, and Tencent Holdings. Geely chairman Li Shufu seeks to boost the company's share price and expand its presence in China's electric car market. The deals could address Geely's under-utilization of its plants and help the company get the most out of its new EV-focused platform.

site_title: Twitter will explore letting users receive payments from followers
summary: Twitter is exploring allowing users to receive digital payments from their followers, aiming to diversify its revenue beyond advertising. The feature, which could introduce economic incentives for contributors, was announced by CEO Jack Dorsey during the Goldman Sachs Technology and Internet Conference. This move comes after the company's acquisition of newsletter startup Revue, and is expected to help the platform earn more money and engagement from its 192 million daily users. Subscriptions are not expected to be significant until next year.

site_title: Far East Orchard expects to post net loss for FY2020
summary: Far East Orchard expects to post a net loss for FY2020 due to the prolonged impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on its business. The company's hospitality business and share of losses from joint ventures in Australia and Europe have contributed to the expected loss. Additionally, Far East Orchard has incurred share of revaluation losses and impairment charges on certain hotel properties and goodwill arising from its hospitality property ownership business. The company's unaudited financial results have been reviewed, and the expected net loss is attributed to the adverse effects of the pandemic.

site_title: STI down 0.01% in CNY eve half-day trading
summary: Singapore shares ended flat on Thursday ahead of the Chinese New Year break, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.01% to 2,925.48 points. Trading was subdued, with investors showing little interest in the market. Key movers included Jardine Strategic Holdings, which rose 2.3%, and Thai Beverage, which fell 2.5%. Banking stocks ended in positive territory, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB gaining 0.3%, 0.1%, and 0.2% respectively.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics boss Mori to resign over sexist remarks
summary: Tokyo Olympics chief Yoshiro Mori, 83, is resigning over sexist remarks that sparked outrage in Japan and abroad. Mori made comments saying women "have difficulty" speaking concisely and insisted he had heard complaints about women speaking at length. Despite apologizing, the remarks were widely condemned, with the International Olympic Committee calling them "completely inappropriate." The sexism row has added to the challenges faced by Olympic organizers, who are also dealing with public disquiet over holding the Games this summer amid the pandemic. Mori's resignation is seen as a response to the mounting pressure.

site_title: Kim Kardashian robber won't benefit from book: lawyers
summary: Yunice Abbas, awaiting trial for the 2016 Paris robbery of reality star Kim Kardashian, will not benefit financially from his book "I Kidnapped Kim Kardashian" due to a court order seizing book sales rights. The book's publishers, Archipel, have not commented on Abbas' efforts. Abbas, 67, is one of five "Grandpa robbers" who made off with a combined haul worth nine million euros in the biggest robbery of an individual in France in two decades. A trial is expected to begin this year, with Abbas' lawyers claiming he sustained psychological consequences from the armed robbery.

site_title: Mastercard to open up network to select cryptocurrencies
summary: Mastercard plans to support select cryptocurrencies on its network this year, following similar moves by Tesla, BlackRock, Square, and PayPal. The company will allow customers to transact using cryptocurrencies, expanding payment options for shoppers and merchants. However, not all cryptocurrencies will be supported due to compliance issues, and Mastercard emphasizes the need for digital assets to improve their trustworthiness. This move may attract new customers to digital assets and create new opportunities for merchants.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 1.63 points to 1,598.48. Losers outpaced gainers 289 to 247, and volume reached 606.41 million lots worth RM265.64 million.

site_title: Tokyo, South Korea, China, Taiwan: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Financial markets in Tokyo, South Korea, mainland China, and Taiwan are closed for public holidays. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4%. In other news, Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion, and US stocks, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Merck in talks with governments, other drugmakers to produce Covid-19 shots
summary: Merck & Co is in talks with governments and other companies to produce Covid-19 vaccines. The company is considering supporting the production of authorized vaccines beyond its own candidates. Merck had halted its two Covid-19 vaccine development after early trials showed inferior immune responses. The company will focus on its investigational therapeutic candidate, molnupiravir, and plans to provide early data from its trial in the first quarter. Merck has also built a portfolio of Covid-19 medicines through recent deals and will supply an experimental treatment to the US government.

images.alt_text: Merck & Co said on Wednesday it was in talks with governments and companies to potentially help with manufacturing of Covid-19 vaccines that have been already authorised.

site_title: Rich countries fall short in sciences gender equality: Unesco
summary: Unesco reported that women face a significant gender bias in science careers worldwide, with only 28% of engineering graduates and 40% of computer science and informatics graduates being women. Despite a global shortage of skills in technology fields, rich western nations lag behind poorer ones in terms of gender equality in science. The organization's Science Report highlights the disparity, which is expected to be fully published in April.

site_title: Yellen says US Treasury will fight misuse of cryptocurrencies, foster innovation
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned about an "explosion of risk" related to digital markets, including the misuse of cryptocurrencies. She noted that cryptocurrencies have been used for illicit activities like laundering and financing terrorism. However, Yellen emphasized the potential of innovation in the sector to combat these problems and reduce inequality. She advocated for a balanced approach that protects against bad actors while also promoting positive change.

site_title: Macron floats brokered Airbus-Boeing accord to Biden: report
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron reportedly told US President Joe Biden that he could help broker a settlement to the Boeing-Airbus trade dispute during a phone call on January 24. Biden expressed willingness to follow up, but remained noncommittal on the outcome.

site_title: UK housing market boom loses steam: RICS
summary: The UK housing market experienced a sharp slowdown in January due to the country's coronavirus lockdown and the near-expiration of a tax break for buyers. House price growth slowed more than expected, with prices in London falling for the first time since July. A measure of properties hitting the market was the second-weakest on record, and near-term sales expectations reached a pre-pandemic record low. The stamp duty tax exemption is set to expire at the end of next month, but the finance minister may extend it in his upcoming budget statement.

site_title: Oil states face US$9t shortfall as demand falters: analysis
summary: Oil-producing nations face a potential $9 trillion shortfall due to declining demand for fossil fuels as the world transitions to renewable energy. This could lead to a 20% decline in government income for affected countries, resulting in cuts to public services and increased unemployment. The worst-affected countries, including Nigeria, could see a 70% drop in oil revenues, cutting state income by one-third. The impact will disproportionately affect poorer nations with significant oil reserves, putting their economies and public services at risk.

site_title: Taxes, ESG are potential wake-up calls to go green
summary: Singapore's 2021 budget emphasizes environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, with a record number of companies disclosing ESG data. The government aims to promote ESG through the Singapore Green Plan 2030, which includes ambitious targets to reduce carbon emissions. Tax transparency is also encouraged as a measure of a company's commitment to society. Companies must embed ESG principles into their corporate culture to remain attractive to investors and avoid risks.

site_title: Oil rally extends for ninth day on Opec+ cuts, demand hopes
summary: Oil prices extended their rally for a ninth day, supported by Opec+ supply cuts and hopes for a demand recovery driven by vaccine rollouts. Brent crude rose 0.7% to $61.51, while US crude rose 0.6% to $58.68. Analysts say prices have moved too far ahead of fundamentals, but Opec-led supply cuts and optimism about demand revival are driving the market. Supply is expected to undershoot demand in 2021 as more people get vaccinated.

site_title: US 'very far' from a strong labour market: Federal Reserve's Powell
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that the US economy is "very far" from a strong job market, citing the need for a full suite of government policies to repair the damage caused by the pandemic. He also warned that the recovery could take years.

site_title: Bank of England governor presses EU on finance deal for post-Covid stability
summary: Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey pressed the EU to agree a post-Brexit financial services deal by March, citing the need for pandemic recovery on both sides of the Channel. He rejected EU demands for Britain to adopt the same financial regulations, arguing that such a move would be "unrealistic, dangerous and inconsistent with practice." Bailey emphasized the importance of healthy competition in global financial markets, urging the EU to accept strong and effective common global regulatory standards.

site_title: US backs Japan concerns on China ships
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken expressed concern over China's increased assertiveness in Japanese territorial waters, particularly around the Senkaku Islands. Blinken reaffirmed that the Senkakus fall within the scope of the US-Japan Security Treaty, committing both nations to defend each other if attacked. The US supports Japan's concerns, reiterating its commitment to the ally's defense amid China's enactment of a new coast guard law.

site_title: ThaiBev's BeerCo reports 72.4% profit growth for Q1 on improved margins
summary: ThaiBev's brewery unit BeerCo reported a 72.4% profit growth for Q1, reaching S$77.4 million, despite lower sales revenue of S$1.32 billion, down 11.4% from the previous year. The decline was attributed to the Covid-19 pandemic and government measures. BeerCo's net profit margin rose to 9.8% from 5.3% in Q1 2020. The company plans to list on the Singapore Exchange, aiming to create the largest beer platform in Asean and increase the value of its portfolio.

site_title: Coca-Cola hit from Covid-19 offset by cost cuts
summary: Coca-Cola reported a 29% decline in fourth-quarter profits to $1.4 billion, due to a 5% decline in revenues hit by the resurgence of the coronavirus. However, the company reported better-than-expected profits thanks to cost-cutting measures, including a 2,200-job restructuring. Executives expressed optimism for a recovery once vaccines are widely distributed and offered a full-year revenue growth forecast of "high single digits" for 2021. The company also faces a potentially costly US tax dispute, with a potential liability of up to $12 billion.

site_title: Biden speaks by phone with China's Xi Jinping
summary: US President Joe Biden spoke with Chinese leader Xi Jinping by phone, expressing concerns over human rights in Hong Kong and Xinjiang, as well as Beijing's economic practices and assertive actions in the region, including toward Taiwan. This marked the first call between the two leaders since Biden took office on January 20. Biden also extended greetings to the Chinese people on the Lunar New Year. The conversation highlighted ongoing tensions between the two nations.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden expressed concerns to Chinese leader Xi Jinping about human rights in Hong Kong and Xinjiang late Wednesday in their first call since Mr Biden took office on Jan 20, according to the White House.

site_title: Myanmar junta leader asks Thai counterpart for help on democracy
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha received a letter from Myanmar's junta leader Min Aung Hlaing requesting help to support democracy, amid mass protests in Myanmar. Pro-democracy protesters in Myanmar appealed to Chinese President Xi Jinping to withdraw support for the military. The protests, which have lasted for a fifth day, come after the army overthrew the elected civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi. Prayuth expressed support for democracy in Myanmar but emphasized the importance of maintaining good relations due to economic and border trade implications.

site_title: SIA, Scoot, SilkAir start flights with Covid-vaccinated crew
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA), Scoot, and SilkAir have started flights with Covid-vaccinated crew, becoming among the world's first carriers to do so. Over 90% of SIA's operating cabin crew and pilots have signed up for vaccination, with more than 52,000 transport sector staff receiving their first dose. Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung emphasized the importance of vaccinating border staff to secure Singapore's border and keep the country safe. SIA's CEO Goh Choon Phong noted that vaccinations will be key to reopening borders and enhancing travel confidence.

site_title: Biden announces new Pentagon task force on China
summary: US President Joe Biden announced the formation of a special Defence Department task force on China, ordering an immediate review of the military's strategic approach to Beijing. The four-month task force will assess US military strategy, technology, force structure, and alliances. Biden emphasized the need for a whole-of-government effort and cooperation from both parties and Congress. He stated that the task force's recommendations will be crucial in charting a strong path forward on China-related matters and ensuring the US wins the competition in the future.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden announced Wednesday the formation of a special Defence Department task force on China and ordered an immediate review of the military's strategic approach to the challenge from Beijing.

site_title: Malaysia's economy posts biggest annual decline since 1998 crisis
summary: Malaysia's economy contracted 3.4% year-on-year in the fourth quarter, marking its third consecutive decline, due to stricter coronavirus curbs. The country's full-year economic performance fell 5.6% in 2020, the worst annual performance since the 1998 Asian Financial Crisis. Despite expectations of a rebound in 2021, economists warn of potential risks to the downside, citing the ongoing pandemic. Capital Economics forecasts a 7% full-year 2021 growth, while Bank Negara Malaysia governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus expects growth to rebound, supported by global demand and domestic normalization.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip ahead of CNY holiday; STI down 0.2% at open
summary: Singapore stocks slipped 0.2% at open on Thursday ahead of the Chinese New Year holiday, with the Straits Times Index falling 5.43 points to 2,920.41. Thai Beverage and Singtel were among the most heavily traded stocks, with Thai Beverage falling 0.6% and Singtel shedding 0.8% after announcing a cyber attack. DBS gained 0.2% despite reporting a 33% decline in net profit, while OCBC and UOB fell 0.2% and 0.3% respectively. The Singapore bourse is open for half-day trading until noon due to the holiday.

site_title: ABN Amro scraps dividend after first annual loss in a decade
summary: ABN Amro Bank scrapped its 2020 dividend after posting its first annual loss in a decade, citing pandemic-related losses and a restructuring of its investment bank. The Dutch lender reported a net loss of 1.2 billion euros, primarily due to losses at its clearing business and its exposure to the failed Singapore oil trading giant Hin Leong Trading Ltd.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust DPS drops 30.7% to 1.38 S cents for H2
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust's (Far East H-Trust) distribution per stapled security (DPS) fell 30.7% to 1.38 Singapore cents for the half-year period ended Dec 31, 2020, due to lower rentals in its hotel arm and rental rebates. Gross revenue declined 34.8% to S$39 million, and net property income eased 38% to S$33.6 million. The trust's full-year DPS was 36.7% lower at 2.41 cents, and total distributable income slipped 35.2% to S$47.9 million.

site_title: SF Group: Staying on track for growth
summary: SF Group, a Singaporean F&B operator, achieved double-digit topline growth despite the pandemic halving its previous 5-year growth rate. The company credited strategic planning, pivoting to food delivery, and leveraging brand strength and customer loyalty for its success. SF Group plans to expand and launch four brands in Q2, including opening its 13th Collin's restaurant, and a 10-times larger central kitchen. The company is hopeful that the economic recovery, driven by consumer confidence and the COVID-19 vaccination drive, will steer the Singaporean economy.

site_title: Name change for Aunt Jemima after 131 years
summary: PepsiCo has announced a name change for its Aunt Jemima brand, rebranding it as the Pearl Milling Co. after 131 years, following widespread criticism over the brand's racist imagery. The change comes after the killing of George Floyd and a nationwide reckoning over symbols of the Old South. The company will continue to sell products with the Aunt Jemima name until June, but without the character's face. The rebranded products will feature a new logo and packaging, with a $1 million commitment to empower and uplift Black girls and women.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Singtel, ThaiBev, SATS, Far East Hospitality Trust
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore stocks were mixed on Thursday, with DBS and ThaiBev seeing gains, while SATS and Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) declined. DBS reported a net profit of S$1.01 billion for the fourth quarter, despite a 33% decline from the previous year. Singtel posted a 3.2% year-on-year decline in operating revenue, but announced plans to hire 500 professionals in the lead-up to the 5G rollout. FEHT's distribution per stapled security fell 30.7% to 1.38 Singapore cents due to rental rebates and waivers during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: With sound management and effective policies, Poland could redraw Europe's economic map
summary: Poland has the potential to redraw Europe's economic map by leveraging its unique opportunities for economic expansion in a region that has long lacked economic structure. With sound management and effective foreign policies, Poland could integrate a new Eastern European economy around a Polish core, breaking free from the middle-income trap. Its large size, natural hinterland in Ukraine, and favorable geography make it an ideal candidate for this role.

site_title: SF Holding to take over Kerry Logistics for HK$17.6b
summary: SF Holding Co. is acquiring a 51.8% stake in Hong Kong-listed Kerry Logistics Network for HK$17.6 billion, boosting its global expansion. The deal will give SF Holding control of Kerry Logistics' air freight, trucking, and ocean cargo services. Kerry Logistics will sell some warehouse assets and its Taiwan business to its parent company, Kerry Group, and proposes a special dividend. The deal is expected to boost SF Holding's distribution network and supply-chain services across Asia. SF Holding's shares have more than doubled in the past 12 months, surpassing FedEx in value.

site_title: Biden team asks court to pause move to ban TikTok in US
summary: The Biden administration has asked a US federal court to pause proceedings aimed at banning TikTok due to a fresh review of the national security threat posed by the Chinese-owned video app. The review will assess the underlying record justifying the previous administration's claims of a national security threat. The administration also put on hold a plan to force the sale of TikTok to American investors, citing a "rigorous" review of data security. TikTok has repeatedly defended itself against allegations of data transfers to the Chinese government.

site_title: Oil in longest rally in two years as vaccines boost demand hopes
summary: Oil prices rose for a ninth consecutive day, extending their rally, as vaccines boost demand hopes and producer supply cuts supported the increase. Crude stocks fell for a third consecutive week, dropping to 469 million barrels, their lowest since March. Brent crude rose 38 cents to $61.47 a barrel and US crude rose 32 cents to $58.68 a barrel, touching 13-month highs. Analysts forecast supply will undershoot demand in 2021 as vaccination efforts drive a recovery in demand, leading to a strong second half of the year.

site_title: With flexible policy, Salesforce says 9-5 workday is 'dead'
summary: Salesforce has introduced a new policy allowing most employees to work remotely indefinitely, effectively making the 9-to-5 workday "dead." The company surveyed employees who have been working from home since the pandemic and found that nearly half want to work from home only a few times a month, while 80% want to maintain a connection to a physical space. The new "flex" plan gives employees flexibility in how, when, and where they work, with most opting for one to three days in the office and others working remotely full-time.

images.alt_text: Most employees at Salesforce will be able to work remotely indefinitely under a new policy unveiled by the cloud computing giant, which says the 9-to-5 workday is "dead."

site_title: Uber posts big loss as pandemic clobbers ridesharing
summary: Uber reported a loss of $968 million in the final quarter of 2020, a 12% decrease from the same period last year, due to the pandemic's impact on ridesharing. However, its food delivery operations saw a 224% revenue jump. The company's mobility segment declined 52% while delivery operations surged. Despite this, Uber's CFO said the improving financials suggest the company is on track to achieve profitability goals in 2021. Analysts praised the results, citing a rebound in ridesharing metrics and a leaner expense structure.

site_title: Cicheti Group: Oven-baked pizzas make for fiery sales
summary: The Cicheti Group, an Italian restaurant chain in Singapore, credits oven-baked pizzas for its success in 2020, with pizza being the most popular menu item. To cater to delivery customers, the group tweaked the recipe and added reheating instructions. This move helped the group achieve "fiery sales." The success of pizza is attributed to the dedication of the group's pizza chef, Iman, and his team.

site_title: GameStop mania could be illegal in Singapore
summary: Retail investors in Singapore are warned that participating in online discussions that incite market movements, such as the GameStop saga, could be illegal under the Securities and Futures Act. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and SGX RegCo advise investors to exercise discretion and not fall prey to dishonest traders. Failure to comply can result in fines of up to S$250,000 or imprisonment for up to seven years. The authorities are monitoring market activities closely and may restrict trading accounts or suspend securities if misconduct is detected.

site_title: Hiking surge leaves wild cows starving on Hong Kong island
summary: A surge in hikers and campers on Hong Kong's Grass Island has left a herd of wild cows starving, as their primary food source - the island's lush grass - has been trampled. The cows are now turning to visitors' trash and potentially fatal food sources, with volunteers shipping in fresh hay to feed them. Conservationists warn that the island's ecosystem is at risk, and visitors must be educated on wildlife protection to prevent further damage.

images.alt_text: The situation has become so bad that volunteers have begun shipping feed into Grass Island to stop the herd from starving.

site_title: Gold firms on faltering dollar, stimulus hopes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,840.96 per ounce, near a one-week peak, due to a weaker US dollar and rising hopes of a US stimulus package. The dollar hit a two-week low, making gold more attractive as a hedge against inflation. However, higher inflation could cause a short-term spike in the dollar and push gold lower. Platinum also gained due to recovering demand for diesel engines in the car industry.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed after dovish Fed Chair comments
summary: US stocks finished mixed on Wednesday, with the Dow reaching a record after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's dovish comments on inflation and monetary policy. Powell expressed skepticism about rising inflation and no change in the central bank's easy-money policies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.3% and 0.3% respectively. Individual stocks such as Twitter, Match Group, and General Motors also saw significant price movements, with Twitter jumping 13.2% and Match Group rising 7.7%.

site_title: China's factory prices snap year-long decline as demand recovers
summary: China's factory gate prices rose 0.3% in January, the first annual increase in a year, driven by strong manufacturing growth and higher raw material costs. The producer price index (PPI) growth is expected to continue, with analyst Betty Wang predicting a positive trend. In contrast, consumer prices unexpectedly fell into deflation in January, the first time upstream prices have risen faster than downstream costs in over two years. China's economy is expected to grow 8.4% this year, following a 2.3% rise in 2020.

site_title: Ninja Van: E-commerce surge was both a boon and challenge
summary: Ninja Van, a Singapore-based courier company, experienced a significant surge in e-commerce demand during the COVID-19 pandemic. The company saw a three-fold increase in parcel volume, with many bulky items requiring special handling. To cope, Ninja Van launched its proprietary Ninja Chat system, expanded its warehouse capacity, and introduced contactless-delivery options. Despite initial challenges, the company has improved its services, increasing parcel processing efficiency by five times. The e-commerce boom is expected to continue, with Ninja Van anticipating increased demand for bulky office-related items and COVID-accessories.

site_title: Home makeovers help S Korean mobile decor startup triple sales
summary: A South Korean mobile decor startup, Home Makeover, has seen its sales triple after launching a one-stop home decor app in 2013. Founder Lee Seungjae started the business with a mission to solve the problem of making home changes easy and enjoyable. Despite initial doubts, the app has gained traction, and the company's sales have increased significantly.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee hopes to turn Bucketplace, the company behind the Ohouse mobile app, into a unicorn in the "near future".

site_title: Myanmar unrest a risk to capital flow from Singapore to young startups there
summary: Singapore-based venture capitalists are concerned about investing in Myanmar's startup ecosystem due to the recent military coup, restricted internet access, and talent outflow. The country's fintech players had attracted significant investments, but the coup may deter international clients from engaging remote tech teams. Singapore's cumulative investment in Myanmar was US$24.1 billion in 2020, but investors are now taking a cautious approach. The military coup is seen as a "second body blow" to the country's startup ecosystem, with concerns about internet connectivity and social media restrictions.

site_title: Gojek, Tokopedia near merger ahead of public listing
summary: Indonesian ride-hailing giant Gojek and e-commerce provider Tokopedia are finalizing their merger terms, aiming to list the combined entity in Jakarta and the US, with a target valuation of $35-40 billion. Gojek shareholders are expected to own 60% of the combined entity, while Tokopedia investors will hold 40%. The companies are discussing various scenarios, including a concurrent listing in both countries or listing Tokopedia first in Jakarta before merging. If successful, the merger would create an Indonesian internet powerhouse and give global investors a chance to invest in the country's fast-growing tech sector.

site_title: The 2020 trade fraud scandals: have we learnt the right lessons?
summary: The 2020 trade fraud scandals in the commodity financing sector resulted in billions of dollars lost due to fictitious trades and multiple financing. The magnitude of losses led to banks downsizing or withdrawing from the sector, prompting Singapore to announce a trade finance registry and Code of Best Practices to guide lenders. However, the problem of liquidity remains, with traders leveraging on it to access funds, and the registry's limitations highlight the need for a fundamental shift in the business. Enhancing transparency, credit information, and auditing are crucial to understanding leverage and preventing future collapses.

site_title: Secretlab: Gaming chairs draw new following
summary: Secretlab, a Singaporean gaming chair manufacturer, has seen a significant surge in demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with its chairs becoming a mainstream choice for non-gamers as well. The company has responded by increasing production, opening 24/7 production lines, and exploring alternative shipping routes. As a result, Secretlab sold its millionth chair last year and has grown 30 times from three years ago, with pre-tax earnings "exploding" multi-fold. The company prioritizes creating a solid product and constantly improving it, driven by customer feedback and a desire to solve everyday problems.

site_title: Pandemic forces a shift in power balance in London's commercial real estate
summary: A pandemic-induced shift in London's commercial real estate power balance has led to landlords loosening terms with tenants, offering rent holidays or concessions, amid empty properties. Some tenants have turned to insolvency law to reduce rents or switch to fluctuating leases based on earnings. The government review of leasing legislation may bring more change, with some landlords calling for more transparency and cooperation with tenants. The pandemic has also accelerated the adoption of turnover rent models, with 75-80% of Pret a Manger's locations on such agreements.

site_title: Europe: Shares track Wall Street's dip into the red
summary: European shares ended 0.2% lower, following Wall Street's decline, despite initial optimism from upbeat earnings reports and the proposed US$1.9 trillion US stimulus bill. Technology stocks led losses, with the Nasdaq Composite sliding 0.4%. Gains in commodity-linked shares and banks were outweighed by losses in most other sectors. Historic stimulus has helped the Stoxx 600 rally 50% since March 2020, but investors now focus on inflation and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Fortune favours the bold: 10 SMEs that rose above the pandemic
summary: In the face of the pandemic, 10 Singaporean SMEs demonstrated resilience and adaptability, with some experiencing significant growth. Lunch Actually's pivot to virtual dating services, Far East Flora's 300% year-on-year growth in online sales, and Prime Group's 15-25% jump in sales are notable examples. Other companies, such as Cicheti Group, X-Inc, and Phoon Huat, also thrived by diversifying their business streams or capitalizing on pandemic-fueled trends. Despite challenges, these SMEs have shown that with the right combination of luck, persistence, and foresight, they can rise above adversity and thrive in uncertain times.

site_title: X-Inc: After surviving, it is time to thrive
summary: X-Inc, a Singaporean SME, has overcome the challenges of 2020 by expanding its business into co-working spaces and shared kitchens. The company secured three new distributorships and plans to build a new facility and enter local produce and alternative proteins markets. Despite a tough year, X-Inc's diversified client base and digital transformation efforts helped it thrive. Co-CEO Nichol Ng said the company is now determined to execute innovative ideas and plans, aiming to "thrive and seek new horizons" in the future.

site_title: Virus threatens 'game over' for Japan's arcades
summary: Japan's arcades, a staple of the country's gaming culture, are facing a "game over" as the COVID-19 pandemic continues to impact their business. With Tokyo and other parts of Japan under a state of emergency, arcades are forced to close early, resulting in lost income. Since early January, the number of arcades has decreased, with some well-known establishments in Tokyo shutting down for good. The industry has had to adapt, with claw-crane toy machines becoming a major source of revenue, and video games accounting for only 13% of sales in 2017.

site_title: SocGen trading contraction caps first losing year in decades
summary: Societe Generale, a French lender, has reported its first losing year in over three decades due to declining stock and bond trading. The bank's equities trading fell 7% and fixed-income revenue dropped 16%, resulting in a 258 million euro loss for the year. CEO Frederic Oudea is trying to turn around the bank by reducing risk, cutting costs, and simplifying products. Despite this, the bank's shares have slumped by about three-quarters since Oudea took over in 2008.

site_title: Maersk shares dive after outlook for 2021 disappoints
summary: Maersk shares dropped 8% after the company's 2021 outlook disappointed the market, with underlying Ebitda expected to rise between $8.5 billion and $10.5 billion. This fell short of analyst estimates, with Ebitda coming in at $8.3 billion last year. The company attributes the shortfall to high freight rates peaking and a demand surge leading to supply chain bottlenecks. Despite this, Maersk expects profitability in the first quarter to be above the fourth quarter, driven by normalizing supply chain issues.

site_title: Musk's US$1.5b Bitcoin bet fuels gains in firms already invested
summary: Tesla's $1.5 billion Bitcoin investment has boosted shares of companies already invested in the digital currency, with gains outperforming Wall Street in 2021. The price of Bitcoin reached a record high of $48,000 after Tesla announced its purchase and plans to accept it as payment for cars. This move has fueled Bitcoin's emerging credentials as a mainstream financial asset.

site_title: Top International: Diversifying business streams is key
summary: Top International, a Singaporean mining company, achieved a 10% growth in revenue last year despite the pandemic's impact on global demand for commodities. The company diversified its business streams by expanding into iron ore, copper cathode, sand, and coal, and expects similar performance this year. CEO Victor Tan plans to embark on decarbonisation initiatives, digitalisation, and improving internal infrastructure to support remote and hybrid working styles. The company aims to expand into new areas and strengthen its resilience by diversifying its business streams.

site_title: Tesco shareholders press retailer to address UK obesity crisis
summary: Tesco shareholders are urging the retailer to set targets to increase healthy food sales, as part of the UK's efforts to tackle obesity. Seven institutional investors, managing £140 billion in assets, have backed a proposal that asks Tesco to disclose its healthy food sales and set a target to significantly increase it by 2030. The UK government has labeled obesity a major health crisis, and Tesco, as the UK's largest grocer, is under pressure to encourage healthier eating habits.

site_title: Singapore's January new home sales break into a sprint as talk of curbs grows
summary: Singapore's new home sales surged in January with 1,606 units sold, more than double the previous month and the highest monthly figure in over two years. This was largely due to speculation of possible property curbs and the launch of mega projects such as The Normanton. January's sales also exceeded the 159% increase from January 2020, with ECs contributing to the total 2,095 units sold. The Urban Redevelopment Authority will release January monthly volumes on February 15.

site_title: Phoon Huat: Riding a pandemic-fuelled baking frenzy
summary: Phoon Huat, a Singapore baking supplier, rode the pandemic-fueled "lockdown baking" trend in 2020, achieving S$100 million in revenue despite initial challenges. The company implemented safety measures, set up an online store, and offered online baking classes to cater to customers. With its digital transformation, Phoon Huat is now seeking external support to improve its digital capabilities, aiming to leverage economies of scale from long-time customers to offer competitively priced products. The pandemic accelerated the company's transformation and helped it thrive in the challenging market.

site_title: Here's a guide to fun this long weekend
summary: Chinese New Year and Valentine's Day coincide this weekend, offering a unique opportunity for celebrations. A lifestyle guide in the next issue of BTLifestyle suggests dining options, games, and activities to fill the time. It also features recipes for a Valentine's Day dinner at home and recommendations for restaurants like Sommer. Additionally, the guide explores the intersection of Chinese culture and romance through art and home decor inspiration.

site_title: US core consumer prices unchanged in January
summary: US core consumer prices remained unchanged in January for a second straight month, with a 1.4% increase from the prior year. The broader CPI rose 0.3% from the prior month, driven by higher petrol prices. Despite tame January data, inflation is expected to firm in the months ahead due to anticipated demand growth and a potential large aid package. The jobless rate and limited wage growth may limit price pressures, but lawmakers continue to debate the size of the next pandemic relief package.

site_title: Far East Flora: A blooming online business
summary: Far East Flora, a Singaporean SME, saw 300% year-on-year growth in online sales for its garden and wholesale businesses during the 2020 partial lockdown. The company's digital readiness helped it maintain business continuity, with a new call-centre phone system allowing staff to work from home. This led to a surge in interest in home gardening and gift-giving, with a new weekly flower subscription service experiencing over 500% growth. The company attributes its success to Singaporeans diverting money to improve their homes and surroundings during the pandemic.

site_title: Covid-19 is changing the face of retail
summary: Covid-19 is transforming the retail industry, particularly in Singapore, where property trends are shifting. The Q3 condo launch wave will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 per square foot. Manhattan rents have reached a record high, with more increases expected. Meanwhile, US mortgage rates have risen after five consecutive weeks of declines. Other key developments include rising homebuyer demand in the UK, Goldman's acquisition of Seoul hotel and retail assets, and the Singapore property market's response to the pandemic. These changes signal significant shifts in the retail landscape.

site_title: Does a greener world need less greenback?
summary: The growing focus on renewable energy and sustainable energy may lead to a decline in the US dollar's dominance as the world's reserve currency. As oil demand is expected to peak within the next decade, the "petrodollar" system, which relies on oil exports to back the dollar, may lose its influence. This could result in a decrease in the dollar's value and potentially lead to a shift away from the US dollar as the global reserve currency.

site_title: US dollar trades at 2-week lows; krona strengthens
summary: The US dollar traded near two-week lows on Wednesday, falling 0.05% to 90.386 due to decreasing demand for safe-haven assets. Meanwhile, Sweden's krona reached a one-month high of 10.0406 krona per euro. Bitcoin consolidated around US$46,500 after reaching a new high overnight, while Ethereum pulled back slightly. Analysts attribute the dollar's decline to optimism over monetary and fiscal support, corporate earnings, and coronavirus vaccines, which is bolstering risk sentiment.

site_title: US core consumer prices show scant inflation
summary: US core consumer prices remained unchanged in January for a second straight month, defying expectations of a 0.2% gain. The core CPI increased 1.4% from the prior year, driven by higher gasoline prices. The broader CPI also rose 0.3% from the prior month and 1.4% from a year earlier, influenced by gasoline prices. The sustained low inflation suggests the pandemic's restraint on inflation continues, with policymakers facing pressure to address potential economic slowdowns.

site_title: Twitter investors look past warning of slower user growth
summary: Twitter beat Wall Street targets with a record $1.29 billion in quarterly revenue, up 28% year-over-year. The company forecast a strong start to 2021, driven by ad spending rebounding from the pandemic, and projected total revenue would grow faster than costs. Despite a slowdown in user growth, Twitter's earnings per share rose to 27 cents, and shares gained 3% in extended trading, adding to an 11% gain this year.

site_title: HK sells premium site to Wharf, tycoons
summary: Hong Kong's Wharf Holdings, along with several tycoons, has bought a premium land site in the Peak area for a record-breaking HK$7.25 billion (S$1.2 billion). The 54,541 square-foot site can produce up to 144,970 square feet of floor area, with a price of HK$50,011 per square foot, the highest on record. The consortium's confidence in Hong Kong's luxury home market rebounding after the pandemic drove the higher-than-expected price, which is 18% higher than the previously valued site of HK$6.8 billion.

site_title: DBS sees India bank takeover turning a profit in 12-24 months
summary: DBS Bank expects its recent takeover of Lakshmi Vilas Bank (LVB) in India to turn a profit within 12 to 24 months, after accounting for asset quality concerns in the fourth quarter of 2020. The merger added 2 million retail and 125,000 corporate customers, growing DBS India's deposit base by 59% to S$9 billion. DBS chief Piyush Gupta is confident that the expansion of its digital strategy will allow the bank to take its digital capability and grow it faster than expected, with a focus on growing retail presence and cross-selling personal loans.

site_title: Emerging Asia output will stay subdued in 2021
summary: Emerging Asia's economic output is unlikely to return to pre-pandemic levels in 2021 due to external funding risks, according to the OECD. Many liquidity-strained governments in the region will focus on stabilizing budget deficits and debt burdens, with debt servicing costs a major concern. External funding risks will remain the overriding issue for these governments, hindering their ability to return to pre-pandemic growth levels.

site_title: Singtel to hire, train 500 staff over next two years in lead-up to 5G roll-out
summary: Singtel plans to hire and train 500 staff in Singapore over the next two years in preparation for the rollout of the country's nationwide 5G networks. The telco will focus on 5G roles, Internet of Things, cloud engineering, and data analytics, while also retraining 2,300 existing employees. The effort aims to develop the overall capability of the ICT sector and transform the skill-sets of existing staff. The company is collaborating with the National University of Singapore, Singapore Polytechnic, and the Infocomm Media Development Authority to create 5G-related training courses.

site_title: Fujian buyers cast wider net in Singapore property market
summary: Fujian buyers from China's Fujian province have continued to expand their interests in Singapore's property market, with the latest deal involving a 13,336 sq ft office unit at The Central above Clarke Quay MRT station, purchased for S$41.74m. The buyer, a Singapore-incorporated vehicle owned by Wang Kuncheng, a Chinese citizen from Xiamen city, is reportedly not taking any loans. This acquisition marks the latest in a series of high-profile deals by Fujian buyers, who have been snapping up high-end condominium units, villas, and shophouses in Singapore since around 2017.

site_title: Toyota Q3 net profit soars 50%, hikes full-year outlook
summary: Toyota reported a 50% increase in net profit for the third quarter, reaching 1.90 trillion yen, and upgraded its full-year forecasts for the second consecutive quarter. The company made 838.7 billion yen in the three months to December, compared to 559.3 billion yen a year earlier. Toyota's global sales forecast has been revised to 9.73 million units for the fiscal year, and the company expects to maintain production despite a semiconductor shortage.

site_title: Sats narrows Q3 loss as cargo volumes increase
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based food supplier and gateway services provider, narrowed its Q3 loss to $2.8 million, driven by a 22% increase in cargo revenue. Cargo associates in Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Vietnam returned to profitability, and global cargo volumes are expected to return to pre-pandemic levels by April. Despite the improvement, the company's aviation business remains affected, and revenue declined 54% to $251 million. Sats aims to grow its non-travel revenue, including security services, to mitigate the loss of government relief.

site_title: Malaysia sets retail fuel price ceiling as global crude demand rises
summary: Malaysia's government sets retail fuel price ceilings amid rising global crude demand. Petrol prices will not exceed 2.05 ringgit per liter, while diesel will not exceed 2.15 ringgit per liter. The decision aims to reduce people's cost of living while balancing government subsidy expenditure. The move comes as oil prices rally for a ninth straight day, driven by supply cuts and vaccine rollout hopes. The ceilings are set just months after the government removed earlier price ceilings due to the pandemic's economic impact.

site_title: Lai see, taxis and the future of cash
summary: Hong Kong residents are seeking fresh banknotes for traditional Chinese New Year (CNY) lai see, a custom that reflects a broader preference for cash over digital payments. Despite the high internet penetration rate and digital payments infrastructure, many businesses, including taxi drivers, refuse to accept cards or digital payments. Policymakers should ensure true equivalence between cash and non-cash forms of payment, allowing individuals to choose their preferred method of payment. This balance is crucial for maintaining financial inclusion and respecting cultural traditions.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore waste-management group Sen Yue Holdings' executive chairman Koh Mia Seng may have breached fiduciary duties due to "wilful non-disclosure" of his relationships with seven customers. This led to the company breaching Catalist rules and potentially exposing it to large losses. In contrast, Tiong Seng Holdings, a construction group and property developer, reported expected FY2020 results in a loss position, impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Volunteers for Olympics in virus limbo
summary: Around 9,600 foreign volunteers for the postponed Tokyo Olympics are in limbo due to virus uncertainty, with many facing an agonizing wait for news on the event's fate. The volunteers, who are unpaid and have to pay their own way, have been preparing for the Games since last year, with some already vaccinated. However, the organizers' decision on how to hold the event safely or at all has left many wondering if they will be needed. Some overseas volunteers have already cancelled their trips, while others remain hopeful that the Games will proceed.

site_title: Credit Suisse loses final bid to block auditor appointment in spying saga
summary: Credit Suisse has lost its final bid to block the appointment of auditor Thomas Werlen to review the bank's activities in a spying scandal. The Supreme Court upheld a lower court ruling, stating that most law firms available in Switzerland had represented major banks, rendering the independence criterion too strict. The bank had sought to block Werlen's appointment due to concerns over his firm's independence. The court's decision paves the way for Finma to proceed with its investigation into Credit Suisse's surveillance activities.

site_title: US: Stocks gain after benign inflation report
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday following a benign inflation report, with the Dow Jones up 0.3% and the S&P 500 gaining 0.6%. The Consumer Price Index rose 0.3% in January, suggesting the Federal Reserve will maintain low interest rates. Major indices have hit records this year due to anticipated fiscal stimulus and economic recovery.

site_title: Extended wage support high on Singapore SMEs' wish list
summary: Singapore SMEs prioritize continued wage support and government assistance to protect jobs, with 59% wanting the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) extended in 2021. Companies in wholesale trade, real estate, and hospitality sectors are more keen on government assistance, while those in manufacturing and professional services seek industry partnerships. Smaller SMEs with turnover under S$10 million need financial support, tax incentives, and easier access to funding, while larger SMEs focus on public-private collaboration opportunities and collateral-free loans for business transformation.

site_title: DBS more optimistic about asset quality; Q4 earnings fall 33%
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender, reported a 33% decline in net profit for the fourth quarter ended December 31, 2020, to S$1.01 billion due to lower net interest margin and higher allowances. Despite this, DBS chief Piyush Gupta expressed optimism about asset quality, citing a decrease in loans under moratorium and low delinquencies. Total allowances are expected to be around S$4 billion, with the bank guiding for 2021 net interest income to remain in the 1.45-1.5% range. DBS' shares closed up 7 cents to S$26.

site_title: Australia-Google dispute could break the Internet as we know it
summary: Australia is poised for a potentially catastrophic dispute with Google over a proposed law requiring the tech giant to pay local media outlets for content on its search page. Google has threatened to withdraw from Australia, while Microsoft has expressed willingness to abide by the law. The EU is also exploring similar legislation. The debate highlights the need for a balance between free online content and the financial sustainability of media outlets, but a fractured internet could have far-reaching consequences, including cybersecurity risks.

site_title: More tax perks down the road to promote use of electric cars in Singapore
summary: Singapore has unveiled its Green Plan 2030, aiming to achieve net-zero emissions and enhance the city-state's livability. The plan includes revising the vehicle tax structure to encourage the use of electric cars, with new incentives expected to be introduced. The government also aims to increase EV charging points to 60,000 by 2030 and develop sustainable energy and chemicals parks, as well as a sustainable tourism destination and carbon-services hub. The 10-year plan sets out targets to reduce carbon-intensive investments and promote green growth opportunities, creating new jobs and transforming industries.

site_title: Lunch Actually: Hearts grow fonder amid Covid-19 isolation
summary: Lunch Actually, a Singapore-based dating agency, saw a surge in demand for its virtual-dating services during the COVID-19 pandemic. The agency's CEO, Violet Lim, attributes this to singles seeking meaningful connections. Despite a revenue decline in April, Lunch Actually quickly rebounded and reported an all-time high in Q4 2020. The company continues to offer virtual dates and consultations, believing its digital initiatives could be a long-term success. Revenue has bounced back to pre-pandemic numbers, with over 800 virtual dates arranged last year, according to Lim.

images.alt_text: Dating agency Lunch Actually arranged more than 800 virtual dates in 2020, said chief executive and co-founder Violet Lim.

site_title: Sen Yue's chairman may have breached fiduciary duties, independent review finds
summary: The chairman of Sen Yue Holdings, Koh Mia Seng, may have breached fiduciary duties as a director by wilfully non-disclosing his relationships with seven customers, resulting in breaches of Catalist rules related to interested-person transactions. An independent review found that Koh likely indirectly controlled the customers and caused the company to extend large credit limits, potentially exposing it to large losses. The review also suggested possible fraudulent transactions and criminal offences, including forgery and false sales-and-purchase agreements. Koh was suspended from executive functions in January and redesignated as non-executive chairman.

site_title: Rigs out, green in for Keppel and Sembcorp
summary: Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Industries, two of the world's largest offshore rig builders, are exiting the offshore and marine (O&M) business due to the historic oil crash. The companies will shift their focus to the booming renewable energy sector, seeking out projects from offshore wind or solar farms to gas solutions. Keppel swung into the red with a loss of S$506 million in FY2020, while Sembcorp is expected to incur its first loss in two decades. Industry experts predict a demand recovery for new rigs for at least another five years, making it challenging for rigmakers to turn around.

site_title: PepsiCo renames 'Aunt Jemima' after protests
summary: PepsiCo has renamed the Aunt Jemima brand to Pearl Milling Company, fulfilling a promise made last year amid protests against racism. The name change comes after widespread protests in the US following the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis. The decision was made in collaboration with consumers, employees, and experts to ensure the new brand is developed with inclusivity in mind. The new brand will hit store shelves in June. This move follows a similar decision by Mars to rebrand its Uncle Ben's brand of rice.

site_title: Road freight prices from France to Britain jump 50% in January
summary: Freight prices from France to Britain rose 50% in January compared to the same month last year, according to Transporeon data. The increase is attributed to lorry drivers demanding higher payments to operate in the UK after Brexit, with some drivers setting higher prices in case they have to return with an empty truck due to customs paperwork issues. This follows a 1.7% decrease in December 2020 due to pre-Brexit stockpiling.

site_title: Sats posts S$2.8m net loss for Q3
summary: Sats, a ground-handler and in-flight caterer, reported a net loss of S$2.8 million for Q3 2020, down from a net profit of S$59.3 million a year ago, due to the pandemic's impact on air travel. Revenue fell 54% to S$251 million, with staff costs decreasing by S$144.2 million. Despite the challenges, the company sees opportunities for growth in non-travel related segments and aims to increase revenues from food-service and retail chains.

site_title: Malay-Muslim businesses hope for Budget support to trim costs: poll
summary: Malay-Muslim businesses in Singapore are seeking support in the upcoming Budget 2021, with nearly half hoping to see government assistance in reducing operating costs. Key areas of concern include manpower regulations, rental costs, and business sustainability. A third of respondents also want help with branding their business, while more than half are looking for schemes to enhance manpower capabilities through skills upgrading. The Singapore Malay Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SMCCI) is urging the government to provide "sustained and targeted support" to businesses affected by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: WHO expert panel recommends wide use of AstraZeneca Covid vaccine
summary: A World Health Organization expert panel recommends the widespread use of the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine, despite some efficacy concerns against a South African variant. The vaccine should be administered in two doses with an 8-12 week interval. The panel deemed the benefits outweigh the risks, particularly for those aged 65 and older. The recommendations come after South Africa paused its AstraZeneca rollout due to concerns over its effectiveness against the dominant South African variant.

site_title: Alexa, it's Jeff. How should I spend my time now?
summary: Jeff Bezos, Amazon's founder, is stepping down as CEO, taking on the role of executive chairman and largest shareholder. This move mirrors the legacies of John D Rockefeller and Andrew Carnegie, who stepped back from active management of their companies and shifted focus to philanthropy. Bezos' anti-monopolist critics compare him to Rockefeller, who built an empire through innovative management and cost-conscious principles. Bezos' philanthropic efforts, including the $10 billion Bezos Earth Fund and the $2 billion Bezos Day One Fund, may redefine his public image, following in the footsteps of Rockefeller and Carnegie, who transformed their public image through extensive philanthropy.

site_title: GIC teams up with Chinese asset manager for Philips' home appliances bid: sources
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has teamed up with Chinese asset manager CDH Investments to submit a joint offer for Philips' US$3.6 billion home appliance business. The duo faces competition from Hillhouse Capital and a consortium of Citic Capital, Sequoia, and TCL Capital. Philips has put pressure on bidders to finalize their offers by the end of March, with the possibility of an alternative listing or IPO if deals are delayed. The sale is part of Philips' transformation into a health technology business, with the home appliance unit valued at about US$3.64 billion.

site_title: 22-year-old construction worker at Bedok dorm is sole dormitory case
summary: A 22-year-old Bangladesh construction worker at a Bedok dormitory in Singapore has tested positive for Covid-19, marking the sole case from migrant worker dormitories. The worker, who was asymptomatic, had negative test results prior to his infection. He was isolated after a positive serology test result and his close contacts were placed on quarantine. Meanwhile, 14 imported cases were confirmed, bringing Singapore's total to 59,747, with 20 cases discharged and 36 patients in hospital.

site_title: Singapore Budget to provide targeted support, avoid hurting attractiveness to HNWIs: Deloitte
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 is expected to provide targeted support while maintaining its attractiveness to high net worth individuals (HNWIs). The government is unlikely to extend the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) and Jobs Growth Incentive (JGI) to all sectors, with potential scaling down of the latter. Instead, efforts will focus on domestic spending through credits or rebates. Tax changes are expected to be minimal, with a focus on reducing tax leakages and potentially raising the carbon tax rate. The government aims to boost revenue without hurting its advantage in attracting HNWIs.

site_title: TikTok sale to Walmart, Oracle shelved amid Biden review: WSJ
summary: The US government has indefinitely shelved a deal to sell TikTok to Walmart and Oracle amid a review of national security risks posed by Chinese technology companies under the Biden administration. The decision comes after multiple legal challenges to former President Donald Trump's executive order ordering the sale of TikTok due to concerns over user data falling into Chinese authorities' hands. A potential deal may still involve Oracle, Walmart, and other companies, but its details are uncertain as the Biden administration assesses the risks of Chinese technology companies and data collection.

site_title: UBS looks to double workforce in booming private credit unit
summary: UBS is expanding its private credit unit, O'Connor Capital Solutions, with plans to double its workforce to 12 by the end of Q1 2021. The unit, which oversees over $2 billion in assets, is capitalizing on a growing demand for private credit in the US$890 billion industry. Co-head Rodrigo Trelles attributes the unit's success to its focus on less crowded areas of the market, such as specialty finance and heavily collateralized deals. The team expects a "great vintage" for private credit and sees opportunities for differentiated solutions and attractive returns.

site_title: KPMG boss sorry for 'moaning' jibe at audit staff
summary: UK KPMG chairman Bill Michael has apologized for telling staff to "stop moaning" about working conditions during the pandemic, amid concerns over potential pay cuts. Michael acknowledged that his words did not reflect his true values and apologized to colleagues. This comes as UK authorities are pushing for the separation of audit and consulting activities among the Big Four accountants, amid allegations of malpractice. Michael emphasized the importance of employee wellbeing and culture, but his initial response was widely criticized.

site_title: Covid situation stable, but maintain safe distancing: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the country's Covid-19 situation has stabilized, thanks to its efforts in controlling the spread, treating infected individuals, and preventing the healthcare system from being overwhelmed. Lee emphasized the importance of maintaining safe distancing measures, even for those vaccinated, as the virus is still spreading globally. The government is also prioritizing vaccination efforts, aiming to offer the vaccine to the entire population within this year. Lee expressed gratitude to Singaporeans for their support during the pandemic and called on them to show appreciation for essential workers making sacrifices during the festive period.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.91% to 30,038.72. This follows a recent rally fueled by hopes for easing of containment measures as coronavirus infection rates slow and vaccines are rolled out. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw significant gains, rising 1.43% and 1.75% respectively. The strong performance is attributed to the improving market sentiment and the rollout of vaccines.

site_title: Sterling breaks above US$1.38 supported by vaccine push
summary: Sterling breaks above US$1.38, its highest level in almost three years, due to Britain's speedy coronavirus inoculation programme and optimism over the UK's economic recovery. The pound has gained 0.2% against the dollar and 0.2% against the euro. The Bank of England's upbeat forecast that the British economy will regain its pre-pandemic size by the first quarter of 2022 also supports the currency. Despite Brexit-related concerns, the pound's gains are seen as a sign of relief and hope for a fast economic recovery.

site_title: Musk's bitcoin bet fuels gains in companies already invested
summary: Tesla's $1.5 billion investment in bitcoin has fueled gains in companies already invested in the digital currency, with shares of companies like MicroStrategy and Mogo surging 22% and 45% respectively. Bitcoin's price has quadrupled in the past four months, driven in part by interest from institutional investors, and is now seen as a mainstream financial asset. The investment has bolstered bitcoin's emerging credentials, with some investors viewing it as a hedge against inflation.

site_title: Myanmar junta leader asks Thai counterpart for help on democracy
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha has received a letter from Myanmar's junta leader Min Aung Hlaing seeking help to support democracy, amid widespread protests against the military coup that ousted Aung San Suu Kyi. Pro-democracy protesters have appealed to Chinese President Xi Jinping to withdraw support for the military, while demonstrators gathered outside Chinese and UN embassies to build international support for the return of a civilian government. The situation remains volatile, with security forces using force to disperse protesters and at least one protester critically injured.

site_title: Italy police make major mafia drugs bust
summary: Italian police seized 1.3 tonnes of cocaine, worth 260 million euros, from the southern port of Gioia Tauro, controlled by the powerful 'Ndrangheta mafia. The cocaine was hidden among coffee, frozen meat, and exotic fruit from Brazil and Ecuador. The 'Ndrangheta, Italy's most powerful organized crime group, has been involved in international drug trafficking, extortion, and money laundering. Police say the group's methods of concealing drugs are evolving, requiring constant surveillance and detection tactics. The bust is a significant blow to the mafia, with the seized cocaine having the potential to be cut up to four times before reaching the market.

images.alt_text: Italian police said Wednesday they had seized 1.3 tonnes of cocaine in the past week from the southern port of Gioia Tauro, a major narcotics entry-point controlled by the 'Ndrangheta mafia.

site_title: Help with lowering operating costs tops Malay-Muslim businesses' Budget wish list
summary: Malay-Muslim businesses in Singapore are prioritizing cost reduction and support in the upcoming Budget 2021. Nearly half of respondents in a survey by the Singapore Malay Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SMCCI) cited this as a top wish, along with easing manpower regulations, reducing rental costs, and ensuring business sustainability. The survey also highlighted concerns over rising labor and rental costs, employability, and business sustainability. The SMCCI hopes the Budget will provide sustained and targeted support to businesses affected by the Covid-19 pandemic and aid companies looking to transform amid the economic recovery.

site_title: Singapore government's Green Plan offers new jobs and economic growth
summary: Singapore's Green Plan aims to make the country a sustainable energy and chemicals park, a carbon services hub, and a green finance center by 2030. The plan seeks to create new jobs, transform industries, and harness sustainability as a competitive advantage. Key initiatives include developing low-carbon hydrogen, carbon capture technologies, and supporting local enterprises to adopt sustainability practices. The government also plans to review the carbon tax by 2023, with MPs on both sides supporting the move. The plan is spearheaded by several ministries and aims to position Singapore as a leader in sustainability efforts in Asia.

site_title: Thai pro-democracy groups to intensify protests as leaders charged
summary: Thai pro-democracy groups have vowed to intensify protests against the monarchy and demand a new constitution after four leaders were charged with royal defamation. The detained leaders, including a lawyer and student leader, were denied bail, sparking warnings that authorities are adopting a confrontational stance. Protests will resume in central Bangkok, putting pressure on Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha's government, which faces a no-confidence vote next week and economic challenges. The government has defended its actions, citing existing laws, but critics warn of a return to "dark days" of repression.

site_title: Thai protests resume, taking aim at royal insults law
summary: Hundreds of protesters gathered in Bangkok, demanding the release of four activists jailed for insulting Thailand's king, a crime punishable by 15 years in prison. The demonstration, which started as a solidarity show with Myanmar's pro-democracy movement, has morphed into calls to change or end the strict "lese majeste" law. The protests, which resumed after a brief pause, have three demands: ousting Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha, rewriting the military-backed constitution, and reforming the monarchy. The protesters, led by youth activists, plan to continue their demonstrations, citing events in Myanmar as inspiration for their movement.

images.alt_text: Hundreds of protesters gathered in Bangkok on Wednesday to demand the release of four activists jailed a day earlier pending their trial for insulting Thailand's king, a crime punishable by 15 years in prison.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 10.72 points higher at 1,596.85 on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 4.84 billion lots worth RM3.615 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 628 to 504.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge up on sound earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks rose marginally on Wednesday, driven by sound corporate earnings reports, particularly from Toyota. The Nikkei 225 index increased 0.19% to 29,562.93, while the Topix index rose 0.27% to 1,930.82. This follows a surge to three-decade highs.

site_title: Macquarie raises almost US$2b for renewable energy fund
summary: Macquarie Group's Green Investment Group raised 1.6 billion euros (approximately US$2.57 billion) for its renewable energy fund, exceeding its target. The fund received commitments from 32 pension funds, insurers, and sovereign wealth funds from the UK, Germany, and other countries. The 25-year closed-end fund will invest in wind and solar projects across western Europe, the US, and Asia. This follows the launch of similar solar energy firms in Europe, North America, and Asia-Pacific, and marks a significant step in the global transition to clean energy.

site_title: 15 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including one in workers' dorms
summary: Singapore reported 15 new COVID-19 cases, including one in a migrant workers' dormitory, bringing the total to 59,747. All 15 cases are imported, with 14 tested positive while serving stay-home notices and one confirmed on a Singapore Airlines flight. The cases, including a 41-year-old cabin crew member, have also been preliminarily classified as infected with the B117 strain. Close contacts have been isolated and quarantined, and the air stewardess has received her first dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.

site_title: Singtel sees fall in Q3 earnings, logs revenue recovery for second straight quarter
summary: Singtel reported a fall in Q3 earnings, with operating revenue and Ebitda down 3.2% and 13.5% year-over-year, respectively. However, the company experienced revenue recovery for the second consecutive quarter, driven by higher equipment sales and strong demand for premium handsets. Operating revenue for the Singapore consumer business fell 10.8% due to reduced roaming and prepaid services, while Ebitda for the business segment declined 21.8%. The company remains optimistic about its growth potential, particularly with its 5G rollout and digital services expansion.

site_title: Myanmar economy expected to grow despite coup impact on FDI: analysts
summary: Myanmar's economy is expected to grow despite the impact of the recent military coup, with analysts forecasting a 3% GDP growth in FY2020/21 and 4% in FY2021/22. However, foreign direct investment (FDI) is a major concern, with Fitch Solutions cutting its GDP growth forecast to 2% due to potential sanctions from the US and EU. Despite this, economists believe the economy will not slip into recession, citing the country's growing reliance on regional trade and limited exposure to Western economies.

site_title: Rocket Internet co-founder files for US$250m tech SPAC
summary: Rocket Internet's co-founder Oliver Samwer is filing for a US$250m technology special-purpose acquisition vehicle (SPAC) called Rocket Internet Growth Opportunities Corp. The company, which will be listed on the New York Stock Exchange, will focus on enterprise software, AI, and e-commerce investments. The SPAC will sell 25 million units at $10 each, with warrants redeemable for $11.50. This move comes as Rocket Internet seeks to take the company private after its shares declined over the past year. The filing is part of a growing trend of SPAC filings in the tech sector.

site_title: Gojek and Tokopedia merger: Why now and what challenges lie ahead
summary: Indonesia's Gojek and Tokopedia are finalizing a merger, aiming for a valuation of $35-$40 billion. The union could create a powerhouse in Southeast Asia, rivaling companies like Sea Ltd. The merger is seen as beneficial for both firms, with natural synergies in e-commerce, logistics, and financial services. Industry sources believe it will also make the combined entity a credible acquirer of younger startups. However, challenges lie ahead, including increased competition from regional players like Sea and Grab, and the need for a cohesive post-merger strategy to succeed.

site_title: Seoul: Shares gains on upbeat news around virus treatment; log weekly loss
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.52% to 3,100.58 on Wednesday, driven by approval of a coronavirus vaccine and an emergency use authorization for an Eli Lilly antibody therapy. The Kospi index declined 0.6% for the week. The Korean won strengthened, while the benchmark bond yield rose. The government granted approval for a coronavirus vaccine to people 65 years or older, and Eli Lilly's antibody therapy was granted emergency use authorization by the US FDA. Local data showed a 21-year high unemployment rate in January.

site_title: SocGen beats profit forecasts despite lag in debt trading
summary: Societe Generale (SocGen) reported a net income of 470 million euros in the fourth quarter, beating forecasts despite a 28% drop in net income and a 6% decline in revenue. The bank attributed the better-than-expected result to lower-than-expected charges linked to the Covid-19 pandemic. SocGen's cost of risk rose 85.7% year-over-year, but analysts had forecast a higher increase. The bank expects economies to recover gradually this year, with bad loan provisions expected to fall.

site_title: Bus, train ridership in Singapore falls to 11-year low amid Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Singapore's bus and train ridership plummeted to an 11-year low in 2020, with an average daily ridership of 5.04 million, a 34.5% decline. Trains bore the brunt of the drop, with MRT and LRT rides falling 41% to 2.162 million daily. The decline was attributed to the Covid-19 pandemic, which led to widespread work-from-home arrangements.

site_title: SF Holding seeking to take over tycoon Robert Kuok's Kerry Logistics for HK$17.6b
summary: SF Holding, a Chinese package-delivery service, is seeking to acquire a 51.8% stake in Hong Kong-listed Kerry Logistics Network for HK$17.6 billion, aiming to boost its global expansion. The deal, conditional on the sale of some warehouse assets and Taiwan business, will give SF Holding control of Kerry Logistics while keeping the company listed in Hong Kong. The acquisition is expected to boost SF Holding's distribution network and supply-chain services, and its shares have more than doubled over the past 12 months, surpassing FedEx Corp in value.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: European stocks remained steady at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.2% at 6,546.33 points. In the eurozone, Paris' CAC 40 added 0.1%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index was marginally lower. Meanwhile, US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Fed views. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq both reached new highs.

site_title: Australia: Tech stocks drive shares higher; NZ down
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.52% to 6,856.9, driven by tech stocks reaching a record high, with shares in Afterpay and Zip Co increasing 4% and 12.2% respectively. Insurance Australia's earnings beat estimates, while Northern Star Resources' net profit jumped 46%. In contrast, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia's net profit fell, but its dividend was higher than expected. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.8% due to weak domestic earnings.

site_title: Toyota posts 54% rise in Q3 operating profit, hikes full-year forecast
summary: Toyota Motor Corp reported a 54% jump in Q3 operating profit to 987.9 billion yen, exceeding analysts' estimates. The company also raised its full-year forecast to a record 2 trillion yen, surpassing previous predictions. This is the highest forecast among 23 analysts, indicating a strong rebound in demand for cars as the pandemic recedes, particularly in China.

site_title: Heineken to cut 8,000 jobs as virus takes fizz out of sales
