Resale volumes increased 8.6% to 1,587 units, with the OCR and RCR seeing significant price increases.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index hits new 30-year high
summary: Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225 index reached a new 30-year high, closing at 29,505.93 after gaining 0.40% or 117.43 points. The move followed Wall Street gains, driven by hopes for additional stimulus. The broader Topix index also advanced 0.08%. The rally was driven by global market sentiment, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Japan's benchmark Nikkei index climbed to a new 30-year high Tuesday, tracking Wall Street gains on hopes for additional stimulus.

site_title: Mongolia seeks more tax revenue from Rio copper mine expansion: source
summary: Mongolia is seeking a revised deal with Rio Tinto to expand the Oyu Tolgoi copper-gold mine, aiming for more tax revenue rather than a larger ownership stake. The government is concerned that the economic benefits of the mine's development have been eroded due to increased costs. Under current plans, Mongolia won't receive dividends until 2051, and the mine won't pay "meaningful" corporate income tax. Government representatives met with Rio's head of copper operations to discuss the plans and work towards a resolution.

site_title: Zaobao launches Lohei Butler, to give free access to online content over CNY weekend
summary: Lianhe Zaobao launched Lohei Butler, an online tool that plays auspicious cheers during Chinese New Year, and made its first-ever publication on the first day of the year. All readers have free access to premium content on zaobao.sg, including e-papers, over the Chinese New Year weekend. Zaobao has also lined up various programs, including a livestream countdown, an online music program, and a premiere of the show "Joys of Spring" on February 16. The move aims to cater to readers staying home due to the pandemic, offering a variety of content to keep them entertained.

site_title: Virus jabs for all regardless of immigration status, says UK
summary: The UK government has stated that undocumented migrants in Britain can register with doctors and access free frontline medical care, including Covid-19 vaccinations, without being subject to immigration status checks. The health ministry has informed NHS officials that those receiving vaccinations are not subject to immigration checks. The move aims to increase vaccination rates among vulnerable populations, including those from black African and south Asian communities, which have been disproportionately affected by the pandemic.

site_title: Online's share of Britain's grocery market hits record 16%: Nielsen
summary: The online share of Britain's grocery market hit a record 16% in January, up from 8% in the same month last year, driven by increased demand during the country's third Covid-19 lockdown. This growth was fueled by 1.4 billion pounds spent online, a year-on-year increase of 121%. One in three British households shopped online, with 770 million pounds coming from new online shoppers. Total UK grocery sales rose 10.6% year-on-year, with Morrisons being the best performer among the big four grocers.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts reiterate 'buy' on Yangzijiang after contract wins
summary: Analysts from CGS-CIMB, DBS Group Research, and UOB Kay Hian have reiterated their "buy" calls on Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, citing recent US$1.3 billion contract wins. DBS analyst Ho Pei Hwa expects more containership orders in H1 and potentially bulk carrier orders in H2, revising up the company's order wins assumption to over US$3 billion for the year. Yangzijiang's order wins represent 72% of the analyst's conservative target, indicating a buoyant newbuilding market and making it an "underappreciated proxy to the shipping boom".

site_title: San Francisco traffic drop shows petrol rebound still elusive
summary: San Francisco traffic slowed further in January, with 8.6 million vehicles crossing toll bridges, a 3.2% drop from December. This follows a slump in Los Angeles and 20-30% lower daily traffic compared to last year. California's strict lockdown measures have contributed to the decline in fuel demand, with the US four-week average for gasoline demand dropping to 7.8 million barrels a day, the lowest for this time of year. Despite some optimism in refined petroleum product flows, a rebound in petrol prices remains elusive.

site_title: JPMorgan's Aguzin said to be named CEO of Hong Kong Exchange
summary: Nicolas Aguzin, head of JPMorgan Chase's international private bank, is set to become CEO of Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing, succeeding Charles Li, who left at the end of last year. Aguzin, a former JPMorgan Asia Pacific chairman and CEO, has a strong connection to the region and is well-versed in navigating China's financial landscape. He will need to balance linking the exchange to China with increased competition from mainland bourses, and faces the challenge of expanding the link to include benchmark stocks.

site_title: Corn and soya bulls look to new US forecast to sustain sizzle
summary: US corn and soybean inventories are expected to drop 11% and 14% respectively in the Agriculture Department's monthly World Agricultural Supply and Demand Estimates, according to analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News. China, the world's biggest buyer of commodities, is purchasing large quantities of US grains, leading to concerns that US supplies may reach fresh multi-year lows. The price surges are raising concerns about global food inflation.

site_title: Record profits for South Korea's Kakao as founder pledges giveaway
summary: Kakao Corp, South Korea's largest mobile messenger operator, reported record quarterly profits of 150 billion won, a 88.3% year-on-year surge, due to the COVID-19 pandemic's boost to the tech industry. Founder Kim Beom-su pledged to donate more than half of his $9.5 billion assets to solve social issues. The company's sales jumped 45.7% on-year to 1.24 trillion won, with operating income also at a record. Kakao Corp shares rose 1.2% in morning trade.

site_title: Koh Boon Hwee to step down as NTU chairman after 28 years
summary: Nanyang Technological University (NTU) announced that chairman Koh Boon Hwee will step down on March 31 after 28 years of service. He will be succeeded by Goh Swee Chen, who has extensive global experience in diverse fields. Under Koh's guidance, NTU progressed from six to 15 schools, welcomed its first medical school in 2013, and increased its QS World University Rankings from 74th to 13th place. Minister for Education Lawrence Wong praised Koh's contributions to NTU, calling him a visionary leader who transformed the university into a world-class institution.

site_title: Fuel-cell truck startup Hyzon's SPAC merger includes US$400m investment
summary: Hyzon Motors, a fuel-cell truck startup, has agreed to merge with Decarbonization Plus Acquisition Corp, a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC), in a deal worth US$626 million. The transaction includes a US$400 million investment from a group of investors including BlackRock, Fidelity, and Wellington Management. The deal would make Hyzon the latest clean-energy vehicle startup to consider a SPAC merger, following Nikola Corp's recent IPO. Hyzon expects to deliver 5,000 fuel cell-powered trucks and buses by 2023 and is targeting annual capacity of 40,000 fuel cell-electric vehicles by 2025.

site_title: Thailand bets on Chinese shots to start rollout by month end
summary: Thailand plans to start its COVID-19 vaccine rollout using Chinese Sinovac Biotech Ltd's shots, with the first shipment of 200,000 doses expected to arrive by the end of the month. The Thai drug regulator is expected to approve the shots for emergency use in parallel. The bulk of the nation's vaccine needs will be met from AstraZeneca Plc's locally produced shots. The vaccine rollout aims to cover two-thirds of the eligible population by the end of the year, potentially paving the way for a full reopening of the tourism industry and economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Thailand will rely on Covid-19 vaccines from China's Sinovac Biotech Ltd to kick off an inoculation drive that aims to cover about two-thirds of the nation's eligible population by the end of this year, potentially paving the way for a full reopening of its tourism industry.

site_title: Family sues trading app Robinhood over suicide
summary: A family of a 20-year-old college student who killed himself after losing a fortune on the trading app Robinhood has sued the company. The student, Alex Kearns, had no income but accessed nearly $1 million in financial leverage through Robinhood. The lawsuit alleges Robinhood's website enticed inexperienced users with a "video game-like" experience, causing Kearns' death and unfair business practices. Robinhood has improved trading features and education, but the family seeks unspecified damages, claiming the app's communications were misleading and Kearns did not owe any money.

site_title: India to be largest source of energy demand growth to 2040: IEA
summary: India is expected to be the world's third-largest energy consumer by 2030 and the largest source of energy demand growth from 2020 to 2040, according to the International Energy Agency (IEA). The country's energy consumption is projected to nearly double by 2040, driven by its rapid GDP growth. India's oil demand is expected to rise to 8.7 million barrels per day, while its reliance on fossil fuels is expected to increase, with oil imports projected to reach 92% by 2040.

images.alt_text: India will make up the biggest share of energy demand growth at 25 per cent over the next two decades, as it overtakes the European Union as the world's third-biggest energy consumer by 2030.

site_title: Canadian province Alberta backs down on opening Rockies to coal mines
summary: The Canadian province of Alberta has reversed a decision to expand access to the eastern Rocky Mountains for open-pit coal mines, following backlash from ranchers and residents. The move comes amid the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on Alberta's oil-and-gas economy and Premier Jason Kenney's declining popularity. Exploration for six previously approved coal projects will continue, with further regulatory review required to begin production. The government will also consult the public and approve no further coal exploration applications in eastern Rockies lands until a new coal policy is developed.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares kick off with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Tuesday on a positive note, extending their recent rally, as US lawmakers edged closer to a new stimulus for the world's top economy. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.42% to 29,442.50, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. The gains follow a record close in New York and come amid uncertainty over US tariffs.

site_title: Time to wear a better mask, experts say
summary: Experts urge wearing a medical-grade respirator or a combination of surgical and cloth masks due to the spread of more transmissible COVID-19 variants. These variants, like B.1.1.7, require a smaller viral load to cause symptoms, increasing transmission risk. Scientists agree that airborne transmission is the primary mode of virus spread, not surface transmission. The use of a better mask is recommended to mitigate the risk of infection.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street records on reopening hopes
summary: Asia's stocks rose on Tuesday following Wall Street's record-breaking performance, driven by optimism over global economic recovery as vaccinations and stimulus packages are rolled out. Despite concerns over valuations, investors remain hopeful for a strong rally. The US$1.9 trillion rescue bill is nearing passage, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Number of newborns in China drops 15% in 2020 as coronavirus weighs
summary: China saw a 15% drop in newborns in 2020, with 10.035 million births, compared to 11.79 million in 2019. The novel coronavirus disrupted the economy and influenced family decisions. The country's birth rate has been declining for years due to rising healthcare, education, and housing costs. With about 250 million people aged 60 and above, rapid ageing poses policy challenges for Chinese leaders. The National Bureau of Statistics is expected to release official 2020 population data in late February.

site_title: East Ventures appoints Pavilion Capital's Koh Wai Kit as venture partner
summary: East Ventures, a venture capital firm, has appointed Koh Wai Kit, a founding member of Pavilion Capital, as a venture partner. Koh brings over a decade of investment experience and expertise to East Ventures, having previously spearheaded investments in Asia and served at Temasek. This appointment strengthens East Ventures' team, following its support of over 180 companies in South-east Asia, including Indonesian unicorns Tokopedia and Traveloka.

site_title: Gold gains as dollar extends slide, stimulus hopes firm
summary: Gold prices rose to a near one-week high on Tuesday, up 0.6% to $1,841.11 per ounce, due to the dollar's slide and expectations of a US fiscal stimulus package. The US$1.9 trillion Covid-19 relief package is expected to pass through Congress before March 15, boosting confidence in gold as a hedge against inflation and currency debasement. Other precious metals, including silver, palladium, and platinum, also gained.

site_title: SME lender Funding Societies expands to Thailand
summary: Funding Societies, a digital SME financing platform, has launched in Thailand, its fourth market in six years of operations. The platform, which operates under a debt-crowdfunding license, will provide short-term financing solutions to Thai SMEs, funded by retail and institutional investors. The expansion aims to address the US$250 billion SME credit gap in Asean's biggest economies, with the platform having disbursed over US$1.4 billion in financing across 65,000 SMEs in the region.

site_title: Australia: Shares dip as earnings trickle in; New Zealand down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% to 6,853.00, despite strong quarterly earnings from Macquarie Group and James Hardie. Investors remain cautious ahead of the domestic earnings season, anticipating devastation in sectors like hospitality and travel. Energy stocks gained, while healthcare stocks slid to a one-week low. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.4% to 13,007.29, with Fisher & Paykel Healthcare and Serko among top losers.

site_title: Macquarie says commodities trading business sees sharp Q3 profit increase, shares up nearly 8%
summary: Macquarie Group, Australia's largest investment bank and asset manager, reported a sharp increase in third-quarter profit from its commodities trading and dealmaking units, with shares rising nearly 8%. Strong hedging and trading activity in commodities markets, driven by high volatility in oil, gas, and precious metals, contributed to the increase. CEO Shemara Wikramanayake expects the second half to be more favorable, with full-year earnings forecast to be slightly lower than in fiscal 2020, potentially down 5%.

site_title: New Zealand suspends Myanmar political, military ties after coup
summary: New Zealand has suspended high-level military and political ties with Myanmar following the country's military coup, which detained civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi and dozens of her party members. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern called for international condemnation and said New Zealand would hold a special session at the UN Human Rights Council to discuss developments in Myanmar. The country will also continue its aid programs with safeguards to prevent military control. This move is seen as a major international response to the coup, with New Zealand being the first major country to take such action.

site_title: Reddit's valuation doubles to US$6b after new US$250m funding
summary: Reddit has doubled its valuation to US$6 billion after securing US$250 million in new funding. The social media company reported a 90% increase in advertising revenue in the last quarter. CEO Steve Huffman stated that valuations are high, making it a good opportunity to raise funds. The funding round follows a recent social media-driven retail trading frenzy surrounding Reddit.

site_title: Sustainable schemes for debt relief key to narrowing rich-poor chasm: study
summary: A new study emphasizes the importance of sustainable debt relief schemes in narrowing the rich-poor gap in Singapore. The Covid-19 pandemic has exacerbated income inequality, and debt relief programs will be crucial when temporary measures end. The study suggests sharing ownership between beneficiaries, charities, and social service organizations to improve financial sustainability. This approach can help low-income households escape poverty and reduce the income gap.

site_title: UK coronavirus variant rapidly spreading in US, study shows
summary: A new study reveals that the UK's B.1.1.7 coronavirus variant is rapidly spreading in the US, doubling in prevalence every 10 days. The variant, first introduced in November 2020, is more contagious and has been observed in multiple European countries. The US, with over 27 million confirmed cases, is at risk of a new surge, with Florida being particularly affected. Current vaccines remain effective, and masks can drastically reduce transmission, but experts urge continued public health measures and vaccination efforts to mitigate the spread.

site_title: Austrian hairdressers reopen but Covid-19 rules ruffle some
summary: Austrian hairdressers reopened on Monday after a six-week lockdown, but new COVID-19 rules, including a 1:20 customer-to-space ratio and a 48-hour-old negative test requirement, have caused some inconvenience. Despite the loosening of lockdown measures, infection numbers remain high, and some hairdressers are struggling to adapt to the new rules, which may discourage elderly customers. The conservative government argues that the economic and social toll of lockdowns outweigh the risks of the virus.

site_title: Tesla Singapore sales portal goes 'live'
summary: Tesla's Singapore sales portal has launched, a day after estimated prices of its cars were listed by The Straits Times. The portal offers the Tesla Model 3 Performance at around S$155,000 and the Model 3 Standard Range at S$113,000 before Certificate of Entitlement (COE). The launch follows years of speculation and comes after Tesla's CEO, Elon Musk, took jibes at Singapore on Twitter for not being supportive of electric vehicles. This marks Tesla's return to Singapore after a 10-year absence, coinciding with the government's plans to expand the EV charging network and introduce greener vehicle incentives.

site_title: Hong Kong's top court denies bail to media tycoon Jimmy Lai
summary: Hong Kong's top court denied bail to media tycoon Jimmy Lai, siding with prosecutors in the first test of Beijing's national security law. Lai, 73, is charged with "colluding with foreign forces" for calling for sanctions against Hong Kong and China. The decision cements the law's impact on Hong Kong's common law traditions and raises concerns about the judiciary's role in enforcing Beijing's will. Lai is one of over 100 activists arrested under the law since its enactment in June, and his case is seen as a key indicator of the law's effectiveness in suppressing dissent in the semi-autonomous territory.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's top court on Tuesday ordered pro-democracy media tycoon Jimmy Lai to stay behind bars as it sided with prosecutors in the first legal test of Beijing's sweeping new national security law.

site_title: Japan says its world-class health system is buckling under Covid
summary: Japan's highly-rated health system is facing strain due to the COVID-19 pandemic, despite having a relatively small caseload of around 400,000 infections. Reports of overwhelmed hospitals and deaths from mild infections have raised concern, with the government extending a state of emergency in Tokyo and other regions. The system's strengths, such as its private hospitals, have worked against it, with many lacking the flexibility to respond quickly and a shortage of doctors compared to hospital beds. The government is now subsidizing hospitals and converting some public hospitals to Covid-only treatment centers to address the issue.

images.alt_text: Coronavirus infections in Japan are at a fraction of major western countries, yet the island nation is signaling increasing concern that its highly rated medical system faces impending collapse.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by hopes for additional stimulus and the start of Japan's vaccination campaign. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.17% and the Topix Index gained 0.14%. Market gains were also influenced by Wall Street's rise, despite ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Broker's take: UOBKH downgrades iFast to 'sell', maintains S$5.12 target
summary: Brokerage UOB Kay Hian downgraded iFast Corporation to "sell" from "hold" citing valuation concerns, maintaining a target price of S$5.12. The downgrade comes after iFast reported Q4 financial results in line with expectations, but with a lower-than-expected dividend payout ratio. Analysts at UOBKH remain optimistic on iFast's assets under administration growth, which they believe will contribute to topline expansion. Other brokers, CGS-CIMB and DBS, have maintained "hold" and "buy" calls on iFast, respectively, with target prices ranging from S$4.15 to S$7.64.

site_title: Bain, Cinven buy Lonza Specialty Ingredients in S$6.25b deal
summary: Bain Capital and Cinven have acquired Lonza's Specialty Ingredients division in a S$6.25 billion deal. Lonza, a Swiss contract drug maker, is focusing on its faster-growing unit that supplies drug and biotech companies. The sale will allow Lonza to double down on its accelerating drug business, with customers including Moderna and AstraZeneca. The deal's enterprise value is 4.2 billion Swiss francs, and the sale will provide Lonza with free cash flows to accelerate its strategic priorities.

site_title: Razer co-founder and director Lim Kaling pulls out of Myanmar joint venture
summary: Razer co-founder and director Lim Kaling is selling his one-third stake in a joint venture owning a Singapore-based tobacco company that holds 49% of Virginia Tobacco Co Ltd, a market leader in Myanmar's tobacco market. Lim cited "grave concern" over recent events in Myanmar, leading him to exit his investment and explore responsible disposal options. This move comes after a nearly three-decade-old investment in Myanmar aimed at spurring economic growth and job creation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 10.51 points higher, or 0.67%, at 1,583.84 on Tuesday, with 1.16 billion lots traded worth RM538.34 million. Gainers beat losers 405 to 226.

site_title: State oil companies' spending seen clashing with climate targets
summary: National oil companies worldwide are set to spend $414 billion on high-cost projects over the next decade, which will only be profitable if emission targets are missed. About $295 billion requires a high oil price of at least $40 a barrel to break even, while the remainder needs $50 to $70. This spending poses a problem for climate protection, as it could lead to increased emissions if prices remain low. State oil companies, which produce half the world's oil and gas, may expand production if international companies reduce output to meet climate goals, posing economic risks.

images.alt_text: National oil companies around the world are set to spend hundreds of billions of dollars on high-cost projects that will only be profitable if emission targets are missed, according to a US-based think tank.

site_title: Singapore ranks 1st in digital inclusiveness, but South-east Asia lags: report
summary: Singapore maintains its top spot for digital inclusiveness in the 2020 Digital Inclusion Index, scoring high in accessibility and attitude, but South-east Asia lags behind globally. The region, comprising 82 countries, ranks fifth among seven global regions, with most countries scoring low in affordability and ability. The report highlights a significant digital divide, with 150 million adults in South-east Asia excluded from digital technologies. The region's low-income populations, rural communities, and illiterate individuals are most susceptible to digital exclusion, with the potential for reduced economic growth and social cohesion if the digital divide is not bridged.

site_title: Facebook ramps up effort to curb vaccine hoaxes
summary: Facebook is increasing efforts to combat COVID-19 vaccine misinformation by banning groups spreading false claims and removing related content. The platform has partnered with the World Health Organization to update a list of debunked claims. People in charge of groups will be required to approve posts before sharing. Additionally, Facebook's survey program, which gathered over 50 million responses, will provide insights into vaccine attitudes across demographics. The survey findings will be shared globally, helping researchers better understand trends in vaccine intent. Facebook will also use automated search tools to make it harder to find accounts discouraging vaccinations.

site_title: Australia's Blue Mountains hit by Chinese New Year slump in Asian visitors
summary: The Blue Mountains in Australia are experiencing a significant decline in visitors due to the country's border closures during the Chinese New Year, a major tourist season. Normally, the area attracts over 600,000 international visitors, but this year, only a handful of people are present. Tourism operators, such as Scenic World and the Blue Mountains Explorer Bus Company, are operating at a fraction of their usual capacity, resulting in substantial revenue losses. Locals are relieved to see fewer tourists, but the decline is expected to have a lasting impact on the area's economy.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher for sixth straight session; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher for the sixth consecutive session, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.8% or 22.55 points at 2,953.95. The gains followed Wall Street's record highs on Monday, driven by hopes for additional stimulus. Banking stocks rose, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC increasing 1%, 0.7%, and 0.7% respectively. Other actively traded securities included Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Thomson Medical, and The Place Holdings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also reached all-time highs, with the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1%.

site_title: Ho Ching to retire as Temasek CEO; Dilhan Pillay to take over on Oct 1
summary: Temasek Holdings' CEO Ho Ching will retire on October 1, succeeded by Dilhan Pillay Sandrasegara. Pillay, a corporate lawyer, has been with Temasek since 2011 and previously led its Americas office. Ho Ching led the group's transformation from a passive owner to a globally recognized investor, but its one-year total shareholder return fell to -2.28% in 2020. Lee Theng Kiat will also retire as executive director and chairman of Temasek International.

site_title: Hot stock: Yangzijiang soars 6.7% on new orders worth US$1.3b
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding announced on Monday that it has secured agreements to build and deliver 29 vessels worth approximately US$1.3 billion. The vessels include 22 containerships worth US$1.13 billion, expected to be delivered from the third quarter of next year. This news led to a 6.7% surge in the company's shares, with 57.1 million shares changing hands. According to the company, the new orders are a sign of market recovery and demand, with revenue visibility expected for at least two years.

site_title: Australian business confidence improves in Jan, activity off highs
summary: Australian business confidence improved in January, with the National Australia Bank's index doubling to +10 points from +5 in December. Conditions eased to +7, still above its long-run average of +6. Employment conditions remained positive at +3, and the labour market has recovered faster than expected. Capacity utilisation edged up to 81.0%, and investment firmed to +1. Business confidence is seen as a positive sign, but conditions are still not at historic highs due to ongoing coronavirus-related disruptions.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust to sell Somerset Xu Hui Shanghai above book value
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) agreed to sell Somerset Xu Hui Shanghai for 1.05 billion yuan (S$215.6 million), a 171% premium over its book value. The sale is expected to net ART a gain of 536.6 million yuan, which may be used to reduce debts, fund acquisitions, or other corporate purposes. The sale comes amid limited operational growth prospects and capital appreciation in China's property market due to the ongoing Covid-19 situation and government regulations.

site_title: Malaysia's gravity-defying lion dancers brought down to earth by pandemic
summary: Malaysia's traditional lion dance troupes, known for their gravity-defying performances, have been halted due to the pandemic. The Kun Seng Keng Lion & Dragon Dance Association, a leading troupe, relies heavily on Lunar New Year celebrations for income, but public spectacles have been banned. The group's deputy, Lim Wei Khang, expressed concerns about the impact of the pandemic on their business. Despite the ban, the troupe's head, Tang Puay Sen, remains optimistic, hoping the pandemic will end soon and performances can resume.

site_title: First sitting US congressman dies after Covid diagnosis
summary: US Republican Congressman Ron Wright, 67, has died after contracting Covid-19, becoming the first sitting member to lose his life to the disease. Wright was being treated in a Dallas hospital for the virus, which also affected his wife, Susan. His death comes after House member-elect Luke Letlow died in December. Wright had announced his positive Covid-19 test on January 21, experiencing minor symptoms. The US has seen 463,000 deaths from the virus.

site_title: SoftBank shares breach 10,000 yen, hits two-decade high, on record Vision Fund profit
summary: SoftBank shares surged past 10,000 yen, reaching a two-decade high, following a record profit report from its Vision Fund unit. The profit came after startups like Opendoor went public, boosting the value of SoftBank's portfolio. Shares were up 5.3% at Y9,990, marking the biggest intraday jump in two months.

site_title: Bitcoin extends gains above US$47,000 in Asia
summary: Bitcoin surged to a record high of US$47,565.86, with a 2.5% daily gain, following Tesla's investment announcement in its 2020 annual report. Ethereum also reached a record of US$1,784. The gains come as cryptocurrencies extended their gains in Asia, with bitcoin up 61% for the year. The investment news sparked a significant increase in the cryptocurrency's value, marking its largest daily percentage gain in over three years.

images.alt_text: Cryptocurrencies extended gains in Asia on Tuesday, with bitcoin and ethereum reaching record highs, in the wake of a Tesla Inc investment in bitcoin.

site_title: Inflation hawks critique Biden's US$1.9t spending plan
summary: US President Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion economic stimulus plan has drawn criticism from some economists, including former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers, who warn it could lead to inflation and crowd out other investment priorities. Summers and former IMF chief economist Olivier Blanchard argue the package is too large and may leave the US without resources for other priorities. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen acknowledges the risk of inflation but believes the US has tools to manage it, and argues the plan could get the economy back to full employment by 2022.

site_title: Trump defence urges dismissal of 'absurd' impeachment trial
summary: Donald Trump's defense team argued that the impeachment trial is constitutionally flawed and "absurd" to hold him responsible for the US Capitol riot, which occurred on January 6. They claimed the Senate lacks jurisdiction to try a former president, and that the charges are "patently ridiculous." Democrats countered that Trump committed the "most grievous constitutional crime" by inciting supporters to storm Congress, and that the trial's outcome is uncertain due to loyal Republican support in the Senate.

site_title: UK consumer spending plunges as new lockdown bites: Barclaycard
summary: UK consumer spending plummeted 16.3% in January, the largest drop since May 2020, due to the new lockdown. Online retail spending increased 73% and takeaway food demand rose 33%, but these gains were offset by the closure of many businesses. Spending in pubs, bars, and travel agents dropped nearly 94%, 84%, and 87%, respectively. In contrast, supermarkets saw a 17% surge in sales as people prepared more food at home. The Bank of England predicts a 4% economy shrinkage in the first three months of 2021, but expects strong growth later this year.

site_title: Soviet spy gadgets to go under hammer in Beverly Hills
summary: A collection of Soviet spy gadgets, including cyanide-filled fake teeth, camera-packed cigarette packs, and miniature microphones, is up for auction in Beverly Hills. The items, created in the 1970s and 1980s, were used by real secret agents and feature retro espionage devices that would not be out of place in a James Bond movie. The sale includes a fake tooth expected to fetch up to $1,200 and a Bulgarian umbrella used to poison a dissident in 1978, estimated to fetch between $3,000 and $5,000.

site_title: Facebook, Twitter outpaced by smaller platforms in fight against harmful content: agency
summary: Facebook, Twitter, and Alphabet's YouTube made smaller strides in battling harmful content, such as hate speech and misinformation, compared to smaller platforms like TikTok and Reddit in the second half of 2020. The Media Responsibility Index, released by IPG Mediabrands, found TikTok made the biggest improvements, partnering with companies to protect advertisers and giving users better control over content. Pinterest and Reddit also showed significant improvements in combating false and misleading content. The study concluded that while progress was made, more work is needed across the industry to effectively address these issues.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, Yangzijiang, ART, HPHT, Thomson Medical
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Asian Gateway Investments are launching an electronic Asian bond trading platform. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding secured US$1.3 billion in vessel building contracts. Other stocks to watch include ART, HPHT, Thomson Medical, and HPHT.

images.alt_text: SGX and Asian Gateway Investments on Monday entered into an agreement to incorporate a joint-venture company in Singapore that will launch an electronic Asian bond trading platform this year.

site_title: Hong Kong proposes new rules for share and bond issuance
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission proposes new rules requiring investment banks to disclose their fee structures and set fixed syndicate arrangements for debt and stock issuances earlier. The goal is to improve transparency in capital market deals and clarify the roles of investment banks.

site_title: Hong Kong's top court to rule on security law bail verdict
summary: Hong Kong's top court is set to rule on the bail of media tycoon Jimmy Lai, who was charged under Beijing's national security law for allegedly calling for sanctions against Hong Kong and China. Lai's case is a landmark challenge to the law, which has removed the presumption of bail for non-violent crimes and gives China jurisdiction in some cases. The ruling will indicate whether Hong Kong's judiciary can serve as a constitutional brake against Beijing's security law, putting the city's independent judiciary on a potentially precarious collision course with China's authoritarian leadership.

site_title: Oil rises 2% to more than one-year high on supply cuts, stimulus hopes
summary: Oil prices rose 2% to a one-year high, reaching US$60.56 a barrel for Brent and US$57.97 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate. The increase is attributed to supply cuts among key producers, including Saudi Arabia's pledge of extra cuts, and hopes for US economic stimulus. The market has risen over 60% since November due to optimism around coronavirus vaccine distributions and production cuts from Opec+ members, indicating a "paradigm shift" in the market, according to analysts.

site_title: Electronic Arts buys mobile game maker Glu for US$2.1b
summary: Electronic Arts (EA) has acquired mobile game maker Glu Mobile for $2.1 billion, expanding its offerings on smartphones and tablets. The deal includes Glu's popular titles such as MLB Tap Sports Baseball and Design Home. EA aims to leverage Glu's talent and games to build on its popular video game franchises with mobile offerings, growing its mobile business. The acquisition is expected to close by June pending regulatory and shareholder approval.

site_title: Singapore agencies must subject key Covid-19 expenditures to checks: watchdog
summary: Singapore's Public Accounts Committee has warned that large Covid-19 expenditures have stretched public resources, leaving less buffer for unforeseen needs. The report calls for checks on key expenditures and questions whether large-scale projects should be delayed or cancelled. New grant schemes were implemented to support businesses and individuals affected by the pandemic. The committee's findings come as Singapore faces ongoing economic challenges.

site_title: DoorDash buys startup behind salad-making robot
summary: DoorDash acquired Chowbotics, the startup behind the robotic vending machine "Sally" that can make and dispense fresh meals. Sally, which can prepare dishes such as salads, parfaits, and poke bowls, is currently used at hundreds of universities, hospitals, and grocery stores. DoorDash plans to use Chowbotics to help merchants expand their menu offerings in new markets without investing in a new store. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. This acquisition aims to capitalize on the growing demand for delivery and meal preparation services.

site_title: Biden, Modi speak of climate, 'democratic' values in first talks
summary: US President Joe Biden and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi discussed climate change and "democratic" values in their first phone call, marking a continuation of the close US-India relationship. Biden committed to working with Modi to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, address climate change, and rebuild the global economy. Modi welcomed Biden's climate ambitions and rejoining the Paris accord, and the two leaders agreed to participate in a climate summit in April. The talks also touched on democratic values and human rights, with Biden expressing support for India's democratic institutions.

site_title: Thiem, Tsitsipas eye greater success in 2021
summary: Dominic Thiem, a 27-year-old Austrian tennis player, had a breakthrough year in 2020, achieving his maiden Grand Slam title at the US Open, reaching the Australian Open and French Open finals, and securing a career-best ranking of third. He was also named the Austrian Sportsman of the Year.

site_title: Japanese investors return to foreign bonds as yields rise on stimulus hopes
summary: Japanese investors bought 2.49 trillion yen (S$31.5 billion) of foreign bonds in January, marking an eighth straight month of net buying, driven by hopes of a US stimulus boosting yields. The buying was led by trust banks and big public pension funds, but life insurers continued to sell, extending their net selling for a seventh straight month. Analysts expect bond yields to rise further, citing the potential for the Federal Reserve to taper its stimulus. The 10-year US Treasuries yield rose to a 10-1/2-month high of 1.191% following soft US jobs data.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on M&A activity; Dialog Semi hits over 20-year highs
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Monday, driven by hopes of a quicker economic recovery and multi-billion dollar deals, including Dialog Semiconductor's 16% surge after a $7.85 billion acquisition by Renesas Electronics Corp. Cyclical sectors, including basic resources and technology, gained between 0.8% and 1.5%, while France's Veolia Environnement SA launched an offer for Suez SA, valuing it at 11.3 billion euros. Despite optimism, the Stoxx 600 remains 5% away from pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Oil's remarkable rebound from a year of catastrophe
summary: Oil prices have staged a remarkable turnaround after a year of crisis, driven by recovering Chinese consumption, freight demand, and Opec's supply cuts. Futures rallied to a one-year high above $60 a barrel, with inventories declining by 300 million barrels since May. The recovery is being fueled by a rebound in oil consumption, particularly in Asia, as well as demand for petroleum products used in industries such as plastics and heating. However, global oil consumption remains down 5-7% from last year, and the market is still subject to uncertainties, including the spread of COVID-19 and vaccine rollout issues.

site_title: DBS rolls out new business support measures
summary: DBS has rolled out new business support measures for micro and small enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore, prioritizing protecting employees' livelihoods amid the economic downturn. The bank's SME Pulse Check Survey found that six in 10 SMEs cited this as their main motivation for sustaining their businesses. Many have relied on personal savings and assets to cope. The measures aim to support these business owners in keeping their operations afloat.

site_title: Muguruza, Bencic ready to rock the women's tour
summary: Garbine Muguruza, a 27-year-old Spanish tennis player, is set to compete in the women's tour, following her impressive performance at the Australian Open last year. Muguruza, who moved to Spain with her family at age 5, has made significant progress in her career, reaching the final of the Grand Slam. With her experience and skills, she is expected to be a strong contender in the women's tennis tour.

site_title: Rolls-Royce to briefly shut UK engine factories
summary: Rolls-Royce, a British aircraft engine manufacturer, plans to temporarily shut its UK engine factories for two weeks in summer to counter a slump in demand caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The move is part of the company's ongoing efficiency drive and aims to achieve a 10% productivity improvement. Rolls-Royce will discuss the plan with trade unions and intends to reduce the impact on pay by spreading the shutdown across the year. The company is holding talks to achieve the agreed-upon productivity and efficiency improvement.

site_title: Underemployment a bigger issue than unemployment: economists
summary: Singapore's labor market appears to be recovering, with the overall unemployment rate falling to 3.2% in December. However, economists warn that underemployment, where individuals work in lower-paying jobs that don't match their skills, may be a bigger issue. The lack of a clear definition of underemployment makes it difficult to track, but experts suggest it's a concern during economic shocks, particularly for displaced workers who take up temporary or lower-skilled jobs. To address this, retraining and upskilling, as well as creating opportunities for workers to utilize their skills, are key to reducing underemployment and promoting long-term career progression.

images.alt_text: One sign of underemployment is the number of qualified professionals who have had to take up "informal jobs" during this recession, such as in the ride-hailing or food-delivery industries.

site_title: Is Jobs Growth Incentive scheme serving the right ends?
summary: The Jobs Growth Incentive (JGI) scheme in Singapore has subsidised the employment of 110,000 new local hires, mostly in sectors such as food services, wholesale trade, and professional services. However, the nature of these jobs is unclear, and there is concern that some positions may be stop-gap or replaced by foreign workers. The scheme aims to support employers in increasing local hiring and creating long-term jobs, but its effectiveness in achieving this goal is uncertain. The government should release more detailed data on the new hires and track outcomes after the scheme's expiry to address scepticism.

site_title: India plans to buy more than 3t rupees in bond purchases
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) plans to buy more than 3 trillion rupees (S$54.79 billion) in sovereign bonds in the next fiscal year to support the government's borrowing plans. The goal is to cap the benchmark bond yield under 6% and narrow the spread with the repo rate to around 150 basis points. This will exceed the RBI's current spending of 3 trillion rupees and provide relief to the market from over supply, but may reduce trading opportunities.

site_title: WHO says don't dismiss AstraZeneca shot after South Africa delays jabs
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has urged against dismissing the AstraZeneca vaccine, citing its continued importance in the global fight against the pandemic. Despite a South African trial showing minimal protection against the virus variant, the WHO and AstraZeneca stand by the vaccine's efficacy against severe disease. Researchers are working to update the vaccine to address the variant, and the WHO has authorized the vaccine for distribution to 145 countries. The WHO also announced a ban on Facebook groups spreading false claims about the virus and vaccines.

site_title: Covid-19 worsens plight of home renters in US
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has worsened the housing insecurity faced by millions of US renters, with many struggling to pay rent due to reduced income and depleted savings. The nation's housing instability, already a significant issue, has deepened, with 11 million households spending more than half their income on housing and overcrowding on the rise. The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia estimates that tenants who lost jobs due to the pandemic owe $53 billion in back rent, while a study by Moody's Analytics found that tenants owe $11 billion.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records, extending rally
summary: US stocks closed at all-time highs on Monday, extending a rally driven by optimism over fiscal stimulus and an economic recovery. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.8% to 31,385.76, while the S&P 500 advanced 0.7% to 3,915.59 and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.0% to 13,987.64. Investors expect President Biden's fiscal relief package to pass, with Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen predicting full employment by next year if the package is enacted.

site_title: Panasonic eyes region to expand consumer business
summary: Panasonic is targeting Vietnam, Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia as key markets to drive growth of its consumer business in Southeast Asia, leveraging rising middle-class populations and concerns over air quality. The company plans to expand home, wellness, and automotive segments, with a focus on its nanoe technology, which inhibits bacterial and viral growth. Despite the pandemic, Panasonic has seen improving sales since July, and is investing in online "click and pick" strategies and business-to-business partnerships to drive e-commerce revenue growth.

site_title: Should investors beware the Lippo effect?
summary: Locally listed stocks with ties to the Riady family have underperformed significantly, with negative returns over the last five years, compared to the Straits Times Index and FTSE ST Reit Index. This is partly attributed to Indonesian developer Lippo Karawaci's liquidity issues, stemming from its 2018 US$21 billion Meikarta township project troubles. The need to raise cash led to asset sales, which ended up in Riady-linked entities.

site_title: Malaysia needs to raise pandemic enforcement chops to pull out of crisis
summary: Malaysia's economy faces strain due to the pandemic and ongoing political turmoil. Foreign direct investment plummeted 68% in 2020, the worst among regional peers, and foreign investors have been dumping Malaysian stocks for 18 months. The country's battle against the pandemic is also ongoing, with active Covid-19 cases surpassing 50,000. The government's strict enforcement of the Movement Control Order has been criticized, and a quicker vaccine roll-out is crucial for a faster recovery. Moody's Investors Service notes that "noisy politics" poses a risk to the economy, highlighting the need for better enforcement to curb the virus spread.

site_title: No heroes or villains in GameStop story
summary: The price of GameStop stock soared 323% in January, driven by a speculative bubble fueled by amateur traders on Reddit's WallStreetBets, challenging common interpretations of financial markets. However, there are no clear heroes or villains in the story, as both the hedge funds short-selling GameStop and the traders buying its shares used the same options trading strategy. The GameStop investors are not villains, but rather riding the speculative wave or trying to inflict pain on hedge funds, with some suffering huge losses. Regulatory scrutiny is now focused on financial-services companies like Robinhood, which imposed restrictions on trading in GameStop and other stocks, leading to a SEC investigation.

site_title: Renaissance clients pull out after firm's rotten run of results
summary: Renaissance Technologies, a leading hedge fund firm, is facing a major crisis after clients pulled out $5 billion in redemptions since December 1. The firm's three public funds, including the Institutional Equities Fund, lost double digits in 2020, with Medallion gaining 76% but still struggling to match its average annual returns of 40%. Renaissance is now trying to convince investors to stay, despite its unprecedented losses and reputation damage.

site_title: Denzel Washington's The Little Things stays at box office summit
summary: Denzel Washington's crime thriller "The Little Things" led the North American box office charts for the second weekend, earning US$2.1 million. The film has made US$7.8 million domestically and US$5.2 million internationally. It debuted simultaneously on HBO Max, a hybrid strategy met with backlash. The Croods: A New Age took second place, generating US$1.7 million domestically and US$101.6 million internationally.

site_title: Democratise finance by decentralising, not mobbing
summary: Retail investors won a temporary victory in the GameStop saga, but their struggle for democratization in finance is far from over. The sudden collapse of GameStop's stock price after a short squeeze by retail investors, facilitated by online brokers, highlighted the uneven playing field in the financial markets. Retail investors, who lack access to privileged channels, were left vulnerable to institutional investors' counterattacks. To truly democratize finance, regulators must reform the market structure, and technological advancements should be leveraged to create new financial services that make inclusive finance more accessible to the general population.

site_title: SoftBank's Vision Fund posts record 844b-yen profit on IPO boom
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund reported a record 844.1-billion yen profit in the December quarter, driven by a global rally in technology shares and initial public offerings (IPOs). The fund's value was boosted by SoftBank's stakes in publicly traded firms like Uber Technologies Inc. However, founder Masayoshi Son's trading in derivatives wiped out a significant portion of the gains. This marks a reversal from earlier record numbers set just a quarter earlier, highlighting the volatility in the market.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust posted a 79% increase in DPU to 7.70 HK cents for its second half, reaching 12 HK cents for the full year, a 57% increase from FY2019. Interra Resources may face labour disruptions in Myanmar, prompting a trading halt. Challenger Technologies reported a 32% increase in net profit to S$23.2 million, despite a 18% decline in revenue.

site_title: Of RCEP, business, and a less messy bowl of noodles
summary: Singapore's Market Readiness Assistance scheme has been enhanced to include FTA consultancy services to support small and medium enterprises (SMEs) navigating the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), the world's largest Free Trade Agreement. RCEP, signed in 2020, aims to eliminate tariffs for 92% of goods and provide better market access for exports. However, the implementation of multiple bilateral and regional FTAs poses a "noodle bowl effect," creating complexity and barriers for SMEs. To address this, the Singapore government has rolled out initiatives to minimize the impact of RCEP on SMEs, promoting open trade and increasing globalisation.

site_title: Tennis stars ready to shine Down Under at Australian Open
summary: The Australian Open, the first major tennis tournament of 2021, is set to begin in Melbourne, featuring top tennis stars such as Novak Djokovic, Rafael Nadal, Serena Williams, and Simona Halep. The tournament, known as the "Happy Slam," offers a record A$80 million in prize money. Djokovic is the hot favorite to retain his title, while Daniil Medvedev and Nick Kyrgios are also contenders. The women's tour is also packed with talent, with Sofia Kenin and Ashleigh Barty vying for the championship. The tournament is expected to be an exciting event, with no clear winner in sight.

site_title: Lawmakers challenge HSBC on HK activist's accounts
summary: A coalition of lawmakers from countries including Britain, Australia, Japan, and the US has written to HSBC chairman Mark Tucker, urging the bank to unfreeze the accounts of Hong Kong pro-democracy activist Ted Hui. The bank froze Hui's accounts after he announced plans to seek exile in Britain, citing a police instruction. The lawmakers criticized HSBC for not providing evidence of a court order and refusing to publicly respond to concerns. HSBC stated it had no choice but to comply with police instructions, while Hui's family accounts were also frozen without charges.

site_title: A$140b Aussie pension fund eyes Europe, US expansion
summary: AWARE Super, Australia's second-largest pension fund, plans to expand into Europe and the US, aiming to grow to manage up to A$300 billion. The fund will likely open offices in Europe and the US, doubling its staff and sourcing more investments globally. AWARE Super aims to reduce its cash pile by buying property and infrastructure assets, focusing on developed countries rather than emerging markets. The expansion is driven by the need to manage its growing portfolio, with two-thirds of its investments expected to be outside Australia.

site_title: Surbana Jurong's Ream City to ramp up Cambodia tourism, economy
summary: Surbana Jurong's Ream City project in Sihanoukville, Cambodia, has received approval for a $16 billion masterplan, aiming to be a model for future development projects in the country. The mixed tourism, commercial, and residential project will be built on reclaimed land, 10 minutes from the airport, and will include hotels, restaurants, business hubs, and residential options. The project is part of Cambodia's strategy to diversify its economy, and its success is seen as a potential boon for the country's tourism and economy, with potential for up to 130,000 residents.

site_title: BT Mark To Market: GameStop short squeeze and the power of retail investors (Ep 4)
summary: The GameStop short squeeze has highlighted the growing influence of retail investors, who are using social media to drive market changes. The popular narrative surrounding the event may be exaggerated, but it has sparked a renewed focus on the role of retail investors in the markets. As markets become increasingly speculative and volatile, investors are advised to be cautious and consult with financial advisers before making any investment decisions. The episode emphasizes the need for investors to be informed and vigilant in today's rapidly changing market landscape.

site_title: UOB and clients raise funds with bamboo art
summary: UOB, in collaboration with its clients, raised over S$500,000 through bamboo art workshops during its annual Chinese New Year fundraiser. The funds, which include matching donations up to S$250,000, will support art, children, and education causes in Singapore. More than half of the funds will be donated to The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, helping financially-disadvantaged children. The remaining funds will support local SMEs and education initiatives. The event aimed to promote community resilience during the pandemic.

site_title: SGX in joint venture to start bond trading platform
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has entered a joint venture with US-based fintech startup Trumid and HH THL Holdings to launch an electronic Asian bond trading platform, Trumid XT, by the end of the year. The platform aims to enhance liquidity and execution in the Asia bond market for global clients. SGX will own approximately a third of the JV firm, while Trumid will operate the platform, combining its technology and expertise with SGX's experience in Asian financial markets and Hillhouse's network in Asia.

site_title: 'It's all open!': French flock to Madrid cafes for pandemic reprieve
summary: French tourists are flocking to Madrid, Spain, where bars and restaurants are open and people can stay outdoors until 10 pm, providing a pandemic reprieve from France's strict lockdown. Despite a mandatory mask-wearing policy and reduced occupancy, Madrid's conservative regional government has set one of Spain's loosest curfews, defying national recommendations. The influx of entertainment-seeking young tourists has drawn praise for its locals' rigor, with many feeling safer and more relaxed than in France or Britain.

site_title: SMEs counting on govt support amid gloomy outlook in 2021: QBE poll
summary: Singaporean small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are optimistic about the economic climate in 2021, but still face challenges. A QBE poll found that SME owners are counting on government support to shield their businesses from the economic downturn. Despite increased positivity, SMEs expect to remain under the weather, with many citing poor footfall and vacant units as major concerns. The government's support is seen as crucial to their survival.

site_title: US dollar steadies as traders await for more data
summary: The US dollar steadied against major currencies on Monday as traders awaited more economic data, following a disappointing jobs report last week. The euro was little changed against the US dollar, despite a contraction in German industry data, which showed the country's industry avoided a decline in December. Speculators have been reducing short positions in the dollar, but analysts expect further gains only if the US economy shows better data and progress in fighting the pandemic.

site_title: All eyes on Biden as he negotiates the Asian triangle
summary: US President Joe Biden's handling of China will be a defining issue of his presidency, following a decade of increasing Chinese assertiveness. China's leaders have abandoned Deng Xiaoping's moderate policy, becoming more aggressive in the South China Sea, Taiwan, and India. The US and China remain interdependent, with $500 billion in annual trade, but shaping Chinese behavior is possible through alliances. The Japan-US alliance, strengthened by former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, remains a key priority for the Biden administration, offering a balance of power against China and cooperation on issues like climate change and trade.

site_title: Facing resistance, China pushes back 50m vaccine target
summary: China has pushed back its target to inoculate 50 million people against Covid-19 by almost two months to the end of March, amid concerns over supply and vaccine hesitancy. The original target was to reach 50 million shots by the Chinese New Year holiday in February. This new plan reflects the challenges in meeting the initial target, highlighting the ongoing challenges in China's vaccination efforts.

site_title: Serena channels late Olympic champion FloJo with single-legged catsuit
summary: Serena Williams debuted a single-legged catsuit in her Australian Open match, paying homage to Olympic track champion Florence Griffith Joyner, also known as "FloJo." The black, red, and pink outfit was inspired by Joyner's flamboyant fashion sense, which included long fingernails and colorful outfits. Williams credited Nike for the idea, saying she was inspired by Joyner's fashion and legacy. The design was not the first to pay tribute to Joyner, with Beyoncé wearing a similar leotard in 2018.

site_title: Expect bumper year for Asia Reit mergers
summary: Expect a bumper year for mergers and acquisitions in Asia's real estate markets, driven by the need for larger Reits to scale up and compete in a global asset chase. With prime assets overpriced and stressed assets not yet falling far enough to be a safe bet, consolidation is becoming inevitable among smaller Reits in Singapore and Japan. Global investors are seeking sound investments, and Reits are merging to become more dominant corporates and agile private businesses. Consolidation will also drive acquisitions of tech companies and proptech firms, and real estate companies buying proptech firms to control key technologies.

site_title: UN human rights experts speak out against rise of lese majeste cases in Thailand
summary: United Nations human rights experts have condemned Thailand's increasing use of the lese majeste law, which forbids criticism of the royal family, citing a 43-year sentence for an elderly woman convicted under the law. Dozens of police cases have been filed against youth leaders who broke taboos by criticizing the Thai king, risking prosecution under the law punishable by up to 15 years in prison. The experts' condemnation comes amid rising concerns about freedom of expression in Thailand.

site_title: Three non-bank e-wallet players to offer PayNow
summary: Three non-bank e-wallet players, Grab Financial Group, Liquid Group, and Singtel Dash, have joined the PayNow peer-to-peer fund transfer service, marking the first time non-banks are involved. A Virtual Payment Address (VPA) proxy has been created to facilitate transfers between bank accounts and e-wallets. This expansion aims to boost PayNow adoption and accelerate Singapore's shift towards a digital economy, with over 5 million registrations and $50 billion in transactions since its launch in 2017.

site_title: George Shultz, who led US' Cold War diplomacy, dies at 100
summary: George Shultz, the former US Secretary of State under Ronald Reagan, has died at 100. A diplomat and economist, Shultz served in various roles including labour secretary, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Treasury secretary under President Richard Nixon. He was a key figure in US Cold War diplomacy and played a crucial role in untying the US dollar from the gold standard. Shultz's legacy as a statesman and patriot has been praised by former colleagues, including Condoleezza Rice and Hillary Clinton, who described him as a "giant" and a "legend".

images.alt_text: Mr Shultz, in a recent Washington Post op-ed piece, wrote that trust is the coin of the realm, and good things happen when it is present.

site_title: Myanmar junta says it will call election as protests spread
summary: Myanmar's junta leader, Senior General Min Aung Hlaing, announced an election will be held and power will be transferred to the winning party, despite ongoing protests and a nationwide strike. Martial law was declared in parts of Mandalay, banning protests and gatherings, and the military has warned that opposition is unlawful. Tens of thousands protested across the country, with textile workers, civil servants, and railway employees participating in the strike. The junta has refrained from using deadly force, but pressure is building, with international leaders calling for the generals to relinquish power.

site_title: Saving jobs in Budget 2021: what and whose jobs to save?
summary: The Singapore government is expected to intensify its push to retrain and upskill workers at Budget 2021, nudging them towards sectors that are likely to thrive from the Covid pandemic, such as IT, technology, healthcare, and financial services. Economists predict this move will help support jobs and mitigate the impact of the pandemic on the economy. The government may also provide support for workers who are struggling to adapt to the changing job market, with some experts suggesting that workers should future-proof their careers before a crisis strikes.

site_title: Myanmar coup leader says public should prioritise facts over feelings
summary: Myanmar's junta leader, Senior General Min Aung Hlaing, called on the public to prioritize facts over feelings in a national address, amid ongoing anti-coup protests. He assured that an election would be held and power transferred to the winning party, while maintaining foreign policy remains unchanged. The junta leader also reiterated that irregularities in last year's election were ignored and that no organization is above the law.

site_title: Engineer who received first dose of Covid-19 vaccine among two community cases
summary: A 30-year-old Indian national who received his first dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine on January 27 tested positive for the virus, despite having negative swabs during quarantine and routine testing. He was among two community cases announced in Singapore, with the other being a 49-year-old bus driver. The Ministry of Health (MOH) confirmed that the patient's positive serology test is likely due to the vaccine, while the bus driver's case is considered a current infection. There were also 20 imported cases confirmed, bringing Singapore's total to 59,721.

site_title: Mudlogic engineers success by catering to the customer
summary: Mudlogic, a Singapore-based engineering firm, prioritizes customer satisfaction over market dominance, focusing on providing tailored solutions rather than just selling products. Co-founder Phui Eng Ko values good business relationships and quality over rapid expansion, maintaining a 40-50% market share in the foundation and tunnelling industries. The company's unique approach, including a holacratic structure and open-door culture, fosters innovation and collaboration. Mudlogic plans to diversify into the pharmaceutical and food packaging industries to circumvent pandemic-related challenges and eventually move into the raw materials industry.

site_title: BP enters UK offshore wind sector
summary: BP, a British energy major, has entered the UK offshore wind sector by partnering with German peer EnBW to build wind farms. Authorities awarded them 60-year leases in the North Sea to help cut carbon emissions. The project will generate enough electricity to power over 3.4 million UK households, aligning with BP's goal of achieving "net zero" carbon emissions by 2050. This marks BP's entry into the UK's largest offshore wind power sector, further expanding its sustainable energy business.

site_title: SGX unit, Trumid and Hillhouse in JV to launch Asian bond trading platform
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has entered into a joint venture with US-based fintech startup Trumid and HH THL Holdings, an affiliate of Hillhouse Capital, to launch an electronic Asian bond trading platform called Trumid XT. The JV company, XinTru, will operate the platform to enhance liquidity and execution in the Asian bond market for global clients. SGX's wholly owned subsidiary AGI will own about a third of the interest in the JV firm. Regulatory approvals are required for the completion of the transaction.

site_title: Japan protests over China ships off disputed isles
summary: Japan has protested to China over two incursions into its territorial waters off the disputed Senkaku/Diaoyu islets in the East China Sea. The move comes after China enacted legislation allowing its coast guard to use weapons against foreign ships in its waters. Japanese government spokesman Katsubonu Kato said Tokyo made a strong protest, demanding Chinese ships leave the waters and warning that Japan "can never tolerate" such moves. This latest row raises concerns about heightened tensions and the risk of a maritime conflict between Japan and China.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo from the US on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and PBOC to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: US insurance asset sales attract new private equity players, strategies
summary: US insurers are selling capital-intensive assets to private equity firms, with deals totaling $25 billion in 2020 and $2.8 billion in January, the most active month in 20 years. Companies like Sixth Street Partners and KKR & Co are buying insurance assets to boost their assets under management, while insurers release capital for share repurchases and investments. Private equity firms can invest the cash into higher-yielding assets, driving operational cost savings. However, insurers face risks from selling assets, particularly smaller private equity-backed insurance vehicles.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher, extending rally
summary: US stocks rose early Monday, extending last week's rally on optimism about additional US stimulus spending and coronavirus vaccines. The Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.5%, 0.4%, and 0.5% respectively. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen predicted the US would return to full employment next year if the $1.9 trillion fiscal relief package is enacted. Investors have largely shrugged off concerns about excessive equity valuations, with major indices reaching all-time records last week.

site_title: Lawmakers challenge HSBC on Hong Kong activist's accounts
summary: Lawmakers from an international coalition, including Britain, Australia, Japan, and the US, have written to HSBC Chairman Mark Tucker, urging the bank to unfreeze the accounts of Hong Kong pro-democracy activist Ted Hui. The coalition criticized HSBC for freezing accounts without a court order or police warrant, affecting Hui and his family. HSBC cited Hong Kong police instructions to freeze accounts under formal investigation. The move is seen as aiding a crackdown on democracy in Hong Kong.

site_title: Chinese regulators call in Tesla over customer complaints
summary: Chinese regulators have met with Tesla representatives over customer complaints, including battery fires, unexpected acceleration, and software update issues. The officials urged Tesla to operate according to Chinese laws and protect customer rights. Tesla has accepted the guidance and will thoroughly investigate the problems, promising to abide by Chinese laws and regulations. The meeting comes as China pushes the industry to increase electric vehicle production, with sales forecast to rise to 20% of all new car sales by 2025.

site_title: Tesla sends bitcoin soaring with US$1.5b investment, payment promise
summary: Tesla has invested approximately $1.5 billion in bitcoin and plans to accept it as payment for its cars and products. This move led to a 7% surge in bitcoin's price, reaching an all-time high of $43,725.51. Analysts predict this will accelerate companies' interest in allocating to bitcoin, giving investors exposure to the currency. Tesla cited its investment policy and diversification goals as the reason for the investment.

site_title: Golden Energy and Resources appoints new CEO
summary: Golden Energy and Resources has appointed Dwi Prasetyo Suseno as its new group CEO, replacing Fuganto Widjaja, who has been redesignated as executive chairman. Suseno, who joined Gear in 2018, will oversee overall management, operations, and business development. He fills the role after Lay Krisnan Cahya resigned as non-executive director and chairman, and Mark Zhou was appointed as executive director and chief investment officer. The company also announced changes to its audit and nominating committees.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 5.30 points lower at 1,573.33 on Monday, with a trading volume of 7.044 billion lots worth RM4.504 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 620 to 569.

site_title: Singapore stocks track Wall Street gains, STI up 0.84%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.84% on Monday, tracking Wall Street gains, as investors await a US stimulus package. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended at 2,931.40 points, with local lenders DBS, OCBC, and UOB among the top performers. Singapore Airlines led the gains, while Jardine Matheson Holdings fell 3.3%. Asian markets, including Tokyo and Hong Kong, also rose, while Seoul's Kospi dipped due to news of a cancelled Hyundai-Apple car deal.

site_title: Dialog agrees to US$6b takeover by Renesas Electronics
summary: Renesas Electronics Corp of Japan has agreed to acquire Dialog Semiconductor, a UK-based chipmaker, for approximately US$6 billion. Dialog accepted the all-cash offer of 67.50 euros per share, a 20% premium to its Friday close. The deal is the latest in a series of UK-based chipmakers being sold to Asian investors. Dialog shares rose 18% in early trading, while Renesas shares dropped 6.9% in Tokyo.

site_title: Yangzijiang gets new orders for 29 vessels worth US$1.3 billion
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding announced orders for 29 vessels worth US$1.3 billion, including 22 containerships valued at US$1.13 billion. Orders come from Shanghai Zhonggu Logistics Co, a new customer, and a returning customer, with deliveries expected from the third quarter next year. This is the group's second major order win since January, following an agreement to build six containerships worth US$162 million.

site_title: Challenger posts 32% rise in FY2020 net profit to S$23m
summary: Challenger Technologies, a consumer electronics retailer, posted a 32% increase in FY2020 net profit to S$23.2 million, driven by a 32% decrease in IT products and services revenue. Despite a 18% year-on-year decline in total revenue, the company's higher profit after taxation was mainly attributed to reduced premises expenses and other cost-cutting measures. The board recommended a final dividend of 2.70 Singapore cents, an increase from the previous year.

site_title: 11 steps to impress your boss and thrive in your job
summary: Managing your relationship with your boss can improve job recognition, raises, and promotions. Key habits include: aligning work priorities, specifying due dates and expectations, adapting to manager style, doing tasks before being asked, bringing recommendations, avoiding surprises, building trust, helping your manager, and understanding their stress. By demonstrating integrity, dependability, and empathy, you can create a positive working relationship and advance your career.

site_title: Industry watchers push Budget schemes for small manufacturers after Chan Chun Sing tours factory
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing announced policy and funding support for local companies, including small manufacturers, to upgrade and grow. He emphasized the government's commitment to supporting companies that desire to upgrade themselves. This comes after a series of visits to various manufacturing sub-sectors, including a precision engineering firm.

site_title: Prestige Biopharma raises 453 billion won from Korean IPO
summary: Prestige Biopharma, a Singapore-based biotech firm, successfully raised 453 billion won (S$539.9 million) from its initial public offering (IPO) on the Korea Exchange, with its shares ending at 42,600 won, up 33.1% from the IPO price. The company's market capitalization reached 2.6 trillion won, exceeding its expected range of 1.8-1.93 trillion won. The IPO was 237 times oversubscribed, with strong support from international and local institutional investors, and plans to utilize funds for research and development, facility investment, and global market entry.

site_title: Vicom posts 14% fall in FY2020 net profit to S$24.5 million
summary: Vicom, a subsidiary of ComfortDelGro, reported a 13.8% fall in FY2020 net profit to S$24.5 million, with revenue dropping 16.6% to S$86.5 million. Operating costs and operating profit also fell year-over-year. Despite the impact of the pandemic, Vicom expects demand for vehicle inspection to remain strong, with non-vehicle testing demand expected to improve under Phase 3. The board recommended a final dividend of 6.22 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Josephine Teo announced the Jobs Growth Incentive, supporting 110,000 local hires in October. Minister Chan Chun Sing committed the government's support for local firms aiming for growth. A new Asian bond trading platform, Trumid XT, will be launched by SGX and partners. The Ream City project in Cambodia has received green light for a US$16 billion masterplan. DBS rolled out support measures for micro and small enterprises. Singapore stocks rose 0.84% with the STI reaching 2,931.40 points, following Wall Street gains.

site_title: iFast looking to balance dividend growth with expansion opportunities
summary: iFast Corporation is expecting a gradual increase in its dividend for the current financial year, with its CEO Lim Chung Chun stating the company aims to balance dividend growth with retained earnings to explore expansion opportunities. The wealth management platform's net profit more than doubled in FY2020, and it has been studying the possibility of a digital banking licence in Malaysia. iFast's Singapore business is expected to continue seeing "good momentum," and the company's in-house advisory arm has shown "very good progress" in the last year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.4% to 6,517.00 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 index and Paris CAC 40 index also advanced 0.7% and 0.5%, respectively. Investors were tracking US stimulus plan developments and vaccine rollouts, contributing to the gains.

site_title: Polish video game maker CD Projekt focuses on fixing Cyberpunk 2077
summary: CD Projekt, a Polish video game maker, is focusing on improving Cyberpunk 2077, a role-playing game marred by glitches and complaints upon its December release. CEO Adam Kicinski stated the company aims to regain player and business partner trust, with the game expected to return to Sony's PlayStation Store. Kicinski attributed the challenges to adapting the game to older consoles and the Covid-19 pandemic.
