The company has faced class action lawsuits in the US and will "actively defend" against any legal claims.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed slightly higher on Monday, following a record lead from Wall Street, driven by US stimulus hopes and slowing infection rates. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.11%, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.03%. This Asia-wide rally comes amidst optimism and uncertainty, including US-EU trade talks and split Fed views.

site_title: Broker's take: SIA to benefit from air traffic recovery, say analysts
summary: Analysts predict a strong recovery for Singapore Airlines (SIA) as global air traffic recovers due to increased vaccine roll-outs. OCBC upgraded its "buy" call, raising the target price to S$4.80, while CGS-CIMB maintained its "add" call with an unchanged target price of S$4.89. Analysts believe SIA's air cargo segment will benefit from the recovery of the global economy and e-commerce, while passenger capacity is expected to improve gradually with Singapore's reopening and vaccine roll-outs.

site_title: Taiwan January exports rocket to record high, outlook rosy
summary: Taiwan's exports reached a record high in January, increasing 36.8% from the previous year to US$34.27 billion, driven by strong demand for chips to power the "zero touch economy." This marks the seventh consecutive month of growth, with exports to China and the US rising 57% and 21.9% year-over-year, respectively. The Ministry of Finance expects exports to expand steadily in the first quarter, citing the global economy's recovery and Taiwan's strong semiconductor industry.

site_title: Thomson Medical reverses loss to post net profit of S$8.1m in H1 FY21
summary: Thomson Medical Group posted a net profit of S$8.1 million for the first half of 2021, reversing a loss of S$1.9 million in the same period last year. Revenue declined 1.3% year-over-year to S$116.6 million, while earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) increased 32.6% to S$31.8 million. The company attributed the Ebitda increase to government grants and additional income from serology testing operations. Despite uncertainty surrounding the pandemic, Thomson Medical remains cautiously optimistic about its FY2021 outlook.

site_title: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust's H2 DPU rises 79% to 7.70 HK cents
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPHT) posted a 79% increase in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to 7.70 HK cents, up from 4.30 HK cents in the first half of 2020. The full-year DPU rose to 12 HK cents, a 10% increase from FY2019. Net profit increased by 57% to HK$831.4 million, despite a 3.7% decline in revenue to HK$10.71 billion. Throughput at HPHT's ports rose 2% year-over-year, with outbound cargoes to the US and Europe growing 33% and 24% respectively in Q4 2020.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB downgrades ISDN to 'hold' as short-term positives priced in
summary: CGS-CIMB downgraded ISDN Holdings to "hold" from "add" with an unchanged target price of S$0.72 due to the company's strong outlook in its core industrial automation business being priced into its share price.

site_title: Brent approaches US$60/barrel as supply cuts, stimulus hopes lift prices
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent futures nearing US$60 a barrel, driven by supply cuts among key producers and hopes for US economic stimulus measures. Brent crude for April reached a high of US$59.95 a barrel, up 57 cents or 1% from Friday. Saudi Arabia's pledge of extra supply cuts is helping balance global markets and support prices. The US oil rig count also rose to its highest since May, as stronger crude prices encourage US producers to increase output.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent futures nearing US$60 a barrel, boosted by supply cuts among key producers and hopes for further US economic stimulus measures to boost demand.

site_title: Australia regulator report on Crown Resorts to be published Tuesday
summary: Australia's Independent Liquor & Gaming Authority (ILGA) will publish a report on Tuesday assessing whether Crown Resorts Ltd, owned 35.9% by billionaire James Packer, is suitable to hold a gambling licence for its Sydney resort. The report, led by retired judge Patricia Bergin, will address concerns about Crown's ties to organized crime groups and money laundering. The company's Sydney casino is set to open without gambling, pending the report's findings. The regulator will suspend Crown's gambling licence until the report is formally considered.

site_title: Focus on chip shortage hurting production as Japanese automakers report results
summary: Japanese automakers Toyota, Nissan, and Honda report third-quarter results, boosted by recovering demand in China and the US, but a global chip shortage affects production. The shortage, caused by a surge in electronics demand and supply chain issues, has led to production cuts by the carmakers, including Subaru and Volkswagen. Analysts expect Toyota to forecast a profit of 1.5 trillion yen, Honda to forecast a profit of 463.6 billion yen, and Nissan to forecast a 230.09 billion yen operating loss. The chip shortage is expected to last until mid-2021, affecting auto production until then.

site_title: Thailand to see Lunar New Year spending slump after Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Thailand's Lunar New Year spending is expected to drop by more than a fifth, from 57.5 billion baht in 2020 to 44.9 billion baht, due to the Covid-19 outbreak and a bad economy. This would be the steepest spending fall in 13 years. The tourism-reliant economy is hit hard, but government stimulus measures are expected to support consumption, which accounts for half of the economy, and may lead to annual growth of over 3% if 4-6 million foreign tourists arrive.

images.alt_text: hailand's consumer spending over the Lunar New Year could drop by more than a fifth to 44.9 billion baht (S$2 billion) from 2020 after a Covid-19 outbreak hits consumption and activity.

site_title: 22 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including two in the community
summary: Singapore reported 22 new COVID-19 cases on Monday, bringing the total to 59,721. Two cases are in the community, including a 43-year-old man who works at Changi Airport, while the other 20 are imported. The community case is believed to be a current infection, and his close contacts are being isolated and tested. There were no new cases from worker's dormitories, and the total number of deaths remains at 29.

site_title: Boohoo snaps up Arcadia brands to complete break-up of Green empire
summary: British online fashion retailer Boohoo has acquired the Dorothy Perkins, Wallis, and Burton brands from Arcadia's administrators for £25.2 million. This deal completes the break-up of Philip Green's fallen empire, following Asos' purchase of Arcadia's Topshop and other brands last month. The acquisition does not include any stores, putting thousands of jobs at risk. Boohoo's purchase marks a significant expansion of its portfolio, further solidifying its position in the UK's online fashion market.

site_title: Pump prices rebound to pre-circuit breaker levels
summary: Petrol pump prices in Singapore have rebounded to pre-circuit breaker levels, with a litre of 95-octane petrol retailing at S$2.19 at all stations except SPC, which charges S$2.15. Diesel prices have also increased, with a litre retailing at S$1.84 at SPC. The price increases are attributed to the strong rebound of oil and refined products, with Brent crude trading at US$59.34 a barrel and RBOB gasoline at US$1.65 per gallon.

site_title: Can national digital IDs benefit both citizens and businesses?
summary: A national digital ID system can benefit both citizens and businesses by verifying identities and improving online transactions, access to public services, and financial inclusion. Over a billion people worldwide lack formal identity proof, leading to struggles in securing basic services. Implementing digital IDs can make these services more accessible, improving quality of life and reducing online fraud. To achieve high enrollment, governments must design inclusive and flexible documentation requirements and consider partnering with central banks. Businesses must assess their needs, understand the level of control they have over user experience, convenience, and security, and consider scalability.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on stimulus hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, extending Wall Street rallies on hopes for a US stimulus package and Japan's economic recovery. The Nikkei 225 index rose 2.12%, while the Topix index gained 1.75%. This follows the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite trade uncertainty. The positive sentiment is attributed to expectations of a US stimulus package, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: Hot stock: Livingstone Health opens above post-consolidation price
summary: Livingstone Health Holdings, a specialist healthcare group, made its debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board, with shares opening at S$0.22, a 12.5% premium above the post-consolidated price of S$0.20. The company, which has 15 doctors and 12 medical clinics, saw 21.8 million shares traded on its first day. Following a reverse takeover and 500-to-1 consolidation, Livingstone's market capitalization increased by 68.3% to S$69.5 million.

site_title: Real household incomes decline for first time in more than 10 years
summary: Singapore households experienced their first decline in median household income from work in over 10 years, with a 2.4% drop in real terms in 2021, mainly due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Lower-income households were hardest hit, with a 6.1% real decline, while resident households received an average of S$6,308 per household member from government schemes. This decline marks a reversal of the previous five-year trend of increasing median household income from work.

site_title: SoftBank files for two more SPACs seeking to raise US$630m
summary: SoftBank Group Corp plans to raise up to $630 million through two new special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs), SVF Investment Corp 2 and 3, in less than two months after its first SPAC filing. The new vehicles target diverse technology areas and have committed capital for potential mergers, capitalizing on record investor demand for SPACs.

site_title: Myanmar police fire water cannon at Naypyidaw protesters
summary: Myanmar police used water cannons against thousands of protesters in Naypyidaw, firing in brief bursts after some protesters were knocked to the ground. The demonstration continued despite police stopping the water cannon use after protesters appealed. The incident occurred a week after Aung San Suu Kyi, the country's elected leader, was detained in a coup.

site_title: Seoul: Shares down near 1% on news Hyundai-Apple car deal is off
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.94% on Monday, driven by a decline in auto shares after Hyundai Motor and Kia confirmed they are no longer in talks with Apple for autonomous electric cars. Hyundai Motor and Kia shares tumbled 8.42% and 15.27%, respectively. The won rose 0.37% to 1,119.6 per dollar. Foreign investors sold 354.6 billion won worth of shares, and the benchmark Kospi closed at 3,091.24.

site_title: Chinese ditch flying (and blind dates) in blow to airlines
summary: Chinese Lunar New Year travel season, known as Chunyun, has seen a significant decline in passenger traffic due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with 71% lower traffic on Jan 28 compared to 2020. Airlines have been heavily impacted, with some flights cancelled and ticket prices dropping to record lows. Despite this, analysts predict the domestic travel market will rebound if infections remain low, with initial capacity increases and higher ticket prices expected.

site_title: Transports of delight: Chinese get a taste of home for Lunar New Year
summary: Chinese people unable to reunite with loved ones for Lunar New Year are sending them care packages with food items, bridging the distance due to coronavirus warnings. E-commerce sales surged 40% during a shopping festival, with online food sales up 40% compared to last year's Lunar New Year. The trend is expected to boost China's economy, where travel restrictions have impacted spending on services. Producers of local delicacies are cashing in on the demand, with sales of Beijing brands increasing by 135% and 500% respectively.

site_title: Diamonds forecast to regain pre-pandemic sparkle in 2022-2024
summary: Diamond jewellery demand is forecast to recover to pre-pandemic levels between 2022 and 2024, driven by growing high and middle classes in China and India, according to a report by Bain. China's demand will recover fully this year, while India's will recover by end-2023 or 2024. The US is expected to recover by 2022-2023. Rough diamond production is predicted to remain stable from 2023 to 2030, with minimal new mine projects. The diamond industry is well-positioned for a strong rebound, with profit margins expected to recover.

site_title: Singtel launches zero-rated gaming bundles for 'League of Legends: Wild Rift'
summary: Singtel partners with Riot Games to offer zero-rated gaming bundles for 'League of Legends: Wild Rift', the world's first such bundles. Singtel 5G customers receive a three-month subscription, while other post-paid customers get a one-month subscription. This move aims to provide seamless gaming experiences for users, especially in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Japan's service sector sentiment worsens in January
summary: Japan's service sector sentiment index fell 3.1 points in January to 31.2, according to a Cabinet Office survey. The decline indicates weakening economic conditions, with workers expressing less confidence in current economic conditions. This is the first decline in the index since March 2020, suggesting a recent downturn in Japan's service sector.

site_title: DBS rolls out support measures to cater to well-being of business owners
summary: DBS has rolled out support measures to aid the well-being of business owners in Singapore, particularly micro and small enterprises, amid the economic downturn. The bank's new measures include complimentary access to an app for managing workplace stress, webinars on mental well-being, and financial planning strategies. The bank also plans to provide more working capital support and connectivity opportunities to help businesses pivot to new income streams and become more sustainable. This comes after a survey found that four in 10 micro and small enterprises have experienced a blow to their mental and physical well-being.

site_title: SoftBank posts Q3 profit gain as Vision Fund rallies
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund reported a Q3 profit of 1.17 trillion yen, a 20-fold increase from the previous year, driven by gains from investments in Uber Technologies and other companies. This marks a significant turnaround from the previous year, when the fund suffered losses due to a failed IPO and the COVID-19 pandemic. The profit gain is attributed to the success of the Vision Fund, which has shown resilience under the leadership of CEO Masayoshi Son.

site_title: Gold eases on higher Treasury yields, rebounding dollar
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,810.65 per ounce, as Treasury yields rose near their highest since March and the dollar rebounded, limiting losses. The dollar's strength makes gold expensive for holders of other currencies. Concerns over a slow US recovery after a weaker jobs report and high expectations for fiscal stimulus kept gold prices in check. However, economists predict gold could rise to $1,900 levels later in 2021 as Treasury yields are capped and inflation expectations rise.

site_title: Australia: Shares close higher on hopes for further US stimulus
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Monday, driven by hopes for US economic stimulus and rising iron ore prices, which boosted miners BHP and Rio Tinto. US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's prediction of full employment next year further lifted sentiment. Tech stocks advanced, with Afterpay and REA Group up 1.4% and 3.2%, respectively. The ASX 200 index closed at 6,880.7.

site_title: China's US$160b livestreaming app for 'ordinary people'
summary: China's Kuaishou, a US$159 billion livestreaming app, has gained popularity among rural Chinese users, known as "tu wei" or "earthy" people, with its focus on everyday content creators. The app's parent company made a US$5.4 billion IPO last week, with shares tripling. Kuaishou's business model, which relies on tipping rather than direct advertising, has resonated with its target demographic. However, the company faces scrutiny from the Chinese government and potential issues with its overseas app Zynn, which may be viewed as a de facto state enterprise due to data privacy and security concerns.

site_title: Marina Bay 24-bedroom penthouse collection for sale at S$138m
summary: A 24-bedroom penthouse collection at Marina Bay Residences in Singapore is up for sale at S$138 million, with a total strata area of 28,258 sq ft. The collection includes five penthouses with 24 bedrooms, a 25-metre rooftop pool, and a minimum size of 10,000 sq ft. The indicative price works out to S$4,884 per square foot. The sale is seen as a rare opportunity for a multi-generational household or ultra-high-net-worth individual, with the Singapore economy expected to drive demand for luxury properties.

site_title: 110,000 local hires supported by Jobs Growth Incentive in October: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's Jobs Growth Incentive (JGI) scheme supported 110,000 local hires in October, up from 50,000 in the first month. The government is considering extending the scheme, particularly for mature workers, and plans to introduce a more targeted Jobs Support Scheme. The Human Capital Partnership (Employment Agencies) programme, which recognizes exemplary agencies, has already helped 5 agencies. Despite stable employment numbers, the government is paying attention to mid-career workers and labour market churn.

site_title: Seadrill Asia files for bankruptcy as virus ends recovery bet
summary: Seadrill Asia, a rig operator controlled by billionaire John Fredriksen, filed for bankruptcy protection in US Bankruptcy Court in Texas, citing the economic downturn triggered by the coronavirus pandemic. This marks the second bankruptcy filing by Seadrill in four years. The company had obtained a forbearance agreement from its lenders but was unable to come up with a plan to shore up its finances, leading to the termination of nine of its senior secured credit facility agreements. Seadrill's financial struggles are attributed to a slower-than-expected recovery in the drilling market.

site_title: Three non-bank e-wallet players to offer PayNow
summary: Three non-bank e-wallet players, Grab Financial Group, Liquid Group, and Singtel Dash, will now offer PayNow services, marking the first time non-banks can participate. A Virtual Payment Address (VPA) has been created to facilitate fund transfers between bank accounts and e-wallets, allowing users to link their mobile numbers to an e-wallet while keeping their existing PayNow registration linked to a bank account. This expansion aims to increase accessibility and convenience for users.

site_title: Shophouses on Amoy Street, Balestier Road for sale
summary: Three shophouses, one on Amoy Street and two on Balestier Road, are up for sale in Singapore. The properties have guide prices of nearly S$26 million and S$6.8 million, respectively. An expression of interest (EOI) exercise for the properties will close on April 8. The sale follows a period of increasing demand for Singapore's prime properties, with a Q3 wave of condo launches expected to test the market.

site_title: Surbana Jurong's masterplan for US$16b 'Ream City' in Cambodia gets green light
summary: Surbana Jurong's US$16 billion 'Ream City' masterplan for a 10-minute drive from Sihanoukville International Airport in Cambodia has received approval from Canopy Sands Development. The 834-hectare project aims to transform the region with tourism, commercial, and residential activities, housing up to 130,000 residents. The plan includes a 6km beachfront, business hubs, hotels, and family attractions, prioritizing the integration of nature. The development will be undertaken by Surbana Jurong, with a focus on sustainability and community facilities.

site_title: Top International makes new leadership hires
summary: Top International Holding, a Singapore-based mining and trading company, has appointed three new leaders to bolster its team. Annie Koh, a professor emeritus of finance, joins as senior adviser, guiding strategic opportunities and corporate partnerships. Ian Gay, former general manager at Giti Tire, becomes chief financial officer. Li Sichuan, a director of investments and business development, joins from His Reich. The company aims to scale up through diversification and neutralize its carbon footprint using low-carbon energy solutions. CEO Victor Tan stated that the new hires will help achieve the company's three-year goals.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.45 points, or 0.16%, to 1,581.08 on Monday, with 397 gainers outpacing 291 losers. Volume reached 1.03 billion lots worth RM511.12 million.

site_title: Australia urges calm over AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine after South Africa suspends use
summary: Australia's Minister for Health, Greg Hunt, reassured citizens over the efficacy of AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine amid South Africa's suspension of the shot due to limited protection against a new virus strain. The AstraZeneca vaccine reduced mild-to-moderate Covid-19 by 22%, according to data. Australia is expected to approve the vaccine's use within days and has ordered 53 million doses, with CSL Ltd manufacturing most of them locally. Australia has had a relatively low number of cases and deaths, with just one new local case reported on Monday.

site_title: Palestinians launch postcodes in assertion of sovereignty
summary: The Palestinian Authority has announced it will begin using its own postal codes, effective April, in a move to assert sovereignty and ease parcel delivery in the occupied West Bank. The new codes will help prevent Israel from seizing shipments and make services more efficient. However, the move may not significantly reduce mailing costs. The rollout will also be extended to the Gaza Strip, where Israel maintains a blockade. Palestinian officials claim that Israel has obstructed deliveries, holding up six tonnes of packages in Jordan since 2018.

site_title: Unrelenting bird flu spread sparks egg shortages in South Korea
summary: South Korea is experiencing egg shortages due to the highly contagious H5N8 strain of avian influenza, which has led to the culling of over 25 million birds. Egg prices have soared, with retail prices rising 43% and foreign supply expected to cool prices ahead of the Lunar New Year. The government has removed import tariffs on fresh eggs and egg products through June 30 to bolster supply, and plans to bring in 20 million eggs from the US by February 10.

site_title: Preliminary report into Sriwijaya Air crash expected on Feb 10
summary: Indonesia's air accident investigator expects to release the preliminary report on the Sriwijaya Air plane crash on Feb 10. The 26-year-old Boeing 7-500 jet crashed into the Java Sea on Jan 9, killing all 62 people on board. Investigators have located and examined the flight data recorder and parts of the plane, but the cockpit voice recorder remains unrecovered. The report will be uploaded to the National Transportation Safety Committee's website once available, providing insights into the human factors related to the crash.

site_title: A new commodities boom beckons when pent-up demand is unleashed
summary: A new commodities boom is expected as the COVID-19 pandemic ends, unleashing pent-up demand and boosting raw material prices. Institutions like Goldman Sachs and Ospraie Management predict commodities will continue to rise, with potential 100% to 300% returns in total commodities over the next 18-36 months. The lack of new supply projects and strong fiscal and monetary stimulus will drive the commodities cycle, making it one of the best in history, according to fund managers.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street records on stimulus optimism
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, following Wall Street's record highs, as hopes for a US stimulus package and improving COVID-19 data boosted investor sentiment. The US economy created fewer jobs than expected, fueling expectations for a large stimulus package. Asian markets, including Tokyo and Hong Kong, also extended their gains, while Seoul fell. Analysts say the global rally may be back on track, despite concerns about valuations, as central banks continue to provide stimulus.

site_title: Govt 'will try our best' to support all local firms that want to upgrade: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing has assured local firms that the government will support those seeking to upgrade, as long as they have the desire to do so. The government will focus on product redesign, services, and production processes, and will allocate funds to the Ministry of Trade and Industry to strengthen capabilities. The government's "very stretch target" is 50% growth in the manufacturing sector by 2030, and it plans to establish a network of industrial parks across South-east Asia.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 2,914.49 on Monday, driven by a positive lead from Wall Street and a weaker US dollar. Gainers outnumbered losers 118 to 50, with shares of Singtel, Thai Beverage, DBS, UOB, and OCBC advancing. The market is expected to remain cautiously positive ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday later this week.

site_title: China aluminium sector must shut inefficient coal power to meet climate goals: report
summary: China's aluminium sector must shut over 1,000 MW of coal-fired power capacity, equivalent to Germany's entire coal fleet, to meet its climate goals by 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2060, according to a report by climate think tank Ember. China's 2020 aluminium production, 37 million tonnes, emitted more CO2 than some entire countries, including Indonesia and Brazil. The country's reliance on coal-fired power for aluminium production is a major obstacle to meeting its carbon pledges.

site_title: Hyundai Motor, Kia say they are not in talks with Apple on autonomous car development
summary: Hyundai Motor and Kia Corp stated they are not in talks with Apple Inc on developing autonomous vehicles. The companies' shares dropped as much as 8.4% and 13.3% respectively.

site_title: Tesco calls on UK's Sunak to introduce higher online sales tax
summary: Tesco and other retailers are urging UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak to introduce a higher online sales tax to help high street stores affected by the pandemic. The proposed 1% tax is part of a letter to Sunak signed by 18 business leaders, calling for a permanent reduction in business rates and a fairer tax system for online retailers. The move comes as the UK considers reforms to business levies ahead of the March 3 budget, with the goal of supporting struggling retailers and communities.

site_title: Malaysia's Dec factory output rises 1.7% y-o-y, better than forecast
summary: Malaysia's industrial production index rose 1.7% in December from a year earlier, beating forecast expectations of a 0.5% decline. The rebound follows a 2.2% contraction in November. This marks the first expansion in the index since August. The better-than-expected performance is attributed to higher manufacturing output.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's industrial production index rebounded in December after two months of decline, rising 1.7 per cent from a year earlier on higher manufacturing output, government data showed on Monday.

site_title: Japan's economic recovery from pandemic likely stalled in Q4: poll
summary: Japan's economic growth likely stalled in Q4, with a Reuters poll showing a 2.3% quarter-on-quarter expansion in October-December, slower than a 5.3% jump in the previous quarter. Consumption, especially service spending, continues to decline due to restrictions, and the economy is expected to remain at 80% of pre-pandemic levels. Private consumption rose just 1.8% and capital spending increased 2.6% in the quarter, driven by brisk overseas demand and government stimulus measures.

site_title: Stocks to watch: mm2 Asia, Frasers Property, Sembcorp, Manulife US Reit, Yoma
summary: A Singapore private equity investor expressed interest in investing in one of mm2 Asia's core businesses, causing the company's shares to remain unchanged at S$0.12. Frasers Property reported lower revenue per average room for its hospitality properties globally, with shares closing flat at S$1.22.

site_title: Chinese sauce maker Salion seeks up to US$400m in sale
summary: Chinese sauce maker Salion Foods Co, a manufacturer of condiments and seasonings, is seeking a buyer in a deal worth about US$300-400 million. The company, founded in 2000, develops and manufactures over 100 products, including barbecue sauce, chicken essence, and blueberry powder, sold in over 30 countries. This potential sale would be the latest in a string of US$9.2 billion food-related acquisitions involving Chinese companies in the past year, following PepsiCo's US$705 million acquisition of Hangzhou Haomusi Food Co in June.

site_title: Accounting firms, professionals to get S$8m lifeline to cope with Covid-19 impact
summary: Singapore's Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA) will provide an S$8 million support package to accounting firms and professionals to cope with the Covid-19 pandemic. The fund aims to help individual accountants and small and medium-sized accounting firms, mainly serving small and medium-sized enterprises. ISCA president Kon Yin Tong noted that the full impact of the pandemic had not yet hit clients last year due to government support. The support package is expected to help accounting firms transform and adapt to the post-pandemic business landscape.

site_title: Blackstone invests in new hedge fund ApaH Capital: sources
summary: Blackstone Group has invested $150 million in ApaH Capital Management, a hedge fund launched by former Lone Star Funds executive Anand Balakrishna Madduri. ApaH Capital will focus on public and private market investments across Asia, including Australia, China, India, and Japan, with around $200 million in assets. The hedge fund aims to capitalize on emerging markets opportunities in the region.

site_title: Hot stock: mm2 Asia tumbles 30.8% after news of potential investor, proposed rights issue
summary: Shares in mm2 Asia plummeted 30.8% on Monday after the entertainment group announced a potential new investment and a proposed rights issue. A Singapore private equity investor expressed interest in taking a minority stake in one of its core businesses, and mm2 Asia received in-principle approval for a renounceable underwritten rights issue to raise S$52.2 million. The company's shares closed at a record-low of 8.3 cents, down 3.7 cents or 30.8% from the previous close.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb on improving US stimulus hopes, no new local virus cases
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to 6,882.30, driven by improving US stimulus hopes and an improving local coronavirus situation. The US$1.9 trillion Covid-19 package appears more certain to pass Congress, with Speaker Nancy Pelosi predicting a final vote by March 15. Meanwhile, Australia logged zero new coronavirus cases for three consecutive days, boosting sentiment. The Australian mining index gained 1.8% and tech stocks reached a record high, with BHP and Rio Tinto advancing 1.9% and 2.3% respectively.

site_title: Mongolia seeking pact with Rio Tinto to end copper mine expansion: FT
summary: Mongolia's government is seeking an agreement with Rio Tinto to terminate the expansion of the Oyu Tolgoi copper mine, citing concerns that the project's costs have increased significantly. The mine, which holds one of the world's largest copper and gold deposits, has seen its economic benefits erode due to rising costs. The Mongolian government, which holds a 34% stake in the project, wants to avoid unilateral action that could harm future foreign investment. Rio Tinto has not responded to a request for comment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened sharply higher on Monday, building on last week's rally, driven by hopes for US stimulus and slowing virus infections. The Hang Seng Index jumped 1.16% to 29,629.08, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose. The gains follow a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and fresh records in the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq. The strong start is seen as a positive sign for Asian markets, despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia's Vocus Group gets A$3.42b takeover bid from Macquarie Infrastructure
summary: Vocus Group, an Australian fibre network owner, has received a A$3.42 billion takeover offer from Macquarie Infrastructure and Real Assets Holdings Pty Ltd. The offer, valued at A$5.5 per Vocus share, represents a 25.6% premium to its last close. This comes after previous bids from AGL Energy and EQT Infrastructure were dropped over a year and a half ago. Vocus will open its books for due diligence and is expected to submit a binding proposal, paving the way for a potential takeover.

site_title: Biden says challenging for US to reach herd immunity by summer's end
summary: US President Joe Biden stated that reaching herd immunity, or at least 75% of the population inoculated against the coronavirus, by the end of summer is "very difficult". As of Sunday, the US has administered 41.2 million doses of Covid-19 vaccines and distributed 59.3 million doses. This contradicts earlier expectations that the country could achieve herd immunity by summer's end.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, extending rallies on Wall Street, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.27% and the Topix index up 0.49%. Investors focus on earnings reports, following a similar trend on US stock markets.

site_title: Manulife US Reit H2 DPU falls 11.3% to 2.59 US cents
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a 11.3% decline in its half-year distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.59 US cents due to lower property income and a provision for expected credit losses. Gross revenue grew 1.2% to US$95.6 million, while net property income fell 8.2% to US$53.7 million. The Reit's income available for distribution declined 5.5% to US$41 million. Despite this, the Reit's DPU for the full year is expected to be 5.64 US cents, 5.4% lower than the previous year.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB bullish on Food Empire, expects growth in demand for products
summary: RHB Holdings has reaffirmed its "strong buy call" on Food Empire Holdings, raising its target price to S$1.27 from S$0.80 due to a higher price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio. The research team expects demand for Food Empire's products to grow, driven by the Covid-19 pandemic and vaccine distribution, resulting in a 24.7% earnings growth forecast for FY2021. Shares of Food Empire closed up 9.14% on Monday, trading at 10 times its forecasted FY2021 earnings, making it an undervalued candidate for privatisation.

site_title: South Africa suspends AstraZeneca vaccination launch over study
summary: South Africa has suspended its launch of AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccinations due to a study showing the vaccine failed to prevent mild and moderate cases of the virus variant in the country. The nation was set to receive 1 million doses of the vaccine but will instead rely on deliveries from other producers. The suspension marks a setback for the country, but officials believe other vaccine supplies will soon be available, allowing the campaign to proceed.

site_title: Taiwan penalises Deutsche Bank, three others for currency trades
summary: Taiwan's central bank penalized Deutsche Bank and three other foreign lenders for speculation on the surging local currency, revoking trading approvals and banning transactions for two years. ING Groep NV and ANZ Banking Group were banned for nine months, while Citigroup was banned for two months. The penalties were imposed due to large positions built by food traders and six overseas banks in Taiwan dollar deliverable forwards, which affected market stability. The actions aim to prevent speculation and maintain currency stability.

site_title: Biden foresees 'extreme competition' with China, not 'conflict'
summary: US President Joe Biden anticipates intense competition with China, rather than conflict, in their rivalry. In a CBS interview, Biden stated that Chinese President Xi Jinping is "very tough" but emphasized the US will not engage in conflict. Biden plans to focus on international rules and protect American interests, differing from former President Donald Trump's approach of open confrontation and verbal attacks. China is considered the US' number one strategic adversary, and Biden aims to address the trade deficit and promote a more collaborative approach.

site_title: Greece hit by power cuts after fire breaks out at power station
summary: A fire broke out at a high-voltage power station in Aspropyrgos, Athens, Greece, causing power cuts in regions across the country on Sunday night. The cause of the fire was unclear, but it was likely a technical failure. The fire brigade and power grid operator ADMIE responded to the incident with 12 firefighters and four engines. The extent of the damage and the number of affected areas were not specified in the article.

site_title: George Shultz, US secretary of state who helped usher out Cold War, dies at 100
summary: George Shultz, US Secretary of State during the end of the Cold War, has died at 100. A diplomat and economist, Shultz served four cabinet positions, including Secretary of State under Ronald Reagan. He played a key role in negotiating with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, leading to the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty in 1987. Shultz's approach emphasized US strength and diplomacy, but also advocated for preemptive strikes and military action, including the 1986 strikes on Libya. His legacy is marked by both significant diplomatic achievements and criticisms of his hawkish stance on terrorism and foreign policy.

site_title: France exceeded CO2 reduction target in 2019: Macron
summary: France exceeded its 2019 carbon emissions reduction target of 1.5% by 1.7%, according to President Emmanuel Macron. The reduction was achieved despite campaigners accusing the government of failing to meet its own roadmap. A Paris court found the state negligent in its fight against climate change, while Environment Minister Barbara Pompili said measures such as boiler replacements are showing results, helping the country stay on track to meet its 2030 emissions reduction target. France aims to become carbon neutral by 2050.

site_title: Google moves away from diet of 'cookies' to track users
summary: Google is shifting away from using "cookies" to track users, a practice criticized for compromising online privacy. The company's Federated Learning of Cohorts (FLoC) approach uses on-device processing to hide users' web history and provide relevant ads while maintaining privacy. Google plans to test FLoC with advertisers later this year, aiming to replace third-party cookies and address growing concerns about user data rights and legislation. The move is seen as a response to criticism and a growing trend towards internet rights legislation.

site_title: Old but gold: Tokyo's retro car owners revel in their modern classics
summary: A group of Japanese retro car enthusiasts in Tokyo gather on weekends to show off their classic vehicles, including a Pontiac Trans Am and a 1941 Cadillac. The owners meticulously maintain their cars, often spending days to achieve a shiny new look. The group appreciates the charm of old cars, which require more care and attention, and the nostalgic appeal of their sleek lines and high shine. The enthusiasts' passion for vintage cars sets them apart from Japan's practical, fuel-efficient vehicles.

site_title: Covid-19 is a game changer for digital payments
summary: Singapore's digital payment use has seen significant growth since the Covid-19 pandemic, with the value of PayNow transactions by UOB customers growing 220% in the first 10 months of 2020. The use of QR payments also increased by 272% during the same period. To encourage digital payments, the authorities and industry players can incentivize consumers by targeting merchants who interact with them daily and working with them to build "muscle memory" for digital payments. This includes supermarkets, hawker centers, food courts, and transport-related merchants.

site_title: Elliott Management looks to raise more than US$1b for a SPAC: WSJ
summary: Hedge fund Elliott Management is reportedly meeting with bankers to raise over $1 billion for a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC). This process is in its early stages and may change. SPACs have become a popular choice among investors, with $24.26 billion raised in January, 20 times more than the same period in 2020. The SPAC market has seen significant growth, with $79 billion raised in 2020. The plans for the SPAC are still unclear, and Elliott Management has not commented on the matter.

site_title: Denmark to build North Sea 'energy island'
summary: Denmark has approved plans to build an artificial island in the North Sea to generate wind power for at least 3 million households, with the potential to supply 10 million households. The island, which will be majority-owned by the Danish government, is expected to cost around $45.4 billion and will serve as an "energy hub" for distributing incoming energy from other countries' wind farms. The project aims to reduce Denmark's CO2 emissions by 70% by 2030 and could also export excess energy to the rest of Europe.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings reported a net loss for the year ended Dec 31, 2020, due to Covid-19 measures restricting activities. The firm recorded lower gold output and impairment losses. In contrast, its subsidiary CMNM Mining Group resumed full operations at its Sokor gold mine. Plastoform Holdings submitted a proposal to resume trading, which has been suspended since April 2019, pending approval from the Singapore Exchange Regulation.

site_title: Manchester City thrash Liverpool 4-1 to close in on Premier League title
summary: Manchester City thrashed Liverpool 4-1 at Anfield, moving five points clear of Manchester United in the Premier League title race. Ilkay Gundogan scored twice and missed a penalty, while Raheem Sterling and Phil Foden also found the net. The win marks City's 14th consecutive league win, with 10 of those coming in the league. Liverpool, meanwhile, lost their third consecutive home league game and are now 10 points off the top, having played a game more than City.

images.alt_text: Manchester City ended an 18-year wait to beat Liverpool at Anfield in style with a 4-1 win on Sunday to take a firm grip on the Premier League title race.

site_title: Philippines plans US$23.7b fund-raising for budget, infrastructure projects
summary: The Philippines aims to raise US$23.71 billion from external sources to fund its budget deficit and priority projects, including US$5.5 billion from commercial markets. This represents a 39% increase from last year's US$17.01 billion. The funds will support an economic recovery, purchase COVID-19 vaccines, and finance infrastructure projects. The government targets a 6.5-7.5% growth rate for the pandemic-hit economy this year.

site_title: How the pandemic left the US$25b Hudson Yards eerily deserted
summary: The $25 billion Hudson Yards development in New York City is struggling due to the pandemic, with hundreds of unsold luxury condos and a mall with few customers. The anchor tenant Neiman Marcus filed for bankruptcy and closed permanently, and several restaurants have also gone out of business. The development's office buildings are largely empty, and the second phase, which included a school and low-cost rental units, appears on indefinite hold. Despite efforts to reassure investors, the project's financial viability is uncertain, and some investors are considering lawsuits.

site_title: US must lift curbs before Iran rejoins nuclear deal; Khamenei cites 'final' stance
summary: Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei stated that Iran will only rejoin the 2015 nuclear deal if the US lifts all sanctions. Khamenei cited the US's "final and irreversible" stance in allowing Iran to return to compliance. This decision comes after the US, under President Donald Trump, abandoned the deal in 2018 and reimposed sanctions that have crippled Iran's economy. Iran has breached the deal's key limits multiple times and has said it can quickly reverse those violations if US sanctions are removed.

site_title: Local retail S-Reits see gradual recovery in tenants' sales
summary: Singapore's retail S-Reits see a gradual recovery in tenants' sales, with Frasers Centrepoint Trust and Starhill Global Reit emerging as top performers. The two retail S-Reits garnered net institutional inflows of S$12.4 million in the 2021 year-to-date period. Despite a 3.6% year-on-year decline in Singapore's total retail sales in December 2020, Frasers Centrepoint Trust reported resilient portfolio occupancy and recovered tenants' sales to near pre-Covid-19 levels.

site_title: Boost family offices, private wealth management sector to spur recovery: BDO
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 may focus on boosting the family offices and private wealth management sector to spur recovery, according to BDO. The government could encourage investment in key areas such as startups or sustainability through preferential tax rates or investment schemes. Tax measures, including increased stamp duties, are also a possibility. However, a wealth tax is unlikely at this stage, as Singapore aims to maintain its international financial hub status and attract wealthy families. The government may instead focus on greater scrutiny of taxpayers and complex tax structures to raise revenue.

site_title: Twin engines of warehousing and concrete production drive returns for GKE
summary: GKE Corp, a Singapore-based company, has reported a significant increase in revenue and net profit due to improved demand for its warehousing and logistics services in Singapore, as well as its strategic infrastructure investments in China. The company's warehouse capacity is currently full, and it is exploring opportunities to acquire or rent additional storage space. The Chinese government's urbanization project is also driving demand for ready-mixed concrete, contributing 40% of the company's overall revenue. GKE Corp's shares have climbed in tandem with the improved performance, and the company is looking to expand its warehouse capacity and diversify into new ventures, including vertical farming.

site_title: Cuba opens door to most small business initiatives
summary: The Cuban government has announced a major reform allowing small private businesses to operate in most fields, expanding from 127 activities to over 2,000, as part of efforts to recover from an economic slump. The move, approved by a council of ministers, aims to boost the economy and diversify the state-dominated economy. The reform is seen as a significant shift towards a more market-oriented approach, following years of economic struggles.

site_title: European aluminium buyers are starting to pay up to go green
summary: European aluminium buyers are starting to pay a premium for "green" aluminium, with multiple transactions fetching up to US$14 a tonne. This trend is driven by the car industry, with BMW AG and Emirates Global aluminium PJSC striking a deal worth at least 100 million euros for solar-powered aluminium. Producers such as Alcoa Corp and Rio Tinto Group are branding their low-carbon options as "green" aluminium, with companies like Norsk Hydro ASA and United Co Rusal International PJSC seeing customers willing to pay a "green premium".

site_title: Central banks edging toward money's next frontier in digital world
summary: Central banks are moving towards creating digital currencies, a significant reinvention of money, as the world shifts towards cashless economies. With the rise of alternative concepts like bitcoin, monetary policymakers aim to ensure they don't fall behind. This development raises concerns over privacy, social equality, and financial stability. A power struggle over the future of money is expected, with key stakeholders vying for control. The creation of digital currencies could lead to a more secure and efficient monetary system, but its implementation will require careful consideration of various factors.

site_title: Empty offices can help ease Germany's housing crunch: lobby group
summary: Germany's housing shortage could be eased by converting thousands of vacant office properties into living space, according to a lobby group. As many as 235,000 residential units could be created by 2025, costing around 1,100 euros per square meter. This would be more affordable than fully modernizing or building new spaces. The proposal comes as the Covid-19 pandemic has exacerbated the shortage of affordable housing and shifts towards remote work may become permanent.

site_title: Malaysia revises Covid-19 rules to allow more to gather for CNY reunion dinner
summary: Malaysia has revised its COVID-19 rules to allow up to 15 people to attend Chinese New Year (CNY) reunion dinners, following criticism from Chinese groups and politicians. The revised standard operating procedures (SOPs) were announced by the National Unity Ministry, lifting restrictions that previously limited gatherings to household members only. The move is seen as a concession to Chinese communities ahead of the festivities.

site_title: Companies make use of technology to reach out to seniors
summary: Companies like OCBC and Hong Leong Foundation have found ways to continue spreading cheer to seniors despite COVID-19 restrictions. OCBC adopted a hybrid volunteering model, with some staff visiting Senior Activity Centres while others participated virtually, folding origami firecrackers and giving design tips online. Meanwhile, Hong Leong Foundation brought 330 elderly seniors on a virtual wildlife adventure, featuring interactive activities and animal acts, and delivered lunch and Chinese New Year goodies to their homes. These efforts aim to keep seniors active and combat loneliness during the Lunar New Year.

site_title: Biden's Cabinet sets the bar on diversity, experience
summary: US President Joe Biden's Cabinet appointments have set a record for diversity and experience, fulfilling campaign promises and diverging from the Trump administration's approach. The new team includes Vice-President Kamala Harris, Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg, and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, all of whom bring extensive experience to their roles. The appointments are intended to create an executive branch that "looks like America," and are seen as a key factor in the Biden administration's ability to hit the ground running and tackle top priorities such as vaccine rollouts and economic stimulus.

site_title: Gear up for a digital future
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 should prioritize social, economic, and environmental sustainability, according to experts. This includes initiatives to support key workers, increase societal recognition of their contributions, and promote a more progressive tax system. The budget should also focus on building a resilient economy, investing in digital skills and training, and encouraging investment in business creation and job creation. Additionally, measures to mitigate climate change and promote sustainable development are crucial, with Singapore positioning itself as a leading regional center for green finance and services. A holistic approach to digital transformation and employee well-being is also necessary for the country's recovery.

site_title: Asset quality stress, dividend cap in focus for Singapore banks in 2021
summary: Singapore banks' asset quality risks are expected to remain manageable due to hefty provisions and relief measures. Analysts will monitor post-moratorium repayment trends in Q4 2020 and await clarity on the banks' dividend cap, with expectations of higher payouts in 2021.

site_title: Climate change presents strategic opportunities for boards
summary: Climate change is now considered a strategic risk, alongside technology disruptions, cyber security, pandemics, and terrorism, with boards needing to identify, assess, and address climate risks to avoid potential stakeholder claims. The crisis presents opportunities for companies to pivot and transform challenges into strategic advantages. Boards should frame climate change as a key business issue, prioritize its value creation potential, and incentivize management to focus on measuring and addressing climate change impacts. By doing so, companies can distinguish themselves in the market and create a competitive edge.

site_title: For sale: London's thinnest house
summary: London's thinnest house, measuring 5ft 6ins at its narrowest point, is on the market for £950,000 (S$1.74 million). Originally a Victorian hat shop, the five-floor house has unique period features, art deco designs, and a garden. Estate agent David Myers believes the house's uniqueness and space will appeal to buyers, despite its high price tag. The house has doubled in value since 2006 and is expected to sell to a "young couple or individual" who appreciates its individuality.

site_title: Hive thinking: Beekeeping makes a buzz in Ivory Coast
summary: In Ivory Coast, beekeeping has become a lucrative and environmentally friendly practice, supplementing farmers' income and improving crop yields. West African bees, known for their wild nature, are being kept by farmers to produce high-quality honey, which is renowned for its unique flavors. Modern beekeeping is on the rise in Africa, with organizations and cooperatives working to promote sustainable practices and protect the bees from insecticides. The industry is expected to grow, with estimates suggesting 30 tonnes of honey are produced annually, and Ivory Coast could become the world's leading honey producer.

site_title: Regulators should avoid dampening animal spirits while policing social media platforms
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) have warned investors to be cautious of misinformation and false statements on social media, particularly in relation to trading in securities. They advise against infringing the Securities and Futures Act and encourage regulators to focus on bad actors spreading misinformation, rather than retail investors discussing their own stocks. This warning comes after the GameStop short squeeze last month, where excitement and speculation were generated by online discussion forums and social media chat groups.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) are getting nervous about all the excitement generated by the GameStop short squeeze last month.

site_title: Is silver's surge sustainable?
summary: Silver prices surged to a 2013 high of $30.10 per ounce, driven by retail traders' interest, despite some analysts warning of potential profit-taking and retracement. The price action, which began from a low of $24.70, saw silver trade in a range before breaking above resistance levels. The surge has led to shortages in physical silver and a 20% rise in Australian mining companies. However, some caution is advised as the price may retrace and consolidate lower, potentially targeting the 23.6% retracement level of $25.43.

site_title: Brokers must 'act and think' like fintechs
summary: Singapore's traditional retail broking business faces intense competition from self-directed online trading, prompting brokers to adopt a fintech-driven approach to stay relevant. Phillip Securities managing director Luke Lim says brokers must "think and act like fintechs" to optimize operations and meet customers' needs. The brokerage has already acquired RHB Securities Singapore to increase scale and scope, and plans to develop its wealth management capabilities and offer innovative technology solutions. To remain competitive, Phillip Securities aims to remain price-competitive while enhancing its capabilities, partnering with fintechs, and focusing on high-touch services.

site_title: Oil 'tailwind' helps Canadian dollar end weekly losing streak
summary: The Canadian dollar ended a three-week losing streak, trading 0.5% higher against the US dollar at 1.2766 to the greenback. This rally was driven by oil's one-year high, despite data showing Canada lost more jobs than expected in January. The loonie traded in a range of 1.2765 to 1.2832, marking a significant turnaround from its previous weekly declines.

site_title: Are new cooling measures coming to Singapore's housing market?
summary: Singapore is expected to implement cooling measures in its housing market if the uptrend in home prices continues to rise. Analysts predict a policy change around mid-February, near Budget 2021, if the property price index increases by more than 5% annually. Proposed measures include higher stamp duties, tighter loan limits, and minimum unit size requirements to target investors and reduce affordability ratios.

site_title: Bitcoin rally takes crypto market value to new record
summary: Bitcoin reached a new record, surpassing $40,658, a 7% increase, and bringing the market value of digital tokens to $1.23 trillion. This marks the largest cryptocurrency's closest approach to its January all-time high of nearly $42,000. The rally comes as the crypto market experiences significant growth.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for February 5, 2021, reveals a mixed market for tankers and dry bulk vessels. The North Atlantic basin saw a decline in rates, with the Transatlantic C8 falling $6,645 week-on-week to $16,605. In contrast, the Pacific region remained at a heavy discount, with the Transpacific C10 closing at $7,788. The market is expected to quieten down ahead of the Chinese New Year, with most of Asia experiencing public holidays. Rates in Asia slowly eroded, with sporadic fixing appearing in the north Pacific.

site_title: Alcohol bans force South African wineries to rethink trade plans
summary: South Africa's government has imposed a third alcohol ban to curb the spread of COVID-19, forcing wineries to rethink their trade plans. The ban, which lasted five weeks, has resulted in significant job losses, particularly in the hospitality industry and among smaller wine sellers. However, some wine producers, like Distell Group Holdings, have managed to maintain revenue through exports and stockpiling. Winemakers like Berene Sauls are now forced to review their expansion plans, with many expecting a longer timeline for growth due to the economic impact of the ban.

site_title: CNMC issues profit warning; Kelantan unit gets approval to operate in MCO 2.0
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, has issued a profit warning due to the impact of Malaysia's Covid-19 measures, which restricted its activities and resulted in lower gold output. The company expects to report a net loss for the year ended Dec 31, with impairment losses to be provided for certain exploration and evaluation assets. Meanwhile, CNMC's subsidiary CMNM Mining Group has received approval to resume full operations at its Sokor gold mine in Kelantan during the current MCO 2.0.

site_title: Term life cover: Pay only for what you need
summary: Term life insurance policies, which offer a death benefit with no cash value, have seen an increase in take-up due to growing awareness of the need for life cover. This trend is partly fueled by the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. According to a 2017 study by the Life Insurance Association, Singapore's mortality protection gap is S$355 billion, equivalent to 2.1 times annual income. Insurers are now offering enhanced features for term policies, making them a more attractive option for consumers. This shift is expected to provide more protection for the same premium.

site_title: Ex-TPG Capital executive to plead guilty in college admissions scandal
summary: Bill McGlashan, a former TPG Capital executive, has agreed to plead guilty to wire fraud and honest services wire fraud in the US college admissions scandal. He faces three months in prison and a $250,000 fine. This marks the 30th parent to plead guilty in the case. McGlashan had previously professed his innocence and had a trial scheduled for later this year. The plea deal was reached after prosecutors claimed McGlashan paid $50,000 to arrange for his son's ACT exam answers to be corrected and discussed paying $250,000 for his son to get into the University of Southern California.

site_title: IMF chief warns of 'lost generation' if low-income countries don't get more help
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warns of a "Great Divergence" in global growth, where low-income countries risk falling behind, potentially leading to social unrest and a "lost generation." She urges advanced economies to provide more resources to low-income countries, citing a significant gap in support measures during the pandemic. Georgieva also advocates for debt restructuring and boosting conditions for growth in heavily indebted countries.

site_title: Malaysia's pension fund weighing sale of up to RM450m of real estate assets
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) is considering the sale of up to RM450 million of real estate assets, including office buildings, a retail property, and a seaside hotel. The decision is part of EPF's ordinary course of managing its investments as a long-term strategic investor for its 14.8 million members. The sale or purchase of assets will be evaluated based on the fund's overall portfolio strategy and the long-term health of the fund.

site_title: Are property curbs looming?
summary: Singapore's property market is experiencing a surge in sales momentum, with two major launches this year and a 2.1% quarterly price jump in the residential index. Analysts, such as RHB's Vijay Natarajan, suggest that policy tweaks, or "property curbs," may be on the horizon to cool the market. This comes as sales momentum grows, raising concerns about the potential for additional cooling measures to prevent a housing bubble. The Singapore government is reportedly exploring measures, including those related to property agents' commissions, to address the market's rapid growth.

site_title: Petrobras expands fuel price parity calculation period to cut volatility
summary: Petrobras, Brazil's state-controlled oil company, has expanded its fuel price parity calculation period from three months to one year, aiming to reduce volatility in local gas pump prices. The change, effective since the first half of 2020, gives the company more flexibility to operate below international prices without registering losses. This move follows a Reuters report and comes amid concerns about the impact of international price swings on consumers. The change has not generated losses for Petrobras and reflects the company's efforts to balance its operational results.

site_title: BofA divided as bankers cry foul over special bonus treatment
summary: Bank of America's CEO Brian Moynihan has faced internal backlash after waiving a new bonus policy for top traders and dealmakers, but keeping it in place for other employees. The policy, which included a "cliff vest" provision for company stock, was initially planned to be applied broadly but was exempted for investment bankers. However, senior colleagues in corporate and commercial banking were left subject to the vesting restrictions, sparking frustration and discussions about options. The decision has been described as a balancing act, with the company trying to reward high-performing traders while reducing payouts for other executives.

site_title: Luxury CEOs rave about Hainan Island, where sales are 'on fire'
summary: US luxury retailers, including Ralph Lauren, Capri Holdings, and Coach, are focusing on Hainan Island in China, where sales are surging due to the easing of virus-related restrictions. The island's duty-free allowances were tripled last July, leading to a threefold increase in daily sales. Luxury companies see Hainan as a strategic priority, with plans to expand their presence on the island. Sales at Hainan have provided a lifeline to luxury companies, with Capri Holdings' travel retail business expected to recover by fiscal 2023.

site_title: UBS to raise investment bank bonus pool as much as 20%
summary: UBS plans to increase its investment bank bonus pool by up to 20% as the bank posts its highest profit in five years, driven by a surge in trading revenue. Variable compensation for employees in the wealth management unit will remain flat or slightly up, with significant regional variations. In contrast, local rival Credit Suisse is considering cutting its bonus pool by at least 10%. The move aims to reward high-performing employees and reflects the bank's improved performance during the pandemic.

site_title: Himalayan glacier breaks in India, sweeping away dam
summary: A Himalayan glacier broke in northern India, sweeping away a hydroelectric dam and causing widespread flooding. At least 150 people are feared dead, with villagers evacuated downstream. The disaster occurred in the Dhauli Ganga river valley in the state of Uttarakhand, over 500 km north of New Delhi. The cause of the glacier break is not yet known, but the incident highlights the vulnerability of India's infrastructure to climate change and glacial melting.

site_title: China to launch public platform to track, crack down on polluters
summary: China plans to launch a public platform to track and prosecute polluters, starting March 1. The platform will allow authorities and the public to monitor real-time emission levels and check historical data. The Ministry of Ecology and Environment will take stronger action against firms that pollute without authorization and falsify emissions data, including fines of 200,000 yuan and possible shutdowns. Firms that repeatedly exceed emissions limits or have poor "social credit" ratings will face more scrutiny and inspections. The move aims to crack down on pollution and ensure compliance with regulations.

site_title: Biggest protests since 2007 sweep Myanmar
summary: Thousands of protesters took to the streets in Yangon and other cities in Myanmar for a second day of mass demonstrations against the military coup. The protesters, wearing red shirts and flags, demand the release of Aung San Suu Kyi, the country's elected leader. The protests, which began on Saturday, are the largest since the 2007 Saffron Revolution that led to democratic reforms. The protests come as the international community remains critical of the military's actions, with many calling for the restoration of democracy in Myanmar.

site_title: Plastoform submits proposal for resumption of trading
summary: Plastoform Holdings, a Mainboard-listed company, submitted a proposal to resume trading on February 6, 2021, after a suspension since April 4, 2019. The suspension was due to uncertainty over its ability to continue as a going concern. The proposal must be approved by the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) and fulfill specific conditions. Further announcements will be made as developments occur.

site_title: Thousands protest against coup in Myanmar's biggest city
summary: Thousands of protesters in Yangon, Myanmar's largest city, demonstrated against the military coup, demanding the release of Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi and other detained leaders. The protesters, many dressed in the National League for Democracy's red color, chanted slogans calling for democracy and freedom. The military has blocked social media platforms and imposed a one-year state of emergency, sparking international condemnation and calls for targeted sanctions. The US is considering sanctions, and the UN has urged the release of detainees and an end to threats against journalists.

site_title: Yoma's services resume operations amid Myanmar unrest; revenue up 0.9% in Q1
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a Myanmar-based company, reported a 0.9% year-over-year increase in revenue to US$24.8 million in Q1, driven by gains in real estate development. Despite disruptions from Myanmar's unrest, the company's services, including Wave Money, KFC, and Kospa, have largely resumed operations. Real estate development revenue grew 52.5% year-over-year, while the food and beverage business fell 29.4% due to dine-in restrictions. Yoma will continue to monitor the political situation and provide updates as necessary.

site_title: Twitter condemns Myanmar's move to block access
summary: Twitter has condemned Myanmar's move to block access to its platform as part of a broader crackdown on social media following a military coup that imprisoned Aung San Suu Kyi and other civilian leaders. The platform's spokesperson stated that the blockade undermines public conversation and the rights of people to make their voices heard. Telenor, a main telecom provider, also reported the blockade, while internet monitor NetBlocks reported disruptions to Facebook-owned platforms. Twitter will continue to advocate for an end to government-led shutdowns.

site_title: Biden urges fast Covid-19 relief as minimum-wage hike hopes fade
summary: US President Joe Biden emphasized the need for swift coronavirus relief, signaling he will push for his $1.9 trillion stimulus plan despite Republican opposition. The House cleared the way for the bill to pass with only Democratic votes, and Biden said he is willing to act without Republican support. The plan includes a minimum-wage hike, which is unlikely to pass due to Republican opposition. Despite this, Biden remains committed to the idea and is girding for a potential party-line vote to pass the package. The stimulus plan aims to address the economic pain caused by the pandemic, with a focus on helping Americans who are hurting.

site_title: Yellen warns of lasting impact of Covid on Black Americans
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned that the COVID-19 pandemic would have a lasting impact on Black Americans, citing data showing they lost small businesses and jobs first and will be the last rehired when the economy opens. Yellen emphasized the need for the Biden administration's $1.9 trillion stimulus plan to prevent a generational setback for racial equality and build an economy that works for everyone.

site_title: Lian Beng chairman continues building stake
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.5% in the five local trading sessions from Jan 29 to Feb 4, while the Nikkei 225 Index, Hang Seng Index, and S&P/ASX 200 Index averaged a 1.4% gain. Lian Beng chairman Ong Pang Aik continued to build his stake in the company, increasing his interest to 31.79%. Boustead Singapore bought back 1,368,800 shares on Feb 3, paying between 89.0 cents and 88.5 cents per share. The group reported stable revenue and a 25% higher profit in H1FY21.

site_title: Yankees stadium becomes vaccination site for New York's poor
summary: Hundreds of people in the Bronx, New York, flocked to Yankee Stadium to receive COVID-19 vaccinations, amid a positivity rate of 6.67% in the borough. The move aims to address the racial disparity in vaccination rates, with 15% of doses allocated to Hispanic people and 11% to African Americans, despite these groups making up 30% and 25% of the population, respectively. The effort is part of a broader push for equity and fairness in vaccination distribution, with New York Governor Andrew Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio emphasizing the need to protect vulnerable communities.

site_title: US Secretary of State presses China on Xinjiang
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken pressed China on human rights in Xinjiang, Tibet, and Hong Kong during a phone call with top diplomat Yang Jiechi. Blinken stated the US will stand up for democratic values, while Yang urged the US to "correct" its mistakes and respect China's sovereignty. The US criticized China's human rights record, including reports of sexual abuse in Xinjiang internment camps. The Biden administration has shown little willingness to engage with China, describing it as a "serious competitor" and vowing to confront human rights abuses.

site_title: Private equity investor indicates interest in investing in mm2 Asia core business
summary: A Singapore private equity investor has expressed interest in investing in a minority stake in one of mm2 Asia's core businesses, with the terms of the non-binding term sheet being deliberated by the board. The company's core business involves content production and distribution, including film, television, and online releases. The proposed investment aims to raise funds for general working capital and operations, following the company's recent announcement of a renounceable underwritten rights issue. The outcome of the discussions remains uncertain, with no guarantee of a binding investment agreement.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records on optimism for new US stimulus
summary: US stocks ended at records on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rising 0.4% and 0.6% respectively, driven by optimism over new fiscal stimulus spending and progress on coronavirus vaccines. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also reached a new high. Analysts attribute the surge to President Biden's $1.9 trillion relief package and the potential approval of Johnson & Johnson's single-shot Covid-19 vaccine. Economists expect another relief package within weeks, further supporting the market.

site_title: US mortgage giant UWM's stock slumps despite 822% profit jump
summary: US mortgage giant United Wholesale Mortgage (UWM) reported a record $1.4 billion in net income in 2020, a 822% increase. Despite this, the company's shares dropped 10% to $10.20 due to concerns over declining profitability in originating mortgages. UWM missed its originations projection and expects lower margins in the upcoming quarter. CEO Mat Ishbia remains optimistic about the company's lending growth, predicting a 15% increase.

site_title: The retail investing coup: Is this the future of investing?
summary: A retail investing coup has taken place, where amateur investors have successfully beaten professional hedge funds by banding together to buy and sell stocks, particularly meme stocks. The phenomenon, fueled by free trading apps and online communities like Reddit's WallStreetBets, has resulted in significant losses for hedge funds and driven up prices of stocks like GameStop and Tesla. However, the trend also highlights risks, such as trading mentality and lack of underlying fundamentals, and underscores the importance of education and improved financial literacy for retail investors to achieve good outcomes.

site_title: US dollar drops after jobs report chills rally
summary: The US dollar dropped 0.5% to 91.028 after the US jobs report suggested a stronger American recovery from the coronavirus pandemic, prompting traders to adjust long-dollar and short-euro positions. The euro rose 0.7% to US$1.2042, its biggest daily gain in over two months, as traders reassessed the economic outlook. The US dollar index still holds a weekly gain of 0.6%.

site_title: China's latest weapon against Taiwan: the sand dredger
summary: China is using sand dredging ships to encroach on waters controlled by Taiwan, a new type of warfare. Taiwanese coast guard commander Lin Chie-ming patrols the waters off the Matsu Islands, monitoring Chinese ships. The move is seen as a threat to Taiwan's sovereignty, with China's actions being described as a "new type of warfare" against the island.

images.alt_text: Taiwanese coast guard commander Lin Chie-ming is on the frontline of a new type of warfare that China is waging against Taiwan. China's weapon? Sand.

site_title: Arrest in Thailand of second drug kingpin tightens dragnet on huge syndicate
summary: Thai authorities have arrested Lee Chung Chak, a 65-year-old former prison mate of Tse Chi Lop, suspected leader of the Sam Gor drug syndicate, which dominates the US$70 billion annual Asia-Pacific drug trade. The arrest, made on October 1, followed an extradition request by the Australian authorities and is part of a decade-long investigation by the Australian Federal Police. The move tightens the dragnet on the syndicate, with Tse already in prison in the Netherlands, awaiting extradition to Australia. The arrests are a rare success in the Asia-Pacific region for law enforcement agencies in bringing senior drug traffickers to justice.

site_title: Chinese rival to Starbucks coffee chain files for Chapter 15 bankruptcy in NY
summary: Luckin Coffee, a Chinese rival to Starbucks, filed for Chapter 15 bankruptcy in New York, less than a year after admitting to faking over a quarter of its business. The move protects the company from US lawsuits while reorganizing in China. Despite this, its coffee shops will remain open, and the bankruptcy won't impact day-to-day operations. Luckin faces scrutiny over its alleged malfeasance, including misstating revenue and expenses to investors, and the US Congress may consider legislation to kick Chinese businesses out of American markets.

site_title: Siam Validus is first foreign fintech firm to get Thai debenture crowdfunding licence
summary: Siam Validus, a joint venture between Validus and SCG Distribution, has become the first foreign fintech firm to receive a debenture crowdfunding licence from the Securities and Exchange Commission of Thailand (SEC). This licence allows Siam Validus to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) via debt crowdfunding, providing a form of peer-to-peer lending. The licence paves the way for Siam Validus to help drive the future of SME financing in Thailand, leveraging technology and data to meet the financing needs of underserved SMEs.

site_title: Europe: Shares flat after US jobs data; pound weighs on FTSE 100
summary: European stocks ended flat on Friday, despite a 3.5% weekly rise, as disappointing US jobs data highlighted the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. Germany's industrial orders declined, and London's FTSE 100 slid 0.2% due to a higher pound. Sanofi SA and Vinci shares rose, while Beazley logged its best day in eight weeks.

images.alt_text: European stocks were little changed at the end of an upbeat week on Friday, with disappointing US data highlighting the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic, while in Germany industrial orders declined.

site_title: White House unites around simple message: Spend now to save the economy
