site_title: South Korea to boost Seoul housing supply by 10% to calm buying frenzy
summary: South Korea's government plans to increase housing supply by 10% by 2025, with 320,000 new homes to be built in Seoul, aiming to calm soaring home prices and alleviate concerns over home shortages. The move follows a surge in housing demand, with the goal of slowing down price growth and providing more affordable options for buyers.

site_title: Standard Chartered gives up multiple floors in Hong Kong offices
summary: Standard Chartered is relinquishing eight floors in its Hong Kong office building, the Standard Chartered Bank Building in Central, due to cost-cutting efforts amid the pandemic. The lender will rent out three levels in its Kwun Tong office, and the vacant space will become available between March and April next year. This move is part of a trend among foreign companies in Hong Kong, with multinational companies accounting for 75% of the total surrender of office stock in the last quarter.

site_title: Why anti-harassment programmes are often ineffective
summary: Anti-harassment training programmes can be effective, but their success depends on content, delivery, and other factors. A study by Aware and Ipsos found that workplace sexual harassment is prevalent in Singapore, with over 60% of women experiencing some form of harassment. However, a review of over 300 companies' anti-harassment training programmes found that these initiatives often fail to deliver lasting change, with many employees continuing to experience harassment after training. The study highlights the need for more effective and sustainable solutions to address workplace harassment.

site_title: Toyota positions to take on Tesla in high-tech auto software
summary: Toyota is developing its own high-tech auto software, called Arene, which allows for over-the-air updates and platform for developers to create software. Led by former Google engineer James Kuffner, Arene is being developed by Toyota's Woven Planet Holdings to compete with Tesla's software capabilities. Toyota is willing to license its software, and Kuffner mentioned that Arene could potentially run on Tesla hardware. The move is part of Toyota's efforts to take on technology giants and compete in the increasingly blurred lines between technology and automobiles.

site_title: Business travel faces hit even post-pandemic; ESG is another factor
summary: Business travel is expected to face a significant decline post-pandemic, with market watchers attributing this to the rise of video-conferencing and climate concerns as part of ESG initiatives. Experts predict varying levels of decline, with some expecting a 20-30% reduction in global business travel and others suggesting it may never return to pre-pandemic levels. Airlines and travel companies are adapting to the new landscape, with some expecting business travel to resume in three to four years but others doubting its recovery.

site_title: Towards a city-state of infinite possibilities
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 aims to address the country's long-term success in the post-pandemic world by cultivating a transformational ecosystem. The budget will provide continued support to businesses and workers, while fostering enterprise resilience and encouraging entrepreneurship. Key initiatives include enhancing the Group Relief scheme, providing corporate income tax rebates for hiring affected workers, and supporting startups with tax deferment on equity awards. The budget also focuses on developing Singapore as a world-leading supply chain hub, enabling digital transformation, and promoting green-based industries.

site_title: 13 HDB resale flats sold for over S$1m in Jan
summary: In January, Singapore's HDB resale market started the year on a strong footing, with resale prices rising 1.7% from December 2020. A total of 13 flats sold for over S$1 million, with the highest price at S$1.21 million for a five-room unit. Resale volume increased by 30.3% from January 2020, driven by strong demand and low supply. Analysts predict prices will rise further by 2-5% this year, with newer and more expensive flats contributing to the price increase.

site_title: URA looking into property agents' commissions, say sources
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is investigating property agents' commissions in Singapore, following a spike in commissions and market speculation of new cooling measures. Industry participants revealed that URA recently inquired about the commission rates developers offer to agents, amid concerns over market trends and home prices. This move may lead to additional scrutiny, potentially requiring developers to disclose the amounts they pay agents.

site_title: DBS boosts sustainable finance target to S$50b
summary: DBS, a Singaporean bank, has raised its sustainable finance target for 2024 to S$50 billion, more than twice its previous target of S$20 billion. The move reflects increased demand for sustainable financing from companies seeking to advance their corporate sustainability agenda. DBS aims to help customers incorporate sustainable business practices into their overall strategy, supporting Singapore's ambition to be a green finance hub. The bank has already concluded over 100 sustainable financing deals worth S$17 billion since 2018.

site_title: Global air passenger traffic fell 66% in 2020: Iata
summary: Global air passenger traffic plummeted 66% in 2020 due to travel restrictions during the Covid-19 pandemic. Domestic traffic fell 49% and international traffic declined 76%. Despite a global rollout of vaccines, the emergence of new virus variants has clouded the forecast for a recovery this year. Iata expects a 50% increase in traffic from last year's levels, but this would still be only half of 2019 levels.

site_title: Hong Kong banking regulator says business as usual, no fund outflows
summary: Hong Kong's banking regulator, Arthur Yuen, stated that the city's banking system is operating normally despite the imposition of a national security law, and he has not received customer complaints about the uncertainty. Fund outflows are not expected, with Yuen describing the situation as "pretty much business as usual."

site_title: Muhyiddin seeks balance as economy reels from virus curbs
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin aims to strike a balance between controlling the surge in Covid-19 cases and minimizing economic disruption. The government will implement tighter Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) while allowing essential businesses to operate, with stricter penalties for repeat offenders. Non-essential businesses, such as car washes and hair salons, will reopen starting Friday. The government also plans to roll out a nationwide vaccine program, targeting 80% of the population, and compensate owners of premises used for Covid-19 screening centers.

site_title: It's a bull run
summary: For Chinese New Year, decorative items such as the Gangzai Fishkoi Square Trinket Tray (S$56), 101 Copenhagen The Bull lamp (S$1,120), Kartell Trullo Containers (S$200 each), Fritz Hansen Ikeru Vases (S$226), Glenfiddich Chinese New Year 2021 Special Edition Gift Pack (S$105), and Gold Series Year of Ox Table Garden (S$89.90) can add auspicious touches to homes. Whisky boxes and unique home decor items, such as a book lamp that transforms into a light source, also celebrate the Lunar New Year.

site_title: Myanmar junta blocks Facebook, clamps down on opposition
summary: Myanmar's junta blocked Facebook on February 4, 2021, citing the social network as a channel for spreading instability. This move comes as the military, led by General Min Aung Hlaing, consolidated power after the overthrow of Aung San Suu Kyi and the detention of her allies. Sporadic protests took place in Yangon, marking a continued challenge to the junta's authority.

site_title: Covax sets first tranche of over 330m vaccine doses for poor countries
summary: The Covax vaccine-sharing facility has allocated over 330 million doses of Covid-19 vaccines for poorer countries, with an average of 3.3% of total populations in 145 participating countries. The allocation includes 240 million doses of the AstraZeneca-Oxford vaccine and 96 million doses from the same manufacturer. The first doses are expected to be delivered by the end of February or early March, with South Africa, Cap Verde, and Rwanda among the first countries to receive the Pfizer shot. The Covax plan aims to deliver 2.3 billion doses by year-end, including 1.8 billion to lower-income countries at no cost.

site_title: Dollar rises on US outlook; euro dips under US$1.20
summary: The US dollar rose to two-month highs, reaching 91.485 against a basket of currencies, while the euro fell below US$1.20 for the first time since December. This follows improved US economic data, including an increase in employment and services industry activity, and renewed hopes for US fiscal stimulus. The dollar's strength is also attributed to elevated dollar shorts and concerns over the slow rollout of vaccines in Europe, which could impact global recovery.

site_title: Sushi no enough at Wa-i
summary: Wa-i Sushi in Singapore offers a unique dining experience, but its focus is not on sushi. The restaurant charges S$200 per person for a set menu, which includes basic kappo dishes with luxury touches. The quality of the food is average, with highlights like wagyu A5 and sashimi, but also missteps like over-seasoning and pre-frozen ingredients. The intimate setting and friendly service make it a great option for those looking for a casual, non-Japanese dining experience. Rating: 5.5/10.

site_title: Lexus IS 300h review: Hybrid, yes. Hijinks, no
summary: The Lexus IS 300h is a desirable hybrid car that excels in handling and ride quality, thanks to its petrol-electric drivetrain and impressive chassis. However, a built-in voice assistant that constantly reminds drivers to obey traffic regulations is a frustrating feature. Despite this, the IS 300h feels solidly engineered and has a beautiful package, with a smooth and quiet ride. It's particularly impressive considering it's an eight-year-old model that has undergone a heavy facelift. The IS 300h is a strong contender in its class, offering lovely steering and grip, making it a better option than some of its rivals.

site_title: New Amazon CEO's scary meetings make sense
summary: Amazon's new CEO, Andy Jassy, has a reputation for intense "Chop" meetings where employees must prepare thorough six-page memos to discuss major initiatives. This disciplined approach to meetings is designed to pressure-test assumptions and data, reducing the risk of sloppy ideas and wasted time. By requiring employees to prepare extensively, Jassy aims to minimize unnecessary meetings and maximize productivity, potentially leading to better decision-making and business outcomes.

site_title: US factory orders beat expectations in December
summary: US factory orders rose 1.1% in December, beating expectations, with business spending on equipment showing solid strength in the manufacturing industry. Orders dropped 6.6% year-over-year, but were boosted by demand for machinery, electrical equipment, and primary metals. Spending on equipment increased robustly for a second straight quarter, contributing to the economy's 4% annualized growth rate. However, shipments of core capital goods are expected to slow as the distribution of vaccines picks up and lifts spending on services by summer.

site_title: A ringleader's videos draw regulator's scrutiny
summary: Keith Gill, a registered securities broker and former financial wellness education director, is under scrutiny for his social media posts under the name Roaring Kitty, which promoted GameStop's stock. The Massachusetts regulator is investigating whether Gill or his former employer, MassMutual, broke rules by not disclosing his outside activities promoting the stock. Gill's posts, which included a disclaimer, drew thousands of small investors and made him fabulously rich, but his former employer claims it was unaware of his activities and had previously denied his request to perform side work. The regulator is seeking information about Gill's employment status and MassMutual's processes for monitoring employees' social media use.

site_title: Yellen vows to probe market mania, in consumer-protection test
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen vows to examine recent market frenzy, aiming to protect investors and ensure financial markets function properly. She will lead a meeting of top regulators, including the Federal Reserve and Securities and Exchange Commission, to discuss potential manipulation and trading curbs. The administration's focus on consumer financial interests marks a shift from years of emphasis on deregulation, amid calls for investigation of recent events.

site_title: World's biggest wealth fund set to target national oil giants
summary: Norway's $1.3 trillion sovereign wealth fund is expanding its ethics council's scrutiny to national oil companies, following its exclusion of PetroChina last year due to gross corruption. The council will review sectors with multiple corruption cases, including oil and gas, and may publish a list of companies under observation next month. The fund has previously steered clear of tobacco, weapons, coal, and palm oil, and has returned $123 billion on its investments last year, with technology stocks being the main contributors to its gains. The review aims to minimize corruption risks in the sector.

site_title: Keeping with tradition
summary: This Chinese New Year, various brands and organizations are releasing red packets, symbolic of good luck and prosperity, while also promoting sustainability and eco-friendliness. The Museum Roundtable features a 32-piece collection, while UOB's red packets are printed on environmentally friendly paper. Other companies, such as Pine on Paper and Left-Handesign, offer seed paper packets that can be planted to grow herbs or flowers. These efforts aim to reduce waste and promote a more sustainable tradition.

site_title: Water demand to nearly double over next 30 years: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's water demand is expected to nearly double over the next 30 years, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said, citing insufficient local catchments and imported water from Malaysia. The government will invest in new technologies to secure the country's water supply, with the addition of a fifth desalination plant on Jurong Island. Despite improved technologies, producing each additional drop of water becomes increasingly expensive and challenging due to climate change, which makes weather conditions more volatile. The government urges Singaporeans to use water wisely.

site_title: Wall Street's favourite suburban housing bet is getting crowded
summary: Wall Street's interest in single-family rentals is growing, with institutional investors, homebuilders, and apartment managers investing in suburban real estate during the pandemic. Companies like Greystar and Lennar are expanding their rental home portfolios, while small landlords still dominate the market. The trend is driven by demand for larger living spaces and the need for investors to find capital during uncertain times. Experts predict that single-family rentals will become a more prominent asset class, with companies potentially owning both houses and apartments to service customers throughout their life cycle.

site_title: Coupe, Cabriolet and chop-chop versions of the Mercedes E-Class are here
summary: Mercedes has introduced the E-Class Coupe and Cabriolet in Singapore, along with the E 53 4Matic+ sedan. The new models feature lightly refreshed styling and new features such as wireless phone charging and a voice control system. The E 53 4Matic+ has a six-cylinder engine producing 425 horsepower. Meanwhile, parent Daimler AG announced plans to split into two, separating its car division from its lorry and bus division, with the goal of allowing both companies to operate more effectively.

site_title: Art for all
summary: Prominent Singapore art collectors Linda Neo and Albert Lim have turned art advocates to promote Asian talents, showcasing their extensive collection of over 500 works by top Southeast Asian artists. Their private gallery has inspired others to start their own spaces, including prominent collector Chong Huai Seng and his daughter Ning Chong, who founded The Culture Story. New Singaporeans and expats are also playing a key role in art advocacy, running non-profit organizations and conducting tours and fundraisers. These efforts aim to foster greater art appreciation and knowledge about Southeast Asian artists, and to create a broader understanding of art history from the region's local perspectives.

site_title: Centara Hotels & Resorts to reopen properties as worst of pandemic seen over
summary: Centara Hotels & Resorts, a Thai hospitality unit, plans to reopen shuttered properties as the worst of the pandemic subsides. The company expects regional travel to resume in the third quarter and some international travel in the following months. Centara will also open eight new properties in countries such as Thailand, Turkey, and the UAE. The group's hotel business is expected to return to pre-pandemic levels as early as 2023, driven by a nationwide vaccine rollout and increased travel demand, according to a recent survey.

site_title: Woman who tested positive for Covid-19 reclassified as an imported case: MOH
summary: A 35-year-old woman who tested positive for Covid-19 on Wednesday has been reclassified as an imported case due to a likely past infection, according to the Ministry of Health. She had recently traveled to India between November 30 and January 6. This brings Singapore's total number of imported cases to 59,624, with 22 reported on Thursday. The patient had completed her stay-home notice two weeks prior to testing positive.

site_title: Shell's profit slumps in 2020 as the pandemic bites
summary: Royal Dutch Shell's annual profit plummeted 71% to $4.8 billion in 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on energy demand. The company's oil and gas production and refining profits dropped sharply, but its retail network and trading business helped cushion the blow. Shell plans to raise its dividend in the first quarter of 2021, its second slight increase since the pandemic. Despite missing forecasts, analysts say the results were not as bad as feared, citing low expectations after rival BP posted a loss.

site_title: US Treasury's Yellen to meet financial regulators on Thursday to discuss volatility
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen will meet with top financial regulators on Thursday to discuss recent market volatility, particularly driven by trading in stocks such as GameStop Corp. The meeting aims to address investor concerns about tighter US trading regulations. Following a sharp sell-off in the prior session, GameStop rebounded in calmer trading on Wednesday as investors turned their focus to regulatory discussions.

site_title: US: Wall St rises as focus turns to stimulus, corporate earnings
summary: Wall Street rose on Thursday as investors focused on corporate earnings and signs of progress on a pandemic-relief package. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 159.70 points, or 0.52%, to 30,883.30, while the S&P 500 rose 15.86 points, or 0.41%, to 3,846.03. The Labor Department reported a decline in new unemployment applications, and private payrolls rebounded more than expected in January, bolstering investor confidence. The market is now awaiting the government's comprehensive monthly employment report due on Friday.

site_title: PayPal's revenue surges in strong finish to blockbuster year
summary: PayPal's revenue surged 23% to $6.12 billion in the fourth quarter, driven by a record 72.7 million active accounts added in 2020, including 16 million in the final quarter. The company's Venmo service processed $47 billion in payments, a 60% increase, and expects $900 million in revenue this year. PayPal's addition of cryptocurrency buying, holding, and selling capabilities also contributed to the growth. The company plans to expand its crypto offerings and expects adjusted profits to jump 50% in the first quarter.

site_title: BT demands tax, regime change to deliver high fibre growth
summary: BT, the UK's largest broadband and mobile operator, is calling for government support and regulatory changes to boost fibre investment. The company wants to remove taxes on fibre networks and a new deal with Ofcom to encourage investment. BT CEO Philip Jansen stated that exemption from Cumulo rates would be worth around £1 billion to the company, and the government needs to show urgency in removing barriers. BT reported a 5% drop in revenue due to Covid-19, but maintained its core earnings outlook for the year.

site_title: US pharmaceutical giant Merck to get new CEO
summary: US pharmaceutical giant Merck announced that CEO Ken Frazier will retire on June 30. Frazier, one of few African Americans to run a major US company, will remain on the board as executive chairman during the transition period. Merck reported a 28% decline in profits to $7.1 billion in 2020, with revenue rising 2.5% to $48 billion. The company is reportedly near a $10 billion deal for London-based lung therapy firm Verona.

site_title: Nissan drivers here go electric and defy... Nissan
summary: A survey by Nissan Asean found that Singapore drivers are less likely to consider electrified cars, with 30% saying they would "certainly" consider an electric vehicle in the next three years, compared to 37% across all countries surveyed. However, a tax incentive in Singapore has boosted interest in the Nissan Leaf, with sales increasing by over three-fold in January. Despite this, Nissan aims to sell one million electric or E-Power cars a year by 2022, and is adding eight pure electric vehicles to its lineup.

site_title: BOE tells banks to start preparing for negative rates if needed
summary: The Bank of England instructed banks to prepare for potential negative interest rates, stating this doesn't signal an imminent policy change. The decision comes as officials review options to aid the UK's economic recovery from its three-century slump. Implementing negative rates within six months poses operational risks, but the BOE may consider it if necessary in the future. This policy has been implemented in the European Union and Japan, but the BOE has maintained its current rate of 0.1%.

site_title: Water demand expected to almost double over the next 30 years: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's water demand is expected to nearly double over the next 30 years, with the country currently consuming 430 million gallons of water per day. Local catchments and water imported from Malaysia are insufficient to meet daily needs, prompting the use of NEWater and desalination. The country has already built four desalination plants, with a fifth set to open on Jurong Island, to supplement the water supply.

site_title: SIA reports S$142m net loss for Q3, as travel demand remains constrained
summary: Singapore Airlines reported a net loss of S$142 million in its third quarter due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with international air travel demand severely constrained. The carrier's passenger carriage decreased 97.6% year-over-year, but showed 44.8% growth compared to the previous quarter. Revenue plummeted 76.1% to S$1.07 billion, and the company reported a nine-month net loss of S$3.61 billion. Despite the challenges, SIA has added cargo capacity and expects its total passenger capacity to be around a quarter of pre-Covid levels by the end of April.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics chief retracts sexist comments, refuses to resign
summary: Tokyo Olympics chief Yoshiro Mori apologized for sexist comments about women talking too much, but refused to resign. Mori made the remarks at a Japanese Olympic Committee meeting, stating that women's speaking time should be restricted to avoid "difficulty finishing." Mori acknowledged the comments were "inappropriate" and apologized, but the International Olympic Committee considers the matter closed. The decision not to resign has sparked criticism and raised concerns about Mori's ability to lead the Games, which have already been delayed due to the pandemic.

site_title: Muhyiddin seeks balance as economy reels from virus curbs
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin has announced plans to strike a balance between controlling the spread of Covid-19 and protecting the economy. Tighter protocols, or Standard Operating Procedures, will be imposed while essential businesses continue to operate, rather than a total lockdown. The government will also allow certain services to reopen, such as car-washes and night markets, starting Friday. A nationwide vaccine rollout is set to begin by the end of the month, with the goal of vaccinating 80% of the population.

site_title: foodpanda to expand grocery delivery to Japan, South-east Asian frontier markets
summary: Foodpanda, a food-delivery player, plans to expand its grocery delivery service, pandamart, to Japan, Laos, Cambodia, and Myanmar. This move aims to capitalize on the growing demand for online groceries, with a 70% month-on-month surge in grocery orders in Malaysia's Movement Control Order. Foodpanda already has food-delivery operations in these markets and plans to grow both its food and grocery-delivery verticals simultaneously. The company aims for efficiency and sustainable growth, despite the investment-heavy nature of the cloud grocery business.

site_title: Jobless claims in US decrease for a third consecutive week
summary: US jobless claims decreased for a third consecutive week, falling to 779,000 in the week ended Jan 30, the lowest level since November. Continuing claims dropped to 4.59 million. Economists forecast a decline in layoffs related to the pandemic as cases fall and more Americans get vaccinated. The data precedes Friday's jobs report, which is expected to show a labor market addition of about 100,000 jobs in January.

images.alt_text: Applications for US state unemployment benefits fell last week to the lowest level since the end of November, a sign that job cuts are starting to slow as Covid-19 infections ebb.

site_title: Yanlord's contracted pre-sales more than double to 5.2b yuan in January
summary: Chinese property developer Yanlord Land Group reported 5.2 billion yuan in contracted pre-sales in January, more than doubling from the previous year. The pre-sales were for 159,718 square meters of contracted gross floor area, a 161.8% increase. Yanlord also disclosed 2.5 billion yuan of subscription sales as of January 31, expected to be converted into contracted pre-sales in subsequent months.

site_title: Rolls-Royce disposal plan banks 150m euros from Bergen Engines sale
summary: Rolls-Royce has sold its Bergen Engines unit to Russia-based TMH Group for 150 million euros, as part of its disposal plan to raise £2 billion. The sale follows the disposal of its civil nuclear instrumentation unit last December. The company aims to create a simpler, more focused group and is facing financial challenges due to the pandemic, which has constrained travel and airline payments. The sale of Bergen Engines, a Norwegian-based unit that employs 950 people, is expected to contribute towards Rolls-Royce's disposal target.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's water demand is expected to almost double to 860 million gallons per day over the next 30 years, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The country's fourth desalination plant has officially opened, meeting up to 7% of daily water demand. DBS has increased its sustainable finance target to S$50 billion by 2024. Meanwhile, the government launched 3,740 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats, including the country's first assisted-living housing for seniors. Singapore's equities fell 0.8% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 2,905.58.

site_title: Prudential appoints ex-Singtel CEO and head of KKR Asia-Pacific as non-executive directors
summary: Prudential appoints former Singtel CEO Chua Sock Koong and KKR Asia-Pacific head Ming Lu as non-executive directors, effective May 1. Chua brings over 30 years of experience in business leadership and operations in Asia, while Lu has experience in investing and developing businesses in the Asia-Pacific. The appointments aim to guide Prudential's transformation into a business focused on Asia and Africa. The annual fee for their appointment is £99,000 (S$179,560) each, determined by the board.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets edge higher at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose slightly at the open on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.2% to 6,523.32 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also increasing 0.2%. Traders are monitoring results from major companies and US-EU trade talks, while the US stock market edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: 22 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 22 new Covid-19 cases, all imported, bringing the total to 59,624. The cases were detected after travelers tested positive while serving stay-home notices or isolations upon arrival. The Ministry of Health confirmed 17 imported cases on Wednesday, and 19 cases were discharged, leaving 39 patients in hospital. Globally, the virus has infected over 103 million people and claimed over 2.2 million lives.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.60 points, or 0.10%, to 1,584.59. Volume reached 797.78 million lots worth RM379.18 million. Gainers outpaced losers 356 to 214.

site_title: GuocoLand's half-year net profit falls 69% to S$22.9m
summary: GuocoLand's half-year net profit fell 69% to S$22.9m due to higher tax expenses in Shanghai. Topline dropped 44% to S$319.6m, with earnings per share at 1.20 Singapore cents, down from 5.86 cents a year ago. The company attributed the decline to lower sales from its Singapore residential projects and a 75% drop in hotel revenue due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite this, GuocoLand remains in a strong position to deploy its balance sheet for strategic land acquisition opportunities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 1.91 points higher to 1,584.9 on Thursday, driven by a gain of 626 to 489 gainer-to-loser ratio. The index saw 8.043 billion lots traded worth RM4.178 billion.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS initiates coverage on Straits Trading with 'buy', sees value unlocking from ARA listing
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on Straits Trading with a "buy" recommendation and a S$3.50 target price, representing a 50% upside from its current price. Analysts believe the company's investments, particularly its 22.1% stake in ARA Asset Management, hold significant value. They expect Straits Trading's core real estate business to continue generating stable cash flows, and anticipate the company's assets under management to reach S$2.4 billion by 2022.

site_title: There are 4,000 variants of the virus that causes Covid-19, UK minister says
summary: UK Minister Nadhim Zahawi says there are approximately 4,000 variants of the Covid-19 virus worldwide, prompting vaccine manufacturers to improve their vaccines. The British, South African, and Brazilian variants are among those that appear to spread more swiftly. Zahawi believes the current vaccine will remain effective against variants, especially for severe illness and hospitalization.

site_title: Singapore equities fall on Thursday, STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.8% on Thursday, closing at 2,905.58, amid dwindling investor optimism and profit taking. Regional markets, including the Nikkei 225 and Hang Seng Index, also declined. However, some Asian markets, such as the KLCI and Jakarta Composite Index, rose 0.1% and 0.5% respectively. US markets ended the day relatively flat, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 inching up 0.1%, while the Nasdaq slipped 0.02%. Market analysts expect the decline to be temporary, citing vaccine rollouts and US fiscal stimulus package developments.

site_title: South Korea PM orders revamp of Covid-19 social distancing rules
summary: South Korean Prime Minister Chung Sye Kyun has ordered a revamp of social distancing rules amid public backlash over unfair restrictions and curfews. The five-tier system, which includes a ban on indoor restaurant dining after 9pm, will be revised to better engage the public in virus prevention efforts. Authorities warned of a possible large fourth wave of infections due to the British and South African coronavirus variants. The country has seen a surge in new cases and deaths, with 451 new cases reported on Wednesday, bringing the total to 79,762 cases and 1,448 deaths.

site_title: Construction for Jurong East integrated transport hub to begin this year
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore has awarded a S$477.4 million contract to China Communications Construction Company for the design and building of Jurong East integrated transport hub. Construction is expected to begin in the second quarter of this year, with a completion year of 2027. The hub will feature a 27-storey block connected by a sky bridge to an eight-storey block, housing offices, retail spaces, and public facilities. The facility will improve transfers between the North-South, East-West, and Jurong Region Line, with inclusive facilities such as barrier-free alighting areas and priority queue zones.

site_title: Singapore's fourth desalination plant underscores Keppel's Vision 2030
summary: Keppel's fourth desalination plant, the Keppel Marina East Desalination Plant, has officially opened in Singapore, meeting 7% of the country's daily water demand. The plant, operated by Keppel Infrastructure, produces 137,000 cubic meters of fresh drinking water per day and is the second water treatment plant developed under a Design, Build, Own and Operate arrangement. The plant's development aligns with Keppel's Vision 2030, focusing on sustainable solutions, as the company pivots towards clean energy and exits the rig business.

site_title: Opec+ pledges to pursue speedy rebalancing of oil market
summary: Opec+ pledged to swiftly rebalance the oil market, aiming to clear the surplus left behind by the pandemic. The group, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, stressed the importance of accelerating market re-balancing without delay amid uncertain global economic and oil demand prospects. Saudi Arabia will further cut its oil supplies by 1 million barrels per day, while Opec+ currently holds back 7% of global supplies. The move is seen as bullish for oil prices, which have surged to a one-year high.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Thursday due to profit-taking, particularly in the tech sector. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.06% to 28,341.95, while the Topix index declined 0.32% to 1,865.12. Despite this, individual shares were supported by sound corporate earnings reports from companies like Sony.

site_title: Ford Motor terminates electric vehicle plans with China's Zotye
summary: Ford Motor has terminated plans to launch electric vehicle joint ventures with China's Zotye Automobile due to major changes in China's electric vehicle industry and government policies since agreements were signed in 2017 and 2018. Ford will instead utilize its existing operations in China and build related business centers. This decision follows other EV makers expanding manufacturing capacity in the world's largest auto market, where the government promotes greener vehicles to reduce air pollution. The move may impact Zotye's plans to make electric vehicles.

site_title: F&N's Q1 2021 earnings up 13.7% to S$45.1m
summary: F&N's Q1 2021 net profit rose 13.7% to S$45.1 million, driven by cost-cutting measures. Revenue declined 1.3% to S$496.5 million, impacted by weak soft drink sales and publishing segment. The company's core markets, including Malaysia, saw sales declines, but strong canned milk sales in the Middle East and Africa cushioned the impact.

site_title: Terms of S$1.65 per share offer are 'fair and reasonable': Sunningdale Tech
summary: Sunningdale Tech's independent financial adviser Provenance Capital has deemed the company's takeover bid of S$1.65 per share as "fair and reasonable". The offer, initially set at S$1.55 per share, was raised after activist investor Quarz Capital Management criticized the initial price as "too low". Sunningdale's non-conflicted directors are advised to recommend shareholders vote in favor of the takeover scheme. The company's revised scheme consideration is below its net asset value, but its price-to-earnings ratio is higher than comparable listed companies.

site_title: South Korea to boost Seoul housing supply by 10% to calm buying frenzy
summary: South Korea plans to increase housing supply by 10% in Seoul by 2025, adding 830,000 new homes, including 320,000 in the city. The move aims to tackle soaring home prices, which have surged 70% since President Moon's term began in 2017. The government will relax building height and apartment reconstruction rules to incentivize high-rise conversions and speed up construction. The plan comes as sales and rental prices surge despite tighter mortgage curbs and heavier real estate taxes, threatening the government's approval ratings ahead of April elections.

site_title: Facebook executive Deborah Liu named CEO of Ancestry.com
summary: Deborah Liu, a former Facebook executive, has been named CEO of Ancestry.com, effective March 1. Liu, who spent 11 years at Facebook, led the company's Marketplace service with 800 million monthly users. She aims to make Ancestry.com more social and accessible, while connecting people with their family histories. Liu's experience and background will influence her new role, and she is seen as a positive addition to the company, which has over 3.6 million subscribers and 18 million people in its DNA network.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as healthcare, gold miners weigh
summary: Australia's shares closed 0.9% lower at 6,765.5, snapping a three-day winning streak, due to declines in healthcare and gold stocks. Origin Energy dropped 6.9% after downgrading its energy markets division outlook, while AGL Energy fell 3.6% after writing down asset values. Gold stocks slid 2.8%, their lowest in nine months, after easing overnight bullion prices. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to provide updated economic forecasts on Friday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower after three-day rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower on Thursday after a three-day rally, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.66% to 29,113.50. The decline was attributed to tech firms being hurt after the US Commerce Secretary nominee indicated she would not remove Huawei from a trade blacklist. In other markets, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the Shanghai Index falling 0.44% and the Shenzhen Index losing 1.16%.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks snap three-day rally on foreign selling, China liquidity concerns
summary: South Korean stocks dropped 1.35% on Thursday, snapping a three-day rally, due to foreign selling and concerns over China's liquidity tensions. Major heavyweights, including Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, fell 2.5% and 3.9%, respectively. Foreigners sold $572.42 million worth of shares, while Asian stocks dipped due to rising Chinese interest rates and policy tightening fears.

site_title: UG Healthcare H1 net profit jumps to S$54.9m; special cash dividend declared
summary: UG Healthcare Corporation reported a 60-fold increase in net profit for its fiscal first half ended Dec 31, 2020, driven by increased demand for gloves amid the coronavirus pandemic. Net profit rose to S$54.9 million, with revenue tripling to S$159.4 million. The company declared a special cash dividend of 0.105 cents per share. UG expects to increase its capacity for glove production to 4.6 billion pieces per annum and invest in expanding its distribution network.

site_title: Ant and China banks are reining in joint loans to consumers
summary: China's Ant Group and at least a dozen banks are scaling back their joint consumer lending platforms, following regulator signals to curb online loans. The move aims to prevent one firm from becoming too dominant and address surging consumer debt. Regulators have proposed additional capital requirements for microlenders and demanded that fintech platforms put up at least 30% of loan funding. Ant needs to inject 70 billion yuan of new capital to comply with the regulations, which may impact its valuation.

site_title: Robinhood to allow buying fractional shares of GameStop, AMC
summary: Robinhood, a brokerage app at the center of a Reddit-fueled rally, has announced it will allow investors to buy fractional shares of GameStop Corp and AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. This move reduces the minimum investment requirement, encouraging participation from smaller investors. The app had previously restricted trading due to a clearinghouse's demand for $3 billion in collateral, but has since lifted restrictions and increased trading limits for both stocks. The move comes after Robinhood raised $2.4 billion in emergency funding from investors.

site_title: HSBC considers moving top executives to Asia to strengthen push
summary: HSBC is considering relocating several senior executives from London to Hong Kong or Singapore to strengthen its presence in Asia. The bank is planning to shift billions of capital to the region, particularly China, to boost profitability. The moves aim to show investors and policymakers that HSBC is serious about its expansion plans, amid an improving relationship with Beijing. The bank has been working to deploy more resources in South-east Asia and has recently announced plans to expand into private banking in Thailand.

site_title: HDB launches 3,740 BTO flats, including country's first assisted-living housing for seniors
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 3,740 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in Singapore, including the country's first assisted-living housing project for seniors, Harmony Village @ Bukit Batok. The flats are available in seven projects across mature and non-mature towns, with prices ranging from S$52,000 to S$60,000 for a 32 square meter unit. The new housing concept comes with a mandatory service package to support seniors. The flats are expected to be completed in 2024 and 2026, with prices varying depending on the project and unit size.

site_title: Sumitomo quits US shale oil with sale of Eagle Ford stake
summary: Japanese trading house Sumitomo Corp has sold its stake in a US Eagle Ford oil project, marking its exit from the shale oil business in the US. Sumitomo bought the stake in 2018 with plans for 3,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, but decided to sell it last year without giving a reason or a sum for the deal. This sale follows the company's earlier sale of its entire stake in a Marcellus shale gas project in the US in 2020, marking the end of its US shale gas and oil assets.

site_title: StanChart gives up multiple floors in Hong Kong offices
summary: Standard Chartered is relinquishing the lease on eight floors in its Hong Kong office, spanning about 60,000 square feet, and will rent out three levels in its Kwun Tong office. The UK lender is cutting costs amid the pandemic and accelerating efforts to adapt to new work styles. This move follows similar actions by other foreign companies, including BNP Paribas and Nomura Holdings, which have handed back office space in Central. The Central district's Grade A office market has seen a vacancy rate reach its highest since 2004.

site_title: Facebook disrupted in Myanmar as UN chief warns coup must fail
summary: Facebook services were disrupted in Myanmar on Thursday, following the country's military takeover, with the UN chief Antonio Guterres warning the coup must fail. The army seized power, detaining de facto leader Aung San Suu Kyi and other civilian leaders, sparking international condemnation and fears of repressive rule. The UN urged the international community to put pressure on the Myanmar generals to reverse the coup, with UN Secretary-General Guterres saying "everything can be done" to stop the coup.

site_title: Asia: Market rally stalls but vaccine, stimulus hope lend support
summary: Asian markets slipped on Thursday, despite a three-day rally, as investors took a breather. However, upbeat data, stimulus hopes, and signs of improvement on the virus and vaccine fronts continue to provide support. US President Joe Biden pledged not to reduce the cash handout in his $1.9 trillion stimulus proposal, while top Federal Reserve officials expressed optimism about the global economy's recovery. Oil prices rose, consolidating at one-year highs, as demand hopes grew with the progress of immunization programs.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics chief says he may need to resign as furore grows over sexist comments
summary: Tokyo Olympics chief Yoshiro Mori, 83, faces calls for resignation after making sexist comments about women's speaking time during a meeting. Mori stated that increasing female board members would require restricting their speaking time to avoid "annoying" interruptions. He hinted at stepping down if pressure continues, sparking widespread outrage over his remarks. Mori, a former Japanese prime minister, is the president of the Tokyo Olympic organising committee. His comments have been widely condemned, and the Japanese Olympic Committee has yet to comment on the matter.

site_title: Australia's exporters weather China squall, find new harbours
summary: Australia's trade surplus reached a six-month high in December, driven by a 21% increase in iron ore exports to China, despite diplomatic tensions between the two countries. China's reliance on Australian iron ore due to its steel-intensive infrastructure and construction needs ensured a steady import flow, despite high prices. This helped iron ore exports to China jump to a six-month high of A$13.3 billion, supporting Australia's trade surplus.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as miners, health stocks weigh
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% to 6,799.6, snapping a three-day winning streak, due to miners and healthcare stocks easing. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to provide updated economic forecasts on Friday, with investors awaiting more risk-supportive economic outlook. Gold stocks hit their lowest since May, while heavyweight miners shrank 0.6% and energy stocks dropped 0.9% amid weakening spot gold prices and a jump in US Treasury yields.

site_title: Global vaccine trust rising, but France, Japan, others sceptical
summary: Global vaccine trust has increased, with over half of those surveyed willing to get vaccinated against Covid-19 if offered next week. However, confidence varies widely across countries, with France showing high scepticism and some Asian nations experiencing declining trust. In contrast, European nations have seen rising confidence. The survey found a significant increase in vaccine confidence compared to November, when only 40% of respondents would get vaccinated.

site_title: Canada designates Proud Boys a banned terrorist group
summary: Canada has designated the far-right Proud Boys as a banned terrorist organization, citing their role in the US Capitol insurrection and engagement in misogynistic, Islamophobic, and anti-Semitic ideologies. The Proud Boys, with thousands of members in North America, were added to Canada's list of banned terrorist groups, along with three other "ideologically motivated violent extremist groups." The designation allows authorities to seize assets and prosecute members for extremist activities. Public Safety Minister Bill Blair described the Proud Boys as a "serious and growing threat" to Canadian society.

site_title: Taiwan opens 'milestone' trade office in Guyana
summary: Taiwan has opened a trade office in Guyana, a milestone move seen as a counter to China's efforts to isolate the island. The US has praised the development, calling it a step towards advancing security, democratic values, and prosperity in the region. Taiwan has signed an agreement with Guyana to set up the office, which is seen as a significant win for Taipei and its biggest unofficial ally, the US. This move comes after Taiwan opened a reciprocal office with Somaliland last year, sparking an angry rebuke from China.

site_title: DBS boosts sustainable finance target to S$50b by 2024
summary: DBS has raised its sustainable finance target to S$50 billion by 2024, more than double its previous target of S$20 billion. The bank's group head of institutional banking, Tan Su Shan, attributes the increase to growing customer interest in adopting sustainability in their strategies. Many companies have doubled down on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) commitments since the Covid-19 pandemic, with a marked increase in corporate interest in sustainable financing. The move reinforces DBS's efforts in "responsible banking" and supports its role as a green finance hub in Singapore.

site_title: IMF to roll out new method to judge debt sustainability
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is launching a new method to assess debt sustainability, aiming to more accurately predict financial crises and improve transparency. The updated methodology, expected to be operational by 2022, will combine multiple indicators into a statistically sound "mechanical sustainability assessment." The new framework will better assess a country's ability to service its debts, including its domestic financing markets, natural resources, and state-owned enterprises. The IMF developed the new framework after extensive consultations with external stakeholders, market participants, and academics.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.73% on Thursday, following a three-day advance, amid concerns over US stimulus talks and global vaccine rollout progress. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 29,093.54, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The decline was attributed to waning investor enthusiasm, with traders focusing on the US stimulus and global economic developments.

site_title: Top California court rejects bid to stop gig worker law
summary: California's top court rejected a bid to nullify a voter-endorsed law treating gig workers like Uber as contractors. The lawsuit, filed by ride-share and meal delivery drivers, aimed to derail Proposition 22, which was passed by voters in January. Justices did not comment on the merits of the case, instead telling those behind the suit to file it in a lower court. The decision upholds the law, which could impact the treatment and working conditions of gig workers in California.

site_title: Parler terminates CEO John Matze
summary: Parler, a social media platform popular with US conservatives, has terminated CEO John Matze following the January 6 attack on the US Capitol. The move was made by the Parler board, led by Rebekah Mercer, on January 29, 2021. The company remains largely offline due to its cloud-hosting division being dropped by Amazon and its app stores being removed by Apple and Google. Parler has styled itself as a "free speech-driven" space, attracting conservatives who disagree with content rules on other social media sites.

site_title: Many UK companies report trade hassles from Brexit shift: HSBC
summary: Around 40% of UK companies that import and export reported trade hassles from the Brexit shift, citing increased bureaucracy and time spent on paperwork. The survey of 1,000 businesses showed 40% of importers and 42% of exporters were affected. Companies reported difficulties in supply chains, exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic, with nearly half expecting to grow and just under a quarter shrinking in the next 12 months. The government is urged to deliver trade deals to help firms reach their growth targets.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens slightly lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index opened 0.28% lower at 28,567.18, following Wall Street's little-changed close. However, individual shares benefited from sound corporate earnings reports. The broader Topix index rose 0.15%. The slight decline was attributed to global market uncertainty, including US-EU trade talks and tariff concerns.

site_title: Alphabet's profit surges on strong demand for search, video advertising
summary: Alphabet's parent company, Google, reported a surge in quarterly revenue and profit, driven by strong demand for search and video advertising. Sales rose 23% to a record $56.9 billion, and net profit increased 43% to $15.2 billion. Revenue from search advertising rose 17% and YouTube ads increased 46%. The company's cloud computing business also saw a 47% gain, marking the first time it disclosed profitability. Shares rose nearly 7% in after-hours trading, surpassing analysts' expectations.

site_title: Singapore shares eke out slight gains at Thursday's open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.1% at Thursday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 2,931.13 points. The gains followed a flat overnight session on Wall Street, with tech and banking sectors performing well. Gainers outnumbered losers 66 to 31, with 36.2 million securities worth S$24.5 million changing hands.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Evans says the more fiscal support, the better
summary: Chicago Federal Reserve Bank President Charles Evans expressed support for the Biden administration's $1.9 trillion economic stimulus package, stating that more fiscal support is better than a smaller package. Evans said a larger package, despite the risk of being too big, is preferable to a smaller one that could lead to a slower recovery. This stance suggests the Federal Reserve is open to a more aggressive economic stimulus approach to aid the US recovery.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, FLCT, CDL, Wing Tai, BRC Asia, Neo Group
summary: Singapore stocks rose on Thursday as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views. Key developments include: SingPost reported a 1% decline in revenue and 38% drop in profit due to COVID-19 disruptions; Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust's portfolio remains stable, but expected to be impacted in the near term; City Developments Limited signed the World Green Building Council's Net Zero Carbon Buildings Commitment; Wing Tai Holdings' first-half net profit grew 73.1% on-year; BRC Asia reported a 24% decline in net profit due to lower revenue and provisions; and Neo Group acquired a 51% stake in Royale International Food Industries for S$1 million.

site_title: Draghi calls for 'unity' as he tries to form Italian government
summary: Former European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi urged Italy's splintered parties to unite behind him as he tries to form a new government and lift the country out of the coronavirus pandemic's devastation. Draghi received a mandate from President Sergio Mattarella to open talks on a national unity government amid the collapse of Giuseppe Conte's ruling coalition. With Italy facing huge challenges, including a recession and over 89,000 coronavirus deaths, Draghi aims to build a majority in parliament and submit a credible spending plan to the EU by April.

site_title: UK government says vaccine roll-out passes 10 million
summary: The UK government announced that over 10 million people have received a first dose of a Covid-19 vaccine, exceeding the 10 million target set by Prime Minister Boris Johnson. The health ministry reported 10,021,471 vaccinations and 498,962 second doses. The milestone comes as the UK continues to grapple with the pandemic, recording 1,322 deaths and 19,202 positive cases. Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty stated that the third wave of the pandemic appears to have peaked, and the vaccine roll-out is being credited with slowing the spread of the virus.

site_title: Daimler to spin off trucks and rename itself Mercedes-Benz
summary: Daimler, the German automobile giant, plans to spin off its truck division and rename itself Mercedes-Benz, focusing on the luxury car business. The company will separate its truck business and list it on the Frankfurt stock exchange, with shares offered to existing shareholders. The spin-off is expected to be completed by the end of 2021 and is valued at around 29 billion euros. The move is seen as a historic moment for Daimler, with investors welcoming the news and Daimler shares rising almost 9% following the announcement.

site_title: Amazon's Bezos, latest tycoon to pursue his 'passion'
summary: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, the world's richest man, is stepping down as CEO to devote more time to his "passions" such as his private space firm Blue Origin and the Bezos Earth Fund. Bezos, 57, will remain executive chairman of Amazon and has a net worth of $197 billion. He follows in the footsteps of other corporate titans like Bill Gates and Ted Turner, who have temporarily stepped away from their day jobs to pursue other activities. Bezos' move comes as he continues to push for space exploration and environmental causes.

site_title: Commerzbank posts 2.9b euro loss on virus, restructuring woes
summary: Commerzbank, Germany's second-largest lender, reported a net loss of 2.9 billion euros for 2020, its first full-year loss since the 2009 financial crisis. The bank attributed the loss to the coronavirus pandemic and restructuring charges, including 10,000 job cuts and 340 branch closures by 2024. The cuts will affect one in three jobs in Germany, as the bank pivots to online banking and cashless payment options to lower costs by 1.4 billion euros.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence improves further in Feb: ANZ survey
summary: New Zealand business confidence improved further in February, according to a preliminary ANZ Bank survey. The headline measure showed a net 11.8% of respondents expecting the economy to improve over the year ahead, up from 9.4% in December. Business growth intentions also increased, with 22.3% of respondents expecting their own businesses to grow in the next 12 months. This marks a further improvement in business sentiment, indicating a positive outlook for the country's economy.

site_title: From collectors to art advocates
summary: Prominent art collectors Linda Neo and Albert Lim are opening their private art collections for public tours to foster greater art appreciation and knowledge about Singapore and South-east Asian artists. The initiative aims to support artists affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The collections will feature artists such as Genevieve Chua, Ian Tee, and Mella Jaarsma, among others.

site_title: Unprecedented 66% drop in air passengers last year: Iata
summary: Global air passenger traffic plummeted by 66% in 2020 due to travel restrictions during the Covid-19 pandemic, according to the International Air Transport Association (IATA). Domestic passenger traffic fell by 49%, while foreign passenger traffic dropped by 76%. The industry faces a challenging outlook, with new virus variants threatening a recovery. IATA expects global traffic to increase by 50% from last year's levels, but this would still be just half of the 2019 result.

site_title: Why did brokers restrict trading in GameStop?
summary: US brokerages restricted trading in GameStop, AMC, and Koss due to the unexpected price surge, citing increased clearinghouse-mandated deposit requirements. These deposits rose tenfold for Robinhood, a major US-based online brokerage, to $33.5 billion, prompting the startup to draw down on credit lines and raise additional funds. The restrictions may also be linked to the risk of real losses for brokerages, particularly for clients engaging in margin trading, which can lead to significant debt if stock prices plummet.

site_title: Going for gold: Eiffel Tower gets Olympic facelift
summary: The Eiffel Tower is undergoing its most extensive 130-year revamp to coincide with the 2024 Paris Olympics. The iconic landmark will receive a new golden yellow-brown paint job, replacing its signature "Eiffel Tower brown," as desired by Gustave Eiffel. The 50 million-euro renovation, which began in 2019, will strip away 19 previous layers of paint, including hazardous lead, and will be completed by 2022. The tower will play a prominent role in the Olympics, hosting triathlon and open water swimming events, and will be a backdrop for festivities along the Seine River.

site_title: American Airlines warns of as many as 13,000 layoffs
summary: American Airlines is set to notify 13,000 workers that they may be laid off due to the prolonged industry downturn caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The airline expects to fly at least 45% less in the first quarter, citing delayed expectations for a travel recovery due to the slow rollout of coronavirus vaccines. This warning comes as the airline industry continues to struggle with the pandemic's impact, with American's executives citing reduced travel demand as the reason for the potential layoffs.

site_title: SingPost's Q3 operating profit down 38% y-o-y to S$26m
summary: SingPost reported a 38% year-over-year decline in Q3 operating profit to S$26m, despite a 41% increase from Q2 FY2021. Revenue fell 1% y-o-y to S$351m, but rose 1% q-o-q. E-commerce packages increased, with 10.3m handled in Q3. International post volumes declined 25% y-o-y, while domestic snail mail fell 21%. Despite challenges, SingPost's property arm is expected to perform better, with its retail mall and office spaces at full occupancy.

images.alt_text: SingPost on Thursday announced an operating profit of S$26 million for the third quarter ended Dec 31.

site_title: Consumers boosted electronics spending in pandemic year: survey
summary: Consumers worldwide increased electronics spending in the pandemic year, boosting revenues by 7% to $358.5 billion. Sales of computers, tablets, and games consoles rose, driven by work, learning, and play needs. Home computer and tablet sales increased 11% to 396 million units, with revenues rising 17% to $199 billion.

site_title: Emirates mulls switching a third of Boeing 777X orders to 787
summary: Emirates, the largest customer of Boeing's 777X, is considering switching between 30 and 40 of its 115 orders for the 777X to the 787 Dreamliner. This move would further reduce Boeing's 777X backlog, now at 191 jets, and could impact the plane's profitability. The delay in the 777X's debut, now slated for late 2023, gives customers the right to walk away from sales contracts, and Emirates may have more leverage to do so due to standard contract provisions.

site_title: The case for preserving Dover Forest is not so clear cut
summary: The fate of Dover Forest, a 33ha site in Singapore's Ulu Pandan area, is being debated amidst concerns over development and conservation. The site is home to at least 158 animal species and 120 plant species, and a 2017 study suggests it could be used for new HDB flats. However, environmentalists and locals are pushing for preservation, prompting several MPs to raise the issue in Parliament. The government has extended public feedback until March 1, and will evaluate the concerns seriously. The debate highlights the tension between development and conservation in Singapore.

site_title: US: Strong data, earnings lift Dow, S&P 500
summary: US stocks finished little changed on Wednesday, rebounding from last week's volatility, as better-than-expected economic data and strong earnings from Amazon and Alphabet lifted the Dow Jones Industrial Average 0.1% to 30,723.60. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The market appears to have stabilized following a social media-driven surge in shares of struggling companies.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks finished little changed on Wednesday following better-than-expected US economic data and strong earnings from Amazon and Google parent Alphabet.

site_title: WEF meeting in Singapore moved to August amid pandemic
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) annual meeting in Singapore has been rescheduled from May 25-28 to August 17-20 due to global travel restrictions and the ongoing pandemic. The event will feature a virtual component, with Marina Bay Sands identified as a potential venue. The move aims to minimize the risk of the virus spreading, allowing for a more secure and inclusive gathering.

site_title: US crude hits one-year highs after US stock drawdown
summary: US crude oil prices rose 1.7% on Wednesday, reaching a one-year high of $55.69 a barrel, amid a 93-cent increase in US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures. Stockpiles fell to 475.7 million barrels, the lowest since March, while refinery utilization rates rose. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) maintained ongoing supply cuts, and the market expects a deficit throughout 2021. The Biden administration's proposed $1.9 trillion coronavirus aid plan also boosted the market.

site_title: Surbana Jurong's public sustainability-linked bond more than 6 times oversubscribed
summary: Surbana Jurong's S$250 million sustainability-linked bond, due 2031, was more than six times oversubscribed, with over S$1.7 billion in orders. The bond, priced at 2.48% coupon rate, will be used to fund growth, refinance existing credit lines, and provide working capital. The proceeds will also support the group's efforts to achieve the UN Sustainable Development Goals. This is the first Singapore dollar-denominated sustainability-linked bond from a Southeast Asia-based company, featuring a premium step-up structure if sustainability goals are not met.

site_title: Singapore keeps key links going with very selective quarantine-free entry
summary: Singapore allows key global travellers to enter the country with selective quarantine-free entry through 'special prior approval'. These business and essential visitors may also be exempt from stay-home notice (SHN) requirements, subject to case-by-case assessments. However, the number of short-term entries remains low, and exemptions are not guaranteed.

images.alt_text: Attendees at last November's TravelRevive trade show, co-organised by the STB. The hybrid event had some 1,000 in-person attendees, including 65 from 14 countries whose entry the STB facilitated.

site_title: Winter disease surge seen hampering China's hog production recovery
summary: China's hog production recovery, which saw a 31% increase in pig herd in 2020, is being hindered by a surge in hog disease outbreaks, including African swine fever and porcine epidemic diarrhoea. The disease surge is expected to slow the industry's recovery, with prices for live hogs in northeastern China reaching a three-year high in December. The government's goal of restoring hog supply and lowering meat prices is being challenged, with rising demand and imports contributing to inflation.

site_title: China's crude stockpiles at 1-year low amid global drawdown
summary: China's crude stockpiles fell to 990 million barrels, the lowest in almost a year, amid a global drawdown in inventories driven by a tighter supply-demand balance and higher costs to hoard oil. This decline is following a global trend, with Opec+ signaling a plan to drain an oil surplus by mid-year. Shrinking Chinese stockpiles are attributed to higher oil prices and limited storage capacity, making it unattractive to hoard cargoes. Global demand is expected to reach pre-virus levels by August, according to Goldman Sachs.

site_title: Silver futures up as Reddit forum users train fire on short selling
summary: Silver futures rose 3.3% on Wednesday following a turbulent market, calming after a buying frenzy sent prices to an eight-year high. The surge was fueled by Reddit forum users training fire on short sellers, but sentiment has since turned with users speculating a pump-and-dump scheme or hedge fund involvement. Despite this, buying interest remains, with the US Mint rationing sales of silver coins due to "exceptional market demand". Silver prices currently stand at $26.91 an ounce, up 1.9% from the previous day.

site_title: Additional 7-day testing regime for newly arrived foreign workers: MOM
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower has introduced an additional 7-day testing regime for newly arrived foreign workers from higher-risk countries or regions, starting from Feb 5. This applies to work permit and S Pass workers in construction, marine, and process sectors, as well as foreign domestic workers and confinement nannies. The test aims to identify workers who have recovered from Covid-19 and can be released from the 14-day stay-home notice (SHN) early. The measure aims to enhance the country's Covid-19 safety measures.

site_title: Art is essential, but not everywhere
summary: Museums in the US are taking diverging approaches to reopening during the pandemic, with some cities and states allowing museums to operate at reduced capacities while others have forced them to close. New York City's museums, which reopened in August, are now averaging over 5,400 new cases per day, but remain open due to the state's decision to prioritize them. In contrast, Chicago's museums were closed for two months before reopening, and Phoenix's museums remain open despite a surge in cases. The inconsistent approaches reflect the complexity of navigating the pandemic and shifting government responses, with economic considerations also playing a role in the decision-making process.

site_title: Europe: Healthcare drags FTSE 100 down; Vodafone jumps
summary: The FTSE 100 index slipped 0.1% on Wednesday, despite a 0.3% gain from the mid-cap index, as healthcare stocks fell 6.3% led by GlaxoSmithKline's warning of a larger-than-expected earnings decline due to the ongoing pandemic. Vodafone jumped 5.9% after beating earnings estimates, while Glencore rose 0.9% after reaffirming production targets. Despite the decline, the FTSE 100 has rebounded 1.3% for the year due to improving corporate earnings, increasing commodity prices, and vaccination progress.

site_title: Rising Spanish designer takes haute couture to village home
summary: Spanish designer Nicolas Montenegro, trained in Milan, has returned to his village of Lantejuela to launch his own haute couture brand after the pandemic. He previously worked for top fashion houses, including Dolce & Gabbana, and has dressed celebrities like Beyonce and Kylie Minogue. Montenegro's sober, elegant gowns have sold well, and he plans to promote his upcoming autumn/winter collection online, which will be inspired by his father's exotic tapestries. The venture has boosted the local economy, which has been hit hard by the pandemic.

site_title: Myanmar police file charges against Aung San Suu Kyi
summary: Myanmar police have charged ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi with illegally importing six walkie-talkies, leading to her detention until February 15 for investigations. The move follows a military coup on Monday, which also detained other civilian politicians and cut short Myanmar's transition to democracy. Suu Kyi, 75, faces accusations of violating protocols to stop the spread of coronavirus during campaigning for an election last November, and the charges have been widely condemned by Western countries and human rights groups.

site_title: Alibaba resumes plan for US$5b bond after revenue gain
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd plans to issue up to $5 billion in dollar bonds, resuming a previously quiet plan after reporting a 37% increase in quarterly revenue that beat analysts' expectations. The company aims to use the proceeds for eligible projects and to boost working capital, repaying offshore debt. The bonds, including sustainability bonds due 2041, have received strong investor interest, with spreads tightening to 97.5 basis points over Treasuries, and have been assigned A1 and A+ ratings by Moody's and Fitch, respectively.

site_title: Truckmaker Volvo rides market rebound but supply chain feeling strain
summary: Volvo reported a 19% increase in core earnings to 10.93 billion crowns in Q4, beating market expectations. The company raised its forecasts for main markets and announced a hefty shareholder payout. Despite the recovery, Volvo cautioned that supply chains are under pressure due to the global chip shortage, causing production disturbances and higher costs. The company's order intake of trucks rose 61% from the year-ago quarter, and it raised its outlook for heavy-duty truck registrations in Europe and North America this year. Volvo's shares have risen 9% since the start of the year.

site_title: Microsoft offers to step in if rival Google quits Australia
summary: Microsoft president Brad Smith has offered to step in if Google quits Australia over proposed legislation requiring the tech giant to compensate media outlets for using their content. Microsoft fully supports the proposed legislation, which aims to address the bargaining power imbalance between digital platforms and news businesses. If Google follows through on its threat, Microsoft is willing to improve its Bing search engine and welcome Australian advertisers to the platform without transfer costs. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella and Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison have discussed the proposal, with the government seeing the offer as a boost in its confrontation with Google and Facebook.

site_title: India's tax hike on palm oil raises demand, price concerns
summary: India's finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman recently announced a 15% cut in basic import duties on crude edible oils, including palm oil, but introduced additional taxes, increasing the effective tax by 5-10%. This move has raised concerns over demand and prices for palm oil, but analysts remain optimistic about the prospects for Southeast Asia's CPO producers, citing supply constraints and a general economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: The longer-term outlook for the CPO market remains intact, given supply constraints and post-Covid recovery, say market watchers.

site_title: The Myanmar coup may have been a pre-emptive strike by the military
summary: Myanmar's military, known as the Tatmadaw, staged a coup on February 1, 2021, taking over the government after allegations of election fraud in November's general elections. The military, led by Senior General Min Aung Hlaing, declared a state of emergency for a year and arrested key officials, including Aung San Suu Kyi, the country's de facto leader. The coup appears to be a pre-emptive strike to maintain the military's power and influence, as Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy had won a landslide victory and threatened the military's prerogatives. The coup may undermine morale and cohesion among the troops and face widespread instability.

site_title: Kia shares jump on news of Apple's 4t-won investment
summary: Kia Motors Corp shares jumped 14.5% after reports that Apple Inc plans to invest 4 trillion won (S$4.8 billion) in the South Korean carmaker as part of a collaboration on electric vehicles. The companies aim to set up production and build Apple cars at Kia's US facility, with a target to produce 100,000 autos annually, potentially introducing Apple cars in 2024.

site_title: Euro hits two-month low against greenback
summary: The euro has dropped to a two-month low against the US dollar, trading at around US$1.20, due to a widening disparity in pandemic recoveries between the US and Europe. Investors are concerned about extended European lockdowns and a decline in eurozone growth this quarter. This comes as the US moves to fast-track more stimulus spending, contrasting with European economic uncertainty.

site_title: Yoma Strategic slides 25.5% to close at 20.5 cents
summary: Yoma Strategic shares plummeted 25.5% to close at 20.5 Singapore cents on Wednesday, following a two-day trading halt due to the ongoing Myanmar crisis. The company's tourism business arm, Memories Group, also issued business updates, warning of a potential change in business sentiment and citing disruptions to their operations. Despite the challenges, both companies resumed trading on Wednesday, with Memories shares ending the day unchanged at 4.1 Singapore cents.

site_title: CDL signs WorldGBC Commitment, eyes 2030 net zero carbon target
summary: CDL, a Singapore-based developer, has signed the World Green Building Council's (WorldGBC) Net Zero Carbon Buildings Commitment, aiming to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2030. To achieve this, CDL plans to retrofit buildings, utilize smart technologies, and transition to 100% renewable energy. The company also advocates for all buildings to be net zero carbon in operation by 2050. This move makes CDL the first real estate developer in Singapore to commit to the goal.

site_title: Novelist Kristin Hannah reinvented herself; says America can do the same
summary: Novelist Kristin Hannah has spoken about reinventing herself, from initially wanting to pursue a career in law to becoming a successful author. Hannah's career change was inspired by her mother's advice to write after she was diagnosed with breast cancer. She wrote her first nine pages of a romance novel at 24, which led to her first published work. Hannah's latest novel, The Four Winds, explores themes of environmental disaster, economic collapse, and fresh starts, marking a departure from her previous works.

site_title: Former ECB president accepts mandate to form Italy government
summary: Former European Central Bank (ECB) president Mario Draghi has accepted a mandate to form Italy's government, aiming to tackle the country's twin emergencies of the coronavirus pandemic and a devastating recession. Draghi, 73, will sound out leaders of political parties to forge a broad parliamentary majority, with the Democratic Party and centrist groups already backing him. Despite the Five Star Movement's refusal to support him, some lawmakers may agree to back Draghi, who will focus on the pandemic, vaccination campaign, and managing the EU's recovery package.

site_title: US: Stocks boosted by earnings, hiring data
summary: US stocks rose in early trading on Wednesday, boosted by strong earnings from Amazon and Google, as well as better-than-expected US hiring data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.1%, the S&P 500 rose 0.2%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.5%. Amazon's founder Jeff Bezos stepped down as CEO, and the US added 174,000 jobs in January, exceeding analyst expectations. The positive momentum reverses losses from last week, when GameStop and AMC Entertainment surged.

site_title: Spike in property agent commissions may draw greater scrutiny given its wider impact
summary: Singapore's physical property market has remained resilient, but its listed developers' share prices have declined 10-30% in the past year. In contrast, property agent shares have risen 60% or more. This divergence is due to the increasing commissions paid to agents by developers, which have risen despite shrinking profit margins for developers. The financial performance of the property sector highlights the impact of commissions on developers' bottom lines.
