Harley is committed to electric motorcycle technology, following the launch of its first electric motorbike in 2019. The plan aims to attract younger riders and expand sales beyond baby boomers.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's 20% fixed-income gain beats Wall Street
summary: Deutsche Bank's fixed-income trading unit generated approximately 1.4 billion euros in the final quarter of last year, a 20% gain, surpassing Wall Street rivals. The unit's revenue growth caps a bumper year, driven by market volatility caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. CEO Christian Sewing has staked his medium-term profitability target on the unit's growth, despite the bank still expecting a small annual loss. The lender is scheduled to report fourth-quarter earnings, with analysts and shareholders keen to know how long the recent gains will continue.

site_title: CFM Holdings warns of higher net loss for H1 2021
summary: CFM Holdings, a metal-stamping firm, expects a higher net loss after tax for the first half of 2021 due to a decline in gross profit margin. The decline is attributed to increased cost of sales, direct labor costs, and subcontract services. Despite higher revenue and lower operating expenses, the net loss is expected to widen. Further details on the company's performance will be disclosed on or before February 10. The stock price closed at 3.8 Singapore cents on Tuesday, down 0.4 Singapore cent.

site_title: Singapore to move ahead with Sora transition by year-end
summary: Singapore plans to transition to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) as the new interest rate benchmark by the end of 2021, despite the potential postponement of the London Inter-bank Offered Rate (Libor) discontinuation to mid-2023. The MAS will allow about 70% of existing SOR cash products to mature before the new deadline, giving more time to transition legacy contracts to Sora. The move aims to ensure a smooth transition towards Sora, with several notable initiatives to be expanded to facilitate price discovery and support further growth of Sora markets.

images.alt_text: Singapore will press ahead with its industry transition to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) as the new interest rate benchmark by the end of this year, even as the discontinuation of a key global benchmark - the scandal-tainted London Inter-bank Offered Rate (Libor) - could be pushed to mid-2023.

site_title: Front-line Covid-19 fighters named Singaporean of the Year 2020
summary: The Straits Times has named COVID-19 front-liners as Singaporean of the Year 2020, recognizing the selfless workers and volunteers who worked tirelessly to keep Singaporeans safe amid the pandemic. The award goes to collective efforts, not an individual, and includes 13 finalists who were chosen by a judging panel and public online voting. The winners received $50,000 and a trophy, while others received $5,000 and travel and accommodation prizes. The recognition acknowledges the efforts of healthcare workers, researchers, and volunteers who helped manage the outbreak and keep Singapore's Covid-19 death rate low.

site_title: Three children among 19 new Covid-19 imported cases in Singapore
summary: Singapore reported 19 new imported COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 59,584. Three of the cases are children under 3 years old. The cases originated from Canada, India, Indonesia, the UAE, and the US, with five Singaporeans and three permanent residents among them. The number of new community cases decreased to three, while 30 cases were discharged, leaving 44 patients in hospital.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 14.09 points to 1,580.49 on Tuesday, with a volume of 6.628 billion lots worth RM5.120 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 671 to 501.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: SMEs in Singapore face a gloomy outlook in 2021, according to a QBE poll, with many feeling under the weather despite increased positivity towards the economic climate. Singapore will proceed with its Sora transition by the end of 2021, while the Libor discontinuation may be pushed to mid-2023. The government emphasizes the need for a 'zero-trust' cybersecurity posture to safeguard against cyberattacks. The Singapore Exchange fully placed out 240 million euros of zero coupon convertible bonds. The Straits Times Index closed higher on Tuesday, up 0.7%, tracking Wall Street gains.

site_title: Exxon posts first annual loss in 40 years on huge writedown
summary: ExxonMobil posted its first annual loss in 40 years due to a $19.3-billion writedown on US natural gas and other assets. The company returned to profit in the fourth quarter, earning 3 cents per share, and maintained its $3.7 billion quarterly dividend. Exxon is cutting capital spending and operating costs, and CEO Darren Woods is exploring a megamerger with Chevron. The company's stock has rebounded despite a 41% decline in 2020, but investors still hold deep losses due to years of underperformance compared to peers.

site_title: UK landlords want banks to share rent burden
summary: UK landlords are seeking help from banks to share the burden of unpaid rent, with over £4 billion (S$7.3 billion) in rent due last year. The pandemic has left businesses struggling, and landlords are demanding lenders offer holidays on interest and capital repayments. Regulators are urging banks to avoid taking a hard line, while retailers and restaurateurs argue they are not at fault for the debt. The UK government has proposed a property-tax holiday and furlough programme, but landlords say this does not address the issue, and lenders are increasing pressure on them to pay.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England has urged lenders to consider carefully their responses to potential breaches of covenants arising directly from the Covid-19 pandemic and its consequences.

site_title: Hong Kong posts largest retail sales slump on record in 2020
summary: Hong Kong reported its largest retail sales slump on record in 2020, with a 24.3% decline in value and 25.5% decline in volume. The slump was attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic, with tourism and consumption severely impacted. Retail sales in December fell 13.2% from the previous year, marking the 23rd straight month of decline. The government warns that the business environment for retail trade will remain challenging in the near term, with hopes for recovery tied to the success of an upcoming vaccination campaign.

site_title: Alibaba beats revenue forecast as Chinese regulators hover
summary: Alibaba Group reported a stronger-than-expected third-quarter revenue, driven by a surge in online shopping during the coronavirus pandemic. The e-commerce giant's China-focused Singles Day sale generated $74 billion in sales in November, beating estimates. Meanwhile, Chinese regulators are scrutinizing Alibaba founder Jack Ma's business empire, including the suspension of a $37 billion IPO for his financial affiliate Ant Group. This comes as China clamps down on Ma's business interests amid regulatory pressures.

site_title: Breast cancer overtakes lung as most common cancer: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) announced that breast cancer has surpassed lung cancer as the most common form of cancer globally, accounting for nearly 12% of new cases each year. This marks the first time breast cancer has taken the top spot, displacing lung cancer which had held the position for the last two decades. Colorectal cancer remains the third most widespread form of cancer.

site_title: Year of the Ox: A year of renewal
summary: The Year of the Ox, which began in 2021, is expected to be a year of renewal and transformation as the world slowly recovers from the Covid-19 pandemic. Unlike the Rat, which is associated with poor stock market returns, the Ox is considered diligent and honest, potentially leading to better economic outcomes. The Year of the Ox is also associated with positive returns in soft commodities, such as agriculture, and is expected to see a shift towards digitalization, artificial intelligence, and remote work. Investors are advised to be diligent, persistent, and disciplined in their investment strategies to capitalize on these trends.

site_title: BP reports US$5.7b annual loss, its first in a decade
summary: BP reported its first annual loss in a decade, with a US$5.7 billion loss for 2020, down from a US$10 billion profit in 2019. The company cited low demand for refined products due to the pandemic, low oil and gas prices, and a shift away from oil and gas towards clean energy. CEO Bernard Looney acknowledged that the payoff from these investments won't come until the 2030s. Despite concerns about the Biden administration's policies on drilling for oil, Looney welcomed the administration's focus on clean energy, which aligns with BP's recent investments in offshore wind projects.

site_title: Russia's Sputnik V vaccine 92% effective in fighting Covid-19
summary: Russia's Sputnik V vaccine has shown 92% effectiveness in fighting Covid-19 based on late-stage trial results published in The Lancet. The Phase III trial involved 19,866 volunteers and found the vaccine to be 91.6% effective against symptomatic COVID-19. The vaccine's efficacy was consistent with earlier stages of the trial, and experts say it provides another effective tool in the global fight against the pandemic. The results support Russia's decision to roll out the vaccine before final data was released, despite criticism from some scientists.

site_title: Pfizer sees about US$15b in 2021 sales from Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Pfizer expects to generate US$15 billion in sales from its Covid-19 vaccine in 2021, with 200 million doses supplied to the US government by May. The company has already supplied 65 million doses globally, including 29 million to the US, with 17 million doses administered. The vaccine brought in US$154 million in sales in the fourth quarter and is forecast to drive adjusted earnings of US$3.10 to US$3.20 per share.

site_title: ByteDance sues arch-rival Tencent over alleged monopolies
summary: ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, sued Tencent Holdings over alleged monopolies in its WeChat and QQ platforms. ByteDance claims Tencent blocked access to its Douyin content on WeChat and QQ, violating Chinese antitrust laws. The lawsuit seeks 90 million yuan in compensation and orders Tencent to cease its actions. The move comes after Beijing's draft regulations aimed at rooting out monopolistic behavior among Internet companies. ByteDance claims competition promotes innovation, while Tencent denies the allegations as false and malicious.

images.alt_text: ByteDance sued Tencent Holdings over alleged monopolies in its WeChat and QQ platforms, escalating a feud between the leading Chinese social media giants.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher on Tuesday, tracking Wall Street gains, STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.7% to 2,917.29 on Tuesday, following Wall Street gains. The STI's rally was led by tech names, with iFast Corporation and Jardine Matheson Holdings being top advancers. The market's upside risks were deemed minimal by Axi strategist Stephen Innes, with investors optimistic about a global recovery. The KLCI rose 0.9% despite Malaysia's extension of its movement control order.

site_title: Uber to buy alcohol delivery startup Drizly for US$1.1b
summary: Uber agreed to acquire Drizly, an on-demand alcohol delivery app, for US$1.1 billion. The deal, Uber's largest since July's Postmates acquisition, involves primarily Uber stock and less than 10% cash. Drizly has seen a breakout year with sales 400% above historical levels during the US lockdowns, as consumers ordered more frequently and purchased more per order. The acquisition aims to capitalize on the persisting demand for home delivery after the pandemic subsides.

site_title: Keppel launches China logistics property fund with 1.4b yuan initial commitment
summary: Keppel Corporation has launched a China logistics property fund with an initial total equity commitment of around 1.4 billion yuan (S$288.8 million), marking the asset-management arm's first China-focused logistics property fund. The fund will invest in high-quality logistics assets in key logistics hubs across China, leveraging Keppel's expertise and a leading Chinese logistics developer and operator. The fund has an option to upsize by a similar amount by the end of the year, and is expected to generate attractive risk-adjusted returns for investors.

site_title: Ascendas Reit H2 DPU falls 0.9% to 7.418 Singapore cents
summary: Ascendas Reit's second-half distribution per unit (DPU) fell 0.9% to 7.418 Singapore cents, down from 7.485 cents in the previous year. Despite this, the Reit reported a 12.5% increase in gross revenue to S$528.2 million and a 7.8% rise in net property income to S$388.2 million. The Reit's DPU for the full year fell 6.1% to 14.688 cents, but CEO William Tay attributed this to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, citing a diversified portfolio and accretive acquisitions.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher after GameStop fever breaks
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday after a chaotic week, driven by optimism about potential emergency stimulus and the spread of Covid-19 vaccines. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged over 400 points, while the S&P 500 rose 1.3%. Analysts attributed the positive sentiment to the possibility of further stimulus measures and vaccine distribution. Despite a massive loss reported by ExxonMobil, the market rebounded, with the Dow gaining 1.4% and the S&P 500 reaching a fresh record.

site_title: Around 15,000 individuals now serving SHN in dedicated facilities
summary: Around 15,000 individuals are currently serving their Stay-Home Notice (SHN) in dedicated facilities, with 30-70 hotels operating as SHN dedicated facilities. National Development Minister Desmond Lee stated that the figure changes based on external factors, and the Ministry of National Development works with other agencies to balance supply and demand. The SDF system is critical to isolate travellers until they're free of Covid-19, and all incoming travellers have paid for their stay since January 2021. Contracts for facilities will be renewed as needed to manage the risk of imported cases.

site_title: Japan extends virus emergency by a month for Tokyo, other cities
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga has extended the state of emergency covering Tokyo and other major metropolitan areas until March 7, aiming to control Covid-19 infections. The current emergency measure, set to expire on February 7, will be extended for 10 areas, including Tokyo, while the prefecture of Tochigi was removed due to a sharp drop in infections. The extension is expected to cut around $28.6 billion off Japan's gross domestic product, putting pressure on finances ahead of the Olympics.

site_title: Fitch Solutions cuts Myanmar GDP forecast from 5.6% to 2% following military coup
summary: Fitch Solutions has cut its GDP forecast for Myanmar from 5.6% to 2% due to the country's political instability following the military coup. The research group warns that foreign direct investment (FDI) could be delayed or cancelled due to sanctions, impacting the economy. Infrastructure projects face high risks of stalling, and project cancellations could lead to job losses, impairing private consumption. Fitch expects a greater clampdown by the military, increasing political unrest and uncertainty, and potentially leading to unilateral sanctions from Western countries.

site_title: Sunpower Group wins 141m yuan manufacturing and services contract
summary: Sunpower Group has secured a 141 million yuan (S$29.1 million) manufacturing and services contract from an existing customer in the polycrystalline silicon industry. The contract, expected to be completed in 2021, will supply core equipment and is anticipated to positively impact the group's performance for FY2021. Sunpower's executive chairman, Guo Hongxin, expressed confidence in the company's green investments (GI) business, which has nine operating projects and four under construction. The company's shares rose 2.21% following the announcement.

site_title: Japfa completes disposal of 80% interest in Greenfields Dairy Singapore
summary: Japfa completes the disposal of 80% interest in Greenfields Dairy Singapore to affiliates of TPG and Northstar Group for US$236 million. Japfa will retain 20% of the shareholding and support the management of the business. The company intends to utilize part of the consideration to pay a special interim dividend of S$0.10 per share, with a book-closure date to be announced with FY2020 full-year financial results. Japfa shares closed 1.7% higher at S$0.91 following the announcement.

site_title: Electrolux sees continued boost from stay-at-home trend after Q4 profit beat
summary: Electrolux, a Swedish home appliances maker, posted higher than forecast fourth-quarter profits, driven by strong consumer demand due to the pandemic. Operating profit rose to 2.5 billion crowns, exceeding analyst expectations. The company expects a continued stay-at-home trend and higher demand in the first half of 2021, despite raw material headwinds, with prices expected to compensate for these losses.

site_title: Singapore should adopt 'zero-trust' cybersecurity posture to safeguard against cyberattacks: Iswaran
summary: Singapore should adopt a "zero-trust" cybersecurity posture to safeguard against cyberattacks, Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran said. This involves verifying all network activity and monitoring for suspicious activities, as well as implementing measures to restrict access and validate transactions. The government will issue public advisories and strengthen engagement with critical infrastructure and organizations to adopt cybersecurity measures. Despite no current indication of impact from the SolarWinds breach, the government will remain cautious and continue to strengthen cyber defenses against sophisticated threats.

site_title: Team became aware of police ability to use TraceTogether data in late October: Vivian
summary: Minister-in-Charge of the Smart Nation Initiative Vivian Balakrishnan revealed in Parliament that he became aware of the possibility that TraceTogether data could be used for police investigations in late October, contrary to his June announcement that it would only be used for contact tracing. This was after a public inquiry raised the question.

site_title: UK needs to install electric car chargers five times faster to hit goals
summary: The UK needs to rapidly expand electric vehicle charging points to meet its 2030 goal of banning new gasoline and diesel car sales. The think tank Policy Exchange recommends installing 35,000 points per year, five times the current rate of 7,000. The government has allocated £20 million to support on-street residential charging, but experts say this is insufficient. Without reforms, rural areas and outside of London and the South East will have limited charging options, hindering the adoption of electric vehicles and the UK's efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Singapore PMI improves further in January, though electronics growth eases
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sentiment continued to improve in January, with the Singapore Institute of Purchasing and Materials Management's (SIPMM) Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 50.7, its highest reading since March 2019. The electronics sector PMI, which eased from December, still showed expansion for the sixth straight month. While manufacturing growth is expected to slow to 3.5% in 2021, down from 7.1% in 2020, the country's PMI figures indicate a cautiously optimistic outlook for the year, with some moderation in momentum.

site_title: MAS and SGX RegCo flag risks linked to trading incited by online discussion forums
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) have issued a warning, urging the public to be on "heightened alert" due to potential risks in trading incited by online discussion forums and social media chat groups. They are monitoring market activities for false trading and misconduct, similar to recent US market activities involving stocks like GameStop, AMC Entertainment Holdings, and BlackBerry. The bodies are flagging speculative activities in the Singapore stock market, advising caution to investors.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end on another high
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng index rising 1.23% to 29,248.70. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased, with gains of 0.81% and 1.66% respectively. The rally follows last week's rout and is driven by bargain-buying and optimism over US stimulus talks.

site_title: VW CEO expects 'significant' market upturn
summary: Volkswagen CEO Herbert Diess expects a significant market upturn in the second half of 2021, driven by the global economy's recovery and ongoing vaccination programs. Diess notes that the company will prepare for increased car sales, despite facing challenges from Covid-19 and semiconductor shortages. VW aims to sell 600,000 battery-powered cars this year, with the ID.4 accounting for 150,000 units, while reducing fixed costs by 5% and material expenses by 7%. The company seeks to maintain profit margins while boosting sales volumes.

site_title: Cross-border collaborations a beacon for SMEs amidst COVID-19
summary: Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore face challenges such as financing and access to new technologies amid the COVID-19 pandemic. To support SMEs, the government introduced the Business sans Border initiative, connecting them to global platforms and logistics services. Despite these efforts, many SMEs struggle with lack of capital and robust financial documentation. Expanding overseas and adopting global technologies can help SMEs grow and thrive, but the pandemic has inspired a more protectionist world, making international collaboration a beacon for these businesses to overcome their challenges.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets rebounded at the open on Tuesday, extending a global rally, with London's FTSE 100 gaining 0.4%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 rising 0.8%, and Paris' CAC 40 up 1.2%. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare sectors, and traders brushed off new US threats to the global economy. The European markets' gains followed earlier gains in Asia and the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close higher as chip stocks gain
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.32% on Tuesday, driven by gains in chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, as well as foreign buying. The Kospi index closed at 3,096.81, reaching a one-week high. Tech stocks led the advance, following a Wall Street rebound overnight. Analysts expect the US stimulus package discussion to be closely watched this week. Meanwhile, South Korea's inflation sped up in January, and the ruling party announced plans for a fourth round of Covid-19 cash handouts. Foreigners bought US$175.01 million worth of shares.

site_title: Japan urged to link up private, public testing to better grasp extent of pandemic
summary: Japan's government is urged to link private Covid-19 testing with public databases to better grasp the pandemic's extent. Health experts say the current regime, focusing on cluster-breaking, is insufficient. Private PCR tests have surged as residents seek alternatives. The health ministry recommends vetting testing companies and merging figures with public clinics. Japan's testing rate is low, with 50 tests per 1,000 people, compared to 100 in South Korea or 900 in the US. The government is expected to extend Tokyo's state of emergency for another month due to strained medical services.

site_title: Panasonic raises profit outlook on sales rebound, cost cuts
summary: Panasonic Corp raised its full-year operating profit forecast to 230 billion yen (S$2.93 billion) after streamlining operations and seeing a sales recovery, exceeding Refinitiv's consensus forecast of 174.6 billion yen. The company's shift to focus on housing fixtures, car electronics, and electric vehicle batteries has contributed to the profit increase, driven by growing demand for electric vehicle batteries through its partnership with Tesla Inc. Panasonic's operating profit for the three months ending Dec 31 rose 30% to 130.2 billion yen.

site_title: Container crisis upends global food trade
summary: A global container crisis is causing food to pile up in ports, with shipping empty boxes back to China becoming more profitable than loading them. The crisis, fueled by China's revved-up export economy, is affecting countries such as Thailand, Canada, India, and Vietnam, leading to shortages of food and other goods. Empty containers are traveling back to China at a rate of three in four at the US's largest port, Los Angeles, while terminals are struggling to return containers in tight windows. The situation is expected to worsen, potentially leading to higher food costs for consumers in Asia.

site_title: Hong Kong leader defends 'ambush lockdown' tactics
summary: Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam defended the use of "ambush lockdowns" to combat the coronavirus, citing the success of a recent operation that uncovered no new cases despite 1,700 tests. The tactic involves surprise lockdowns with no warning, followed by mandatory testing of all occupants. Despite limited success, Lam argued that the approach is effective in prevention, not just recovery. The government plans to use more frequent and wider lockdowns as the Lunar New Year holidays approach.

site_title: UK defends delay to quarantine meant to keep out virus strain
summary: The UK has defended its delay in implementing a hotel quarantine for travellers arriving from virus hot spots, citing logistical efforts. The policy, aimed at preventing the import of new strains of the coronavirus, was announced last week but has yet to be implemented. Despite this, English authorities are boosting testing in eight areas where cases of the South Africa variant have been found, indicating community transmission.

images.alt_text: The UK defended the delay in imposing hotel quarantine for travellers arriving from virus hot spots, even as officials battle to contain the spread of a new variant of coronavirus from South Africa.

site_title: Biden to keep tariffs on aluminum imports from UAE, reversing Trump
summary: US President Joe Biden will maintain a 10% tariff on aluminum imports from the UAE, reversing Donald Trump's decision to exempt the country. The tariff was imposed in 2018 to boost domestic production and protect national security. Biden cited evidence that imports from the UAE may displace domestic production, threatening national security. The move also reverses Trump's deal to sell 50 Lockheed Martin fighter jets to the UAE. The Biden administration will review other deals, including the arms sales, but did not comment on broader ties with the UAE.

site_title: Removing barriers to cross-border payments could be the key to unlocking Southeast Asia's economic potential
summary: Removing barriers to cross-border payments is crucial for Southeast Asia's economic growth, with SMEs expected to drive the region's projected 5% annual growth to become the fourth largest economy by 2030. The ASEAN Federation of Accountants emphasizes the need for a level playing field for businesses to buy and sell internationally. The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (RCEP) is a step towards this goal, but more needs to be done to facilitate cross-border digital payments and unlock the region's economic potential.

images.alt_text: Leslie Choo, Senior Vice President & Managing Director - Asia, ACI Worldwide

site_title: South Korea's Jan inflation speeds up, beating forecasts
summary: South Korea's consumer prices rose 0.6% in January from a year earlier, beating forecasts of a 0.3% gain. This is the fastest growth since September 2018. Month-on-month inflation was 0.8%, exceeding expectations of a 0.5% rise. The increase is attributed to rising food prices and a stronger currency.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain as RBA expands quantitative easing
summary: Australian shares rose 1.5% on Tuesday, marking their best day since January 7, after the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) expanded its quantitative easing program by A$100 billion to support economic recovery. The RBA held its cash rate at 0.1% and reiterated its pledge of record-low interest rates until inflation targets are met. Tech stocks, including Afterpay and Appen, surged 7.9% and 4.5% respectively, contributing to the market's gains.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on US rallies, cheap yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.97% on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index ending at 28,362.17. Investors were encouraged by US rallies and a cheaper yen, despite ongoing earnings reports. The broader Topix index also edged up 0.94%. This follows recent rallies in other markets, including Singapore's 5-day rally.

site_title: Gloomy outlook for SMEs in 2021: QBE poll
summary: A QBE survey of Singapore SMEs found that despite increased optimism towards the economic climate in 2021, 81% expect their businesses to remain stagnant and 39% anticipate workforce downsizing. Only 3% rely on government support, with 70% seeking financial aid and 37% wanting enterprise development programs. Many SMEs are adopting cautious approaches, with 95% aware of government funds but only 61% applying for support. High digitalization costs and cyber threats remain significant concerns.

site_title: Philippines is negotiating for 178 million coronavirus vaccine
summary: The Philippines is negotiating for 178 million COVID-19 vaccine doses, enough to inoculate 92 million people, amid a severe economic contraction due to the pandemic. The country's gross domestic product contracted by 9.5% in 2020. The government has secured $1.4 billion in funding and aims to prioritize healthcare workers and economic frontliners for vaccination. China has agreed to donate Sinovac Biotech Ltd vaccines, pending FDA approval, and the government targets to secure additional doses this month.

site_title: SpaceX aims to launch 'all-civilian' trip into orbit
summary: SpaceX plans to launch its first all-civilian mission into Earth's orbit later this year, led by tech billionaire Jared Isaacman. Three novice astronauts, including a winner of a raffle, will join Isaacman on a multi-day journey into space. The mission, targeted for the fourth quarter of 2021, will include a water landing off the Florida coast after orbiting the Earth every 90 minutes. SpaceX has already certified its Crew Dragon spacecraft and is providing commercial astronaut training to the crew members.

site_title: UK house prices fall for 1st time since June before tax break ends
summary: UK house prices fell 0.3% in January, the first decline in 7 months, as demand slows ahead of the end of the stamp duty tax break. The annual increase slowed to 6.4% from 7.3% in December, with economists expecting a sharp decline in housing market activity if the tax break ends as scheduled. The slowdown may be due to people bringing forward their purchases before the tax break ends, and labor market conditions continuing to weaken.

site_title: China's short-term money rates fall to two-week low as PBOC injects liquidity
summary: China's short-term money rates fell to a two-week low as the People's Bank of China (PBOC) injected 78 billion yuan into money markets, easing liquidity tension. The Shanghai Interbank Offered Rate (SHIBOR) for one-week tenor dropped to 2.241% and the volume-weighted average rate of benchmark seven-day repo fell to 2.2285%. This follows the Lunar New Year holidays, which are expected to reduce cash demand due to coronavirus fears and travel restrictions. The PBOC's actions aim to maintain financial stability and avoid fueling potential bubbles in the property and share markets.

site_title: Golden Globe nominations set tone for Hollywood's pandemic awards season
summary: The 78th Golden Globe nominations, set to be announced on Wednesday, will kick off Hollywood's pandemic-affected awards season. Smaller, stay-at-home movies like "The Trial of the Chicago 7" and "Mank" are expected to excel, as traditional studios held back big releases. "Nomadland" is a top contender for best picture, and acting heavyweights such as Frances McDormand and Meryl Streep are among the lead contenders. The ceremony will take place on February 28, with Tina Fey and Amy Poehler hosting, and will be a precursor to the Oscars on April 25.

site_title: Chinese syringe producers under pressure as vaccination programmes drive order surge
summary: Chinese syringe manufacturers are facing unprecedented pressure due to the surge in global coronavirus vaccination programmes, with some predicting they may only fulfill large orders as late as June. Companies like Zhejiang KangKang Medical Devices and Shandong Qiaosen are working around the clock to meet the demand, raising prices and expanding production. The companies, which are the world's largest producers of syringes, are experiencing a significant increase in orders, with over 90% of their orders coming from China before the pandemic.

site_title: Lights out: Brexit shuts off market for English cheese truckles
summary: The Cheshire Cheese company, a UK-based artisanal cheese producer, has been forced to halt its sales to the European Union due to Brexit-related regulations. The company, which sold £180,000 worth of cheese to EU customers last year, now faces significant costs and bureaucratic hurdles. Managing Director Simon Spurrell is considering setting up a hub in France to continue wholesale sales, while putting plans for a new UK distribution centre on hold. The company's sales and jobs are at risk due to the new trade deal's obstacles to trade.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rally again as optimism returns to markets
summary: Asia's stock markets rallied on Tuesday, extending the previous day's gains as investors regained optimism over US stimulus hopes. Analysts noted concerns over social media-led retail investor battles with Wall Street hedge funds were easing, but the coronavirus and vaccine rollouts continued to limit gains. Despite this, the mood was lighter than last week, with the Singapore Stock Index (STI) rising 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Myanmar generals in firm control after coup
summary: Myanmar's military leaders maintained control after a successful coup, detaining democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi. Despite global condemnation, the streets of Yangon remained relatively calm with few signs of extra security. The military appears confident, with a taxi driver expressing dissatisfaction through protests. The international community continues to respond to the situation, with various economic and diplomatic implications unfolding.

site_title: Buying into 'poor man's gold', Chinese investors jump on silver
summary: Chinese investors surged into silver investments, driving up prices on the Shanghai Futures Exchange to a four-month high, with prices rising 9.27% to 5,939 yuan per kilogram. This follows a rally in share prices of US video game retailer GameStop Corp by retail traders on Reddit, who are now targeting silver. China's domestic silver prices have not been this high since September, and related stocks and funds have also seen significant gains, with open interest on the Shanghai futures contract jumping to 516,568 lots.

site_title: Singapore to proceed with Sora transition, even as Libor discontinuation may be pushed back
summary: Singapore will proceed with its transition to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) by the end of 2021, despite the potential pushback of the Libor discontinuation to mid-2023. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will continue to use Sora in its interest rate calculations, even if Libor ends in mid-2023. This decision comes after a proposed extension of Libor discontinuation by the ICE Benchmark Administration.

site_title: Study shows variant spreading in Britain could become resistant to vaccines
summary: A coronavirus variant in the UK, B.1.1.7, has gained a mutation that could make it harder to control with vaccines, according to Public Health England. The variant rapidly spread across the UK in just two months and has been shown to hold onto cells more tightly due to its mutations. This development raises concerns about the effectiveness of vaccines in controlling the spread of the virus. The UK is facing another blow to its economy, with the economy shrinking for the second month in a row.

site_title: AIA, China Strategic among bidders for Bank of East Asia's life insurance unit: sources
summary: AIA Group and China Strategic Holdings are among final bidders for Bank of East Asia's (BEA) life insurance unit, with a potential sale price of $500-600 million. BEA aims to boost profitability and lift shares by selling the unit, which has about $25.4 billion in assets. AIA and China Strategic have submitted binding bids, with an announcement possible as early as this month. China Strategic has seen its shares rise 25% after the report, while AIA's shares declined 1%. BEA is seeking a long-term distribution agreement to generate ongoing revenue.

site_title: Moderna proposes filling vials with additional doses of Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Moderna Inc proposes filling vials with up to 15 doses of its Covid-19 vaccine to ease manufacturing capacity constraints, as the company approaches producing almost a million doses per day. This move comes after the US FDA authorized the use of extra doses from Pfizer's vials due to labelling confusion. As of Monday, the US CDC had administered 32.2 million doses and distributed 49.9 million doses. Moderna must obtain FDA approval before implementing the new vial filling strategy.

site_title: TraceTogether data use balances between protecting public health and public safety: Vivian
summary: Singapore's government has introduced a Bill to balance the use of TraceTogether data for Covid-19 contact-tracing efforts with public safety. Minister Vivian Balakrishnan acknowledged an error in stating that the data was exempt from the Criminal Procedure Code, allowing police to obtain it for investigations. The Bill restricts the use of data to contact tracing, with some exceptions for serious offences, and ensures that data administrators must delete personal contact-tracing data no longer needed. The legislation also includes a one-year extension for Covid-19 safe-management measures until April 2022.

site_title: EU aims to boost vaccination rollout as variants spread
summary: The European Union is bolstering its vaccination rollout amid concerns about the spread of new, more contagious variants of the Covid-19 virus. EU leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel, have pledged to increase vaccine deliveries, with pharmaceutical giants such as BioNTech and Pfizer promising to ramp up production. The EU aims to send 75 million doses in the spring, while AstraZeneca has also increased shipments. Despite progress, vaccination rates remain slow, and countries continue to impose restrictions to curb the spread of the virus.

site_title: Australia's Woodside says assessing impact of Myanmar coup on offshore drilling
summary: Australia's Woodside Petroleum is assessing the impact of Myanmar's military coup on its offshore drilling plans. The company, working with Total SA and MPRL E&P, had started a three-well drilling campaign in a block near a proposed ultra-deep water gas project. The US has threatened to reimpose sanctions on Myanmar, and Woodside is reviewing the situation to protect its workers and contractors. The company has invested over $400 million in Myanmar since 2014 and is working with the Australian government to ensure safety. Delays to the project are possible, according to analysts.

site_title: India raises import levy on several items to boost local output
summary: India has raised import duties on various products, including raw cotton, electronics, and farm equipment, to boost local manufacturing and create jobs. The move is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's plan to reduce reliance on imports. The increase in duties is effective immediately, targeting products such as compressors, leather, and solar lanterns. The goal is to capitalize on supply lines moving out of China and incentivize local manufacturing.

images.alt_text: The government raised import duty on a range of products from raw cotton to electronics items to boost local manufacturing and generate jobs, Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman said on Monday.

site_title: Japan to extend virus emergency, months before delayed Olympics
summary: Japan's government is set to approve a month-long extension of its coronavirus state of emergency, less than six months before the postponed Olympic Games. The extension, expected to apply to 10 of Japan's 11 prefectures, comes despite a dip in new infections and follows public pressure. The measure, which includes increased teleworking and closures of bars and restaurants from 8pm, aims to maintain vigilance in the face of the ongoing pandemic. The extension is seen as a sign of the government's caution ahead of the Olympics, which are expected to go ahead this summer.

site_title: Sequoia, GIC invest in TPG's Novotech at US$2.3b valuation: sources
summary: Sequoia Capital and Singapore sovereign fund GIC have invested in TPG's Novotech, a clinical research and testing provider, in a deal valuing the company at over US$2.3 billion. Kaiser Foundation Hospitals also plans to invest in the company. Novotech, which has increased revenues by over 30% annually under TPG's ownership, is preparing for an initial public offering in Hong Kong later this year. The investment is seen as a testament to the growing demand for biotech companies in Asia.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB upgrades SATS to 'add' with higher S$4.30 TP
summary: Brokerage firm CGS-CIMB has upgraded its rating on SATS to "add" from "hold" and raised its target price to S$4.30 from S$3.27, citing expectations of a profit reversal in the near term due to a recovery in cargo revenue and potential government support. Analyst Lim Siew Khee forecasts SATS to report a profit of S$3.5 million in Q3 FY2021 and for its cargo-handling division to grow to 22% of revenue by FY2022.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 18.33 points, or 1.17%, to 1,584.73 on Tuesday. The index saw 1.23 billion lots traded worth RM764.46 million. Gainers outpaced losers 368 to 337.

site_title: Covid forces Orthodox Jews to seek new dating venues
summary: In Israel, the COVID-19 pandemic has forced Orthodox Jews to find alternative dating venues due to restrictions on indoor gatherings. Young couples are now meeting in private homes, gardens, or on outdoor benches, adhering to Jewish law's strict guidelines on physical contact and solo meetings. To combat the decline in marriages, an app has been launched, "Project 252," offering private homes as venues for courtship, with over 250 couples already using the service.

site_title: Americans scramble for appointments for second Covid-19 vaccine dose
summary: As the US moves towards vaccinating its population with a second Covid-19 vaccine dose, Americans are facing challenges in securing appointments, with many relying on family members to navigate complex systems. The CDC reports 26 million people have received their first dose, but the pace of second doses is slower than expected. Providers are experiencing long wait times and finite vaccine supplies, leading to concerns about unequal access to the vaccine.

site_title: Shaky iron market turns to Vale for final piece of supply puzzle
summary: Vale SA, the Brazilian iron ore producer, is expected to report its production report on Wednesday, including updated annual guidance, which could impact iron ore prices. Stronger-than-expected output or increased projections could support prices, currently at around $150 a metric ton, while a disappointing report could lead to a "stronger-for-longer" case for higher prices, potentially reaching $165 a ton in the next three years.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, tracking gains on Wall Street, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.45% or 127.02 points at 28,218.07. The Topix index also gained 0.47% or 8.52 points. Gains were offset by concerns over Japan's coronavirus-triggered state of emergency.

site_title: What is GameStop, the company, really worth? Does it matter?
summary: GameStop's stock price surged 1,600% in January, reaching $21 billion, despite the company's declining sales and losses. Analysts say the valuation is unreasonable, citing a valuation ratio of 200 times estimated profits, compared to Walmart's 23 times. Experts believe the company's business model is not as threatened by online gaming as thought, and its ability to cut costs and invest in its online offering could be key to a turnaround. The company's future is uncertain, and its stock price may continue to fluctuate as investors weigh the potential for a miraculous turnaround.

site_title: Wall Street 'predators' make allies of political foes
summary: US politicians from both parties have joined forces to condemn market manipulation by Wall Street, particularly hedge funds, after a recent surge in stock prices. The "short-selling" tactic, where investors sell borrowed shares expecting to buy them back cheaper, was disrupted by amateur investors on Reddit's WallStreetBets forum. Senators Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders have called for regulatory action, while Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton has vowed to crack down on hedge funds and Robinhood. The issue has sparked a rare convergence of right-wing and left-wing ideologies, with some seeing it as a call for reform of the financial system.

images.alt_text: Recent stock market mayhem has done what appeals to rise above self-interest could not - gotten US politicians of all stripes to agree.

site_title: China state media celebrates top entrepreneurs. But not Jack Ma
summary: China's state media has published a list of top entrepreneurs, excluding Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma, who has faced backlash from Beijing due to his criticism of regulators. Instead, Pony Ma of Tencent Holdings, Wang Chuanfu of BYD Co, Lei Jun of Xiaomi Corp, and Ren Zhengfei of Huawei Technologies Co made the list. The omission may signal a broader crackdown on private technology corporations, with Tencent's shares rising 2% on the news. Jack Ma's absence is telling, given his significant presence in Alibaba's backyard and the recent investigation into his e-commerce giant.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on tech-led Wall Street rebound; central bank policy meeting in focus
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to 6,704.9, driven by tech stocks following a US-led rebound, and gains in financial and mining stocks. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to hold its cash rate at 0.1% and may extend its quantitative easing program. Investors will also focus on RBA Governor Phillip Lowe's speech on Wednesday. Meanwhile, miners climbed 1.8% and tech stocks rose 3.8%, with Afterpay gaining 6.5%.

site_title: Africa's pandemic-hit mining sector faces exploration challenge
summary: Africa's mining sector faces a significant exploration challenge due to the ongoing pandemic, with mining exploration budgets falling 10% to a four-year low in 2020. The decline is attributed to travel restrictions, supply chain disruptions, and risk aversion. African nations, including South Africa, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and Ghana, have been particularly affected, with exploration budgets at a 17-year low. The sector's reliance on public markets and private equity capital has also been hindered, with junior explorers and miners struggling to raise funds.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally out of the blocks
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.68% to 29,378.12, following a previous day's surge. Investors returned to buying, driven by a recovery from last week's rout. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid US-EU trade talks.

site_title: UK's Sunak to keep pledge not to raise key tax rates: FT
summary: UK finance minister Rishi Sunak has ruled out raising income tax, value-added tax, or National Insurance rates to strengthen public finances, despite high public borrowing due to the coronavirus pandemic. The pledge, made by the Conservative Party before the 2019 election, aims to maintain a stable tax environment. The UK's public borrowing is expected to reach £400 billion in the 2020/21 financial year, prompting calls to reconsider the tax pledge. Sunak's stance maintains the Conservative Party's pre-election commitment.

site_title: The Little Things leads US box office despite HBO Max debut
summary: Denzel Washington's crime thriller "The Little Things" topped the US box office with $4.8 million from 2,171 venues, despite being available on HBO Max for a monthly fee. This performance is seen as a sign of the audience's insatiable appetite for high-quality films. The film's success comes as the theatrical market remains bleak, with many cinemas shuttered and limited capacity. Analysts predict the industry will return to normal in 2022, citing "healthy demand for quality entertainment."

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.4% or 10.89 points to 2,907.21. The rally follows a rebound in US equities, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. Gainers outnumbered losers 127 to 33, with 116.9 million securities changing hands worth S$88.9 million. The market's positive sentiment appears to be sustained, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, SPH, iFast, PropNex, CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has fully placed S$386 million of zero coupon convertible bonds due 2024, with shares closing at S$9.92. Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) and Temasek have merged their MICE subsidiaries, with SPH shares rising 1.7% to S$1.20. iFast Corporation reached a record high of S$6.40, while PropNex is selling its property management arm stake for S$1 million. CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust issued HK$713 million fixed-rate notes.

site_title: Nintendo smashes expectations with best quarter since 2008
summary: Nintendo exceeded expectations with its best quarterly earnings since 2008, reporting 229.7 billion yen in operating profit. The company raised its annual forecast for Switch sales to 26.5 million units, surpassing its previous projection of 24 million. Strong sales of Animal Crossing: New Horizons and the Switch console, which sold 11.6 million units in the holiday period, drove the growth. Nintendo President Shuntaro Furukawa stated that the company doesn't plan to announce a new Switch model soon, leaving room for new hardware later in the year.

images.alt_text: Nintendo Co raised its annual forecasts a second time after continued momentum for the Switch console helped the company to its best quarterly earnings since 2008.

site_title: SGX fully places out zero coupon convertible bonds
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has fully placed 240 million euros (S$386 million) of zero-coupon convertible bonds due March 1, 2024, with a "high-quality book of institutional investors" after being over four times subscribed at 101% of the principle amount. The bonds can be converted into ordinary shares at an initial conversion price of S$13.0944, offering a 0.331% negative yield to maturity. SGX plans to allocate 80% of the bond proceeds to refinance existing debt and 20% for general corporate purposes.

site_title: Facebook pop-ups to escalate feud with Apple
summary: Facebook is introducing pop-up messages on its iPhone and iPad apps to promote the benefits of targeted ads ahead of Apple's new iOS feature, which includes a tracking transparency prompt that could limit Facebook's ability to serve targeted ads. The tech giants have been clashing over the feature, which Facebook claims could hurt small businesses and apps. Facebook claims Apple's actions are anti-competitive, while Apple's CEO Tim Cook implied Facebook's business model promotes disinformation and violence. The feud escalated after Apple's iOS feature was announced.

site_title: Covid ICU deaths have plunged, but progress may be stalling: study
summary: Covid-19 ICU deaths have decreased by over a third since the pandemic's early months, falling to 36% by October, thanks to effective treatments and hospital care. However, a recent meta-analysis suggests that this progress may be stalling, with ICU mortality rates plateauing between June and October 2020. The study, which analyzed data from 43,128 patients, found that new variants of the coronavirus may put further pressure on ICUs, but experts believe that current treatments, including steroids and improved oxygen therapy, should still be effective against the new variants.

site_title: Huge snowstorm hits US east coast
summary: A huge snowstorm hit the US east coast on Monday, causing widespread disruptions. Thousands of flights were canceled, schools closed, and coronavirus vaccinations were postponed. New York City declared a state of emergency, with 60cm of snow expected, and residents were advised to stay indoors. The storm also caused power outages, with New Jersey and Philadelphia declaring states of emergency. The storm's impact was felt across the eastern seaboard, with heavy snowfall and high winds causing hazardous conditions.

site_title: MediaTek launches 5G chip aimed at gaining US market share
summary: Taiwanese chip designer MediaTek Inc has launched a new 5G chip, the M80, aimed at gaining market share in the US. The chip supports millimeter-wave technology, a variant of 5G networks used by US carriers like Verizon, and is compatible with both sub-6 and millimeter-wave networks. MediaTek hopes to win more contracts to supply chips for US models, building on its existing partnerships with phone makers such as Xiaomi Corp and LG Electronics Inc. The company aims to capitalize on the growing demand for 5G technology in the US market.

site_title: Robinhood raises US$3.4b to meet needs amid GameStop saga
summary: Robinhood raised US$3.4 billion to meet its needs amid the GameStop saga, surpassing its total funds raised since inception. The funding round, led by Ribbit Capital and existing investors, will help the company continue to invest in growth. The surge in demand for Robinhood, driven by social media campaigns targeting GameStop and other companies, has put a strain on the platform, leading to the decision to limit trades on volatile stocks and a US$3 billion security deposit with clearing houses.

site_title: Trump's new impeachment team signals aggressive defence
summary: Former US President Donald Trump has hired two new lawyers, David Schoen and Bruce Castor, to defend him in his Senate impeachment trial. The two, known for their expertise in high-profile cases, will face prosecutors arguing Trump's alleged role in inciting the January 6 US Capitol attack. Trump has insisted on arguing that the 2020 presidential election was marred by fraud, a claim that could erode Republican support. The new team will need to prepare a strategy within a week, with a formal response and pretrial brief due by February 8, amidst concerns about the constitutionality of the trial and the likelihood of Trump's acquittal.

site_title: Exxon creates unit to commercialise carbon-reduction technology
summary: ExxonMobil has created a division, Low Carbon Solutions, to commercialize its carbon-reduction technology, including carbon capture and storage. The move aims to reduce the company's greenhouse gas emissions by 15-20% by 2025. Exxon plans to invest $3 billion in lower-emission solutions, directly competing with Occidental Petroleum's Oxy Low Carbon Ventures. The company's efforts come amid pressure from investors and activists to address climate change, as Exxon engages in a proxy fight with hedge fund Engine No. 1 to push for a more renewables-focused future.

site_title: 'Saved by the Bell' star Dustin Diamond dead of cancer at 44
summary: US actor Dustin Diamond, best known for his role as Screech on the hit TV series 'Saved by the Bell', died at 44 due to an aggressive form of cancer that spread rapidly throughout his system. He was diagnosed just weeks before his death. Diamond's agent described him as not suffering, and his former co-stars Mark-Paul Gosselaar and Mario Lopez paid tribute to him, stating he will be deeply missed.

site_title: AI startup Databricks valued at US$28b, tech giants join funding
summary: AI startup Databricks raised US$1 billion in funding at a US$28 billion valuation, backed by Microsoft, Google, Amazon, and new investors including Salesforce and Fidelity. The company, which serves 40% of Fortune 500 companies, aims to expand its "lakehouse" architecture to improve analytics. This investment validates Databricks' vision for a unified data platform and follows a surge in cloud computing firms' values, including Snowflake's US$80 billion valuation.

site_title: WHO slams critics of Covid-19 origins probe
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has defended its investigation into the origins of the Covid-19 pandemic, challenging critics to come forward with information. The WHO's emergencies director, Michael Ryan, blasted those claiming to know better, saying it's irresponsible to reject the report before it's written. The investigation team, led by Maria Van Kerkhove, has started visiting key locations in Wuhan, China, including the Huanan seafood market and the Wuhan Institute of Virology. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus noted that while the global number of new cases has fallen, the virus can be controlled, but warns of the risk of reopening too quickly.

site_title: Europe: Miners push British stocks higher; ASOS gains on Arcadia deal
summary: British shares rose on Monday, led by gains in mining stocks, with the FTSE 100 index gaining 0.9% and the mid-cap index adding 0.8%. Mining companies BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Anglo American were top gainers. Silver prices surged to an eight-year high, driving gains in silver-mining stocks. ASOS gained 6.9% after acquiring Topshop and other brands from Arcadia's collapsed group, while JD Sports jumped 7.0% on a US takeover deal.

site_title: Biden demands Myanmar military cede power, orders sanctions review
summary: US President Joe Biden called on Myanmar's military to immediately relinquish power, ordering a review to consider reimposing sanctions lifted during the nation's transition to democracy. The US removed sanctions based on progress toward democracy, but Biden said the reversal of progress will necessitate an immediate review of sanction laws. The move comes after the military arrested democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi and other politicians after her party scored a sweeping election victory, prompting criticism from the international community. Biden vowed to stand up for democracy and work with partners to support the restoration of democracy and rule of law.

site_title: Economic growth has 'devastating cost to nature', review finds
summary: A 600-page review commissioned by the British government found that humanity's unbridled economic growth has come at a "devastating cost to nature," with global biodiversity declining by 40% since 1992. The review warns that nothing short of a significant shift in economic growth strategies can prevent catastrophic impacts on nature and humanity. It calls for a new way of defining economic well-being, one that takes into account nature's services, and warns that transformative change is necessary to prevent the worst impacts of climate change and biodiversity loss.

site_title: Broker's take: Metro's possible department store exit may impact SPH Reit, FCT, says DBS
summary: DBS Group Research suggests that Metro Holdings' potential exit of its department store business may have a greater impact on SPH Reit than Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT). Metro's two department stores, located at Paragon and Causeway Point, are set to expire in a few years. The exposure is deemed material for Paragon, a key asset for SPH Reit, as the department store occupies a "cold corner" with less traffic. Having an anchor tenant is necessary to "pull" traffic to the space.

images.alt_text: Metro has two department stores with a few years left on the lease at SPH Reit's Paragon and FCT's Causeway Point, where it stands as an anchor tenant.

site_title: US: Wall Street rallies as Reddit fear eases, Dow gains 0.8%
summary: US stocks rallied on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.8% to 30,212.37, as traders shifted focus from GameStop to other stocks after a week of social media-fueled buying. Despite concerns over rising Covid-19 cases and variants, positive manufacturing data and expected economic revival helped lift investor sentiment. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index rose 2.6% to 13,403.39, while the S&P 500 climbed 1.6% to 3,773.77, as analysts predicted economic growth would return to pre-pandemic levels in the middle of this year.

site_title: State-owned units headed for new Indonesian SWF
summary: Indonesia is preparing to launch the Indonesia Investment Authority (IIA), a state-owned enterprise aimed at managing the country's sovereign wealth fund. The IIA will start operations in Q2 with an initial injection of $5 billion in assets, with a goal of $40 billion in investments by the end of the year. This move is part of Indonesia's efforts to diversify its economy and increase foreign investment.

site_title: India's 'get well soon' Budget boosts healthcare spending 135%, opens up insurance
summary: India's Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman unveiled a budget that boosts healthcare spending by 135% and opens up the insurance market to foreigners, aiming to create "wealth and wellness" in a country battling the world's second-highest coronavirus caseload. The government increased healthcare spending to 2.2 trillion rupees, with a fiscal deficit of 6.8% of GDP for 2021/22. The budget also allocated 200 billion rupees to recapitalize state-run banks and increased foreign direct investment caps in the insurance sector.

site_title: China's impatient about the new China policy but US is in no rush
summary: Chinese officials are becoming impatient for the US to unveil a new China policy following the inauguration of President Joe Biden. Despite acknowledging Biden's success, Chinese spokeswoman Hua Chunying expressed a desire for clear guidance from Washington. This comes as China seeks to navigate its relations with the US in a rapidly changing global landscape. The lack of a new policy has sparked concerns about the future of US-China ties.

site_title: Oil settles up more than 2% as US inventories fall, demand picks up
summary: Oil prices rose more than 2% on Monday as US crude inventories fell and winter fuel demand increased due to a severe snowstorm in the US North-east. Brent crude rose 2.4% to $56.35 a barrel and US crude gained 2.6% to $53.55 a barrel. A recent drawdown of 2.3 million barrels in US crude stocks is expected to continue, with analysts predicting a weekly decline. This increase in demand and reduced supply led to a nearly 8% gain in oil prices in January.

site_title: The Closet Lover: from hobby to four retail stores in Singapore
summary: The Closet Lover, a Singaporean clothing blogshop, has expanded from a hobby to four retail stores in Singapore and two overseas in Malaysia and Cambodia. The company, founded by sisters Brianna and Bertilla Wong in 2007, initially generated $3,000 in savings and grew into a profitable business with 7-15% profit margins. Despite the challenges of the pandemic, the sisters prioritized staff health and paused operations for a month. With the expansion of retail stores, The Closet Lover aims to improve its omnichannel experience and strengthen its community.

site_title: Sheng Siong was already there before ESG became a buzzword
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a Singapore-based supermarket chain operator, will reward its over 3,000 employees with bonuses of up to 16 months, contrary to recent media reports. The company stated in a filing that it has been rewarding staff with bonuses since 2007, before going public in 2011, and has no change in its policies. This move highlights the supermarket operator's long-standing commitment to its employees, predating the current ESG buzzword trend.

site_title: Bringing bags of CNY cheer to the elderly
summary: Standard Chartered Bank (Singapore) volunteers packed and distributed 6,700 festive bags to senior citizens and their families during the Community Chest's Fu Dai initiative, supporting SG Cares and timed with Chinese New Year festivities. The event, now in its eighth year, provided essential household and food items to those in need. Key figures, including the CEO and Minister for Social and Family Development, participated in the event, highlighting the importance of community support and giving back. The initiative has evolved to meet community needs, especially in the face of the pandemic.

site_title: Google closing in-house Stadia video game studio
summary: Google is closing its in-house Stadia video game studio, shifting the focus of exclusive titles to outside developers. Launched in 2019, Stadia aimed to provide console-quality games through cloud-hosted access. The decision marks a significant shift for the service, which has been struggling to gain traction in the market. The closure of the in-house studio will allow Google to outsource game development, potentially reviving the service.

site_title: 'Black Panther' TV series in development for Disney+
summary: Disney is developing a "Black Panther" television series set in the fictional African kingdom of Wakanda, as part of a five-year content deal with director Ryan Coogler. The series follows the global success of the 2018 film starring Chadwick Boseman, which grossed over $1 billion worldwide and became the first comic book movie to be nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars. Coogler is overseeing the development of multiple projects for Disney+, including the untitled Wakanda series, which will be released on the streaming service in the coming years.

site_title: Opec+ sees almost full compliance with agreed January oil-supply cuts
summary: Opec+ reported almost full compliance with its agreed January oil-supply cuts, with 99% of the 7.2 million barrels per day target met. Implementation was at 103% among Opec members and 93% among non-Opec partners. The group will maintain output unchanged in February and March, with Saudi Arabia pledging a unilateral cut of 1 million barrels per day. Opec+ will review its strategy at a meeting in early March, where no policy changes are expected.

site_title: EU calls Apple tax ruling 'contradictory reasoning'
summary: The European Union is appealing a court ruling that found Apple's Irish units weren't liable for a 13 billion-euro tax bill, citing "contradictory reasoning" in the lower court's decision. The EU claims judges improperly conflated Apple's lack of employees at two Irish units and its level of responsibility for intellectual property on iPhone and iPad sales across Europe. The EU's determination to challenge the ruling shows its continued push to close tax loopholes and target multinational firms.

site_title: Hainan Airlines may draw new investors despite bankruptcy filing: analysts
summary: Hainan Airlines, China's largest non-state-owned carrier, may attract new investors despite filing for bankruptcy and facing financial woes due to the pandemic. The airline's strong route network, high brand value, and experienced management team are seen as attractive factors. Analysts believe Hainan Airlines will continue to operate, but may change ownership. The airline expects a significant net loss of 58-65 billion yuan for 2020, with impairments of 46 billion yuan. HNA units will negotiate to bring in strategic investors this year.

site_title: Evergrande unit gains most in two weeks after buying rival
summary: Evergrande Group's property services unit surged 13.5% in Hong Kong trading after buying rival Ningbo Yatai Hotel Property Services Co for 1.5 billion yuan. The acquisition aims to increase profit by 50% this year and become the country's largest property manager. The deal will add 940 projects serving two million homeowners to its portfolio, increasing its area under management to over 380 million sq m. The move is seen as a reliable source of cash for debt-saddled Evergrande, which faces pressure to lower leverage under new requirements.

site_title: Covid-19: How close is the light at the end of the tunnel?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is showing signs of rapid progress, despite initial slow vaccination rates. The UK has already seen a significant drop in hospital admissions and deaths, with vaccination efforts expected to reduce deaths by two-thirds by the end of February and 85% by March. The vaccines are most effective in protecting vulnerable populations, such as the elderly, and have the potential to prevent two-thirds of deaths. However, the pace of progress will be slow until a large percentage of the population is vaccinated, and social distancing measures are still necessary to suppress the virus.

site_title: New digital solutions available under 'Start Digital' initiative
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) and Enterprise Singapore (ESG) have launched the "Start Digital" initiative, a suite of digital collaboration solutions for companies to improve remote work and digital marketing. The initiative, launched in 2019, aims to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) access digital tools at competitive prices. Over 30,000 SMEs have signed up for the program, with adoption rates doubling in 2020. Digital solutions include digital collaboration tools, social media advertisement templates, and invoice management with e-payments, offering businesses a more targeted approach to digital marketing and transactions.

site_title: US hotels try to woo guests with rooms that look like Netflix sets
summary: The 21C hotel in Lexington, Kentucky, has designed a room inspired by the Netflix series "The Queen's Gambit" to attract guests. The room, called the Harmon Room, features retro-inspired furnishings, a chess board, and local products, and is priced at $220 per night. The hotel's marketing effort aims to regenerate tourism in the city, which saw a decline in revenue due to the pandemic. The project was a collaborative effort between the hotel and local businesses, and its success may inspire other destinations to create similar initiatives.

site_title: Swiss franc drops to 2-month low
summary: The Swiss franc dropped to a 2-month low against the US dollar, falling 0.5% to 0.8964 francs per US dollar. The US dollar rose 0.2% against the euro, while the Japanese yen weakened to an 11-week low of 104.95 yen per US dollar. The US dollar's resilience is attributed to growth and vaccination favoring the US, while a weaker euro contributed to the franc's underperformance.

site_title: BOE to release results of study on negative interest rates
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) is set to release the results of a study on negative interest rates, a policy that could stimulate the UK economy but has concerns from banks. Economists expect the BOE to consider negative rates as a tool but stop short of implementing them for now. A decision on monetary policy is due on February 4, with most economists surveyed expecting the key rate to remain at or above 0.1% until the middle of 2023. The BOE's asset purchase programme and bond-buying plan are seen as key tools for stimulating the economy, and investors do not expect negative rates to arrive for at least a year.

site_title: Myanmar coup may see investors exit; currency may weaken: analysts
summary: Myanmar's military coup may lead to investors exiting the country and weakening its currency, negatively impacting Singapore-listed companies with a presence there, according to analysts. The disruption of phone and internet connections has already affected businesses. Phillip Securities analyst Tan Hui Jie warns that the country's business environment will deteriorate, causing investors to flee and potentially weakening the currency. This could have a negative impact on companies operating in Myanmar.

site_title: Australia in hydrogen tech push beyond fuel production
summary: Australia is launching 13 hydrogen technology clusters nationwide to develop and commercialize hydrogen production, storage, and distribution. The government has committed over A$500 million to support the development of a hydrogen industry, aiming to produce clean hydrogen at under A$2 per kilogram. This will enable the use of hydrogen in the domestic energy mix, reducing energy prices and ensuring energy security. The goal is to create a competitive industry that can also be exported, with the potential to play a significant role in cutting carbon emissions.

site_title: JAL forecasts record loss as Covid surge dampens travel demand
summary: Japan Airlines (JAL) has revised its full-year forecast to a record operating loss of 420 billion yen ($5.3 billion) due to a surge in coronavirus infections dampening domestic travel demand. This is worse than its previous forecast of 330-380 billion yen and exceeds analysts' average estimate of 338.8 billion yen. The airline's revised forecast is a significant decline from its previous estimate, highlighting the ongoing challenges posed by the pandemic to the airline industry.

site_title: Growth in China's home prices to cool in 2021
summary: China's home prices are expected to rise at a slower pace in 2021, with average growth estimated at 3.3%, down from 4.9% in 2020. Sales are forecast to remain steady, driven by bigger cities, while smaller cities and stringent lending regulations will curb demand. Housing transactions are expected to be flat, and investments are estimated to rise 6.4% this year. Regulators have tightened controls on the sector, including borrowing caps and transaction restrictions, to tackle rising debt risks and maintain market stability.

site_title: CoAssets in the crosshairs of MAS, CAD on 'suspected misconduct'
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) are investigating CoAssets Group, a fintech company, for suspected misconduct. CA Funding, a crowdfunding platform arm of CoAssets, has faced regulatory issues since 2020, including lapses in credit assessment and inadequate disclosure to investors. MAS has returned investors' monies and is monitoring CA Funding's business cessation plan. Industry experts predict that this case may lead to increased regulation and scrutiny of crowdfunding platforms, but they believe it will not hinder fintech development.

site_title: Driving productivity using remote working
summary: Singapore may adopt a more aggressive policy to support better adoption of remote working and unleash its benefits. A potential remote workforce of up to 45% across all sectors is expected, with many employers opting for hybrid arrangements. The government could provide incentives and deductions for companies to offer mental health support and standardized deductions for home office expenses. Despite some support measures, the limited assistance may not encourage or optimize remote working setups, leaving untapped growth and productivity potential.

site_title: Singapore seeking frontier firms for 'Manufacturing 2030'
summary: Singapore aims to attract frontier manufacturing companies to secure a niche in global value chains, with a 10-year "Manufacturing 2030" plan to grow the sector by 50% to S$106 billion. The plan involves investing in the manufacturing ecosystem, building research capabilities, and promoting Industry 4.0 adoption. Companies like Illumina, which has set up a 36,000-square-metre facility in Woodlands, will be targeted to showcase Singapore's capabilities. The government will also invest S$25 billion in research and development, and establish centers for innovation and Industry 4.0 technologies.

site_title: Microsoft talks up Bing's prospects as Google eyes Australia exit
summary: Microsoft is confident its search tool Bing can fill the gap in Australia if Google pulls its search function over required payments to media outlets. Australia's laws require Google and Facebook to negotiate payments to domestic media outlets whose content links drive traffic to their platforms. Google has threatened to withdraw its search engine if the regulations go ahead, but Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella has spoken with Prime Minister Scott Morrison about expanding Bing's presence. Microsoft is ready to grow its search tool's presence in Australia if Google exits.

site_title: Tribal Worldwide launches programme for design SMEs as part of SkillsFuture initiative
summary: Tribal Worldwide, a digital agency, has launched the SkillsFuture Queen Bee initiative, a transformational skills development programme for Singapore's design SMEs. The 12-month programme, in partnership with DesignSingapore Council and SkillsFuture Singapore, aims to support 30 SMEs in identifying capability gaps and accessing government funding solutions. The initiative includes training for design talent and leaders, as well as a curated skills development framework, to equip them with holistic experience design solutions.

site_title: Ex-Googler turns virtual gifting into huge success
summary: Kuaishou Technology, a Chinese live-streaming platform, has raised US$5.4 billion in its initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong, the largest Internet IPO since Uber in 2019. The platform, founded by ex-Googler Su Hua and Cheng Yixiao, has become the biggest live-streaming platform for virtual gifts, with more paying monthly users than any other in the world. The company's success is attributed to its focus on attention and engagement, with viewers spending an average of 90 minutes on the platform daily. Kuaishou's IPO is poised to create at least four billionaires and valued at US$15 billion.

site_title: Push to go electric could wipe out Japan's affordable microcars
summary: Japan's popular "kei" cars, known for their affordability and small engines, face a potential threat as the country aims to go electric by 2050. The government plans to ban petrol-only vehicles by the mid-2030s, which could lead to a price increase of up to $25,400 for kei cars, making them less affordable for buyers. The kei category makes up about a third of new domestic automobile sales, with 1.7 million units sold last year, and is a necessity for rural residents who rely on them for transportation.
