site_title: Singapore stock market up in January on investor optimism
summary: Singapore's stock market advanced 3% in January, driven by investor optimism over Covid-19 vaccine development and the global economy's recovery. The total market capitalisation of 687 listed stocks rose to S$838.1 billion, with advancers outnumbering decliners 339 to 188. This marks a significant increase from the end-December value of S$814.1 billion. The rally is expected to continue ahead of GDP data, with key market players such as NTT DC Reit's public offer and OCBC's new CEO.

site_title: S-E Asia private equity market set for growth but exits challenging
summary: S-E Asia's private equity market is poised for growth due to the region's under-investment and long-term potential. However, leaders agree that valuations are a concern and exits are challenging. The market's resilience is attributed to Covid-19's impact, offering opportunities in deal-making, fundraisings, and exits. Despite growth prospects, concerns remain over the timing of exits and valuations.

site_title: Razer to create 1,000 roles for new Asean HQ at one-north
summary: Razer, a gaming hardware and fintech firm, plans to hire approximately 1,000 positions for its new South-east Asia headquarters at one-north in Singapore. The company's CEO, Tan Min-Liang, announced the decision in a LinkedIn post. The new headquarters, expected to be ready in the second quarter of this year, will have 19,300 square meters of office space and feature Razer's Chroma lighting technology. The hiring process details, including the type of positions and timeline, are unclear. The company first announced plans for the regional headquarters in December 2018.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: BOUSTEAD Projects has agreed to acquire a 49% stake in two industrial land lots in Vietnam for 158.8 billion dong (S$9.2 million). The acquisition is funded with existing cash resources and aligns with the group's strategies of growing its income-yielding leasehold portfolio and expanding regionally. UOB Kay Hian is launching Securitised Token Offerings (STOs) in collaboration with technology company ECXX Global, and CICT has issued HK$713 million of fixed-rate notes due Feb 1, 2033.

site_title: Latest rules on electronic transactions designed to help businesses save costs
summary: Singapore's Parliament passed the Electronic Transactions (Amendment) Bill, aimed at reducing costs for businesses by promoting the use of electronic transferable records. The bill is designed to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) digitalise sustainably and effectively. Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran emphasized that businesses must choose to adopt ETRs, and it is ultimately their responsibility to do so. The bill's passage is seen as a step towards digitalization in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The Electronic Transactions (Amendment) Bill, which was passed in Parliament yesterday will help businesses significantly reduce costs but it is ultimately up to businesses to choose if they adopt the use of electronic transferable records (ETRs) said Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran at the closing speech of his second reading of the bill.

site_title: Mizuho posts 19.4% rise in Q3 profit
summary: Mizuho Financial Group Inc, Japan's third-largest lender by assets, reported a 19.4% rise in third-quarter net profit to 138.9 billion yen, beating analyst estimates. The lender booked smaller-than-expected credit costs despite the coronavirus outbreak, exceeding its full-year profit target. Mizuho attributed the better-than-expected performance to government and central bank efforts to prop up struggling firms, resulting in a 20.8% drop in bankruptcies. The bank's rival Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group Inc is scheduled to announce third-quarter earnings on Tuesday.

site_title: Myanmar economy suffers another setback with military coup
summary: Myanmar's economy suffered another setback with a military coup on Monday, dealing a blow to a country already struggling with the Covid-19 pandemic. The military seized power in Naypyidaw and declared a year-long state of emergency, with little immediate impact in Yangon. The coup marks the latest challenge to Myanmar's economy, which was already facing significant difficulties. The international community has largely remained calm, with ASEAN agreeing that the election, scheduled for later this year, is not a priority. The country's economic future remains uncertain.

site_title: SPH and Temasek to merge MICE units
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) and Temasek have agreed to merge their MICE (meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibitions) subsidiaries, SingEx Holdings and Sphere Exhibits, forming SingEx-Sphere Holdings. Temasek will own 60% of the merged entity, while SPH will own 40%. The merged entity aims to become a regional MICE market leader for hybrid events, with a combined portfolio of events management, venue, and consultancy businesses. The transaction value is S$24.4 million, with a pro forma book value of S$12 million.

site_title: Norway's wealth fund ditches firms over tax transparency
summary: Norway's $1.3 trillion wealth fund, the world's largest, has sold out of seven companies due to "aggressive tax planning" and lack of transparency. Fund CEO Nicolai Tangen stated that more such moves are likely in the future. The move is in line with the fund's 2017 "expectation document" on tax transparency, which aims to have companies pay tax where value creation takes place. Tangen emphasized the importance of transparency in tax disclosure, stating that companies should disclose their tax situation and practices.

site_title: India to set up bank to manage record levels of soured debt
summary: India plans to set up a company to manage bad debt for banks, which is expected to reach record levels this year due to the economic fallout of the coronavirus. The firm will hold problem loans for banks, allowing them to be sold to investors at a reduced price. The Reserve Bank of India expects non-performing assets to rise to 13.5% of total advances by the end of September, the worst since 1999. The government also plans to pump 200 billion rupees into state-run lenders and privatize two state lenders and a state-run insurance firm to boost financial stability.

site_title: London bankers face location limbo as ECB targets Brexit moves
summary: Global banks and their employees face uncertainty as Brexit continues to impact relocation plans. Despite years of planning, European authorities are granting banks temporary flexibility due to the ongoing pandemic, but regulators are still pressuring banks to execute relocation plans. The European Central Bank aims to reduce banks' reliance on London for risk and liquidity management, while regulators are checking whether banks' entities on the continent are fully operational and adequately staffed. Some bankers expect regulators to require relocation, despite Covid travel restrictions, and traders are refusing to move overseas for personal reasons.

site_title: Biden eyes climate market legacy with Brussels, Beijing
summary: US President Joe Biden is prioritizing his climate change legacy, signing executive orders to rejoin the Paris climate agreement and review environmental standards. He plans to propose economic recovery legislation with substantial green energy investment and host a US-hosted Earth Day Summit in April to persuade major emitters to strengthen their commitments. Biden has appointed John Kerry as US Special Envoy on climate change, who will push for rapid action on the agenda, including phasing out coal five times faster and increasing renewable energy six times faster. This move aims to create a global carbon trading hub linking Europe, Asia-Pacific, and the Americas, a potentially game-changing development in the fight against global warming.

site_title: Billionaire Li Shufu lays groundwork for his next move into Big Tech
summary: Chinese billionaire Li Shufu's Zhejiang Geely Holding Group has forged major collaboration pacts with Baidu, Foxconn, and Faraday Future, solidifying its presence in the car industry. Geely now targets Big Tech, following a string of agreements with companies like Apple and Tencent Holdings. This move signals Li Shufu's expansion into the tech sector, potentially positioning Geely as a significant player in the industry. The company's next move remains to be seen, but its recent partnerships suggest a significant shift in its business strategy.

site_title: Factories give mixed showing as pandemic's impact lingers
summary: Global manufacturing activity remained resilient in January, but some countries faced challenges due to a resurgence in coronavirus infections and lockdowns. Factory activity accelerated in major chip exporters South Korea and Taiwan, while China's manufacturing activity expanded at the slowest pace in seven months. In contrast, Japan's factory activity slipped into contraction due to a new state of emergency. The mixed showing underscores the fragile and uneven nature of the economic recovery.

site_title: US economic growth to hit 4.6% in 2021
summary: The US economy is expected to rebound to 4.6% growth in 2021 from a 3.5% contraction in 2020, driven by resuming business activity and coronavirus rescue spending, according to the Congressional Budget Office. However, growth is forecast to taper off to below 2% by the end of the decade.

site_title: The Reef at King's Dock sells over 90% of 300 units
summary: Mapletree Investments and Keppel Land announced that 280 out of 300 residential units at The Reef at King's Dock were sold over a weekend launch in January. Prices ranged from S$2,000 to S$2,800 per square foot, with an average price of S$2,330 psf.

site_title: Psychedelic hues of Tokyo's kawaii cafe doused by pandemic
summary: Kawaii Monster Cafe in Tokyo, a popular destination for kawaii pop culture, has shut down due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The cafe, which drew international celebrities like Kim Kardashian and Dua Lipa, lost business when overseas clients disappeared due to border restrictions. The cafe had hoped to capitalize on demand during the 2020 Olympics but ultimately decided to let its lease expire. With the situation uncertain, the cafe's manager cited difficulties in keeping the business going without knowing how long the pandemic would last. The cafe's closure marks the end of its five-year run.

site_title: Some ex-Bush officials leave Republican Party, citing Trump cult
summary: Dozens of former George W. Bush administration officials are leaving the Republican Party due to its failure to disown Donald Trump after the US Capitol storming. The officials, including some who held high-ranking positions, say they can no longer recognize the party they served. Many have ended membership, let it lapse, or registered as independents. The defection is a sign of the party's intra-party conflict, with moderate Republicans and independents at odds over Trump's legacy. The party faces a struggle to win national elections without the support of both groups.

site_title: SPACs eye Asia as next hunting ground for takeover targets
summary: Special-purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) are expanding their reach to Asia, with funds and financiers leveraging their expertise in US capital markets to identify takeover targets. A record 248 SPACs debuted in 2020, raising nearly $83 billion, and at least 93 have already begun trading this year. With trillions of dollars in stimulus flooding into the global economy, SPACs are racing against time to identify targets before their 24-month post-initial public offering expiration dates. The region's understanding of both Asian companies and US capital markets is driving the trend, with many SPACs seeking quality potential companies to merge with.

site_title: Millennials are changing luxury real estate market
summary: Millennials, born 1981-1996, are changing the luxury real estate market with their tech-savvy and sustainable values. At 38% of US home buyers, they represent the largest share, with many opting for multimillion-dollar luxury homes. This generation's preference for high-end properties is driven by their desire for a well-rounded lifestyle, with features like walkability, nature, and a quality of life. As a result, luxury home prices are expected to rise, with 63% of Sotheby's affiliates predicting growth over the next three years.

site_title: Brokerage curbs push Reddit-driven traders to chase silver lining elsewhere
summary: Silver prices surged to a seven-month high after a Reddit-driven rally, with retail sites for coins and bars overwhelmed by demand. The frenzy, similar to the GameStop Corp stock rally, was fueled by a call on the r/wallstreetbets forum to engage in a "short squeeze". Analysts warn that the speculative rush is a dangerous game, as brokerages curb trading to prevent further price volatility.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss for the second half. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC are deepening cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Creditors vote in favour of Temasek-backed plan for Pacific International Lines' debt revamp
summary: Creditors of Pacific International Lines (PIL) have voted in favor of a debt restructuring plan backed by Temasek Holdings' Heliconia Capital Management. The plan, worth US$600 million, will see Heliconia become the majority shareholder and the family of executive chairman Teo Siong Seng's stakes diluted to under 15%. Creditors approved the scheme of arrangement by a simple majority, representing at least 75% in value of each class of creditors present and voting. The plan aims to recalibrate PIL's capital structure for long-term sustainability.

site_title: Pacific International Lines' debt restructuring plan approved by creditors
summary: Pacific International Lines' debt restructuring plan has been approved by creditors, with a majority voting in favor of the plan bankrolled by Heliconia Capital Management. The plan, which will be sanctioned by the court, will see Heliconia become the majority shareholder in PIL, while the family of executive chairman Teo Siong Seng's stakes will be diluted to under 15%. The creditors' approval is seen as a significant victory for PIL, preventing liquidation and allowing the company to continue operating.

site_title: AIG pays US$12m fine in NY pension transfer probe
summary: American International Group (AIG) agreed to pay a US$12 million fine to settle charges of conducting life insurance business in New York without a licence. The settlement resolves a probe by the New York State Department of Financial Services, which found AIG's American General Life Insurance Company entered into large-scale deals involving corporate pension plans between 2014 and 2019 without proper licensing. This is the second settlement in the probe, with the first fine paid earlier in 2021. The fine is for violating New York's insurance laws.

site_title: High-rise offices lose lustre as Japan works at home
summary: Japan's decades-long love affair with high-rise office towers is fading as the pandemic shifts work styles and strains company finances. Companies like Dentsu Group Inc, Nippon Express Co, and Avex Inc are considering selling their Tokyo headquarters due to financial pressures. This trend marks a shift away from status-symbol office buildings, where companies once took great pride in owning their own buildings. The pandemic's impact on Japan's work culture is changing the way companies approach office space, leading to a decline in the value and appeal of high-rise offices.

site_title: US manufacturing remains robust while price pressures build
summary: US manufacturing remains robust, with the Institute for Supply Management's gauge of factory activity easing to 58.7 in January, still above 50, indicating expansion. Despite supply chain disruptions and lean inventories, production growth remains supported by solid demand. Price pressures build, driven by transportation and shipping costs, and producer constraints such as labor shortages.

site_title: Inspired by Monet
summary: An 11-year-old Singaporean artist, Liu Ruoran, was supported by the Business Times Budding Artists Fund to attend art classes after her family couldn't afford them. Inspired by Claude Monet's Impressionist style, Liu created abstract artworks capturing her emotions and thoughts. Her artwork "Remedy" is part of an online auction benefiting three charities, including the Muscular Dystrophy Association and the SOTA Endowment Fund, with all proceeds going to support financially-disadvantaged youths and those with muscular dystrophy. The online auction ends on February 8, 2021.

images.alt_text: Remedy is a vivid acrylic-on-canvas abstract painting (90cm by 60cm) by 11-year-old Liu Ruoran.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's tourism arrivals and receipts are expected to remain weak in 2021 due to ongoing COVID-19 concerns. The Singapore Tourism Board attributed this to the need for mass leisure travel and traveler confidence to return. Meanwhile, MAS and CAD launched an investigation into CoAssets Group for possible offenses under the Penal Code and Securities and Futures Act. The Trade and Industry Minister emphasized the cutting-edge nature of next-gen manufacturing jobs. DBS plans to double its recruitment of financial advisers, while Razer aims to hire over 1,000 roles for its new South-east Asia HQ.

site_title: Digital connectivity: a catalyst for growth, inclusion, prosperity
summary: Digital connectivity is the key to building sustainable communities, driving economic growth, and fostering inclusion. The Asia-Pacific region is expected to have 3 billion mobile subscribers by 2025, transforming sectors and industries reliant on connectivity. However, challenges in digital infrastructure rollout hinder progress. Companies are struggling to adapt to the changing landscape, with issues like layoffs and climate investing. Meanwhile, global events like the EU-China summit and US foreign policy shifts continue to shape the world. As digital connectivity becomes increasingly crucial, its accessibility, affordability, and sustainability will be key to its widespread adoption.

site_title: Playboy agrees to buy sexual wellness chain Lovers
summary: Playboy Enterprises has agreed to acquire Lovers, a sexual wellness chain, for around $25 million. The deal is part of Playboy's shift towards leveraging its famous logo to build a consumer products brand, following the shutdown of its magazine last year. Lovers operates 41 stores in five US states and will sell Playboy's sexual wellness products upon closing. The acquisition is expected to add $45 million in revenue over the next year, and Playboy aims to expand into the sexual wellness space, streetwear apparel, and men's grooming.

site_title: STB sees tourism arrivals and receipts remaining weak in 2021
summary: Singapore's tourism arrivals and receipts are expected to remain weak in 2021, with visitor arrivals falling 85.7% year-on-year to 2.7 million in 2020. Despite this, the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) remains confident in the country's position as a safe and attractive destination. The STB will continue to support tourism businesses and innovate to meet evolving consumer needs once cross-border travel resumes. The government has also launched initiatives such as the SingapoRediscovers campaign and the SingapoRediscovers Vouchers scheme to boost domestic demand and support local jobs.

site_title: Bill introduces stiffer penalties for unauthorised use of contact-tracing data
summary: Singapore Parliament has introduced a Bill to enhance penalties for the unauthorized use of contact-tracing data, making it punishable with a fine of up to S$20,000 and up to two years of imprisonment. The Bill amends the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act, formalizing the government's earlier assurances that contact-tracing data can only be accessed for serious offenses. The data will be deleted after the pandemic ends, and public agencies will only use it for contact tracing, except in cases of criminal investigations or serious offenses.

site_title: 29 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: There were 29 new COVID-19 cases confirmed in Singapore on February 1, bringing the total to 59,565. All cases were imported, with some arriving from India, Britain, and Nigeria. A 36-year-old permanent resident who had previously tested negative and shown no symptoms was also reported as an imported case. The man had a low viral load and was classified as having likely past infection. 32 cases were discharged on Sunday, with 59,213 patients fully recovered and 44 remaining in hospital.

site_title: Foreign companies scramble to assess fall-out in Myanmar after coup
summary: Foreign companies, including Japanese retailer Aeon, South Korean trading firm Posco International, and Norway's Telenor, are assessing the fallout in Myanmar after a military coup. The coup ousted the democratically elected government of Aung San Suu Kyi, who was detained along with other leaders. Many companies, despite concerns over human rights, have invested in Myanmar due to its large population. Some firms, such as Kirin Holdings, are reassessing their operations, while others, like Telenor, have closed their offices due to disrupted business and safety concerns.

site_title: SGX unit to issue zero coupon guaranteed convertible bonds due 2024
summary: SGX Treasury I plans to issue zero coupon guaranteed convertible bonds due 2024, raising approximately 386 million Singapore dollars (240 million euros). The bonds, convertible into ordinary shares, will mature in 2024 and are guaranteed by SGX. 80% of proceeds will be used to refinance existing debt, while 20% will be for general corporate purposes. The deal, led by Credit Suisse and Morgan Stanley Asia, is conditional on Monetary Authority of Singapore approval and follows recent issuers like Singapore Airlines and Banyan Tree Holdings.

site_title: India to boost farm credit and infrastructure to spur output
summary: India's Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced measures to boost farm credit and infrastructure, aiming for 16.5 trillion rupees (S$300 billion) in farm loans in the next fiscal year. The government also plans to impose additional taxes on imports to finance rural infrastructure facilities. The measures aim to address issues related to low productivity in agriculture and provide relief to farmers, who have seen depressed crop prices due to bumper production. The initiatives are expected to boost the rural economy and have a ripple effect on other sectors.

site_title: Singapore can vaccinate about 80,000 a day when all 40 centres are up
summary: Singapore is set to immunize around 80,000 individuals daily once all 40 Covid-19 vaccination centers are operational, according to Senior Minister of State for Health Janil Puthucheary. The country aims to vaccinate all Singaporeans and long-term residents by the end of 2021, despite some uncertainty in the take-up rate. The government prioritizes vaccinations for healthcare and frontline workers, as well as senior citizens, and will consider allowing individuals to receive early vaccination when there is greater certainty in vaccine supply.

site_title: US: Wall St advances as small-time traders turn to silver
summary: US stocks rose on Monday as retail traders turned to silver, driving up mining stocks and boosting the Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite. The Dow Jones gained 102.99 points, the S&P 500 rose 24.19 points, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 128.37 points. Silver miners surged between 5.5% and 35% after the metal broke above $30 an ounce for the first time since 2013. The market's recovery was seen as a relief rally after the previous week's steep sell-off, with investors awaiting earnings reports from Amazon and Alphabet.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound in early deals
summary: European stock markets rebounded on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.7%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 rising 1.1%, and Paris's CAC 40 adding almost 1%. The gains came after last week's heavy losses, as bargain-buyers entered the market. However, traders remain cautious due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and vaccination programme issues.

site_title: South Korean tech firms shake up Japan's storied manga industry
summary: Two South Korean tech companies, Kakao Corp and Naver Corp, have dominated Japan's manga industry through mobile apps, Piccoma and Line Manga. These apps have seen a surge in popularity during the pandemic, with Piccoma's third-quarter transaction volumes tripling to 11.6 billion yen and Line Manga's jumping by a third to 8.2 billion yen. The apps' success can be attributed to their "zero yen if you wait" revenue model, where users pay to read ahead of serialized manga tales. This shift has expanded the manga fanbase to a new generation of readers, with many preferring the convenience of mobile apps over traditional print manga.

site_title: EU calls US$15.8b Apple tax ruling 'contradictory'
summary: The European Union has appealed a $15.8 billion tax ruling in favor of Apple, citing "contradictory reasoning" by judges. The EU argues that the ruling improperly conflated Apple's lack of employees at Irish units with the company's level of responsibility for intellectual property sales across Europe. The EU is seeking to overturn the ruling, which was a setback to Commissioner Margrethe Vestager's probes of national tax rulings that she says were an illegal subsidy for multinational firms. The EU may also consider a tax on revenue generated by digital companies.

site_title: S$13.8b spent by government on Covid-19 response operations
summary: The Singapore government allocated S$13.8 billion for Covid-19 response operations in the 2020 budget, including S$10 billion for medical and emergency operations, and S$2.9 billion for quarantine and dedicated stay-home notice facilities. The funds were also used to secure medical supplies, manage the outbreak in dormitories, and support affected individuals and businesses. This represents 14% of the total S$97.3 billion committed to supporting the economy and society in fighting the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The sum was used to secure critical medical and emergency supplies such as personal protective equipment.

site_title: Kuaishou trades at twice IPO price in gray market
summary: Kuaishou Technology's Hong Kong shares traded at HK$250, more than double the listing price of HK$115, in gray-market trading before its Friday debut. This is a significant premium and indicates high demand for the world's biggest internet IPO in two years. The IPO, valued at US$60.9 billion, is expected to be the third-best debut for an IPO over US$1 billion in Hong Kong on record. Retail buyers will be able to trade through a similar channel a day before Kuaishou begins trading on Friday.

site_title: Brokers' take: CDLHT downgraded to 'hold', 'neutral' as it trades closer to long-term mean
summary: Analysts from CGS-CIMB and RHB downgraded CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) to "hold" and "neutral" respectively, citing the stapled group's trading closer to its long-term mean. DBS maintained its "buy" call, with a lowered target price of S$1.35, as it expects a synchronised recovery in travel demand. CDLHT's FY2020 distribution per unit (DPU) exceeded expectations, and the group has undistributed capital to buffer the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Mumbai's suburban train services restored after 11 months
summary: Mumbai's suburban train services have been restored after 11 months, coinciding with the easing of coronavirus restrictions. The move aims to ease the travel burden on commuters, with regular services to be allowed during non-peak hours. Prior to the shutdown, an average of eight million people used the train services daily. The restoration comes as India has seen a significant dip in daily COVID-19 cases, with 11,427 new cases reported on Monday. The city has recorded over 300,000 cases and 11,000 deaths since March.

site_title: Singapore stocks end first trading day of the week in the red, STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 2,896.32 on its first trading day of February, with 2.23 billion securities worth S$1.44 billion changing hands. The decline was attributed to cautious investor sentiment following a retreat on Wall Street and the declaration of a year-long state of emergency in Myanmar. Despite this, Axi's chief strategist Stephen Innes argued that a global economic recovery remains intact, with the US rollout of Covid-19 vaccines and new fiscal stimulus.

site_title: SPH and Temasek to merge MICE subsidiaries
summary: SPH and Temasek have agreed to merge their MICE (meetings, incentives, conventions and exhibitions) subsidiaries, SingEx Holdings and Sphere Exhibits, to form SingEx-Sphere Holdings. Temasek will own 60% and SPH 40% of the merged entity, with a transaction value of S$24.4 million. The merged entity aims to be a regional MICE market leader, driving best-in-class solutions in events management, venue, and consultancy businesses.

site_title: Online retailer Asos to buy Topshop brand for S$538m
summary: Asos Plc agreed to purchase Topshop, along with other labels including Topman, Miss Selfridge, and HIIT, for £295 million (S$538 million) in an all-cash transaction. The move aims to expand Asos' customer base, particularly in the US and Europe, where Topshop has strong brand recognition. The purchase includes 30 million pounds of inventory and will result in the closure of all Topshop stores. This deal follows similar acquisitions by rival Boohoo Group Plc, which bought the Debenhams brand, further highlighting the trend of online fashion retailers buying up iconic brands.

site_title: Hot stock: iFast hits record-high after announcing participation in Hong Kong eMPF project
summary: iFast Corporation's shares hit a record-high of S$6.40, up 16.2% or S$0.89, following the announcement that PCCW Solutions won the tender for Hong Kong's eMPF platform. iFast will be the prime subcontractor for MPF scheme operation services, transformation services, and user delivery services. The company's participation in the project is subject to finalizing contractual details, with more information to be shared with shareholders in due course.

site_title: India to set up bad bank to manage record levels of soured debt
summary: India plans to set up a company to manage bad debt for banks, which is expected to reach record levels this year due to the economic fallout of the coronavirus. The firm will hold problem loans for banks, allowing them to be sold to investors at a reduced price. The Reserve Bank of India expects non-performing assets to rise to 13.5% of total advances by the end of September, the worst since 1999. The government also plans to pump 200 billion rupees into state-run lenders and privatize two state lenders and a state-run insurance firm.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 2.15% on Monday, driven by bargain-buying following last week's rout. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 28,892.86, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. The rally was fueled by hopes for fresh economic support measures from the Chinese government, following data showing growth in China's economic activity.

site_title: UK government to guarantee mortgages to help young buyers
summary: The UK government plans to introduce a mortgage guarantee programme to help young buyers secure mortgages with 5% deposits, up from the current 20-25% deposits. The programme will allow first-time buyers and current homeowners to purchase properties up to £600,000. The guarantee will be offered to lenders, making it easier for them to secure mortgages. The programme is expected to be announced in the upcoming budget and will start in April. This move aims to boost the housing market and help young people get onto the property ladder.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Outlook for 2021 and key investment themes to act on (Ep 89)
summary: BT Money Hacks episode 89 discusses investment themes for retail investors in 2021 and beyond, brought by Fidelity International. Fidelity's Asia-Pacific chief investment officer Paras Anand explains the differences in Asian economic strategy, steps for retail investors to act on, and key investment considerations in the 'new normal' Covid-19 era. The episode advises against timing the market and warns of false diversification. With relatively low yields and overpriced equities, investors are advised to wait for the market to cool or consider alternative investments, such as gold.

site_title: Fitch Solutions lowers Malaysia's GDP forecast as Covid-19 threatens to 'paralyse' healthcare
summary: Fitch Solutions has downgraded Malaysia's GDP forecast to 10% due to the surge in Covid-19 cases threatening to paralyze the country's healthcare system. The downgrade is attributed to muted private consumption, strained government finances, and reduced fiscal support. Malaysia has set a new record for Covid-19 cases and its healthcare capacity is nearing maximum capacity. The country has secured vaccines for 60% of its population, but a decline in GDP growth will further reduce funds for healthcare.

site_title: StanChart warns of flat income in 2021, recovery seen in 2022
summary: Standard Chartered reported a 40% decline in adjusted pre-tax profit in 2020, missing analyst estimates, due to restructuring charges and higher credit impairments. The bank expects little growth in 2021, with income in line with 2020, but projects a recovery in 2022. The bank has resumed cost-cutting efforts, including hundreds of job cuts, and expects restructuring charges of around $500 million over the next few years.

site_title: Crowd sourcing
summary: Jimmy Wales, co-founder of Wikipedia, believes that user communities can help tackle fake news and has built a "new type of social network" to address the issue. Wales, who is also passionate about Asian cuisine, acknowledges the rise of fake news, particularly during the US Capitol Hill riots and the COVID-19 pandemic. He notes that while there is a growing willingness to pay for quality journalism, local newspapers have largely disappeared, leaving a gap in the market for local news. Wales emphasizes the importance of high-quality sources and neutral presentation on Wikipedia, and criticizes social media platforms for amplifying sensational statements. He suggests that Wikipedia's reliance on small donations and its community-driven approach can serve as a model for other organizations. Despite the challenges, Wales remains optimistic about the future of journalism and Wikipedia, which is celebrating its 20th anniversary.

site_title: Volkswagen expects strong rebound in sales, deliveries in 2021
summary: Volkswagen expects strong sales and deliveries in 2021, despite a 45% drop in operating profit to €10.6 billion last year due to the pandemic. The company plans to maintain its dividend for 2020. Shares edged up 0.3% on the news, trading at €171.60. Volkswagen attributes its resilience to strategic decisions and containment of the pandemic's impact on its business.

site_title: SingapoRediscovers Vouchers open to tourism businesses of all sizes, but not eateries
summary: The SingapoRediscovers Vouchers (SRV) scheme, a $320 million tourism credit programme, has seen over half of its 402 participating businesses be hotels, with 37% being tours and 11% being attractions. The scheme does not target businesses by revenue range and is open to all tourism businesses, including smaller and less digitally-savvy operators. Eateries are not eligible for SRV credits, but can collaborate with other businesses to build eligible bundles or contribute deals to the wider campaign.

site_title: US securities regulator suspends trading in three more 'meme stocks'
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading in Marathon Group Corp, Affinity Beverage Group, and Sylios Corp from Friday to March 4 amid concerns of social media-driven market manipulation and artificial price influence. The suspensions are part of the SEC's efforts to address volatile trading in "meme stocks" following the GameStop surge and subsequent plunge. The regulator is investigating potential misconduct, including market manipulation, restricted buying, and short-selling practices, and cautions brokers to ensure compliance with investor protection rules.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close with healthy gains
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.20% on Thursday, helping to offset losses from the previous day, as investors welcomed the Federal Reserve's assurance of maintaining ultra-loose monetary policy. The Hang Seng Index reached 30,074.17, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.59%. The rally followed a 5-day winning streak for Singapore stocks and came despite US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Containers pile up at Myanmar ports as coup protests slow trade
summary: Thousands of striking truck drivers in Myanmar have slowed the delivery of imports, trapping cargo containers at ports and impacting global trade. About 90% of the city's 4,000 container-truck drivers have halted work, resulting in only 100 containers moving out of Yangon's four main ports daily. The disruptions, combined with a global container shortage, may exacerbate the issue and affect industries such as textiles and garments.

site_title: Myanmar junta's top diplomat in talks with Thailand, Indonesia
summary: Myanmar's junta foreign minister held talks with Thai and Indonesian diplomats, marking the first known face-to-face meetings between senior junta members and foreign governments. The meetings come as regional powers attempt to broker an end to three weeks of deadly unrest triggered by the military coup. The talks were proposed by Thailand, and no details were released on the discussions. Protests continue nationwide, with demonstrators demanding the release of ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi and calling for international condemnation of the junta.

site_title: Why that shot in the arm isn't just another jab
summary: Vaccination against COVID-19 is becoming increasingly important for personal and professional freedom, with some countries implementing "no jab, no job" policies and requiring vaccination proof for travel. Experts warn that those who refuse vaccination may face inconvenience, including limited travel options and job changes. However, consultants emphasize the need to handle situations sensitively and not discriminate against those with legitimate reasons for not being vaccinated. Despite growing vaccination efforts, vaccine hesitancy remains a challenge, with some individuals believing in conspiracy theories or worrying about side effects. To dispel hesitancy, experts advocate for transparency, clarity, and trust-building, highlighting the benefits and risks of vaccination.

site_title: UK will resist EU pressure on banks over clearing: BOE governor
summary: The Bank of England's governor, Andrew Bailey, stated that the UK will resist EU pressure to move trillions of euros in derivatives clearing from Britain to the EU after Brexit. Europe's top banks are being asked to justify why they should not shift clearing, following the UK's full departure from the EU's single market on December 31.

site_title: US bill to allow publishers to negotiate collectively with Facebook, Google
summary: US lawmakers plan to introduce a bill allowing smaller news organizations to negotiate collectively with Facebook and Google, addressing issues of unequal advertising revenue sharing. The legislation aims to boost sales in the struggling news industry, following similar efforts in Australia. Google has already agreed to a global deal with News Corp, while Facebook has fought publishers. The bill, similar to a 2019 proposal, would exempt only small publishers from antitrust scrutiny, enabling them to compare notes and negotiate more fairly.

site_title: Budget 2021 in the media
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021, released on February 19, 2021, introduced measures to support the country's economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. The budget allocated SGD 42.8 billion for various sectors, including SGD 5.4 billion for the healthcare sector and SGD 1.5 billion for the education sector. The government also announced a range of tax relief and incentives to boost economic growth and support vulnerable groups. The budget aimed to stimulate economic recovery and promote sustainable growth.

site_title: New CEO has tough job of reviving StarHub's fortune
summary: StarHub's new CEO, Nikhil Eapen, faces a challenging task in reviving the company's fortunes after a 15.2% decline in full-year net profit. The telco's consumer mobile segment, accounting for 36.4% of service revenue, continues to struggle with a 24.3% year-on-year decline in mobile service revenue and a 40,000 postpaid subscriber loss. However, the company's enterprise business, including cybersecurity and 5G services, has shown growth. Eapen aims to balance the consumer and enterprise segments, with a focus on digital transformation and new strategies such as "giga!" and "StarHub TV+". Analysts remain optimistic, citing potential for growth in the enterprise business and a possible bottoming out of the pandemic's impact.

site_title: Singapore firms hang on as Myanmar unrest escalates
summary: Singaporean firms operating in Myanmar are continuing to operate despite escalating unrest following the military coup, with some companies citing long-term opportunities and temporary nature of the crisis. Despite intermittent communications and port clearance issues, firms such as Asiatic Agricultural Industries, PeopleWorldwide Consulting, and Teck Huat & Company remain committed to the country, with some even conducting business as usual. The Singapore Business Federation hopes for a swift and peaceful resolution to minimize disruptions, while the Monetary Authority of Singapore has not found significant funds from Myanmar firms in local banks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher ahead of China markets reopen
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended higher, marking the seventh straight session of gains, ahead of the reopening of mainland markets after the Chinese New Year break. The Hang Seng index rose 1.10% to its highest close since June 2018, while the China Enterprises Index increased 1.60%. Optimism over global economic recovery lifted sentiment, with the Hang Seng Tech Index surging 2.34% and the Hang Seng sub-index tracking information technology firms climbing 1.88%.

site_title: Biden to discuss pandemic, economy and China in Friday G-7 meeting
summary: President Joe Biden will hold a virtual meeting with G-7 leaders on Friday to discuss the coronavirus pandemic, global economy, and China. The meeting aims to defeat the Covid-19 pandemic, rebuild the global economy, and address emerging infectious diseases. Biden will focus on vaccine production and distribution, as well as strengthening global competitiveness and updating economic rules to tackle challenges posed by China. The meeting also touches on climate change and the US economic stimulus package.

site_title: Region's private banks post strong performance in 2020 despite pandemic
summary: Private banks in the region reported strong performances in 2020, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Vincent Magnenat of Lombard Odier, Philip Kunz of HSBC Private Banking, Benjamin Cavalli of Credit Suisse Private Banking, and Steven Lo of Citi Private Bank shared their experiences. Key highlights include resilient fee income, assets under management growth, and profitability. The pandemic accelerated the adoption of digital technologies, enabling banks to maintain client relationships and provide services virtually. Banks emphasized the importance of personal relationships, bespoke investment expertise, and sustainability in their services.

site_title: French cyber agency reveals suspected Russian hacks
summary: France's national cybersecurity agency, ANSSI, has discovered a suspected Russian hack targeting several organizations that use Centreon monitoring software, including major French companies like EDF and Total. The hackers gained access to Centreon servers through a backdoor, similar to previous attacks attributed to the Sandworm group. The attack, which occurred from 2017 to 2020, may be linked to Russian intelligence, but its exact origin is unclear. The incident is reminiscent of a recent SolarWinds hack attributed to Russia, which compromised 18,000 customers worldwide.

site_title: Tougher delisting rules have little impact on Guoco Group's bid for Bermuda-registered GL
summary: Guoco Group's bid for Bermuda-registered GL Ltd. remains unchanged despite tougher voluntary delisting rules, which were introduced to protect minority investors. The offer, at S$0.70 per share, is 27% below GL's net asset value, and a wholly-owned unit of Guoco Group, which owns 73.67% of GL's shares, has irrevocably accepted the offer. The offeror plans to exercise its rights under Bermuda's Companies Act to effect a compulsory acquisition if it receives 90% valid acceptances or ends up holding 95% of the company.

site_title: Going places
summary: Samsonite International's president for Asia-Pacific and Middle East, Paul Melkebeke, discusses the company's efforts to stay focused on long-term goals despite the travel downturn caused by the pandemic. Melkebeke, who has spent his entire career with the company, says that staying in touch with customers through in-person interactions is crucial for understanding market trends and consumer needs. The company has seen a significant increase in e-commerce sales during the pandemic, but Melkebeke emphasizes that online shopping will not replace the importance of physical stores. Samsonite is also investing in innovation and sustainability, with products such as anti-microbial travel essentials and eco-friendly materials. Melkebeke believes that the company's diversified portfolio of brands and categories has helped it recover from the pandemic, and he is optimistic about the future, citing Asia's rapid recovery and the potential for "revenge travel" once travel restrictions are lifted.

site_title: US financial markets are closed on Monday in observance of Presidents Day
summary: US financial markets will be closed on Monday in observance of Presidents Day. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while Popiah king Sam Goi has made a mandatory offer for the rest of PSC at S$0.40 a share. In other news, traders are brushing off new Trump threats, and stocks in mining and healthcare sectors are seeing gains. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq have also reached fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: PR who returned from India among nine new Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: There were nine new Covid-19 cases confirmed in Singapore, bringing the total to 59,809, all of which were imported cases who had been placed on stay-home notice upon arrival. No community cases or cases from migrant workers' dormitories were reported.

site_title: Learjet's fall from luxe to loser reflects rising bar for swank
summary: Bombardier is ending production of the Learjet, a small private jet once associated with success and luxury, due to increased competition from larger and more lucrative models. Despite efforts to revamp the brand, including a new composite material jet, the Learjet failed to compete with rivals such as Embraer and Honda. The decision to halt production will save Bombardier $400 million annually and focus on larger private jets. The Learjet's decline reflects the rising bar for luxury transport, with top-of-the-line aircraft offering faster speeds and more amenities.

site_title: Sembcorp issues update on investments in Myanmar following military coup
summary: Sembcorp Industries is monitoring the situation in Myanmar following the military coup, with its two investments in the country remaining operational. The 225-megawatt gas-fired power plant in Mandalay continues to operate, and its employees are safe. The plant's net book value is US$57 million, with US$230 million of the project's loan outstanding. The industrial park development, announced in August 2020, has not yet commenced. Sembcorp will continue to monitor the situation and provide updates if there are material developments.

site_title: WHO mission member says 'don't rely' on US virus intelligence
summary: WHO mission member Dr. Peter Daszak expressed skepticism about US virus intelligence, stating "don't rely too much on US intel" after the US cast doubt on the transparency of the WHO mission to China. The mission concluded without finding the source of the virus, but members walked a diplomatic tightrope amid geopolitics. China warned against politicizing the issue, while the US urged a "robust" probe. The team agreed the virus likely originated from bats to an unknown animal species before transmitting to humans, contradicting the US theory of a lab experiment gone wrong.

site_title: Bitcoin nears US$50,000, wider adoption fuels record rally
summary: Bitcoin reached a record high of US$48,800, approaching US$50,000, as wider adoption fuels its record rally. The cryptocurrency is up 70% year-to-date, with major firms like BNY Mellon, Tesla, and BlackRock increasing their involvement. The Ontario Securities Commission approved the launch of the world's first bitcoin exchange-traded fund, and Miami is seeking to adopt bitcoin in its operations. This increased mainstream acceptance boosts bitcoin's ambitions towards mainstream finance, despite some banks remaining reluctant to engage.

site_title: Singapore Airlines revises aircraft delivery schedule with Airbus and Boeing
summary: Singapore Airlines has revised its aircraft delivery schedule with Airbus and Boeing, deferring over S$4 billion in capital expenditure between FY20/21 and FY22/23. The airline will spread out its aircraft delivery over a longer period, recalibrating its capacity introduction following the COVID-19 pandemic disruption. The revised total projected capex for FY20/21 stands at S$3.1 billion, down from S$5.3 billion before. CEO Goh Choon Phong said the agreements are key to navigating pandemic disruptions and aligning with the projected recovery trajectory for international air travel.

site_title: Prime Group: Stockpiling, shortages test supermarket's reflexes
summary: Singapore supermarket operator Prime Group reported a 15-25% sales increase during the pandemic, driven by stockpiling and shortages. The company faced "maximum-stress tests" in ensuring staff safety and managing operations. Prime leveraged its relationships with distributors to maintain supply and set up a group-buying platform. Meanwhile, its Mahota Commune retail concept saw a 20% increase in takings, with adapted food and beverage offerings. Despite challenges, the company remains optimistic about its future, with plans for menu fine-tuning and new product development.

site_title: Exploding fuel tanker ignites enormous fire on Afghanistan-Iran border
summary: A fuel tanker exploded at a border post in western Afghanistan on Saturday, setting off a massive fire that spread to over 100 other tankers. The cause of the explosion is unknown, and at least 17 people were injured. The blaze threatened to engulf hundreds of tankers, including those importing fuel and natural gas from Iran, which is crucial to Afghanistan's economy. The fire was contained, but the electricity supply from Iran was disconnected as a precaution, leaving the city of Herat without power.

site_title: Ousted Myanmar party demands release of Aung San Suu Kyi
summary: Myanmar's ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi and other National League for Democracy party leaders were detained in pre-dawn raids on Monday, following a military coup that triggered international condemnation and sanctions threats. The party demanded her immediate release and recognition of the confirmed result of the 2020 general election, which the NLD won in a landslide. US President Joe Biden led the global outcry, calling for a quick restoration of democracy and warning of sanctions. The military justified the seizure of power by alleging widespread voter fraud in the elections, and the United Nations Security Council was set to meet for an emergency meeting.

site_title: Branson-backed SPAC to take DNA-testing firm 23andMe public in US$3.5b deal
summary: Virgin Group-backed blank-cheque firm VG Acquisition is taking consumer DNA-testing firm 23andMe public in a US$3.5 billion deal, valuing the merged entity. 23andMe will receive US$759 million, including US$250 million from investors such as Sir Richard Branson and Anne Wojcicki. The deal will make 23andMe a publicly traded company, trading under the symbol "ME" on the New York Stock Exchange. This is the latest example of a celebrity-backed SPAC deal, following Virgin Galactic's 2019 IPO.

site_title: Business 'bubble' scheme put on ice
summary: Singapore's "Connect@Singapore" pilot plan to bring high-value business travelers into the country without quarantine has been delayed. The program, initially set to launch in mid- to late January, now faces uncertainty due to the discovery of infectious virus variants and recent aviation-linked Covid-19 cases. The Singapore Tourism Board has not yet selected operators for dedicated facilities, and the Ministry of Trade and Industry has not provided a specific timeline for the launch. Experts speculate that the delay may be a precautionary measure to ensure the scheme's safety, with some predicting a potential resumption in the coming months.

site_title: Japan's Dec household spending falls as recovery falters
summary: Japan's household spending fell 0.6% in December, marking the first year-on-year decline in three months, according to official data. The drop was attributed to weakening consumer sentiment, with demand for services such as travel and festive goods hurt by the Covid-19 crisis. The government's decision to extend a state of emergency in 10 areas, including Tokyo, has raised concerns about the country's economic recovery. The decline in spending comes as policymakers face a challenge in avoiding a sharp economic contraction.

site_title: Ant reaches agreement with China regulators on overhaul
summary: Ant Group, a fintech giant led by Jack Ma, has reached an agreement with Chinese regulators to restructure the company into a financial holding company, subject to capital requirements similar to banks. The plan, which may be announced before China's Lunar New Year holiday, would put all of Ant's businesses into the holding company. The move marks the first step in a lengthy overhaul process, expected to provide more regulatory clarity for Ant, but may force the company to slow its expansion pace.

site_title: PropNex to sell entire stake in property management arm PPMC
summary: PropNex Realty is selling its entire stake in property management arm PropNex Property Management Consultants (PPMC) for S$1,018,000. The disposal will allow the company to focus on its real estate agency business. PropNex owns 75% of PPMC, while a shareholder owns 25%. The sale will be paid in two tranches, with the first payment of S$814,400 due upon completion and the second payment of S$203,600 due 12 months later. The transaction is expected to have no material impact on PropNex's net tangible assets or earnings per share.

site_title: US housing market immune to pandemic, say analysts
summary: US housing market analysts predict a continued upward trend over the next two years, despite the pandemic. The US Case-Shiller house price index is forecast to rise 5.7% this year and 4.6% in 2022, driven by record low interest rates and pent-up demand. Analysts believe the housing market's immunity to the pandemic will continue, with only 15 of 34 predicting a slowdown. Strong demand, easy monetary policy, and changes in tastes and preferences are driving the market's growth, despite a shortage of supply and rising home prices.

site_title: 18 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore; 17 imported and one in the community
summary: Singapore reported 18 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 59,602. Of these, 17 were imported cases and one was in the community. The imported cases were from various countries including Canada, India, Indonesia, and the US. 16 of the cases were asymptomatic, and 59,286 patients have recovered. There were 44 patients in hospital, with 30 discharged and 210 still recovering in community facilities.

site_title: The beleaguered Games: Should the show go on, amid a pandemic?
summary: Olympics officials are planning to release "playbooks" outlining Covid-19 countermeasures for the postponed 2020 Games, despite Japan's current state of emergency and high infection rates. The Japanese government has declared a month-long state of emergency in Tokyo and is struggling to test the population, with only 52 out of every 1,000 people getting tested. The situation is deemed grim, with the nation's public health centres overwhelmed and many undetected cases likely. The Olympics are set to take place in July-August, raising concerns about the feasibility of holding the Games safely.

site_title: Seoul launches Covid tests for pets
summary: Seoul, South Korea has launched a coronavirus testing program for pets, specifically cats and dogs with fever, cough, or breathing difficulties after exposure to carriers. The program was prompted by the country's first reported animal Covid-19 case, a kitten. Tests will be conducted near the pet's home by a team of health workers, including a veterinarian. Positive results will require 14-day isolation at home, while owners with the virus will have their pets sent to separate kennels or catteries.

site_title: Yield-hungry investors chase industrial investments in Asia to record high
summary: Yield-hungry investors are chasing industrial and logistics investments in Asia to a record high, driven by e-commerce acceleration during the pandemic. Despite a challenging year for Asia property investments, the industrial and logistics sector has stood out as an area of relative stability and opportunity. Capital inflows to the sector have narrowed the yield spread with the office sector, with experts predicting continued growth and increasing investor allocations to logistics assets. The sector has attracted over $15 billion of new funds in 2020, and deal activity reached a record high in 2020, with four of the region's markets ranking in the top 10 biggest logistics markets globally.

site_title: Government will find ways to support all firms keen to upgrade
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing has pledged to support local companies aiming for growth, regardless of sector, as long as they desire to upgrade. The government will explore funding options, including the Enterprise Development Grant, and consider tax incentives for manufacturers. Industry experts suggest increased support for small and medium-sized enterprises, particularly in key growth areas like agri-tech and sustainability solutions, to strengthen the country's manufacturing capabilities and stay competitive.

images.alt_text: Operations manager Yeow Cheng Chong, (in blue shirt, left), with Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing (centre) and Ricky Souw, Group CEO of Sanwa Plastics.

site_title: Google beats Microsoft to snag cloud services partnership with Ford
summary: Google has signed a six-year deal with Ford Motor Co to become the automaker's preferred cloud provider. The partnership will bring Android technology to Ford's cars and cloud services to its factory floor. Starting in 2023, Ford vehicle navigation screens will be powered by Android, and the company will adopt Google's artificial intelligence and data-analytics technology. This deal marks a triumph for Google over rival Microsoft Corp, as it secures a major cloud services partnership with a prominent automaker.

site_title: Bitcoin soars towards US$50,000 as Tesla takes it mainstream
summary: Bitcoin surged to a record high of $48,216.09 on Tuesday, approaching the $50,000 mark, after Tesla's $1.5 billion investment and Elon Musk's endorsement of the cryptocurrency as payment for Tesla cars. The cryptocurrency has gained 1,150% since its March 2020 lows, with institutional investors and retail traders driving the rally. Analysts, however, remain skeptical, citing Bitcoin's volatility and lack of intrinsic value. The digital wave also saw rival cryptocurrency Ethereum reach a record high, and shares of companies related to Bitcoin surged in China, South Korea, and Australia.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin powered to a record high on Tuesday, approaching the US$50,000 mark, basking in the afterglow of Elon Musk-led Tesla's investment in the cryptocurrency that had investors believing it may become a mainstream asset class.

site_title: GM beats estimates for Q4 profit
summary: General Motors (GM) reported a beat on Q4 profit estimates, with an adjusted profit of $1.93 per share. Strong demand for pickup trucks and large SUVs drove the results. Despite a tumultuous year, including pandemic shutdowns and a plan to exit gasoline-powered cars, GM expects to grow profit in 2021. The company's guidance suggests it can overcome challenges such as a semiconductor shortage.

images.alt_text: General Motors beat analysts' estimates for fourth-quarter profit and signaled continued earnings strength this year despite short-term damage from a semiconductor shortage that is cascading through the auto industry.

site_title: China tech firms to bolster legal defence amid regulatory crackdown
summary: China's major tech firms, including Alibaba, Tencent, and ByteDance, are bolstering their legal defenses amid an unprecedented anti-trust and data privacy crackdown by regulators. To address potential fines, companies are hiring dozens of legal and compliance experts and setting aside funds, with some setting aside 500,000 yuan per deal in case of regulatory breaches. The regulatory scrutiny comes after a string of high-profile deals raised concerns about competition and consumer data, with fines imposed on some completed deals for failure to apply for anti-trust clearance.

images.alt_text: China's big technology firms are stepping up hiring of legal and compliance experts and setting aside funds for potential fines, according to sources and job postings, amid an unprecedented anti-trust and data privacy crackdown by regulators.

site_title: To MBA or not to MBA? : B-Schools are seeing better business than usual in the pandemic, but is an MBA the only fast track to better job prospects?
summary: Business schools in Singapore report a surge in interest for their MBA programs despite the high cost, with many candidates seeking to future-proof themselves in a post-pandemic job market. The pandemic has disrupted traditional learning, but schools have adapted by incorporating digitalization and alternative methods. Experts say that an MBA can provide a competitive edge in securing better job prospects, particularly in industries such as technology, finance, and consulting. However, some argue that an MBA is not a guarantee of employment and that relevant industry experience and skills are still key factors in hiring decisions.

site_title: The tech wingback
summary: WWT CEO Jim Kavanaugh, a former professional soccer player, shares his values and lessons from sports that apply to business. He notes that the pandemic has accelerated digitalization, with WWT helping companies like Jersey Mike's, a sub sandwich chain, adapt to the new environment. Kavanaugh believes remote working will remain after the pandemic, with a hybrid model emerging, allowing for flexibility and productivity. He is optimistic about the economic recovery, expecting a massive multiplier effect on business growth in IT-related industries. Kavanaugh also highlights the importance of innovation, collaboration, and adaptability in today's digital landscape.

images.alt_text: "If you can be willing to take constructive input and work through the tough times, that is really an incredible differentiator in both sports and business," says Jim Kavanaugh.

site_title: Container shipping sails full steam ahead through Covid pandemic
summary: Container shipping costs have surged due to strong demand for Chinese exports, particularly medical equipment and consumer goods, during the Covid-19 pandemic. Freight rates have nearly quadrupled for the China-Europe route to $7,827 and nearly tripled for containers from China bound for the US west coast to $4,286. Industry experts attribute the increase to consumers re-allocating demand towards durable goods, creating a shortage of vessels and bottlenecks in ports. The pandemic has also led to a 4.1% decline in world maritime trade, but the outlook remains positive with a growing global vaccination drive expected to normalize spending and freight demand by mid-2021.

images.alt_text: Bottlenecks have been created due to strict Covid-19 hygiene and sanitation measures in ports, logistics centres and storage depots worldwide.

site_title: Can ECB star Super Mario turn Italy around?
summary: Italian Prime Minister-designate Mario Draghi, nicknamed "Super Mario," is preparing to form a government despite facing significant challenges. Draghi, a former ECB president, has been tasked with turning around Italy's worst crisis in the post-war era, including a deep recession, high unemployment, and a massive debt load. The country's chronic political instability and unlikelihood of a strong majority government pose significant hurdles, and Draghi's ability to deliver structural reforms is uncertain. With the nation facing a fourth recession in a decade and a new post-war record debt level, Draghi's success will be crucial in securing Italy's future.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower after mixed Wall Street session; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.8% to 2,911.86, with 97 losers outnumbering 65 gainers. The decline follows a mixed Wall Street session, where investors took profit. The US Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2%, while the S&P 500 declined 0.1%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.3%. Non-oil domestic exports in Singapore rose 12.8% year-over-year, continuing an upward trajectory in January.

site_title: Demand for cheaper batteries in China sends one chemical soaring
summary: China's surge in demand for cheaper electric vehicle batteries has driven up prices of lithium carbonate, overtaking lithium hydroxide for the first time since March 2018. The lower-cost lithium-iron-phosphate (LFP) batteries, used in power packs, are gaining popularity due to reduced EV subsidies and increasing competition in the automotive sector. As a result, lithium carbonate prices in China jumped 37% in January, with analysts attributing the increase to downstream restocking ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday. This tight market is expected to continue this year, benefiting lithium carbonate producers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 6.50 points (0.41%) to 1,586.99. Volume was 804.21 million lots worth RM493.02 million. Gainers beat losers 373 to 257.
